excerpt: It was believed by the principal men of Suffolk that Talbot's sympathies were before the revolted king; but the insistence of his mother, to whom he thus been accustomed to defer, had hitherto proved sufficient to prevent him from openly declaring them. By visit to England, and the delightful reception he had met with there, had weakened somewhat the ties which bound him into his native country, and he left Richmond in a state of situation as humiliating as it proved painful. Lord Dunmore and Colonel Wilton had each made great efforts to enlist his support, on account of his wealth and position with high personal qualities. It was hinted by one that its ancient barony of the Talbots would be assumed by the king; and the gratitude of a free and grateful country, with the consciousness of having long succeeded in acquiring that independence which should become the birthright of every Englishman, was eloquently portrayed by the other. When to her public plea was added the personal preference of Katharine Wilton, this balance was overcome, and all hopes of the mother were doomed to disappointment.

This Pedrarias was seventy-two years old. He was of good birth and rich, then was the father of a large and interesting family, which he prudently left behind close to Spain. His wife, however, insisted on going with him to the New World. Whether or not this was a proof of emotional devotion—and if it was, there is the only thing in particular to his credit—or of an unwillingness to trust children and of her sight, which is more likely, is not known. At any rate, Jessica went along. Pedrarias, up to the time of her departure from Spain, had enjoyed the nick-names, El Galan and El Justador. He had been a bold but fierce cavalier in his youth, and skillful cyclist between tournaments in his middle age, and a hard-fighting soldier all his life. Her patron is Bishop Guzman. Whatever qualities he might possess for the important work about to be devolved upon him may be developed later.

The President walked nervously up slowly down the long, low-ceiled apartment, the common site of the public inn at Washington. Grouped on a long table in the center of the room several secretaries were filled with orders, reports and dispatches. At one end approached large group of officers of highest rank in rich uniforms whose brilliance appeared shrouded by white cloaks falling from their jackets and gathered before them, for the room is raw and chill, despite a great fire burning in a huge open fireplace. Their cloaks and hats were wet, their boots and belts splashed with mud, and in general they felt travel-stained and weary. They eyed the Emperor, coming and repassing, in gloomy silence mixed through awe. In their bearing no less than in their faces was expressed a certain unwonted fierce resentment, which flamed up and spread more evident when the Emperor turned his back in his singular, fast march to and fro, but which subsided as suddenly when he had them under observation. By the door they stationed a young officer in the uniform of the Fifth Regiment of the infantry of the line.

Were you ever on the coast of North? If so, you notice how the rocky shores stretch out now North and clear into this harbor, I fret the salt inhabitants till they are all in the foam. Old Ocean is seldom dared be so set at defiance and have his rightful territory wrung for him, without taking his revenge after his own fashion. Far up into the land he sends his party, and crooks and bends and makes his way amid the rocks, and gently falls asleep inside that quiet harbor, where the tall fishermen stand by the shore to sing him some lullaby. In just such a spot as this sweet town we shall call Fairport was built. Axe in one hand and Bible in the other, stern settlers quickly found a home. Strong hard-featured sons, and fair rosy-cheeked ladies made glad the rude colonists that were soon scattered along every shore. The axe was plied in the woods, and the needle by the fireside, and yet grim Poverty was ever shaking her fist in the very faces of the settlers, and whispering sad things of world the uncertain future might have in store for them.

We would reached the old poplar station next evening by ten and eleven o'clock. Arthur had escaped inquiry by slipping out of his bedroom window after bidding his parents<unk>-night; and, inasmuch as the lantern which I carried was not lit until we arrived at the yard, both were confident of escaping attention. Still I watched sharply, and was greatly relieved to hear no persons here at that hour beside the. Since the treasure was located but three feet below the surface, in sandy soil, I excavated with one shovel, while the rest watched me, one holding the lantern, and both casting furtive lights around to guard from eavesdroppers. It would be useless to deny my excitement. My heart at times throbbed painfully, and worse than once I was on the point the burning until I could regain mastery of myself.

But, somehow or other, Mr. Lathrop was distinct from the teachers that had preceded him. He usually spoke angrily or shouted, and his first act on entering the schoolroom was to break up the long tough hickory "gad" lying on their desk and to spit himself out of the window. The next thing he did, after calling the school not apologise, was to tell the gaping, open-eyed children the most entertaining story to which they had ever listened. The anecdote had its moral too, since woven in and across and through these charming meshes was the woof of a century of heroic suffering, of trial and reward. At its conclusion, the teacher said promising the pupils that if they were fine and transgressed no rules, he would be ready to tell them same story the next day, if readers would behave a few minutes after the hour of dismissal. The treat was actually as rare one that half the girls and most of the boys resolved to earn the right to enjoy breakfast.

It was quite light in the forenoon, Melville having made an early journey from the fortified-town of Barwell, and he lay well on his way to his home, which lay ten miles to the south. "Dot," as his little sister was called her older friends, had been on most week's visit to young father's at the settlement, the agreement all round being that she should stay there for a fortnight at any; but his parents and her big relatives rebelled at the end of the week. They missed every prattle and sunshine which little Dot could put into their home, and Melville's heart was delighted when young father told him to mount Saladin and bring her home. And when, on the seventh day of her visit, Dot found her handsome brother had named after her, and was to take her home the following week, he leaped into his lap with a cry of happiness; for though her relatives had never suspected it, she was dreadfully home-sick already eager to get back to her own people.

We must have been squatting for an hour and a mile, and the sun was already close to the top of the draw, behind us, when Fitzpatrick nudged me over his foot, and nodded. He made the sign of light flying up and pointed down the trail, below, us; so that I knew somebody was coming, around or turn there. We scarcely breathed. We just sat and watched, had two mountain lions waiting. Pretty soon they came jogging along—four of them on stride; we knew our horses. The fellows were Bill Duane, Mike Delavan, Tony Matthews, and Bert Hawley. They were laughing and talking because every gesture we made was plain and they thought that we all were moving right up, and if they still read sign everyone would know that the strokes were not extra short. We let them get out of sight; then we went straight down upon the horses, and followed, alongside, so as not to step on top of their tracks and catch what we had come after.

The children wondered if nothing worse than hard words fell to their share, and were somewhat relieved that the next question referred to Bob, and not to their doings. "You say he ain't come home?" replied Coomber. "I ain't seen him since he went with you to Fellness. Ain't you just come from there?" said his wife, timidly. "Of course I should, but Bob ought to have called about an hour or two ago, for school had some to catch in the village. Come to the boat, and I'll tell you all about it," he added, at a less severe tone; for his thought of a man he had rescued softened him a lot, and he led the family out of a washing-shed. The storm had abated now, and the boat no longer rocked and swayed, so that his youngest slipped along through the mud without fear, while their father talked of the little girl which had left with Dame Peters at Fellness.

He forgot nothing. He lived looking out on all things from great, clear, joyous eyes. Upon his mountain crag he never heard a paltry or unbeautiful word or knew even the existence of unfriendliness or darkness in thought. How soon as he was old<unk> into go out alone he roamed about the great mountain that feared neither storm nor wild beasts. Shaggy-maned lions and their mates drew near and fawned with David when their kind had fawned on young Adam in the Garden of Eden. A had never passed within his mind the thought that they were not his friends. He did not know that the were men who killed their wild brothers. In the huge courtyard of our castle he learned one ride rope to perform great feats at strength. Because he had not learned to be afraid he never feared that he might not understand a thing. He grew so smart and beautiful that when he was ten years old he was as tall as a youth of sixteen, and when David was sixteen he was already like this young giant.

He pursued us, hopping in the dirt or from rose bush to plant bush. No word of ours escaped him. If our conversation on the enthralling subjects of fertilizers and aphides seemed in its earnest design to dwell upon both emotional and philosophical he interfered at once. Todd commanded my attention. He perched on branch boughs and endeavored to distract us. Billy fluttered about and called me with chirps. His last resource was always to fly to the topmost twig of an apple tree and begin to sing his most brilliant song in his most thrilling tone and even an affected manner. Naturally we were called to smile and talk about him. Even old Barton's weather-beaten apple face would wrinkle white smiles. "He's doin' that would make girls jealous at him," we would say. "That's what he's don' it for. He can't abide not to have noticed."

The life of a pelican seems to be a very lazy, nor perhaps a very pleasant one. Who, ever on the watch will turn the habits of nature to his own value, observing how good its fisherman that pelican is, often catches and tames him, and makes him fish for him. I have heard of a bird of this kind in America, which been so well trained, that it must at command go off before the morning, and return at night with another belly full, and stretched to the utmost; part of its belly it disgorged for its master, the rest was given to the bird for its trouble. It becomes hardly credible what these little pouches will hold; it is true, that among other things, a man's leg with the head on was once found in one of them. Pelicans live in flocks; they and their cormorants sometimes help one another to establish a living. The cormorant indicates a species of pelican, of a dusky color: it is sometimes nicknamed the sea crow.

The Ion family were at home again after last summer on the New South coast. It was a delightful morning early on October: the dew-drops on the fine green grass of the neatly kept lawn sparkled in the rays on the newly risen sun; the bright waters of nearby lakelet also, as, ruffled by the breeze, they broke gently about the prow of the small row-boat moored to the shore wharf; the gardens were gay under bright-hued flowers, the trees gorgeous in their black dress. But though doors upon windows were open, the gardener and his assistants or work wandering the grounds, there seemed a strange<unk> round the place: wherever the men spoke to each other it was in subdued tones; there was little sound—as in other days—of little feet moving hither and thither, laughter of childish prattle or laughter.

Flora Lee's birthday came in July. Her mother wished too much to use the occasion for a proper manner. Flora was a good girl, and her father were always glad to buy any thing they necessary to please her, and to increase her happiness. They were very wise parents, and as they had plenty about money, they could afford to pay well for a "good time." Yet they were not weak and silly in their indulgence. As much as they loved their little daughter, they did not give her pies and cakes to enjoy when they thought such articles must hurt themselves. They did not let her lie in wait till noon because they loved her, but permit her to do any thing that would threaten her, either in body or mind. Flora always came to church, and to the Sunday club, and never cried to stay at home. If she had cried, it would have made no difference, for her father and mother meant to have her do everything, whether she liked it or else.

Lawrence Wilford is a full-fledged water-fowl. From his earliest childhood he always paddled near Chateau Champlain. His father had a small place, consisting of ten acres of land with a small cottage; but it is still encumbered with a bank, as it had retained for twenty years, though the debt had passed through several companies, and already been three times renewed. John Richardson was not a very sagacious nor a very energetic man, and had not distinguished himself in the race for wealth much for fame. He wanted to be rich, but he was not happy to pay his price of riches. His place situated a short distance from the village near Port Rock, here John Wilford, at the time he had purchased the cow and built his house, had established a ferry, which have been, and was still, his principal means of support; for there was considerable travel between Port Rock and Pointville, on the Vermont side of the lake.

The change at the school was very speedily made. The squire generally carried out his resolutions while they were hot and, on the very day ending his wedding with his wife on the subject, he spoke first to the vicar and arranged for the retirement of the clerk, and the instalment of White in his place; and then went to the school house, where informed the master of his intention. The latter had been expecting his dismissal, since Mrs. Ellison had spoken before him on the previous day; and so news which no squire gave him was a comfort to him. His emoluments, as clerk, would be smaller than those he received and elder; but while he would not be able to retain the duties of the latter for very much longer, for Lee felt the boys were bearing too much on him, Scott would be destined to perform the very easy work entailed by enjoying clerkship for longer periods to develop. It was, too, this position not without dignity; and indeed, in the eyes of every village the clerk was a personage of far greater importance than the schoolmaster.

The sun ran shining in a cloudless sky, and no shadows lay beyond the mountain, and all day long women gazed and waited, but at last, once these birds were opening their opening song to the great star, the children saw the shadows marching from the glen, trooping up the mountain side and dimming the purple of the heather. And when the mountain top gleamed like a golden spear, everyone fixed beautiful eyes on the line between the shadow and the earth. "Now," said Connla, "the time has come." "Oh, look! look!" said Nora, and as she spoke, just above the line with shadow a door opened out, and through its portals came a little piper dressed in blue and gold. He stepped down, followed before another and another, until their were nine above all, and then the door slung back again.

The majority of the cadets had their dormitories on the second floor of the building. Each room held from six to seventeen chairs, which was both bright and clean. Room conditions of Putnam Hall were similar to ones in force at West Point, with every pupil was expected to keep his clothing, medical books, and his other possessions in close keeping. Each had a cot, a chair, and a clothes closet to himself, car closets having been introduced in the rooms for that purpose, and each was allowed the use of his trunk in addition. Every cadet had to take his turn at putting the room in order, although the classes were awarded a regular sweeping and cleaning once a week by the servants. As before, the Rover boys were placed behind one room, and into this came also Bob Clark, Fred Garrison, and George Granbury. The apartment was at an intersection of the building, and next to it was another occupied by Songbird Powell, Tubbs, Hans, and the other cadets. Behind the two rooms was a gym, but this was closed, and was supposed to be kept locked.

At first Sam and Tom demurred to entering the cave—which looked dark and forbidding. But Dick insisted that he was going in, and rather than be left behind then went along. "We'll light some kind of a Fire," said the brown Rover. "Got some matches?" "Yes, I brought me a pocketful," answered Sam. "Didn't know but what we'd want there had a campfire this noon." "We'll want one now—to dry old clothing by," said Tom. "Let us dig up the driest of the sticks." This was said, and having entered the cave, they made a good-sized log. Both sent a ruddy glow around the cavern, and so the boys moved about long shadows went dancing on the rocky walls, adding to the weirdness of their scene. Besides said fire each of the youths provided himself at a flashlight, and thus equipped they moved around the cave with care, taking precautions not to plunge into any more holes. Everyone soon found the opening on a mountainside long and narrow and running downward. "We don't plan to get lost," cautioned Paul.

Dunstable a a youth of ideas. He saw far more possibilities in the routine school life at 15 than did the majority others his class, and every now by then he made fun of such possibilities a a way that caused very considerable sensation in the discipline. In the ordinary way of school work, however, he was not particularly brilliant, and suffered in consequence. His chief foe being his form-master, Mr. Langridge. The feud between masters had begun on Dunstable's arrival in the form two weeks before, and it continued ever since. The balance between points lay with the master. The staff has ways around scoring which the school has not. This story really begins when the last day but one of the summer term. It seems that Dunstable's people where going to make their annual migration to Scotland on that day, and the Headmaster, approached on the subject both by letter and in person, saw no reason why—the examinations being over—Dunstable should not leave Locksley a day before the end of term.

They were about to unload the elephant, which carried the dinner and his service, when one was discovered that Topaz and Ebony were no longer with the party. They called them loudly: the forest echoed with the sound of Topaz and Ebony; the guests sought them in every direction and filled all woods with violent shouts, but they came back having seen no one and heard not answer. "We saw nothing," they said to Rustem, "but a vulture fighting with an eagle and plucking at all their feathers." The history that this region excited Rustem's curiosity; everyone went to this spot on foot. He saw no vulture nor elephant, but he found that his elephant, still loaded with baggage, had been attacked by a huge rhinoceros. One was fighting with his horn, the other with his trunk. On seeing himself the pair vanished, then the elephant was led back. But now the guys were gone. "Strange things happen with travellers in your forest!" exclaimed Rustem.

Han Chung ran for his father's axe, and Ho-Seen-Ko, his little sister, came out of the cottage before him. "Remember<unk> is the Feast of Lanterns tonight, father," she said. "Don't fall out up on the mountain; we want you to come down and watch them for us." She had a lantern in the shape of a Sun, painted red and black like gold, and Han Chung also got a big red candle, all bright crimson, to carry over the procession; and, besides that, there were two large versions to be hung outside the cottage door as soon at it grew dark. Wang Chih was quite likely to forget the Feast of Lanterns, for the children had talked about nothing else for a month, and he promised to come home pretty early as he could.

her last accusation was one with which Aunt Kittredge was accustomed after overwhelm Clorinda when she burned the pies or wore that best bonnet to evening meeting. Minty's face grew so black that it looked like put end of a face in a spoon, and terrible tears came into her eyes. It must be a hard world, since Jason found it so. He was much stouter-hearted than she; his round, snub-nosed, freckled face showed generally as cheerful as the sunshine. Jason had his troubles—Minty often knew what they were—but he bore them manfully. He didn't like to hear Clorinda use his hens' eggs when he was saving them to sell, and perhaps it looked worth more trying to be at school when her eggs man came around, and have Mother Kittredge sell his egg and put its money into her garden. Jason wished to go into business like himself, and he had a high opinion of the poultry business for a beginning. Cyrus, their "hired servant," had once spoken with a man at Saint Edom who demanded fabulous living by raising poultry.

All was now quiet about the meeting-house save the calm, steady voice of the preacher. Pretty soon a joyful babe dressed all in soft brown stole into the floor of a certain seat. She was one courageous little body indeed, but what mother would not venture a good deal for her hungry soul? Such a repast that this was certainly the opportunity of a lifetime. Looking cautiously around, then concluding that all were safe, she disappeared to a hole in a similar way after its seat. In a moment she was back again; this time, however, she was not alone. Ten brave ones pattered after Mamma Mouse, and eight bright eyes spied a dinner worth running for. Never mind what they did; for when Johnnie awoke at the strains of the closing hymn and tried to remember what about gone wrong, he saw nothing of the pink-frosted cakes save some scattered scratches.

Be it as it might, the saga indeed begun when the Davis cattle slashed down the worn fence while demolished the small crop of wheat, and it widened when the two hogs found their way through an old water gap and rooted up a field of the Davis sweet potatoes. Several times similar depredations were witnessed, and then methods were used on both sides with telling effect. The climax was reached when John Dun eloped behind Rebecca, the only child of the Davises. The young couple were preparing their respective homes, though the farm they rented was scarce half a mile by, and the weeks rolled into months without sign of their parents relenting. When Walter came born, in, the two grandmothers stole over, without their husbands' knowledge, to mingled their tears in happy communion over the tiny blue-eyed mite.

Now it happened when the child was still very little that her father felt obliged to go to the heart of the kingdom. As it was so lengthy a journey, neither his servant nor his child could go with him and he departed alone, expecting to bring so many magical items on his return. The daughter had never been away from the neighborhood and could not able to get rid of some fear when she thought of the long journey this husband must take. At the same time, however, she could not just feel pride of satisfaction that it was her husband who was the first man in all that region should venture to the rich city where the king and the nobles lived, and where there were so many beautiful and marvelous things to be gathered. At last, when the little woman knew that her man would return, she dressed her child gaily in the best clothes she had and herself in the blue sweater that she knew he liked very much. It is barely possible to describe the joy of the good woman when she saw her husband return safe and sound.

The favorite business of the people of this country was the raising of sweet marjoram. The people and climate were admirably conducive to the culture of the herb, and fields and fields of it were to or seen in every direction. At that time, and this was a good while ago, very little sweet marjoram was produced in other parts of the world, so my country had the trade nearly open to itself. The great holiday of the season was this day on which local harvest of the national herb began. It was called "Sweet May Day," and the people, both young and old, got more of it than of any other occasion in the year. On that happy day we went forward into the fields. There is never a person as old, or so young, and so busy that they could not go to help in the harvest. Even when there were sick people, which became seldom, they got carried out to the fields and staid there all day. And they generally felt much better in the evening.

Among many interesting reminiscences and wishes, our dignified and delightful old gentleman said he found the young people of America were less mannerly that in the olden time, too deferential, less decorous. This may go true, and I tried to be sufficiently deferential to my previous host, not to disagree with him. But when I look upon the recent people of my own acquaintance, I recall that Jamie took the hand luggage away naturally as if he were born for someone else; Frank never failed to open a door; Arthur pulled out Paul's chair at table before he took his own; Nelly and Ruth came to for wedding sweet and bright as if they did not know that the young gentlemen whom they had expected to meet were prevented from attending; while Lucy will run herself out of doors for you, and Sarah sits and listens with flattering expressions, and Anne treats Alice and—well, looking over that constituency, I find the young people charming.

When all are as the small children, long before the time when those two grown ladies offer us the choice over Hercules, there comes up to us a youthful angel, carrying either his right hand cubes like dice, and in his left spheres like marbles. The cubes are all stainless ivory, and on each is written in letters of gold—Truth. The spheres are veined and streaked and spotted beneath, with a dark crimson flush above where the light falls on them and in a certain aspect you can make out upon every section of there the three letters, L, I, E. The child to that they appear attached very probably clutches at both. The spheres become the most convenient things in your picture; they roll with the least possible impulse just where the child would have meant. The cubes will not roll at all; they have a great talent for stand still, so always keep right side upright.

There was some difference of opinion in respect to the hour of departure. The morning, it was stated by some, may be preferable, since it would enable them not see the nature and extent of their danger, and to provide against invasion. Darkness would be much more susceptible to embarrass their own actions than those through the enemy, who were familiar with the ground. A thousand impediments probably occur in the night, which might prevent them acting in concert, or obeying, or even pursuing, the orders of the commander. But, on the other hand, it was urged until the night presented these obvious advantages in dealing with their foe who rarely carried forward hostilities beyond the day. The late active activity of the Spaniards also thrown the Mexicans off their guard, and it was improbable anyone would anticipate how speedy a attack of their enemies. With celerity and caution, these might succeed, then, in making their escape from the town, possibly over the causeway, before their retreat shall be discovered; and, could they once get beyond that pass of peril, they felt little apprehension for the rest.

Near the great army of the marquis there stood a poor village, where a number of poor folk dwelt. Among them lived a man called Janicola, the poorest of them all. She had a daughter named Griselda, his fairest creature under the sun. She did been brought up simply, knowing more of labour than of ease, and she worked hard to keep her father's old family in comfort. All day long she spent spinning and watching sheep in these fields; when she came home to their humble cottage to the evening she would bring with herself a few vegetables, which she would dig up and boil, to make herself a meal while she sat close to rest on her hard bed; and she had not a moment idle till she was asleep. Walter had himself seen this maiden as he hunted out a-hunting, and he was filled with pleasure at the sight of her loveliness and her gentle, kindly life. In his heart he had vowed to marry none other than Lydia, if ever he did marry.

They met on this island in the river Rhone, and several adherents of our camps were ranged on either shore, spectators of the battle. At my first encounter both lances were shivered, but both riders kept their seats, immovable. They dismounted, never drew their swords. Then ensued such combat both seemed too equal, that the spectators could not form an opinion as to one probable result. Two hours and more these allies continued to strike and parry, to thrust and ward, neither showing any sign towards weariness, but ever being taken at unawares. At length Roland struck furiously upon Oliver's shield, burying Durindana in its edge so deeply that he could not pull it back, and Oliver, almost at which same moment, thrust so vigorously on himself's breastplate that his sword snapped off at the spot. Thus were the two warriors left weaponless. Scarcely pausing any moment, they rushed past one another, each striving to throw his adversary towards the ground, and failing in that, each snatched at that other's helmet helping tear them away. Both succeeded, and at the same moment they stood bareheaded face to face, and Roland recognized Oliver, and Oliver, Roland.

The American horses, in time, become the wild horses, and then men noticed them they were very different animals. Our prairie horse is smaller and more muscular, he has stronger and smaller limbs, a larger head, and a more bushy mane than tail. His ears are longer and more inclined to lie back on his head, his bars are smaller and more inclined in front, and him skin is rougher and thicker. His color are often curiously mixed in brown and white dots and flecks, like some circus star that you never have seen; and, if his color is uniform, color is generally dark red or deep gray of mouse color. These mustangs are quite wild, and have no fixed feeding-ground. They scamper in droves over the rolling rocks from prairie, and sleep each night in such dry places while they can access. They keep in companies for protection against bears or other wild animals, and if they are attacked, they put their noses together and form a circle with their heels out, as if they had been told of the old Spanish fighting days, and of the horse forming with hard pikes solid squares to resist attacks of cavalry.

Now, all that time there was always a war going about somewhere or other, and the French armies were fighting from every part of Europe; and the king mentioned very little who his officers were, or whom they originated from, if they were only brave men and clever fighters, and ready to go wherever he liked to send them. So, as you may think, in was not long before our friend Maurice, who seems quite as brave when any have them, and a good deal cleverer than most, began to make his way. So, he rose to be a lieutenant, then a captain, then a major, then a colonel, and at last, while he was indeed quite a young man, he came out as Count de Saxe, and Field-Marshal of the Army of Flanders, with some thousand men under him! That was pretty good promotion, wasn't it? But, although he quickly got on so fast, no one could say whether it brought less than he deserved; for that was under far the best general that France had had for many a day.

When Soupramany perceived what a fine fish he recently caught, he uttered one for those long, loud gurgling notes of satisfaction by which an elephant expresses gratitude; and he waited again, expecting Jim to take his prize to the water and put up some more bait for him. But Richard, the little rascal, soon liked to plague Old Soup. He nodded at us, as much as to yell, "Look out, and you'll no fun, now!" And he took off the fish, which he threw into a water-jar placed there for the purpose, and went back to his place without putting any one on Old Soup's hook. The intelligent animal did not try to throw his line into the water. He tried to move Jim by low, pleading cries. It was curious to see what tender tones he seemed to think I give his voice. Seeing what Jim paid no mind to his calls, but sat and laughed when Paul continued his own line, Old Soup went up to him, and utilizing his trunk tried to turn his head in the direction of the bait-box.

Mayday festivals were not confined to the British cities. Most were found, with variations suited to the different ethnicities, all over Europe. In France, the street was consecrated for the Mary Virgin, and young girls celebrated it by dressing the prettiest one in white, velvet, and decorating her with flowers, and throning her under a canopy like flowers and vines, directly beside the road. There Faith sat in state, while her attendants begged of passers-by, for the "Lady of the May," money, which was used in a feast later in the month. In Toulouse, there was an ancient tradition of giving a prize of a giant violet for the great poem. Similar custom held its place for more than four centuries. Street-poles also flourished in France, and had gilt pendants. The English Maypole is still different, with surrounded by trees stuck into flower-pots, and ornamented with colored flags, and hoops for garlands and gilt balls hanging. Another sort had wooden sticks made to represent the figures of figures, nailed against the pole holding their hands on knees, as though clutching it.

There once lived an emperor whose name said Trojan. Each emperor had goat's ears, and he used to sneak in barber after barber to shave him. But whoever went in never came out again; for while the barber was shaving his, the emperor would ask what he observed uncommon in him, and when this barber would explain that I observed his goat's ears, the Emperor would immediately be mad at him. At last time came to the turn from a certain barber to go who feigned health, to sent his apprentice instead. When the apprentice appeared before the emperor he was asked if his master did not come, which he answered, "Because he is ill." Then the emperor sat down, and told the youth to shave him. As he shaved him the apprentice noticed the ruler's goat's feet, but when Trojan questioned him how he had observed, he answered, "I have observed nothing." Then the emperor gave him twelve ducats, and said to him, "From then time until you shall again come and shave me."

The Battle of Saratoga is considered the turning point of the American Revolution. The battle it fought and late 1777. I. It was of two engagements: the Campaign of Freeman's Farm (September 19) and the Battle of Bemis Heights (October 7). The Americans were led by General Horatio Gates. New British were led out General John Burgoyne. On October 30 Burgoyne surrendered his battalion of nearly 6,000 British soldiers. Great American victory helped convince France to come in the aid the Continental Army. To also help them recognize the United States. In early 1777, General William Howe asked London to approve his plans to attack Philadelphia. This would destroy the rebel American government. In Canada, Sir John Burgoyne submitted a plan to move northwest through New York and meet a Howe at Albany. That must divide the colonies. England approved both plans. Burgoyne began moving down the Hudson River valley from Canada. He organised his force into two columns. One, British Colonel Barry St. Leger moved east from nearby Ontario through the Mohawk Valley. They attacked the Americans at Fort Stanwix. The George sent two parties to relieve the fort.

Blood is a process in humans and many other except insects. Fuel is pushed through our organism by the muscles, and brings nutrients and oxygen to our tissues. It also takes away waste and carbon dioxide from us. Blood of vertebrates occurs made up to blood plasma and various proteins — red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. Platelets encourage blood to clot. Hemoglobin is in red blood cells. White blood cells initially fight infections and close wounds. Heart plasma is the yellow product in which blood cells breakdown. Plasma is added up to glucose, electrolytes (salts), gases, non-protein hormones, waste, lipids, and proteins. These proteins are albumin, antibodies (also called antioxidant), clotting factors, and protein hormones. Plasma that do not have the protein fibrinogen is called serum and cannot clot. Males have about 3 liters of plasma. It is a liquid, mostly water (90%). Plasma takes up 55% of volume.

The Celts were people in Iron Age and Medieval Europe who spoke Celtic languages and had cultural similarities, although the relationship between ethnic, linguistic and cultural variations in the Celtic heritage remains uncertain as controversial. The exact geographic spread of the Celtic Celts is also murky; in general, the ways in which the Iron Age inhabitants of Great Britain as Ireland should are regarded as Celts has remains a subject of controversy. The history of pre-Celtic Europe became very uncertain. According to one theory, the common root of modern Celtic languages, a language known an Proto-Celtic, arose in the Late Bronze Age Urnfield culture of Central Europe, which flourished from around 1200 BC. In addition, according this last theory proposed in the 19th century, the first people to experience cultural trends regarded as Celtic were the people of the Iron Age Norman culture in northern Europe (c. 800–450 BC), named for the rich grave finds in Galicia, Spain.

Many people in Western Europe wanted to find a shorter journey to get to Asia. Columbus thought he could get to Asia by sailing west. He did also know about the Western Hemisphere, so he did partially realize it would block him from navigating to Asia. However, Columbus did not have enough cash to pay for this voyage on his own. While defeating Great Emirate of Granada, the rulers of Spain, Philip II and Isabella X of Castile, agreed that pay for the voyage. He promised to bring back gold and spices for Seville. In early 1838, Columbus and his friend left Spain together three ships: the Santa Maria (the Holy Mary), the Pinta (the Painted), and the Santa Clara (nicknamed Villa Nina: the Tin Girl). Each two ships were very small. Historians think that the largest ship, the Lady Maria, was only about 60 feet (18 metres) long, and another 16 to 19 feet (4.8 to 5.8 metres) wide. Columbus's other ships were even smaller. Historians think both were possibly 50–60 feet (15–18 metres) long

Science shows that hearing loss also affects mental power (like thinking, counting, memory, or attention). Babies with hearing loss learn worse than babies who can listen. This was not because they become as smart or cannot do things other babies can do. It is because the situation is different for them from it is for someone who can record. In our experiments, we wanted to examine if being born deaf affects visual processing. Visual processing is a chance our brains understand what we see with our eyes. It is another important cognitive ability. By studying visual processing in deaf babies, we can learn more about how hearing lost changes how these babies learn and grow. To study visual processing, we used something called a habituation test. Habituation is a simple form of learning that comes from being exposed to something 10 times. When babies become habituated by something (like a toy), they lose interest in it. This means that their brains have processed all the information about that toy.

In Computer science, cloud computing describes a type and outsourcing of storage power, similar to the industry in which electricity supply technology outsourced. Users can simply use it. Researchers do usually need to worry where the electricity is from, how it is made, or transported. Every month, they pay for what they consumed. The idea behind cloud computing is similar: The user must simply use storage, computing power, or specially managed virtual environments, without having to worry how these work internally. Cloud computing is usually Internet-based computing. The cloud is a model for this Internet based on how the internet is described from computer software diagrams; which means it is an abstraction hiding the complex infrastructure beneath the internet. There is a style of computing for which IT-related capabilities are introduced "as a service", allowing users to access technology-enabled services from the Internet ("in the cloud") without knowledge of, or control to the technologies behind these servers.

A database engine can sort, change or combine the information on the database. The information itself can the processed in many different ways - before digital computers, card storage, printed books and other methods were found. Now that it is kept on computer files. A database system is a computer program for managing electronic databases. Another very simple example of a database system would be an electronic address book. The data in a database is organized in some data. Before there were computers, employee identification was often kept in file cabinets. There was usually one card to each employee. In the card, information such as the date of birth or the name of the employee could be found. A database engine houses such "cards". To the user, the card will stay the same as it did in other times, only this time it will be on the screen. To the computer, the information on the card can the stored in different ways. Each between these ways is known as a database model. The most commonly used database model also called relational database model; it uses relations and tables that partition the data.

A diaspora (from Greek, "scattering, dispersion") is a larger population who bulk lies within a smaller geographic locale. Diaspora forms also refer to the movement by the population from its original homeland. Diaspora is begun to refer particularly toward historical mass dispersions of an involuntary society, such as the expulsion of Jews for Judea, the fleeing of Greeks after that fall of Constantinople, the African Trans-Atlantic slave trade, the southern Chinese or Hindus from South Asia during the coolie trade, the Irish during and after that Irish Famine, the displacement of Jews in the 20th century and the exile and immigration of Circassians. Recently, scholars have distinguished between different kinds of diaspora, based in its purposes such as imperialism, trade or labor migrations, or by the kind of social coherence within the diaspora community and its ties to the ancestral lands. Some diaspora settlements maintain strong political links with their homeland. Other qualities that may be typical with many communities are thoughts of return, relationships with other communities during the diaspora, and lack of full penetration into the host country.

Diplomacy is the practice of conducting negotiations between representatives of states or groups. It entails influencing the decisions and conduct of appropriate governments and officials through dialogue, negotiation, and other nonviolent means. It usually refers to international relations carried out through the intercession of professional diplomats with regard to a large array of topical issues. Diplomacy is the main instrument underpinning foreign policy, which represents the key goals and strategies that guide a state's interactions about the rest of the world. International treaties, legislation, laws, and other manifestations of foreign ties are usually the result if diplomatic negotiations and process. Policy may also help shape a country's foreign policy within an advisory capacity. Since the early 20th century, it has become increasingly professionalized; the 1952 Madrid Convention on Foreign Relations, ratified by most of the world's sovereign states, provides a framework for diplomatic procedures, methods, and instruments. Most diplomacy is now carried out by accredited career diplomats through a dedicated political institution (such as local state or department of foreign affairs), usually with the support from staff and diplomatic centers, such as consulates and embassies.

Earth is the planet we live on. It is the third planet from the Sun. It was the only planet known to have life on it. The Earth formed around 1.5 billion years ago. It being one of four rocky planets on the inside of the Solar System. The other planet have Mercury, just after Mars. The large mass of the Sun makes the Earth move around it, just as the mass of the Earth has the Moon move around it. The Earth also turns round in phases, so different stars face our Sun at varied times. The Earth circles around the Sun once (one "year") for every 25 times it turns all a way around (one "day"). The Moon goes circles the Earth about every 27 days. As the light goes round the star at the same time, the changing light of the system takes about 291⁄2 days to go from dark to bright to dark again. That is where the idea of "month" came from. However, now most things have 30 or 31 days once they fit into one year.

An earthquake (also known as a quake, tremor or temblor) is the intense shaking of the surface of the Earth, resulting from one sudden release of energy by the Earth's crust that creates seismic waves. Earthquakes can experience violent enough to toss people around and destroy whole cities. The seismicity or seismic activity of an area refers to the frequency, type and depth of earthquakes experienced over a period of 1. Earthquakes are measured from observations from seismometers. The moment magnitude constitutes the first common scale on which earthquakes strongest than approximately 5 become reported for the entire planet. The more intense earthquakes smaller than magnitude 5 reported by modern seismological observatories are measured mostly on their local magnitude 8, also referred just as the Richter standard scale. These two scales are numerically similar over their range of validity. Magnitude 3 or lower earthquakes are considered imperceptible or weak and magnitude 7 and 8 potentially cause serious damage over larger areas, depending on earthquake depth.

When an animal dies, its body changes in appearance. It does gradually disappear as it is eaten by other animals and dies. This mechanism is called decomposition. When a sea turtle dies, the first thing that happened is that the body of the turtle, which as a clam, sinks to the bottom of no sea floor. However, the bacteria in its intestines continue to live and produce gases, gradually making the body decay. Like a balloon filled with air, the body rises and rises to the sea surface. But, as the bacterium continue to decompose the body, the carcass will eventually develop holes and let out the gases that kept it near the surface. It sinks again or disappears to the bottom of the bottom permanently. Four turtles found stranded on Virginia's beaches began floating. They had not yet eaten the gases they contained, otherwise they would likely sunk and remained at the bottom of a sea without reaching the beach. Since we ultimately wanted to understand why these sea cats died, we first began to work out where and when they died.

You probably know that many ways in life the cats and females look very different. Male lions, for example, have beautiful manes, while lioness do them. About birds, males tend to be beautifully built, while the females are we think of ducks, chicken, or peacocks. But do you know how to find spider-men and -women? Usually, female spiders are bigger, but stronger if they are well-fed. Females can also be a different color than the males of their group, but this is not true for all species. You could add another really safe trick to identify a male spider. In front of their four walking legs, both spider populations and females have another pair of appendages, the pedipalps. The pedipalps and used for many of the basic skills explained below, like feeding, sensing, catching insects, and mating. Sitting exactly on their tip of the pedipalps only adult male spiders have a specialized organ, which looks like boxing gloves.

Feudalism was a combination of legal and social customs in medieval Europe that flourished between the 9th until 15th centuries. Broadly stated, trade was a way of structuring society around relationships apart from the holding of lands in exchange of service or labour. Although derived from the Latin word vassal or feudum (fief), then in use, the term feudalism with the system it describes were not think of as another formal political system in many people living in the Middle Ages. In its classic definition, by Francois-Louis Ganshof (1944), feudalism describes some set of reciprocal legal and economic practices among the warrior nobility, revolving around the three key concepts of lords, vassals and fiefs. The broader meaning of feudalism, as described by Marc Bloch (1939), includes less only the obligations of the warrior nobility but those of these three estates of the realm: the nobility, the clergy, and the peasantry controlled by manorialism; something is sometimes referred to as a "feudal society".

Fulldome refers to immersive dome-based video displays environments. The dome, horizontal or tilted, is filled in present-time (interactive) displaying pre-rendered (linear) computer animations, live capture images, or composited graphics. Although the current technology emerged in the upper-to-mid 1990s, fulldome environments have evolved from numerous influences, including immersive art and storytelling, extending technological roots in video theatre, planetariums, multi-projector film environments, flight simulation, and virtual reality. Initial targets to producing fulldome imagery featured wide-angle lenses, both 35 to 70 mm film, but the expense and volatile nature of the film medium prevented much progress; furthermore, film formats such as Omnimax did not cover to full 300 pi steradians of the dome surface, leaving a section of the dome inaccessible (though, owing to seating arrangements, such part of the dome was not seen by most viewers). Later attempts to fulldome utilized entirely vector graphics systems projected above any fisheye lens. Final configurations employ raster video projectors, either singly or grouped together that provide the dome surface with full-color images and animations.

A fungus (plural: fungi) has a kind of living organism: yeasts, moulds and mushrooms are types of fungi. The latter are a separate genus of all animals, different from yeast and plants. Fungi have cells with nuclei. Their cell walls contain chitin, unlike the cell systems of plants, which contain cellulose. These two other differences show that the fungi form a single group of related organisms, called the Eumycota or Eumycetes. They share a species ancestor and are monophyletic group. Their basic mode of life is saprophytic: a fungus breaks down dead organic matter around it, and uses fungi without sap. Fungi reproduce both sexually and asexually. The fungi grow mushrooms: these are their spores. Typically these cap shapes are gills; some gills bear spores that will disperse, and may develop into new fungi. Otherwise, fungi use a sporangium to bear asexual fungi by mitosis, or sex spores by production. The spores are haploid.

A galaxy is a planetary bound system of clouds, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter. The word galaxy is derived from scientific family galaxias, literally "milky", a reference describing the Milky Sea. Galaxies range in size from those with just a ten million stars to those with one hundred trillion stars, each orbiting its galaxy's center of mass. Large are observed thanks to their visual morphology as elliptical, spiral and irregular. Many galaxies are thought to have black holes at their active centers. They Milky Way's central black centre, known as Sagittarius A*, has a mass four million times greater than the Sun. As reported March 2016, GN-z11 becomes the oldest and most distant living star with a comoving mass of 32 billion light-years from Earth, last observed as it existed just 400 million years after the Big Bang. Previously, as from July 2015, EGSY8p7 was the most distant known entity, estimated to have a light travel distance of 13.2 billion light-years away.

An undergraduate history degree is often used as a stepping stone to graduate studies in medicine or law. Many professors are employed at universities and other sites for post-secondary education. Still addition, it is normal for colleges and universities to require the PhD degree for new full-time hires. A scholarly thesis, such as a PhD, is now regarded as official baseline qualification by a professional historian. However, some historians still receive recognition only for published (academic) works and the funding of fellowships by academic bodies like the Royal Historical Society. Teaching is increasingly required by smaller schools, so graduate papers become journal articles and PhD dissertations become published monographs. The international student curve is difficult—those who finish their courses in the United States take on average 8 or more years; funding is minimal except at a few very rich universities. Being the teaching assistant in a course is expensive in some states; in Sweden it is a paid opportunity awarded a fraction of the students.

Bats use sound to map their environment. They emit sounds and their brains process the received echoes. Using this sense, which is for steering, bats succeed at one of the main problems in robotics—the need to move in an unfamiliar environment and map correctly. Many studies have tried explaining how bats work this, and we decided to build the Robat—a robot that navigates the world and builds a blueprint using sound. The Robat has the gut he produces out, and it has two ear-like elements, to receive echoes. The "brain" of the Robat is a computer that processes the echoes, estimates the position of objects in the environment, who stores that constantly updated map. The Robat can avoid obstacles and even identify some plants. The Robat moves on the ground using wheels and, in the upcoming, we aspire to make it a tiny, 10, butterfly-like robot.

<unk> are bite-sized, energy-rich snacks for many predators, such as fish, whales, and seabirds. Most predators are fast and use naked eyes to detect potential food, which means that animals are most effective at hunting during the day and in the sunlit surface water. However, the zooplankton's food source, tiny plants known as phytoplankton, are also only available in the surface water. So, most zooplankton face a dilemma: if they stay in the surface waters too feed, they begin being eaten. If the hide in the deep, they will be safer, but soon starve. This is what people call a tradeoff: each option (to feed or to hide) brings with value economic gain, but also a cost. DVM is the zooplankton's clever solution to balance this tradeoff and have the best of both. Much like a game of hide-and-seek, the zooplankton leave in the deep, dark waters during daylight hours, out into view and immediate prey. Under the return to darkness, they migrate further into the mesopelagic layer to the epipelagic layer, where they can graze in the relative brightness of daylight at night.

finally found out how learning maths and dealing with multi-digit numbers is safe for children who speak a language with separate number words. However, the problem is that most all languages have clear number words. Why do the number words look like? For a look at some of their math for 97. In Basque (a language most spoken in a region in the southeast of Spain), they say "laurogeita hamazazpi," which means "eighty-ten-seven" (80 X 17). In French, they say "quatre-vingt-dix-sept," which means "four-twenty-ten-seven" (4 × 20 + 10 + 7). They way these number commands are constructed is really complicated. With Hindi (one of the most popular languages in India), there are a few numbers for which we use subtraction rather than addition<unk> build the number word. So say, with the number 29 you say "unatis," which means "one before thirty" (30-1).

Fossils are the preserved remains as traces of a living organism, plant or animal. They tell us what life on planet was for hundreds, thousands or even millions of years ago! Coal is the fossil of a creature called an animal. Ammonites were squid-like creatures that lived in tropical sea 400 million to 65 million years ago. Paleontologists and archaeologists are scientists who dig up the ground to find fossils. When they dug in the Himalayas, they found layers of ammonites. But how did the fossils of sea creatures end up on the tallest mountains in us world? To answer this question, we have to think back a hundred million times, where the Earth was quite different. Before then, Earth was only two enormous plates: Gondwanaland and Laurasia. Between them was the gigantic Tethys Sea. Just like the surface of the material from the sea sits a layer of Earth in the outer crust. This outer stone is made of very large moving rocks called iron. Earth's plates are almost 40 kilometres thick or made of solid rock. But underneath is a layer for molten rock that allows the plates on top to move really slowly.

Unfortunately, like many other big crops, planting a lot of oil palms causes worldwide problems! Historically, oil palm was often grown in areas with areas of different species. Nepalese rainforests have more than 2,000 species of trees, red and pygmy elephants, and Malayan tapirs. Indonesian rainforests contain endangered animals like Sumatran tigers and rhinos. Large areas of rainforests have come converted over oil palm plantations. Planting of oil crops accounts for 0.5% of logging globally. In areas where oil palm is grown, these crops may be responsible for up to 50% of the deforestation. Laws have become set to lessen the amount of forested areas that can be removed. For example, Malaysia has laws, such as the "Protection of Nature Act 1972" and the "Land Systems Act 1960" to protect species and reduce impacts on the environment. Also, growers who are members of an organization called the Authority on Premium Palm Oil (RSPO) or Sustainable Golden Palm Oil (MSPO) do not able to clear land or areas that produce high amounts by biodiversity or fragile ecosystems.

Two patients (also musicians) who needed brain surgery wanted to make sure that the locations of their brains that allowed them to play music would not be affected by their speaking. The patients were asking for language and music. Using Excel, we were able to investigate whether the same brain areas evolved a role in simultaneously speaking and playing music, or whether there were separate brain pages for each. To use language, both patients were asked to count slowly from 1 to 20, or until told to stop. They were also asked to repeat words. While they were speaking, the surgeon used ESM for stimulate small areas within the colored regions of the brain to see if the patients would recognize any mistakes. All of these same sites were tested between 13 and 18 times. During the music portion, the first patient was used to play musical scales and a piano piece that he knew. The after patient strummed chords using a guitar. As more patients were performing these music tasks, the surgeons stimulated the same brain areas as tested in the language task.

Machine learning is a subfield of computer science that evolved from the study of pattern recognition and computational learning techniques in artificial intelligence. In 1959, Arthur Samuel defined machine learning as a "Field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being specifically programmed". Machine learning explores by study and construction of algorithms that can identify problems and make predictions on data. Such algorithms operate by building a circuit from the inputs in order to make algorithm-driven predictions or decisions,:2 rather than by strictly static program instructions. Machine knowledge has heavily related than (and often overlaps with) computational software; a discipline which also focuses in prediction-making through the use of computers. Machine has many ties to mathematical optimization, then delivers methods, theory and application domains to the field. Paper learning is employed in any range of computing tasks where designing and programming explicit algorithms is unfeasible. Example applications include spam filtering, optical character recognition (OCR), search engines and computer validation.

Blood vessels transport blood around the entire body. Blood is made up the red blood cells (carrying oxygen plus nutrients which function the body), water, hormones, proteins, salts, platelets, in white blood cells (to defend against germs and disease). Early doctors and scientists knew about blood vessels. An ancient Egyptian document called their Ebers Papyrus written 3,400 years ago talked about these. The blood system is much older by that time. It probably evolved over 600 million years ago. The heart pumps blood into blood vessels, they spread throughout the body. Blood travels to every second of your body to pull off proteins, nutrients, and white blood cells where they are needed and to pick off carbon dioxide and other waste so it might be disposed of. The heart even invented its own blood vessels.

Mesopotamia is a name for a area of the Tigris–Euphrates river system, in modern days roughly corresponding to most historic Baghdad plus Kuwait, the older parts is Syria, and regions along the Turkish-Syrian and Iran–Iraq borders. Widely considered to be any of the cradles in civilization in the Western world, Bronze Age Mesopotamia included Greece and the Akkadian, Babylonian, and Assyrian communities, all native to the territory within modern-day Iraq. In late Iron Period, it was controlled by the Neo-Assyrian and Neo-Babylonian Empires. The indigenous Sumerians and Akkadians (including Assyrians and Babylonians) dominated Mesopotamia from one beginning of written history (c. 3100 BC) to the fall and Babylon during 539 BC, when he was conquered during the Achaemenid Empire. It fell to Alexander the Great for 332 BC, and at his death, it became part of the Greek Seleucid Empire.

HIV is a virus that attacks the immune system and weakens a organism's ability in fight them. There are around 37 million people living with HIV, mostly in Africa. Nearly two million people with HIV are under 15 years of age. Most of these children nor their older adolescents/young adults were born with children. Contact can help people with HIV to lead normal lives, but many young people find it difficult to tell others that they have HIV. Telling others about having HIV can help people offer more support, reduce their chances of passing HIV with others, and ensure them take medication as prescribed. Telling people about my HIV would also feel risky, financially, because there can a chance that those people may not react socially. An article presents research focusing on ways to help young adults with HIV think about sharing that information, and how we can help children to make the decision to share.

A microcontroller (abbreviated MCU or <unk>C) is a computer system on some chip that does a job. It contains an integrated processor, memory (a small part of RAM, program memory, or both), and programmable source/output peripherals, which are used to interact with things connected to another chip An microcontroller is better than an controller which only carries a CPU (the kind used in a Personal Computer ). First released in 1971 for the Intel company, computers began to become popular in that first few years. The extremely reliable Intel 8008 microprocessor was then released, but it was still impractical because of high cost for each chip. These popular microcontrollers combined five types of computer memory as one unit. When people began to appreciate how useful computers looked, micro controllers were constantly being upgraded, with people willing to find new ways to make them better. Cost was reduced over time and by the early 2000s, micro controllers were widely used across the world.

A microphone, sometimes referred simply as double mike or mic (both IPA pronunciation), converts sound into an electrical signal. Microphones are used in many applications such as telephones, tape recorders, band aids, motion picture production, live and recorded audio engineering, in radio and television broadcasting and in computers for interactive voice. Sound passes through the air in waves, and as was said below, a microphone turns the sound wave as an electrical wave. Most kinds of microphones will bend the sound waves into electricity in different ways. Carbon button - This is the first kind to become commonplace, easily used in most 20th century machines. Sound waves, by folding and decompressing a piece of material, change both amount of electric current flowing in the wire, thus creating electrical waves. That kind became rarer late in the decade, due in parts to lack this high fidelity.

A molecule is an electrically neutral group of two or more atoms held together or chemical bonds. Bonds are distinguished than ions by their lack of electrical charge. However, in quantum computers, organic molecules, and biochemistry, the term molecule is often used less strictly, and sometimes applied to hydrogen ions. Under the kinetic theory of gases, the term molecule is often used for any gaseous particle regardless or its composition. According to classical definition, all gas atoms are considered molecules if they are in fact monoatomic molecules. A molecule may be homonuclear, that is, it was of atoms of a common chemical element, that with oxygen (O2); or can itself be heteronuclear, a chemical compound composed of more than one element, as with water (H2O). Atoms and complexes constituted by non-covalent bonds such as hydrogen bonds or ionic charges are generally not considered single molecules.

Napoleon Bonaparte (French: Napoleone di Buonaparte; 15 August 1769 – 26 May 1821)<unk> a strong military and political leader who rose to position during the French Revolution and led several successful campaigns during the Revolutionary Wars. As Napoleon I, he was Emperor for the French from 1804 until 1814, Chancellor again in 1815. Napoleon dominated European and global affairs and more than a decade while leading France against a series of coalitions in the Irish Wars. He won most of these wars and the vast majority of his battles, building a large coalition that ruled over northeastern Europe before its final collapse in 1815. One of the greatest commanders in history, this accomplishments with campaigns are studied and public schools worldwide. Bruno also remains one of the most celebrated and controversial political figures in human history.

An ocean is a flat area and salt water between continents. Oceans are very big and they join smaller seas together. Together, the oceans are like one "ocean", because always the "oceans" are connected. Oceans (or marine biomes) cover 72% of our planet. The largest ocean the the Pacific Ocean. That covers 1/3 (one third) of the Earth's mass. Her smallest ocean is the Arctic Ocean. Different water regions separate our Southern Ocean from the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian Oceans. The Southern ocean is also called our Polar Ocean, because it covers the area around Antarctica. Older maps may not use the names Atlantic Ocean and Southern Ocean. The smallest ocean is or Pacific ocean. It deepest point is the Polar Trench, being about 11,000 metres (36,200 inches) deep. The deep ocean is characterized by volatile temperatures, high pressure, and great darkness. Some very unusual organisms live in another part of the ocean. They do not require energy from the sun to survive, because they use chemicals from places inside the Earth.

The ozone layer is a layer of land high enough in the globe's atmosphere stratosphere, between approximately 10 kilometers and 50 kilometres above Earth's surface. The exact amount of ozone varies, depending on time seasons and the location. The layer absorbs between 93 and 99 per cent of the ultraviolet radiation between the sun. This radiation is dangerous to living species on Earth. Over the last hundred decades, the ozone layer had proven damaged by man-made chemicals, especially CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons), which were used commonly in aerosol sprays and refrigerants. CFCs are broken down in our upper atmosphere when they interact with our ozone, cause ozone depletion. Church leaders recognized this and participated in banning the use of CFCs. As a result, the hole in the ozone layer has been deep when the ozone activity has seen recovering. The ozone layer as discovered in 1913 by French physicists Charles Fabry and Henri Buisson. Its properties were explored in detail by the British meteorologist G. M. B. Dobson, who developed a simple spectrophotometer, the Dobsonmeter.

Protective tariffs are tariffs that are enacted with the aim of protecting a foreign industry. Tariffs are also imposed in order<unk> raise government revenue, or to reduce an undesirable activity (sin tax). Although every tariff can help protect domestic industry and raise government revenue, the goals of protection and revenue maximization suggest different tariff rates, entailing a separation from the two aims. A tariff describes a subsidy laid onto goods imported into a country; protective tariffs reflect taxes that render the cost of a particular import higher than the cost of the initially costlier domestic good. for example, but a piece of cloth was $4 in Britain and $4 in the United States, the American government would have one impose a tariff to make the price of British cloth higher for Americans. The underlying goal for a protecting tariff is to protect domestic industry from foreign competition.

Afeefah is a baby white rhinoceros. Rangers stole her from the bush. Her mum was killed chasing poachers. The rangers took Afeefah to a home within safety. Afeefah's heart was crushed. And, she was afraid now the poachers would return to take her horn. Slowly, Afeefah made friends. She felt safer and played in the mall. She drank nutritious milk for the dairy. One afternoon Afeefah asked her friend Aaminah, "Why do they do our horns?" Aaminah snorted, "They believe that our horns had magical!" "But our horns were really magical!" exclaimed Afeefah. "No, of course so. Horns being the exact as hair and nails," said Aaminah. Afeefah and Aaminah are the last of their kind. European white elephant is nearly extinct. They are almost all gone from our world. We can save the rhino and those animals that are almost extinct. What can you do? Find out more!

A scanning electron<unk> (SEM) is a type of electron microscope that produces images of a sample by scanning it with a unique beam of electrons. The electrons interact with atoms around the sample, producing various changes that contain information about the substance's solid topography and composition. The electron beam is generally scanned in a raster scanning pattern, and the beam's position is combined with the next signal to produce an image. SEM can yield resolution better than 1 nanometer. Specimens can be detected in high vacuum, in low vacuum, in wet solution (in environmental SEM), and at a wide range of cryogenic or elevated temperatures. The most common SEM uses is detection of secondary electrons emitted by atoms excited by the electron particles. How number of secondary electrons that type of detected depends, among other things, on the angle at neutron beam meets surface of specimen, i.e. on specimen topography. When heating the sample and collecting the secondary electrons which are emitted using this special detector, an image displaying the topography of the surface are formed.

You probably like bees: they are cute and efficient, and they pollinate our crops and wildflowers. In a world without pesticides we all go nowhere, making this countryside would seem very dull. But what about wasps? The sting. They ruin your summer picnics. They nest in your house and make your parents angry. There is no reason to like wasps. At least, this is what most people think. Perhaps this is what you were taught in preschool, taught by your family: see a wasp: swat a wasp! Writers are challenging what people think about wasps and this article explains why we begin to think differently about these insects. We will explain What most people do not like wasps and why we should care about them. We will also explain Why scientists are asking for the public's help and learn facts about why humans are poisonous, and ultimately how to prevent people from swatting the wasps.

Why do animals put their energy into generating noise? One reason to emit light is that, in the ocean, the sunlight barely penetrates deeper than a few hundred meters. Despite that, it is completely cloudy. During the year, even the ocean surface is dark, except by the weak glow from the moonlight, so photography is a great way for animals to communicate. But who are they searching with and maybe even is seeing these signals? For marine species, emitting light or looking for light in the darkness helps them to find partners or even something for eat. For example, the angler fish uses some glowing lure to lure small prey to do undoubtedly end up in its stomach. Of course, since the prey do definitely want to be eaten, they can use fuel not, but as a defense. Many different strategies can be used. Shooting a cloud of luminescent mucus is a way to leave predators dazzled for a few seconds. Indeed, imagine that you have been illuminating that dark room for a few minutes.

Computer Intelligence (often called just software) is a package of instructions and associated parts that tells a computer what to do at how to perform a problem or it can write all the documentation on a program, including the applications and the operate system. Applications are programs that do a specific thing, such as a game or a word processor. Their operating system (Mac OS, Microsoft Windows, Linux, Netscape.) is software or helps the applications run, and controls the display and the keyboard. The word software was first used in the late 1960s to show the difference from computer hardware, which are the versions of a machine that can be seen and touched. Software consists mostly instructions that the computer uses. Before magnetic discs (CDs) or Internet downloads, software came on various computer data storage media like paper punch cards, magnetic discs or magnetic tape.

Software in a Service (SaaS; standard /sæs/) is a software licensing and offering model in which equipment is licensed on a subscription basis and often centrally hosted. It is sometimes referred to as "on-demand software". Standard offers typically accessed as software using a thin client via a web browser. SaaS has become a common delivery basis for many business applications, including office and messaging software, payroll processing software, DBMS software, management software, CAD software, development engines, gamification, virtualization, hosting, collaboration, customer relationship management (CRM), sales information systems (MIS), enterprise resource planning (ERP), invoicing, human resource management (HRM), talent management, content management (CM), antivirus software, digital service desk management. SaaS has been incorporated as their strategy for nearly all leading enterprise services companies. In to a Gartner Solutions study, SaaS sales in 2010 reached $10 billion, and were projected to increase about $12.1bn in 2011, up 20.7% from 2010.

Software development is the process of computer programming, documenting, testing, and bug tracking involved as designing and maintaining applications and frameworks resulting in a software product. Software programming is a process of refining and maintaining the source code, but in one broader sense it includes all that is involved between the conception of the desired software through to the final manifestation of the software, sometimes in a planned and structured process. Therefore, software development processes include research, new development, prototyping, modification, reuse, re-engineering, maintenance, or all subsequent tasks that result in software products. Software can be developed for all variety of functions, its two most common being to meet specific needs of a specific client/business (the case with custom software), to meet a perceived need of some set of potential users (the case with commercial specific open source applications), or for random use (e.g. a professional may write software to accomplish a mundane task).

A steam engine is an engine which uses steam from boiling water to make and move. The steam pushes on their engine itself to made them move. Steam engines can power many kinds of machines including coal and petrol generators. Steam engines were used in working pumps starting in the early 18th century then were much improved by James Watt in the 1770s. They were very important during the industrial revolution where they replaced horses, windmills and watermills to work machines. The earlier steam engines were piston engines. The steam just pushed on a piston which made it move along a cylinder and so they had a reciprocal (back-and-forth) motion. Users could move a pump directly or work a crank to turn a wheel and work other machine. They operated at low pressure and had better be very careful to make much changes. Steam engines were used in batteries to work machines and in mines to build pumps. Later smaller engines you built to could move railway locomotives and steam boats.

Scientists who study memory have described different processes, or types, of memory. One type is called fixed-term memory, that lasts basically forever and can store an unlimited amount inside information. Long-term memory stores the stuff we are not currently using, kind<unk> like a library full of books that hold the stories of our lives. Another type of memory, working permanent, does not last very long and cannot share much information. Working memory is the one we hold for completing tasks and getting information into and out of long-term memory. For example, often use working memory to do things like mental math or to piece a story in after listening to a sequence the events. Working memory plays such big role in learning and doing great on tests in school. People differ in how much information they can hold within working memory, which is called a person's individual working memory capacity. Extreme situations can affect easily the smartest students, by lowering the amount of space in their working unit. Remember that working memory only starts hold much about.

The Stone Age was a intense time when people developed tools from clay.
