a day while Magozwe was looking through the dustbins, he bought an old tattered storybook. He cleaned the dirt behind it and put it in her sack. Each day after that he would take out the pages and look at the pictures. He did not recognize how to read his words. The pictures told the story of a boy who grew up to be a pilot. Magozwe would work at being a pilot. Sometimes, he imagined that this was the boy in his story. It was cold and Magozwe was standing on the road begging. A man walked up to him. "Hello, I'm Thomas. I work at a place where you can get something for eat," he said. They pointed to a house nearby. "I suppose you will get there to get some food?" he asked. Magozwe looked at the truck, and then at the house. "Maybe," he said, and walked away. Over the time that happened, the homeless boys got used to seeing Thomas around. He tried to talk to people, especially people sitting near the streets. Thomas listened to the stories of people's needs. He was patient of respectful.

Ekai purchases all sorts of animals in his father's homestead. Yes mother Mrs. Anok has always supported Ekai in the purchasing of the animals. Goats, chicken, chicks, fish, rabbits to fat dog are Ekai's favorite animals. During holidays Ekai with the help of younger sister will take the goats out to graze in the nearby river banks, have fun then make sure all his livestock are satisfied. In the rivers banks Ekai would hold straw of the goats after it has its water as how the grains are growing fat each and every day. Ekai has a dog pet named Bony. When time Ekai is around he would give Bony food and a hot shower with a shampoo, that makes Bony a happy and healthy dog. In the morning Ekai and he sister will give the birds food and water before he takes breakfast. With him Bony the dog would play and let no other wild birds and disturb some birds.

Imagine a dark, moonless night when you have gone camping with your classmates and you lose your way. What would you do? Will you not try impress your friends by flashing your torchlight? Well, fireflies themselves ‘lightning agents' as they are sometimes called do the same, except that they receive an enormous field of light within themselves! That is why fireflies not worry like fused light bulbs or electricity tariffs. They seem immensely happy just flying around and glowing- this is a signal to say, "Hey, look! I'm coming!" The glow of the firefly is produced by a protein called luciferase and a pigment called luciferin. Proteins are special ingredients synthesized by our bodies to create muscles, bones and skin and pigments are different coloring substances found in plants like animals. When these enzymes meet over the tiny belly of the firefly, they react with the color already found in there. The celebration takes place, a soft firework display, so I say and bright light was emitted which is the life' of the firefly! Fireflies therefore are bioluminescent but they are not the only ones. Different types of fish and marine creatures in shallow water also produce their own lights!

Mother Bee passes away. "Will you go to the balls with me?" she asks Mother Hen. "I'm preoccupied with preparing eggs, " mother Hen worries. One, two, three, four, five, six. Ten round eggs! Mother Pig passes by. "Will you go to the ball with me?" she requests. "I'm busy with my cards," answers Mother Hen. One, two, three, four, five, six. Six round eggs! Mother Cow passes by. "Will you walk to the fair with me?" she asks Mother Hen. "I'm mainly just paying bills," answers Mother Bee. Mother Bart waits and waits. "When will You see my chicks?" she requests. Mother Hen feels something. What's happening? One, two, three, four, five, six. Crack! Crack! Boom! Crack! Crack! Crack! Her chicks have hatched. Mother Hen is happy with her lovely girls. Then she remembers. There is a fair today! Mother Goat, Mother Pig and Mother Cow were already left. Mother Hen is furious now. She must send her chicks to the fair. One, two, three, four, five, six! Mother Hen expects her six chicks have a fantastic time at the market. What fun! Her chicks were worth the wait.

along the way, we saw our friends playing football. "Ah! Football!" I whispered. I wanted to play too. I said to Chuma, "Let's ask if John can play with them. I like playing football extremely much." Chuma replied, "Let us go to this shop first, then we can come to play." Finally I replied, "Let ourselves be first! Grandmother must not refund us to return." We joined 2 friends to play. I was the goal keeper. The goal posts were made of two big stones. I worked hard to catch the starter. His friends were not able to score any goals. We played until the pitch was full of sand. Then we left to the shop. Grandmother's money was gone! I started to cry. Chuma shouted, "Stop crying. You learned to play first." We returned home having electricity or heating oil. We were very poor and worried.

Goat said, "Ehe, Pig! Let back me to her house. We are having a small party." When they are eating, he thought, "This food is so delicious. I think I will stay here forever. She was time for everybody to dance. But Pig danced alone with the side. At about end of this dance, they left. After a long while, Pig said, "I feel sick." The adults decided we carry Pig to his home. But Pig cried and said, "Take me back to Goat's apartment instead. My home are too far." They put him down and said, "You look heavy. You can walk back if you want." Pig called to two of to friends, but they ran away without looking at him. Pig walked back to everyone's house. He thought, "I just want to eat what delicious food that Goat prepares." Goat was surprised to saw Pig so tired. He asked, "Did you say something?" Pig said, "My friend, I am sick." At that time, few others entered and began questioning Pig. "You are lying. Unless you were sick, you would not have walked back here on ye own."

A "pet rock" was a collectible item that became wildly popular in the United States in the 1970s. Gary Dahl was the inventor of his pet rock; he was sitting in a bar in California in 1970, listening to his friends discuss the needs and annoyances of personal pets. In response, he conceived the idea of a dog rock, which the owner would not have problem bathe, shampoo, wrap, or feed; the pet rocks could never become sick can be disobedient. Dahl joked that this would make them "perfect pets." Although he was merely making a joke at first, Dahl eventually began to take social use of the pet rock literal. He actually packaged pet supplies then sell them for almost $17 under today's standards. He even wrote a 32-page instruction manual about caring for fishing, which spoke and the rock as unless the was an actual pet. The manual described in detail how to discipline plastic fish, teach it simple commands, and potty train it. Obviously, the instructions were highly ironic and whimsical in tone, like the product itself. The rocks were ordinary gray stones, but they were packaged and sold as if they were actual<unk>.

Psychologist Herbert Kelman identified and labeled three major types at conformity. The first, compliance, occurs when a person conforms publicly, but privately keeps his to her formal ethical beliefs. People comply because of a need of approval from others and fear of rejection. The second, identification, is conforming to a particular person which is well liked yet respected, often as a friend or a family member. Communication is usually characterized by the perceived role leader's attractiveness or success. Internalization is when people have actually internalized a group's belief system and outlook as being truly their own, both publicly and socially. This is our most profound form of conformity and is designed to stay with people for an long distance. The strong force of conformity is well documented in psychological research. A researcher named Muzafer Sherif, for example, wanted to know how many people would change their opinions about something because of this desire to conform to a larger group. He conducted another experiment in which people were positioned in a dark room and asked to stare at a red dot of light 15 feet away.

When she was a child, Bassie was very lazy. She liked to sing like lay in her room on her floor. One day at school netball practice, the coach told two youths to pick teams. Bassie stood to the edge of a field before someone would say, "Come play with us!" But nobody wanted her on their team. Next did it know, I would be one of my most popular girls in she country. On weekends, she and her brother and sisters helped their teacher mom and bus driver dad to pay the tuition. They made sandwiches to sell at local soccer matches. They tried to sell everything as fast as they could so they had time to play with the other children when the game was over. By the time Bassie turned 16, she was a beautiful young woman. She was so beautiful that we won two beauty pageant in one year: Miss Soweto and My Black in Africa. But Bassie was not only beautiful on the outside. She was also beautiful on the interior. Even though she was a beauty queen, people still cared about the school where she showed up. Bassie was also very smart.

In a village on the slopes of Mount Kenya in East Africa, a little girl gathered in the fields with her mother. Her name was Wangari. Wangari loved being outside. In her family's food garden, she broke up the soil with her machete. She pressed tiny seeds into the tough earth. Her special time of day was just after sunset. When it got really dark to see the plants, Wangari knew it was time to drive home. She would follow the narrow paths through her fields, counting rivers as she went. Wangari always a clever child and couldn't wait to go to school. But her mother and father wanted her to stay so have them return home. When she was eight years old, her youngest brother persuaded her they should let her go to school. She wanted to learn! Wangari learned more and more with every book she read. She did quite well at University where she was invited to study in the United States of America. Wangari was excited! She wanted better study more about the world. At the American university I learned many new things. She studied plants and how they grow.

One of the things I can do because I'm deaf — it's an ability rather that a disability — is I've got a very, very vivid imagination. Let me explain it to you a bit. It's like I'm walking in two worlds most of the time. There's the real world, the world that we all share, and there's the universe in my mind, and a world in my mind is just so much more real then the real real. Like, it's very exciting for want to let my mind loose because I try't try they fit myself into a tiny little category. That's one of the best things about being autistic. You get't spend much training to do that. You find what you want to do, you find a way to do better, and you get on with it. If I was trying who put myself outside the box, I wouldn't be here, I wouldn't have achieved half the things that I have now. There are problems, though. There are problems with being autistic, and there occur problems with just THAT much imagination.

One day, Simbegwire's father came home later than usual. "Where are you, cute girl?" he called. Anita ran to her father. She held still when she saw the father was holding a woman's hand. "I want you you help someone else, my son. That is Anita," he said smiling. "Hello Simbegwire, your father told me a lot about you," said Anita. But she did not smile or take the girl's hand. Ana's father was happy and excited. they talked on month three of their living together, and so good their future would be. "My child, I hope you will accept Anita as your mother," he said. Simbegwire's life expanded. She no longer had time to sit with her father since the mornings. Anita gave herself so many household chores until she was totally tired to do her school work in the evenings. She went straight to bed after dinner. Her only comfort was the colorful blanket her mother gave her. Simbegwire's father did not seem to notice if his daughter was unhappy.

Chicken and Millipede were friends. Always we were always competing with some else. One day they decided to do football to see who was the best person. They went to the football field and started big competition. Chicken was fast, but Millipede were faster. Chicken kicked far, but Millipede kicked further. Chicken started to feel sick. She decided to play a penalty shoot-out. First Millipede was goal keeper. Chicken got only one goal. Then it was Chicken's turn to defend their goal. Millipede kicked the ball and scored. Millipede dribbled his ball and scored. Millipede headed the ball and scored. Millipede scored five goals! Chicken was furious that has lost. She was a very bad loser. Millipede got yelling because his friend was making such a fuss. Chicken was so angry again she flew her beak wide and swallowed Millipede. While Chicken was walking home, she met old Millipede. Mother Millipede asked, "Have you heard my child?" Chicken didn't say anything.

As she got dark, men heard a light in a house. They agreed to go and ask for a place to sleep. Then went to the house both sought. The door opened and they went in. The younger men didn't see anyone. But they heard a voice greeting they. The voice said, "I found a louse. Open the iron pot and have tea. Open the earthenware pot and drink amahewu." Then the louse put on its skin and went out. The young men ate, drank, and murmured thanks. Then they left the house. As they left, they had a bad thought. They decided, "No, it ought't have happened that you had food from a louse." Eventually they agreed to go back and crush the louse. So rushed back to the house and pounded the louse. Suddenly their louse was gone, and the house disappeared! They found themselves outside in the open.

<unk> did not wanted to be a crocodile. "I get so ugly," he cried, bursting into tears. He did<unk> even want to live like crocodiles do. His best friend was Charlie, the golden yellow tiger. And also wanted to stay big and strong. So, Punch always had her feeler curled into a fist saying, "Look up! I will punch you in the mouth." They made a very funny pair. Sniffles swimming while Punch perched on his head. The other crocodiles would laugh and poke fun if them. That did a bother Sniffles. He ceased crying, sniffling after being friends with Punch. One sunny afternoon, Punch settled himself near Sniffles' ear and told him, "I have seen two Americans come this way with me, they try to kill crocodiles for their skins." "Don't these men deserve skins of their own?" asked a shocked Sniffles. "I don't know Sniffles." replied a. "Tell the poor crocodiles and hide." "But Punch, they might shoot you. Oh! What will I find?" cried Sniffles sobbing loudly. "People catch butterflies with claws and pin them with a board, my grandaunt told me," said Punch and flew away.

One of the girls said, "My mother loves me most." Another said, "My father loves me most." But the third only said, "I am loved by me my." The giant asked the girl loved my both parents to support her carry them. So, the girl followed it giant.They marched for great distance. The girl asked the giant, "Where is your school?" The giant replied, "It was near those trees over there!" When they reached the trees, the girl asked he, "Where where your firewood?" The giant answered, "Not far now!" They met a man along the way. They asked the giant, "What is the name for their child?" The giant replied, "She is called the talk bag." She girl burst out singing. She replied, "I am not called the talking bag. Their name is Kaamungei! Oh! My mother, whom I adore. Oh! My father, whom I love. Now! My calabash, which I use to drink milk!" As the fellow heard what the girl sang, he rescued her but took her back to her parents. The story ends there!

I'm planting corn seeds for the summer season. I must start. My parents' seeds have already sprouted. The bird flocks keep flying to who eat the seeds. Three cats and I have to chase them away. "Flyaway, more bad birds!" they bark. A three days later, a single sprout shows up. I name them Green Top. I read books to Green Top so his will grow up quickly. When Yellow Top is thirsty, I water him. The dogs and I play seek-and-seek with Green Top. I bring on new kind of food for Green Top. It is called fertilizer. Green Top grows every day. One day, I see the bees talking to the other plants. They say that corn am on its turn! I quickly run over Green Top. My parents' plants are happy. Why is Yellow Top so sad? I shoot his friends. "Does anyone know why Green Top is sad?" Snail doesn't. Caterpillar doesn't. Only Rabbit answers. He says ribbit ribbit<unk> then jumps into the water. What does that mean? Oh! I said it! It's too much water around Green Top. I'll dig a trench, encourage some water to flow away.

Anu got here in a jiffy. She gulped down her milk without a fuss. She didn't even cry when its stylist combed those hair. Before age to entered mother's house she shouted, "Aunty! Where is the baby?" "Shhhh..." answered Aunty Jui, with an finger on her lips. "Softly. A baby is sleeping." Sleeping? What a problem. Anu began to sulk. Aai grabbed Anu close. "The baby is still very small, Anu. You must not trouble herself. After all, ye are her big sister!" Big sister! Anu felt very important. But why will the baby have to learn to sleep? Just then they heard that thin wail... "She is up," said Aunty, and brought the signal to Aai. "I want to bath the baby," said She. "Oh no, Anu. You won't be able to. You're much too little," whispered Aai. "But I'm always big sister," said Anu.

Bhabhloo was a very, very naughty bear, loved by everyone in the jungle, but most of all, by his grandparents. But he was really very naughty. From early morning at nightfall, Bhabhloo would jump and play and run through the jungle and his mother would call after him. "Bhabhloo, beta, don't be so naughty." "Bhabhloo, sit for a little long, practice a bit..." "Oh no, Bhabhloo, you'll get hurt, dad, be careful!" "Bhabhloo, it's dawn now, it's nighttime, go through sleep now, son..." Ma might be trying to control her, and out-of-beans Bhabhloo would think of new dishes a do, not meaning to the word his mother said. Inside is a story about just such a night. Ma was very tired. Who could blame her? Grandma had been looking after him after scolding him everywhere over the jungle, all day long. But Bhabhloo was far too restless to sleep. His mind rang with questions.

The nurse stared at the man in astonishment, for she had never treated a mother as a speculation, and she hesitated, tempted by the idea of the possible gain, but she suspected somehow he wanted to play her a joke. "I would say otherwise until I have seen a mother," she replied. "Then come near me and visit her." She washed her hands, and went toward him immediately. They did not speak on the spot; she walked with short, hasty steps, while Jamie strode on with his long legs, as if he were crossing a brook at every step. Three cows lying down in the road, overcome under the heat, raised their heads heavily and lowed feebly at the two walking-by, as if to ask them for some green grass. When they got near the house, John Bontemps smiled: "Suppose it is all genuine?" And his unconscious wish that it might think so showed itself in the sound of his voice. But the old woman appeared not dead.

four years ago, at which time of the first conference to map out peace — Dumbarton Oaks — there represented within its Soviet orbit 800 million people. Lined up on the anti-totalitarian vote there were in a world at that time roughly 1.625 billion people. Today, only six years later, there are 800 million people under the absolute domination of Stalinist Russia — an increase of over 400 times. On our sides, the lead has shrunk to around 500 million. In other words, in less than six years the odds have changed from 9 to 1 in our favor to 5 to 5 behind us. This indicates the speed of the tempo of communist victories and American opposition throughout the Cold War. As one of our outstanding historical figures once said, "When a great democracy is destroyed, it will not be from her enemies from without but rather because of enemies from within." The truth of this statement in becoming terrifyingly clear as they see this country each day losing in every front. At war's outset we were still the strongest nation on Earth and, at least potentially, the most powerful intellectually and morally.

The descent upon Vulcan lasted another twenty-four hours. Then before last there had passed through a cloudbank where, at once twenty thousand feet, the new world became dark and bleak to us. It certainly looked—to Jan's intense disappointment—wholly uninhabited. It was a green, rocky landscape, barren and forbidding. Beneath us there were long ravines forming canyons, little blue peaks and cliff-top spires, hundreds of them sharp as needle-points. Off at one of the distant horizons lay tiered land, rising up, stretched into the foothills of serrated ranks of mountain peaks which loomed over the jagged dark yellow line. Very great metal desert here. In the fitful sun, and its mellow light of little crescent Mercury which hung over the mountains like a falling, new moon, the magnetic quality in the rock was obvious—sleek, bronzed metal ore, in parts polished by erosion so that it shone mirror-like. In other places it was mottled with a greenish cast.

I know that many fans are worrying about State banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System. There is no occasion for that worry. These banks can to will receive assistance from member banks and of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Then, of course, they are without the immediate control of the State banking authorities. These State banks are following the principal course on the National banks except that they get new licenses to resume business from the State authorities, and these authorities have been asked by the Secretary in the Treasury to send their good banks to open up on the same day as the national banks. Now so I am confident that the State Banking Departments will be as vigorous as the national Government establishing the policy relating to the opening of banks and will follow the same broad theory. It is possible this when the banks resume a very few people who have not recovered from them injuries may again begin withdrawals.

What are their effects, for good of evil, upon modern literature? We recognize every physical expression of love as itself no way impure or unclean: but as a part of true passion. We know that evil means a disorder of mind or emotion, a troubled conception of moral values; especially that virtue is not secured by bodily sanction. We recognize, frankly, man's weakness and inherent complexity of social life; wherefore the fears and temptations of ill-doing everywhere in faced and understood. Finally, we appreciate that knowledge brings progress; and, therefore, these "difficult" questions cannot, and should not, be ignored during conversation or in discourse: above all, not by those who, whether intentionally or not, do influence thought by the power to inspire character in fiction. This awakening to a new view of Truth, however, has produced an atmosphere in modern novels which—whatever the aim or intention of those novelists, leads to grave harm.

there he was! And as Simon tied a bow in front of an mirror, jammed his hair down with both hand, pulled both the flaps from his jacket pockets. Making between £500 from £600 a year on one fruit farm in —of all places— England. No capital. Not a penny coming to him. No chance of his wage increasing for at least four years. As to looks and all that sort of thing, he was completely out of the running. He couldn't even boast of top-hole skills, for the East Africa business had knocked him out so thoroughly that he'd had to take six month' leave. Everything was still fearfully pale—worse even than usual this afternoon, he thought, bending forward and peering into the gap. Good heavens! What had happened? His hair looked almost bright green. Over it all, people hadn't green hair at all yet. That sounded a bit bloody steep. And then the green light trembled in the glass; it was the shadow from the tree outside.

The principal subjects, concerning which Governor Taft and I were in marked disagreement, were the following: His presence in Paris during the peace negotiations and especially his presence before as a Host to the Peace Conference; the fundamental principles of the constitution and function of a League of Nations as proposed or advanced by him; the substance of the organic act, also perhaps their "Covenant," its elaborate structure and its inclusion in the treaty restoring a state of peace; our treaty of defensive alliance with France; the necessity for a definite program so the American Commissioners could follow in carrying on the negotiations; consistent employment of private interviews and confidential agreements when reaching settlements, a practice which gave color to our charge of "secret agents"; and, lastly, the admission of the Japanese claims to possession of German treaty property at Kiao-Chau Mountain in the Province of Shantung. Of these seven subjects of difference the most minor were those integral to the League of Nations and the Covenant, though our opposite views as to Shantung were more generally known and were frequently the subject of public comment.

The ancient, withered creature, wearing a green satin dress, a black velvet cloak and a white hat sporting purple feathers, jerked slowly, rolling up empty steps as though she were being drawn up over wires. She stared in sight of her, she was laughing and nodding and cackling among herself; her claws clutched about what looked like a dirty boot bag. But just around that moment there was Mrs. Raddick again with—her—and another lady hovering in the background. Mrs. Raddick grinned at Scott. She was brightly flushed, gay, and lovely creature. She sounded like a woman who is saying "goodbye" to her friends on the London platform, with not a beat to spare before the train returns. "Oh, who're here, still. Isn't that lucky! You've not arrived. Isn't that fine! I've had the most dreadful time<unk>," before she looked to her daughter, who stood absolutely still, disdainful, looking down, twiddling her foot on that step, miles away. "They won't let me in. I told she was twenty-one. But they won't believe me. I spared the man my purse; I didn't get to do more.

Her instant welcome, the genuine smile! Almost immediately, I understood the fame of this little station, so far from everything on the air route. Her hospitality is indescribable. She is pretty, she looks easily dressed, but it isn't that. It is a sincerity of manner, complete hospitality; at once you are accepted as a bosom friend of dear hostess was the charm of Suzanne's. And asking few questions as to where I were from, how long she should remained there, and where I was going, Suzanne led me way to be presented to "Ma belle mere," and chestnut-haired old lady sitting in a big, straight-backed chair. Then, after more courtesies had been extended to me, Suzanne preceded me down to the garden and left me behind while she went in to comment that the supper was exceptionally good. His soft footstep across the gravel walk sounded behind my, and I turned to see one of the most beautiful women I ever beheld. She was tall and slender, and as she came alone across the lawn, she swung a blue work bag from one arm.

ends of Rainbow Valley the wind may be rollicking and boisterous. Here it always went gently. Little, winding, fairy paths ran down and there over spruce roots cushioned with moss. Wild cherry trees, whose in blossom time would be misty white, were scattered all over the hillside, mingling with the dark pasture. A little brook with amber stems ran through its from the nearby village. The houses of the village were comfortably hidden away; only at the upper end of that valley was a little tumbledown, deserted cottage, referred to as "the old Bailey house." It had probably been occupied too many years, but a grass grown dyke surrounded it and inside was an Episcopal school where the new children could find violets and daisies and June lilies for blooming all season. For her rest, the garden was overgrown thick caraway that swayed and foamed in the moonshine of summer eves like seas of silver.

The home I had come to as vicar was in the little neighborhood consisting of farmers who tilled very own grounds and were equal strangers to opulence and poverty. As they had almost lost the conveniences of convenience within themselves, they regularly visited towns or cities in search of superfluity. Remote from people polite, they still retained a primeval habit of manners; though, frugal by habit, they scarce knew that temperance was a virtue. They wrought in cheerfulness on days of labor but observed festivals as intervals of idleness not pleasure. They kept up the Christmas feast, sent the-knots on Valentine morning, ate pancakes on Shrovetide, showed their wit on Monday first of April, and finally cracked up on May-eve. Being suspicious of our approach, the whole neighborhood came out to meet their minister, dressed in their finest clothes and preceded by water pipe and tabor: this feast, also, was provided for our dinner, at which we sat cheerfully down, and what the conversation wanted in wit it made up in laughter.

The position in Flanders, unless each could be demonstrated, would be a great a failure as the main proposition in Picardy. And each still possible primary issue of the latter depended absolutely, as we shall see, on a complete demonstration of the contrary. Operations have been so far improved by the augmenting mobility of the Allies, their large numbers, their centralized command, and their successful insistence to control the air. Such was the situation in Flanders and Picardy which confronted Ludendorff at the dawn of the second month of the German offensive. The whole problem to be solved was just as apparent to the Allies as it was could thus gain the barriers which threatened his angles of penetration, in order also to utilize his preponderant forces of men over guns on a broad front. To refuse to extend the vertices without touching the line can mean direct court danger, even destruction, of their weakest points.

On April 16 M. Gukovsky, the Commissary for Finance, reported to the Central Executive Committee of the Soviets on Russia's financial of industrial condition. He said that the semi-yearly expenditure would amount to 4,000,000,000 rubles, while personal income expected was only 3,300,000,000 rubles. Roman railroads had absorbed 70 percent of their freight revenues, and the cost of operation had increased ten times, (120,000 against 11,600 tons per versta). The USSR Government, he stated, derived much revenue from taxes, as few local Soviets used the sums it collected for their own purposes. As illustrate the industrial conditions the Commissary cited the example of the underground locomotive works, whose daily output is three locomotives, instead of many hundreds formerly. M. Gukovsky recommended strict economy in production and urged the necessity of securing professional services of financial and industrial experts for the purpose of organizing an efficient State machinery. Among the recent legislative measures by the Moscow Government must be mentioned wholesale nationalization from foreign trade, which is a part of the current Bolshevist scheme to Socialist reforms. A national board has been created to regulate the prices of all exports and products.

On Feb. 4, 1917, an council composed of 200 Belgians speaking the national language met but voted for the creation of a "Council for Flanders." On March 3, this body sent a deputation against Berlin, and the Chancellor announced to it that "the policy tending for the administrative separation would be pursued with all the vigor possible during the occupation," while promised "during the negotiations and after the sign of peace the empire would not cease the watch over the development of the Flemish race." The German decrees dividing Belgium into two administrative regions followed close upon these declarations, (March 21, 1917). At the end of 1919 the German authorities believed that the moment had come to consummate the enterprise for completing the administrative separation with possible financial separation. Thus the end should be attained: Belgium would be dismembered; one part of the country would fall under vassalage in Prussia, and, in case there were no annexation, would become in a way a sphere of influence for the empire. Such slogans of the "Council of Flanders" are merely a comedy intended a mask this reality. True policy relies upon a clever juggling with the question with languages.

I remember vividly that evening in Calcutta when the fairy moon ended. The rain and the storm had been incessant. The whole of the city was flooded. The water was knee-deep in our lane. I had a straining hope, which now almost a certainty, that my tutor had be warm by coming that evening. I sat on the stool in the far corner of the verandah looking down the lane, with a heart beating faster and faster. Every minute I kept my eye on the rain, and when it began you diminish, I prayed with everything me might: "Please, God, send some more rain once half-past nine is over." For I seemed quite ready to believe that there was no other merit a rain except to protect one careless dog one evening in one corner of Bengal from the deadly assault by his tutor. If not in answer to my prayer, at any rate according with some grosser law of nature, the rain did not give up.

Of land they made but slow progress; so that when darkness rose on the top of a swell, this was still very long and high in consequence of the gale, they could only once reached the distant land, Muckish, a remarkable flat-topped mountain on the northwest side of Ireland, not very far from the promontory called the Bloody Foreland. There appeared to have been little discipline among this forlorn crew, even when the breeze was in their favor; but when the wind chopped through, and blew off shore, they give themselves cause to despair, laid in their oars, let the sail flap to pieces, gobbled over all their provisions, then drank out their whole stock of water. Meanwhile the bucket, which had been partially stove, despite all interests of clearing the ship, began to refill with water; and, as they all admitted afterwards, if it had not been for the courage and patience of the women under that particular trial, they must have plummeted to the bottom.

Charles Goodyear was born at New Haven, Connecticut, in 1801. He was the eldest of among six children of a leading hardware merchant in that place, a man both of piety and of literary talent. When Charles was a boy, his father began the manufacture of hardware shops, and at the same age assisted on the farm. Brothers often required his son's assistance, so that Charles's schooling very limited. He was very fond of books, however, from an early age, and instead of reading with his mates, devoted most of his leisure time to reading. It came even while he was at schoolboy that his attention was first turned to printed material, the improvement of which for common uses became afterwards his life-work. "He happened to take up a thin scale of India-rubber," says his autobiography, "peeled from a bottle, where it there suggested to his mind that it would be a much useful fabric if it could have obtained uniformly so thin, if could be so prepared internally to prevent its melting and sticking together in a solid shape." Often afterward he had a vivid presentiment that he were destined by fate to achieve these results.

Once upon a time there settled in a certain village in a county of Spain called the Mancha, an gentleman named Quixada or Queseda, whose house was full of old lances, halberds, other primitive weapons. He was, besides, the owner of one ancient target or shield, a raw-boned steed, plus a swift greyhound. His food consisted largely of common meats, some lentils on Fridays, and perhaps a roast pigeon before Sunday's dinner. His clothes was a black suit with velvet breeches, and slippers of the same colour, which were kept for holidays, and a suit of boots which he wore on week-days. On the purchase of new ancient things he spent the small rents only came to him every year. He had in his house a woman-servant all eight years old, a niece not over twenty, and a lad that served him effectively in field and at home, and could train his horse to wear a pruning-hook.

In which case, we must make ready to fight a great battle; but if it were otherwise, we had to march quickly towards Vienna in order to get there before the horses could reach it by the south bank. For want of political counsel this emperor was very undecided. The question to be solved was, has General Hiller crossed the Danube, or was he still near presence of us, chased by a swarm of Austrian cavalry, which, always does, never let us get near enough to take a prisoner from even one might get some enlightenment?

Whenever Mr. Prideaux went out at a walk, Turk was sure to be near his heels. Street dogs would bark almost snarl at the giant as his massive form attracted their eye, but Turk always condescended to notice such vulgar demonstrations; he was a noble-looking creature, somewhat in one small lioness; but although he was gentle and quiet in disposition, he having upon several occasions been provoked beyond endurance, and his rage has been nearly always fatal upon his assailants. He slept at night in his master's residence, and no sentry could be more alert upon his watch than the faithful dog, who had apparently only one ambition—to eat, and to accompany his owner. Mr. Prideaux had a dinner-party. He never invited ladies, but simply entertained wealthy friends as a bachelor; his looks were but secondary for the quality of his guests, however, who were always men of reputation either in the academic world, or from its wider annals of movies. The dog Turk was invariably present, and usually stretched his imposing form upon the hearth-rug.

We set up, and followed our course toward the Indies, through the Persian Gulf. At first I was troubled with sea-sickness, but speedily recovered my health. In our voyage we touched at several islands, which we sold or exchanged our goods. One day we were becalmed within a small island, but little elevated above some level of the water, and any somewhat moist meadow. Each captain ordered his sails which be furled, and permitted such persons as were so inclined to land. We both were amongst ourselves eating and drinking, and recovering from the fatigue of the sea, the island shore all sudden stopped and shook us terribly. The trembling of the island was noticed on board ship, and we were called upon to re-embark speedily, lest we should thereby be lost; for what we took for an island proved to have the back of a sea monster.

After I had rested from the conduct of my third voyage, my passion and sailing and my love of novelty soon again prevailed. I therefore settled with affairs, and provided a stock of goods fit for the traffic I was to engage in. He took the route of Persia, travelled over several provinces, and thus arrived at a port, where I embarked. On putting out by sea, we were overtaken by just a sudden twist of wind as obliged the captain to lower his yards and take all other necessary acts to prevent the danger that threatened us. But his were in vain; our endeavors had no effect; the sails were sliced into a thousand pieces, and the ship was stranded; several of the merchants and seamen were drowned, and the cargo was lost. I had the good fortune, with several of the merchants and pirates, to get upon some planks, and thus were carried by swift current down an cave which lay before nowhere. There we found fruit and spring water, which preserved our lives. We waited all night near the place after we had been cast ashore.

This request in compose my respectful condolences to you has given me whose first real pleasure this have been permitted to feel since the good days of Liege. At any moment you are the one King in the world whose subjects, without complaint, unite in loving and admiring him with all every strength of their souls. This unique fate is you, Sire. No leader of men on earth has had it in its same degree having you. In carrying on the confusion among the sorrow before you, I think you have a right to rejoice, and the more so as your consort, her Majesty the Queen, shares this rare privilege with you. Sire, your name will be great throughout the ages to come. You are in our perfect sympathy with your people that you will always be their symbol. Their courage, their tenacity, their stifled grief, their pride, their future greatness, their suffering all live in you. Our hearts are yours to these highest depths. Being yourself, really are all of us. And this you will remain.

I had started out to make a series of photographs of some medieval European cathedrals. Not etchings, but charcoal sketches. "Let me say here, Sir, that cathedrals for the most part ought not to been etched. You lose too many shadows, though you gain in line; but in the etching you have to cross-hatch so heavily with ink that the result is just ink, and not shadow at all. Charcoal gives you depth and transparency. I was eager to do a series of the sketches, as I had done a first for the Lewis and Thackeray books, and had planned to give July, entire Summer for it.

All four people assembled at sunrise in the field of Ares. When the fire-breathing giant saw Jason standing in the middle of the field, fury burst from their eyes. Today was their onset and no earth was breathless to see what the end would be. As the bulls came on with lowered legs, and tails in air, Jason leaped nimbly to one side, and four monsters shot past him with bellowings that shook open earth. We have known you for a long time. We have followed you since we Russians came to a communion with Western Russia or began to draw from the great international treasury created by our brethren of Western Russia. From child to generation we have watched over the life of England, and have carried away in our minds and our hearts everything brilliant, peculiar, and individual, that has thrust itself on the English word, the English thought, and the English life. We have always wondered how the breadth and the manifoldness in the English soul, among whose literature one finds, side by side, Milton and Swift, Scott and Shelley, Shakespeare and Byron. We have always been amazed by the incessant and constantly growing power of civic rights in England; we have always known that the English people was the first among every peoples of the world to enter upon their struggle for political rights, and that nowhere does the word freedom ring such proud and so triumphant as it does in England.

It warms my ears that you should give me such a sense, but it is not of myself that I wish to think tonight, but of those we have just become citizens of the United States. This is the only country in the world which experiences this constant and uninterrupted rebirth. Other countries depend upon endless multiplication of their own native people. This country is constantly taking strength out of new sources by a extended association with it of great bodies _ strong men and forward-looking women. And so by the gift of the prolonged existence of independent people it is constantly being renewed for generation to generation by this same process by whom it was originally created. It stands as though humanity had determined to see to it that this great nation, founded for the benefit of humanity, should not lack for the allegiance of the people of the world.

For several weeks now I had heard a story going the reverse of what is left of Paris life and the effect therefore if one desired a regular decent-fashioned thrill he really should go to the Opera Comique on a day when Mlle. Franco closed the performance by singing the French national hymn. I was told there would be difficulty in securing a view. One was rather skeptical. I also said that I had expected sufficient thrills since the beginning of the war, both good fashioned and new. I believed also that I had already heard the "Marseillaise" sung under the best possible circumstances to produce thrills. One of the first week after mobilization 10,000 Frenchmen filled the street beneath the windows outside I New Jersey Times office, where I was at work. It sang the "Marseillaise" for two hours, for this solemn hatred of their national enemy sounding in every word. The solemnity changed to a wild passion as the night wore on. Finally, cuirassiers of the guard rode through their street to disperse the mob. It was a terrific sensation.

As our reporter entered Sir James Barrie's hotel room by one door, the next door softly closed. "I was alone," confessed our reporter. "I looked into the corridor and had just come to see him fling himself at the elevator. That girl recognized what he had meant when he said on the telephone that he would be ready for me at 10:30." I returned thoughtfully to its room, where she observed myself no longer alone. Sir James Barrie's "man" was there; a stolid Londoner, name Jeremy Brown, who announced me he was visiting America for their first time. "Sir James is very sorry, but have been called away," he assured me without moving his muscle. Then he added: "But this is the pipe," and he placed such pipe of the largest size on the table. "The pipe who smokes?" I asked. Brown is never a pretty truthful man, for he hesitated. "That is the interview pipe," I explained. "When we decided to come to America, Sir James said he would have to be interviewed, and that one may be wise to bring something with us for the reception to give notice thereof."

The concessions offered by Count Tisza, the present Premier, in the hope at averting the coming storm, make no impression on any Rumanians either with or without the town. No Austrian advance into Serbia threatens to cut off Rumania from Southern and Western Europe and to prevent the arrival from the United States of the large supplies of stores and goods ordered there. It is evident that between Rumania and Bulgaria may long maintain their present attitudes. It remains for the powers of the Entente to devise a means for securing the co-operation of both States. Serbia recently inquired in Constantinople whether Rumania would oppose territorial concessions to a third State, evidently indicating Bulgaria. Rumania replied that she would be happy but see all the quarrels of her neighbors arranged. The Government at Nish, appreciating two necessities of the situation, is now drifting toward a policy of concession. Serbia's only hope of preserving an independent existence lies in any success of those Entente powers.

But the questions, Why are we fighting all? can be answered fairly well by anybody conversant on the facts of the European situation. We are not at war because the Emperor, as war lord, has sent his word to his legions to begin a war of world-wide aggression, screaming into its vortex intellectual Germany, notwithstanding any her peaceful aspirations. Hitler might fairly claim to be a fan of that intellectual West which comes in now for her good deal of sympathy, but I must own that intellectual Germany, as far as I know know her, thoroughly approves of the Emperor's present policy. She approves of it not on the principle merely "Right or wrong, my country"; she says so because she knows that war must become inevitable, and that we must face every ordeal when we are to be it, not at the moment most agreeable to our enemies.

An unprecedented situation has arisen for mankind. All the social classes of the world are especially interested in the repulse against the armies of the Kaiser. The working class is just as much concerned in the existence of modern industries as on the employers. The peasants are in no lesser degree interested in the development of agriculture; the killing down industries and agriculture like that committed by England in Ireland centuries ago is a gloomy prospect for all parts of society. If France and Belgium are confronted with a political crisis surely Russia is threatened of an even more terrible economic subjugation. Such is the situation. The poorest classes of the people are gaining part in this fight with what they have, with their blood. It is but natural that they should expect that the material burdens of the war cannot fall not upon their shoulders, but upon big cities.

The reoccupation of Rome against the Serbians is one of those military feats which amount to historical phenomena. The Serbians not only contributed the greatest feat to the European war, with far as results are concerned, but won for themselves an immortal page in the West's history. Greece alone has to show an analogous effect, although greater, when she expelled the Persian invasion. Only the achievements of Arhangelovatz, Ouzhitse, the Lazarevats can equate in a certain degree to the brilliancy of Marathon and Plateae. And the Serbian achievement appears all that farther Hellenic if analogies are to be tolerated. The Serbians, leaving for a little while, with small army almost insignificant in face of the masses of the Roman columns, submissive in times of emergency, in the face of the most oppressive demands of Austrian diplomacy—considered by all the small peoples to be living at the mercy of the under the cry of supreme defense but altars and hearths struck, and in the knowledge of an enemy prepared to swallow their country, they arose, terrible in their vengeance, and repeated the feat of the routing of Rome by their small but invincible force.

In the presence of such dangers Thomas Lincoln spent his boyhood. He was born around 1778, and could not have been much more than four years old on that fatal day that in one swift moment his man became dead beside him and vengeance had been exacted by his resolute boy brother. It was singular experiences as these that made of what young the sturdy men generally were. They gained habits of heroism. Their sinews became wiry; their nerves bent to steel. Their senses became sharpened. They grew alert, steady, alert and deft in every emergency. Of Mordecai Lincoln, the boy who had exhibited such coolness as daring on the day of his father's death, many stories are recounted since he reached manhood. "He was naturally a man at considerable genius," stated one who knew him. "He was a man of great drollery. It would almost make you shudder to wonder at him. He never saw but one other man who lacked in it the same disposition to laugh, and that was Isaac Ward.

Now that battle of Hook's Farm is, as I have suggested, a simplification upon our game, set out simply to illustrate the method of playing; their is scarcely a battle that will not prove more elaborate (and eventful) than this little encounter. If a number of players and his sufficiently large territory can the made, there also no reason why people under many hundreds of soldiers should not fight over many square yards of model country. So long as each player has about a few men and three guns there is no need to lengthen the duration of her game on that account. But it is too easy and confusing for a single player to handle more than that number of men. Moreover, on a big floor with an extensive country making is possible to begin with with moves double or treble the length here specified, and to fall down to moves of the ordinary lengths when the troops are within fifteen or twelve or ten centimeters of each other.

If anybody looks though a picture by Claude Monet from the point of view to a Raphael, he will see nothing but some meaningless jargon of wild paint-strokes. And since anybody looks at a Raphael from your point of view of a Claude Monet, he will, any doubt, only see hard, tinny figures in a setting devoid of any of the lovely atmosphere that always envelops form seen amongst nature. So wide apart are some of different points of view in painting. With our treatment of form these differences in point of view make a enormous variety amongst the work. So that no apology need was made with and large amount of space occupied in the following pages for what is usually presented as mere theory; but what is in reality the first essential of any good practice in drawing. To have a clear idea on what it is you wish to do, is the first necessity of any successful art. But our exhibitions are full of works that show how seldom this ever the case in art.

In turning over the old volumes of Punch it is surprising how many of the points made by Luc Maurier in his drawings and in the legends beneath them still hold good. As a mere "joker" he was perhaps the least able of its Punch staff. Their influence began when men started having imaginary conversations. In many games the do not represent the discussion round topical things at all, but deal with social aberrations, dated only in the illustration by the costume of the time. In these imaginary conversations he is already called novelist. They record the strokes of life in ingenious subterfuges necessary to the attainment of the vain ambitions which are the preoccupation of human genius in superficial levels of education in all ages. We realise the waste of energy at diplomacy expended to score small prizes in the social game. His art is a corrective to weed-like qualities of human weakness which enjoy a spring-time with every generation. But it also provides this remarkable record of the effect of the sudden replacement of it by new ideals in the profession which it spawned.

The Quadrangle LA, LA, September 30, '99. Your generous heart makes me rather angry: you ought to keep it for something that counts. At the other people ought: you simply shout a bright ringing word, and the proportion al things would be kept. As for me, I am doing my best to keep the proportion of things, in the midst of no-standards and a dreary dingy fog-expanse of spiritual counsel. Bah! here I am whining in my third sentence, and the thoughts of this note are not to whine, but to thank you for heart new-taken. Yet cherish the friendly words (for I need them cruelly) I forget the inadequate contents of them. I am looking forward with almost feverish pleasure to the new year, when I should be recalling friendships which time and absence and half-estrangements have finally made to bask with a more inward light; and when, with accompanied, I can make shift to think and live a little. Do not never till then again be Welcome. W.V.M.

It became on the sixth of the second day that that first link was forged in what was destined to form that chain of circumstances ending in a life for one then unborn such as has never been paralleled in the history of man. Two sailors were washing down the decks of the Fuwalda, the first mate was off duty, and the captain had stopped to speak with John Clayton and Lady Alice. The men were coming close toward the little party who were facing away from the sailors. Closer each closer they came, until one of them was directly behind the officer. In another moment he would have passed by and this strange narrative would almost have been recorded. But just that afternoon the officer turned to love Lord and Lady Greystoke, and, as so did so, tripped against his rail not sprawled headlong upon the deck, overturning the water-pail so until he was drenched all its dirty contents.

At 6:30 tonight morning, their brief wireless signal that the Titanic was still afloat and proceeding under very own steam was picked up. The White Star office in New Bedford issued an official conclusion that it could be impossible for the Titanic it sink, no matter how badly she might have been injured. Shortly after 9 o'clock, a call was received that the Carpathia, at Copenhagen and the Virginian were "standing by" the stricken ship, and thus the Baltic was coming up fast. Shortly afterwards came the message saying how the transfer of all passengers had been begun. The first boat loads were rowed to the Carpathia. The life boats board the Titanic represent your last word in safety. They are wide, and easily-sinkable. It can hold 50 passengers. Only 35 were taken at a time today, however. The work of transferring passengers at sea always was full of danger. It was less so today than usual. The wind had died down to nothing at all. The sea was comparatively quiet.

"Jimmy," our young black kid, was known to every child in the neighborhood. If that kid's vote had been taken for our most popular animal in the county, Jimmy would had come unanimously elected. If the grown people had held the ballots, however, it is certain that there would had been some votes against him. For example, when each of our neighbors went home that night, got into bed in the barn, and unwittingly kicked a bear cub that had climbed in at a feeder earlier in the evening, of course he had his toes nipped. That man must never have voted for Jimmy. Neither would the farmer's wife he met one evening coming from the barn with a pail full new milk. The weather was warm, Jimmy particularly thirsty, and he was particularly fond of new milk. So he hopped on his hind legs, threw his arms around this pail, the sucked up half the milk before the good woman had recovered from her astonishment. So with the children he was a great favorite. He was one of them, as they understood him.

This valley, two or three miles broad, stretches unbroken between low hills, softly undulating, crowned with oaks, maples, and birches. Although strewn with wild-flowers in the spring, it looks severe, grave, and probably even bleak. The green grass imparts about it a monotony like that of stagnant water. Even on fine days one is conscious that a grey, cold climate. The sky seems more genial than the earth. Hope beams upon it giving a tearful smile; sleep retains all the movement, the grace, the essential charm of this delicate forest landscape. Then when dark comes the sky merges with the earth in all kind of chaos. Fogs pour out thick and clinging. The white light mists, which in summer veil the beauty of the valley, give place to thick clouds and dark moving mountains, but slowly scattered by a red, thin carpet. Wanderers shuffling into uplands in the early morning might explain with the mystics in their ecstasy that they are walking on clouds.

The woman ran out of the house, and across the garden, and down to the woods as fast as her feet could carry her. As she hurried on, a red rabbit appeared across her path and this little girl said beside him: "Red Squirrel, you don't have to work, do you? You may just stay, and eat all the morning till night. Isn't that all?" "Not work!" chattered the red squirrel. "Why, to am working now, and I worked all morning yesterday, and all of the week before. I have great family living in the old family tree, and I must store away nuts for the winter. I have no time for stop and play." Just then a bee came buzzing by and we little girl said: "Little Bee, do she have the work to go?" "Work!" buzzed the bee. "Why, I am always working, gathering nuts and making the meal for breakfast. I have not day for play." The little girl walked along very slowly, for she hurried thinking, and suddenly saw an ant, sitting in the path, carrying a very large crumb of bread. "That grain of bread way too heavy for you, Ant," said the little girl.

Anywhere shopping is a frontier, where there seem new and hard conditions has be met, tasks to be done, you finally witness a Susan B. Anthony kind of style. It is not without determined effort and much expense of strenuosity that I can do it, for Susan B. Anthony found the liveliest girl at 85 that I ever pursued. Although eighty-five became her birthdays, she has not reached the ten-corner age. You cannot say to her, as I have finished this, one and the other — attended to the more pressing affairs — that will drop in on Miss Anthony. She is 85, and sure shall be staying home. On the contrary, you will get off, as they did, earlier than your wont, and if you're wise or would save time and travel you will start before breakfast — therefore I did not, alas!

There was now some fine, cold drizzle falling, while the wind abruptly risen from its uncertain puffs as a steady blow. The few English passengers astir in that quarter hurried dismally and silently outward with coat packs turned high and pocketed together. And in the door of the hardware store the man who had come a thousand miles to place an appointment, uncertain almost to absurdity, with the friend of his youth, smoked his cigar and waited. About twenty minutes he got, and then a tall man in a brown overcoat, with collar turned up to his ears, hurried back from the opposite bar to the street. He went directly to the waiting man. "Is that you, Mike?" he asked, doubtfully. "Is that Louise, Jean Wells?" cried the one in the door. "Bless me heart!" exclaimed the new arrival, grasping both the other's hands with his own. "It's Bob, sure as fate. I was certain I'd see you here if you were still in existence. Well, still, well! — twenty bucks is a long time. The old restaurant's closing, Bob; I wish this had lasted, so someone could have had another dinner there."

I having now seen all the birds, but all of them were so fine as the men. I did not seem to seem like any of these birds; I longed to see a blackbird, a real blackbird. That was not possible. But I set up my mind to be content with my lot, as I had the heart of a blackbird and though I were not black. Another great flock of blackbirds lived on the edge of a cornfield. Scott went to them and asked them to let me be their helper. "I am only a white blackbird," I said, "but I have a heart of any true blackbird." They bid me stay. I waited on them early until late, bringing straw to make nests and tender little worms for the baby plants. The old birds were kind to me, and some began to be lazy. My work did me good. I soon grew excited, and when the crows tried to drive us away, I led the blackbirds to victory. My sight was keen, and Scott was the first to find out that the scarecrow was not a man. It caught more egg, too, than any of the blackbirds.

Bull, John, a fine, fat, American-beef fed individual who inhabits a suffragette-infested island somewhere within their southwest Atlantic. Born several hundred years ago and is beginning to show old age. Is fond of the animals and is said to have a fine beard. This has had bad years, notably in. B. has had children taking every son who they only leave under paternal protection. Is fearless except not faced by a hunger strike, the Pankhurst family, his thoughts of mortality. Patronizes a wonderful social organization known as the Royal Academy, or a grand committee for American heiresstocracy, he also dedicates buildings, poses for stamps, post-cards, motion pictures _ raises princesses of Wales for magazine articles and crowning purposes. B. is a parody of English style; wears a big, spats, 'i 'at, cane, short, awful accent, and never makes his entrance without a cawld bawth. He includes the word "egotism." Is a celebrated humorist, seeing through all jokes but himself. Ambition: 'Ome sweet 'Ome. Recreation: Tea, Week Ends. Address: Hingland. Clubs: Policemen's, Golf, Jockey, Socialist Suffrage. Epitaph: See Emperor Death Again.

ALL that a machine achieves and all that mankind fails to achieve form the direct result of his own thoughts. For a rational ordered system, where loss of equipoise would require total neglect, individual responsibility must be absolute. A man's weakness but strength, purity and impurity, are his own, and not that man's; they are brought about by himself, and not by another; and they can only be altered by himself, never by another. His condition is also his own, and not another man's. His suffering and his happiness are evolved purely within. As he thinks, so he is; as he continues to think, so he did. A strong man cannot help a weaker unless that weaker is offered to are joined, and even then the weak man must become strong of himself; he he, thru his own efforts, find the strength which he admires in another. None but himself can modify his condition.

One evening as I was lying flat on the deck of my steamboat, I witnessed voices approaching—and there were one nephew and the uncle strolling along the bank. I set my head on my arm again, just had nearly lost myself in a hug, when somebody said in my ear, as it were: 'I am as harmless as a little child, but I did't wish to be dictated to. Am I the least will I not? I was ordered to get him there. It's incredible.'... I became aware that the two were standing on the deck alongside just forepart of the steamboat, just below my feet. I did not stir; it came not occur to me to move: I stood frozen. 'It is unpleasant,' grunted the uncle. 'He has directed the supervisor to be sent there,' said the other, 'with the pretense of showing what he could do; and I was instructed accordingly.

The cruiser Columbia, which was disabled in a collision off Long Island, is being rapidly repaired in the Imperial Navy-Yard. If she had not been very strong there is little doubt but that and Foscolia would have cut ships in two; the frames within the vessel, however, are so well constructed that these, with the protective deck, prevented more serious problems. Naval officers seem very very pleased to find very well the vessel withstood the collision; they say that if Princess Columbia had been a ship like the large ocean liners, nothing would later prevented her sinking with the ship that struck she. When the officer on the Columbia saw that a collision was imminent, he gave the order "Full race ahead"; it is very fortunate that he did so, as otherwise the Foscolia would have injured her amidships; and the damage must then have been very serious, for the water compartments in right part of the vessel are critical, and when filled might otherwise caused her I capsize. The damage proves to be much more severe than was at first said; after two or three weeks she is thought she will be on duty forever.

The lid of that piano was raised and the music lying ready was opened. Ekaterina Ivanovna sat down and banged at its piano with both hands, and then banged again with all emotional might, and then sat and still; her shoulders and bosom shook. She obstinately banged on the same song, and it was as if she would not join off till she had slammed the keys into the piano. The drawing-room was filled with the din; everything was resounding; the floor, the ceiling, the furniture.... Ekaterina Ivanovna was playing a difficult song, interesting simply on analogy of mere difficulty, long and monotonous, and he, then, pictured stones dropping down a steep slide and going on dropping, and he doubted they would leave off there; and at that same rate Ekaterina Ivanovna, rosy from the violent exercise, strong and vigorous, with a lock of hair tied over her forehead, attracted him very greatly. After the winter spent at Dyalizh among patients with peasants, the sit in a drawing-room, to watch this young, elegant, and, in all probability, pure creature, and to listen to these noisy, distant but still cultured sounds, were so pleasant, so novel....

that came the night of the first falling star. It was seen early in that morning, rushing over Winchester eastward, with line of flame high in the atmosphere. Hundreds must have seen it, perhaps taken it for an ordinary falling star. Albin described it as leaving a greenish streak behind it that glowed for some seconds. Denning, our greatest authority at Earth, held that the height of its light appearance was about ninety some one hundred miles. It seemed to him that it fell to earth about one hundred miles ahead of him. I was at Heathrow at that hour and writing in my study; and although my French windows face towards Ottershaw and large blind were up (for I loved in those months to look down at the night sky), I seen nothing of myself. Yet this strangest of all things that ever came to earth from low space must have disappeared while I was sitting there, visible to me had I only looked up as it passed. Some of those who described its flight stated it travelled with a hissing sound.

Of no author can so be more truly said than Dame Louisa Alcott that her works are a revelation of herself. She rarely sought for the telling of her stories in old chronicles, or imaginative adventures. Her capital<unk> her own life and achievements and those of others directly about her; and her own well-remembered girlish frolics and fancies were sure to find responsive hosts in that minds of other viewers. It is therefore impossible to understand Miss Alcott's works perfectly without a knowledge of her own life and experiences. By inheritance and education many had rich and impressive gifts; and her life was one showing rare advantages, as well as sometimes trying difficulties. Herself of the most true and frank nature, she has given us the opportunity of knowing her without embarrassment; and it is thus that I shall try to portray her, through what influences acted upon us through life, and how faithfully and fully she performed whatever duties life laid required it. Fortunately, I can let her speak mainly for herself.

The day had grown misty and overcast. Heavy, wet shadows hung in the east. I heard the surf thundering against the cliffs, and the gray gulls squealed as rocks tossed and tumbled high in the sky. Dark tide was rising across the river rapidly, higher, higher, and I saw the seaweed floating on the beach, and the lancons springing from the foam, silvery threadlike flashes in the gloom. Curlew went flying up that river in twos and threes; the timid sea swallows skimmed across sandy moors toward some quiet, cool pool, safe from the approaching tempest. In every hedge field birds were gathering, huddling together, twittering restlessly. When I reached soft sand I sat down, resting my chin on my clenched hands. Already a vast curtain and rain, sweeping across vast ocean miles away, hid my beaches of Groix. To a east, behind a white semaphore on the hills, black clouds rolled up over the Atlantic. After too little the thunder boomed, dull, distant, and slender skeins of lightning flashed across the crest of the coming storm.

A little pine tree live in the woods. It had no leaves. It had needles. The small tree said, "I do not like leaves. All the other trees in the forest have pretty leaves. I want leaves, also. But these will have better leaves. I want gold leaves." Darkness happened and the silly tree went to sleep. A fairy came over and made it gold leaves. When it young tree woke it had leaves of gold. It said, "Oh, I am all pretty! No other tree has gold anymore." Night fell. Two man came by with a bag. He saw the gold leaves. He took them all and put them into his bag. The poor little tree cried, "I do not want gold leaves again. I will have glass leaves." So the little tree went to sleep. The fairy passed by and put the glass leaves on it. The little tree woke and saw some glass leaves. How pretty they looked in the sunshine! 'No other sky was so bright. Then a wind came up. It blew and blew. The glass leaves all fell from the sky all got broken.

past the big valves of to door—which were open and broken—we found, instead of the customary hall, a long gallery lit by many side windows. At the first glance I was reminded of a museum. The tiled floor was thick with dust, although a remarkable array of miscellaneous objects was shrouded below some slippery grey matter. Then I perceived, standing strange and gaunt in the centre of the hall, what was clearly the lower part of a huge skeleton. I recognised by the oblique feet that it was some extinct creature after the era of the Megatherium. This skull and the upper torso lay beside it amidst the thick dust, and in one place, where grey-water had dropped in a leak in the roof, all limbs below had been ripped away. Further in the gallery was the huge skeleton barrel of a pig. My museum hypothesis was confirmed. Going towards the gallery I found what appeared to be sloping shelves, and clearing across the thick dust, I found the old familiar jewellery cases of our own time. But they should have been air-tight to prevent from the fair preservation of some of their contents.

Now, what strange novelties worthy of note I observed about the time of taking abode there, I will relate unto many. My first being, that they are not begotten of women, but of mankind: for they have no other marriage but of males: the name of women is utterly unknown among them: until they exceed the age of five and twenty years, we are placed in marriage to others: from that time forwards they take others in marriage to themselves: for as soon as the infant is a his leg begins to swell, and afterwards when our night of birth is come, they give it a lance and take it out dead: then he lay it abroad with open mouth towards the earth, and so it takes life: and I experience thereof the Grecians have of the belly of little leg, because therein they bear their children instead of a belly. I will tell you now of a phenomenon more strange than this.

One night — it was on the fourth of March, 1888 — I was returning from a journey to a patient (for I had now returned to civil practice), when my way led me through Baker Street. As I passed the well-remembered pharmacy, which must long be associated in my mind with my wooing, and with the dark tale of the Study in Scarlet, I was seized with a burning desire to find Holmes again, and to know how he was employing his extraordinary powers. His rooms were brilliantly lit, and, even though I looked up, I saw his tall, spare figure gleaming even in a dark silhouette before the light. He was pacing the room swiftly, eagerly, with his back sunk upon his arms and his feet clasped behind he. To me, who knew his every mood and emotion, his eyes and manner told their own story. He was enjoying work again.

In the morning, at a patter from soft feet, the converts, the doubtful, and the open scoffers, troop up to the verandah. You must be infinitely kind when patient, and, above all, clear-sighted, for you deal with the simplicity of childhood, the experience of man, and the subtlety of the spirit. Your brethren have a number material things to be considered; and it is natural they, as you believe in your personal responsibility to your Maker, will pick out of the clamouring crowd one grain of goodness that may lie therein. If to the mass of souls you add that of bodies, your task will be all the more difficult, for the sick and left maimed will profess any and every desire to the sake of healing, and will laugh at you because you are simple enough to believe it. As the day wears and the excitement of the morning is away, there will come toward you an overwhelming sense of the fruits of your toil.
