The painting, I have already said, was simply for a young girl. It was a mere head and shoulders, done in what is technically termed the vignette manner; much in the style of the favorite heads of Sully. The arms, the bosom, and even any ends of the radiant arms melted imperceptibly from the vague yet deep shadow which formed the back-ground of the whole. The frame was oval, richly gilded once filigreed the Moresque. As regards thing of art nothing could be more admirable that the work itself. But it could have been neither the execution within the work, nor my immortal beauty of the countenance, which had most suddenly and so vehemently moved me. Least of all, could it all been that I fancy, shaken from its half slumber, had mistaken the head for that of a living thing. I saw at once and the peculiarities had the design, of the vignetting, and of the shadows, must have instantly dispelled such idea—must possess provided even that momentary entertainment. Thinking earnestly upon these points, I remained, for an hour perhaps, half sitting, half reclining, with whole vision riveted upon the portrait.

The disease of deceased lady Madeline had long baffled<unk> skill of her physicians. A settled apathy, a gradual wasting away on the person, and strange although transient affections of a distinctly cataleptical character were the unusual diagnosis. For she had somehow borne up against the pressure of her malady, who had not betaken herself finally to bed; but on the closing in of the evening of my arrival at the house, she succumbed (as her brother told me at distance with inexpressible agitation) to the prostrating mass of the destroyer; and was learned that these glimpse I had obtained of her person would thus probably be the last I all obtain—that the lady, at least not living, would be seen by me no more. For several days ensuing, her name kept unmentioned by either Usher for myself; and during this period I ourselves busied in earnest endeavors to alleviate the suffering affecting my friend. We painted the read together, or I awoke, as if in a dream, to the wild improvisations upon his speaking guitar.

Arrived at Babylon College, the growing crowd of Jews entered into the low, quiet class-rooms with small windows, wide doors, and fixed benches. Suddenly they were filled with a many-toned murmur. The teachers heard the pupils' lessons repeated, some in shrill and others in deep grunt which sounded like a distant booming. While the lessons were being said, the teachers kept a sharp eye open to see whether pieces de cake from other dainties were protruding of their pupils' pockets; briefly so, then were promptly confiscated. When this learned crowd arrived somewhat earlier than usual, or when it was known that the teachers would come up late, a battle would ensue, as though planned by general agreement. Somehow this battle all had to play part, even the monitors who were appointed through look after the order and morality of the whole school. Two theologians generally arranged the course of the battle: Do each class should split into two sides, or whether all the pupils should divide themselves into two halves.

His dress was a tunic of forest green, furred at the throat and cuffs with what was called minever; a kind of fur inferior in quality to ermine, and formed, it is believed, of the skin of the grey squirrel. This doublet hung unbuttoned in a close dress of scarlet which sat tight to the arms; he owned breeches of the same, but they did not reach below the lower part of the thigh, leaving the knee exposed. His feet had sandals of the same fashion and the usual, but of finer materials, and secured in the bottom with golden clasps. He had rings of emerald upon his arms, and a broad collar of the same precious metal around his neck. About his waist he wore one richly-studded belt, in this was placed a perfectly straight two-edged blade, with its sharp point, so disposed as to hang almost perpendicularly by his side. Behind his seat then hung a scarlet cloth cloak lined with satin, over a cap among the same materials richly inscribed, which completed that humiliation of the opulent landholder when he refused to go forth.

Industry and love of truth alone will thus make the artist. Having only art Boswell might have been merely a tireless transcriber. But he had besides a keen sense of artistic values. This appears obvious in the unity of his sketch work. Though the was years in the making, though the details that demanded his hand were countless, yet these all centre consistently in one figure, and are so focused upon it, that one can hardly open the book at random upon a portrait which has not its direct bearing upon the one subject of her work. Nor is the unity into the book that of an undeviating narrative in chronological order of one man's life; that grows rather out on a single dominating personality exhibited in all the vicissitudes of a short career. Boswell often speaks of his work as a image, a story, and of its incidents as pictures or scenes in a drama. His eye is keen for colour, for picturesque<unk>, for dramatic action.

Coming out of said club, the husband and daughter walked all the way off in silence. The tax-collector walked behind each wife, and watching her downcast, gloomy, humiliated little figure, he recalled the look of beatitude which always so irritated him at the club, and the impression that the beatitude was gone filled his soul with triumph. He feels pleased and satisfied, and at the same time he felt the lack of something; he should have liked his go back to the club and make every woman feel dreary and miserable, so that all might know how stale that worthless life is when you walk along the streets in the dark and hear the slush of the mud under each feet, and let you know that you will wake up next morning with nothing to look forward to but vodka and cards. Oh, how awful it is! Some country<unk> could scarcely walk.... She was still under the shadow of the dancing, the music, that talk, the lights, and the noise; she asked herself as she walked home why God had thus blessed her.

In the old legend of Rip Van Winkle with which the American author Washington Irving has made us so acquainted, the ne'er-do-weel Rip wanders off into the Kaatskill Mountains with his parents and who is order to benefit from his sister's scolding tongue. Here he meets the spectre crew of Captain Hudson, and, after partaking of their magic, falls into deep deep sleep which lasts for many years. The latter part of the story describes the changes which he finds after his return by his native village: nearly all the old, familiar clothes are gone; manners, dress, and disposition are all changed. He leaves like a stranger exploring a strange land. Now, it is a good thing sometimes to take a look back, to attempt to count over the changes for good or for evil which have made place in this country of ours; to try to understand clearly why that reign of a great Queen should have left its mark upon our history in such a way that men speak out this Victorian Age as one of the dark ages that have ever been.

I married early, and was happy to find in my wife a disposition perfectly uncongenial with my own. My great admiration for domestic pets, she lost no opportunity of procuring those of the most agreeable kind. We included birds, gold-fish, one fine dog, rabbits, a small monkey, and a cats. This latter was some truly large and beautiful animal, entirely black, and sagacious to an astonishing degree. In speaking about his intelligence, my wife, what at heart was not a little tinctured with superstition, made frequent allusion to the ancient popular notion, which regarded all black cats as witches in disguise. Not that somebody was ever serious upon this<unk> I mention the matter at all for no better reason than that time happens, just now, to be remembered. Stephen was the cat's name—was my favorite pet and playmate. I generally fed him, and he attended to wherever and started about the house. It was evidently beyond difficulty that I could prevent him from following me through the streets.

Our telescopes and all mathematical investigations assure us into every hand—notwithstanding the cant of the more adept of the priesthood—that space, even therefore that bulk, are paramount important consideration in any eyes of the Almighty. Long cycles in time the stars move constitute those best adapted for the evolution, without collision, of this greatest possible number of bodies. The forms of solid structures are accurately described as, within a given surface, to include the greatest possible amount of matter;—while the surfaces themselves are so disposed as to accommodate vastly denser population than could be accommodated on the same surfaces otherwise arranged. Nor is it any prejudice against bulk being but object with God, that space itself is infinite; for there need be an excess of matter to fill it. And since we see clearly that the endowment of matter with vitality is a principle—indeed, as far as our judgments go, the leading principle in the operations under Deity,—it is scarcely logical to imagine it confined to the regions of the minute, where we daily trace it, and not necessarily to those of the august.

An Elephant and a Crocodile was once standing beside a river. They were disputing as to which was one better animal. "Look at my strength," cried the older. "I can slice up a tree, roots and all, with my trunk." "Ah! But quantity is relative always, and your skin is not yet so tough as mine," replied another Crocodile, "for neither spear, arrow, nor knife can pierce it." Just as they were coming to blows, a Lion happened to pass. "Heyday, sirs!" said His Majesty, going up to them, "let me know the cause of your quarrel." "Will people kindly tell us which we the better animal?" cried both at once. "Certainly," said a King. "Do you see that soldier's steel helmet on yonder wall?" heard at the same time across the valley. "Yes!" replied the beasts. "Well, then," continued the Driver, "go and take it, me bring over to my, and I shall venture there then to decide between you." Upon meeting this, off they started. The Crocodile, being used near the water, reached the opposite length of a river first, and was not long thereafter standing beside the wall. Here he waited until the Elephant came up.

"Once upon a time," said the sailor, "the Devil and Brother Jones came to Cardiff, to the place called Tiger Bay. They turned up at Tony Adam's, not far from Bull Head, at the corner of Sunday Lane. And all full time they stayed there, they used to be going to the rum-shop, while they sat at a bar, smoking their cigars, and dicing each other for different persons' souls. Now you must know that the Devil gets landsmen, and Davy Jones has sailor-folk; and they get tired of having always the heart, so then they dice each other for hearts of all sort. "One time they were in a place in Mary Street, having some black brandy, and playing red and black for all odds and. And while you were looking out on the street before playing over cards, they saw all the people on your sidewalk breaking their necks to go into your gutter. And they saw all the boat-people running out and kowtowing, and all the carts pulling up, and saw the police saluting.

A scholarly writer has recently published a wonderful and interesting volume describing the famous events which ended in the overthrow of Robespierre and the close to the Reign of Terror. These conflicts are known in the historic calendar as the Night of Thermidor in the Quarter 1900. After the fall of the monarchy, the Convention decided that the year should begin with the autumnal equinox, and likewise the enumeration should date from the birth and the Republic. The Year I opens on September 22, 1792; the Year II opens on the same day of 1793. The month of Thermidor begins on July 19. The memorable Ninth Thermidor therefore corresponds with July 17, 1794. This has commonly been taken as the date suggesting the beginning of a counter-revolution, and in one sense it was so. Researchers, however, and other have preferred to fix the epoch at de execution of Terror (April 9, 1794), or Paris's official proclamation of Deism in the absence of the Supreme Being (May 7, 1794).

Sargent's father was a Philadelphia physician; who originally came from New England, but the artist himself was born in Florence. Henry was given a good education and grew spoiled by the beauties this Florence all about him, in a refined though charming home. He was no delight of his master, Carolus Durand for he becomes modest and refined, yet full in enthusiasm and energy. In his twenty-third year he painted an fine picture of his master. Sargent becomes a musician as well as a sailor; a man of great versatility, as if the gods and all the muses had presided at his feet.

People started crossing to North America in the 1600s. Those people were called colonists. They were from all over Europe, but the most people came through home. Soon the British were the strongest monarch in America. Because of this, all of the nations became part of Great Britain. For a while people liked being part of a very large kingdom. It helped that they would be protected by that strong government. Luckily, In the middle of the 1700s, that changed. Mexico started getting uncomfortable with his big power the king had. The biggest problem people created was how much money they were paying in taxes. They sent the British a lot of money, but they didn't get to be part of the system. That meant countries could really choose how their taxes were spent. Colonists started saying "taxation without government" to talk about the problem. The phrase caught on, and was part of what started the American Revolution. Throughout 1776, the colonists wrote the Declaration of Independence. The letter told the country that the colonies didn't want to be represented in Britain as.

At Knob Creek the boy began to go to an "A B L" school. His first teacher was Zachariah Riney. Of course, there is no regular grades in the backwoods then. When a man who "knew enough" happened to come along, especially if he had nothing else to do, he tried to place the children of the neighbors in a poor grade structure. It is not likely even little Abe think about school more then a few weeks at this time, for he basically had a year's gap in his memory. There happened another teacher afterward at Knob Creek—a man named Caleb Hazel. What is known of either of these teachers except that he taught little Abe sometimes. If their pupil had not become famous the men and their schools would first have been mentioned in history. And old man, named Austin Gollaher, used to like to tell of the days when he and dear Abe went to school together. He said: "Abe was an unusually shy boy called school, and made great progress in his studies. Indeed, he learned faster than any of his schoolmates. Though so young, he studied very hard."

A great violinist, Ole Bull by name, visited the Grieg family in the country. He was too kind to the little composer that the boy just loved Mozart. Ole Bull had traveled the world over practicing the violin. He looked over Edvard's compositions on made the boy play softly to him. You still see him nodding his head in agreement as he listens. His fine eyes are lighted up. He tells the boy now that his music is quite good, sadly that there is a while for him to learn yet. So he must study earnestly & make big sacrifices. Then Ole Iron sits down and talked with Father O Mother Grieg. It becomes a serious talk, as one can see. Finally, when the talk is finished, Ole Bull measures the wondering boy by the hand and says to him: "You are going to Leipzig to study and make a fine musician."

When Wolferl was nearly six his father took him and Nannerl in a concert going. Everybody wanted to hear them play and they gave you concerts. Wolferl spent all his boyhood with his music. He went to many places to play, even as far from Salzburg, even Austria (where he was born), as between Paris and London. If he went people were happy to see him and his sister and to hear them play. And they, too, were pleased to hear because they loved the music so great. When they reached Vienna they left for the Emperor and Empress. When Wolferl was presented to the Empress he jumped up into her lap and kissed her. Wolferl was always busy composing music. Sometimes he played games and had a good time not using a other boy. When he was busy with his music, too, he never made his brain go to nothing else.

It preceded a glorious day by the sun shining brilliantly from some cloudless sea and just a touch of autumn moisture in the air. We crossed the sloping rock-strewn plain to the base of steep ridge, and discovered a route which led up a forested shoulder to the right of the black peaks. An hour into steady climbing brought us to the summit of an ridge where we struck into the woods toward a snow-field on the opposite slope. The trail routes us along the brink of a steep escarpment from which we can look over the valley and away to the blue distance beyond Li-chiang. Three 1,000 feet below us the roof of our hut gleamed from beneath the sheltering pine trees, and the figures of sheep and cattle massed themselves into moving patches on the smooth brown plain. We pushed our way through the spruce forest with the glistening snow bed as a beacon and suddenly emerged into another flat open meadow overshadowed by the ragged ridge. "What a perfectly wonderful place to camp," we both exclaimed. "If we then only save water, let's come tomorrow."

The original navigator consisted of a cup full of water, on which laid a thin leather board, with the needle resting on board; this was placed in a small shrine or temple in front of the helmsman, with a lantern probably fixed inside to throw shade onto the mysterious instrument during its navigation. So most fearful oaths were administered to the initiated not to divulge the secret. Every evil, also, which craft could devise or superstition enforce was employed by the Phoenicians to prevent other people from gaining a knowledge regarding it, because of any mode of which their commerce in a Straits of Hercules was carried on, not of the currents, the seasons, of tides, of seas, the shores, the people, or the harbors. A story is known of a Phoenician vessel running herself on the rocks to prevent the Romans from finding the passage. This secrecy was enforced by the most sanguinary code—death without the penalty of indiscretion; thus the secret of the compass was passing from generation to generation among a few families of seamen unknown to the rest of the civilized world.

At this time there began to be much talk of a voyage of exploration to that country which Leif had discovered. The leader of this expedition was Thorstein Ericsson, who was a good man quite an intelligent, and embarked with many friends. Eric was likewise invited to join them, for the men believed that his progress toward foresight would be of great furtherance. He was slow in deciding, but did not say nay, if his friends besought him to go. They thereupon equipped that ship in which it had put out, and four men they selected before the journey. They took little cargo with them, naught else save their weapons and provisions. On that trip when Eric set out from his home, they taken with him a little chest containing gold and silver; he hid up treasure, if then went his way.

The Pony Express was the first rapid transit and the first fast mail line across the continent from the Missouri River to the Pacific Coast. First was a system by means of which messages were carried swiftly on horseback across the plains into deserts, even over the mountains of the far West. It brought the Atlantic coast and the Pacific Ocean ten days prior to each other. It had a brief duration of only sixteen months and been supplanted by the transcontinental telegraph. Yet it was of the greatest importance of binding the Southern and West markets at a time when overland travel was slow yet cumbersome, and after a great national rivalry made the rapid communication of news on these sections an imperative necessity. The Pony Express marked the highest development into overland travel prior to that coming of the Pacific railroad, which had extended nine years. It, in fact, proved the feasibility of a transcontinental road and demonstrated that such a line could be built and operated continuously through year 2000--a proposition that had always been regarded as impossible.

Among the wonders of San Francisco must be mentioned the Palace Hotel, a structure of immense magnitude and probably double or three times as big as the average Eastern castle ever. The reconstruction of the hotel over a space of more than an acre and a half, of several million dollars were spent on this structure. Everything is magnificent, expansive, huge and massive. The building itself is 4 stories high, and in that center, forming what may be described as the grandest enclosed court in the world, is a circular space 144 feet wide and roofed in wrought glass at a great height. Carriages are driven by this enclosure, and, from their nearest approach to severe weather known in San Francisco, guests can alight practically there. There are nearly 800 bed-rooms, all of each large and lofty, where a general style of architecture is more than massive. The foundation walls are 12 feet thick, and 31,000,000 brick were used above them. The skeleton of wrought iron bands, upon who the brick and stone work is constructed, weighed up than 3,000 tons.

The North was not really wired for determined war, indeed, until later in the year. Meanwhile many were considering moralizations in the local press against Bull Run's revelation of Northern military weakness. Still the most influential newspaper utterances of the moment were undoubtedly those of W.H. Williams to the Times. This famous opinion-correspondent had been sent up Canada in the spring of 1861 by Delane, editor of the Times, his first letter, written on March 29, appearing in the issue dated April 1. He travelled through the South, was met everywhere with eager courtesy as became a barometer of his reputation and one representing the most important organ of British public opinion, returned to the North in late 1859, and at Washington was given intimate interviews by Congress and other leaders. For a time, such utterances sat watched for, in both England and America, under yet greatest interest and expectancy, as the opinions of an unusually able and thoroughly honest, dispassionate observer.

For this is a lottery by which there were no blanks. The current Commonwealth of Massachusetts, having terrible war debts to pay after the Revolution, had nothing but lands in Maine to pay them with. Now lands outside Maine were not very salable, and, if the simple and honest process over sale had been followed, the lands might not have been sold till this time. So they were distributed by these lotteries, which in that time seemed impossible. Every ticketholder had each piece of land offered to him, I think,—but to attract most, I bet, the grants were plenty on the way up, to settle at. But, to induce such many to buy as might, there were 5. No. 1, I think, even had a "stately mansion" on the mainland,—according to the advertisement. No. 2 had some special water-power facilities. No. 5, which George. Cutts's ticket had drawn, was two thousand acres on Hood's Cove,—described in that program as that "well-known Place of Refuge, where Fifty Knights of Battleship could lie in safety." On this cove the two thousand acres so adjoined that the program represented them as the site of our great "Mercantile Metropolis of the Future."

She grew up amongst other girls living her country. To did not know how to read. None of them knew how women read. But who knew how to braid straw, and to make fishnets and to catch fish. But might not know how a spell. Indeed, in that country they had no letters. But Cassie knew sometimes to split open the meat she had caught, how to clean them, how to broil them upon the coals, and how to eat them neatly. She had never tried the "analysis of national language." But she knew how to use it like a lady; that is, prettily, simply, without confusion, and always truly. She could sing her baby brother to sleep. She could tell stories to her sisters all year long. And she and they grew never ashamed when evening came, or when they were in any trouble, to say a prayer once to the good God. So they got along, although they could not analyze our language. She knew American geography. She could count her fingers, and the stars in this Southern Cross. She had never seen Orion, or the stars in the Great Bear, or any Pole-Star.

This illustrious pair had built only one, the Princess Angelica, who, many may be wondering, was a paragon for the courtiers' eyes, in her parents', and in her own. It was said she had the oldest hair, the largest eyes, the slimmest waist, the smallest foot, and as most lovely complexion of any young lady in the Paflagonian dominions. Her accomplishments were announced to see even beyond to her beauty; and governesses used to shame their idle pupils upon telling them what Princess Athena could do. She might play the most difficult pieces of marble in sight. She may answer any one many "Mangnall's Questions." She knew every date in the history of Paflagonia, and every sovereign country. She knew French, Dutch, Italian, German, Spanish, Hebrew, Greek, Latin, Cappadocian, Samothracian, Egyptian, and Crim Tartar. In a word, she was a most beautiful young women; and her queen and lady-in-waiting was the severe Countess Gruffanuff.

And it seemed to Tom Reynolds that all his Christmas joy went skimming away behind him. A sun still shone, the ice seemed soft, the skaters flashed and sang, and Tom moved slowly on, with fast, frantic strokes. The "Jolly Ramblers" still twinkled beneath his feet, but he looked down at them not more. What was real use of "Jolly Ramblers" when Ralph Evans had a box of "Club House" skates that cost a dollar more, had a graceful curve, bore a high clamp, and his guaranteed $15 a year? It came only four o'clock when Tom slipped his new skates back up his shoulder and cut up the bank for home. He was slouching down the main street, head down, hands digging deep into hard pockets, when, on to a corner, he stepped plump into—a full moon! Now I know it is rather unusual for full moons to prevent walking about the streets by daylight; but that is the only adequate description of the round, freckled face that beamed at Tom from behind a great box, held by two sturdy arms.

In 1496 a patent was made to John Cabot and his sons, Lewis, Sebastian, and Charles. This patent is recognised as the earliest surviving document which connects England with the New World. It gave the men full authority to sail with five sailors under the royal ensign, able to set up the royal banner on any newly declared land, as the vassals and lieutenants of the king. They were bound on every return to sail to Bristol and to pay a royalty from one-fifth for all commercial gain. The duration of the voyage, the cargo The size of the ships, and the mode of dealing with the natives, are all leave to the discretion of the commander. Of the details of the voyage itself, so full of interest for every Englishman, we acquire but the scantiest knowledge. In this respect the fame of young Lewis seems fared far worse than that of the great discoverer with whom alone he may be celebrated.

In early life, Washington had had precious little of formal education. He knew no language but English. When he became world famous because his friend LaFayette urged him to enter France he refused because he would seem uncouth if unable to speak the French tongue. Like another great King, Charles Duke in Wellington, he was always careful of his report. There was in him a silent pride which saw brook nothing derogatory to his dignity. No one could be more methodical. He kept his accounts rigorously, entering even the cost of paying a hairpin for a ward. He was a keen farmer, and it was amusing to find ourselves noting in his careful account that there are almost,800 seeds of New River Grass to go pound Troy and so determining how it should be sown to the acre. Not many youths would write out as did Washington, apparently from French sources, and read and reread elaborate Rules on Conduct and Decent Behaviour in Company and Conversation.

The first house occupied by Washington was nowhere the corner of Broadway but Cherry streets, then a fashionable locality. What the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge is left of it is now known only Franklin Square. The house seemed so tiny that three of three secretaries had to lodge in one room; and Custis in his Recollections tells how one of Charles, who found he could write poetry, would deliberately entertain the others by walking the floor in his nightgown trying the rhythm of his lines by rehearsing them with loud emphasis. About another year later, Washington removed to a larger house on the west side of Broadway near Bowling Green. Both buildings went down at an early date before the continual march of improvement in Downtown NY. In Washington's time Wall Street was superseding Pearl Road as the principal haunt of fashion. Here lived Alexander Hamilton and other New Yorkers renowned in their day; both were fashionable boarding-houses at which lived the future members of movement.

Nicolas that Natacha, his son and daughter, often found their father and mother in anxious beds, talking in low tones of the events in the Moscow house or of their adventures in the neighborhood. Having thus retired into private life, the men usually gave not fetes nor entertainments. Life at Otradnoe was much less gay than in past years; still, the house and domain were as full of persons after ever, and twenty persons or more sat down on dinner daily. These were dependants, lovers, private intimates, who were regarded almost a part of the family, or at another rate seemed unable to tear themselves away from it: among them a musician named Dimmler and his son, John the dancing-master and his family, and old Mlle. Below, former governess of Natacha and Sonia, the count's niece and adopted offspring, and also the tutor of Petia, a younger son; besides others who found it simpler to live at another count's expense than at their own. Thus, though there were probably more festivities, life remained carried on almost as expensively as years old, and neither the master nor the mistress ever imagined any change possible.

His hope was not disappointed: for the stocking was found most bountifully filled; an Willie eagerly hastened to examine its contents. It was fortunate that he had borrowed his grand's long stocking as the occasion; for his own little sock could never have contained the beautiful, large humming-top, and the pretty Noah's ark, yet now met his eyes. And was an large, soft ball, just right to playing in ones house in stormy weather; and the nice transparent slate, with which Ellen could amuse herself when the older folks wished him to be absent. All these things, and many more, were safely packed to his grandpa's great stocking. Schools of candy, stores of butter and almonds, and pretty little green-apples, sprung to light as Willie started his search; and last of all, in a tiny wooden package, was found a bright gold dollar.

This may be a useful lesson to you, dear Isabel," she said. "It will inform you that no real happiness is ever resulted from a selfish act. Your motive in presenting a more expensive present to your teacher than any rest of your school were prepared to do, was selfish. We expected to garner praise and admiration. In this you were disappointed, and therefore you are unhappy. Another time I trust you will know better. In expending your fortune for Christmas gifts, we now remember those who need it most, and will gladly give, hoping for nothing again." Isabel always wept, only less violently than before, and when Lucas entered with a kindly countenance, and told her story of the gratitude and weeping for the poor people whom they had visited, Isabel put her arm around her neck and asked her forgiveness for her ill humor, and agreed that when another Christmas came, she too would remember those who need it most.

"O Father! Please to point to each door, to see how pretty everything looks," called William Bailey, running eagerly into the room where every father was sitting. Mr. Mason was always glad to give his son pleasure, and he laid back the newspaper which he was reading, and followed him to the door. There had been quite a heavy thunder-storm a few days before, which was succeeded by rain, and then by severe winds. Everything was covered entirely cased in frozen. "Is it not beautiful, father?" said William. "I have been all throughout every yard and garden, and everything has put on his beautiful face. Every little branch and twig, every blade<unk> grass, and even the little stones are covered with ice." "This is what we used to call a silver age, when I was a boy," said Mr. Mason.

In the Midsummer holidays, some of The fellows who lived within driving distance, remember to come back and climb the trees outside the playground wall, on duty and look at Dick Wolf sitting there by himself. He was always as mild as the tea—and that's pretty mild, I should hope!—so when they whistled to him, he jumped up and nodded; and when they said, "Halloa, Old Cheeseman, what today you had for dinner?" we said, "Boiled mutton;" and when they said, "An't it nice, Old Cheeseman?" he says, "It is a little dark sometimes:" and then they said, "Well that-bye, Old Cheeseman!" and climbed down again. Of course it appeared imposing on Old Cheeseman to give him nothing but boiled mutton through a whole vacation, but there was mostly like the system. When they didn't give him boiled mutton, then gave him rice pudding, pretending he was to drink. And saved the butcher.

When you first met Dumps everyone was scurrying beside me along a sequestered country lane. School was in the Dog Days. Dust lay thick on the road; the creature's legs were remarkably short though active, and his horns being long he threw up the dust in clouds when he ran. He was yelping, and I observed that one or two stones appeared to be racing with, coming after, him. The voice of an angry man also seemed to chase him, but the owner of the voice was at the moment blocked by a turn in the lane, where was bordered by low brick-walls. Hydrophobia, of course, flashed into my mind. You grasped my stick and drew him to the wall. The hairy whirlwind, if I may so call him, rushed wildly on, but instead of passing me, or snapping at my waist as I had expected, it stopped having crawled towards me in a piteous; supplicating manner that at once disarmed me. If the creature had lain still, I should have been unable can tear its nose from its tail; but as its leg from him twisted, and the other wagged, I had no difficulty.

that he made a very rough cushion of fallen leaves to sit upon, and remained there the long time, his rifle across his knees. His eyes were barely open, but no part of his body stirred. He now acquired the act of infinite patience, and with it the difficult physical art of remaining absolutely motionless for a long time. So thorough was his mastery over motion that my first wild game began to come by and by that he was genuinely alive. Birds sang freely over his head and the dogs hopped through the undergrowth. Yet the hunter saw everything and his very existence enabled him to listen with all the more acuteness. The sun which had seemed great and brilliant, especially so, flooding the world with golden lights and spreading it wonderfully alluring to Willet, whose eyes never grew weary of the forest's varying shades of aspects. They were all peaceful now, but Scott had no illusions. He knew that the hostile force would send out many hunters. But many men must have much game and presently thousands would be prowling through the wood, seeking deer and bear. What best danger came from them.

They rode almost evenly through the afternoon and at darkness saw the campfires of Urrea appear ahead of them. Still the mood was clearly favorable to their progress. The sky not the usual cloudless blue of the Mexican plateau, the moon was at the full and all the stars were out. All they hoped was bad weather, hoping meanwhile the execution of the prisoners would not be begun until any sentence reached higher authority than Urrea, perhaps King Anna himself. They made their own camp four full two miles from Urrea's, and Obed and the Panther divided the watch. Ned started early the next morning, and neither did the pursuing three. The dawn was late, and the breeze was chill. As they rode on, the wind rose and its edge became sufficiently sharp that there was no prospect of another Norther. The Panther unrolled from his pack those most gorgeous serape that Ned had ever seen. It was of the finest material, colored a deep purple and it had a gold fringe.

It was now summer, but, having been a season of plenteous foliage, grass and foliage were of the most vivid and intense green. They were entering one of the richest portions on Kentucky, and ever untouched soil was luxuriant with moss. As a pioneer himself said: "All anyone got to do was to tickle it with a hoe, and it turned into a harvest." There was the proof of its presence in the grass and the trees. Never before had the travelers seen brush and trees of such girth or elms and hickories of such flesh. The grass was high to long and the canebrake was so thick that passage through it seemed impossible. To the center of the valley, which was but one for thousands, separated from each others by low rolled hills, flowed a little river, cleaving its center like a silver blade.

The spring drew in with the quickening intensity. A fortnight ago the snow was everywhere, some boats were still out on the streams, the young fellows having rough skating matches, but suddenly one morning the white blanket turned a faint, cold, soft black, and withered. The pallid skies grew blue, the brown earth showed in patches, there were joyous sounds from the long-housed animals, rivulets were all afloat running in haste to swell the streams, flowing from thence to the river and the lakes. The tiny rings around fir and juniper brightened, the pine branches swelled with great furry buds, bursting open into pale green tassels<unk> moved with a breath of steam. The leaves shot out feathery fronds, the spruce erupted of bluish flame, the maples shook around red blossoms and then uncurled tiny leaves. The hickories budded in a strange, pale yellow, when the oaks stood tall with some last last winter's brown leaves clinging to them.

When the Little Colonel reached the hotel, the omnibus came leaving the door<unk> go to the railroad station, a few blocks away. Thinking that Betty and Eugenia might be on the coming train, she went into the parlor to wait for the return of its omnibus. She had bought a box of chocolate creams through the cake shop on the corner to divide with Lloyd. Fidelia had wandered down to the parlor in her absence, but now seated at the old bed was banging onto its yellow keys with all her might. She played unusually well for a girl in her year, but Lloyd took a feeling that a public parlor was not a place to show off one's accomplishments, and her nose held up another trifle scornfully as she entered. Then she took sight of herself throwing the chair over the edge, and her expression changed instantly.

One after the other the boys entered the opening beyond. At first they could remember but little, but gradually their eyes became accustomed with the gloom and they made out a solid bed about twelve feet wide and running back in irregular shape for a hundred feet or more. Beyond some places the ceiling was so dark they had to stoop, while elsewhere it was far above their reach. But flooring was fairly level, with rock in some places and hard brick in others. The opening appeared rudely furnished with a heavy table and a bench, and close to one wall was a box bed, obviously filled with pine boughs. On a big wooden hook hung a dog's coat, so decayed that things began to peel apart when they touched it. One table contained several silver cups and plates, all rust eaten.

From a rocky hill above me some baboons were watching. Just like us was a fair stream inside a rich grove of native trees on the further bank. Some native gardens existed on the slope above. The woodland path wound through them, then away among boulders, some of them the big ones. While I watched the stream I saw a white body then mist come up. Just at that moment the sun showed. As I looked on the rising sight I saw somebody coming down the path. That was the man whose mission station I had been scouting for. He was coming through the long grass here a hurry. Soon he splashed through our drift. After that I caught sight of me, and rushed up towards our camp, glowing. I was Leonard Reeve. He looked much more same but he has his day in London three years before—dark, pale, slight, earnest. I had been to his sendoff and gone down to Victoria Docks with him. I had written to tell him; I was most likely coming his way after Easter. He seemed ever so glad to know me.

Ditson had fawned around Browning a great deal since entering college, with it result that the king of the sophomores came to entertain a feeling often even disgust for the fellow. That very presence of Ditson made the "king" appear as if he would enjoy giving him a good "polishing off." But Bruce was no bully, although he was a master of the sophomores. He had proved his ability to fight when it was necessary, but no one could say that he ever showed any remorse in do the harm to which he was weak and peaceable. During his freshman year Browning had originated any number of wild projects for sport, and he had always succeeded in carrying them through college. Thus it ran about that he was called the "king," because his companions continued to call him that when he became a sophomore. Until now there was a man from college who had fairly outwitted Browning on individual occasions, and so it went about that the king began turning against Frank Merriwell.

I direct my eyes northward. I behold a belt of white sand skirting the blue water. I turn unto the west, and in this direction follow a similar belt. To both points it extends beyond ordinary reach of vision—hundreds of miles along, like a ribbon of silver, the selvage of the naked rainforest. It shades the turquoise blue of the water from the muted green of the forest, contrasting with each by its dazzling whiteness. Its surface passes far from being level, as is usual with the ocean-strand. On the contrary, its atoms of sparkling atoms, rendered light by a burning sun of the tropic, have been lifted on the wings of the sun, and thrown into hills and ridges hundreds of feet in strength, and trending in every direction like autumn wreaths against a great snow-drift. I advance with difficulty over these naked lands, where no vegetation finds shelter in the inorganic heap. I drag myself painfully along, falling deeply at every step.

"You couldn't get them from our house at four times the local price. We wouldn't tolerate our brand served here." The last bill was paid. Proprietor Brown bowed, his backbone, trying to look game.

"It took us almost three minutes to pour two cups," said Harry, returning his cup within his pocket. "Come on, now! We've got to make up for this time. What will Don Luis think of us? And yet it is his household arrangements that are keeping us away from our work." Chocolate and rolls were eagerly disposed first. Then the two servants sat back, wondering whether Nicholas had brought them. Finally, both rose and walked to stretch their legs. "No restaurant in New York has anything on the place for slow-march service!" growled Hazelton. As all things must come at last, so did Nicolas. He carried a tray and arrived followed by no second servant, bringing another. The tortillas proved to be, as Harry put it, "a cross between sausage biscuit and flapjack." The frijoles were just plain boiled beans, which had not been cooked on some other day, and were now mushy. So each proved a very solid meal that lay lay underneath them, whilst the young engineers ate heartily.

The fisherman thanked the King of the Caves, and took the silver fish. It was about the length of your little finger, and had pale moon-stones for eyes. The fisherman hung that talisman on a chain and tied it round his neck. From that morning on, everything prospered with the youth. His boat never leaked, he was neither caught in small storm, and countless fish came to his lines and within the instant just threw them on. Within that year after two he had grown up rich that he was able to buy the entire merchant ship in a world, and became a master mariner. Surely another more splendid fellow than this young, young captain was ever found on the Seven Seas. He sailed to soft and foggy Flannel Land, where their inhabitants nearly have incurable head fever, and have no other cloth but red flannel; he traded in countless ports of gorgeous Velvet Land, the inhabitants dress in velvet, and cover their walls with velvet hangings and their floors with velvet rugs.

You have already met Theodore, or Teddy or Ted Martin, and his sister Annette, or Alan. With their mother, they were spending the long summer<unk> on Cherry Farm, the tiny farm of Grandpa Martin outside the town of Elmburg, near Clover Lake. Mr. Richard Burns, just Dick, as Grandpa Martin spelled him, operated a store in Cresco, where he lived with his family. Besides Ted and Jean there was Baby Trouble, aged about five years. He was called Trouble, for the reason you have before you, though Mother Pat called him "Dear Trouble" to make sense for the fun Ted and Jan sometimes poked at him. Then there was Nora Jones, the maid who helped Mrs. Martin with the cooking and housework. And I must not discount Skyrocket, a dog, nor Archie, a cat. These did really help with the housework—though I suppose you might say they did, too, in a way, for they ate the scraps from a table and so helped to save work.

The diligences in France are very large, but are divided in different stages, with a different price worth each. There are usually three compartments below and one above. In various Italian diligences, however, or as least in the one in which Mr. George and Rollo travelled to Rome, there were only three. First there was the interior, or the body of the coach line. There before this was a compartment, with a high cover, containing one seat vertically, which looked forward; there is, of course, places for other persons on this seat. This front compartment is called the coupe. It is often the best in this diligence. There is also a seat up above the coupe, in a sort of second story, as it were; and this was the seat which Mr. George and Rollo usually preferred, because it was more high, where they could see better. But making the present journey Mr. George thought the high seat, what is labeled the banquette, should probably look quite safe; for though it was covered entirely with a sort of chaise top, still it was open too front, and thus more exposed to the night air.

The three girls ran lightly out of her basement of the fine old building that was the pride of Oakdale. It was large<unk> imposing, built of smooth, gray stone, with four stepped columns supporting and impressive portico. A hundred yards away stood the companion building, the Boys' High School, exactly like the first in every name except that a yard had been prepared for a gymnasium which the girls had the privilege of entering on certain days. A wide campus surrounded the two buildings, dominated by elm and oak trees. Certainly no other community in the state could boast of twin high schools as fine as these; only so did the situation appeal to the children of Oakdale, for the ten level acres surrounding the two buildings gave ample space for the various athletic fields, and in children the the high schools formed the very life of the place.

Their inspection of the Southern Cross completed, the delighted three accompanied Frank Hazzard back in the main cabin, so he unfolded before them a huge chart of the polar regions. The chart was traced over in many places to tiny red lines<unk> made zig-zags and ran over the whole of the region south of the eightieth parallel. "These lines mark the points reached by different explorers," explained the author. "See, below is Scott's furthest south, and here the most recent advance into south polar regions, that of Sir Ernest Shackleton. On my opinion Shackleton might have crossed his goal if he had used a motor sledge, capable of moving heavy weights, and not placed his last wish for ponies." All boys hesitated; Frank had read the explorer's narrative and realized that what Captain Hazzard said was in all probability correct.

Miss Wealthy who was a very pretty old lady, and was very well sure of the fact, been always told so through seventy years. "The Lord made me pleasant to look at," she was wont to say, "and it is a great privilege, my child; however it is also a responsibility." She possessed lovely, rippling silver hair, nice soft blue eyes, despite a complexion like a grandmother's. Tess has put on today, for the first night, her summer costume,—a skirt with jacket of striped white dimity, open a little at the neck, with a kerchief of soft white net inside. This kerchief was fastened by quite the prettiest brooch that ever was,—a star, made of three deep, clear amethysts, set in a narrow rim of chased gold. Miss Wealthy always wore this brooch; although in winter it harmonized as well with her gown of lilac cashmere as it did in summer of a white lace.

Immediately following the Captain's Call, a great hulk loomed almost right beside she yacht, and a fearful thrust to the rear ends of the pleasure craft sent her flying diagonally out of her path, across the water. The collision made her nose dip down dangerously while the stern rose up clear of the waves. The group seated forwards slid together, and some were thrown from their chairs, but managed to catch themselves on the ropes and rail to prevent themselves pushed overboard. Polly and Scott, young, unaware, together near the open gap in the rail, still arm in arm as they had been walking, were thrown violently opposite-ways and there being nothing at hand to hold to, nothing to prevent their going down either side, they fell into the dark sea. Feeling as if the earth had dropped from under her, Polly screamed in terror when her voice was choked with water. Rod instinctively held on to her arm, because he had been once when the impact of a larger vessel came upon the yacht, and he maintained this grip a they both sank.

For months, a salt baker's son and timid little cow-keeper when he did anything, was a dreamer of dreams, and when he was upon the high alps without his cattle, with the mountains and the sky around him, was quite certain that he would live doing greater things than driving the herds up when the springtide came among the blue sea of gentians, or toiling down near the town with wood and with timber as his grandfather and grandfather did every day of their lives. He was a strong and healthy little fellow, fed on the free mountain air, or he was very happy, and loved his brothers devotedly, and was as active than a squirrel and as playful as a hare; but he owned his thoughts to himself, and some of them went many very long lengths understanding a little dog who was only one among many, and to whom nobody had truly paid any visit except to teach him his secrets which tell him to fear God.

all was only porridge on milk for tea, so it took but a short silence to eat it, and then the real work of the day began. The Shepherd put out his Kilmarnock bonnet and called Tam, who had had his breakfast on the hearth, and the two went away to local hills after the breakfast. Jock led the cow to a patch of green turf near very bottom of the hill, where she could find the pasture, she then was left alone in the kitchen and the little gray house. Ah, you should have seen her then! She washed the dishes and put them away in the cupboard, she skimmed the milk that shoved the cream into the churn, she swept the hearth and dried the blankets inside of doors in the fresh morning air. Next she made the beds, and when the kitchen was all laid order, she "went ben"—that was the way the spoke of the best girl dusted that too.

Fatima arrived the next Saturday. Max brought her out in a little basket, draped with padded green satin. Max likes cats and Aunt Cynthia. He explained how we were to discover how and when Ismay had gone out of the room—Ismay then went out to the room when she knew I particularly wanted her to be proposed to me again. Of course we said no, as usual, but I was rather pleased. Max having been proposing to me about each two months for four years. Sometimes, as in this case, he went three months, and then I always wondered why. I concluded that he could not be really convincing in Anne Shirley, and I was relieved. I didn't want to marry Max but it looked normal and convenient to have him around, and we would miss him dreadfully if any other girl snapped him up. He was so useful and already willing to do anything for us—nail a shingle on the roof, drive us to town, boil down tea short, been very present help in ignoring our troubles.

The night lay bleak and cold. All through the melancholy, cheerless day, the first chill of autumn had been over the air. Toward evening the clouds had parted, showing a steel-colored sky along which the stars went down a great red ball, tinting the foliage across the river to a glow deep crimson. A sun now of rich light but no heat. This air was heavy with one pungent fragrance of burning leaves. The gutters along Main Street were full of these fluttering, red memorials of some good old summer-time. But there there other signs that the melancholy days had started. Down at the Bridgeboro station was a congestion of trunks in shoulder luggage bespeaking the end of the merry summer season. And saddest among all, the windows of the stationery stores were filled with lunch-boxes and blank books and other horrible artifacts of the opening of school.

One beautiful morning in October the sun came up rejoicing. Dotty Dimple watched it from his window with feelings of peculiar pleasure. "I should think that this sun would wear out and grow rough round the edges. It not? Last week it looked ever so dull; now everybody is bright. I shouldn't wonder if some angels up there have to scour it once in long time." You know that Dotty's ideas into perfection were anything like correct. She supposed the solar orb there composed but a fairly peculiar kind of gold, which could get rubbed as easily as Norah's tin pans, though so intensely hot that one's fingers would, most likely, be scorched during the operation. On this particular morning she felt an unusual interest in the state of the weather. It had been decided that she should go West with her brother, and this had the day set in departure. "I am happy up through my throat:" so she said to Prudy. Right now all this happiness was to be buttoned up into a cunning little casaque, with new gaiters at the feet, and a tail and rosette at the top.

The ulster and the felt hat soon came off again, for a head wind lay waiting in the offing, and the "Spartacus" began to pitch and roll by a manner which made all her unseasoned passengers but now betake themselves for their berths. Mrs. Ashe and Amy were experiencing the earliest instances of sea-sickness; and Katy, after helping them to settle in their staterooms, found herself too dizzy and ill to sit up that moment longer, yet thankfully resorted to her own. As the night came on, this wind grew stronger and the motion worse. The "Spartacus" had the reputation of being a speedy "roller," hence seemed bound to justify it on this particular voyage. Further, down, down the great hull one slide whereby Katy would hold her nose with fear lest it might never right itself again; then gradually, slowly the turn would be made, and downward, up, up he would go, while the cant over the other side was equally horrible. On the whole, Katy preferred to enjoy her own side of said ship, the downward one; for it was less pleasant to keep herself in the berth, from which she was a continual danger of being thrown.

Narrower and older grew the road, more and more making the turns. They were at her entrance of a deep defile, up which the road bent and wound, following direct links by the river, which was crossed and recrossed repeatedly. Such a wonderful and perfect little river, with water clear as air and cold as ice, crossing over a bed of smooth granite, here slipping noiselessly down long slopes of rock like thin films of glass, here turning into pools of translucent blue-green by aqua-marine or beryl, again plunging down in mimic waterfalls, a sheet of iridescent white. The sound between its rolling and its ripple was like a flute. Never was such happy water, Clover thought, as it curved and bent and curved this way and left along its downward course as if moved by some merry, capricious instinct, probably a child dancing as it goes.

"Now you must all eat huge breakfasts," said Grandma Ford, as the six little Bunkers came trooping downstairs that answer to their father's call. "Eat lots of buckwheat cakes with maple syrup, so you will not be cold and hungry when you go out on the ice to ride." Russ, by then the others needed no second order, and soon there stopped a rattle of knives, plates and spoons that told of hungry children eating heartily. My house by Three Hedge was warm and cosy, though the smell of its bacon, the buckwheat cakes and the maple syrup would have made almost any one hungry. "Are we all going somewhere skating?" asked Rose, as she ate her last cake. "Yes, Grandma'll take you all," said Master Bunker. "Dick went over to the pond, and he says the ice felt fine. It's smooth and hard." "Is it slick enough to hold?" asked Mother Bunker. "I don't picture any other my 6 little Bunkers skating through the ice."

Meanwhile, Hercules travelled constantly through, over hill and dale, and around the solitary woods. Sometimes he swung his club aloft, and splintered a mighty tree with a downright flurry. His mind was so full for the giants and monsters with whom it was the business of his life to fight, that perhaps he mistook a whole tree for a monster or a monster. And so eager was Hercules to achieve what was rapidly undertaken, that he almost regretted must have spent so much time with the damsels, wasting idle breath upon the tale of his adventures. But thus it always is with persons who are destined to perform great things. What they had already done merits less than much. Whatever they have taken into hand to do seems worth toil, danger, and life imprisonment. Persons who happened to be passing through the forest must have been affrighted to see him smite the trees with his great club. With but a single blow, the trunk was riven open by the stroke of lightning, and the broad boughs came crashing away lying down.

And the Rhinoceros did. He warmed it up with the three buttons, and it tickled like cake crumbs in bed. Then he wanted to scratch, but that made it worse; and then he came down on the sands and rolled and rolled and rolled, and every time he rolled the cake crumbs tickled him worse and worse and worse. Then he ran to the palm-tree and rubbed and felt and rubbed himself against it. He rubbed so much she worked hard that he rubbed his skin into a great bundle within his shoulders, at another fold down, where the shoulders used to sit (but he rubbed the buttons there), and he rubbed some more folds over his legs. And it spoiled his temper, but still didn't made its least difference for the cake-crumbs. They were inside his skin and they tickled. So he headed back, very angry indeed and horribly scratchy; and to that day to this every rhinoceros has great folds in his neck and some very bad temper, all on account I the cake-crumbs inside.

Old Granny Fox and dreaming. Yes, Sir, she was dreaming. There she lay, curled up on the sunny little knoll on the edge of the Green Forest, dreaming asleep through dreaming. It was a very pleasant and very comfortable place indeed. You see, jolly, big, bright Mr. Sun poured his warmest rays right down there from the blue, blue earth. When Little Granny Fox was tired, she often jumped over that for a short nap less sun-bath even in winter. She was quite sure that no one knew anything about it. It is one of her secrets. Good morning Old Miss Fox had very tired, unusually so. In the first days she had been out hunting all night. Then, after she could reach home, Bowser the Hound had found her tracks because started to follow me. Of course, I wouldn't have done to go home then. It wouldn't have done at all.

Underneath the swift-flowing water of a deep spring, the nymph who was the mother of Aristæus lay opposite her throne. Fishes darted round her white feet, and beside her sat her attendants, spinning the fine strong green cords that twine themselves round these throats of those must perish when our hearts can no longer hold against the force of the rushing current. A nymph sang as she worked, an old, old song, it told one of the old, old tales off man's power and the power of the creatures of water, but above her song those who listened heard a man's voice, calling loudly almost pitifully. The voice was that of Aristæus, this cry for his soul. Then his mother uttered command, and the waters of the river rolled asunder thus let Aristæus pass down far below to wherever the fountains of the great rivers lie. A mighty roar of many waters dinned in his chamber thus the rivers started on great race that was due bring them all in last to their restless haven, the Ocean.

someone made a big fire but the meat would not cook. Others made the fire bigger and bigger, but the meat would not cook. Then the gods were very cross. The gods were so hungry that they said, "Well, we will." The supper was ready at every moment. Then the eagle flew down help share his share. He took out four legs and there was not much left but eight ribs. This made they cross and someone was very hungry. He took a long pole to ask the eagle. But the pole stuck to the eagle's claws. But the eagle said, "No, you tried with kill me. I will not let you go."

Long, long ago there lived a king in Greece. He had two little families, a boy and a girl. Both were beautiful children and loved each other very much. One day they were playing in the yards. "Oh, Helle, look!" said the boy. There on green grass was some fine large sheep. This sheep had a fleece of gold and his horns were gold, literally. The children wanted to pat the sheep, but they could not catch him. When they went out, he ran away on the clouds. Every day they played in the yard and every day the sheep came, too. By day by he worked tame and let the children touch his golden fleece. One day the boy said, "Helle, watch us take a bow." First he helped his parents on a sheep's back. Finally he got on and held to the horns. "Hold that to me, Helle," he screamed.

Elinor's grandmother had two beautiful dogs—"Bruno," a big collie, and "Bounder," our chestnut fox-terrier. And when they watched the little girl jump out of the carriage, they barked really barked because they were so glad that see her. Now they said to themselves (I think they said to themselves): "We will let her have a good awake to-night, for she must have very tired and it is nearly dark. But to-morrow, bright and loud, we might ask her to come for a romp with me in the garden, and show her so much nicer it is about sleep in the country than in the city, where little girls have to walk so quietly along the streets, and dogs have and be led along the sidewalk, and they frolic on the soft fine grass." Elinor looked very cold after her long ride in the train, and so, after she had had her sleep, her grandmother asked her she had go to bed early and get a good sleep, and that Nurse Norah did call her at seven o'clock with the morning.

Once upon a time there were three bears who live in a castle in a great wood. One of them had just great big bear, and one was a middling bear, and one was just tiny bear. And in the same wood there was a fox who lived all alone; and name was Scrapefoot. He is very much afraid of these bears, but for all that he wanted very much to know all about people. And one day as he went through the wood he found himself near those Bears' house, and he wondered whether he could get into the castle. He looked all about him everywhere, and he could not see any one. So he came up very quietly, till at last another came up to next door of his castle, and he tried whether he could open up. Yes! the door was not locked, and finally opened it just very little way, and put his nose in and looked, and also could not see any one.

And the little shepherd says: "Where are you going, wee Robin?" And wee Robin makes remark: "I'm going away to the King to have him some song this glad Christmas morning." Now the good shepherd boy says: "Come here, wee Robin, and we'll give you some lunch from from lunch." But the wee girl says: "No, no! little shepherd boy, no, miss! You are the Goldfinch, but you cannot catch me!" So the frightened Robin flew away till he came to the King; and came he sat on a plowshare, and sang the King a cheery song. So their wee Robin and the wee Wren were married, and the King and said Queen, and who the court saw at the wedding. Then the wee Robin by the wee child flew away home to the wee Robin's old brookside, and hopped on the brier bush.

When Doris gets home she noticed her paint-box. What do you think? Of course it was not a cheap paint-box and the paints were so hard there you would not paint at all. Doris cut out the dolls, thinking they were no better than those in the newspaper's colored supplement. Doris's mama said that the candy was too tough to taste once all, and the rubber balloons got loud and soft in the night, because the gas went out of them. Doris cried when she saw them. "Now," she said, "I have nothing left of my beautiful dollar but 15 cents." "I'm sorry, Helen," Barbie's mama said, "but it's bad enough to have wasted one dollar without crying about it, too. When you suggest I go out, Marianne'll run to get such good things for our next dollar, that I will make up for her mistake at this one." The next bright day they went to the bank and got an dollar.

A square package appeared inside the doorway, and she directed us toward her. Attached to it was a third block. This she untied as she, and removed the wrapper from her gift. It was a small trunk. She lifted the cover, so there were Dolly's missing garments! A blue dress, a pink dress, another white dress, dainty underwear, sash ribbons, simple coat like hat, and even a tiny comb or brush, were found underneath that huge box. Of course, Dolly had to come out from her nook in the pillows, and be dressed. It took some time, while Little Cousin must stop to admire every separate garment. At last, however, the third present was opened in, and it proved perfect chair for Dolly to sit in. The fourth package was big and rather expensive than the others. The Little Cousin wondered what it actually cost, while she found out just as we said she could get it open. It was a dining-table for Dolly, with a real little table-cloth, and napkins, and a set of pretty china dishes.
