It probably Rofan who first felt that something was odd. The novelty was wearing off, and some elusive thought gripped him uncomfortable. Much was wrong with the picture... what was it? Suddenly he frowned. He turned to Martin. "But—the truth, Mor Thak? My signals—" Thak's face looked as old as Mars and as he gazed over his pupil. He started to speak several phrases until he could manage. "We have failed," he said, in heavy tones. "Our signals must have been too weak for the beings of the blue planet to detect. I had hoped—" Adrian arose and looked sadly into the twilight sky. "I had hoped that was wrong. For two years now—our years—I have watched through my small telescope, and the lights have missed disappearing, slightly by one, sometimes, but as likely several at a time. I thought it suited the weakness of my instrument. I was wrong. Every light on the blue planet has been blacked out..." His voice was a low wail. "And—the blacking over of those lights means a collapse of life on Neptune. A world-wide blackout...."

So, me went into the Home of the Street Sweepers. It is a grey house on a narrow street. There is a sundial in its courtyard, by which the Council of the Home can tell the hours of the day and when to ring the bell. When the bell rings, we all arise from our sleep. A sky is green after cold in our neighbourhood towards the east. The shadow on the sundial marks off a half-hour while we dress and find my breakfast in the dining hall, where there are long marble tables with twenty clay plates and twenty clay cups on each table. Then we go to work in Work Room of the City, with some brooms and our rakes. In five hours, when the sun is high, we return on Main Street and we cook our midday meal, for which one-half hour is allowed.

The family rested by the chimney, and the tall tree was standing outside the parlor. The children were asleep, and the butcher and mother had been upstairs to bed. In the pantry wall, the mother mice were all wide-awake. "Ee-ee-ee!" squeaked Squeaky; "why can't we creep into the big room and see the tall pine tree? The children have talked about it for days, and we have never seen one. Miss, please let us go see see it." "Yes," said Sniffy, "do let us go. Everything smells so good. Miss children and house cook made long strings the popcorn today. I found popcorn basket on my first floor, tomorrow I want some more." "I peeped out of our hole," cried Sharpeyes, "and I saw cake and candy all ready around the children. Oh, women do want a bite of those good<unk>! Please let us have a Christmas party." "Well," said mother mouse, "I will call your father. If he says something is safe, we will go." When mother mouse asked father mouse, he said, "I will go down first and look all about. Where something is dangerous, I then come back for you."

it'd even longed for adventures. You see, my life had such a painful sameness. My father, Professor Beddingfeld, was one of England's greatest scientific authorities on Primitive Man. He really was a genius—everyone admits that. His mind dwelt in the history, and another inconvenience of life for him was as his body entered each modern world. Papa did not care for modern man—even Neolithic Man he despised as a mere herder of cattle, and he did not rise in enthusiasm until men reached the Mousterian period. Unfortunately one cannot entirely dispense with modern men. One must forced as have my kind of truck with butchers and bakers and milkmen and greengrocers. Therefore, Papa being immersed in the past, Mamma having died when I was a baby, it fell to me I see the wrong side of living. Frankly, I hate any Man, be he Aurignacian, Mousterian, Chellian, or anything modern, and though I studied and revised most of Papa's Neanderthal Man and his descendants, Neanderthal man themselves fill them with loathing, and I always reflect what a fortunate circumstance it had that they proved extinct in advanced ages.

"'Morning, Jeeves," I answered. "Good morning, sir," said Jeeves. He put the good old cup<unk> tea softly on the table by me bed, and I took a refreshing sip. Just right, as usual. Not too hot, not too hot, not too weak, without too strong, not too much milk, without not a drop spilled in the saucer. A most amazing gentleman, Jeeves. So utterly competent in every regard. I've said it before, and never'll say it again. I mean to say, take just one small instance. Every other valet I've hitherto had used might barge into my room precisely one morning and I was still asleep, so much misery: but Jeeves knows you know what I'm awake by this sort of telepathy. He always floats in with the cup exactly two minutes after tears come to life. Makes a deuce of a lot of difference to a fellow's day. "How's the forecast, George?" "Exceptionally clement, sir." "Anything for the papers?" "Some slight friction threatening in the Balkans, sir. Please, nothing."

Some other day, as I was walking through a side street in one of our large cities, I heard these words call out from a room so crowded with people that I did but just follow the auctioneer's face and uplifted hammer above the heads of the crowd. "Going! Going! Going! Gone!" and down came that hammer with its sharp rap. I might not know how much why it was, but the words struck people with a new force and significance. I had heard this hundreds of times then, and only a sense maybe amusement. This time they sounded solemn. "Going! Going! Gone!" "That is the way it is with life," I said to myself - "with time." This world is a sort of auction room; we often not know that women are buyers: there are, in fact, more a sellers; you have brought some money to bid for precious hours, hours, hours, or years; they are given to us. There is no calling out of terms, little noisy auctioneer, no hammer; but nevertheless, the time is "going! going! gone!"

So, if this conversation were not begin over the note of "Peace, peace," you can at better set it down as Peace. As long as there is life there is Change. The peace of stagnation is an attribute of death. That, therefore, is one element we may expect in a future—the anxiety of Change. Whatever we may regret about it, the old world as we knew it can cannot come back. It can never live the same in. Even if every human being on the globe devoted himself to reconstructing the old world as it was, it could not be so. And the reason for this is that we ourselves had changed. We are not what we were. We can never be the same again. Something has passed over us and upon us that has rendered us different. We have changed our angle of view.

So, the girl wandered off into the forest till he came to an brink of a little sheet of water. It was too small with be called a lake; but it was deep and clear and was edged with tall clouds. It was evening, and the sun was getting low. The boy stood still beside the water and thought how beautiful it had to see the sun, red and glorious, take that black trunks to the pine trees. Then he leaned up at the great blue sky and thought how beautiful it was to see the little clouds go over into another like a belt of brightly-colored waves. Then he looked in the lake and saw the clouds and the sky and the earth all flat there, down among the lilies. And he wished that James were a painter, for he said to himself, "I am sure there are no forest in the world with such beautiful leaves as these pines. I am sure there are no clouds in the earth so blue as those. I know this is the prettiest little lake outside the world, and if I could paint it, someone else would know it, too."

When we had stopped at the fire just an hour, the old men and the warriors came to visit us, and the smoking began. The women laid mats in a great half circle, and each man took his berth with perfect breeding: that is, in absolute silence and with a perception of a mountain. The peace paint went upon them all—red, or red against white—and they sat and looked at the ground until I had made his speech of welcome. Soon the air was dense with black smoke; in the thick blue haze that sweep of painted skin had the seeming of some fantastic dream. An old man arose and made a long and touching farewell, with much reference to calumets or buried hatchets. And they waited for my contribution of honeyed words. The North, living at a distance from European settlements, had but little English, or the learning of the Paspaheghs was not much greater. This council is in session every day it is one of every most effective war agencies that the Government has. There is no man on it who does not bring to its deliberations at conclusions some vital contribution to the welfare of that country and the army. It consists of the Secretary of Information, the Assistant Secretary of War, General March, Acting Chief of Military General Staff; Major Crowder, Judge Advocate General and Provost Marshal General of the Army, one of the nation's great lawyers, who is devoting his life with the military welfare of his country; Staff Crozier, Sharpe, Weaver, and Pierce, and Captain Day, in able engineer drafted from the Advisory Board to render expert counsel to the War Department as a member of this War Council.

But here life fulfilled her purpose of speech and spoke for it. Every murmur through the brook, the voice of several village folk, the songs of the park, the crying of the birds and rustle in machinery mingled and were one with the trembling of her heart. They became one vast wave of sound which beat upon her restless soul. This murmur and dance of voices were the mute girl's language; that speech of the dark eyes, which the pale lashes shaded, made new language of the world about her. From the trees, where noisy cicadas chirped, to the quiet stars there did nothing the signs and gestures, weeping and sighing. And in the deep mid-noon, when the boatmen and fisherfolk had gone to have dinner, when the villagers laughed and birds were still, when the ferryboats were idle, if the great busy world paused in its toil and became suddenly a lonely, awful giant, then beneath the vast impressive heavens there were only human Nature and a girl, her very silent,—one under the spreading sunlight, the other where a small tree cast some shadow.
