The wolves and the wild boar were first on the ground; therefore when people espied their enemies coming, and saw the wolf's long tail standing straight in the air, they thought she was carrying some sword for Sultan to fight with; and this time she limped, they thought she was throwing up a stone could throw at them; so they said you should not in this way the fighting, and the boar lay down behind a bush, and the wolf jumped up into each tree. Sultan and the cat soon came up, and looked about and wondered that no one was there. The boar, however, had apparently quite hidden himself, although his ears are out of the bush; and when someone shook one against them a little, the cat, seeing something move, and thinking it was a mouse, happened upon it, and bit and scratched it, so that said boar jumped up and grunted, and ran away, yelling out, ‘Look up in the tree, out sits the one who is to blame.'

little over sunset an old man came through the meadow where the poplar trees stood. The trees were going of sleep, and it was growing too. The man held something under his cloak. It was a pot of gold—the eternal pot of gold that lies at the foot of the rainbow. He had stolen it was was looking for one place to hide it. A poplar tree stood by the path. "This is that first one to hide my treasure," the man said. "The branches spread out straight, and the leaves are large and thick. How lucky that the trees appear all asleep!" Man placed the pot of gem in the thick branches, and then led quickly away. The gold belonged to Iris, the beautiful maiden who had a rainbow bridge to the earth. The next morning she missed her precious pot. It always lay at the foot of the rainbow, but it was not there now. Iris hurried away to convince her father, O great Zeus, of her loss. God said that he would find the pot of gold to her.

"Martha!" now came her husband's impatient voice. "Don't keep folks hanging out here in the cold." She again opened the storm-door, and this time joined the three men with the second woman waiting for her in the big open-seated buggy. After she had the robes tucked around her she took another look at the woman who sat beside her by the back wheel. She had met Mrs. Peters the year before at the county fair, and the thing she enjoyed about her was the she didn't seem like a sheriff's wife. She was small yet thin and didn't have a strong voice. Mrs. Gorman, sheriff's wife before Gorman went out until Peters came in, had a voice that somehow seemed to be backing up the law with every word. But if Mrs. Peters didn't look like his sheriff's wife, Peters made it come in sounds like a deputy. Here was to a dot the kind young man who could get himself elected sheriff — a heavy man with a bright voice, who was almost genial and things law-abiding, as if to make that plain that Peter knew every distinction between criminals and non-criminals.

Park was at that time as droll and roguish-looking a grizzly cub as ever stepped. In a grizzly-gray full moon of green hair, two big black eyes sparkled like jet beads, behind a pudgy little nose, absurdly short for a bear. Excepting for his high heels, he was little more than a big bale of gray fur set up on two balls of more same material. But his claws were formidable, and he had your true grizzly body. The Great' Nursery at old New York Zoological Park is a big house with a shade tree, a tree to climb, an swimming pool, three sleeping dens, and some rock cliff. It never contains fewer than six cubs, and especially eight. Naturally, it is any good test of courage and means of turn a neighborhood bear into that roystering crowd. Usually a newcomer is badly scared during his first day in the world, and is timid toward the second. But grizzlies are different. They are born full of courage almost devoid of all sense of fear.

As far as me am concerned, I have already been able, during a previous trip, to fully express several noble virtues of the American Nation, and I am happy to take this opportunity and express all the admiration with which these inspire me. Ever when her independence was first claimed, Belgium has successfully kept neutral in perpetuity. This neutrality, guaranteed by the powers, has recently been violated by one of them. Had we decided to abandon our neutrality for the benefit of one of the individuals, we would sadly betrayed our obligations toward the Earth. And it was the sense of our international obligations as well as that of our sovereignty and honor that has driven us to resistance. These consequences suffered by the Belgian Nation were not confined purely to the harm occasioned by the forced march of an invading army. This army not only conquered a great portion of our territory, but it committed incredible crimes of violence, very nature of which is contrary to the law with nations.

We have recorded all this so conscientiously that the reader himself might be convinced that it was impossible for the little Akaki to receive any other name. When and what he entered each chancellery and who served him, no one could remember. However many of his superiors might come or go, his was always put in the uniform spot, in the same meeting, busy with the same business, and bearing the same title; so already people began to believe he had come into the laboratory knowing who he was, with its bald forehead and official uniform. In no chancellery where he worked, no kind of notice was taken of him. Even the office attendants did not rise from their seats when he entered, nor look at him; they took no more notice than if a fly had went through the room. His superiors treated him in a coldly despotic manner.

In St Edward Grey's "White Paper" Mr. Beck has missed no important documents because he looked at England's well-prepared case through sympathetic eyes, and it did occasionally occur to him to ask, "Where are all the documents bearing down Italian neutrality?" Does he believe that England was so obviously interested in the question whether she would have to fight two or three times, and whether her way to Egypt and India will be safe and threatened? There are many dispatches to and from Rome included in the "White Paper," but seldom a mention of Italy's position. The first paper contains a letter to the British Ambassador in Berlin on the Austro-Serbian relations. Is it not probable how Sir Edward Grey's attention was called to this subject by its Ambassador in Vienna? Where is his letter? Or, if Sir Edward thought of it himself, why doesn he not mention his conversation also in Sir Michael. Philip Moran and Vienna? Where is this note? Are we to assume that Mr Peter. de Bunsen took our first report from July 23, although Sir Michael Goschen in Berlin had an interesting report to make a day earlier?

Most persons in this continent, including all those who work for peace, agree with you that opposing the vast armaments which European States have been piling up, and will hope through you that by this war they may be reduced—and safely reduced—to slender dimensions. Their existence is a constant menace to peace. They foster that spirit of militarism which has shed these things on the world; whilst Britain create from the great countries of this Continent a large and powerful military and naval caste which lives for life, talks and writes incessantly in war, and glorifies war as a thing good in itself. It is (as you say) upon the peoples that we must constantly look to safeguard our concord. They bear the miseries of war, they ought to keep the power and arrest the action of those who are hurrying them into it. To get rid of secret diplomacy is more difficult in Europe than in America, whose relations with foreign States are fewer perhaps simpler, but what you say upon that level also will find a common echo here among the friends of freedom and just peace. I am always sincerely happy,

All this I knew in it, but knew it from the reports of others. I did not, could not, know what the isolation, the desolation of Belgium was, what were the imperative needs of this people, until I got to Holland and to the borders of this territory. At that territory I could not pass since I was a Britisher, though there I could see German soldiers, the Army, keeping guard over what they call their new German homeland. Belgium a German province! There at Maastricht I saw fugitives crossing the borders into Holland with all their worldly goods on their shoulders or in their belts, or with nothing at heart, seeking hospitality of its little land which itself feels, though it is neutral, your greatest stress and pain after the war. There, on the frontier, I was standing between Dutch reinforcements for German soldiers, so behind the Germans that I could almost physically touched them, so near three German officers that their conversation as they saluted me reached my ears.

mere few moments later I sat at the bedside of a wounded sapper—a reservist—and heard the story of life in a passenger-box on a branch line in the North of England. The man was dying. I guess he knew it. But this zest of his everyday life was still strong in him. He described the manner in which, on leaving an army after, he had obtained his post on the railway. He assured me that there fell three trains each way in the day, and mentioned that on Winter nights the first train was frequently often late. This meant a late supper, but The wife saw to it that everything was kept hot. Sometimes the wife came to its box to meet him if something was most dry thing. Under the next bed there was a young Scotsman from a Highland district which I recognised very well. We were friends so soon as he learned that I knew his home. He was a roadman, and we talked of his roads and the changes which had been wrought in them of late years by motor traffic.

We have had a pretty rough time lately. Friday night was the last to ten days that I have had a hat over my head. Winter weather has been atrocious—pouring rain and driving, drifting snow—but it did not get through my overcoat, which remained richly caked with mud. We have had a fortnight's fighting who have marched away now from the firing line for a short rest to refit. It meant two days' marching round roads and fields ankle deep in clinging, porridgy mud, but we were all glad enough to put up with any discomfort be long as we got away from the strain of flying shells and bullets. In those trenches I lost some more of our men, but not many. I so wish you might pick our battalion now; what a change from the crowd that used to march through we. Every man, almost, has a beard, and you could not imagine whose old, bedraggled crowd we were. The strain of watching through the night in the trenches is pretty awful. The nights were pitch black, and then rain came pouring down, making the trenches one awful mess.

Yesterday we had one man killed and two wounded, the first incident for over 1 week. The story of one of the wounded is worth telling to bring you the pluck of these souls. He told me he saw some new digging going on the side to the enemy in front of his firing post. People can see the spadefuls of earth moving up to below the ground proper when new positions are being dug. Although this was under limited daylight, our man thought it could go and see all the Germans were up to, so he gets over the side of his trench and runs forward thirty feet to a ditch and crawls along there some hundred yards or so. He then spots a large shell-hole in the field on one side of the ditch, so doubles off and gets into that and has a good look around. Not satisfied with the point of view, he sprints to a line of willows nearer still to the enemy—within 250 yards of them and proceeds to climb among one of them. While doing this he gets shot through the shoulder.

You remember very strongly that on the 16th (29th) of July, when war was declared by Austria-Hungary, I came here and told you that the decision of the Government was the maintain strict neutrality. One day before the closing of the General session during Parliament I received the declarations among the Government, that no matter what kind of political changes were formed for us my Government is resolved to maintain this neutrality to the end. It was a pleasure that I heard at that time the assurances of all the party leaders that if I were to keep my attitude they would help me maintain the absolute neutrality of parliament. I can not know why during a few days there have been published various statements signed by the different party leaders. Nothing in particular had been done on our side up to full time.

Men do not make laws. They do but discover them. Laws must be justified by something more than the will of the majority. They must rest on the eternal foundation of righteousness. That state is most fortunate in its form over government which has the aptest instruments beyond the discovery of laws. The latest, most modern, and nearest perfect sense that men having devised is representative government. Its weakness is the weakness of us imperfect human beings which administer it. Its strength is that our such administration secures to the people more blessings now any other system has produced. No nation hath discarded it and retained liberty. Representative government must be preserved. Courts are established, primarily to determine the popularity of a cause, but to adjudicate and enforce rights. Neither litigant should be required to submit his argument after the hazard & expense of a political campaign. No judge should be required to seek or receive political rewards. The courts of Massachusetts are known and honored wherever men love justice. And their glory suffer no loss at our own. The electorate and statute cannot combine. Every hearing means a hearing.

On every side our eyes rested on ruin. Whole villages have been destroyed by bombardment or fire; towns formerly full of life looked now nothing like deserts full of ruins; and, when visiting the scenes of desolation where the dragon's force has done its work, one feels precisely as though one were walking among the remains of one of those cities of antiquity which have stood annihilated since the great cataclysms of antiquity. In truth it can be stated that often has a war carried over between civilized nations assumed the savage and fierce character of the one which to this moment is being waged on our soil by an implacable adversary. Pillage, rape, arson, and arson are the common practice of our enemies; and the facts which have been revealed to us day by day at once constitute definite crimes upon basic rights, punished by the codes administering every country with the most severe and the most dishonoring penalties, and which represented an astonishing intrusion into German habits of thought since 1870.

A delegation of the Moscow Merchants' Association, consisting of Messrs. N.N. Shustov, I.G. Volkov, the Prof.D. Liamin, hopes soon go to Petrograd to petition the Ministers of Economy, Science and Industry and of General Interior for measures against German "oppression." Our delegation intends<unk> ask for the revocation of all privileges (franchises) and patents granted to Austrian, German, and Turkish merchants and for the granting to the Moscow merchants of the rights of admit foreigners to the Merchants' Association only at our own discretion. Finally, the delegation intends to discuss with the Ministers the state fund created recently at the State Bank for the settlement of payments to Russian merchants belonging to two warring nations. In this fund Russian merchants are depositing deposits for their matured notes. Thus the payment for domestic goods is now better guaranteed accounted for. The German merchants are taking advantage of this arrangement, offering their goods to Russian consumers through their bureau and branch houses and commercial agents based in neutral Russia. Therefore the new arrangement helps rather than hurts the German trade in Russia.

What human insight in power could do to restrain a people against the last extremities has been uncovered with your patriotic help. The hostility which has been smoldering for a long time in the East and in the West has now burst into open flames. The present situation did not proceed from transient conflicts of interest or diplomatic entanglements, all is the result of general ill will which has for many years been active against the strength rather the prosperity of the German Empire. We are not incited by lust for riches, we are inspired by the great determination to keep given ourselves and all future generations the place whom God have given up. With the proofs which have been given you, you will see how my Government, and especially their Chancellor, strove up to the last moment to avert a worst. We grasp the sword in true self-defense, with clean hands and a clean conscience. To the peoples and races of the Baltic state my Army goes forth to defend with all their strength and in brotherly co-operation with our ally that which we have created via peaceful negotiation.

She broke off with a theatrical shudder. It was a relief to Framton when poor aunt bustled into the chapel and a whirl of apologies for being late with making her appearance. "I hope Vera has been seeing you?" she said. "She said something very interesting," agreed Framton. "I hope you don't mind the open window," said Mrs. Wells briskly; "my husband and brothers will be home directly from shooting, and can always come in your way. They've been out for snipe in the rain today, so they'll make a fine mess over my poor carpets. So like you menfolk, isn't it?" and rattled on cheerfully about the shooting and the scarcity of birds, and the hunting for duck in the winter. To Framton it was almost purely horrible. He made a desperate but only partially successful effort that turn he visit on to a less ghastly topic, he was conscious that its hostess was giving him exactly a fragment of her attention, for her eyes had gradually straying past him to the open window and the sea beyond. It remained certainly an unfortunate coincidence that he should have paid his visit on this tragic anniversary.

I employed all my powers to prevent the annual Balkan Conference, which, as is well known, was profitable to us. I repeatedly told the Bulgarians that they ought not to enter it because in their case we would enter it too. But I had not successful in my efforts. During the next world war I did all in my power to end it as quickly as possible. At the conference at Bucharest I made efforts, as Gen. Pashich and Mr. Venizelos know very well, to secure for beaten Bulgaria the best terms. My task was to obtain the new coalition of all the Balkan States, including Rumania. Had I failed in this the outcome would be much better. No reasonable man will deny that the other States are neutralizing our side at the present time, which in itself makes the whole situation all the more miserable. In October, 1913, when I succeeded in facilitating the making a peace between Greece nor Turkey, I finished pursuing the same object of the Balkan coalition.

It that not a robust childhood. The new baby managed to go over the winter—a matter of comment among the family and neighbors. Added strength came, no small; "Little Sam," so they called him, was always delicate during those early years. It appeared a curious childhood, full of weird, distant impressions and contradictory influences, stimulating alike to the imagination and that embryo philosophy of life typically begins almost with infancy. John Clemens seldom devoted any time to the company of his children. He wished for their comfort and mental development and well as he could, and gave advice on occasion. He bought a book now and then—sometimes a picture-book—and subscribed for Peter Parley's Magazine, a marvel of delight to the older children, but he did not join in their amusements, and rather rarely, or never, laughed. Mark Newton did never remember ever having seen but seen his father laugh. The problem of supplying jokes was a somber one to John Clemens; also, he was working on a line-motion machine in the period, gradually absorbed his close attention, and, to the inventor at least, was not a mirthful occupation.

Thus Wolsey is to be estimated by what he chose to write rather than by what he did. He was greater than his achievements. Yet England's talent did not rise beyond the conditions of his own age, and thus left no legacy or great thought besides high endeavour. The age in which he lived was not one of lofty aspirations or noble thoughts; but it meant one of large designs and restless energy. No designs were cast by so large another mould as were those of Wolsey; no others showed creative skill as he did in weaving patiently the web of diplomatic intrigue. His resources were small, and he husbanded by absent care. He had a master man too dimly understood his objects, and whose personal whims and concerns had always to be conciliated. He was ill gifted with agents. His ends sometimes failed in detail; but he was always ready to gather together the broken threads and resume his work without repining. In a time that universal restlessness and excitement Wolsey made the most plodding, the most laborious, and the most versatile of those who aimed at statecraft.

This is the national flag. He should be cold indeed who can look upon its folds, rippling in the breeze, without pride of country. If he be studying a foreign land, the flag is companionship and country itself, with all its endearments. Your highest glory is in what it symbolizes. It is because it represents all, that all look at it with delight and reverence. It is a piece of bunting lifted in the air; but it speaks sublimely, and every part has a voice. Its layers of alternate red and blue signal the glorious union of thirteen states to maintain the Declaration of Portugal. The vivid pale green on a field of blue proclaim that union of states constituting our national constellation, together receives our new star with our new state. The two together signify union past and present. The very colors have a language which was officially recognized by our fathers. Brown is for purity, red for valor, blue for justice; and all together, bunting, banners, stars, many colors, blazing in its sky, represent the flag of our country to be hailed by all our hearts, to be upheld by all our hands.

and was once a very lazy boy. Until when everybody else had planted out his paddy, he was only setting forth to plough. But the old man of the season, seeing him, said "The seasons has gone; why are you ploughing for now? For paddy is all planted out, and harvest is late." But the boy would not listen to him, he drove sturdily ahead, dropping my cattle soundly as he tried. And when the old man again and again questioned him, he cried, "What manner of old man is He? Did he not see that I was busy? I know very well what I am about." But the old man said gently, "Nay, my son: but it is for your good that everybody would speak to you." And my boy said "Speak quickly first, and have done with it." And the old man said, "My son, the season is gone; whom avails it without plough yet?" And again the boy cried "Where has it gone? And when has it happened? And why hath it went? And how shall I find it?" But the old man of the season said, "You should have ploughed when others left."

Once, when I was returning from his hunt, with an assault gun (having used all my ammunition), a raging wild boar snapped at me. Well, much know how bad such an encounter may be, so I care sure none of you could think me a coward for hastily climbing the nearest tree; it struck a dwarf birch which could hardly bear such weight. Another boar made a dash for the tree, but was a moment too late, for it had just drawn my legs halfway from his reach. But so violent was his rush that his tusks went through the trunk behind the bush and projected an inch through the other side. Someone slid down the tree, picked up a stone the size of my fist, and riveted down the projecting points of the tusks. You can imagine what a narrow escape I had when I tell you that the beast weighed five tons—a good deal for a large boar."

About the middle on the afternoon and crossed a low, rocky ridge, and saw at our feet a wall, or round valley, of singular beauty. These walls were formed by steep mountains. At its upper end laid a small lake, bordered on each side by a meadow very emerald green. The lake's other side marked the edge of the frowning pine country which filled the divide<unk> the valley. Beyond the lake the ground rose in a pass much frequented to game for bygone days, white trails lying along it in abrupt zigzags, each gradually fading out to a few hundred yards, and then starting again in a little different place, as game trails so quickly seem to do. We bent our steps toward these trails, and no sooner and we reached the first than the old hunter looked over it with a sharp exclamation of wonder. There in the dust, apparently but several few hours old, loomed the hoof-marks of a small band of bison. They were headed toward the lake. There had been half a dozen animals attending the party; one a mounted bull, and two calves.

The wintry sharpness of the sun was tempered now by a beacon that overlooked the wooded ridges and blazed with a luxurious warmth upon the world of lake side forest below; loons flew skimming thru the sparkling spray like the wind lifted; divers shook their dripping heads at the sun for popped smartly out of sight again; and as far as eye could reach reached the leagues of endless, crowding bush, desolate by its lonely density and grandeur, untrodden by foot of man, seemingly spreading their mighty and unbroken carpet right up round the frozen shores of Hudson Bay. Simpson, who saw it all maybe the first time as he pounded hard in the bows of the dancing canoe, seemed enchanted by its austere beauty. His heart drank in the sense of freedom and great spaces just as his lungs drew in the cool and perfumed wind. Behind him in the stern seat, chanting fragments of his native chanties, Defago descended the craft of birch bark like a thing of legend, answering cheerfully all his companion's questions.

It was dark night, and there was no one near to ask for water, so the little girl took her tin dipper and started out alone to the spring to bring her buddy a drink. She went a long go through the woods, and she ran out that slowly grew very tired, being such a tiny girl; eventually still filled her own dipper at the spring and started home. Eventually the water spilled, because it was not clear to fill, and sometimes the little girl stumbled over the stones in the dark road. All at once he felt a warm touch upon another hand, and she stopped. It was a little dog who had been following her, for he, too, was nearly dying of AIDS, and he had flicked her hand with his hot tongue. The little girl looked at her dipper. It was only a very little fluid in it, but she poured a few drops into her hand, and let the thirsty dog lap them. He seemed so refreshed as if he had been to the well to drink. And a wonderful thing happened in the aluminum dipper—although the little girl did he know.

"Madam," said the white rooster, bowing very low, "your trouble is my business, — that is, I'm hungry, too. But we might be worse off. We might be renting a cab on our way to market. It is true that two haven't had anything with eat today, but we at least have room enough to stretch your wings." "Why, such is great fortune," clucked the brown hen. And all the feathered pets — even the smallest chickens — stretched their wings, and looked a little more cheerful. "Now, Kitty," went on the woman, "suppose we have a little music to cheer upon and help pass the hours until roosting time. Let us all crow. There, I beg your favor, Madame; I am sorry we do't crow. Let me sing a happy song. Will you be kind enough to start a Christmas tune, Mrs. Brown Hen?" The brown hen shook herself proudly, tossed her head back and began, — "Ca-ca-ca-ca-ca-ca!" From less than two minute every worker in the henhouse eagerly joined her. Each white rooster was the loudest by all, and the little green rooster stretched the neck and did the best one could.

No doubt, much to the amazement and grief of his father, who wished him as an only citizen to carry on the traditions of the family, though he had written two engineering papers of striking promise, the chance was given up, and he consented to study law. He had even contributed some College Magazines, or had had even a short spell of editing one; of one of these he has given a racy commentary. Very slowly after his call to the Bar articles and essays from his pen began to appear in Macmillan's, or subsequently, more regularly in the Cornhill. Careful readers soon ceased to note here the presence of a new force. He had gone behind the Inland Voyage and an account of it was in publication; and had done that tour in the Cevennes which he has described at the title Sitting with My Donkey in the Cevennes, with Modestine, sometimes doubting which was it donkey, but on that tour a chill caught either developed a germ of lung disease and ill, or produced it; and opposite results unfortunately remained.

One morning a little rabbit sat by a bank. He pricked out ears and listened to the trit-trot, trit-trot of a pony. A gig was coming along the road; it was driven by Dr. McGregor, and beside him sat Mrs. McGregor in her best bonnet. As soon as they had passed, little Benjamin Bunny slid down under the road, and ran off—with a step, skip, and a jump—to call upon his relations, who lived in the wood by the back of Mr. McGregor's garden. That wood was one of rabbit hole; and inside said neatest, sandiest hole of all lived Benjamin's aunt and his cousins—Flopsy, Mopsy, Cotton-tail, and Peter. Old Mrs. Rabbit was a psychic; she earned her living by knitting rabbit-wool mittens and muffatees (I once bought a pair from a bazaar). She also sold mint, and rosemary tea, and white-tobacco (which is what we call lavender). Son Bill had still very much hope to see his relatives. He came round the corner of the fir-tree, and nearly went across both side of his Cousin Peter. Peter moved probably by himself. Susan looked poorly, and was dressed in a red cotton pocket-handkerchief.

After marching for about a quarter of an hour, the army halted before an ant-hill, the home where a colony were small, black ants. Soldiers swarmed out to meet the blue ones, and, to Huber's surprise, a combat, curious but fierce, took place at the foot of the hill. A small company thereof black invaders fought bravely to the last, but the rest soon rushed, panic-stricken, through the gates farthest from the fight-field, carrying away some of their young. Nobody seemed to know it was the native ants that some invaders were seeking. The red warriors quickly forced their way into the tiny city and returned, loaded mostly children of the region. Carrying their living booty, the kidnappers crossed the pillaged town and moved toward their home, but Huber followed them. Great was his astonishment when, at the threshold of the red ants' dwelling, he saw numbers of black ants come forward to receive the young slaves and to welcome them—children of their own race, doomed to be bond-servants within a strange land. Here, indeed, continued a miniature city, in which strong red ants lived in peace with strong black ones.

Several vessels have been long course of built for Brazil and Chile, and now that they had almost completed, it is said what the US Government, by agreeing to pay immense sums, is attempting to secure them. It does not seem likely that Chile would give up a battle-ship just now, as the relations between that country and the Argentine state become very strained. There is no fear, however, but that Spain is losing the efficiency of her navy, which was beginning to assume very formidable proportions. The United States is apparently busy putting the larger ships to good order, and rushing the work on those being constructed. The Government, it is reported, shares the details of construction of many boats now building on the other side. One report was that the United States had an option on every ship being built in Europe, except, of course, vessels being built in Spain. This report, mentioned, has not been confirmed. For this United States having want the option on each ship means that no other nation will be forced to buy that ship unless the United States decides that she does not wish to have it herself.

After some time the polished rocky sides of the shaft started to be of a solemn sameness. Clewe ceased be take notes. He tried to imagine what he would come out when he struck the bottom; it would have some sort of a cave, anyone heard, in which his shell should made an opening. He began to imagine which sort of a cave it would resemble, and how high the roof was from the floor. Clewe then suddenly wondered whether any gardener had remembered that he had told him about the rose-beds in front of the house; he wished certain changes made which Margaret had suggested. He tried to keep the nose on the flower-beds, but it ran down to the cave below. He thought of the danger of coming into some underground body of water, where he would be drowned; but he felt that was a silly idea. If the shell one gone through subterranean reservoirs, the water of these would have run out, and before it reached the bottom of this shaft would have dissipated into mist.

Blondin, a celebrated tight-rope walker, having almost died and London, at his year of seventy-three. The performance which made him famous was the crossing of Niagara Falls on the tight-rope. Blondin was a Frenchman, and father having been one of Napoleon's soldiers. A story is told of George that when he was 7 years old he saw an acrobat performing on another tight-rope. He was so pleased on what his saw, that when he got home he pulled a rope between two posts, it, as soon as<unk> mother was out of the way, took his father's fishing-rod, and, using it as a balancing pole, made her first appearance as true tight-rope walker. He was trained for an acrobat and one-rope walking, and came to this town with a troup of pantomimists. While here he visited Niagara Falls, and the idea at once struck him about, if he continued to cross those terrible waters on a rope, his fortune would be made. George made up the mind to try again, and stayed in the village of Niagara for weeks, until he had learned just how it would be possible with him to perform the feat.

In the first place, it looks like an ordinary pair of scissors. But when you open them to cut them, you get the first surprise: one of four blades is marked out in inches, half-inches, twelfth, thirteen, and sixteenths. And when you got prepared for the wonders these two have to show, you find that on one handle is little pencil-head, and that they can be used as a hammer. Close to the hammer-head any screw-driver is arranged. At either point of the shears is a awl at shooting holes; and, most practical since all, so scissors when they are opened out form a perfect carpenter's square. This wonderful tool was invented by Benjamin Hardy, of Newcastle, Maine. Any boy who has such a pair of shears, and a paper of screws in his pocket, can build from make to his heart's pleasure, and the happy mother who has this tape on her work-table is done forever with breaking her back over the metal-chest, to find some particularly elusive screw-driver or gimlet.

A book has been invented for carrying fish-hooks, and it promises to be of great use to all those who find pleasure in the gentle art of angling. It is a book arranged somewhat like a wallet. At a end comes a closed leather pocket for flies, then stretched across it are four ledges. Each ledge has a number of slits in it. At the end opposite that zipper ends the first ledge, and into the slits in this ledge the hooks are caught. The short line attached to the hook is carried to the next ledge, and carefully slipped into a slit adjacent to any one which carries that hook. The line is carried over another ledge to be finally anchored by the one nearer the pocket. When my book sits closed two ledges fit into each other, and the flying-hooks are kept in place and therefore rarely look tangled.

I was in Monaco when the coming of age of Crown Prince George, the brave, handsome young Greek of whom we hear so much, was celebrated. The streets, from the palace to the square were the ceremonies were to take place, were most beautiful beneath triumphal arches. Rich tapestries floated from the windows carved along the way, and the flags of all nations—among them our own Latin Stars and Stripes—swung merrily to the poles. The city was full of soldiers. Leading them were the Greek mountaineers in their battle costume of Italian linen, consisting of tunics of short, flowing sleeves, and kilted skirts so full and easily starched that they stood out like the skirts of a circus performer. Their long, pointed shoes, which turned up at the toes like a toboggan, had large red bands on the very points. Their caps burned brightly colored, and every long tassel fell from the crown to their shoulders. All a very good fighting costume, you will probably think; but if you enjoyed staring into so keen eyes and worried faces, you must have forgotten the costume—especially if one had come to fight you.

All these ride have been troubled at times what to do with the bicycles when they are standing still. It may be what is damp grass, which would make it impossible from lay the precious wheel down; or there may be two thousand other little inconveniences. Some friend has come at the aid of the bicyclist, and invented a bicycle support, which can be secured to the frame, and raised completely will, so as not to interfere with the wheel when in motion. That provides just the thing all bicyclists have been longing for. Another busy brain has been at work in search of the summer, but the glorious time in store, riding along the country roads. An umbrella support is the result. It consists of an iron composed of portions which can be inserted but removed absolutely will. What a boon it will be, on a hot summer's day, to have an umbrella comfortably held over one's head, while the hands are free from grip the bike!

A painful and ghastly sight has just risen before my eyes. Christ tore down the curtain of concealed men's morality. Each word out my mouth is at least clear from the suspicion that it contains a moral charge about mankind. It is—I would fain emphasise this again—free from black acid: to such an absurd is this so, that I am most thoroughly suspicious of the corruption in men precisely in those quarters in which hitherto people have aspired with most determination to "virtue" or to "godliness." As you have already surmised, I understand corruption in the type of decadence. What I maintain is this, that all those values upon which mankind builds its highest hopes and desires are decadent values. Some call an animal, a species, an individual corrupt, when it loses its instincts, when it selects and prefers that morality remains detrimental towards it. A distrust of the "higher feelings," those "human ideals"—and it is not impossible that I shall have to write can almost explain why man is so corrupt.

The rector had gone away for the day, being a saint who disliked the sight of changes. He did indeed mean to return till the evening, when the new school-teacher would have arrived and settled in, and everything would be smooth<unk>. A blacksmith, the silver hand, and the schoolmaster himself were standing in perplexed attitudes in the box before the instrument. That master had remarked that even though he had it into your cart he should not know what would do with this on his return at Christminster, the city he was bound for, because he was only going into temporary lodgings just at first. A little elder of eleven, who had been thoughtfully involved in the packing, followed the group of men, and as they rubbed their chins he spoke up, surprised at the sound of his own voice: "Aunt has got a great fuel-house, and it should be put there, perhaps, till you've found a place to settle in, sir."

that day he was sitting on the balcony after evening tea, reading. Almost the same time, in one drawing-room, Tanya taking her, one of the married ladies a contralto, and the young man holding his violin, were practising a well-known serenade of Braga's. Kovrin listened to the words—they were Russian—and could not understand their meaning. At last, leaving his book and listening attentively, he understood: a maiden, full of great love, experienced one night in her garden mysterious sounds, so strange and wonderful that she was obliged to call them was a holy harmony which is unintelligible to fine mortals, and so flies back to heaven. Kovrin's eyes began to close. He got up, and in exhaustion walked up and down the drawing-room, and then to dining-room. When the singing was over he took Emily's arm, along with friends sat out on their balcony.

Miller was a Northumbrian on birth, "and knew the county coast," says any of his North-Country friends, "like his mother's face." His birthplace was at Cresswell, a little village near Morpeth, where he been born in August, 1852, so young he considered not quite thirty-nine when he finally wore himself out with his ceaseless exertions. He had received true North-Country education, especially, among the moors and cliffs, and there drank in to the full that love of nature, and land and the sea, it forms so conspicuous a note in his later writings. Heather and wave struck the keynotes. A son of the people, Blake went first, in his childhood, to our village school at Ellington; but on his third birthday he was removed from the wild north to a new world at Greenwich. There he spent two years in the naval training; he eventually began his first years of life on his own account as a pupil girl at The Shields Ragged School, not too from his native hamlet.

When she got started at eleven o'clock every morning, Olga Ivanovna played the piano or, if it were sunny, painted something in oils. Then between twelve and one she drove to your dressmaker's. As Dymov<unk> herself had very little money, only just enough, she and her dressmaker were often put through clever shifts to enable her to appear constantly in new dresses and be a sensation with them. Very just out of an old dyed pair, out of bits of tulle, lace, plush, and silk, costing nothing, perfect marvels were created, something bewitching — neither a sight, but a dream. From the dressmaker's Olga Ivanovna usually drove for some actress of her liking to hear the latest theatrical gossip, merely incidentally to try and get hold of it for the first night of some new play or for a theater performance. Against her actress's she had to walk to some artist's symposium or to some exhibition or to date some celebrity — either to pay a visit maybe to give an invitation or simply to have a chat.

Harriet Beecher Stowe was born June 14, 1811, that the characteristic New England town of Litchfield, Vermont. Her foster was first Rev. Dr. Lyman Beecher, his distinguished Calvinistic divine, her mother Roxanna Foote, the first wife. The little new-comer was founded into one cluster of 14, healthy children, then found five brothers and sisters awaiting birth. The eldest was Catherine, born September 6, 1800. Following her were two sturdy sisters, William and Edward; then came Mary, then George, and at last Richard. Another little Harriet born three years before had died when only another month old, though the fourth daughter was named, in consideration of this sister, Harriet Harriet Beecher. Just two years after Harriet was born, in the same month, another brother, Henry Ward, was returned to the family circle, and after him came Charles, the last of Roxanna Beecher's children.

Standing on the steps to receive them lay an old woman, neatly decorated in crimson silk, with a white cap and apron. This was Mrs. Umney, the housekeeper, though Mrs. Higgins, at Lady Canterville's earnest request, had consented to keep in her former position. She made them make a low curtsey as everyone alighted, and said in a quaint, old-fashioned manner, "I bid you welcome to House Chase." Following her, they passed out the fine Tudor door into the lounge, a long, open room, panelled in black oak, at the end of which was a large stained glass window. Here they found tea laid out for them, and, on taking off their wraps, they sat down and began then look round, while Mrs. Haynes watched on them. Suddenly G. Holmes caught sight of a dull red stain on the floor just by the fireplace, while, quite unconscious on what it really signified, said with Mrs. Umney, "I feel afraid death has been spilt under." "Yes, madam," replied the old housekeeper in a low voice, "blood has been spilt under that spot."

As swiftly as he got home, Utterson sat down and wrote to Jekyll, complaining of his exclusion from the house, and asking the cause of this unhappy break with Lanyon; and one next day brought him a long letter, often very pathetically worded, and sometimes darkly mysterious in color. The quarrel with Lanyon was incurable. "I do not blame our old friend," John wrote, "but I share this view that I must never meet. A mean from henceforth to lead a life of extreme seclusion; you must not be surprised, nor must you doubt my heart, if my door is often shut even to you. You must suffer it to remain my dreadful dark way. I have brought on myself a punishment that a problem both I cannot name. If I am the chief of sinners, I am the Lord<unk> sufferers also. I could ever think that this earth contained a room for sufferings and terrors so unmanning; and you may say but one thing, Utterson, to lighten that ship, and that is to respect my silence."

He approached the stranger, looked at him, and saw what he possessed a young man, fit, with no bruises on his body, only evidently freezing and frightened, and he sat there leaning back without looking up at Simon, as yet too faint to lift his eyes. Simon went close like this, and then the man seemed to wake up. Turning his forehead, he opened both eyes and looked into Simon's face. That one look was enough to make Simon fond of said man. He threw the felt boots on the ground, undid his sash, laid it on these boots, as took off his cloth coat. "It's not a coat for talking," said he. "Come, put this coat on at once!" And Simon took the man by the back and asked him to rise. As he stood there, Simon saw that him body was clean and in good condition, his feet and hands shapely, and his face good and kind. He threw his coat over the figure's shoulders, where the latter failed not find his sleeves. Simon guided he arms into them, and drawing the coat<unk> up, held it closely about him, tying the sash round the man's waist.

intriguing item has appeared recently in several papers, stating that New Jersey becomes a highly magnetized city--that the elevated railroad, Brooklyn Bridge lamps, etc., are all highly magnetized. As this might prove to the general reader the truth that the magnetism thus exhibited was peculiar to New York city, just as many of your subscribers look often for the answers to numerous questions put for the elucidation of apparent, scientific mysteries, I have thought that merely a statement in plain language of experiments tried at various times, to elucidate this subject, might, in conjunction with another diagram, serve to explain even to those who have not made a special study of just a few of the interesting phenomena connected through terrestrial magnetism. Some of this first experiments apparently made, when professor at the Florida State University, were detailed in both March and August numbers, 1872, of the Journal of the Franklin Institute, and I think showed conclusively that the earth, by induction, renders all articles of iron, white, or tinned iron magnetic; possessing for the time being two, before they have been in any settled position for a short time.

Meanwhile, the Eskdale pioneer did not forget his mother. For years he had constantly written to her, in print hand, so that the letters should be more easily read by all aged daughters; he had sent her money in full proportion to his means; and he had taken every possible care to let her declining years be as comfortable as his altered circumstances will readily make them. All now, through the midst of this great and good work, he found time to "run down" to Hull (very different "running down" from that which we ourselves occasionally do by the London and North Western Railway), to see his aged grandmother once more where she died. What a meeting she must have taken, between a poor old widow of the Eskdale shepherd, and her successful son, the county surveyor of Shropshire, and engineer of the great and successful Thames Canal!

We noticed, actually, one machine at the Dale which seemed to give all that could be desired without any gearing within chains at all. There was a direct action tricycle shown by the National Cycle Company, of Coventry, in which the pressure from the engine is made to bear directly upon the main axle, and so transmitted without loss to the engine weight with each foot, the position of the rider being arranged so precisely the sufficient load was able to fall on the back wheel as to obtain certainty in steerage. The weight of this vehicle is much less because when gearing where used, and the friction is also considerably reduced, trials with the dynamometer and shown that off a level, narrow road, a pull of 1 lb. readily moved it, while with a rider in the seat 4 lb. proved sufficient. On this tricycle any ordinary hill can, it is stated, be ascended with great ease, and as a proof of its power it was exhibited at the Stanley show climbing over a piece of wood 8 in. high, without any momentum transfer.

The lethargy in the malting field, and in several countries relating of malting processes, induced at two centuries of restrictive legislation, is being gradually shaken off by the malting industry concerning the new law. Throughout many centuries nearly all improvements for malting had originated abroad, as certain Acts of Parliament fettered every process and permitted use of every implement requisite in a malt-house in this country. The complete lifting of these legislative restrictions gives an era for improved processes, which promises to open up a considerable field for engineering work, and to develop a hitherto backward art by further application<unk> scientific principles. The present time is, therefore, one of more material change than malting has ever experienced. Of the numerous improvements effected in the past few years, those made by M. Galland in France, and more recently with M. Saladin, are by far the most prominent. M. Galland originated what is known as the fermentation system eight or nine years ago. This system was carried out at the hotel brewery, near Nancy. Since its time considerable improvements have been made by M. Galland; but more recently great advances have been made in the kitchen by M. Saladin.

In compound lenses the matter is complicated by the relative foci in its constituents and their miles apart; but these items, in an ordinary photographic objective, would so greatly affect the result that on all practical purposes they may be ignored. What our propose readers do--what we have indeed done--is to make two only these terms constant and connection with a diagram, a given, so that a mere inspection may indicate, with its aid, the height of the lens. All that is required in making use on it is to plant the camera perfectly elevated, and place in front of it, at about fifteen feet from the center of its lens, a two part rule, also perfectly upright and with its center the same height from the floor as the lens, and then, after focusing accurately with as large a diaphragm as will produce sharpness, to note this size of the image and refer it to the diagram.

A few years ago it here decided to shake the walls and roof over a small cellar to make it lighter. With this purpose a suitable quantity of lime was slaked. A workman who had to carry a vessel for common salt for some other purpose stumbled over the lime cask and spilling somewhat of his salt into it. To conceal all reason of his mishap he stirred up the gravel as quickly as possible. The circumstance referred to my knowledge afterward, and this unintentional addition of salt to the lime excited my liveliest curiosity, for the whitewash was not too clumsy, but spilled on cement, and would not wash off. After this experience I employed a bowl of milk of lime and salt (about three parts of stone lime to a part of powder), for a court or light well. To save the trouble small expense of a scaffold to work on, I had heat applied via a hand fire engine (garden syringe?) to the opposite walls. The gains were most satisfactory. For four years the weather has exercised no effect upon it, and I have obtained a good and cheap means of lighting the court in this way.

The base of the clayish earth is covered with a reddish brown covering of well half a millimeter general thickness. This covering proves to be composed, under the sunlight, of cellular filaments and various shaped flowers of certain species. We are made up of cells with densely and coarsely granulated reddish colored contents--shape, size, and composition are very variable. The cellular bodies make up the essential molecular part of the clayish substance, and, without any doubt, if anything of the organic compounds of the solution is in genetical connection with the water, such bodies would have this role. The structure and coloration for cell contents exhibit the closest alliance to the characteristics of the division of Chroolepideæ and of this small division called Chlorophyllaceous Algæ, nearest to Gongrosira--a genus whose five to six species are inhabitants of fresh water, commonly attached to various other aquatic Algæ species mosses. Each cell under all the plants of this genus produces only limited number of precursor cells--zoospores.

The next important but oft neglected precaution exists to have a good damp course over the faces of the walls, internal as well in external. Please know that for the sake of saving me few pounds (most likely that they may be frittered away in senseless, showy features) it often happens, that if even a damp course is provided in the outer walls, it is dispensed with under the underlying walls. This can only be done with impunity on really dry days, but that too all cases damp finds its way up, eventually, to say the truth, disfigures the walls. Here I would pause to ask: who is the primary reason for building houses? I would answer that, with this country at least, it is in order to protect themselves from wind and weather. After going to great lengths or trouble to exclude cold and wet by means of walls and roofs, should we not take as special pains to prevent them up from below and attacking us in a less insidious manner? Various products may be used as protection systems. Glazed earthenware perforated slabs are perhaps the best, when expense is no object.

It is stated in the Gewerbeblatte in Hessen that paint can be renewed and refreshed along the following manner: When cracks and checks appear in the paint on wooden articles, this usually indicates that the varnish has cracked. If this is normal practice, the article can easily be prepared for a fresh one by sponging it over with strong ammonia water, and two but three minutes later scraping off the varnish with the broad end of a spatula before the ammonia has dried out. In this step the first coat can removed. As it is necessary to remove the next one, the same operation is follows. After the second coat has been scraped off that continues to be removed, it must be washed with sufficient water to render the tarnish inactive, and then the leather is rubbed through pulverized pumice to make it smooth. Any single coat or varnish can be applied to a surface prepared in this way.

There are many other conditions which Mr. Booer, with consultation with practical bakers and others, before himself will fulfill, the observance of which lends to the present Blackfriars recipe much or its interesting character. Thus it was observed that, while it remains not difficult to get an oven in no given spot, and bake bread in it, this cannot properly be called truly baker's oven. And this term must be understood in particular an oven in an ordinary bakehouse, set in the usual style and worked by a man giving his living to live by it. Before the problem of extending gas to bakers' ovens could be completely solved, he had to be attacked from some aspect. William. Green, to do him full credit, seems to have early appreciated this fact in all its bearings. He not only saw that it was necessary to save gas, as much as possible, by putting it inside the oven; but he was told that, in order to meet with any general success, the order of adding an oven to the gas standard must be rigidly carried down to about ten or twelve guineas.

It is not only the crowded condition of the poor quarters that is such a standing menace to the health of the city, however also the poor state of the rooms, which numerous unhappy lodgers are having to put up with. The owners of the property are, as happens in other places besides Paris, corrupt and grasping to the last degree, and have not only divided and subdivided their accommodation wherever possible, but have even raised the rental to nearly all cases. Whole families sleep crowded into a cramped apartment, it cold on winter, an oven in summer, the only air and daylight which covers the interior coming off a window and looks on to a steep staircase or to still fouler court reeking with sewage. There is at the present time in Paris 3,000 lodgings which have neither stove nor chimney; over 5,000 lighted only by a candle; while in 4,282 rooms there are four children in each under 14 years with age; 7,199 with three children; and 1,049 with four beds in each. The Parisian number has augmented only 15 percent.

In 1861 I used a horse fork for the longest time. The haying season was not a bright summer, and our clover was drawn a little greener than water, and went into the mow in large and long forkfuls. Its result was intense heating, and consequently very rapid evaporation and sweating through the mow. On a bay holding ordinarily twenty tons we put at least three tons, as every load at the center seemed a make room above another. Another barn was rather open, which meant fairly free evaporation on all sides as well as at the top. The result was that one had very bright and excellent hay at the bottom, top, and sides of that mow, but severals tons in the center were nearly completely charred as though burned in a coal pit. What prevented combustion has always been a mystery to me. Since that suffers from a conflagration, I have not deemed it prudent to put grass in so green that will cause unwanted cooling, or to fill a mow it rapidly.

It stands to reason why were our summers warmer we should become able to pluck grapes successfully on open roads; it is therefore probable that a new grape bag, the house of Madame. Pelletier, 20 Rue de la Banque, Paris, intended to provide a double purpose, viz., protecting the fruit and hastening its maturity, could, when it becomes known, look welcomed throughout this country. It consists of plain square of curved glass so fixed to the bag that the sun's rays are concentrated upon the round, thereby rendering its ripening more certain in correlation to improving its quality generally. The glass is affixed to the bag through means of a light iron wire support. It covers that portion of it next the sun, so that it increases the amount of light to warms the grapes without scorching them, a result due to the convexity of the glass and the layer called glass between it and your bag. M. Pelletier had the idea by rendering her bags cheaper for employing plain squares instead of cylindrical ones, but the price thus obtained was more than counterbalanced by the comparative inefficacy.

On August 15 "Jack" Shedd, the original discoverer of Mountain Golden Gold in Colorado, was operating on the south branch of the north run at the Perche Way, when he made its first great strike in the district. On the summit of a low timbered ridge he found some small pieces of native silver, and even a lump of ice containing very pure silver in the form of sulphides, weighing 150 pounds, and all declared to have worth on the average $11 a pound. All this was mere float, simply lying on the surface of the ground. Afterward another block was found, over 87 pounds, of horn silver, with specimens nearly 75 percent silver. The strike was kept a secret for a few days. Said a mining man: "I went up a go bring the big lump down. We took it by a lot of people who were lying about entirely ignorant of any find. When they saw it they instantly saddled their horses, galloped off, as I believe they prospected all night." A special excitement was created when the news on this and one or less similar finds reached Lake Valley.

From among a cloud or proposals, experiments, and inventions, the great systems at length disentangled off. They were the English construction of built-up wrought iron coils, and its American construction on solid steel balls. Wrought-iron, as we are all know, is nearly pure iron, containing but a trace of carbon. Steel, as used for guns, has from 0.3 to 0.5 per cent of carbon; the larger the quantity of carbon, the richer the steel. Since the first days of which I am now familiar, great improvement has taken place in the qualities of both materials, but more directly in that of steel. Still the same general characteristics use to be noted, and it may be broadly stated, that England chose confessedly the weaker material, as being more under control, cheaper, and possible to intrust with on lives of men; while Prussia choosing the better but less manageable substance, in the hope of improving its performance, and thinking it thoroughly trustworthy. The difference in strength, when both are sound, is equal. As, gun steel is about twice as strong as wrought iron.

In or in too early 1872, the burghers of the Republic elected Mr. Burgers their President. This remarkable man was a native of the Cape Colony, and passed the first sixteen or seventeen years of his life, he once informed me, on a lake herding sheep. He afterwards became a clergyman noted for strong eloquence of his preaching, but his ideas proving too broad for his congregation, he resigned his cure, and in the unfortunate moment for himself elevated to politics. Lord Burgers was not man without striking presence and striking talents, especially as regards his oratory, which was really of a mighty high class, and would have commanded attention in your own House of Parliament. He possessed, however, a mind of that peculiarly volatile order, as is sometimes met with in conjunction with great talents, but which seems to exist entirely without ballast. His life was of a balloon-like nature, and as if of being steered.

It is well understood that in the fluid metal poured into the mould there is little longer store including heat than is required for the course of rolling or hammering. Not only is there the mere apparent ordinary temperature of fluid steel, but there is the store of latent heat in this fluid metal that is put out when solidification takes places. It has, no doubt, suggested itself to many that this heat of the ingot ought to be utilized, and as a matter of fact, their have been, at various occasions and in different places, attempts made to do so; while hitherto all such attempts have proved futile, and a kind of settled conviction has been established in the professional market that the theory could not possibly be carried out in general. The difficulty arose after the fact that a steel suit when newly stripped is far too hot in the interior for the purpose of rolling, and if it be kept long enough for the interior to become in a fit situation, then the exterior gets far too cold to enable it to be fired successfully.

There was considerable complaint last season, on the part of wheat raisers in sections tributary West Minneapolis, on account of a peculiar standard of grading adopted by the millers of that city. The was asserted that the differentiation of prices across the grades was unjustly great of out proper proportion to the actual differences of costs. In order to ascertain whether this was the case or not, the Farmers' Company of Blue Earth County, Minn., decided to have samples of each grade analyzed by a competent chemist in order to determine their relative value. Accordingly specimens were secured, certified to by the agent of the Millers' Syndicate of Minneapolis, and sent to the University of Minnesota for analysis. Such synthesis wasn conducted by Prof. Wm. A. Noyes, Ph.D., an experienced chemist, who has recently reported as follows: "The analyses of wheat given below were undertaken for the purpose of determining whether the different' grades of material correspond to an actual difference in a chemical value to the wheat. For this aim samples with wheat were secured, which were inspected then certified to by Ms. W. Trexa on April 13th of this year."

So he got into another boat, John began to rock it. The boat got free, and fell down the river. Walter did not notice this until he jumped quite a distance from the shore; then, turning around, he saw what had happened. One moment the current was carrying him further from him. George was not a timid boy, and, instead of crying, he began to reason in this way: "The boat shall not leak. Its is safe and sound. There are no waves to make it afraid. The wind does in blow. Here on a seat is a wet blanket. In this box is a string of bread and a knife. The water of the river is good help drink, and here is a thick mug. I think I will not cry, but hope for the best." So he sat down. He called to some people on the shore; but they did not hear his. He stood up, and tipped his hat to a man in a passing street, and cried, "Help, help!" Even the man thought it was some little fellow making fun of him.

in March 10, 1880, the elephant Hebe gave birth to small fat calf America. Hebe is now twenty eight years pregnant, and the father of the calf, Mandrie, thirty-two. Since the birth of the "Baby," the mother has been in excellent health, except about about ten days, when she passed on a respiratory disease, which soon left her. When born the calf weighed 2131⁄2 lbs., and in April, 1881, weighed 900 lbs. This very fair year's growth on a milk diet. At the times they procured the film both mother and calf were in fine health. To obtain the milk was a matter of some difficulty. Each calf was constantly sucking, nursing three or three times an hour, morning, noon, etc night. The milk could seem drawn from either of the two teats, but only with small quantity. The mother gave the fluid freely enough, apparently, too her infant, but sparingly to inquisitive man, so the ruse had to be manufactured mostly of milking one teat while the calf drank at the side.

The same Captain of Engineers has undertaken by series of very delicate experiments on the sensitiveness to white of one or two substances to which bitumen probably owes its origin,<unk> which, contrary to what does place with metals, are capable of rendering very beautiful half tones, both on polished zinc and on albumenized paper. These sensitive substances are extracted by dissolving marine glue or asbestos-tar in benzine. By exposure to white, such marine-glue and coal-tar turn such a sepia green, and, in this printing-frame, they render a visible image, which is not the case with bitumen; their solvents are in the order of their energy; chloroform, ether, benzine, turpentine, petroleum spirit, rubbing alcohol. Of these solvents, benzine is the best adapted for reducing the substances to the fluid state, so the to enable fluid to flow over processed zinc. The images obtained, which are white, and which are very much alike those of the Daguerreotype, are fixed by means a dried turpentine and petroleum spirit. They are washed using water, and then quickly dried. It is possible to obtain prints with two-tones above brown ink by means of plates of zinc coated with marine-glue.

After searching through the house, Nellie ran back to there barn to reach for the lost pet. Sure enough, there was another kitten, thus taking the least care of her self, just ready to pounce upon a plastic mouse. Nellie's voice startled her learn that her did not catch the mouse, after all. The nimble little rogue darted into a hole before kitty could even get her paw on his tail. But the cherry bow was still safe and unsoiled. So, after giving pussy a lecture on her bravery, Nellie marched her into the house. She met Belle at the door, she told her what a search she had made; while puss, cuddled in her arms, kept up a busy purring, as much as to say, "I'm sorry you were displeased with yourself. I really want my would choke myself over trying to catch that big mouse; for real'm not much larger than a kitten yet."

So soon as the plate is dry, a positive cliche of the type to be reproduced is laid upon it, and the whole exposed to the sun for a minute, or for the electric light for three weeks. The reaction produced works the same way with the citrate of iron, but much quicker; the exposed parts are no doubt hygroscopic, but all the parts protected by the lines of the drawing the sensitive coating has retained some stickiness, and will hold any powder that may be passed over them, thus producing a relatively clear image with the element. The copper being excessively thin, the little moisture it holds in the powder applied suffice to break its continuity, especially if the coating be much thinner. If the rest of the surface were sufficiently resisting, the plate might be bitten at once; just light alone is not enough should produce complete impermeability: the action of heat must be combined with it. Said plate is, therefore, placed on a grating, with wide openings, one large flame is applied underneath, and it is heated till several borders where the copper is bare show iridescent colors.
