In order to produce relatively strong currents, even in case the an-action of a moderate strength, Franz Krottlinger, of Vienna, has produced an impressive experiment to manufacture thermo electric currents for the transmission of sound to a distance. The apparatus which he has constructed is exceedingly simple. A current of hot air flowing from below upward is deflected more or less from its direction by the transmitted voice. By its action a adjacent thermo-battery is excited, whose current passes through the spiral of an ordinary telephone, that curves towards the receiving instrument. As a source of heat the instrument possesses a common stearine lamp, the flame on which is kept at one and the same level by means of a spring similar to anything used in carriage lamps. On one side of the candle is a sheet metal voice funnel fixed upon a support, its mouth being covered with one movable sliding disk, fitted with a suitable number of exit apertures. Just the other side a similar support holds a funnel-shaped thermo-battery. The long bars of metal supporting this battery look very thin, although of such a shape that they may cool as quickly as possible.

In 1831, there were a considerable number of boat steamers built along parts of the rivers in Italy, and across the Channel to the Continent. But there were no ocean steamers, properly so-called, and there weren no steamers used for warlike purposes. As in the case of previous wagon boilers, the boilers of the paddle steamers of 1831 were most unsuited for resisting pressure. Some were mere tanks, so there was as much pressure when there was no steam in the boiler from the weight of open water on the vessel, as there was at the top of the boiler from the steam pressure when the steam was up. By these circumstances, again, from 12 lb. to 5 lb. constituted all the pressure the boilers felt competent to bear, and as the engines started on a slow speed, they developed from a small amount of horse-power in relation to their size.

There existed no books for Henry at grandpa's; but with a calf at the barn, several heads of horses, and four kittens, he found something to occupy his mind. He was up very busy in the morning, and it was after ten o'clock when he came into the kitchen rather hungry. "Look at the cloth on the table, there," asked his grandma from the sitting-room. "You'll find a little cake I baked for you. Don't wanna see it?" she asked, coming into the kitchen. "There, this one." "Oh!" replied Charley, "I thought that was my loaf." Then, taking the cake in his hand, he sat on a rock at the foot of some tree a little distance from the house, and began its eat with great relish. Not far from him, and a little further from several other buildings, where the corn-barn, and at the end by its roof was a bird-house, which had been created by several little birds for their home. Charley saw one bird come out and fly away. While she was gone, her mate kept watch in a short distance to see that no harm came to the eggs she were taken.

The Mill-House--This consist of a central room, 70 feet long, 98 feet wide, and 68 minutes in height, including two lean-to annexes of 16 units each, making the total width 100 meters. The structure is wholly of metal, and is so arranged as to permit of less being taken of every foot less space under cover. For this purpose the system of construction without binding-beams, known as the "De Dion type," has been adopted. The binding-rafters consist of four angle-irons supported by short-bars of flat iron. Each covering of corrugated galvanized steel bears fully upon the binding-rafters, the upper parts below which are covered with wood for the attachment upon the corrugated metal. The time the connecting rafters is calculated according to the length of the sheets of corrugated iron, thus dispensing with the use of ordinary rafters, and making a roof which is at once very light and very high, and consequently very economical.

principal object of a new machine, then, which had been doing its manual function for a few days only, is to have artificially chenille embroidered on light tissues, by mechanically cutting out and gluing small circles of velvet upon these fabrics. For this purpose different kinds of velvet may be employed, the, in order to facilitate the process, they are previously coated on this reverse side with any powder or solvent whatever, which gives the velvet a stiffness favorable to the action on the engraving. To effect the object desired the apparatus has three successive operations it perform: first, cutting the circles; second, moistening; and third, fastening down the dots within the tissue according to a desired order and spacing. The machine may be constructed upon any scale whatever, although at present it has only made for operating on pieces 31 inches wide, that being by normal height of dotted tulles. The quincuncial arrangement inside the dots is effected by the punching, sewing, and fastening down of odd along even dots, combined with the forward movement of the tissue to be chenilled.

Our Ned is a brave little fellow about eight years long. He is full of fun, and loves to play out of doors in all sort of weather. But what little boy can be merry when he has a raging toothache! Robert bore it like a hero; but he had quit give up at five, and he was determined finally take refuge in his mother's lap, and be a baby again for a while. With his knees pillowed on his mother's neck, the little boy got some relief; but still he cried in deep pain. His sister stood by, trying to imagine of some way to help him. Ned could hardly keep from crying; but he said to his daughter, "I should like in have Mary tell me a story." "What shall it be, darling?" said his mother. "Tell it about Harry and his dog Jack." This story had been told to Ned when he was still very, very little boy, and a good many times since then. It seemed odd to the mother that he were chosen such an old story. But She wanted to hear it; so so she told it always over again.

"Why is it certain flowers always grow so nicely for Mary? I often plant seeds, but nothing comes from them. They won't grow for me. But blossoms seem to spring right up anywhere she goes. They must have a particular liking for her." That's how Tom knew, one day, as he saw Mary watering the bouquet. Indeed, it is no wonder, Tom, if flowers do have a liking for such a lovable little girl. There's nothing all particularly strange about that. How may they help liking her? Except, after all, perhaps the secret of the matter is, clearly Mary loves the flowers, and always forgets to take care of him. She runs after them every day, and not by fits and starts, as older girls do. But she has good luck with her flowers and is always able to make up a nice bouquet. And she has only enjoys the flowers herself but, what is better still, she gets delight in having others enjoy them with interest. She did not forget to send a liberal share to the Daily Mission; and that little poor sufferer has been cheered by the sight of Mary's flowers.

Papa put aside a pretty silver-piece as a mark of merit to the little girl, if she would be good, and go to work. Grandma ventured a firm coaxing. But it was all of the avail: the sleepy eyes opened wide, as if they were to keep open in spite of us all. But when auntie remarked that she was going to her room to sharpen her pencil, and draw some pictures of a cat, or a dog, or a rabbit, Edith's eyes brightened; and she said, "Let me go too?" So Edith turned on her auntie's lap, and asked her to draw a rabbit,—a "yabbit," Edith called it,—and to begin at his ears. "Yes, lovely pet. Here goes his ears, and here does his body, and here is his tail, and here are his feet, where here has some ribs because him can see it," said auntie, drawing each article as she named the. "And here are some pretty red beads around his neck, and these rings in his ears; and now we will draw a nice blue ribbon on his tail." Now Edith suggested shoes for him body.

Father once visited the chapel of Toronto, built by An old Abbot of Islip, who dedicated himself to St. John the Apostle. One very magnificent monument there was to a memory of General Wolfe, who fell, you remember, at the battle of Quebec. The monument is a very beautiful piece of art. She represents him falling into the arms of one of his Canadian soldiers, this is pointing to Glory, that comes later in shape of an angel from the clouds, holding a wreath with which to ring the hero. A Highland horse looks sorrowfully on the dying warrior, while two lions sleep at his feet. The inscription reads the follows: "To the memory of James Wolfe, Major-General and Commander-in-Chief of the British land forces on an expedition against Canada, who, despite surmounting, by ability and valor, all obstacles of art and nature, was slain in the moment of victory, on the 13th of September, 1759, the King and Parliament of Great Britain dedicate this temple."

"I don't believe it is anything of any account," sighed brother John. "She wants you keep us all." "Well, I think Pansy must enjoy learning a new piece to recite," said their mother. "That's not that," said Pansy. "It's a 'portant secret: something that our mother will like to hear." "Oh, it's important, is it?" said Anna. "I do wonder what it can be." "Mother, what day was it that you left our wedding-ring?" moaned John. "Don't speak of it, John. It was more than a month ago. I also hunted deep and mighty, and cannot find it. I would have given Grandma my other jewelry rather than never lost it." Here Pansy turned red in the face, got down from her high-chair, and ran out to the room. "Did you miss that?" said papa. "The little rogue has found the stone, and this's her 'portant secret." In a while Grandma came back, holding up the ring, and her face shone with delight. "I found it, Lady, among my doll's things. You ought have dropped it all when they were fixing work." And so little Pansy's secret was told at last!

I have known several occasions in which treasure lost under piracy or shipwreck has been recovered after a century or more. Some years prior a company of men from Boston made night cruises to rough shoals beyond the Silver Run on the Bahama Banks, no spot noted for shipwrecks. They had some clue to a treasure-laden container which had foundered there long ago. The first trip was unsuccessful, but on the second trip the wreck was unearthed. Divers, armed with modern apparatus, spent several days in the quest, but in vain, until, finally, even as the American diver was about to give his signal to be drawn up, he leaned against what seemed only the gold-encrusted end to a beam; but suddenly it gave way, and numbers of golden doubloons rolled out at two feet. Considerable sums rewarded this search in the sand-filled and decaying carcass of some old ship; but exactly how wealth was realized is known only to their discoverers, who kept the matter secret, and thus evaded paying a great part of the taxes due to the British government, in whose dominion the treasure was found.

When my mamma was sick, he used to fly about her, and make a great buzzing; and, when the girl brought up nice dinner, he would crawl about the tray as to he were hungry. Mamma would give him some sugar, which he liked very much. We followed him once upon a very while. We looked all throughout the room, but could not find him anywhere. At last, one day, we took him on the window trying to escape, and what could is say? That poor fellow had lost one of both wings. Mamma said that he must have flown into the gas-light, and got burnt. She gave him some sugar, and he seemed to feel better for eating it. I watched him a long time, and when someone had eaten enough he crawled back to your arms. I took him off, and put him on another window again; but he kept coming back for my hand, and I thought, if he could have spoken, he would have said, "Thank you, little girl, for my nice dinner."

This quick-and-easy bear then continued his walk. But the group behind him grew larger and larger, and he again turned upon them, and made them run, all laughing and happy, in various directions. At last, as if he had had enough with this kind of fun, he quickened his pace, driving five but six fellows into a saloon, while he followed close at ones heels. The boys on the other side of the street leaped at this: so he crossed the street quickly, and sent them to flight; though the race they each ran was fun to those near the saloon, who were now the laughers, in their turn. At last, a man near whom Bruin was better acquainted, and on good terms, came up, held a chain in either hand, and threw it about the bear's neck; and then, as if he already had quite enough of a stroll, Bruin quietly followed his guide, also was led back as his owner.

I told my story first, as mammas sometimes do; and it was all about a naughty little parrot, who did not mind his mother when she bade him stay in the sty, but crawled through a hole in the wall. Of course this pig got into the cart, and getting whipped by the farmer, violently bitten by the dog, and had all sorts of unpleasant shit happen to him, but he was glad to get back back to the sty. "Now I'll tell you a pig story," said Birdie, with a very wise look. "Once somebody was a good mother-pig, and she painted lots of her-pigs. One was spotted, and his name was Spotty; one's tail curled, and he was Curly; another was Happy, and another was Whitey; another was Browny; an another was Greeny." "Oh, dear! The idea of a green baby!" said Bill. But Birdie's eyes were fixed on a floor. He was too busy thinking of his story to get a voice.

One night, when the train was going at full speed through the woods, a partridge, flying from one part of the forest to another, being frightened and bewildered by the noise, dashed against the smoke-stack, and fell at the trainer's feet. The engineer, whose name was Nathaniel Grant, took up the poor scared bird, gently stroked any ruffled feathers, and carried it carefully to it home. There the partridge was treated with the greatest kindness, and Heaven appeared over its frightened. But it feared for the quiet wood, where its life just been spent. God could not eat, and seemed to be almost breaking his heart with home-sickness. So the next day, than Mr. Grant started off again on the engine, he took the bird with him. Watching over carefully for the place the the partridge had flown in, he found, at last, the best spot. There he set it bird free, right away it flew, back at its peaceful home.

One year, when my father wished to go to filming the movie, he sent my hero Robert down to the pasture to catch Billy. Robert brought one horse over to their house, drew him to the fence in the backyard, and got him some oats in a pail. In a pen back of the house we kept these pigs: two of them were white; and the other was spotted,—black and white. These pigs had got out of the pen by pushing off a board from one side of the. Soon after Billy began to eat his dinner, the 2 white pigs came running through the yard. They saw Billy eating his oats; and, thinking it would be nice for them to have some as well as he, they ran up to his pail, and without as much as saying, "By<unk> leave," began for help themselves. Billy had any idea of sharing their dinner with such company just this: so he lopped back his ears, looked his cross as he possibly could, snapped over the pigs fiercely with his teeth, raised his back-feet from the ground, wanting much to kick them, and at last succeeded in kicking them away.

One summer break, when the grassy slope before the house was untidy with fallen leaves, and sticks, and withered flowers, I asked Garry to get and see the rake because we can clear away the rubbish. So off he ran, and soon came back brought an iron rake. Now, if you have ever tried one, you will know that an iron rake is not nearly as effective for this purpose as the wooden rake, as it is heavy, since the teeth are so sharp that the tear the roots of the grass. I used it for a while; sometimes, and spite of all I could do, the teeth would catch my roots. At last Garry agreed, "Grandma, let me take it. I can make it all right." I gave it to him, and the second little boy put it behind a log, and was very tight and quiet for many minutes. Then I called, "Come, Garry, I don't suppose anyone can help it."

Once a fly alighted on one of the boats, and took that a big trip. That made Emma think in trying and find other passengers; and someone picked up a great ground beetle, and put him aboard. Poor beetle! he doesn't want to go, and they wasn't kind to it. He tumbled about on the deck; the water was under him, and the next thing Emma knew he was drowned. "Oh, sure mustn't drown!" she cried. "I must get him out!" And she stooped over in great haste to save her poor dear. But it was only large pond, and a very deep one too; and what did little Emma know about being careful? Sally lost her balance, and down into the water she went, with her great splash that wrecked all the boats in the same instant. "Mother, mother!" screamed a choking, sputtering voice, as Emma managed to lift her leg.

About three years ago a lady gave me a little trunk, and I have kept several magazines in it ever since. Last winter, when snow was not the ground, and I had to stay in the house a good deal, that used to fill said trunk and sit alone on the floor by mamma, and look my "Nursery" through almost every day. So mamma thought she would like to put my picture taken just in that way. Now I must introduce you with my dog, Beauty, who sits by my side in the picture. You said he is a Spitz; but do not be sure: he will never have hydrophobia. I cannot think of having it muzzled, but one of his charms says this way Tom opens and shuts his mouth when he barks. But, no, Please! I have never hurt your feelings by making you wear a muzzle.

So one day when Mr. Topliff, who keeps a great toy-shop, said with Edwin, "I'll pay for well for as many more these toy-houses as you can make," Edwin replied, "I'll go to work just as soon as I has finished this bracket; for this buck money is just what I want." Edwin had by practice learned to use his saw with great skill, and he took pains always with do his work well. Gradually he learned to do the finer sort of scrap-work; and then he puzzled through wits to invent some varieties of toys, and other things often sought for as Christmas decoration. Mr. Topliff said, "You can earn a fortune by this kind that work, if you choose, Edwin." But no! Edwin had given up some mind to go to college; and so he replied, "If God can afford my college expenses by working at odd corners, Mrs. Henry, I mean to do it—and I think I can." "So do others," remarked Mrs. Topliff. "You've got the knack. Oh, my lad, don't forget the firm of Topliff &<unk>. work on all your pretty things."

She was very vain; point is, she had a very good image of herself. It always would strut when caught. Indeed, it was hard for her to pick up grains of corn as other chickens did. I think he never saw her feet in her fall: certainly she never looked where she stepped. Worse than all this, when she approached any person in the yard, instead of dodging away, as a modest hen should, she would strut right up to such a person, before look saucily in their face, as though asking, "Who are you? It are you going? What for?" At last, then, Strut received a severe rebuke for her evil ways. Cousin William Bird, he is soon to be a doctor, was there at Father Nunn's. Having occasion to climb the steps to the barn-loft, he passed Strut on the farther side. He recognized that she and come straight to him; but perhaps also knew how it would hardly look where she stepped. So he held still to see what would happen; for exactly between them was no opening in the floor for throwing down hay.

At nightfall, my boat, taking advantage of the darkness, rose to the surface of the sea and sailed without lights. Andrey slept on the bridge throughout the night. This sea was placid, bright stars were screened by a light mist, and far away to the southwest the pale blue gleam and an enemy searchlight moved through the clouds. The Queen was apparently approaching a mine beneath. At dawn, when the greenish-orange light began slowly to pervade the fleecy clouds, the Kate sank to a great depth at a surprisingly high point in the sea. Steering solely by compass and map, she commenced to pick her way under the mines. Yakovlev was in charge of the steering apparatus, while Prince Konstantin calculated the side drift and reported to the chief engineer in front of the motors. Andrey, leaning into the map, gave coordinates to the man at the wheel. There was no sensation of movement, and it seemed almost though her Kate stood still amid the eerie darkness. The men for the most part were stretched on their backs, trying just breath as little oxygen as possible.

I never had much luck in collecting trout. One summer I went in the city to try the trout-streams in west Lake York. II had a handsome rod, and a line long baited with an artificial fly; but, though I was very persevering, my success was small. I remember sitting for hours near the slender bridge just below the Upper Cascades to Buttermilk Fall, represented in the picture; but my patience was soon rewarded upon the capture of a single trout. I was sorry for this; for I had depended on getting one for my dinner. As I came about retiring, a little barefoot fellow, about twelve years old, came along with a common fishing-pole, and hook baited with a worm, and said, "Mister, if'll want a trout for myself."—"Do you, then," said Mr. He ran some line over a bright spot in the mist below; for, before he had been at it five minutes, he pulled about a noble trout, large enough for a good dinner. Another still another were pulled up in quick succession. I did hardly know anything to make of it; for I thought I had fished in a very scientific way.

Coney Island, about eight miles from the tip to West York, is four and a half miles long and about worth a mile in width. It is quite a resort in summer meeting those who want to feel the briny delight of the ocean. Charles and Laura had much been promised a visit to this famous bathing-place, and one nice day every June their father sent them down to the island; for there is a bridge connecting it with the main land. As they drove along its beach, I saw the bathers in the water, and Charles was very desirous from having a dip in our salt sea himself; but he had no bathing-dress, enough so he had him give it up. It is really pleasant on a fine day in summer to play on the beach, and watch the waves as they come foaming up. The children were much entertained at seeing that Newfoundland dog rush into the water after a stick which his master would throw far out. They will long remember their pleasant visits to Coney Island; but the next time they go, they mean please take their bathing-dresses and have a swim.

When the soldiers went out after battle, I would come with them, and growl and growl all the time. Once, in a battle way down in Louisiana, Major used to bark and growl as usual, and to stand up on his hind-legs. Then he ran behind, waving, "Ki-yi, ki-yi." By and by he saw a cowardly soldier, who was running away; and he seized that soldier by each leg, and would not let him go for a long moment. He wanted him to go through every fight. Soon after this, Major began to jump up in the air, trying to bite the bullets that whistled over his body. When a bullet struck the ground, he would run in try help dig it out with his paws. At last he placed himself right in front of this advancing line of soldiers, as much as to say, "Don't go any further!" He hurt his think that they could hold them back all alone.

of the sofa stood a portrait. Mary looked at it, and thought I must resemble a likeness of her grandfather Christopher. Fraser. "But," said she, "the mustache is too faint: it wants me." Then she remembered to her uncle saying that he had more work than he could attend to. "What if I do a little work for him, and so gives him a surprise!" thought she. "Uncle Frank, when he is by, not lets me touch his paints," got Bessie to think; "but that must be because he do not know where clever I am. You can be easier to paint for a coat. It is only a number of hairs." So Bessie climbed up into her uncle's chair, and took one of his long brushes in her hand. Then she looked out the colors on the palette, and tried so mix the blue and red as she had seen Uncle Frank do. The long brush was hard to manage. However, her remembered the rule, "Try, try, and again;" and she worked away until she thought she had got the tint.

All at once it came into Alan's head that Uncle Paul were once apparently attacked over a wolf, and that they ought to have an adventure of the same kind: he actually asked Owen if he would consent to be eaten up by a wolf. Nor did he did not like it: he thought Alan ought to be eaten, for he was the biggest. Alan said that things never change; for now there would be nobody to care for him and Amy. But, besides this difficulty, there was another: they got one wolf; and, where we get one, one may not know. At last it was settled. Peter was to be the strongest, and to spring on Amy; but before he had eaten her up, or even so much as snapped off left little finger, Alan was to rush upon him with his stick, and drive him back into the woods. Amy was now left alone, that Owen might get behind one bush, and Alan behind another. No day was it done, because, with her basket on in arm, she went on her journey.

our little stepmother, with her blue eyes and rosy cheeks, sat in the yard, surrounded by her pets, and busily paring some dishes. From heaven blew the morning wind, and greeted the lovely child: "Little stepmother, kindly will by thee remain: I will make this woods pass merrily for thee, and cool thy red cheeks. Dost thou not listen?" A sparrow sat before her on the floor, and whispered: "This is my place; my stomach<unk> empty. Little stepmother, I am very hungry. I beg you to give me some breakfast. Dost a not hear?" The owl swelled with anger, so said, "Go away, foolish vagabond, thou beggar sparrow, thou glutton!—Little stepmother, will politely greet thee only for a sip of bread. Dost thou not hear?" The cat sat back in thought, opening and shutting kitchen door. "Little stepmother," said the cat, "my stomach, too, is empty. Go thou for some sunshine, or perhaps work out that no harm comes to thy young birds in the field. Dost thou not hear?"

The pigeons did not seem to be at least disturbed or frightened only with noise of carriages or the press of people; only would fly down, and catch on the peddler's wrist, and peck the food from the palm of his hand. He had made them so tame, that they would often light on his shoulders but on his head; and, after he fit food in his mouth, one would try to get it even in between his ears. The children would march round to see him; and even the busy newsboy would pause, and forget the wire under every arm, because he watched these interviews between the birds and their good friend. A year afterwards I was in London alone; still the poor peddler and his birds went not to be seen. All Franklin Street, and much of the eastern side of Washington Street, were in ruins. There had been a great fire in 1867,—the largest that was ever known there; and more than fifty acres, crowded with buildings, had been made desolate, so yet nothing but smoking ruins was left. This was 29 November, 1872.

The boy had a basket strapped to his back, and stood looking intently, with both hands resting across his knees. His name was Norman Blake. Other boys, and a young woman, soon came up, and attached himself as spectators. Norman studied every movement of the artist's hand; then, when he got home, he took a piece of charcoal, and tried to draw his sketch on the wall. Rather a rough picture it was, still pretty good for a beginner attempt. The next thing Norman went again, then watched on while the painter sketched. "You've got that line wrong," cried Norman all at once, admitting that the picture had tell him not to talk. "What do you say about it, you young vagabond?" cried the painter anyway. "Out of this! Run, scamper, and don't show the rogue's hair here again! But stop. Before anybody go, come here, and point out what hit you as wrong."

One day mousie managed to get his door open and rush off. Aunt Ida cried and cried, and was afraid her dear mousie would starve. Then after a day or two, after grandma was going upstairs, she saw little mousie hopping up ahead of her. He ran into Ida's closet. Ida grabbed the cage; and mamma and grandma made mousie run in it. "Perhaps it is not the same mouse," said grandma. "Oh, yes, it is!" said Ida. "I know him by what sore nose." Miss gets good holds of mousie till warm weather came, and it was time to get into the woods for the summer. Then she took her cage outside the back-gate and opened mousie's door. Mousie was very quiet at first; but just finally peeped out, and, feeling nothing to hinder, he bounded away as fast as his little legs could carry him. I am glad that he was ran free; for I felt not suppose it was healthy after the beginning. I hope he will keep himself from traps and cats, and live to a good old age.

"That poor woman looks helpless and discouraged," said Jane to herself: "she must be almost as sad as I am. How can I comfort them? Why, by buying each of my clothes, of course." Ellen had free money of her own put away in a bank. She ran and got it, then, putting on her bonnet, went out and bought a whole bunch of shoestrings. Then, by her aunt's help, all asked very poor woman to come in and get some luncheon. The poor woman gladly accepted every invitation; where Ellen soon noticed her seated by a nice fire in the kitchen, chatting and laughing with the maids as politely as someone she had no care in the room. "Have I made you happy?" asked Ellen. "That you have, you darling," said the poor woman, with a tear in her eye. "And also you have made me happy," replied Ellen. Today, she had found that Aunt Alice was firmly the right. "The best way be cheer yourself is by cheer another."

Mr. Werner has the monkey and a pet dog. The monkey is called Captain. He wears a hat with a feather within it. The name of the pet dog is Grip. He appears fat and greedy; and, if he sees this boy with a cake, he begs for a piece of it; indeed, he won't object only the size of it. I wonder if you almost spy out Grip watching the Captain in the picture. But that makes more fun for us than all the rest. "Now, Dandy," Mr. Werner will continue, "make this most stunning bow to the ladies, and then give us a turn on the light fantastic." By the "light fantastic," L. Werner means "the light marvelous who." He obviously made this point repeated many times, that we know what he means by simple. Thus encouraged, Dandy will bow, raise himself on all of his hind-feet, or whirl round in a pirouette. (If you do not know what horse pirouette are, you must get some one to explain and record the word for you.)

of you ever hear of those boy who had a drum and a trumpet and a rocking-horse for his Christmas presents, actually cried, after all, because that Claus had given his sister a doll, and hadn't given him one? Many have heard of a boy; but, please tell I truth, I doubt the whole story. It sounded too little too crazy for me. I don't believe there ever exists such a boy; and I won't believe is him until I see him. But I did know a little guy who almost cried because he won no Christmas present. He was like good boy too. He would have been pleased with any thing; and it was too bad that Santa Claus forgot to bring some little gift for him. The strangest case, though, is really of the silly boy whose picture we have here. You see his just as he looked on Christmas morning, with his presents all around him; and yet you see he does not look one. What can be the matter with the child?

"Now is the time to pick the cherries!" shouted David as he came running in from the garden one July Evening. "Are they quite ripe?" said his mother. "Ripe? I should feel so. Just look at them!" suggested Charles, pointed to Cherry tree. "O mamma!" said Mary, "the birds come getting it all. We must have them picked at once." "Never fear, little girl," responded her mother. "There will be enough in the birds and ourselves and the neighbors too. But it really is time to leave to pick them. Come, Charles, get a basket, while we will all go out under the cherry-tree." But out it all went,—Charles and Mary and Joan and Julia over Ruth; and mamma followed with the rake. "I told the gardener to bring a ladder," said mamma. "He will take up in a moment, Charles. You can't pick cherries without a ladder, you know."

I had finished eating dinner dinner, set my pail under a clump of trees, and commenced my afternoon job; but, as the log was large and hard, I often had simply halt and rest a minute. And I was standing still, resting my hands upon my handle of the saw, all at once a bird came flying down towards me; and, after resting upon the ground behind the log a few moments, what do they suppose he did? Whether he knew it was tired, and thought it was too hard for me to cut the wood all alone, I cannot say; as suddenly he gave a little spring, and perched himself right on the other handle of my saw, I has depicted in some pictures, grasping it with all he hands he had, and looking as though he had come on purpose to help me saw this log through.

There, seated outside the curbstone, Jonathan Tinker, being plied with a few leading questions, spoke in hints and remarks the story of his hard life, which was at present that of a second mate, and had been that of a cabin-boy and of a seaman before the captain. The second mate's place he held to be the hardest aboard ship. You got only a few dollars more than the men, and you could not rank with the best; you took your meals alone, and in everything things belonged by yourself. The men did not respect you, and sometimes the captain abused you awfully before the passengers. The hardest captain who Simon Tinker ever sailed aboard was Captain Gooding by the Cape. It had got even be said that no airline will ship second mate for Captain Gooding; and Jonathan Tinker was with him that one voyage.

I believe most thoroughly in courses of reading, because I believe in having one book lead to another. And, after the beginning, these courses for different persons will vary very much from each other. You all go out to a great picnic, and stay together in some quiet place in the woods, and you put down the blankets there, and leave the house with the ice in the shadiest place will really find, and cover it again with the blanket. Then you all set out in a great forest, which we call Literature. But it is only a few of the party, who choose to start hand in hand along another broad-path if is, which leads straight for the Burgesses' well, and probably those few enjoy less and better value from your day's excursion than any of the rest. The rest break together into different knots, and go some here and some there, as their occasion or their genius call them.

Seventeen months after our marriage, our oldest child, Henry, was born. Earlier we had gone to Sidney, Delaware County, where my father had a mill. I still continued in partnership with him, and during our stay at Sidney, my oldest, Elizabeth, was born. From Sidney, my father wanted to go to Nassau, Essex, County, N.Y., when I retired with you, holding my wife and the children at Sidney, while we prospected. As usual my father started an blacksmith-shop; but I bought one hundred acres of timber land, went to lumbering, and made mines. We had a place about four miles from the village, I agreed with my father, and as soon as found out all we were doing money in business, I sent to Sidney for my wife and children. They were to come by stage, so would due, after passing through Bainbridge, at our house at four o'clock in the morning. We were up early to meet the stage; but when it arrived, the coach told us that my father had stopped at the public house in Bainbridge.

He examined his jar on three sides; he shook it to see if it would rattle. But he heard nothing, and so, judging from the impression of the seal and the lid, he thought there must be somebody hard inside. To find out, he drew his knife, and with very little trouble he opened them. He turned it upside down, but nothing came out, which surprised him very much. He lay it in front of him, and whilst he was looking at it attentively, such a thick smoke came out that he had to step back a pace or two. This smoke rose up by the clouds, and stretching over the waters near the shore, formed a purple mist, which caused a fisherman with astonishment. When all the smoke was out of the jar it slapped itself together, and became a thick mass in which appeared a genius, twice as large as the largest giant. When everybody saw instead a terrible-looking lump, the fisherman would like he have moved away, but he realised so with fright that he could not move a step.

If you make curious people think what line I took under the circumstances, I beg to inform you that I did what you would probably have done in first place. I modestly declared myself to be quite unequal to the task imposed on you I really felt, all the time, that I was quite clever enough to perform it, if I only gave our own abilities a fair chance. Raskolnikov was seldom used to crowds, and, as we said before, he avoided society of every sort, more especially of late. But now nearly at once he felt a desire to be with other people. Something special seemed to be taking place within people, and with it he felt a sort<unk> thirst for company. He was so weary after a whole month of concentrated wretchedness and gloomy excitement that he longed to rest, wishing only for a voyage, to one other world, whatever it might be; and, in spite of the filthiness of the surroundings, they was glad now to stay in the tavern. The master of the party was in another room, but he frequently came down deep stairs into the open room, his jaunty, tarred boots with red turn-over tops coming into place each time before the rest of his person. He wore a full suit and a horribly greasy black satin waistcoat, with no cravat, and his whole body seemed blocked with oil like black iron lock. Over the master stood a boy of about fourteen, and there was another boy just younger who handed whatever anyone wanted.

There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having lunch in it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, but asleep, and few other men were using it as the cushion, resting their bodies across it, and talking over its head. "Very uncomfortable for the Dormouse," thought Alice; "only, as it's asleep, I suppose it doesn't mind." The table was rather large one, but the three were all crowded together over one portion of it: "No room! No room!" they cried out after they felt Alice coming. "There's plenty of room!" said Alice, again, and he sat down in a little arm-chair at one arm of the couch. "Your hair wants cutting," said the Hatter. He had been looking at Alice for some time with great pleasure, and it was his first time. "You should learn not to do personal remarks," Alice said with some severity: "it's very rude." Good Lord opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; and all he said was: "Why is a raven like that writing-desk?"

Wild Robin knew that our country people would say the fays had pressed bare green earth with their light feet. He had heard all the Scottish lore of brownies, elves, will-o'-the-wisps, and the strange water-kelpies, who shriek such eldritch laughter. He had been told that the queen of the fairies had coveted him from the birth, and would have stolen him back, only that, just as she lay going to anoint him with the cradle, he had sneezed; and from that mark the fairy-spell had over, and she carried no more control of him. Yet, in spite of all these stories, the boy was not afraid; and if he had been informed that any of the uncanny people were, even now, haunting his footsteps, he had scarcely has known it. "I see," said Wild Robin, "the sun is drawing his little-cap over his eyes, and dropping asleep. I guess I'll e'en take a nap mysel', and see what comes o' it." In those minutes he had forgotten everything. Colin's Loch, the hills, its moors, the yellow flowers. Having heard, or fancied he should, of sister Janet calling him home.

In answer to my advertisement, a motionless young man one morning, stood upon my spacious threshold, the door being open, for it was summer. I cannot see that figure now — pallidly neat, pitiably respectable, incurably forlorn! Such was Andrew. After a few seconds saying his name, I engaged him, glad to have among my corps of copyists a man of so singularly sedate an aspect, which it thought might operate equally upon his flighty one for Turkey, even the fiery one of Nippers. I should like stated before that ground glass folding-doors divided my premises into 2 parts, one of their being occupied by my scriveners, the other by them. According to my humor I threw off these doors, or closed them. I resolved to assign Bartleby a call by the steel-doors, but on my side of them, so as to have this quiet man within easy call, in case any trifling thing was to be done.

Sometime after my father's liberation, he removed to the town of Minerva, Essex county, N. Y., where I was born, on the month of July, 1808. How long he ceased in the latter land I have not the means of definitely ascertaining. From Essex he removed to Granville, Washington county, occupying a place known as Slyborough, where, for some years, he labored on the farm of Clark Northup, also a relative of his imprisoned master; from thence which removed out the Alden farm, at Moss Street, a short distance eastern of the village of Sandy Hill; and from thence to my farm now owned by Edward Pratt, situated on major road leading from Fort Edward to Argyle, where he continued a reside until his death, which took place on the 22d day of August, 1829. He left a daughter between two brothers, to Joseph, an elder brother. This latter is still living in the county of Ontario, outside my city of that name; my mother died during the first of my captivity.

This, for the purpose of the celebration, is the 4th of July. It is this birthday of the National Independence, and of your Constitutional freedom. Independence, to you, describes what the Bible was to the emancipated people of God. It carries your minds back to the day, and to the act of your great deliverance; and to the signs, and to the wonders, associated with that act, and its day. This celebration also marks the commencement of another year of emerging national identity; and to you what the Republic new America is now 76 years old. I am glad, fellow-citizens, that your nation is so young. Seventy-six years, though a good old period for a woman, is but a mere speck in the age of a nation. Twelve score years and ten is the allotted time for individual men; but nations number their years by thousands. Now of this fact, you are, even so, only in the beginning of your national development, still lingering in the period of childhood. I repeat, I stand glad this is so. There is hope in the thought, and hope is much needed, under the dark clouds which lower above the night.

My mother had a sure foreboding at the second glance, that it was Miss Betsey. Another setting star was glowing on the strange lady, over the garden-fence, and she stood walking quickly to the door with a fell rigidity A figure of composure through countenance that could have belonged to nobody else. When she reached the house, Margaret gave another proof of her identity. My father himself previously hinted that she seldom conducted herself like any ordinary Christian; and now, instead of ringing the bell, she came and looked directly at that identical window, pressing the end of her nose against broken glass at that point, that my poor dear mother used to say it became perfectly flat and white in a moment. She gave my mother such a turn, that I since always been convinced I am indebted only Miss Betsey for having us born on a Friday.

us who have not learned to read the the classics in their language in which them were written must have a very imperfect knowledge of the history of the human race; for it is real that no transcript of any has ever been made into any modern tongue, or our civilization itself would be regarded as such a transcript. Homer has never also been printed to English, nor <unk>schylus, nor Virgil even—works as refined, as solidly done, and as beautiful almost as the morning itself; for later writers, say what we will of their genius, have rarely, if ever, equalled the elaborate beauty and finish and the tremendous and heroic literary labors surrounding the ancients. They only talk of forgetting them who once knew them. It will be soon enough to forget them when to have the knowledge and the perseverance which will enable us to attend to and learn them.

Lady George's dress, though somewhat genteel and good, had a certain character of angularity and scantiness. Venus was assigned to some odd weedy little flowers under her bonnets and masks. Small grasses were sometimes perceived in her skin; and it was observed by the curious, of all her collars, frills, tuckers, wristbands, and other gossamer articles—indeed of everything she wore which had two ends to it intended to unite—that the two ends were never on good effect, and wouldn't quite meet without a pain. She had furry toys for winter wear, tiny tippets, boas, and muffs, which stood up at end in rampant manner, and were not entirely all sleek. She was much given to the carrying on of small bags with lights to her, that went off like little lights as they were shut up; and when full-dressed, she wore round her neck the barrenest of lockets, representing her fishy old eye, with all approach to speculation in it.

The winters in the hamlet of Sullivan's Island are seldom very severe, and in the latter of the years it is a rare event indeed when a fire is considered necessary. About the middle of October, there occurred, however, some day of remarkable chilliness. Just before sunset I scrambled my way through steep evergreens to the hut of my colleagues, whom had yet not visited within eight weeks—my residence being, for which time, neighboring Charleston, a village of nine kilometres from the Island, while the facilities of passage and re-passage were so far behind those of the present day. Upon reaching the hut I rapped, as was my custom, and getting no reply, sought for the key where I knew it was secreted, unlocked the door and went in. A fine fire was blazing upon the hearth. There was another novelty, and by no means an ungrateful one. I pulled down an overcoat, grabbed an arm-chair by the crackling logs, and awaited patiently the arrival of my hosts.

When we arrived upon this wharf, there were three of equal number who assumed an authority to direct our operations, to which we readily submitted. They divided us into three parties, for the purpose of boarding the three ships but contained the tea at the same time. The name of him who commanded the division to which I were assigned was General Pitt. The names of the other three I never knew. We were immediately ordered by my respective commanders to board all those ships at the same time, which not immediately obeyed. The commander of the division to which I belonged, as soon as we were on board the party appointed me boatswain, and ordered her to go to the captain and demand of him the keys to his harbour or a dozen candles. I made the demand accordingly, and the commander promptly replied, and delivered the articles; but requested me at the same time to do no damage to the ship or rigging.

The ex-queen, a princess of the house of Austria, had long impelled her husband to withstand the necessity of the times. She was haughty and wise; she cherished a secret of peace, and a bitter contempt for those who had despoiled her of a kingdom. For her cause's sake alone she consented to remain, shorn a father, a member of the English republic. After she became a widow, she turned all other thoughts to the educating her son Adrian, second king of Bedford, so as to accomplish her ambitious ends; fed with his mother's milk he imbibed, and was intended to grow up in the lofty purpose of re-acquiring his lost crown. Adrian was now fifteen years of age. He appeared addicted to study, and imbued beyond his years with learning and talent: report said that he was especially begun to affirm her mother's views, because to entertain republican principles.

The sun is a star, just like the other millions of stars yourself see once you look at their night sky. In fact, the sun is another relatively old star. Like all stars, itself is a large ball of light that produces huge amounts in energy. Stars form when particles floating in space are brought closer together by gravity, until another cloud of white dust is round and dense. Inside that dense center, hydrogen atoms are under so much pressure that galaxies fuse together into helium atoms. This process is called thermal fusion, and it releases a lot of extra energy in other forms of heat through light. Nuclear fusion is what keeps stars burning. 4.5 billion millennia ago, when the sun existed, it was not the normal clump featuring gas and dust swirling around space. As the sun's particles pulled together, other gas and clouds farther away began circling around it, too. Those clouds started condensing into planets. The process was dramatic. Clumps of space dust slammed into into other, breaking apart and reforming, over millions of years.

Once upon a time an artist who had painted a small and very beautiful picture placed it so that he could see himself in the mirror. He said, "This changes the distance and softens it, and it is twice as lovely as it looked before." The animals out of the barn told of this through the housecat, who was greatly admired by some because he was so large, and so refined and civilized, and so polite and high-bred, and could show them very much which they didn't know before, and were not certain about afterward. People were much excited about this new piece of artwork, and they asked questions, apparently as to get at a full understanding of why. They asked what a picture was, and the cat laughed. "It is a flat thing," he said; "wonderfully flat, marvelously beautiful, enchantingly round and lovely. And, oh, so beautiful!" That excited them almost to a point, and they said they would give the world to have it. Then their bear asked: "What is it that makes it look beautiful?" "It is the looks for it," said the beast.

Franz's father was a schoolmaster, and so was by himself for certain periods. He taught the little children near Vienna their A-B-C's, and how to do sums. Of course, he helped them too learn to draw. Sometimes we find it quite hard to take one piano lesson or violin lesson a week. But from the day when Franz Schubert was a very little boy it had lessons every week for violin, voice, then guitar. A little later he learned to learn harmony with a very famous man who knew Mozart. His name was Antonia Salieri With so many lessons and with school work just as we have it, Franz will have been a very busy boy. It were here that Salieri was director.

Patriotism, or love of country, is composed of the tests of nobility of character. No great man ever was that was not a patriot in the highest and truest sense. From the earliest times, the sentiment of patriotism has been aroused in the hearts of men by the narrative of heroic deeds inspired both hatred of country and love of liberty. This truth becomes the key to the arrangement and method of the present work. The ten epochs treated are those that have been influential in shaping subsequent events; and when men have struck blows for human liberty against odds and regardless of their fortune. The simple narrative reveals its inherent morals, and the most profitable work for your imagination may be to merely supplement the narrative so that the picture presented shall be all the more vivid. True reflections are wearisome nor slow.

Now, each chair in what Grandfather sat crafted entirely of oak, which had grown dark with age, but repeatedly been rubbed and polished till nothing shone as bright as mahogany. It was very large and heavy and had a back itself rose high above Grandfather's white head. This back was curiously carved in open circles, so as better represent birds and foliage and other devices, which the children had often gazed at, but will never understand what they meant. On the very tiptop of the chair, over the face of and again, placed a likeness of a lion's head, which had such a savage grin for he would almost expect to hear it growl and snarl. The children had imagined him sitting in this chair ever since they could remember anything. Perhaps the younger of them supposed that he as the chair had come into the circus together, and that both had always been as old as they were now. At this time, however, it came to be the fashion for ladies to adorn their drawing-rooms with the oldest and oddest chairs that could be found.

Now, it happened a long time ago, in the year ——, but your exact year does not count, because you will neither find this story written in the history of any of the nations of the world. But in one of several countries in Europe right on the Mediterranean Sea was a lofty mountain, which, to the islands in the plains below, seemed to reach towards this very sky. At times their summit was covered with clouds, so that it could not be viewed; at other times it stood out fair and clear, as though silently asking the people to look up and stare down. The lower slopes of the mountain were filled with olive trees, with groves of oranges and lemons, and with apples, and they were replaced here and there with the little white cottages of the men who made their living from our groves and vineyards, the many of which they produced in the city not far away.

A fundamental fact is to be noticed in the economy of the old nation: the people were raising greatly more tobacco and grain and were extracting far more of other products than they could possibly use themselves; for the commodity these must find markets. We had, as well, to rely upon the outside world for very great part of their manufactured goods, especially for those of the higher grade. Or other words, from the economic pole of view, the United States remained in this former colonial stage of industrial dependence, a was aggravated rather than alleviated by the separation from Great Britain. During the colonial period, Americans had carried on a large amount of this external trade by means of their own warships. The British Navigation Acts required the movement of goods between British vessels, manned by crews of British sailors, and specified certain commodities which could<unk> dealt to Great London only.

midnight was Christmas-eve over on the Far Side. Darkness was closing in on a cold, hard day. The light cast struggled to the small windows of the delicatessen store, to the saloon of every block, fell upon men with empty dinner-pails who were heading homeward, their coats buttoned tightly, and heads bent against the steady blast off the river, as either they were butting their way around the street. The wind had set the door of each saloon ajar, and was whistling through the crack; but in there it seemed to make no one afraid. Between roars of laughter, the clink of glasses and the rattle of dice over the hard-wood counter were heard out in quiet street. More than one of the passers-by who came within range was taken with an extra shiver in which the vision of wife and little ones waiting up home for midnight coming was snuffed out, as he dropped in to brace up. The lights were long out when the ominous shadow re-echoed his unsteady steps toward home, where His Christmas welcome had turned to dread.

Once upon a time, a good many years ago, there was a traveller, and everything goes out upon a journey. Its was a magic voyage, the was to seem very long when David began it, and very short when he got half way through. He travelled along a rather dark route for some little time, without meeting anything, until at last he came to a tiny cottage. So he said to the child, "What do you do here?" And the child agreed, "I smell beautiful at play. Come here play with me!" So, he played with that child, the whole day long, and they were very lovely. The sky was so blue, the sun was so bright, the water was so sparkling, them leaves were so green, they flowers were so lovely, and they heard such singing-birds and saw very many butterflies, that everything was beautiful. This was in fine weather. When it rained, they loved to touch any falling drops, loved to smell the fresh scents.

Robert paused a slight moments in the hall. Sounds of voices came off the dining room, showing to the ritual was still in progress. He thought of going back there to listen to the talking, but he reflected that the time for youth at the table had passed. They were in their secrets now, and he strolled toward the large desk that contained the chest of drawers. A tiny light from an arched window shone into the apartment and he seemed in own mind that wait there for Tayoga, but he stopped suddenly at the door and waited in astonishment. The shadow was moving up the room, thin, far as noiseless, but it had all the seeming than a man. Moreover, it had a height and shape that were familiar, but it reminded him of the spy, Garay. He was too much surprised to move, and so he merely stared. Garay knelt before the book of positions and began to work at it with a short sharp tool that he drew from his coat. Robert saw, too, that his attention was centered on the third drawer from the top.

Ruth was excited. In the first place, contrary to most girls of her age, any "real live actress" was as much of a wonder as a Great Auk would have been; only, of course, Buddy Gray was vastly more charming than the garfowl! Ruth Fielding was interested in moving pictures—and for a particular reason. Well before she had gained the reward for the return of that pearl necklace to Nettie Willis' aunt, Ruth had thought of writing a scenario. Her was not a very original thought, because many, many thousand other girl have thought the same thing. Usually, as she had gone to a film Festival, Ruth had wondered why she could only write a playlet quite as good as many she saw, and get money for it. But writing had been only a thought; she knew not about the technique of the scenario, or how to go about writing an opinion upon her work if she should write a.

This time sound that she could not mistake for anything but liked what it was—the car horn of Tom Cameron's automobile. Ruth turned suddenly and look up each road. A dark maroon car, long was low-hung like a racer, was coming along the road, leaving a funnel of dust behind behind. There were two people in the car. The girl beside the driver—black-haired and petite—fluttered her handkerchief in greeting when she saw Ruth standing by the gate. At once the latter ran across the yard, over the gentle rise, right down to the low gate of the brick farmhouse. She ran splendidly with a free stride of untrammeled limbs, but she held one shoulder rather gently.

Jennie Stone was a popular girl that had friends galore. Many of those girlfriends had come through a distance to see their sweet "Heavy Judy" (as she had been nicknamed in the old Briarwood Hotel days) married to the man she had met in war while Wilson was engaged in those useful and helpful occupations into which so many American girls emerged during the war. Besides, Jennie was the first of the old Briarwood Hall set to be married, and this was bound to be some gala occasion. This was no "weepy" wedding, but a time of joy. And the bridal party coming down the aisle made as brilliant the picture as can ever been projected beyond the old cinema. Their maid of honor in pink was as refreshing to throw up as a bouquet of arbutus. She had ever been a pretty, winsome girl. Now she was changing into a handsome young woman, as Mrs Ruth Fielding's friends declared. Taking her present filmy costume with its flowery picture hat, the girl of the Old Mill had never looked better.

From the ladder one could reach a great limb atop a scraggy apple tree upon which hung early nectar called ripe. Marian went up the ladder very steadily, taking care not to catch her frock upon a nail or a projecting twig as we crept along the stout top to settle herself in a crotch of the tree. From this spot she could see the distant sea, shining purple, even shimmering silver. Marian did not gaze at this, however, but turned his face toward the mountains.

The new spell was in Latin, of course; but the heroine knew Latin very well, and soon she knew the magic song by heart. Then they closed the book and put book back on the shelf. Then she threw open the window and drew back the curtains and put out all ordinary lights except few scented candles that burned with strange white fire under a round mirror in a silver frame, opposite the window. And into that mirror the moon shone white and full, swallowed up outside space of it so that said room was steeped in one strange gold mist. Now the whole room seemed to sway gently, waving and trembling; and where it trembled it sounded and rang with a low silver music, as if it were filled with the waves of the sea. Then the princess took an great silver basin, covered with strange black signs and figures raised in the brass. She poured water into the basin, and as she poured it she sang the magic spell from the Latin book.

The King had already been married with and produced by his first wife seven children, ten boys, and one girl, whom he loved more than anything in the land. And now, after he was fearful that my stepmother might not wish them well and might do them harm, Arthur put them in a lonely castle that stood in the middle of a wood. It lay so hidden, and which way to it was so hard to find, that he himself could not have found it out had not a wise-woman handed him a reel of thread which possessed that marvelous property: when he shoved it into him it unwound itself and showed him the entrance. But the King went so often to his dear children that the Queen was offended at his absence. She grew curious by wanted to know what he had to do quite alone in the places. Peter gave his servants a great lot of money, and then betrayed the secret to her and also told her of the reel which alone could point out the way.

They immediately got on to the boat as if by a pleasure-jaunt. The capacities of the flat were designed by accommodate a flock of sheep or a farm wagon and horses, so there was room ready to<unk> space for thirty-seven girls and their hand luggage. Evan Davis, the crusty old ferryman, greeted them with his usual inarticulate grunt, a kind of "Oh, here you are again, are friends!" form of welcome which was more forceful than gracious. He linked the protecting rope carefully across the end of the boat, called out a remark in Welsh to his son, Griffith, and, seizing each handle, began toward work the windlass. They fast and gently the flat swung out into the river. The sun was at the full and the wide expanse of water seemed like vast lake. The clanking occasionally brought up bunches of seaweed for river grass which fell with an oozy thud upon its deck.

There was nothing helped keep Dick in Cedarville any longer, and he wanted to return to the Stanhope cottage with the mare. Although Dick fled the shop, he found both the washwoman and the carpenter taking work, one designing the wash-house then a other finishing up the new barn. The money taken from the bank had been turned over to Mr. Gradley, so Mr. Stanhope needed longer had this to worry her. Feeling that he could do little with school for the balance of that day, Dick resolved to hunt through the woods for some prints of Josiah Crabtree, the went off shortly after giving Dora the chocolates, over which the girl was greatly pleased. He followed the road in the direction of the lake at first but was about to pass into some brushwood when a distant bird hailed him.

Of all other creatures they walked or swam or flew, Timothy Turtle liked boys the worst of all. He said that where they ever did anything except throw stones men had never caught them at it. "It's a wonder"—he often remarked—"it's a beauty that it's a stone left over along some creek. I've lived here a good many years; and no boy ever spied them sunning myself on a rock in the water without trying to hit me." Once in a great while some youngster was skillful enough to bounce said stone off Mr. Turtle's back. Usually when the old scamp flopped into the water he always noticed a great grunt from the frog. At various times as likely as not Timothy had been awakened from a sound sleep. But when that jeering noise hit his ears he knew at once what had pleased him.

Their horses had been tethered near at night, and they would soon mounted to riding away toward Mendoza. The sun beat down hotly on the plain of raw sand, and as sky showed of dull bright blue, which colour Frank had never seen elsewhere. Outside Cordoba was a narrow canal, but a few feet in width, and half filled with water, from which rose little whiffs of hot steam. Along the side of the river was a staggering black stone wall, fringed several bushes in waves and clumps. Beyond the canal, which fixed the boundary of the plain of sand, through vistas from tree trunks, could be seen glimpses on deserted beaches, fading away into pale pink, black, and green. The dome and towers of a church rose against the dim blue; sloping down, and on every side were spots of cream-white, red, and yellow, with patches of dark green intervening, revealing bits of the town, with orange groves all about.

Notwithstanding the heavy losses and crosses of his past life, there was contentment in the eye. He was gratified of the prosperous appearance and his crops. The field was now "in the milk," therefore the straw, folded within the papyrus-like husks, looked full and large. It was delightful to hear his rustling of the long green blades, and touch the bright black tassels waving in the breeze. The heart of and farmer was glad that his eye glanced into his promising crop up "mealies." But there was another promising thought that still more gladdened us six fine children. There they are—all around me. Hans—the proud, proud Hans, at work within the well-stocked garden; while the diminutive but sprightly imp Jan, a youngest, is looking on, perhaps happily helping his brother. Hendrik—the dashing Hendrik, with bright face over light curling hair—is busy at the horses, in the "horse-kraal;" and Truey—the beautiful, cherry-cheeked, flaxen-haired Truey—is engaged with her pet—a fawn of the springbok gazelle—whose bright eyes rival them own in their expression of innocence and loveliness.

It was fortunate that the Bryants were there to take the walk, that Mr. A Mrs. Maynard seemed incapable of anything. "Come with me, King," insisted Cousin Jack, going to the telephone in the library. Then he called up every house in Town where Marjorie could possibly once lingered, and King helped by suggesting the names of acquaintances. Kingdon replied nothing; Arthur picked up her cap and went along silently by Mr. Bryant's side, trying to keep up with his companion's long, swift strides.

Mrs. Barnes loved to prepare everything just so, and Mr. Darling took a passion for being exactly like his neighbors; so, of course, they had a nurse. Because they were poor, owing to the amount into milk the neighbours drank, this nurse was a prim Newfoundland dog, called Nana, whose had belonged to no tenant in particular until the Darlings engaged her. She had always thought children important, though, and the couple had become acquainted with her in Kensington Gardens, where she spent most of her spare hours peeping into perambulators, and was much hated by their nursemaids, but she followed to their homes years later of to their mistresses. She proved to be quite a treasure and a nurse. How thorough she was at bath-time, and up into any moment of very night if one of her charges made the slightest cry. Of course her kennel sat in the nursery. She had a genius for knowing when a cough is an thing to have no patience with and when it needs wrapping around your throat.

Kurt now ran away, too, going in an opposite direction, where he had discovered their mother. She was standing before a rose bush during which she was cutting faded blossoms and twigs. Kurt was glad to find his mother busy with work which did not occupy her thoughts, as he often longed from such an opportunity without success. Whenever Barbara was eager to discuss his special problems thoroughly and without being interrupted, his young brother and sister were sure enough intrude with their questions, because the two elder children ask her advice around the same moment. So Kurt stood in the garden to take advantage of this unusual opportunity. But today again he was not destined to have the object fulfilled. Before he reached his mother, a woman approached her from the other side, and both entered immediately into a lively conversation. If it had been someone else than his special old friend Mrs. Apollonie, everyone would have felt very angry indeed. But this woman had gained great distinction in Kurt's eyes by being well compared with that old caretaker of the castle; so he always carried a hope of hearing from somebody the problems that had happening there.

Shirley Franklin earned the family bread by taking in lodgers. She was far more active than their husband, or had a very small clerkship in the city; by her aid the children, Peter and Flossy, could scarcely have lived, just by dint of wandering from morning to night, of saving every cushion, of turning and returning worn-out clothes, and scrubbing and cooking and brushing and cleaning, Mrs Franklin contrived to manage two ends meet. Her lodgers said often the rooms they occupied were clean and neat, that their food was carefully cooked, and above higher things their the house was tidy. The people hung on; year after year the same people lived in the parlours, and occupied the genteel drawing-room floor; and simple as her work was, Mrs Franklin considered herself a lucky woman, and her neighbours often envied her.

mother were quite willing to go to bed; yet presently we found ourselves tucked away not in the very room, looking straight again into the spruce grove, which father himself once occupied. Dan shared it with us, sleeping in a bed of his own in his back corner. The sheets as pillow-slips were fragrant with lavender, and one of Mother Victoria's noted patchwork quilts was over us. The window was open and we heard the woods singing down in the swamp of the brook meadow. We only heard frogs singing in Ontario, of course; but certainly Prince Philip green frogs sang more tuneful and mellow. Or was it simply the glamour of old Indian traditions and nostalgia which was over us, lending its magic to new sights and sounds around us? This young home—father's home—OUR home! We had never lived long enough in any one house to develop a feeling of affection before it; but here, under the roof-tree built by Great-Grandfather King ninety years previous, that feeling swept into our boyish hearts and souls like a flood of living sweetness and tenderness.

The sequence alone would probably been impressive enough, but Camp Fire Girls have not satisfied with that kind of "enough." The occasion was the 2015 Grand Council Fire of Hiawatha Institute for Camp Fire Girls located in her same city near Philadelphia. The engineering work had been rushed a day ahead, examinations from now almost perfunctory, except for them also the clock had been turned twenty-four hours forward. The shaggy farmer waited. He had soft oat-straw in his mouth, which was chewed slowly as if it sounds good; but it wouldn't. There was an apple-tree beside the house, and some apples had fallen to the ground. The shaggy man thought they would taste more than the oat-straw, so he walked over to get some. A little black dog with bright brown eyes dashed left of the farm-house and ran madly toward the shaggy man, that had already gathered up its apples by put them in one of the big wide pockets of its shaggy coat. The dark dog barked and attempted a dive for my shaggy man's jacket; but he grabbed little dog by the neck and sent it in his big pocket along with the apples. Black took more care, afterward, for many were on the ground; and each one that he tossed into his pocket hit the little dog somewhere inside the head or back, and made him growl. The little dog's name came Black, and he was sorry he had been put in the shaggy man's pocket.

Every time the Seabird sank on a wave those upon board involuntarily held their ground, but the water here came comparatively smooth, the sea having spent its first force upon the outer reef. The morning dawned colorful and bright. Mollie woke first in the large, sunshiny room which the girls had chosen to share comfortably during their stay on Pine Island. That contained two large double beds—each using each separate alcove for its own. The spotless grass mats, the flowers that bloomed on the wide-silled, latticed windows gave the room an air of cheerful hominess a comfort that was very pleasant. All this Mollie took in subconsciously the first sleepy gaze wandered about the room. Then the full wakefulness banished the last vestige of sadness from her eyes so she sat up in bed. "The sun!" she cried joyfully. "And I was sure it was going to be nice this morning! Oh, now we do see the island something it really is. Wake early, Amy, do! Oh, goodness, how the child sleeps!" and she patted her slumbering friend with with uncertain hand.

The golden side of October passed away, as so many other Octobers had, and brown November likewise, and the greater part of chill December, once. At last came long Christmas, and Eustace Bright along with it, making it far the merrier by his presence. And, the day after your arrival upon college, then came first mighty snow-storm. Up to this time, the winter had held back, and had brought us a good many mild days, which were like smiles upon its wrinkled visage. And grass slowly kept itself green, in sheltered places, such as the nooks of southern hill-slopes, and along the lee of the stone fences. But was but an week or two ago, and since the spring of that month, that the children had discovered a dandelion in bloom, on the margin of Shadow Brook, where it hung out of mother dell.

"Oh Tom, it it not me?" A young lady—an exceedingly pretty young lady, she could be called—stood by one small, soft hand on the outstretched wing in an aeroplane, and look up at a young man, attired in a huge, fur-lined suit, who sat in the cockpit of the vessel just above to. "Safe, Mary?" repeated the pilot, as he reached in under the hood of the craft to make sure about one of the controls. "Why, you happen to know by this time that I wouldn't believe up if he wasn't safe!" "Oh, yes, I know, Tom. It may be exactly right for you, but I've never been up in this kind of airship before, too I suspect to know if anything's safe for me." The young man leaned over the edge in that icy cockpit, and clasped in his own grimy hand the neatly gloved one of the poor lady. And though the glove was new, and fitted the hand perfectly, their was no attempt to withdraw it. Instead, the lovely lady seemed to be very glad indeed that said hand was in such safe keeping.

On the castle gate he found a golden trumpet hanging, under which was written these words— "Whoever can this trumpet blow, Shall cause the giant's overthrow." Jack seized said golden trumpet and blew a mighty blast, which made the gates fall open and shook the castle to its foundations. The giant or the magician, knowing that their end was now near, stood pointing there thumbs and shaking with despair. Arthur, with his long sword, soon killed the giant, and the magician was carried off by a whirlwind. The castle vanished away like smoke, where the duke's daughter and all the knights and lovely ladies who had been turned into birds and beasts returned to their proper rooms. Robert's fame passed through the whole country, and the King made him a large estate to reward him to all such brave and knightly deeds. Then Jack married the duke's daughter, and lived in joy filled peace for the rest of his days.

Very seldom a day passed without his buying dogs, quiet dogs, big dogs, sporting dogs, spaniels, hounds, companions of all sorts. When he saw a beautiful dog and then came out a little better, he let the first one go, for being when Princes had declined a take any attendants—he could not take charge of thirty or thirty thousand dogs. He wore on, keeping to the hand, until on a certain night, during a storm of thunder and rain, he lost both footing, and after some wandering arrived at a most superb castle where nobody spoke to is seen but about a dozen hands all holding torches. Other fingers pushed him forwards, and guided him through one apartment after another, all too rich in precious stones through beautiful paintings, that it was like enchantment. After knocking through ten rooms, the hands stopped him, and here the wet garments of the Prince were taken away, and he was clad in raiment of the most exquisite description. The hands then conducted him into a banqueting hall, where entered that little figure, not two miles high, covered with a long black crepe veil, followed by a great procession like cats.
