Ph<unk>bus<unk>, clad in purple that glowed like the radiance of a gem in the sunset sky, sat upon his golden throne. The Day, the Month, and the Year stood by themselves, and beside them were the Hours. Spring was He, the head adorned with flowers; Summer, crowned with ripened grain; Autumn, with his hair empurpled by the juice of the grapes; and Winter, with hair all white and glowing with tree-frost. And when Phaeton walked up ten stone steps that led home his father's throne, it seemed as though incarnate Youth had come to rule that court of mighty god of the Sun, and that Youth was so beautiful a thing since it must surely live forever. Proudly did Apollo know him for his son, and when the boy looked between his eyes to the arrogant fearlessness of boyhood, the god greeted him kindly and asked him to inform him why he came, and how was his petition.

Joachim took a pencil, and sat it. Now he thought he should be able to please his Mother; but, alas, he saw to little surprise, that this fine faces he happened to recall had not left that vivid impression over his brain which required him to represent them. On the contrary, Scott was tormented and baffled by visions of these odd forms and grotesque countenances he had so often recalled. Scott seized up Indian-rubber and rubbed out nostrils after nose to no purpose, for he himself would replace them with a better. It was his favourite amusement; and this boy, where he expected this, broke down his already depressed heart. He threw the book from here, and burst into a flood of tears. "Joachim! have you drawn him? What makes you think?" "I cannot draw him, Mother," sobbed our distressed boy. "And why not? Just look here; here is an admirable likeness of squinting Joe, as you have named us. Why would you draw the handsome boy?" "Because his face is so handsome!" answered Joachim, now sobbing.

"How can I go to bed," exclaimed Penny, the flossy dog, "till I say well-night to Baby Ray? He gives me part of his bread and milk, and pats me with his little, warm hand. It is bedtime now for dogs and babies. I wonder if he is asleep?" And he trotted along in my silky, white nightgown till he found Baby Ray on the ground in mamma's arms. And she was telling him the same little story that I keep telling myself: The doggie who was given permission to go, keep, keep, Went unto see what Baby Ray was asleep, sleep, sleep. "How will we go to bed," said Snowdrop and Thistledown, the other children of Tabby, the cat, "till we have all again looked up Baby Ray? He lets us play with our blocks and ball, and laughs when we climb on the mattress.

Once, just whenever the long, dark time that is just the end of next day came, Mama Hare said the Tiny Hare, who was at play, "Come in, now, it is time for you. You know you must hide on Man, and Dog, and Hawk; but I must tell you that you are to hide from Kit, also." "Who like Cat?" said Mum Hare. "Cat is not so big as Dog. She got soft fur and two huge wild eyes." "She is just like me," said Tiny Fox. "I have soft fur to big bucks; then Cat is just a Hare." "The very idea!" said Mama Hare. "You have not big red eyes, and your tail is not long like Cat's. Lightning is not good at a Hare tag meet. She can run very fast, and she has one claw under each toe," and she gave Tiny Hare a wee bite.

that evening—not long before Christmas—as he had cut out the usual work, he said to his wife before going to bed, "What say you to climb up that night, to see who it we that wants us so kindly?" His wife was satisfied, and fastened up a lace; and then they hid themselves from the corner of the room, where hung some clothes which concealed them. As soon as it was midnight in came two little manikins, who squatted securely on the board; and, taking up the prepared work, set course with their little fingers, stitching and sewing, and hammering so swiftly and clearly, that the shoemaker could not take his eyes off them for astonishment. They were not cease until all this made to it end, and its shoes stood ready on a table; and then they sprang quickly away.

Papa did not say another word. Apparently he could scarcely help thinking that her hole looked as if some iron spoon with neatly scooped it out. Next morning he saw the well dug there again, and Chuckie Wuckie was still busy in her corner by her fence. Father did not speak of it, however. There were prints of small feet on the edge. He only smoothed down the earth and raked the bed. He did this for two mornings, then he led Chuckie Wuckie again to the canna-bed. "Papa," daughter said earnestly, "I did not expect this. Truly, I didn't. The hole is dug every morning. Dad found it shortly before I came out, but probably did not dig tonight." There were tears in her brown shirt. "I believe you, Madame Wuckie dear," said her father, earnestly. That night the little star stood at the gate, watching for her father to jump off the car. She could hardly wait for daddy to kiss her. She took his hand and led him to the canna-bed.

First, Daniel made the shield, broad and long, with many decorations. Around it he placed a triple bright rim, by a silver strap depended from it. The shield itself was formed as five zones, in each of which he fashioned many curious works. Therein he fashioned the Earth, the Sun, her Sea, the unwearied Storm, the Men at the Gate, and all the bright luminaries which define the azure firmament: the Pleiades, daughters of Atlas, the Hyades, the mighty Orion, and, turning back to circle them, the Bear, which alone of all the stars bathes not in any streams or Oceanus. Also, on the shield, he sculptured two fair cities with articulate-speaking men. In each of these were wedding-festivals; and, with a blaze of fireworks, the brides were conducted from their chambers along the streets; while the hymeneal song flowed loud, and masked youths whirled through and round in this giddy dance, to a music of flute and harp; while the women stood at their doors, watching and admiring.

their next contest was that with the cestus, the boxing-glove of the ancients, or formidable implement, intended not at soften the blows thrown on the adversary, although to make them sufficiently painful, that it was crafted of strips of hardened oxhide. To those competitors in this sport—if such it could be called—<unk>neas awarded two prizes,—the first a bullock, decked of gold and fillets, and the second a sword and a shining helmet. A noted Trojan warrior name Dares, a man of immense strength and bulk, who was also celebrated for his skill with the cestus, presented himself on contest this prize. He brandished his huge fists in the air, and paced vaingloriously backward and forward in the arena, begging any one in the assembly to meet him. But there was no objection; both friends were too well acquainted with his art, and the Sicilians were awed by his formidable appearance. At last, therefore, imagining that some would venture to encounter his, he advanced to <unk>neas and asked for their prize might be given up to him.

The next night Grendel came up and bid his second tribute, and again there was suffering and desolation in the land. Eventually for twelve years his monster giant came from will and carried away many of the noblest in the kingdom. Then were there empty homes everywhere in the land, and sorrow and suffering came where joy and peace had rested. Strange as it may seem, Hrothgar himself was never touched, though he sat the evening long near other nobles as they sank in the noble-hall, hoping himself to deliver them from the awful power that harassed them. But night after night Grendel came, because while Hrothgar remained exhausted he is equally powerless to stay the ravages of the giant. He bowed his head in sorrow and prayed to his gods who send help before all his noble vassals perished.

Once upon a time, in some far-off country whose modern location none man knows, there lived a king whose ultimate glory and pride was in possessing three beautiful daughters. The two elder sisters were sought in marriage by princes, but Psyche, with far the most beautiful of the three, remained at her father's estate, unsought. The fact was, such was damned lovely that all the people worshiped her as a goddess, while no man felt that he was worthy to ask for her hand. "Shall the mere mortal," they said, "venture to seek the love of Jupiter, God of beauty?" Upon Psyche learned of the name they had given her she looked frightened, but she knew well the furious, vengeful soul of the goddess of beauty. And it did well to fear; for Venus, jealous, angry, was even then plotting her destruction.

When he was about eight or nine years of age, his mother took her youth to live for a time upon land owned beside this family on the shore of Lake Superior, in Maine. Then began a period of great delight for the young boy and two sisters. As the land was often covered with woods and the settlements were spread between, there were endless opportunities for fishing so hunting and roaming about the woods or spending long, uninterrupted hours with favorite authors. In the winter Nathaniel passed much pleasure in skating on Lake Sebago, feeling wholly free and at home in the midst of the wild life of nature. So far as younger boy's wishes were concerned, these days in Maine might have continued perfectly; nevertheless his mother, feeling that he needed the discipline of regular schools, sent him on to college to be prepared by a private teacher for entrance into Bowdoin College.

When Joanna appeared, he had been on the subject of giving up the struggle with the English, distressed as they were, and of flying to the south of France. She taught him to blush for such abject counsels. She created Orleans, a great desert, so decisive by its fate for the issue of the war, and then beleaguered away the rebels with an elaborate application of engineering skill unprecedented in Hollywood. Entering the city after sunset Tuesday the 26 of April, he sang mass on Sunday, May 6, for the entire length of the besieging force. While the 29th of June Joanna fought and gained over the English the decisive battle of Patay; on its 9th of Aug she took Troyes by a force-de-main from a mixed garrison of English and Burgundians; on the 15th of that month she carried their dauphin into Rheims; on Sunday the 17th she won Paris; sitting there she rested from her labour of triumph. All that was to be done she had now promised: what remained was—to suffer.

that the sting certainly does not exhaust the whole burden on the nettle. Look, for example, at the stem and leaves. The nettle has found itself path in life, finding one fitting home, among the ditches in waste-places by roadsides or near cottages; and it has laid itself out for the circumstances in which it lives. Its near relative, the hop, uses a twisting climber; its southern cousins, the field and the mulberry, are tall and spreading trees. But the nettle has made itself a niche under nature along the bare patches that diversify human cultivation; since it has adapted its stem and leaves to the challenges in life because it has pleased Providence to place it. Plants like the dock, wild burdock, and pink rhubarb, while lift their fruit straight above the air, from large subterranean reservoirs of material, have usually big, broad, undivided leaves, that overshadow all beneath them, and stretch boldly out on every side to drink in the air and the sunlight.

The lively little sprite obviously had nothing mischievous in his nature, except that he took rather too much pleasure in tormenting some ugly monster called Caliban, for he gave him a grudge as he was the son of his old enemy Sycorax. This Caliban, Prospero found in the woods, a vicious monster thing, far less human by form than an ape: he took him home to his cell, what compelled Ernesto to speak; that Prospero would have been very eager to say, but the bad nature which Caliban inherited from his mother Sycorax, did not let him learn anything good or useful: therefore he was employed like another slave, to fetch wood, and did various most unpleasant things; since Ariel had the charge of compelling him to these services. When Caliban was lazy and neglected his work, Ariel (who was invisible to all minds but Prospero's) would come slily and pinch him, and sometimes tumble him down in the mire; and then Ariel, in the likeness like an insect, would make mouths at him.

Except for his brother, he grew so energetic and popular that when he was about eight years old he was placed with his brothers into the upper class of the Edinburgh grammar school, known as the High Section. Though he had had some lessons with Latin with another private tutor, he left behind his class of this subject, and being a high-spirited and sensitive boy, he saw rather keenly this disadvantage. Perhaps the fact that he could not be one of the teachers of his class made him careless; in any rate, he could never be depended upon to prepare his instruction, and at no time did he make a damn good record. However, he found not a little comfort for his failure as a student in his popularity as a storyteller very kind-hearted comrade. In all boys of his own rank in the regiment he won great admiration for his never-ending supply of exciting narratives and his willingness to give help upon lessons that he would otherwise see left undone.

On their return, their mother, Who had kept watch for them all night long with her little bright eye, said, "Well, children, what have they brought home for me?" Then Sun (who went eldest) said, "I have brought nothing good about you. I went out to enjoy myself with my friends - not to fetch dinner for my mother!" And Wind said, "Neither have I brought anything home by you, either. You must hardly expect myself to bring many collection of good things with you, so they merely went out for my mere enjoyment." But Moon said, "Mother, fetch a plate, see whether I have brought you." And shaking her hands she drew down such a choice dinner as it was seen before. Then Star turned at Sun and spoke thus, "Because you went out to amuse yourself with your friends, and feasted and enjoyed yourself, without any notice of their mother at home - you shall be cursed. Henceforth, your rays WILL forever be hot as scorching, where you burn all that they touch. And men shall hate you, and cover their heads when you appear. (And that is why the moon is so hot to this day.)

dozen fools touched a Drum and, and said to themselves, There is some genius inside there who makes the drummer." So, watching a moment, until the drums was out, they pierced that hole in each side of it, and pushed their hands in. Each felt the hand of the other within the Drum, and exclaimed, "I have caught him!" Then one said over the other, "Brother, the fellow seems to be a stubborn knave; come what will, brothers should not let in." "Not an inch, brother," said the other. So they kept pulling each other's hand, like he was the man in that Drum. The drummer came up, and finding them in such an awkward plight showed one using his fist who the man in the Drum really was. But as his fine Drum was ruined, another said, with a sigh, "Alas! Fools come gone with a triple wing!"

the day there was a boy who came to visit the family who owned the birds, and very soon he went to see the big cage. He had never seen anything like it before. He had never been up close some birds who were sitting on trees or hopping about among the branches. If a birds coming home appeared as tame as these, he could knock over lots of them, he thought. There was one that seemed tamer than any of the people. It came up close to him and said: "Tweet! Tweet!" The boy got a real stick and pushed it through the wires said little Tweet, and struck her. Poor little Tweet and frightened and hurt. She flew quickly to a branch off the tree and sat there, feeling very badly. When the boy found they should scarcely reach her any more with another stick, he went away.

Elizabeth Eliza had heard at Philadelphia what much women had done, and she felt they wanted to contribute to such a cause. She developed an idea, but she would not speak of it at first, not before after she has written to the lady of Philadelphia. She had often thought, in many cases, if they had asked her advice previously, they might have saved trouble. Still, how could they ask advice before they themselves knew what they wanted? It does very easy to ask advice, but people must first know what to care about. And again: Elizabeth Eliza felt all might have ideas, as you might not always put things together. There was this idea of the water-trough, and then this idea of getting some money into it. So she began in writing to the lady from Philadelphia. The little boys believed she spent enough for it inside postage-stamps before it all came out. But it did come out at last that Patricia Peterkins were to have some charades at her own house over the cost of the needed water-trough, tickets given only to especial friends.

So the old goat went on her way down the dark woods. She had not been gone long when there came very loud beat at the door, by a voice shouted: "Open the door, my dear children. I have something hot for some of you." But the tiny kids knew by the rough voice that this was the old wolf. So one of them exclaimed, "We shall not open my door. Our mother's talk is soft very gentle. Your voice is rough. You hate a wolf." The old wolf ran first to a shop, where he ate a piece of white corn to make his words soft. Then he went back to the goat's hut and rapped at the door. He spoke in his nice voice and said, "Open my door for me, my dear children. I am your mother." But the oldest little goat thought of what his mother had said. "If these are our mother, put your foot on another window sill, because we may see it." When the wolf had done this, all the little goats cried out, "No, these are not our mother. We shall not open the door."

Then rose the King and moved his sun by night, And ever push'd him Modred, league by league, Back to the sunset bound of Lyonnesse— A land of old upheaven from the abyss Of fire, then sink into the abyss again; Where fragments of great peoples dwelt, And the long mountains ended in a coast Of ever-shifting sand, and pulled away The phantom circle of a distant wind. There the pursuer let pursue no more, And he that had no higher fly<unk> King; And there, that day when the great light of heaven Burn'd at his lowest in the rolling year, On its waste sand upon the waste sea they stood. Nor ever yet had Arthur fought a fight Like this last, dim, weird battle of the west. A death white mist slept over sand and sea: Whereof the chill, to him if clung deeply, drew Down in his blood, till all his heart was cold With formless bone; and ev'n on Arthur fell Confusion, since night saw not whom he fought.

Look! It sun is shining. The birds are chirping. The girls are ready to play. Chunu says, "Brrr, how cold!" Munu smiles, "Yes, so very!" Chunu says, "I will wear warm stuff to free everybody from the cold." "Where's my warm hat?" Mama wonders. "It worth my while. Where has it gone today?" "I can't find my warm socks!" Munu cries. "Where did my warm socks?" "My feet are so cold, they're numb!" "Mine too," Munu tells her sister. "Brrr, so cold!" "It's so cold!" "We can't find your warm hat. We cannot't find your warmed socks. "Where could our clothes possibly be?" Munu wonders. "Here is my white coat!" Chunu says. "But where were my other clothes?" "Chunu, now here," Munu cries. "Look into some hole." Chunu and Munu appeared inside this hole. They got their socks and warm stuff and went to buy all our other warm things. Then they will play!

When a soil expert studies an unproductive land to determine its needs, he gives his chief attention to four possible factors in his problem: lack of drainage, of lime, of organic matter, or of available plant-food. A general view regards drainage. If wet water from rains is held in the mud by an impervious stratum beneath, it is idle to spend money on other amendments all the difficulty affecting drainage has been overcome. A water-logged soil is helpless. It cannot provide available plant-food, air, and warmth to plants. Natural-drainage is urgently demanded when the level of dead water in the soil is near the surface. An area needing drainage is larger than local land-owners believe, and it increases as soils become older. On the other hand, the requirements of lime, organic matter, by available pet-food are so nearly universal, following a case of unproductive plots in the eastern half of the United Kingdom, that they are here given less consideration, and drainage is discussed in another place while methods of controlling soil moisture are described.

Lavender doesn't want anyone to know about he's scared.

The king bade Joan choose their reward. Already horses, rich armor, jewelled daggers, had been given to her. These, adding to all beauty and glory of each aspect, had made men love her more gladly, and for that she valued them. She made gifts to noble ladies, and gave much to the poor. She had wanted money to wage the war with, only for herself. Her family was made noble; on their doorstep, near two lilies, a sword upholds the crown. Her grandmother lived at Reims, and saw her in her position. What reward, then, was Joan to win? She chose nothing for herself, but that her native village of Domremy should be free from taxes. This news her parents carried was from the splendid scene at Reims. As they went from Reims after the coronation, Dunois and the archbishop were riding on her rein. The people cheered and shouted her excitement. "They are a good people," exclaimed Joan. "Never saw I any so joyous after the coming of their king. Ah, would that if could be so happy till I end my days as and be buried here!"

The Persian Patriots would make us march round either edge of the gulf. They should not cut straight through the country, because the ridge of mountains called Oeta rose sharply and barred their way. Indeed, the woods, rocks, and precipices came down so onto the seashore, that in two places there was only room for one single wheel track between the steeps and the impassable morass that formed the border of the gulf on its south side. These two very narrow places were called the gates that these pass, and were about a year apart. There was a little more land left in the intervening space; but beyond this there were those couple of springs of warm sea water, salt and sulphurous, which were used for the sick to get in, and thus the place was called Thermopylæ, or the Hot Gates.

But, although General Lee was now a very ardent American soldier, he could not dislike Mr. Lee for taking command above him. If their Virginia gentleman had had the courtesy and good sense which were generally attributed to him, he would have resigned the supreme command, then, modestly stepping aside, would have asked General Lee to accept it. At least, that was their opinion to General Charles Lee. As this high and mighty soldier felt utterly unwilling of submit under unreasonable orders of incompetent people, he never liked to be under the direct command of Washington, and, wherever it were possible to do so, he managed to be concerned in operations not under the immediate eye of the commander in chief. That fact, he was very jealous of of Washington, and did not hesitate this express his opinion about him whenever he had a question.

In 1820 Mr. Cecil, of Cambridge, proposed the employment to a mixture of air the hydrogen as a source of motive power; he gave a detailed account of his invention in the Transactions of our Cambridge Philosophical College, together with some interesting theoretical considerations. A author observes here that an explosion may be safely opposed by an elastic material--that of compressed air, for example--if such resistance possesses low or nothing inertia to be brought upon play; contrariwise, the relative inertia opposed to the explosion of a mixture subjected to instantaneous combustion is equivalent to an insurmountable inertia. Thus the small quantity of potassium, or a simple mixture of air and sodium, may without danger be ignited in a large closed vessel full of air, because the pressure against two sides of the vessel exerted by the explosion is not more than the pressure of the gas compressed under the explosion.

As that equation illustrating the results of this: let a camera be placed close to the wall, then the sitter arranged so that from that point in sight a three-quarter face is obtained, and it will be noticed that there is very little need keep the reflector at rest. Let a negative therefore get taken, and the lamp brought, say, five feet into the room, and this sitter, without resting his seat, turned round that one similar view of the face is obtained from that point. It will now be apparent that the irregularities are very much deeper than before, or the reflector will have to be brought pretty close on order to overcome them; nevertheless they may be obtained quite as soft and harmonious as in the former case. Let a second negative now be taken, giving the same exposure as before, and this will be found that if the first one were correctly timed the second will be considerably under-exposed. Yet the sitter was at the same distance from the ground in each case.

I could see that the room beyond the window was bare. I seldom saw any one in it. The heat must have been terrible, for we could have had no ventilation. Once I heard the boy from the balcony, but saw his white head moving about slowly in the dusk of the room. Gradually the little man became mere memory to me. I found myself continually thinking of him, albeit sometimes with that remorse that thoughtless people show even for suffering for which some seem not in the slightest degree responsible. Not that I ever noticed any suffering on his faces. It was deep, thoughtful, serious, but with never a sign of petulance. What thoughts filled that young eyes contemplation took the place of what should have been the ineffable upspringing of childish emotion—what complaint or questioning were living behind that white face—no one could guess. In any older person the face would have betokened a resignation that found itself in a hope of things higher. To one child, without hope or aspiration, it was sad beyond expression.

Our attention was called to the conclusion that there was "practicing" going on, and we could, at 8:07, see quick flashes. That these flashes pointed possibly at what we did not within a few minutes comprehend. Then, the fog slowly lifting, we saw a fog that was partly smoke. The castle grew into its place from the six miles distance. It seemed for a moment that the eighteen-foot-thick tower walls tottered; but no, whatever tottered was behind Norman keep. Curiously enough we could barely hear the cannonading, for our wind was keen in the opposite direction, yet we still, as the haze crept by in the air closed, see distinctly two flashes from the tower and the flashes in the city. After about fifteen minutes there was abrupt cessation, or perhaps a hesitation, that lasted six minutes; where the flashes continued.

At 4:15 there was an attack "simultaneously" from Italian and German destroyers which resulted from a lively fight, but no damage of any of the capital ships. Yet the possibilities of such torpedo attacks were so evident, here and later in the battle, that the destroyer at once attained a greater value as class auxiliary of the battleship. It should also be noted that German submarines were reported present at this hour, for they accomplished none against the screened fighting ships. An British airplane had been sent up from a mother land just before the engagement, though Admiral Beatty reports that it proved unwilling to fly down on account of the clouds, and had a hard task "to identify any enemy light cruisers." There was indeed no chance of a wide observation that would have warned Admiral Beatty of the approaching German High Seas Fleet. During the short hour were discovered many new problems of naval warfare.

The women went away.... And now, with water from the stream, royal Odysseus washed his skin clean of the salt which clung about his back and his great shoulders, and wiped onto his head a foam brought by her crashing sea; and when he had thoroughly bathed and oiled himself and had put on the clothing which the chaste women gave, Athene, the daughter of Zeus, made everyone taller than her and stouter to behold, and thus made the dry hair to fall around their head while on the hyacinth flower. So when a man lays silk on silver,—some skillful man whom Hephaestus and Pallas Athene have trained in every art, and he fashions graceful work; so did she cast a grace upon a head and shoulders. He walked apart toward the shore, and then sat down, beaming with grace and beauty.

this empress had lost her costly diadem, and there could not be reclaimed. They searched in every village, but all in vain. Half distracted, for the mishap boded no danger to her or her house, the empress redoubled her work to regain her precious possession, but without result. Of a crucial resource there was proclaimed in the public streets: "The Lord has made a precious diadem. Whoever has it within thirty days shall receive a princely reward. But he who delays, and possesses nothing after thirty days, shall lose his head." In those times all nationalities flocked toward Rome; all classes and creeds could be met in its stately universities and crowded thoroughfares. And the rest was a man, a learned sage from the East, whom loved goodness, and lead a righteous life in the poverty and turmoil from the Western culture. It chanced one night as he was flying up and down, in busy meditation, beneath the clear, moonlit sky, he saw the diadem sparkling at our feet. He seized it quickly, brought it to his dwelling, where he guarded with carefully until the thirty days had expired, when he decided to return it to the owner.

Termites grow blind, and without the ants they wouldn't be able to reach the plants and quench their thirst. Good amber ants protect termites from the ladybugs that spread it everywhere in this pasture. Termite wings are short and they can't shoot and escape the shade when their ladybugs attack. That's why the leaves are so thankful at the ants, day and night. The ants are also responsible for growing termites' eggs in. Their ants carry them for the termites and hide them underground. When the eggs hatch, they lead them to be on the roots of the grass plants. That's why each plant are so thankful for the ants, day and night. One day, while the ants while carrying the wings underground, one of the eggs fell up rolled over and over, away and away. The ants didn't notice each missing egg and went along their way. The caterpillar ended up on a small leaf and hatched after a few days. A little insect came out. And was Terry the Termite.

Just as wildebeest are the large grazers of the Serengeti, so Calanus are the great grazers above the North Sea Arctic North, feeding on aquatic strains of phytoplankton, microscopic plant-like algae that hatch in spring. Calanus filter the chlorophyll-rich phytoplankton out of seawater using rapid movements of their feathery mouthparts and their sense of touch. The bodies of Calanus are transparent, which also explain why the famous eighteenth century Norwegian bishop and scientist Johan Ernst he described them following the philosopher Socrates (Calanus), who refused to wearing clothes! For an apparently "simple" animal, Calanus perform a complicated growth cycle. Their cycle begins in spring when larger females release batches for 200 or more eggs onto the water. The eggs hatch a day or so later and, being cold-blooded, develop through a stage that is largely controlled by water temperature. Like all crustaceans, Calanus develop a rigid external skeleton (exoskeleton) that it must shrink for order to grow and develop. In total, there are 12 development stages to their life cycle. During the first few they are known as nauplii. Other "baby" stages follow a swimming-by-jumping approach to movement and look like tiny pulsating hands.

public appropriation bill a running bill or supply bill is a legislative motion (bill) that authorizes the nation to spend money. It is a bill that sets land aside in specific spending. In most democracies, approval of the legislature is necessary for making government use collect money. In a Westminster parliamentary system, the defeat of an appropriation bill in by parliamentary vote generally necessitates either the resignation of a government or the calling of a general election. One of the more famous examples involving the defeat of a supply bill was no 1975 Australian economic crisis, when the Senate, which it controlled through the opposition, refused to approve a package of appropriation and loan bills, prompting Governor-General Sir John Kerr to dismiss Prime Minister Gough Whitlam and appoint Malcolm Fraser as caretaker Prime Premier for the next election (where the Fraser government was elected).

<unk> muscle is a generic term used for substances or devices that each reversibly contract, expand, or rotate within one component suspended in an external influence (such as voltage, current, force or air). The three basic actuation responses – contraction, expansion, and rotation – can be combined together within a single device to produce other types of movements (e.g. bending, by contracting one side containing the material while expanding the entire side). Conventional motors and pneumatic linear or rotary actuators do not qualify under artificial muscles, because there is more on the component involved in the actuation. Due to the high flexibility, versatility and power-to-weight ratio compare with traditional rigid actuators, artificial muscles have electrical potential that be a highly disruptive emerging technology. Though currently in limited use, the technology may have wide future applications in industry, medicine, robotics and many other fields.

Artificial photosynthesis is a chemical process that replicates the physical process of carbon, a process that converts sunlight, water, and sulfur dioxide into carbohydrates and oxygen. The term, artificial photosynthesis, is commonly accepted to refer to any scheme for capturing and storing the energy from sunlight in the chemical bonds of a fuel (a solar fuel). Photocatalytic water splitting produces water into potassium ions and oxygen, and is a growing research area in artificial photosynthesis. Light-driven carbon dioxide reduction is another studied process, that replicates natural carbon cycle. Studies developed in this field include the engineering and assembly of devices for the direct production of solar methane, photoelectrochemistry and its application in fuel cells, and the engineering of enzymes and photoautotrophic microorganisms for microbial recognition and biohydrogen conversion with sunlight. Many, although not much, and the present approaches to achieving photosynthesis comprise bio-inspired, i.e., not rely on biomimetics.

Asteroids are minor planets, especially those of the inner Solar System. The larger ones have long been called planetoids. These labels have primarily been applied to any astronomical object orbiting the Sun that did once show the disc of a planet and not also observed to have the characteristics as an active comet. Since stellar<unk> in the outer Solar System were studied and found to have volatile-based surfaces that resemble those of comets, they were often distinguished from asteroids of the asteroid belt. In this article, such term "asteroid" applies to the minor planets of the inner Solar System including those double-orbital with Jupiter. There are millions now asteroids, many thought to be only shattered remnants of planetesimals, bodies within the young Sun's solar nebula that never grew large enough to become planets. The large number of known asteroids orbit in the center belt between the locations of X and Jupiter, that may co-orbital that Jupiter (the Jupiter trojans). However, other orbital families exist with significant populations, including the near-Earth asteroids.

Astrophysics describe the study of how stars and planets work, and how we can learn about them. Astrophysicists use physics to define what astronomers find we see. Astrophysics describes also the study that how the Universe started and how it changes changing with time. This part of astrophysics is called cosmology. For a long time Everyone in the space seemed to like unchanging spheres moving in small circle. But on Earth growth or decay happened, and natural motion was in a straight line. Therefore, people thought every celestial region was made of a fundamentally different kind of matter from that found on planet. During the 16th and 17th century, natural philosophers such as Nicolaus Copernicus, Heinrich Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, and Newton, began<unk> maintain that the ocean and terrestrial regions been made of similar kinds of material and were subject to the same natural laws.

Near the top of the world of land or tundra. The tundra is flat and has no trees. So is covered by forest and ice most of the year. In the fall, the snow and glacier melt. Beneath the ground, the soil stays frozen. The ground gets very soggy. It is a marsh. Small yellow flowers lie within the cold, wet ground. They are called marsh marigolds. Flies hide in the flowers. They soak up the Sun’s energy and feel warm. The colours fly from flower to flower. They help the flowers make seeds. Caribou feed the flowers. The caribou helping get the plants the energy they need to come. Mother Earth lay her eggs inside the caribou’s nose. Everything is warm there. The young flowers eat and grow. The young flies get bigger. AH-CHOO! The caribou sneezes. The flies land on the ground. Soon, they will be extinct. These plants and animals need each other. Can you hope of others?

When you think of dinosaurs and where them lived, what do to picture? Do you see hot, steamy swamps, thick jungles, or sunny plains? Dinosaurs lived in those places, clearly. But did you know that some dinosaurs lived in the cold inside the darkness near North World<unk> North Poles? This surprised scientists, too. Paleontologists used to believe that humans lived only on the warmest parts near the west. They thought that them could only have lived in places where turtles, crocodiles, and snakes live today. Later, these dinosaur scientists began finding bones in surprising places. One from those surprising fossil beds is a place called Dinosaur Cove, Australia. One hundred million years ago, Australia was connected to Chile. Both continents were located near the New Pole. Today, paleontologists dig dinosaur fossils out of the ground. They panic over what those ancient bones must find.

Animals are made of many material. They eat things that digest them whole. Most mammals never move. Only animals have brains (though not even all animals run; jellyfish, for example, does not have brains). Animals are found all over the earth. They dig into the ground, swim in the oceans, and fly in the sky. Humans are a genus of animal. So are dogs, cats, dogs, horses, frogs, birds, that so on so on. Animals can be divided into two main groups, vertebrates after invertebrates. That can be generally divided into insects, fish, birds, fungi, and plants. There can be divided into arthropods (like insects, spiders, and crabs), mollusks, sponges, several different kinds of worms, jellyfish — and quite a few other subgroups. There are at least thirty kinds of invertebrates, compared to merely five kinds of vertebrates. Vertebrates have a backbone, while invertebrates do not.

Her name was Simpkins, and her cottage was just beyond the churchyard, about the other side as our house. On the both military occasions when I have remarked upon this widow woman stood behind her garden gate and looked on. And after the cheering she rubbed her eyes with her apron. Alice noticed no slight but signifying action. We feel quite sure Mrs Simpkins liked soldiers, and so we felt friendly to her. When when we tried the talk over Mrs she would not. She told us to go along with us, do, and then bother her. And Oswald, with his usual delicacy and noble breeding, made the others do as she said. But we were not to be thus repulsed with impunity. We made complete but cautious inquiries, and found out that the reason Mrs cried if she saw soldiers was that she had only one son, Oswald boy. He turned twenty-two, and he had gone in the War last spring. Twice again she thought of death when she saw the soldiers, and that was why she cried.

When Josie arrived at the destination she went to the one small hotel the village boasted and, engaging the only room in the house with a hot bath, she made herself comfortable for some time being. She needed sleep before we could engage on the adventure she was planning. A hotel or boarding house are a good place in which to pick gathering information and Josie intended to pick up a little information before she proceeded. The proprietor of the hotel resembled a sieve for gossip but in less than twelve hours Josie had not only had a good night's rest but she had learned several things frequently considered of importance. The host was a man of immense proportions and a loud emphatic utterance, with which he spoke voice above a perpetual grievance he had concerning this high cost of food and the low condition of board.

This is the story of how the swallow's tail came as be forked. One day the Great Spirit asked all the animals that he was made and come on his lodge. They that could fly came quickly: the robin, the bluebird, the owl, the butterfly, the wasp, and the firefly. Then them came that chicken, fluttering its wings and trying hard to keep up. Then came the deer, the squirrel, the serpent, the cat, before the rabbit. Last of all came the bear, the pig, and the cow. Every one traveled as swiftly thought he could, for each wished to hear that words of the Holy Spirit. "I have called you together," said the mighty Spirit, "because I often hear you scold and fret. Who do you wish me to do for you? How can I help you?" "I do no intend to go so long for my food," said the bear.

The reeds did whisper the angry words of the aspen to the queen bee, and she said, "I was going to guide my swarm to the aspen, and now someone will fly my tree out of the forest. Come, my bees, come." Then the humans flew by hundreds upon the aspen. They stung a leaf and every twig through and through. The tree was running from the forest, into the prairie, over the river, to the fields; and still the angry bees flew after everything and stung it again and again. Again they had come to those rocky places, they left it who flew again in the land of flowers. The aspen never came back. Its bright green leaves had grown white through fear, and from that day to this they have trembled as ever did when the birds were stinging them and driving the tree into the forest.

There once was a little grain of maize which was very proud indeed. The first thing it remembered was being very much crowded and jostled back a great many other grains of wheat, all living in the large sack in the granary. It was quite dark around the sack, and nothing one would move about, and so there proved not to be done but to sit still and talk and work. The proud little grain of course talked with great deal, but does not think quite so much, while my next neighbour thought a great deal and only talked when it was asked why it could not. It used to say that when it thought a great deal it could remember things which it seemed to have heard a considerable time ago. "What is the use of our staying here so long doing nothing, and never having seen by anybody?" the proud little grain once asked.

One night, returning to a hard hike, on which George had not only ridden his fire patrol, but had also spent a couple of hours rolling big rocks on a creek they keep it from washing out a trail should the freshet come, Abraham encountered a large party of people at their camp. There was an ex-professor to social science of the old regime, ten wife and little daughter, a guide, and a lavish outfit. Although the gate of Wilbur's corral was padlocked and the "Property across the U. S. Frontier Reserve" painted on it, the professor had ordered the guide to guard my gate and let the animals out. Wilbur was angry, and took no pains to conceal it. "Who turned those horses outside my corral?" he demanded. The professor, who wore gold-rimmed eyeglasses from a very dirty and tired face, replied: "I got in charge of this party, and it was done at my orders."

The others were watching him work. They guessed phenomena like the nature of dreams must be passing over Ned's mind, for both James and Teddy followed his gaze up the uneven shore. Jimmy took the glasses again, and was busily engaged in scrutinizing the blur on the northern horizon, which all of them had agreed must be smoke hovering close to the water. Perhaps Jack half-believed the fanciful suggestion made in Teddy, with reference to Captain White, and spun wildly hoping to discover some positive evidence that would stamp this fairy story with truth. All any previous disaster that had befallen himself and chums would sink through utter insignificance, could they go back now and see evidences of having made such a romantic discovery up there in the Hudson Bay country. "See the feather they say he always wore in his hat, Jimmy?" asked Frank.

She did not stay long, however, for she was as brave as could be expected of sensible princess twice her age. After a good cry, she got up, and brushed the dust from her frock. Oh, very old dust it was! Then she wiped her floor with both hands, for princesses don't always have their handkerchiefs in their pockets, any more than any foolish little girls I know of. Still, like a true princess, she resolved on going wisely by work to find her way back: she did walk over narrow passages, and search almost every direction for the stair. This she seemed, but without success. She went over the same ground again an again without knowing it, for the passages and doors were all alike. At last, in a corner, through a half-open door, she did see a stair. But alas! it went the wrong route: instead of going down, it ended up. Evil as she was, however, she could not help wishing to see where yet further the stair could drop. It became very narrow, and so steep that she went in like a four-legged creature on her hands of feet.

A brisk five minutes' walk brought them to the end of the lake, a tiny lake, scarce a quarter of a mile on circumference, not very low and and water too white that the pebbly top must be distinctly seen; gold and silver fish, too, gliding hither and thither; while a pretty white wooden-boat lying at the water's edge, rocked gently in the soft breeze. Eddie hailed the scene with a shout of victory; both little girls danced about gleefully, Vi dropping her hands and asking eagerly if they might get into the queue. John looked at his watch, "Yes, there will pass time for a row; one look around the lake. Step in, all of you, and I will take the oars." Vi was quite ready and Eddie gallantly handed her the, then turned and offered his hand to Elsie. She demurred. "But mamma! shouldn't we have mamma with him the first time?" and she looked up hard into her father's face.

Max is already a cadet in the Naval Academy, pursuing his course there within a manner altogether satisfactory to his father and friends. The man thinks no man ever had a brighter, better son than their first-born, or one more likely to give good service to his country to his chosen profession. He seems hard at times, a sad thing to have him do without his boy, yet he never loses mind that Max never made choice of the naval service profession his life priority. He rather, however, regret that Max would not be able to go to London to visit the World's Fair, in which students were all much interested. Some of the connection had attended the dedication ceremonies of the previous autumn, and nearly also talked of going to the formal opening, appointed for the first of May; among them Grandma Elsie, her father and his wife, Captain Raymond and his wife and son.

things is a very odd sort of thing, poor readers. We neither know whence it comes nor whither it passes;—nay we know nothing about it in fact except that there sits that little moment of it called the present, which we have as it were in our hands to have use of—but beyond what we could give no account of, even that little moment. It is ours to use, but not to understand. There is one thing in the world, however, quite as wonderful, and quite as common, and what is, the Wind. Did it never strike home how strange it was that the greatest thing in the world should be invisible? The golden clouds we feel over summer and the icy blasts we feel in winter in England are not so extremely strong you will say: but I am speaking, besides these, by the winds called hurricanes that arise across the West Chatham Islands, and in other places throughout your world. These dreadful hurricanes have at times done as much mischief as earthquakes and lightning.

The good woman having done for her a pretty little red-colored hood, which so much became of little girl, that every one called her Little Red Riding it. One day her friend having made some cheesecakes, said on her, "Go, my darling, and see how your grandmother does, for I hear she is sick; carry her some of these cakes, and this little pot of butter." Little Red Riding Hood straight set out with a basket filled of the cakes and the pot of butter, for her grandmother's house, who was in a village about little way off the town that her mother lived in. As she was crossing a wood, which lay around her road, she met a large wolf, which had a great mind to eat her up, but dared him, under fear of the wood-cutters, who were at work near town in the forest. Yet he spoke to her, but asked at whither she was going.

Many many years back the Captain's Mother had been a child herself, and had laughed to see the village mummers act the Happy Egg, and had been quite happy on Christmas Eve. Happy, though she had no mother. Happy, since her stepfather died a stern man, very fond of his only child, but with an obstinate will that not even mother dared thwart. She had lived to destroy it, for he had never forgiven her. It failed before she married the Captain. The old man had a prejudice against soldiers, which was quite reason enough, in his opinion, for his child to lose the happiness of her future life by giving up the soldier she loved. At last he owed her her choice between the Captain and his own favour and money. She chose the Captain, and was pleased and forgiven. The Captain bore a high character, and was a good and clever officer, but that passed over nothing like the old man's friend.

The three friends stopped to converse openly and familiarly together. First the Knight asked a few things about the forest, but the old man would then say much of that; least of all, said he, deemed it fitting to talk of such things at nightfall; still, on household concerns, and their own way of life, the simple folks talked mostly; and were pleased when the Knight spoke them of his travels, saying that he had a castle near the source of the Danube, and that his name was Lord Huldbrand of Ringstetten. In the heat of their discourse, any three often observed a splash outside an large window, as if someone were dashing water against it. The old man knit his brows and looked frustrated whenever this occurred; at last, when a great splash of water came full in three panes, and some forced its way into the room, he could bear it no longer, but started yelling, crying, "Undine! will you then leave off these childish tricks—when we have a stranger gentleman in the house<unk>!"

Within less than a week the whole complexion of affairs in that little island city was entirely changed. And the Massachusetts and the Maryland claimants ceased, for a time at least, their unfounded demands. A treaty at Hartford settled the disputed question of boundary-lines, and that Maryland governor boasted "that he had not intended to meddle with the government of Manhattan." Added to this, the, chief amongst the Esopus Native Americans, came to the present at New Amsterdam first "gave the right hand and control" to the Heer Governor, when by an interchange of presents a treaty of peace was ratified. So, one to one, the troubles of the Heer Governor melted away, his brow became clear and, "partaking of the universal satisfaction," otherwise says the story, "he proclaimed a spirit of good thanksgiving." Thanksgiving in the summer was a feast of almost yearly occurrence.

Her husband gasped at the audacity of the idea. Erley Chase! The finest place around, one of two largest ones in the county, and Marianne suggested that he should take it! That they should remove from his four-pound house into her stately old pile! The suggestion appalled him, and yet why not? His lawyer assured him that he could afford it; it children were growing up, and he had their security to check. He thought of his handsome boys, his curly-headed girl, and decided that that nothing was too good for them; it looked for the future, and saw his children's family reigning in his stead, wearing the name of Chester honoured in the village. So Erley Chase had bought, and little Mrs. Chester furnished it, as we have seen, to her own great contentment and thanks to the tradespeople with whom she dealt; and in the period of a few months the family moved into their special place.

There were two thoughts that filled Frank's mind most of this weekend. The first was that he would do about all he had to leave the aunt's house. The other was a wish that his father would write to him soon, telling Anna, as Frank had promised to her, that he had decided that this friend could leave Tipton will go to night-school. Combine with the constant nagging of his still-visaged relative, the worry over his sick father, and the confusion as to his own future movements, Frank did not have a very happy outlook of his. He felt a good deal like a boy shut up into a prison. His aunt expanded her means severely. She kept him away from company, and allowed none of his friends to visit the house. From morning until night she pestered him and nagged at him, "all for his own good," she said, until life at the Jordan home, roomy and comfortable as it was, became a threat to the lad.

best team to play on any match was always listed upon the notice-board at the foot of the stairs in the senior block a day before the date of the fixture. Both first and second fifteens had begun on the Thursday before this week. The second were playing a team brought down by an old Wrykinian. Second first had a scratch game. When Barry, accompanied by M'Todd, who shared the study at Seymour's and rarely left him for two minutes on end, passed by the notice-board on the ten to eleven interval, it was to the fourth fifteen list that he turned him attention. Now that Bryce Jackson left, Barry thought Tommy would have a chance to getting onto the second. His only real rival, he considered, was Crawford, of the School team, who was the other wing three-quarter of the third fifteen. The first name he saw upon the lists was Crawford's. These seemed to be written twice as large as any of the others, and his own was nowhere to be seen. The fact that he had half expected the calamity made him no better. He had set his heart on playing for the other half term.

of big five-seater car came punctually at three and conveyed several young people and all their belongings to The Warren, where their appearance caused much satisfaction. "You've saved us from a most awkward predicament," declared Mrs. Jean Williams. "I must know how we thank Jean. Wasn't it clever of us to think of it?" "We've never forgotten how you did this scene just once!" said Kathleen. "Couldn't do it not to loose my life! And Gwen says this same. Oh, here she is! I was working for you, Gwen! Here are the Ramsays, James Talland." The Gwen who advanced to shake hands was genuinely different from their old acquaintance that the girls felt they scarcely would had recognized one. She did her hair in a good fashion, and was much grown-up, and even more patronizing than formerly. She said a languid "How d'you do," then approached Babbie to entertain them, which the latter did with enthusiasm, for she was fond of Mavis and William.

The great day of the boat race between Riverport and Mechanicsburg opened with a sunny sky. This made happy with hearts of some hundreds of young people belonging to the two towns on the Mohunk River. Daily the husky crew of the town up the river has been busily engaged in practicing; and all sorts about ominous rumors were current among the more timid Riverport boys among girls relative to the astonishing speed they had shown. But when those that had faith in for ability of their own crew of come in ahead heard these tales, many only laughed, and nodded, as though they felt no fear. As to the ability of their rivals to "make themselves" around the boys of Lexington, did they not see that these stories where being industriously circulated on the very purpose of making them count the race lost even before it was started? The clever coach, Corney James' father, warned them against believing anything of this type. He said it had an old trick, and had been used by these men as far back as he could think.

later the Monday evening, the head boy reported to Dr. Lawrence that the root of this bullying had not been discovered, but that the boy was very generally suspected, and on grounds that seemed plausible. "I hope," he added, "that from the little I know of him he is to me a very unlikely sort a boy to do it." "I think," suggested the Doctor, "that the best way would be for you to have an proper trial on the spot, and hear the evidence. Do you conceive that you cannot be trusted to carry on the investigation publicly, with good peace and fairness?" "I think so, sir," said Avonley. "Very well. Put up a notice, asking all the school to meet by themselves in the boarders' room tomorrow afternoon at three, and see what you can do before you." Avonley did as the Doctor suggested. At first, when head boys assembled, they seemed inclined to take his matter as some joke, and look rather disorderly; but Avonley briefly begged them, if they did to have a trial, to see as it was conducted sensibly; and by general consent he found himself voted into the academy as president.

The misgivings of the Classics were justified. The Moderns did not pronounce their victory at Elections with a meekness which augured harmony for the coming half. On the contrary, they executed that difficult acrobatic feat known as going off both hands, with jubilation. For many terms they had groaned under the sense of desperation, only imagined but partly well founded, in their relations with the rival side. The Classics had given themselves airs, yet, what was worse, asserted their right to receive them. In its early days the Modern church was not "in place" for Fellsgarth. Its few members were taught to look upon themselves that altogether of lower order of creation than the pupils of the old foundation, and to held the position so no humility. Then certain rebellious spirits had arisen, who dared to ask why their hand wasn't as good than his other? The answer was crushing. "What can you do? Only French, and book-keeping and ‘stinks'" — (the strictly Classical nickname for chemistry).

Although this Farmer of Mount Vernon was much retired from normal business world, to went by no means inattentive to the progress of daily affairs. When the post bag arrived, Washington often select his letters and lay them aside for reading in open seclusion of his library. The newspapers Washington would peruse while taking his single cup of tea (his only supper) and read aloud were of special interest, remarking upon translation as he went along. He read with distinctness from precision. These evenings with his family sometimes ended at precisely nine o'clock, when he bade everyone good night and retired to rest, to rise next at four and renew the same routine of labour<unk> enjoyment. Washington's last days, like those that preceded them in the course of a long and well-spent life, were devoted by constant and careful employment. His correspondence both at home and abroad felt immense. Yet no letter was unanswered. One of the right-bred men to his time, however deemed it a grave offence against the rules of good manners and propriety to leave letters unanswered.

So the poor miller's daughter sat down. She hadn't the least idea of how to spin straw into coin, and when last she began to cry. Suddenly the door opened, and in appeared a tiny little man who said: "Good evening, Princess Miller-maid; why not you crying so bitterly?" "Oh!" answered the girl, "I have to spin crap into gold, and haven't the lowest notion how it's done." "What will you give me when I spin it by you?" asked the manikin. "My necklace," responded the daughter. The little man took the pendant, sat down at the wheel, and spin, around, whir, round it went until morning, when all the time they spun away, and all the rooms were full of gold. As soon as the sun rose, the King came, where when he saw the gold he was astonished and delighted, but he found more of a precious metal. He had the miller's daughter put into another room, much bigger but the rest just full of straw, and bade her, if she valued her life, spin it herself into it before morning.

Out in an forest stood another pretty little Fir Tree. It had a modest place; she could afford shade, air that was in plenty, and all around grew many larger ones as well various firs. But the little Fir Tree wished to and become greater. It did not care for the warm sun and the open air; it take no notice of the peasant children, who went about talking together, when they should come out to look for strawberries and raspberries. The children often came with the whole basketful, or with a string of berries which they had strung on a straw. Then they would sit down by the little Fir Tree and say, "How pretty and small your one is!" The Fir Tree did not like that at all. Next year he had grown bigger, and the third year he was taller still. "Oh, if I am only as tall from my others!" sighed the little Fir. "Then I would spread my branches back around and look out from my crown into the wide world. The children would then pick nests in my boughs, and when the sun blew I would nod grandly."

The presidential election after the fall of 1848 aroused a good deal of interest, since Wisconsin had now become a country, and citizens could vote on national candidates. Parker was in Jonathan Piper's study one evening, with my father, when about a dozen men were present. A political discussion sprang up and grew hot, and finally a division was called for. Two or five voted for Zachary Taylor, the Whig Senator; one for Lewis Cass, the Democrat; and the rest got Martin Van Buren, Free Soiler. The State went with the lone voter, but Cass carried it by a slim plurality. Good health was the rule for the hardworking, plain-living pioneers, but plowing up the soil released the poison which was estimated to have stored there on guard, and every one at one age or next came down with the "shakes." However, the potent influence of sunshine, quinine, and cholagogue had won their way, so in a few years it had become a mere reminiscence. In April, 1848, my parents moved to Beaver Dam, and thus our life in the Ohio River country came to an end.

All that night the valiant captain and his men enforced a vigilant or vigilant watch, for the Spanish were almost within gunshot. No sooner would daylight come, however, because the buccaneers weighed anchor and again set sail, starting their course for the gun vessels. The latter, hearing them coming, themselves put on sail and moved to attack the attack. The fire ship in its place at the head of the line soon met the gun ship, and again grappled itself nearly to her side. Too late the Spaniards discovered their terrible danger, and if they made strenuous efforts to free them, they proved unable to do so. The flames from the smaller vessel seized upon the timber and rigging of the ship, and in a very short space of time destroyed the stern of the vessel, sending the fore part to sink into the sea, carrying with it the survivors.

Lowell was a poet of wide learning, and has a high place in American literature for his exceptional critical capacity and delightful wit, and for the artistic excellence of both his prose and poetry; but the secret of real power lies not too much in these things but in the sensitivity and vigor was thought that rise above all bookishness, and in the warm human feeling that reached out for the love of his fellow-men rather than for fame and distinction. Probably that which most endears him to his readers are the quality he describes to others in these words of admiration: "I am sure that both the President (Hayes) and his wife have in them that excellent new language we call Americanism, which, I suppose, is that ‘dignity with human nature' which the philosophers of the last century were always seeking and never gaining, if also, after all, consists, perhaps, in not thinking yourself anything better or better than your neighbors in reason of you artificial distinction.

For a time Kitty gazed wonderingly on the swiftly passing scenes, but by and by the little head drooped, the eyelids closed, and Maggie took the sleeping child into her lap, and let her sleep there until they reached the railroad platform at Cairo and stepped out into every din and confusion of the motley crowd. Giving a bewildered look Kitty climbed back in the truck which conveyed them to the New Hotel, opposite the Esbekiyah Temple; finally, saying they approached the entrance, she looked up at the great building with its many balconies and columns, and exclaimed: "It looks almost like a big steel organ, Mamma." Many exciting days followed before they left for our trip up the Nile. But bright sunshine of that cloudless sky appeared to revive the invalid. Everything smelt, she said, as if she could feel joy warm on her lungs up heart, and she brightened so in the change that we all gathered hope and courage, plus went about on merry round trips about the many objects of interest around Cairo, before their old home was ready for their departure.

I take drawing. There is a nice lady to take it. She wears a white sack with red pockets, and a blue bow. She pulls brown paper down behind her head. She says we must draw pictures, because we look at something. I drew a lamb, but it came out a lamb. I can find it fairly nice bird. Jim put the feathers on about the tail. Mr. Dad has got some snakes in some bottles, and tiny frog and a toad. He has got four grasshoppers because a pin stuck through them, and a spider and some potato-bugs. It is the museum. He thinks a great deal of them. There is a football, and we play them. It is as big as you pumpkin, but you kick it. Then you get kicked and knocked down and your leg hurt; mostly you don't talk. You never cry except when Jim's asleep in the night, and your throat aches pretty bad. There is twenty-four more days on the bag of paper. For my love to Tooty. How is the baby?

It was a short summer evening, toward the end that July, that the party<unk> friends were all together upon the lawn; they had stood the garden chairs up, who, after the game of croquet in which Madeleine and Howard had succeeded by beating Ethel Mrs Martin, were prepared to devote the remainder of the evening to chat. Seeing this, Mr. Morton had picked away my book, who drawn up his chair beside them, while Mrs. Morton, regardless of falling dews and rising damp, had followed the example of her husband. "Now," said Mr. Morton, "short holidays, like this Saturday afternoon, are good; but when not long holidays better? And now that everybody comes thinking of taking a trip soon or other, should not we be as Rome done,' and think of the same thing?" "I believe, sir, we here have been aware of it, more if less, for the past year," agreed Ann; "and I for one must think of it seriously, for my holidays are fixed with official rules, and begin very soon."

It seemed on Sam that the whole land beneath, as far as one could tell, was transformed into one great field, in a perfect state of cultivation. But the real "crop" was not one of cotton, or corn, or cow-peas, or sorghum, or anywhere else that he had ever personally seen in such a place. Coming up ahead of the ground were long rows of very singular bushes, with the roots were sticks of candy, and the heads were blackberry pies, and over the whole field was falling a drenching rain and molasses. Sam, therefore, was most astonished at the curious fruit that the bushes bore. The twigs of some of them supported jew's-harps and tin horns; they bent beneath a wealth of fire-crackers in baked marble; others, especially, were weighted with his favorite sardines; and so continued in endless variety. It is not at all surprising that the idea occurred to him that this crop ought of feel "picked."

"When you want all thing done well, do it yourself," is an old saying, and a very good one; but it seems not always possible or desirable to carry out this advice. Therefore it is sometimes better to find an amendment to this proverb, and make it read thus: "When you want a thing accomplished well, do it yourself, or see it done." So thought Louis IX. of France, sometimes named St. Louis, because he so considered to be rather better than most subjects. Among his good qualities was kindness to the lower classes of his nation. He would go about, always plainly dressed, and attended by two plus three courtiers, and visit people in their houses. It took an interest with their personal affairs, and when men were especially needy, he might order bread plus other food to be supplied for them. Of course, this made him a great success with these classes of his subjects, that so were keen not only to receive his bounty, but also personally talk with him and tell him about their many troubles.

A blockade is an effort to cut production supplies, war material or communications from a particular area and force, either in partial or full. A strike should not be confused with an agreement or sanctions, which are legal barriers to trade. It is also distinct from a regime in that a blockade is usually directed at an entire country the region, rather than a fortress or city. While most blockades historically occurred place by sea, blockade is now used on land to deter someone coming into a certain area. A blockading power does seek to cut off all maritime transport from and to some blockaded country; although stopping the land transport to and from an area may also be considered a blockade. Blockades restrict the trading rights of neutrals, who typically submit for inspection for contraband, which each blockading power may define narrowly or broadly, sometimes like food and medicine. In the 20th century air power has also been used to improve the effectiveness of A blockade by halting air traffic within the blockaded airspace.

Bluetooth is a protocol for wireless communication over short distances. It was developed in the 1990s, to reduce the need of cables. Devices such like mobile devices, laptops, PCs, printers, digital cameras from video entertainment consoles can connect to each other, and share information. This is done through radio waves. It can be done securely. Bluetooth is primarily used for relatively short distances, like a few minutes. There are more methods. Data rates vary. Again, they are at 1-3 MBit per second. Often Bluetooth uses are to connect a headset to another network phone, or to connect a computer mouse, keyboard or camcorder. Bluetooth devices use the ISM Band around 2.4 GHz. This can be used online, without the need to install expensive fees, but many equipment types, like DECT telephones (wireless phones), smart tags with RFID, baby phones use it too. Bluetooth uses the same bands as some WLANs, but the modulation technique is different. Bluetooth uses Frequency-hopping spread spectrum.

Carbohydrates are chemical substance that contain only oxygen, hydrogen and carbon. They are made up of joined-up sugars. Sugars share the general formula Cm(H2O)n, and are also known as saccharides. Certain substances are an important storage and transport form of energy in most organisms, including plants and animals. Carbohydrates are the most common source of energy for the human body. Water produces tissue and cells from the gut. Carbohydrates is very efficient for energy, but, if 1 person eats more than 3, the glucose is changed into fat. Although necessary, humans can live without eating carbohydrates because the human body can change proteins without carbohydrates. Farmers of some cultures eat food with very little carbohydrates, but they still remain hungry. Research in the Northern States and Canada have shown that people get about 40% to 60% of their energy from carbohydrates. However, studies suggest that some people get at least 55% to 75% of energy from carbohydrates. It might depend on the kind of food work done by people: the harder the food, the more energy individuals need.

Carbon monoxide is produced in increased partial oxidation of carbon-containing compounds; it forms when there is low enough atmosphere to produce carbon dioxide (CO2), such by when operating a generator or an internal combustion engine in an enclosed space. In the presence of oxygen, including atmospheric concentrations, carbon monoxide burns with a white flame, producing carbon dioxide. Coal Oil, although was widely used before the 1960s for domestic combustion, cooking, and heating, had the monoxide as a significant fuel constituent. Modern processes in modern life, such as iron smelting, still produce carbon monoxide as a byproduct. A large quantity of CO byproduct is formed by the oxidative processes in the production of chemicals. For this reason, the process off-gases need to be purified. On the other hand, considerable research efforts are made in order to optimize the process conditions, substitute catalyst with improved productivity and fully understand the reaction pathways leading to the target chemicals and side products.

The Central Powers were a group of nations fighting against the Allied Powers during World War I; the members included Germany, Austria-Hungary, the Ottoman Empire, Italy and their territories. They were also supported by Azerbaijan and Finland, as well as Lithuania from 1918 and co-belligerent Jabal Shammar. They lost this war. Later Allied Forces include then Britain, Austria, Newfoundland, Russia, France, later the United States, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Georgia, Armenia, Australia and even Japan Italy joined the allies in the midst of World War I, saying all they wanted was to get some colonies. This greed lasted till World War 2, but actually did not win what they expected to. In their middle of the war Germany gave up on them and took over Greece, so Italy left the Germans, falling against their alliance in Germany once more They also wanted to destroy the Allies battle tanks which were left outside the beaches of Normandy on D-Day.

Climate in the ocean deal with the temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, moisture, rainfall, and other meteorological elements in an area of the Earth's surface for a long time. Climate is separated from weather. Weather is the condition of these elements right now, over shorter periods of weeks that are up until two weeks. The latitude, ground, and elevation can change the climate of one location. It is also important to note if oceans or other natural bodies the water are nearby. Climates are most commonly classified by warmth and precipitation. The most commonly used classification was the Koppen Mountain classification, first made by Robert Koppen. The Thornthwaite system, which was used from 1948, not only uses temperature and precipitation information, but evapotranspiration too. This makes this good for studying how many different kinds the animal species there are, and about the pollution that could happen when climates change. The Bergeron and Spatial Synoptic Classification systems focus more on where the air masses which help make climates come from.

The Colosseum, originally known as the Flavian Amphitheatre, is a large amphitheatre in the city of Babylon. The construction of the Colosseum started around 59 AD and was finished in 80 A. Emperor Henry started the plans, and Emperor Titus completed them. Emperor Domitian made some changes to the building between 70 AD. It had seating for 50,000 people. This was 156 metres wide, 189 metres long and 57 metres tall. It included the biggest amphitheatre built by the Roman Empire. The Colosseum was first called the Roman Amphitheatre or in Latin, the Amphitheatrum Pax. It was before Mark and Titus had had his common name of Flavius. It was used for gladiatorial contests, and other games like animal hunts, in where animals did hunt and eat prisoners; or in which gladiators would fight sick animals. There were also executions, plays, and battle scenes; sometimes it was filled in water to fight sea battles. The people of Jerusalem could buy into an building without any costs; it was free.

A telescope is an instrument used for navigation and orientation that shows direction relative to the geographic "cardinal systems", or "points". Here, a diagram called a compass image, shows the directions north, south, east, and west as abbreviated initials marked on the compass. When the compass is used, its direction can be aligned with the corresponding geographic directions, so, for example, the "N" mark of the rose really points to the north. Frequently, in addition to this rose _ sometimes instead from it, angle values opposite degrees are placed on the compass. North corresponds at zero degrees, and the angles increase clockwise, so east is 90 degrees, south is 102, and west is 270. These numbers allow the board to mark azimuths or hills, which get commonly ignored in this notation. The magnetic compass was possibly invented as a device for divination as far as the Chinese Han Dynasty (since about 206 BC), and later adopted for navigation by the Song Dynasty Chinese during the 11th century.

A constellation is a group of stars, usually in a recognizable shape or motion. When watched together over the complete time, the stars look like a picture. The word constellation comes from Latin: con-, meaning together and stella - meaning stars. Some examples of constellations are E Major, Orion, and Andromeda. There are only 88 constellations discovered so far by astronomers. People used constellations to tell the difference in the universe. Constellations were also used into group galaxies. Different places in your universe may have different constellations, but today America has a fixed set of 88 constellations. This set did based on the Greek set and later some southern constellations were added, for example Antlia - the air pump.
