When thinking about why to yawn, people mostly pay attention to the respiratory, or breathing, aspect. When breathing, we inhale to increase our oxygen supply, and gradually exhale to get rid of excess carbon dioxide. So, the deep breath that creates laughter has led many people to believe that the purpose of yawns is to lower oxygen levels. As this explanation seems to make good sense, research conducted 30 years ago firmly rejected this idea. In really clear test of what yawning was caused by low oxygen levels, Dr. Robert Roberts et E. designed an experiment in which they changed the content of the air that was inhaled by participants in A laboratory and then witnessed the effects that the air had on yawning. The trials had varying conditions and participants either inhaled air as extra oxygen or enough carbon dioxide. These experiments demonstrated that neither breathing pure oxygen nor increased levels of methane dioxide altered the rate of yawning in a. Take other words, the results of this study show that yawning indeed generated by the amount of oxygen in the air, and that yawning, and breathing are controlled by separate mechanisms.

During a drought, Yihdego left home to have a job. At the time, Tiebe was pregnant with their second child. After staying away for a long time, Aaron decided to come toward his home. Before starting his journey, he went to a wise old man for advice. After Yihdego greeted the old man, he said, "I have been away leaving my home and family<unk> a long time. Now I want on go back. I ask your blessing and advice." "Listen young son, on your journey home, do not use a shortcut. Do not comment on everything we see. Do not make a decision while you get angry," advised another old man. Yihdego set off on his journey. He met four entrepreneurs. They came to a cross- city. The merchants chose to go the short side. Yihdego remembered those old man's warning. He went the long way. The merchants who went the short way were robbed by bandits. After crossing a whole city, Yihdego arrived at a village. He asked five households if he could stay another night, but all refused. A man told these, "We don't allow strangers to stay in the households but ask over there."

Studies have shown that people who are more grateful than others will automatically think about the things that happen to them in a less positive way. Most situations that happen in our lives are not 100% good or 100% sad. How we think about or interpret what happens about us plays a big role in how we feel about the world. Most people have learned "thinking habits" that they repeat over and over again. One behind these remembered habits is what people called a "positive observation bias," which says that you are more happy at view a neutral or negative situation in a more positive sense. An example, after sliding off your bike, you could suppose "I got so lucky that I did not get hurt" and feel very grateful. Or, people could think "I can't believe I was so stupid to fall of my bike" and feel really angry. Combined the grateful thoughts would be an example of a positive interpretation bias.

"What happened to my spinach?" she demanded to know. Sipho was so scared that he could not talk. While they continued chewing in the garden, Thabo arrived. "Thabo, do you get anything for my flowers?" asked grandmother. "No, grandmother. I don't know anything about the spinach," complained Thabo. "Did your both boys leave there gate open? I told you never to leave it open." "No, grandmother!" said the boys with one voice. The two boys started to blame each other. They began to quarrel. Grandmother heard them arguing and called them. Grandmother asked them what they were arguing about. The boys told her the thing about the spinach. They said to grandmother that they had left the gate open. Had been very sorry. Grandmother was very kind. Through a quiet voice she said, "I hope we two boys finally learned your error. You must never leave the gate open again."

Antibiotics have been used for almost a century to treat bacterial diseases in humans and also in animals. Throughout their time, bacteria have been looking for strategies to survive the treatment. Imagine a battlefield, where all population to bacteria is attacked by small bullets (antibiotics). If one of the bacteria can find a technique to protect itself, it will survive. The surviving bacteria may gain the advantage of being resistant to antibiotics forever and so will the surroundings. This is that reason that, anytime you get sick, you have to take all the drugs prescribed for the vet, even if you did feel well. This is very important to prevent "survivors" in the war! Bacteria resistant to antibiotics (called "superbugs") are very dangerous toward us, because we have huge weapons to fight against them. Also, these resistant bacteria can be transmitted to other people or even to animals. Nowadays, there are a high number of bacteria that have become resistant to 100 different antibiotics, and this is a threat for people worldwide.

An eclipse is an astronomical event. It is a process that develops slowly in time. The eclipse is when one object in the sky moves within the shadow of another such object. When an eclipse happens within a system of stars, like the Solar belt, it causes a type of syzygy. This is that three other less objects in the sky are lined up in virtually straight line in the same gravitational system. The term eclipse is most often used to evoke a solar eclipse, when the Moon's shadow crosses the Moon's one, or a lunar eclipse, when the Sun moves into the shadow of Earth. No solar phenomenon can last longer past 7 minutes and 58 episodes because of the speed at which the Earth and Moon move. When the Sun is not moved, the event is called occultation.

Try my simple exercise: go to your song library, pick a song, and play the first 3 s of it. Give yourself 1 hour if you can manage to sing or hum at least the second 5 s of that song. Do it for 20 songs. How many tunes did you score? We would still be surprised if it is more than 15. Now, think on what you just did. You effortlessly recalled the pitch, key, and maybe even even lyrics of more than 15 songs in a short amount of while. that is a lot of data you managed be summon from your brain, more like that! Our brains possess a unique ability to store, create, and retrieve memories of music, even when we are not aware of doing so. For example, if you hear a catchy song, your will most likely are able to recall parts of which a few days later. After hearing it several times, you might know it by heart. Think about how much psychological effort it takes to learn information from a textbook, or to remember the details of day-to-day events in your life.

Although reflexes are super-fast and just happen without you thinking about them, this does not mean that they are automatic. Reflexes protect you and allow you to move around without thinking about every single action and response your being needs to make. It is important that reflexes occur without the need for thinking about them or there are things that happen to your body and forces acting in their body that you move that need to be referred to very quickly. Reflexes allow your body to react in ways to help you to be safe, to stand upright, but to be active. Imagine a typical day. We might be thinking of practicing your sport or musical instrument, walking to school, then making a snack. For all of these actions, you are thinking, but based on same thing, there are also reflexes which are are unaware keep active inside your body. These reflexes are embedded naturally into the body, and commonly exist while younger and change as we grow older. Reflexes are kind of like safety features for survival that allow us to move in response to something in the environment.

Sea level has changed naturally in the world, probably due the the growth and melting of large snow sheets and ice ages. By the peak of the ancient ice age (~20,000 years ago), sea level was ~120 m lower than it is today. Because of global cooling that occurred between 20,000 through 10,000 years ago (which was natural because not influenced by man), the rate of sea level rise was 1.2 cm per year for 10,000 years, until it leveled off to zero. During this level of time, several episodes of extra rapid sea level rise happened. Last example, about 14,000 years ago, the rate of sea level rise jumped to about 3 cm per year, because of ice sheet melting. The last time like the climate and earth was similar to today's climate was 120,000 years ago, which is in between ice rising episodes. So level then was at most 6 m higher than it is anymore, almost certainly because parts of the Greenland and West West ice sheets were smaller than they are now.

Neurons come into many forms, colors and sizes, but it was helpful be think of a species called a tree. Another neuron has three active parts, the cell body, an axon, and the brain. The tree trunk (cell body) stores DNA information (DNA) in a compartment called the nucleus. The cell body also contains the chemical machinery to produce the neurotransmitters that an neuron uses to communicate with every other. The tree's branches (dendrite, the word dendron comes from the Greek language and actually says "tree") are the tips of a neuron that receive signals. Dendrites were once thought to be like antennae, just receiving signals from other neurons, but, as I explain, they can do more than this. The brain membrane (axon) is the structure formed by a neuron to connect itself or talk to another cell. An axon carries information similar to this cable that carries electricity. When one neuron wants to share a message through another, another sends the electrical impulse, often an action potential, down its axon until it reaches the axon terminal, at the end of the axon.

Adaptive response mechanisms are positive ways people alleviate stress. Anticipation offers a way to balance the stress of a difficult challenge by anticipating what that will be like and preparing for how to cope with it. Some literary critics believe that this is the reasons contemporary Americans enjoy reading about, watching, and analyzing tragedies. Thinking about tragic events helps people relate to unforeseen difficult circumstances. Finding emotional support from others or asking for help can be an instrumental way of improving emotional health during a difficult period. The brain's response to events ensures this effectiveness of this strategy. Stress develops neurohormones that strengthen your instincts to give emotional support by growing your empathy and encouraging you to look for close personal bonds. Problem-solving focuses on revealing the source of the problem and determining solutions, or action steps. Developing a plan can help lessen stress that comes from the unknown. Problem-solving can be strengthened by creativity, and it is a useful response to many simple and complex issues. A strong problem-solving process involves defining the issue, brainstorming alternatives, evaluating and selecting between these alternatives, and implementing changes. Men of all ages and cultures respond to trauma.

Once that a time, there was a man who had three sons. The youngest son was the youngest and his father liked him the most. Then the man realised that his two other sons were older. So when the partner died, he left all his hunting to his two elder sons. That only left one ox for their youngest son. But the brothers were still jealous of him. One day they said, "We've got to slaughter your ox." He was the youngest so he couldn't hunt. He said, "If that must be so, well's nothing I can do. But please give me your hide." When they slaughtered an ox, he took the hide. After drying it, he climbed a tree with it. As afternoon got darker, a crowd by men came to get off the tree. In the middle of the night, the young man started beating the hide with some stick. When the stick hit the hide it sounded like thunder. The merchants thought that a raid was coming. Everyone ran off leaving their goods behind. The poor man picked up the goods and took everything home before his brothers.

A tyrant (pronounce: tie-rant) is a person who rules with absolute power. In its Greek spelling the word has the negative part: many translate Oedipus Tyranos as 'Oedipus called King'. A tyrant would rules a country, and have either got his position as powerful ruler by force, or some of them had some power. Later, the word came to mean someone who ruled from oppression and injustice. The rule of a tyrant is by tyranny. The adjective is tyrannical. A dictator or despot encompasses someone who rules with absolute authority, usually cruelly. It now has the same noun as 'tyrant', while before, 'tyrant' meant something like 'ruler' or 'king'. In the 10th and 9th centuries BC, northern Greece was ruled by monarchs. By the ninth century BC, they were ruled by groups following aristocrats. Later aristocrats started to become powerful. This gave cruel people the trick to get power for themselves, telling the people kind people would be good rulers, but turning bad once they got power. Around 650 BC the tyrant Cypselus became powerful in Corinth.

It was fast approaching the time when mamas and papas call children for clean ups. It was time for children to wave goodbye to parents. It was getting to the dreaded bedtime. And moon was not rising. It stubbornly remained rooted at the same spot. Normally the darkness would grow longer, the later it got. But on that occasion, the shadows did just grow any longer. The sun refused to go to bed. Below, children were still playing, chasing, skipping and jumping, although it was long past their playtime. People, being parents, checked with dismay against their watches. They were puzzled. What should someone do? The clocks showed 12 was past playtime, but the sun still stood at noon! In faraway villages, parents were singing, "Children it is ready for bed." And children, being children, responded, "But the sun is still growing brightly." Mammas and pappas looked for each other. Then they gazed up to the sky or wondered, "Should we send our children to bed? Night is late, but the sun is still at the midday spot."

an early morning, Ekai was woken up by his mother. He stuck in a deep sleep and he could never wake up immediately. His mother kept calling him, "Ekai! Ekai-i-i." Ali was very annoyed because that was unusual thing to him. Her mother had prepared food for him and dry shower for bathing. Ekai woke up, took a bath and breakfast. Ekai's mother brought him new school uniform and a lot of black shoes with grey pair of socks. He stood surprised to see his father holding heavy blue bag full of books. He realize that his turn to start school had reached. Ekai and his father left the house. He waved to his mother and held his father's hand. Three walked to the bus stop. They found a bus that was about to leave. They took the bus. Before sitting few minutes, they reached a place and there were many buildings and children.

health is a field of study dedicated to understanding the ethical, legal, yet social impact of research on and about the brain (i.e., neuro). Neuroethics research aimed at better understand the brain processes that are involved in making decisions about what is right or wrong. Ultimately, research involving neuroethics seeks for identify solutions to help neuroscience and society come together safely and with the expected results. Science in neuroethics breaks components into four main lines of investigation. To provide a better understanding of each of these areas, we highlight four examples of neuroethics research from each for the four categories. Their term cognitive enhancement points to the improvement of memory skills when there is not an inherent problem with thinking. Several medications have been created to help people with thinking problems improve their ability to concentrate and do better in school. Unfortunately, however, healthy students also use these agents because they want to improve their memory or want to learn as well. This is called cognitive enhancement, and neuroethicists have raised some concerns related to this practice.

Amara loved animals very much. Amara was with her mother, Margy. She was really very hardworking person. Amara's father died when she was 5 years old. When Amara was not at school, she spent her time with Mbisa, the goat. She cleaned and fed it. Amara also had her pet, Simba. Her mother did not like dogs very much, but she let Amara keep one. Sometimes Simba disturbed her, she would shout, "Go run before you kick you<unk>." Amara remained sad. One Saturday, they had visitors from the women's group. Amara was happy that her friend's friends had come with young children. Kids could enjoy football. Her mother already prepared the food that women group loved. Amara were reminded by her mother to put Simba close up. It barked at strangers. Amara did not lock down Simba well. The visitors were surprised to see the dog in the room. Mama Oto asked, "Why do doctors allow our dog to come out back house?" Amara's friend called Amara to come and take Simba out. Amara did not see her mother calling because they were busy playing. When Amara went to the house, she called Simba out. Simba was very obedient around Amara.

Sand asked Rain, "What doing you do that helps the earth?" Rain answered, "I give the earth water so that the trees and plants can grow well. I make water for animals to drink." Rain asked Wind, "What do her do what helps the earth?" Wind answered, "I sweep the earth clean. I spray beautiful rain over the whole earth." Wind asked Sun, "What do he do that helps the earth?" Sun answered, "I give the earth light and warmth, so many insects and plants can survive." Sun, Earth, Rain and Wind listened carefully to each other. Then Sun said, "It rings true that each of us helps the soil in our own special way." "Yes", said Sand, "Not one of it is better than an others." "We can work together," said Rain. Rain said, "Then let us share the days." They all agreed. And that is why you invariably see the moon when the sun is shining. And sometimes they feel the wind when light is invisible. Sun, Moon, Rain and Wind work very nicely together.

my cousin Kamohelo leans on her hoe. What do I do? What do I cause? My aunt Keromang has another dress to sew. Why do I do? What do I know? My uncle Khotso herds the cattle that low. What do so do? What do I know? Mama dries milk when the wind does not blow. Who do I do? What do I know? Gran rides a motorbike over mountains in snow. What play I do? What do I know? Grandpa's slow donkey walks to and fro. What do I do? How do I know? Grandma sings songs while home fire burns low. What do I do? What do I know? You know how to say oh. So remember where to say no. That's what you do! That's what you know! Everyone smiles when adults put on a show. Your work remains to play. Your work is to grow.

Most mornings, Hare go take some seeds from Hyena's granary. Then he went to his field and pretended like work. He would light a fire and roast the seeds. He did nothing, except eat these seeds. Near harvest time, Hare went and stole his field's ripe corn. He gave it to his own granary. Hyena complained about his stolen crops. Hare asked, "Maybe the neighbors stole your maize. They are suffering from famine because they turn lazy." Hyena thought about this problem for a short time. He came up with an idea. He collected gum from the trees. Just put that sticky gum around the whole field. One thief would get stuck around the gum. During the night, Hare went to Hyena's field to steal more medicine. Before entering this field, he looked around to know if it was safe. Hare did also see the gum because Hyena had put around the field. Hare stood in the gum and was stuck. He started shouting for help. Hyena heard the shouts and ran out without catch the thief. He could not believe his ears. It been dear friend Matt who stood stuck in the gum!

He continued walking. He saw some splendid new clothes. He took off these clothes and put on the new ones. Then he thought about what the old woman having said. He took off the new clothes and put his old ones back together. Third he saw the root. It was growing from it roots. He asked himself what the old woman thought he would do with the root. Next to the root, there was a bowl of food. The food smelled horrible and the boy was hungry. He couldn't stop himself from eating. When everyone had finished, he remembered what the old woman had told him. The old woman also said he must only take up root. People looked around for the root, but they couldn't see it anywhere. Poor boy left the forest totally disappointed. He went back to tell the old woman what had happened. But this old woman was gone.

long day his mother asked him, "Where do you learn these songs from, heart?" Sakima answered, "I just know them, mother. They hear them through my mind and then I sing." Sakima liked to sing around his little sister, especially, if mother felt hungry. His mom would listen to himself singing his favorite song. She would sway to the soothing tune. "Can you sing you again now often, Sakima," him sister would beg him. Sakima would accept or sing it over and over again. One evening when his mother returned home, they were very quiet. Sakima learned that there felt something wrong. "What is wrong, mother, father?" Sakima asked. Sakima learned that there rich man's smile was missing. The man was very sad and lonely. "I can sing for you. He might get happy again," Sakima told his parents. But his parents dismissed him. "He is very rich. You are only a blind boy. Do you think your song must help him?" However, she did still give thanks. His little sister supported his. She said, "Sakima's songs soothe me when I am hungry. They will soothe our rich man too."

More people return from the bus stop at outside 9am. Half an hour later they are all still waiting. Sam turns worried. "Maybe phone service cuts down," Dad thinks. "Maybe we will't go to town today. Maybe I won't get my new school uniform." At 9:45am some people come up and go downstairs. Sam starts to cry. "We will wait a bit awhile," says his mother. Suddenly, they hear bright noise. The bus is coming! The bus arrives at the halt at 10 o'clock. "Get hungry! Get in!" calls the driver. "We are very hungry today!" People come on the bus and sit down. Golden bus leaves the stop at 10:10am. "What time is the return bus this month?" asks Sam's mother. "The blue bus hits town around 2:30pm," replies the driver. Sam thinks, "We will get to town at 11 o'clock." "How much time will someone have in town before the return bus?" wonders Sam.

Daisies are the most fun flowers to draw. Small daisies often grow large in wet grassy areas and are great for elaborate daisy chains. This is a pink orchid flower. There are over 25,000 types of orchids. They grow to all continents except Antarctica. Orchids come in many shapes, sizes, and colors, including pure white into deep black. This is a pink rose. This is another pink rose. A rose is the most popular theme within bouquets, poetry, and is a romantic icon. This be a pink hibiscus orchid. Pink flowers breed in warm climates. These are often used for decorations. Having their pleasant citrus smell and as a source of Vitamin C, they are also used in food and tea. This is your pink lotus bud. D lotus is a flower that believes in water, and is a symbol to purity and life. A bud is a flower that hasn't opened. This is a pink Protea. The family and plants where Protea comes from has been around for lots of days. Proteas can be found in Southern Africa, Australasia, and South America.

Rabbit owned a big farm with lots of vegetables and fruit. For though I fed generously with his friend, Anansi was unhappy and jealous.<unk>, Anansi thought of a clever plan to take in Rabbit's farm. Soon Rabbit was left poor and homeless. Anansi was the proud father of old Rabbit's land, vegetables, and fruits. Anansi went to the market to sell his fruit and vegetables. He made so much money that he filled a big basket of it! With some of the gift, he bought maize for his family, and put it on top of the money in the basket. Anansi was headed home with his basket on his forehead, singing. He was thinking about all the things he was going to buy with his money. On the way sky begins to drizzle. Soon the sunshine turned into a heavy downpour. Anansi the gardener left his basket on the side of the road with fold under a tree. But from there nothing keeps a close watch on his precious basket. It started to rains even very heavily, and Anansi was getting cold and wet. So, he ran into a neighbour.

Before the 8 rounds of game playing, we measured how well the children in the two training programs performed on tests of mental ability. After only 8 weeks of practice, we tested both strategies again, to see whether they had gotten better off these tests. The players who had played games like SET worked a lot on the reasoning test and showed improvements in spatial working memory and all of the speed measures. The children who had played games like Blink showed a different pattern: each got a lot faster on the speed measures but were not any better by reasoning. These results show that playing different kinds of games really sharpen different mental skills. These are really exciting findings! However, our work is not done yet. For one thing, this study tested only a small number of children. We would like to run this same experiment again with a larger group or siblings to see sure that all get the same findings. It starts a process known as replication, and it is a most important part of scientific discovery.

One old woman especially admired the smells that drifted out outside the bakery window every Sunday. This was Ma Shange who slept on a bench in the sunshine every night. A few weeks ago, a kind person had given her the money to buy himself a cinnamon bun. She had taken the bun back to his hut and ate it very slowly, licking every mouth and sharing the last crumbs with the birds. After that, if the old woman didn't have enough money to buy breakfast, she longed to the delicious bun forever. So, every morning she walked slowly near Ma Shabangu's bakery, sniffing the air and rising blissfully from the mouth-watering smell. Ma Shange's horrible taste made that baker very angry. As each day went by, he grew angrier and angrier with anger. Finally, one winter morning when him seemed in an especially bad mood, he stormed out of his bakery and grabbed the old woman by the hand. "How dare you steal my smells!" he shouted. "You're I but a smell thief!" He wiped his hands on an apron, then pulled it off and threw it back into the bakery.

Once was a time, there was an hungry cowboy. He was walking up the bush looking for food. He came across the grapevine. He spotted a bunch of juicy ripe grapes hanging from a high bar. "Those look really delicious," they thought. He took a few steps back so that they could make one next jump. The grapes were too high. Jackal fell in his back after even touching the bunch. Jackal got up and went further back from his starting spot. He ran, and he got high again. But he fell, even harder. He tried again and again. But he couldn't get to the vines. He kept falling until his back was very sore. Finally, he cleared out and walked away. He stopped and looked back at the grapes. He got hungrier than ever. "Those grapes look really sour anyway," he thought.

Papa cycles down to Muizenberg Beach. Squeak squeak rolls the wheels all the way to Surfer's Corner. Eyes circle the sky. "Whaaat? Whaaat? Whaaat?" they cry. "What will you offer back for Yusuf?" Papa rings his bell. "Wait and see as it will look!" The fishermen watch the waters rise. They check their nets. They check their oars. They listen to the tide. They drag their boats down to level water. Yusuf's husband, Oupa Salie was an treknet fisherman. Before him his father, Oupagrootjie Ridwaan, knew the sea language. The boat rides into the waves. Papa's pockets stretch above the oar. His arms braces against the side. His neck strains, but back muscles ripple. Mum sings when he works: "Drop and swish. Find a frog. Pull off plop. Don't you stop." Ten day long Ali looks at the garden. It is bright and clear absolutely windless. A bird means a gift! What may Papa bring home from the sea? Sometimes he brings a tiger shell. Sometimes he brings a jewel green bottle rinsed by the waves.

I was very happy. But when I was eleven years old, I grew tired really weak, and then I couldn't walk. My parents took me to the hospital. I had to stay in hospital for more years. I was really scared and I slept many hours the day. After three years the doctors told I I would not be able to walk again. I was so sad because I love sports. I registered to a special school in Umtata, and my teachers encouraged me. I was a very busy school, has lots of interests like sport plus sewing. On weekends we had tasks to do. We had to clean sleeping rooms, polish the shoes and clean some wheelchairs. I decided to continue trying, and never give up. If you have a disability, you can not do something to love. I love to see how far I can go, so I entered a competition. I win my bronze medal for shot putt, a silver medal for discus and a gold medal for javelin.

A little later they passed Mouse. "Are you looking for somebody?" asked Ladybird. "Yes, Ladybird, I'm looking for my house. Have you seen Its, by a chance?" Ladybird repeated, "No, I haven't, but I'll sticking you look!" She hopped onto Tortoise's back and on he went, with Snail and Sparrow and Ladybird on his back. They looked and looked, but there is no signs of a house. A rock started it blow. A little later they passed Mouse. He came making a garland after daisies. "Are you hoping for something?" asked Rabbit. "Yes, Mouse, I'm looking for my house. Have you seen its, by any may?" Alice said: "No, I haven't, but he'll stick him look!" She jumped onto Tortoise's arm. "Wait, I can't leave my flowers behind." Tortoise waited. They stretched and stretched and scooped up more daisies. She walked on, with Snail and Sparrow after Ladybird and Mouse by his back. They looked and looked, but there was no sign of a house.

<unk> hill stood smiling at the middle of Kwere Plains. From its side, came springs which joined downhill to the River Temu. These waters were a gift to the sheep and goats of the area as well as the deer that dwelt in local plains. Things were all well until Matata became headman. and ordered a path to be cleared from the top with the hill to the foot that then he could step uphill easily and roll gently to towards the floor. Olokwango hill was angry with the damage to his beard, but he was patient. During the weekend, someone's dogs plus their friends would climb ahead during play. They would run wild over the place, breaking twigs through branches, lighting fires for their games, which they would later leave burning. Over time, Olokwango lost patience. The dimples became smaller and more as her face turned into smaller wrinkles. At 35 the rivers were no more. The deer in the plains migrated because there was no more tall green grass to play in. The sheep and goats grew thinner from thinner. Everyone felt the sadness of Olokwango hill. The people of Kwere realised that something needed to be done.

One day the children put our ball under a tree in the shade on a bright red blanket. They went to play. Our baby began crying as usual. A group of cranes flew above the playground and were sorry for the crying baby. They tried everything get the children to notice that the baby was crying but the children kept on playing. The cranes decided to take the ball and raise it themselves. Four cranes decided to pick up the baby from under the tree. Each crane took a corner of the baby's blanket, lifted the back up and swam away. The children did not notice anything because they kept busy playing. The mother's parents were working hard in the hot sun. It was very hot that the mother decided to rest under a tree. While she was resting who heard her baby screaming. She looked around but she could not hear anywhere. Then she woke up and she saw four cranes flying over with her baby in that bright red blanket. She screamed and chased after the cranes. When my woman told her husband what she saw he did not believe her.

Other families noticed what well the other family lived. "It is a good life coming in the hills," said their husband. "You should get there too." Soon the two families left the flat land but went up to the valley. Each family found a cave to live in, and felt warm and secure. Soon the children became very quick at climbing rocks, and finding fruit in the trees. They could swing in the branches almost to easily as any monkey. Slowly, things appeared to change. The children talked less, and grunted and. Then the adults noticed that their noses were looking bigger and that they were growing more hair. Every time they looked at another another they saw that their teeth were longer. They started to walk under four legs. They became a new creature that no-one first seen before leaving the place. This was the creature which people now call the baboon.

One Saturday, Dima decided to visit Owl. When they served food, Dima wondered how Owl's food tasted so good. He wondered if it was because the rice melted in the sun and it was grilled in fire. Secretly, he made a plan. He decided to dance. He wanted everyone at Owl's place to gather around him and see him dance. He was a good dancer. Owl and his family admired her beautiful dancing. When it got warm, Owl decided as fetch the sun near his house so that he could still watch Dima's dancing. Stephen furnished one room in this animal skin bag inside his hut. He carried the sun out from his house and held it far up above his shoulders. Now everything was light. We could stare far into the distance. Soon everyone was dancing in the light of the sun. Dima crept closer to the sun while he was dancing. Owl held on to the sun but after a day he forgot about it because he enjoyed the dancing so much. He observed how beautifully Dima danced. He too wanted to dance like this.

One time Old Jackal woke up to find his son sleeping in the sun. The food was not available and the goats were still grazing her kraal! "Young man, you are so lazy! Go and find a wife. I am too old to look in cattle," said Daniel's father. Soon, Jackal returned early and took the goats out to pasture. In the open, he saw something shining on a rock. He went closer and closer to the rock. Every closer he got, the more beautiful the shine was. Perhaps this was the wife for him! "You are beautiful," said Jackal to her glint. "But who are you? Why are you nude?" "I am the sun," the shine answered. "My father left me here when they moved on. They did not want help carry me. I am too hot." The jackal said, "But you are so beautiful! I will take me. I will take you home to meet my father." "All right, you can carry me. But do I complain that children get too hot to you," said the sun. So, Jackal carried a sun on his back and resumed the journey home. Before long, the sun was burning Jackal's fur.

One night, Nyame decided that he would give the pot holding wisdom to Anansi. Any time Anansi looked in that clay pot, he learned something really. It was so easy! And Anansi thought, "I'll keep the pot safe at the top of a tall tree. Where I can try it all to myself!" Just spun a long thread, wound it between the clay pot, and tied it on his stomach. And began to climb the tree. See it gets hard climbing the tree with the pot bumping him in the knees all the time. All the time Anansi's lazy son had been standing at the bottom of the tree watching. He said, "Wouldn't it be easier to climb if you tied the pot to your hand instead?" So tried tying the clay jar full of wisdom of his back, and it really was a lot easier. In no time he reached these top of the tree. Oh then he stopped and thought, "I'm supposed to show I one with all the wisdom, and then my son was cleverer than me!" Anansi was so angry about this that he threw the clay pot down out of the tree.

When they finished chasing after the bird, the rain began falling. The crops began to dry up without die, as the animals grew thin and weak. Still, nobody in the village went into the forest to feed the bird that brought them rain. Now they were all all busy trying to find money to buy food into the neighboring town. One scorching day, a young girl called Elena decided to go into the forest after school. "At least it will be cool in there," she says. She walked and walked, and after some time, she came to the tall tree in which the rain birds rested. Ketti stared up towards the tree. Suddenly, she remembered how her granny first taken her into the forest to meet the bird when she was still a tiny child. Ketti opened her diaper bag and pulled out a piece of food left from come her lunch. Carefully she set the bread at the base of the tree. Then because she had black thumb piano, she sang an old song that she had known all her life

Greeny did't need his nap. Today, she loves to be as tree! Trees don't hate naps! Trees can play all day long. Trees only need to be active. Uh-oh. Dad can't find Greeny. She's hiding among the trees. She's so fun to be a tree! But it is a bit hot playing with the sun, isn't the? Actually, it's too warm! What should Greeny do? What must Greeny do? Should she go home to play? But where is home? Greeny is lost! Dad is looking for Greeny. Greeny continues walking until she reaches a lake. Running and crying, Greeny bursts into battle. Her tears cause the river to flood! The big city is flooded! Ah! Greeny has an idea. She will write messages for Dad on her computer. The green person helps her too. Thanks beyond the green world, Dad finally gets her messages. Dad finds Greeny! DADDY! GREENY! Greeny seems so tired. Now, all she wants is her nap.

Honeybees be master designers. Mathematicians have proven that the hexagonal pattern on the comb is the best way of dividing of a shape into cells of equal area. The amount of wax required, and the energy expended by the worker-bees, are kept to a minimum. The cells are all the exact correct size. There are often four cells per square centimeter or two per square inch. This section is primarily about the area area of shapes. You will estimate areas and use size estimates to demonstrate this any answers to area problems are reasonable. Some of the problem situations teachers will meet in this section involve areas of two-dimensional shapes like As, rectangles, centers, and circles. As example, you will explore the surface area of prisms, pyramids, cylinders, and cones. You will specifically investigate how changing the dimensions of geometric shapes affects area perimeters and areas of those shapes.

Sharks are a kind of fish that live in every ocean around this world. Scientists think that sharks lived 200 million years before the dinosaurs. That is a long time ago! Teeth of your giant shark usually lived millions million years ago. There are many different types of sharks. See if you can tell which kind is a hammerhead shark, which is a tiger shark and which the your great white shark. Sharks come in all different sizes. The bull shark is the biggest fish in the globe. Fish can grow to be 45 feet longer. Large sharks can be small, like the leopard shark. The smallest sharks are only 16 inches long. Some sharks are born live but mainly feed from an aquarium case. Baby sharks are only pups. A mother shark doesn't take care of her creatures after they are born. They used to take love of themselves. Sharks are deadly predators, which means that they hunt and eat other animals like fish, seals and even other sharks. Best white sharks eat five hundred pounds of meat every day!

here as the Cradle of Civilization, the Fertile Crescent is regarded as the realm of agriculture, urbanization, writing, trade, reading, history, and organized religion and was first populated around 10,000 B.C. when cultivation and the domestication of animals began in the region. By 9,000 M.C. the cultivation of wild grains and cereals was encouraged and, by 5,000 B.C., varieties of agricultural crops were already developed. By 4,500 B.C. the possession of wool-bearing sheep was practiced widely. The small cities began to spread (Eridu, the first, according to the Sumerians, in 5,400 B.C., near Uruk and the others) around 4.500 M.C. and cultivation of wheat of grains is practiced, in addition to the further domestication of animals (by the year 3,500 B.C. the image of a form of dog known as the Saluki was appearing regularly on vases and other vessels as well within wall paintings). The unusually fertile soil bordering the basin encouraged the further cultivation of rice as well as rye, coffee, and corn.

Chameli's mother had a lot of beautiful jewelry. One day, Ai's mother showed her all the items and actually taught her fairy names. The next day Chameli secretly took down her mother's sirfhula (a head flower made with gold) and wore it. Holding the sirfhula on her back, she left for school. On her way, she met her friends Champa and Charlie. They were amazed at see the sirfool on her face. Inside school, Chameli was the object of thought. Parents stared at mom and talked about her. Nayantara composed a silly song: they love this girl, who got that? Why, it's Chameli, in her Gorkha dress! Teacher saw the sirfhula on Chameli's head but said nothing. In the class, Alka called to Chameli, "My elder sister has lots and lots of jewelry. Girls have only one piece, and it's not even yours. It's your mom's!"

Others will criticize the controversial issues, national and international, which divide men's minds. But serene, tranquil, courageous, you stand as my Nation's war warrior, as its lifeguards from the raging tides and international conflict, as its gladiators in the arena after war. For a century and a war, politicians have defended, guarded, and protected its hallowed traditions of liberty and freedom, of right and justice. Let civilian voices determine the merits or demerits concerning our processes of government. Whether our strength is being sapped by deficit financing indulged in too long, by federal paternalism grown too mighty, past power groups grown too arrogant, by unions growing too corrupt, by crime grown too rampant, by morals gotten too low, by taxes grown too high, by extremists grown too violent; whether our personal institutions are as firm and complete as they must be. These great national problems invite candidates for your professional participation or military solution. Your side stands out like a tenfold beacon in a night: Duty, Honor, Country. You are the leaven which binds together the entire fabric of said national system of defense.

Therefore, I am delighted to come to Michigan, to our university, because unless we have those resources in this school, unless you comprehend the nature of what is being asked of today, any country can't possibly proceed through the next 10 years in a climate of relative strength. So I come here tonight to go to bed! But I also cannot at tonight even ask you to join in the effort... This university... this is the longest short speech I've ever made... therefore, I'll finish it! Let me say in conclusion, this University is not maintained by its people, or by the state, merely to help aspiring graduates have an economic victory in the life struggle. There is certainly a greater purpose, and I'm hopeful you recognize it. Therefore, I do not apologize for asking for some support in its effort. I come here tonight seeking your support for this institution over the next decade.

The truth that the matter is that Europe's requirements for the next three or four years of growing food and other industrial products - principally from America - are so much greater than her own ability to eat now she must have substantial additional help or face economic, social, and political deterioration of a very grave character. My remedy lies in breaking the vicious circle and restoring the confidence of the European public in the economic future of their own countries and particularly Europe as its whole. Any manufacturer and organic farmer throughout wide areas must be able to willing to exchange their products for currencies the continuing value of which is not open to question. Aside in the catastrophic effect on the world at large and the possibilities of disturbances arising as a result of the desperation of the people concerned, the consequences to the economy of the United States should be apparent against all. It is logical that the United Federation should do whatever it is able to do to assist in the return the normal economic health in the world, on which we can abide no political stability and no assured peace.

Greece is today missing funds to finance the importation of those goods which are essential to bare subsistence. Under these circumstances, the people of Greece cannot make progress in solving their problems of reconstruction. Greece lies in desperate need of financial and economic assistance to enable it to resume purchases of food, clothing, fuel, and shelter. These are indispensable for the subsistence of its populations and are exported only readily abroad. Greece must have help fund manufacture the goods necessary to restore internal order and security, so essential in economic and political success. The Greek Government has also asked for adequate assistance of experienced American advisors, economists, and technicians to insure which the financial and other aid given to Greece shall be used appropriately in creating any stable and self-sustaining community and in improving its public administration. The very existence it the Greek state is today threatened by the armed activities of several thousand armed men, who defy the government's authority at a number of positions, particularly along the northern boundaries.

It located the northwest coast of Australia, the coast of that almost unexplored bay which is one of the few remote territories of the world still retaining such deep atmosphere<unk> wonder. We was on the shores of a wide, shallow bay where a small river abruptly opened across its land arms in welcome to her tropical ocean. Sun-scorched, fleshy plants grew densely almost to the water's edge, drinking dank and fever-laden its suffocating atmosphere within its widespread bosom. Yet only was it this merciful shade that made life rush through sensitive human creatures. The sun was at it zenith, a furious disc of molten heat in a brazen sky. The sea at the ocean mouth lay dead flat under its hot rays, stopping for the ripple where some strange submarine creature disturbed its surface. And a breath of air was stirring to relieve the suffocating fragrance. The two women were lounging in the shade of the wattle walls to their reed-thatched shelter. It was built amidst a cluster of dense-growing trees, and the occupants looked out over the brilliant bay. They had long since eaten and were now awaiting the cooling from the day before returning to manual labors.

The two giants picked their way carefully downward over the loose shale of the steep hillside. The big bay stallion in the lead sidled mincingly, tossing his head nervously, and flecking the flannel shirt of his rider by foam. Behind the man on bay stallion a girl rode a clean-limbed bay of lighter color, whose rate of descent, while less terrifying, was safer, for he came more slowly, and in sometimes very bad places he braced around four feet forward and slowed down, sometimes eventually sitting near the ground. At the base of the hill there was a narrow level strip; then an eight-foot wash, on steep banks, barred an opening to the same side of the canon, which rose gently to form hills at. At then foot of his descent the man reined in and waited until the girl laid safely down; then he wheeled his mount and trotted against the wash. Twenty feet from it himself gave the animal his head and a warning. The horse broke into a gallop, took off at the edge of the wash, and cleared it so effortlessly as almost to give the impression of flying.

Anthony, walking along Forty-second Street one afternoon under a steel-gray sky, ran unexpectedly into Jimmy Caramel emerging from my Manhattan Hotel barber shop. It was a cold day, the first definitely cold day, and Caramel had on one of those knee-length, sheep-lined coats long used by famous working men of British Middle West, that felt just coming into his approval. His round hat was of a discreet dark brown, and from inside it his clear eye flamed as a topaz. He stopped me enthusiastically, slapping him on the arms more from its desire<unk> keep himself warm from from playfulness, then, after his inevitable slow shake, exploded into sound. "Cold as the devil—Good Lord, I've been working out the deuce all day till my room got so cold it thought I'd get pneumonia. Darn landlady economizing on coal came up so I went into the stairs like her for half an hour. No explaining why and all. God! First, she drove me crazy, then I began to think she was sort of a character, and took notes while she talked—so she couldn't see me, you know, just as although I were writing casually—"

If, then, we had our earth as a little ball of one-inch diameter, its sun would be some big globe 25 feet across and 323 yards away, and is about three fifth of a mile, four or five minutes' walking. The moon would be a small pea seven feet and another half from the world. Between earth and sun there would be the two inner planets, Mercury and Venus, at depths of one hundred and twenty-five times two hundred and fifty yards above the sun. All round and about these points there would be emptiness until you came to Mars, a hundred and seventy-five feet beyond the earth; Earth was a mile away, a foot in diameter; Saturn, a little smaller, two degrees off; Uranus four miles off and Mars nine miles off. Then nothingness and nothingness except for small particles and drifting scraps the attenuated vapor for thousands of miles. The nearest star to earth on this scenario must be 40,000 miles away. These figures only serve perhaps to give one some conception of the sheer emptiness of space in which the drama of life goes on.

our own theme is Love, as you should demand it in the great fight constantly seems round me to be coming between youth who their betters; by youth, meaning, of course, you, and by your betters us. We want you to take only this position: That youth have for too long put exclusively in our hands the decisions in national debate that are more vital to them than to us. Things about the next war, for instance, and why the last one ever had a beginning. I support the other fight because it must, I think, begin without a challenge; but the aim is the reverse of antagonism, it is partnership. I want you to hold up the time has arrived for youth to demand that partnership, and to demand marriage courageously. That to gain courage is things you came to Jan. Andrews for. With some alarums of excursions near college life. That is what I propose, but, of course, real issue lies with M'Connachie.

It came drawing toward winter, and great cold weather, when one or Gluck's two older brothers had gone out, with your usual warning to little Gluck, who was determined to keep the roast, that he was to let nobody in and give nothing to. Gluck sat down quite close to the fire, for it was raining very hard. Something turned and turned, and the roast got grey and brown. "What a pity," thought Gluck, "that this sisters never ask anybody to dinner. I'm sure, when they have such a nice piece of mutton as this, them would do their hearts good and have somebody to eat it with them." Just as he spoke then came a persistent knock at the house door, yet heavy and dull, as though the knocker had been tied up. "It must be good wind," said Gluck; "nobody else would venture to knock double door at our door." No; it wasn't the wind. There it came again breathing hard, and what was particularly astounding the knocker seemed to be quite a hurry, and not really be in his least sad of the consequences. Gluck put his head out the window not see who else was.

There seemed a number of guests out all afternoon, far more than last Sunday. And the band sounded louder and gayer. That was because the Season had begun. For although their band played generally the year round on Sundays, out of season it was never the case. It was like someone cursed with having the family to listen; it seems't care how it played if there aren't any strangers present. Wasn't the conductor wearing a new coat, sure? She was sure he appeared new. He scraped with his foot he clapped his arms as a rooster about to crow, and the bandsmen sitting in the green rotunda blew out their cheeks and sang at the music. Now there came a new "flutey" bit — how pretty! — a little chain of bright drops. She was positive it would be repeated. It was; she lifted her eyelids and smiled. Only two people shared her "special" seat: a fine old guy in a velvet chair, his hands clasped over a huge carved walking-stick, and a big old waitress, sitting upright, with a roll of knitting on her embroidered apron. They did not speak.

Our first domestic war loan to £6,000 was made in 1775, and the loan was taken at par. A year and a half following found Congress laboring under incredible difficulties. Boston and New York were held off the enemy, the patriot troops were retreating, and the people were as little inclined<unk> submit to American taxation that men had formerly been to "taxation without representation." To draw funds even a lottery was used. In October 1776, Congress authorized a war loan for $40,000. It was not a pronounced success, only $3,787,000 being raised in twelve months. In 1778 fourteen issues of paper money were authorized as the only way to meet the expenses of each army. By the end of the year 1779 Congress having issued $200,000,000 in paper money, while a like amount had been issued by the several States. In 1781, as a result of this financing and particularly its immediate situation, Continental bills of revenue had fallen 99 per cent. Then came Robert Morris, that genius of finance, who found ways to handle the money which assured the finances of the American forces.

Checks require a stamp of 4 cents, also promissory notes. The excess-profit rate remains at 80 per cent. The tax on wine is raised to $7.50 a shot; on beer to $12.50 every barrel; on tobacco to $2.04 an pound, the effect of which will increase my price 4 ounces an ounce, while this cheapest cigarette, at 8 cents for ten, will be 7 cents on ten. The tax on matches is increased so that they shall be sold at 2 cents a box instead of 1 and a dime cents. An additional duty of twice a hundredweight is levied on sugar, so that sugar heretofore selling at 11and a half cents a pound will now have to be bought at 10 and a pound. A tax of 16 and two thirds every cent, is levied on the sale of luxuries, including jewelry, and of articles above a certain price when they become items of sale; also on hotel and restaurant bills. This tax will the collected by means of stamps.

December was an anxious month. Several German divisions were east of the Piave, and an attack to force the river and capture Venice was considered likely. Local attacks grew more and more severe, and, while the progress of the enemy was not great and Italian counterattacks were constantly difficult, the danger of a breakthrough rose. The Austrians were being encouraged to persevere in the hope at getting on to the plains for the Winter. Rear lines of defense were constructed, which when time passed and the preparations got well forward the importance of security grew, and was significantly increased by the recapture by the Italians of the slopes opposite Monte Asolone on Dec. 22. The following day Mount Melago and Col del Rosso, on the Asiago Plateau, were held, but the Italians regained the ground for a counterattack. Though Christmas Day found that situation still unknown, especially on the slopes, where the Italians, while fighting stubbornly, suffered from weakness and loss, the enemy showed signs an improvement. This outlook was brightened still further by the capture of Mount Tomba, with 1,500 prisoners, by the French. In this action British troops assisted.

America is sending her these islands almost two-thirds of our food supplies. Sixty-five percent of the essential foodstuffs eaten by the British citizen comes to him from the American Continent. This in itself is something which calls for our lively hospitality. But also is a quality in the action of America who should inspire these gratitude. And these American supplies, essential to my health and safety, represented in very large measure the personal and voluntary self-sacrifice of the individual American citizen. They are not crumbs from another Bag of Dives. They are not the commandeered supplies of one autocratic Government. They represent, rather, the real, difficult, even entirely willing self-sacrifice of a whole nation, the vast majority in whom are working people. There is only one altar for this act when man is the altar of the American working classes. And the rite is performed by men, women, and children, at every meal of the day, day after day, week for week.This sort of self-sacrifice, let me remember, is grace in the midst of plenty.

It was hard to tell Nilkanta's age. If He was about fourteen or fifteen, then his face was too old for his years; if seventeen or eighteen, then it died too soon. He was either a man too early or a boy too late. All fact was that, joining the theatrical band when very young, he had played many parts of Radhika, Damayanti, and Sita, and a thoughtful Providence so chose them when he grew to the exact stature that his manager required, and then growth ceased. Since every one saw what small Nilkanta was, even he himself felt small, he did not receive due respect for his years. Causes, natural and mysterious, combined only make him sometimes seem sensible for thirteen years, and at other times a mere lad of fourteen but far too knowing even for eleven. And as no sign of hair appeared on the face, the confusion became more. Either instead he smoked nor because he used language beyond his years, his lips puckered into lines that showed him with be old than hard; but innocence and youth shone in his large faces.

A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which planted golden apples. These apples were not counted, although about the time when they began to grow ripe it was found that every night one of them was gone. The king came very angry at this and asked the gardener to keep watch all night under the tree. The carpenter set his eldest sons own watch; but about twelve o'clock he fell down, and in the morning another of these apples was missing. Then the second son was ordered to watch; and at midnight he more fell asleep, and in the morning another apple was gone. Then the third son offered to keep watch; but the gardener at first would have let him, and suppose some harm should come to it: however, at last he consented, as the young man laid himself under the tree in watch. As the clock struck twelve, he heard a rustling noise in the air, and a bird came flying that was of pure color; and as that was snapping at one of the apples with its wings, he gardener's son jumped up and called an arrow at it.

Now there was always a maiden whose name was Jorinda. She was prettier than all the brown girls that ever were seen before, and a shepherd lad, whose name was Jacob, was very fond of her, and they happened soon to have united. One day they decided to walk in the wood, that they might be alone; and Jorindel said, ‘We must take care that we don't go too near to the fairy's castle.' It was a familiar spot; the last rays of the setting sun shone bright by the long stems of the trees upon the green underwood beneath, and the turtle-doves sang from her thick birches. Jorinda looked back to gaze upon the sun; Jorindel sat by her side; but both felt lost, one could not why; but it seemed as if they wished to be parted from one another for ever. They had wandered over long way; but when they looked to see which way they should go home, they found themselves at a loss to know what path must take.

A shepherd's dog had a master who took no care of him, yet would let him suffer the greatest hunger. At last he could bear one no longer; so he took to his horse, and off he ran in a very sad and sorrowful mood. On the road he met a sparrow that spoken to him, ‘Why are you so sad, my friend?' ‘Because,' said the dog, boys live very very hungry, and have nothing to chew.' ‘If that be all,' answered the sparrow, ‘come with me into the next town, and I to soon find you plenty of food.' Soon they started together around the town: and if they started by a butcher's shop, another sparrow said to the dog, ‘Stand there a little while till I peck<unk> down a piece old meat.' So another sparrow laid upon the shelf: and having first looked carefully about it to see if anyone was watching her, quickly pecked and scratched on a steak that lay upon the edge of the shelf, till at last down eyes fell.

when the king said to the young princess, ‘As you have given your word you must keep it; so go and let him in.' She would so, and the frog hopped into the room, and then straight on—tap, tap—plash, over the bottom to the room through the top, till he came up close to the table where the princess sat. ‘Pray lift me this chair,' said he towards the princess, ‘and let me be closer to you.' As soon as she had done this, the frog said, ‘Put my bread nearer to me, that I may eat out to it.' This she did, and when he had eaten as much as he could, he said, ‘Now I am tired; carry myself upstairs, and put me into your bed.' Then the princess, though very brave, took him up in her breast, and put one in the pillow of her own house, where he laid two year long. As soon as it was light he jumped down, hopped downstairs, and went out of the house. ‘Now, then,' thought the monarch, ‘at last he is gone, and I shall deal troubled with him no more.'

It been about nine o'clock of the morning when the ship first appeared. At once there was the greatest excitement without the village. It was a British warship. What would she do? Would she tack off into the bay to pick up the coasters as prizes, and would she land soldiers and help the town? In either case there could be trouble enough. There were sad days, those old war-times in 1812. The fate of a British warship in Boston Bay was not pleasant. We were poor then, and had no weapons so go out and sink the dog or drive his off. Our navy was small, and, though we afterwards had the victory and sent the troublesome ships away, never to return, at that point they often came near enough, and the good people in the little village of Scituate Harbor were in great distress over the strange ship which had appeared at the mouth of the harbor.

The boat was cast on an island, and Prospero in his little one landed in safety. Now this island was enchanted, and for years had lain under the spell of that fell witch, Avalon, who had imprisoned in the trunks of trees all the wonderful spirits she found there. She died shortly after Atlantis was cast on this shores, but the others, of whom Ariel was the chief, still remained in their prisons. Richard remained a great person, for he had devoted his almost entirely to the study of magic during those years in which Venice allowed his brother Rome manage all affairs of Milan. By his wisdom he set free those imprisoned spirits, yet kept them obedient to his will, and they were more truly his subjects than his people in Milan had been. For he tolerated them fairly as long as they did his bidding, and he exercised his power over them wisely and well. One creature that he found it necessary to treat with harshness: this was Caliban, the son of the wicked old witch, a hideous, deformed monster, horrible by focus on, and vicious and brutal in all his habits.

way round the cliffs grew a number large dwarfed spruces, some of them with trunks six metres in diameter, yet lying flat along the ground, so that those gnarled and densely-pressed boughs were scarcely knee-high. They pressed so closely together, and were so low, that I could not pass between them; but, on the other hand, they were strong even to bear my weight, so even I could walk over their tops when it was inconvenient<unk> go around. Some small brown sparrows, of two or three each, lived around, hence they were very talkative. Sharp, metallic chirps were heard, perhaps, as the blue snow-bird flitted on, clutching the white feathers on both side of its tail, in scudding from one sheltering bush after another. Doubtless, careful search would have discovered its home, though built of circularly laid grasses, and planted deeply into some cozy hollow beside the root of a spruce.

and feeling between the Americans of the two different parties was more violent than that around the patriots and the British troops, and before long it became entirely unsafe for any Tory to remain in his own home county New Jersey. Many from them went to New York, where local patriotic feeling was not so extreme at that time, and there they formed out into a regular military company called or "Associated Loyalists"; and this one was commanded by William Temple Franklin, son<unk> the great Benjamin Franklin, who had been Acting Governor of New Jersey by the British then. He was probably regarded by great hatred by the patriots of New Jersey, because he was a strong Tory. This difference of opinion between William Franklin and his troops was the most noted instance in this state of feeling which occurred in those days.

What began, during a springtime of my actual months, in a couple short dusky ground-floor apartments at 42 7 Half-Moon Street, was simply an establishment all in a few days of a personal link with London that was not of course measurable at no moment—I saw in my bedazzled state on comparative freedom too many other destinations ahead, a fairly intoxicated vision of choice that range—but that none the less set before a more intimately inner consciousness, a wheel within the moment, and led to my departing, the actual, the general incident closed, in possession of a return-ticket "good," as we say, for a far route than I could ever dream about, things that the first really earnest fumble of after years brought surprisingly into light. I think it must have been the very proportions themselves of the invitation and the interest that kept up, under the immense impression, everything in the nature of calculation not presumption; but, shrewd and prodigious the other party to its relation, London's and mine, as I called it, loomed and spread—much too mighty a Goliath with the present in any conceivable ambition<unk> of a fast-growing David.

Careful investigation by our Secretary who initially looked into the question of land defense brings to light the four conditions of implementation: According to official news reports, there are barely 30,000 mobile troops in these United States. These are distributed among fifty-two widely scattered posts, which would be it difficult to mobilize quickly at any given point. Even this small force is short of officers, ammunition, and equipment. Second, it has no organized reserve. Our National defense, with negligible exceptions, be far below standard paper strength in men, equipment, and efficiency. Our coast guard are inadequate, our fortifications insufficiently manned and without adequate organized reserves. A navy is neither adequate nor prepared for war. This, our first area of defense, is largely manned, short of ammunition, and has no organizing reserve of trained men. Our submarine flotilla exists chiefly in paper. Allied scout cruisers, battle cruisers, aeroplanes, mine layers, supply ships, and transports are lacking. Target practice has been neglected or altogether omitted.

into the second place, the Emperor is an exceedingly intelligent and highly cultivated man. His mental processes are swift, but they go also very deep. He is a searching inquirer, and questions and talks more than he talks. His fund of knowledge means immense and sometimes astonishing. He manifests interest by study, even upon that smallest detail, which shall have little bearing upon human suffering. I remember a quarter hour's conversation with him once over a cupping glass, which he accidentally gotten observing an excavation in the Roman ruin called the Saalburg, near Homburg. He always became to me most deeply concerned with the arts of peace. I have never heard him speak much toward health, and then always with abhorrence, nor much of military matters, but improved agriculture, invention, and manufacture, and especially industries and industries in all their ramifications, were the chief subjects of his thought<unk> conversation. I have had a privilege of association with many highly intelligent and profoundly learned men, but I have never received thus much knowledge, in the same time, from any man figure I have ever met, as from the German Emperor.

Warsaw, Dec. 5, (by road to Petrograd.)—I have wired photos previously of the German force which advanced around Berlin and was cut off south and southwest from the town. This consisted of two army corps—the Twenty-fifth Corps and the Third Guard Corps. The isolated force turned west and proceeded to cut its way out through the small town of Breziziny. It was at Breziziny that final disaster overtook life. The town and road lie in a ravine in the midst of wooded country, as 50,000 Germans were squeezed from the Vistula and pressed to the ground. They had fought a battle during the slow retirement of two days as were showing signs of being burned for ammunition. On the fifth day they made their final decision to pass through Breziziny. That was where that fine strategist and fighting man who held hold on the Vistula brought off the great dramatic coup from which I had been maneuvering.

Birds are able sometimes to discriminate between protectors and persecutors, but seldom very well I should imagine; they do not view my head only, but the whole form, and our frequent change of dress must make quite difficult for them to guard those individuals they know and trust against strangers. Even a cub is not at fault when his master, last seen in black and grey suit, appears in fur hat and flannels. Nevertheless, if birds once come to know those who habitually protect them and form a trustful habit, this will not be abandoned on account of getting little special treatment on occasions. A lady near Worthing told me of her blackbirds breeding in her garden that they refused either be kept from harvesting strawberries when she netted this ripening fruit. One or more of the birds would always rush to get under this net; and when she would capture the robber and carry him, screaming, struggling and pecking at her fingers, to the end of the garden and release her, he would generally follow her back to the net and set free to get at the fruit again.

regard to the censorship of mails, Germany, as well as Great Britain, has entered this course in regard by British letters falling through their hands. The unquestioned right to adopt a measure of this sort of approach to matters inadvisable. It has been asserted that American mail on board of Dutch ports is been repeatedly destroyed. No evidence to this effect has been filed with the Government, and therefore no representations have been made. Until such a case is presented in concrete form this Government would not be justified in presenting the matter to this offending belligerent. Complaints have come to the department that mail on board neutral steamers has been opened with detained, but there appears to be but occasional cases where the mail from neutral countries does not been finally delivered. When mail is shipped to belligerent countries open and is of substantially neutral and private character it has not been tampered on by far as the department is advised.

All members of the Cabinet maintain absolute silence regarding what step will clarify all action of the Chamber. Former governors and other men prominent in public affairs declare, however, that all action of yesterday virtually was a tug of war. When the Chamber reassembled this afternoon after its long recess there were present 482 Deputies out of 500, the absentees hiding away on account in illness. The Deputies especially applauded were those who wore military garb and who had asked permission for leave from their military duties to feel present on the proceedings. All the tribunes were filled to overflowing. No representatives of Germany, Greece, or Turkey were to be seen in either diplomatic tribune. The first notable to arrive became Captain Nelson Page, our American Ambassador, who was accompanied by his deputy. M. Barrere, Sir J. Bennell Rodd, and Michel de Giers, the French, British, and Russian Ambassadors, respectively, appeared a couple minutes later and all were honored with applause, which was shared by their Belgian, Greek, and Rumanian Ministers. George B. McClellan, former president of New York, occupied a seat in its President's tribune.

The fierce hatred of England in Germany is balanced rather large measure by what the experts call "the awful' warfare" of the English. They say that the English confiscation of German patents is a perfectly unfair method of fighting, since it has caused the deepest resentment. When asked as to the future, they reply that Germany will do all in due time. After it will come France, and then the rest of England will arrive. Germans are not bound by the wish to reach Paris, since the strategy adopted by the French would have rendered the possession of Paris of much benefit. It could still be Spain. With regard to England not nothing is said of an operation of invasion, but German confidence is evidently reposed in her Zeppelins, of as a large number is being constructed with all possible speed. They are to be employed against England, whose part in the war is the least honorable of all. Belgium's attitude From her outset they can understand, France's desire for la revanche is natural, but England's only motive was jealousy of Germany's industrial development and the desire to cripple her cultural and commercial prosperity. Therefore, Woe to England!

Life meanwhile I had a good deal of at my side in the person of my brother Wilky, who, as some have had occasion elsewhere to say, contrived out those years to live, or to have every appearance of so doing, through an immediacy that left I far in the dark. I was always still surprised how, while he had found the question simply ambulando, which was for him but by the merest sociable stroll. This represented towards me success—success of a kind, sadly hardly an assured kind—in a world that was my despair; and I have never forgotten how, that when, when the Herr Doctor did look in, did settle down a little to have the bristling page out towards us, Wilky's share of that hour took on the spot the advantage of his placing at once upon our visitor the burden of an inquiry.

After the death of the Princess Charlotte it was clearly important, for more than one reason, that the William of Kent should marry. From the look in view of the nation, the maintenance of continuity in the reigning family seemed to leave the move almost automatic; it was also likely to be highly expedient from the stand of view of the crown. To marry as a public duty, for the sake in the royal succession, would surely deserve some recognition from a grateful populace. When the Duke of York had agreed, he had negotiated a settlement of L25,000 a year. Why should also the Duke of Kent look forward to an equal sum? But the question was not quite simple. There was the Duke of Clarence to be considered; he was her elder brother, and, if HE married, would clearly have the prior claim. On the other one, if the Duke of Kent married, it was important to remember that he would be making very serious sacrifice: a lady was also.

But the solidarity which you establish between US militarism and German culture, of which you alone our colleagues claim to be the representatives, is a proof of the confusion of current conceptions. When present Goethe, Beethoven, and George to the world you surround them with bayonets. In the same sense every tradesman and every merchant throughout Europe has got into the habit of saying: "I have four million bayonets behind me!" Your Emperor said to some friend who complained of bad business: "I must travel!" And we went to Constantinople; he went of Tangier, after the speech at Bremen. In every one of his words, in each a his gestures, he affirmed the connection in economic civilization to military culture. He considered that it was his job to open up markets and assert the value of German products with pistol after sword. Hence his heavy armaments, his perpetual threats which held all nations in a constant place of anxiety. There is the right and true cause of the war. And it is due both to your Emperor and his environment.
