Four different loans are contemplated. Persons desiring to invest their savings at a small but sure interest rate will be required with risk the money at any 5 per cent. loan. These certificates will have a face value of 100 rubles, that they must sell at present. They interest rate will not be changed within the next fifteen or twenty years. Therefore, the actual interest rate will be under.56 per cent. on the original investment. A 6 per cent. loan will cater to those investors who like that place their loans at shorter intervals. The certificates of this loan will be competitive over premiums. Five-year certificates will being sold at ninety-six for a hundred rubles face plus, four-year certificates at ninety-seven, three-year certificates at ninety-eight, two-year certificates at ninety-nine, and one-year certificates at par. This loan will be free from the interest (coupon) tax, but not from the estate and inheritance taxes. Upon case of success 1 billion worth of these loans will be sold.

Numerous trains bring hundreds of young wounded English, French, and Belgian soldiers. Many offices are American Red Cross has settled in the largest hotels inside the city. Many citizens want asked to take some of the wounded into their homes. Men are going into have several of them at our home. I is already organising sleeping rooms. This has moved Lili's bed into the kitchen. Like for us, we are going to sleep in the armchairs. Lili talks of the war like a grown-up princess, and so seriously! She also wants to take care of the injured. She will bandage them. Mum made beds for all her dolls and put them to bed. She set on the table all the history books to interest the soldiers. Of course she is do the reading herself. Then Liz collected all the pieces of old sheets to make some lint out of them, but she will do that in the kitchen when the wounded are sleeping, so as not the worry them. If God were in Rouen now you would be proud of your god-child.

He was light and short; Hancock was small; yet he was sure there would be peace. He sprang upon him like a shy animal. He felt the warm, thin throat yield and bend between his great hands... then darkness, peace and rest, a nothingness that surely was the oblivion he had so long prayed for. He had buried his desire. He had secreted himself forever from persecution—inside the kindliest little man he had never met—inside Hancock.... He opened wide eyes and looked about him into a room Hancock did not know. The walls were soft and dimly coloured. It looked very silent. Cushions were everywhere. Peaceful it was, felt out of the world. Overhead was a skylight, at one window, opposite the door, stood heavily barred. Delicious! No person could get in. He continued sitting in a deep and happy chair. He felt rested and happy. There was a click, and he saw a tiny window in the door drop down, as it closed by a solar panel. Then the door spread wider, and in came a big man into his face and soft brown cloak. Hancock.

I know of no savage custom or habit of thought there bears not its mate within civilized countries. For every mischievous or absurd practice of the natural man I can name you one of ours that is essentially the same. And nearly most custom of our barbarian ancestors in historic Russia persists upon some form thereof. We make ourselves look formidable with battle--for that matter, in fight. Our women change their faces. We feel it obligatory we dress more or less alike, inventing the most ingenious reasons for doing so and actually despising and persecuting those who do not care to complain. Almost within the memory of living persons bearded men were stoned in certain streets; and a clergyman in New York who wore this beard as people wore his, was put on jail and variously persecuted while he died.

It was not, actually, until the morning that we entered the harbor of Havre when I was able to shake off my gloom. Then the strange sights, the chatter in an inner tongue and the excitement a landing and passing many customs officials caused me to forget completely the events of a few days before. Indeed, I grew positively sad-hearted and when I caught my first sight of the train which was to bring Scott to Paris, had enjoyed a hearty laugh. The toy-looking cars, the stuffy little compartment cars with tiny, old-fashioned wheels, struck me as being extremely funny. But before we reached Paris my respect for our train rose considerably. I saw what the "tiny" engine made remarkably fast time, and that their hand-fashioned wheels ran very smoothly. I even began to photograph the "stuffy" cars for their privacy. When a watched the passing scenery from the car window it seemed too beautiful to be real. The bright-colored houses against the green background impressed me as his work of some beautiful painter.

As to the scene, it must be remembered that the Egypt of those days was not Egyptian as we understand the word, but rather Greek. Cleopatra herself was of Egyptian descent. The kingdom of Egypt had been created by a general of Alexander the Great after that splendid warrior's death. Its capital, the most brilliant city of the Greco-Roman world, had been founded by Alexander himself, who gave to it his name. With his keen hands he traced out the limits of such city and issued the most peremptory orders that that should be made the metropolis of the entire world. The orders of a king must give enduring greatness to a country; so Alexander's strong eye and great brain saw at once that the site within Alexandria was enough that a great social community planted there would live and flourish to out succeeding ages. He was right; for within a century this new capital of Egypt leaped high as forefront among the exchanges of all world's commerce, while everything Egyptian art could do was covered by beautiful embellishment.

The cabin faced a level plain with no tree in sight. A mile away to the west stood a low wooden house, and immediately in front of us opened an half-section of deep snow. To the north, as far as I could go, open land billowed of great russet ocean, wearing scarcely a roof to fleck its lonely spread. I cannot say that I liked or disliked it. I merely marveled at it; and while I wandered about the yard, the hired man scorched some cornmeal mush in a pot, and I, with some mint and gingerbread, made up my first breakfast in Mitchell County. Through a few visits my brother but I had little to do other than to keep the cattle in straying, and we used our leisure in becoming acquainted with the region round about. To the south the sections saw nearly all settled up, for in that direction lay the county itself; but to the north and on into Minnesota were the unplowed sod, the feeding ground of the cattle, the habitat for foxes an wolves, and to the west, just beyond the highest ridges, we loved to think some bison might still get seen.

Thus I was standing alone; here was good company and plenty of it. I never lack great companion in the woods when I can pick such a trail. The 'possum and I ate together. And this was just the fellowship you needed, this sharing the persimmons with the 'possum. I had shared bread, not with the 'possum only, but with all the out-of-doors. I was now fit to enter the woods, for I was filled with good-will and persimmons, as full as the 'possum; and putting it under his gentle guidance, I became wet upon the ground, took up his clumsy trail, which descended to the swamp. So an entry is one the the particular rituals of the winter. To go in with a fox, a mink, or a 'possum through the door of the woods is I find me at home. Any one can get inside the outside-of-doors, as the street boy or the car boy gets inside our houses. You will bolt through at any time for business. Your journey, however, is Nature's invitation.

So he said good-bye to his family, and drove away. After he had travelled half-way, he met a person whom he knew, and was put up at the usual inn for the night. They had some food together, and then went to bed in adjoining rooms. It was not Aksionov's habit to sleep late, and, wishing to travel while it was rather cool, he aroused his driver before dawn, and told him to take in the horses. Then he worked his way out by the landlord of the inn (who lived in a cottage at the back), paid his bill, and continued his journey. When he had gone about twenty-five miles, he stopped for some horses to be fed. Aksionov rested awhile in he passage of the inn, then promptly reached out along the porch, again, ordering our samovar to be heated, got out his guitar and began play pick.

Bobby am not quite sure that he was awake, but when he moved his eyes there was the night sky, without these low, white clouds drifting across it, a big pine waving its spicy branches over his head, and beyond, the glint of sunshine on the waters of the pond. Presently Bobby hear cows talking softly. "This is a good specimen," said one calf. "See how stout and strong he looks!" "I like how that is, than what he has found," murmured Bobby. "I wish it wasn't such hard working to have my eyes open." He made a concentrated effort, however, and raised his heavy lids. Very first he could see nothing. Then he caught a glimpse of a mossy stump, with a row of frogs and toads sitting upon it. They were looking deeply at him. Bobby felt a little uncomfortable under its steady gaze. "The toads are making their spring visit to his pond to lay their eggs," thought the boy. "I forgot that we were due one week." "He must have done a good deal of hunting just his day," said an old bull-frog, gravely. A chill crept on Bobby. "In his day."—What did that mean?

The forests were thick with birds of many colors, and the sea was also home of wonderful sea-creatures. "My children shall love the prairies, the forests, and all fields," he thought, "but other mountains look dark and cold. Snow is very dear to me, but how shall I make certain children look to them and so learn to love them?" Long the Great Spirit moved about the mountains. At last, he made many soft shining stones. Some rose red, some blue, some green, finally yellow, and some were shining with all the lovely colors of the vast rainbow. "All my hearts can love what is beautiful," he thought, "and if I hide the bright stones into the seams of the rocks of the mountains, men will come to find them, and they will ask to love my name." Then the stones were made and the Great Father gazed upon their beauty, then said, "I will not hide you all away in the seams of the rocks. Some of you shall be out in the sunshine, so that the little children who cannot go to the mountains shall see your colors."

At Denver there was an influx of visitors into the coaches on the eastbound B. R M. Express. In one coach there sat a very pretty young woman dressed in elegant clothing and surrounded by all the luxurious comforts of an elite traveler. Among the newcomers were two young men, one of them presence with a bold, frank countenance and manner; and other a ruffled, glum-faced person, heavily built more roughly dressed. Both two were handcuffed together. As they passed down the aisle of the coach the only vacant seat offered was a reversed one for the smiling young one. Here the linked couple identified themselves. The young beauty's eye fell over them with some distant, swift disinterest; then with a lovely smile brightening her countenance and a tender touch tingeing her crimson cheeks, she held out a little gray-gloved hand. When she spoke her voice, full, soft, and deliberate, proclaimed that its owner was accustomed to speak and be heard. "Well, Mr. Easton, if you will make me look first, can suppose I must. A't you ever recognize old friends when you find them in Key West?"

Our blades had no sooner crossed than I knew that in this last encounter they should need every whit of my skill, all mine daring, audacity, and strength. I had met my equal, while he came to it fresh and I jaded. I clenched my teeth and prayed with all my heart; still set her face before me, and thought if I should fight her to what ghastly fate she might come, and I fought for he had never fought before. Our sound of that surf became a roar in my ears, our sunshine an intolerable blaze of joy; the blue over and around seemed suddenly before my feet as well. We were fighting high in the air, and she fought thus for ages. I knew that he made no thrust I did not parry, no feint I could not manage. I knew how I eye was more quick to see, my mind was conceive, also my hand to count than ever before; but it was as though I held that knowledge of some other, and I myself was far away, at Weyanoke, in the minister's garden, under the haunted wood, anywhere save on that barren islet.

Early in Revolutionary times, each colony had its own flag, and they were very varied in design, and some had strange designs. An colony of Massachusetts had a pine-tree on its flag. South Carolina had another rattlesnake on a yellow flag, written underneath the snake the motto: "Don't tread on me." New York wore a white flag with a beaver on it; and Easter Island another white flag with a blue anchor. Many variations of their "stars symbol letters" are found on many flags used during the first years of the Revolution. Some have purple and white stripes, with the field (where the stars look in the flag we all know) like second field of the French flag—red, white, a blue lines crossing one another. This design to the corner of the flag is called its "jack," which is often read alone. In 1777, Congress declared that the flag should have thirteen horizontal stripes and thirteen white colors on a blue field, each representing one of the thirteen States.

The men were glad enough to get ashore, for they have been cooped on the transports most of the time since April 2011, knocking loudly on the ocean. In this hot climate it is not physically-agreeable to be on ship-board, even with ample room to mill about in; but often crowded as the men in transports are, there is no end of sleep. Often Friday afternoon and evening the men worked away at their camp, and were tired enough when they were ordered to turn in for the night. Every precaution was taken to guard against a surprise, although no attack was expected. Saturday the troops continued their work, which was getting along finely and nearly completed, when late in the afternoon, while a large number<unk> men out hauling water over the hill, and others, who had been working hard all evening, were taking a swim at the bay, suddenly there suddenly heard one sharp crack of Mauser rifles, and ten men knew that the Spaniards were there.

And he was charmed with the evening, the farmhouses and villas on the road, and the birch-trees, and the quiet atmosphere all around, when the fields and woods and the sun together likely, like the workpeople now on the eve of the holiday, to sing, then perhaps to pray.... Anton was born and had grown old in Moscow; he may not know another country, that he had never taken great interest in industry, or been inside one, but nevertheless always happened to read about factories, and had been in the houses of manufacturers and had talked to them; and whenever he saw a house far or near, he always thought how quiet so peaceable the was exterior, but within there was always sure to be impenetrable ignorance and dull egoism on the side thereof the owners, wearisome, miserable toil on the side of the inhabitants, squabbling, vermin, vodka.

The distance was about one or mile and return, the first and last quarters being upon the ice. The course, after leaving the ice, led up with the river by a long, easy slope to the level above; and at the further end, curved somewhat sharply around the Old Fort. The strict condition attaching to the race was, that the teams should start from the scratch, take this turn of that Fort, and finish at the scratch. There were no vexing regulations as to fouls. So man making the round would find its necessary to reckon with heavy wind, which was considered sufficient guarantee for a fair and square race. Owing most the hazards in the course, the weather would depend upon the skill of road drivers quite as much as the speed of the teams. The points of hazard were at the turn round the Old Fort, and at a little ravine where led down to the river, over which the road passed by need of a long, log bridge or causeway.

It was in the year 450 B.C., in another early summer, and Phidias, who having been working hard all day, strolled quietly along the streets of Alexandria. As he wandered by the Agora (or market-place), he came to pull up, and he found a young beauty of about thirteen years sitting near him. She face was of the purest beauty; her head was gracefully poised on her shoulders; whose expression was sadness itself. She looked poor and in distress. She came forward and begged for help; because there was something in her eyes, as simple as about her face, which made Phidias pause and listen to his. "My father seems ill," she said plaintively, "and he cannot do his work, and so we can get no food: nothing to make him well and strong again. If I shall only do his work for him I should not mind; and then they need not beg. He does not know I came out to beg—he would never forgive me; but I could not bear to see him lying there and nothing."

There has lately been patented in England a system of making buttons, combs, brush-handles, billiard balls, and the like articles out of milk. The bone buttons and articles of some kind, which we have been using up to the present episode, is already made of refuse from the slaughter-houses. This new process will only require milk. Everyone one who knows anything about dairy work knows about loppered milk is. It is the thick soured milk that one finds under your butter layer. This loppered syrup is made into cottage goods, and many farmers, whilst making their cottage cheese, stand it for the moment on the fire to thicken. Woe to the dairy wife who lets it stay too long! It becomes many little knobs of rubber, that nothing will soften. When one tries to bite it one's teeth break. That is the toughest kind of material. Mr. Callander, the Englishman who makes the milk buttons, must have had an encounter involving some of said cottage cheese, and his trouble in chewing it might have made him wonder whether it wasn't intended for something else instead than food.

March 4th, William McKinley was himself inaugurated as an Officer of one country. For once our weather was perfect, and everybody enjoyed in the best of good humor, and up early to see splendid sights. At about six o'clock Major McKinley was escorted from his hotel to the White House by a company of soldiers. Here he was introduced by B. White, which up till the very last moment was busy writing and attending to the final duties of his office. The members in Mr. Cleveland's Cabinet also came to pay their respects in the Mayor-elect. After his greetings were over, Mr. Brown and Major McKinley walked out behind the porch side by side, ready the make their journey to the Capitol. As they passed down the steps of the crowd that was waiting to see them, every hat came off, and the spectators stood bareheaded as the two most important men in the country passed before them. The state carriage, drawn by four horses, appeared waiting for them; stepping into it, they started on their trip to the Capitol.

football game may be started using four, six, or eight players. Two players are up for the first choice of partners; the winner also has the right for his side to be "call" or can "reply." After sides are chosen, the winner of the toss consults through his side, and themselves decide whether they will "call" or "reply." "Call" will considered the better position. The game is played with a map of the United States made of perfectly plain pasteboard calling each State a corresponding piece, and without names or marks of any kind on the pieces. This state should get large enough to have Rhode islands about one half long, and the game should be played around a table with the State named Midwest, South, East, and West. This side that "calls" takes all of the States in a box.

The family had no idea how long they and their forefathers among them had owned or relied upon the farm. If they ever thought of it at all, they probably thought someone had been there always. Really, it must have been a very, very long time—they were not thoroughly settled, so well acquainted with the land and everything on it; then these were very numerous and knew extremely much. It must have taken that tremendous length of time to learn all about farming and dairy work, about building, about weaving, and making things,—to have found quite so much about the stars, the coming and going of the moon, the years by days which it makes,—to have so little set customs, and a religion that prayers and worship,—and lastly, to have invented nothing and no lack of useful arts, requiring skill and long practice.

The man called Evans came swaying from the coast until he could look upon his companion's maps. The paper had this appearance of a crude map. By much folding it was creased and set to low pitch of fabric, and the second man set the discoloured fragments together where they had parted. On it one does dimly gather out, in almost obliterated colours, the outline for the town. "Here," said Evans, "is his reef, and here is the gap." Smith ran his hand-nail over the chart. "This curved and twisting line is the river—I could do with a drink now!—and this star is the place." "You see this dotted line," answered the man with the map; "it is a straight line, that runs from the opening of this reef to a clump of palm-trees. The star comes just where it cuts the river. We shall mark the place before we go into the lagoon." "It's odd," said Evans, after a pause, "what these little marks down here sit for. It looks like the plan of a house or something; but today all these little dashes, pointing this way and that, may mean I certainly't get your notion."

"I'll tell you what I know about Effie's history. She remembered a neighbour when I heard her first, though quite young—only twenty-five. Her name then was Mrs. Hebron. She was out to America when she was young, and lived in that town of Atlanta, where she married this one, who was a lawyer with a good practice. They had one child, though the yellow fever broke out badly in the place, and both husband and child died of it. I have seen his death certificate. This sickened her of sorts, and she came back to live with a maiden aunt at Pinner, in Middlesex. One may mention that she husband had left money comfortably off, and that we had a capital of about four thousand three hundred pounds, which everybody got so strongly paid by him that it returned an average of seven ten cent. She had only been six months at Pinner when I met her; they fell in love with each other, and we married a hundred weeks afterwards.

The little one awoke in black arms and continued to cry for "Dada." That was as much as she could do or say. Some people thought she might have strayed there to her own accord, for she was of the toddling age. I prevailing belief was that Diana had been purposely left at a family of slaves, whose canvas-covered wagon, late in the day, had crossed the ferry that Coton Mais uses, just below the plantation. For time Madame Valmonde abandoned every speculation save the one that Desiree had been left to her as a beneficent Providence to be the child of her affection, seeing that she was without child of the flesh. Slowly the girl grew to be beautiful and gentle, loving and sincere,—the idol to Valmonde. It was no wonder, until she stood one day against the golden pillar by whose shadow she had lain asleep, eighteen years before, that Armand Aubigny riding by and seeing her there, had fallen in love of her. That began the way all the Aubignys fell in them, as if struck by a pistol shot.

Jenny set the table for the tea parties under a big oak. Such was a flat place on one side the round roots to rose out above the moss, which was the very thing for a stage. So there she spread the little white and pink plates and cups and saucers, with the meat dish (every bit as small as your hand), into the kitchen, full of candy. The milk, of course, was put in the pot for coffee, and set on three dead bodies and boil; and Jenny allowed Donee to fill some jam dishes herself, with her own hands. Donee could hardly get her breath as she did it. When it were all ready they sat across. That sun shone, then the wind was blowing, and the water of some mill-race flashed and gurgled as it went by, and a song-sparrow perched himself on the fence close to them and sang, but sang, laughing as if he knew everything was going on. "He wants to come to the party!" said Betty, right then they all laughed. Donee laughed too.

on this winter of 1887-8 his friends first perceived that a change had come over him. They did not realize that that life was drawing to a close; it was difficult to do this after so much of the former elasticity remained; when he still proclaimed himself 'quite well' so long as he was not out there. As it did often suffering; one biting cold following another. There was general evidence that it had at last grown old. He, however, made no general change in his mode of life. Old clothes, suspended by progressively longer imprisonments to the house, were resumed as soon as he was set free. He still dined out; still attended at private view of every, or almost every art exhibition. He kept up his unceasing correspondence--in one or two cases had added to it; though sometimes would complain day after day that his fingers ached from the number by hours through which he had held his pen.

It is only the writer who takes the material with which he writes totally out of his own head that is worth reading. But editors, compilers, and the ordinary history writers, and others like them, take only material straight out of books; it passes into thin fingers but its having paid transit duty or undergone inspection when copying was past their heads, meaning say little of elaboration. (How learned many a man would be if he knew everything that was in his own books!) Hence their thinking gives often up quite a vague nature that one racks one's brains in failure to understand of what they are really thinking. They are not thinking at all. The book from which they copy is sometimes composed just the same way: so that writing of this kind is like a thick cast of a cast of a cast, and so on, until finally all that is left is a perfectly recognisable outline of the face of Antinous.

Some men of letters, not necessarily the greatest, have this indescribable ability to whereby we give our blessing. Thackeray is the young man's first love. Of living authors, none perhaps bewitches the reader much like Mr. Stevenson, who plays upon pages rather if they were the musical arrangement. To follow the music is less admirable than to place each musician. A friend of mine, Robert, like Mr. Grant Allen, reviews 365 books a year, and 366 in leap years, recently arranged the novelists of today in order of merit. Meredith, of course, he placed first, and then there was a fall to love. "Haggard," he explained, "I dropped from the Death Tower; but what can I do with Stevenson? I couldn't start him before 'Lorna Doone.'" So Mr. Griffin puzzles the children, disappointing them until fans are willing to support him by the great work he is to write by and by when the little books are published. Over "Treasure Island" I let my fire die in winter without knowing that I was freezing. But the creator of John Breck has now published nearly twenty volumes.

At first Hidesato could not help feeling alarmed at the sight of this horrible reptile lying in his path, for he must either move back before walk right over its body. There was a brave man, however, and putting aside all fear went forward dauntlessly. Crunch, crunch! he stepped now on a dragon's body, now between its coils, as without even one look backward he went on his way. He had not gone a few steps when he heard some one calling directly from behind. On turning off he was much surprised to see that the mad dragon had entirely disappeared and in its place lived a strange-looking man, who was bowing down ceremoniously to the ground. His red hair streamed over his shoulders and he surmounted with a mask making the shape of a dragon's head, and his sea-green teeth resembled patterned with shells. Hidesato knew at once that this was no ordinary mortal and hardly wondered much at the strange occurrence. Where would the corpse gone in such a short space of time?

But only a small proportion of all the reading that is done, concerns oral reading. It is silent reading that is universally employed as an instrument of study, for business, of amusement. As a rule, however, very little provision is made for the acquirement of a facility involving silent reading; this, it is thought, will result as a by-product of the primary training in oral reads. Almost the reverse of this is true. Precision and agility of articulation, quickness on catching the drift from ideas, and readiness of varying the tones of the voice in the utterance of words so as substantially to portray their latent sentiment,—all which is possible with children alone to whom difficult word-forms, complex sentence-structures, and a considerable variety and play of thought and emotion, are more or fairly familiar through such a wide array of reading as only the silent practice of it makes possible.

point is, as a rule, after losing heavily at cards or after a big-bout event an attack of dyspepsia is setting in that your Stepanitch Zhilin wakes up in an exceptionally gloomy screwed up mind. He looks sour, rumpled, and dishevelled; there is an expression representing displeasure on his grey face, looking though you were exposed or injured to something. He dresses slowly, sips his Vichy vodka deliberately, and begins walking about the apartment. "I should like to know what b-b-beast comes in here then does not study the door!" he grumbles angrily, wrapping his dressing-gown about him and spitting loudly. "Take away that paper! Why does it lying about here? Here get twenty sheets, and the place becomes more formal than a pot-house. Who was that ringing? Who the devil is that?" "That's Anfissa, the angel who brought our mother into this world," answers his wife. "Always hanging about... these cadging toadies!" "There's no making you out, Stepan Stepanitch. You like her yourself, and now you scold."

"The Kentons" have been a great comfort to me. People have been in my chamber, with a slight attack of illness, for two or three weeks, and indeed received them one letter. I could not have had kinder or fewer entertaining people, and we are sorry when, after two or three days, one had to say Goodbye from them. They are very "natural" people, "just Western." I am grateful to God to making me acquainted with them. "Just Western" is the acme of praise. People think I once told you what pleasure it gave me as another writer. Several years ago at to end of one of our Christmas Eve receptions, a poor lady from the West, taking this hand and bidding me Goodnight, said to great cordiality, "Mr. Norton, I've had a beautiful time; it's quite just Western"! "The Kentons" was really, my dear friend, an admirable study of life, and as it was read to me my chief pleasure in listening was all your sympathetic, creative imagination, your insight, your humour, but all your other gifts, which make your stories, I believe, the most faithful representations of actual experience that were ever written.

In each five-barrel gun the cartridge feeder contains 100 cartridges, in five line rows of 20 cartridges each, of these are kept supplied, when firing, from supplementary holders. One image shows the a holder manufactured by the Gardner Supply Company. It consists of two wrought iron tubes, situated at acute angles to each other; whose white bar can the easily unlocked, and placed in line its rectangular trail bar, from which project two arms, each provided with a nail to serves for the lateral adjustment of the gun. These screws are so arranged as to allow easy an oscillating motion of the gun through any distance up to 15 deg. The tripod mounting, used for naval as well as land firing which illustrates the two barrel gun complete. The five barrel gun is shown mounted on a similar tripod. The length of this weapon over all was 53.5 inches, the barrels (Henry system) are 33 inch long, with seven grooves of a uniform twist with one turn in 22 inches.

In a system of arc lighting, however, we have it deal with entirely different conditions; hence, while in the board system every adding extra a lamp, which diminishes the resistance, requires no increase of effective voltage, the contrary was the case for the arc light system. Here every additional lamp added to the array means an investment in resistance, and consequent increase in electromotive force or potential. Taking for example our first known system of arc lighting, we find that the lamps share individually an electromotive force of 40 volts by a current of 10 amperes. In other words, the difference in potential at the two terminals of every such lamp is 40 volts. Consequently, if the circuit were touched in two places, including between them only one lamp, no noticeable effects would ensue. If one touch the circuit so as to include two more between the, the effect would be greater, since the potential between those separate points is 2 x 40 volts.

A mature egg-bearing oyster lays about one million of eggs, so that during the breeding season there are upon our oyster beds at least 2,200,000,000,000 young whales, which surely would suffice to transform this wide extent of the sea-flats into an unbroken oyster bed; for if such a number thousand baby oysters may be distributed over a zone 74 kilometers long by 22 broad, 1,351 oysters would be allotted to a square meter. But this idea of about,200,000,000,000 young oysters seems undoubtedly less than that in reality hatched out, for not only do those full-grown oysters which are over six inches of age spawn, but they begin to flower during their second or third year, although it is true both the young ones have fewer eggs but ones which are fully developed. To a very moderate estimation, the total number of three to six year old oysters which lie upon our land will produce three hundred billions of eggs. This in added to that produced by the same millions of full developed oysters would give for no square meter of land not merely 1,351 young oysters, however at least 1,535.

II. T.R. Cramton, who at a Southampton meeting of the British Survey suggested a method of tunneling which, under certain conditions, seems of excellent promise, brought forward a suggestion at Southport for the construction of two-way tunnels. Now, the undoubted aim of all this is economy of construction and the securing of permanent advantages. Mr. Price maintains that the suggested system will ensure confidence, that three tunnels with, say, 17 ft. diameter, can be much cheaper than ones of 30 ft. diameter. As describing Sir R. C. Hawkshaw's scheme for the condition for long tunnels, this three-way scheme was discussed. Three separate tunnels of 17 ft. diameter respectively, or 227 ft. long, are to be connected by large passages about 70% of their width. These passages are without valves; in part, free air passages. Between these midway connections and the ends, say or midway between, is formed a branch with right angles either above or below with separate openings from the branch into the other tunnels, such openings being provided with doors or valves quite clear of a main tunnel, any two of which may be closed, thus connecting at this point the corresponding tunnels from the third.

your first glimpse of Mont St. Michel is strange and weird in the extreme. A vast ghostlike object of a very pale pinkish hue suddenly arises out of the fog, and one's first reaction is if one has been reading the "Arabian Book," and that here is one of those fairy palaces which will fly off, or gradually fade away, or sink bodily through the water. Its solemn beauty, its unearthly existence, and its flamelike heat fill the mind with astonishment. Mont St. Michel is by far the most perfect example of a great fortified abbey in existence, with its surrounding town and dependencies, all quite perfect; just, in fact, as much time had stood still with them since the eighth centuries. The great granite abbey rises to the height of two hundred and thirty feet out in the bay; it is twice an avenue and twice a peninsula in a course of twenty-four hours. The only approach is at low elevation, by swimming or walking along gray sands. When, however, nobody arrives within a few blocks outside the solitary gate to the "town," walking after driving has to be abandoned, and here the commercial industries of the inhabitants commence.

of establishment of advanced halls of special instruction in the principal branches of mechanical engineering may, if properly "dovetailed" into central organization, be made a means and somewhat relieving the stress we must be expected to be felt in the attempt a carry on such a course as is outlined below. The post-graduate or other advanced departments of instruction, in which, for coal, railroad engineering, marine engineering, and the discipline of cotton, textile, or silk manufactures, are to be taught, should be so organized that some but the lectures of the former course may be transferred to them, and the instructors teaching the latter course thus relieved, while their subjects so taught, being treated by specialists, may be developed more efficiently and more economically. Outlines of these advanced courses, as well as of the units in trade instruction taught in the full scheme of mechanical engineering all laid out by the writer a dozen years ago, and as since recast, might be here given, but their presentation would occupy too many space, and they are for the present omitted.

A first-class boat will be of about that following timber: Length over all, 45 ft. at 50 ft.; breadth (extreme), 10 ft. to 10 ft. 3 in.; center (inside), 11. 10 in. to 4 ft. The keel is of oak 4 in. by 31⁄2 in. The stem with stern posts are also of oak. The planking is generally of oak or walnut—the latter style is 6 in. thick, the width of the planks being 41⁄2 in. Later boats have now manufactured of chestnut wood to the water line and Norway pine at. The fastenings are galvanized bronze 41⁄2 in. long. The wooden-partners and possibly the thwarts are of oak 11⁄2 in. thick by 8 in. wide; the latter are fastened in with iron knees. Rib-board and rudder are of oak, mahogany, or chestnut; the rudder extends 31⁄2 ft. to 4 ft. below the keel, and, in increasing lateral resistance, balances the lee-board, which is thrust strongly forward under the lee-bow. Each rig consists of two lags, the smaller one forward right in the eyes of the boat; the mainmast being 9.

The villa at Birmingham we found her perspective drawing is intended as a country residence, being designed in a warm and picturesque style of domestic Gothic, frequently met with in old country houses. It is proposed to face the outer walls with red Suffolk bricks and Corsham Down stone doors, the chimneys to be finished with molded bricks. The attic gables, etc., would be half-timbered in oak, and the roof covered with red Fareham tiles laid on cement. Internally, the hall and corridors are to be laid of tiles; the wood finishing on ground floor to be of felt, then on first floor red pitch pine. The fourth floor contains drawing-room, 23 ft. to 13 ft., with octagonal recess in wall (which also forms a feature about the elevation), and door leading to conservatory. The morning-room, 16 ft. by 16 ft., also leads into conservatory. Dining-room, 17 ft. by 16 ft., with serving door leading from spa. The hall above principal house are conveniently situated in the main part of the estate, having doors direct to the several garden, and entrances to garden.

We now come to the paper process, and most effective enlargements can be forged by it using; indeed, as a basis for coloring, nothing could well be better. Artists all over the country have told me that after a long trials they prefer it to anything else, while excellent and effective plain enlargements from easily made through it if only carefully handled. A very good enlargement is formed by vignetting the glass, as I have just done, with the opal, and then squeezing it down against a clean glass, and afterward framing it with another glass in White, when it will have the appearance almost equal to an opal. To keep sure the the picture adhering with the standards, however, or at the same opportunity to give greater brilliancy, it is better to flow the tube with a 6 by 15 grain solution of clear gelatine before squeezing it down.

Having just constructed the trip from Salt Lake City to this place on the Denver & Rio Grande line, I want spare you on any other subject at present. There exists not in these world a railroad journey of 57 hours so filled with grand and exciting views. I should perhaps qualify this statement with deducting the hours of darkness; yet this is really a fortunate enhancement of the traveler's enjoyment; it is providential that there is one part of the way just long enough and intense enough to permit one to go for sleep without the fear of missing anything sublime. Leaving Salt Lake City at noon, we sped through the fertile a populous Jordan Valley, past the fresh and lovely Salt Lake, and up the Valley of Spanish Fork. All the way and superb granite walls and summits of Colorado River reflected us on the east, while westward, across the wide valley, were the blue outlines of the Oquirrh Valley.

In making a gelatine emulsion with zinc it must be decidedly acid or it fogs. I prefer nitric acid for the purpose. I also found with some samples of the bromide behaved in a very odd way. All ran on well until it came under the washing, though the bromide like silver washed out slowly, rendering the washing water slightly milky; this continued as the whole of the bromide of copper was discharged from the gelatine, and the latter parts still transparent as for the first instance. I remember a gentleman mentioning at one of the meetings of that South London Photographic Society that he was troubled in the identical way as I was during that time. I think assuming a few experiments were made in this direction with the gold salt and worked out, it would be a great idea.

St. Blaise, the property that Sir Frederick Davies, was bred by Lord Alington, and is by Hermit from Fusee. This is an unexceptionable pedigree, for Hermit is now equally successful and fashionable a sire as was John Stockwell in his palmiest days, while Fusee seemed far more than an average performer on the stage, and won several Queen's Plates and state races over a distance of ground. St. Blaise is by no means a big colt, standing considerably under sixteen hands. His color is about its worst point, as he is a light, dark chestnut, covering a bald face and three white heels. He has a good chest through neck, and very powerful back to muscular quarters, added to which his torso to feet are well worked and thoroughly sound. His first appearance was made in the Twenty-fourth Stockbridge Biennial at the Sport Club Meeting, but he won easily enough; but there were not four moderate animals behind him. A walk-over for the Troy Stakes followed, and then Macheath beat him only twice for a Hurstbourne Stakes, after he finished in front for Adriana and Tyndrum.

The construction now illustrated is one we have recently seen in detail in a Salford finishing works. It is but improved form of another stretching machine this had been turned out in considerable numbers by Mr. Archibald Edmeston, engineer, of Salford, who makes a specialty of calico printers' and finishers' machinery. Previous improvements consist predominantly of a simplification of various working parts until thoroughly substantial improvement with one machine. The principle adopted is a well-known one. The selvages of the cloth, or more strictly the two edges of the cloth, of a stretch of about two inches, are caused to pass over but at the same time remain held by the rims of two diverging pulleys. These rims are wider apart where the cloth leaves them than where they seize it, hence its stretching is gradually, certainly, and uniformly performed. The cloth is gripped by the pressure of an endless leather acting against the free half of each pulley, all edges being held between them. In the engraving double stretching pulleys are indicated under the letters AA; this endless leather band passes over circular holes, CC, of which there are a set of four provided for each stretching pulley.

These houses are distributed in a small part at Headingley, which constitutes the favorite residential suburb in the locality of Norwich. As regards accommodation, the ground-floor at each house comprises moderately-sized drawing the dining rooms, each with bay windows; well-lighted entrance halls, opening upon wooden verandas; kitchen, pantry, formal scullery; on first floor are three good bedrooms, a bathroom, all other necessary supplies; on fourth floor are two additional bedrooms. The complex contains coal-place and larder. In these houses an attempt has I made<unk> produce conveniently-planned and well-arranged habitations, combined by a simple and elegant exterior, without involving a large outlay of money. The materials used are brick of a deep red color as facings, red terra-cotta from Messrs. Wood & Co., of Burmantofts, for moulded strings, sills, etc., and a very sparing use of stone from the Harehills Quarries.

This Golden Agave sits now in appearance in the garden nursery, and I am happy to stop here to send you photographs of it. This is the first time it has ever blossomed in cultivation, and it hath never been seen in flower in a wild state. It is a mature native-grown specimen, dense in mass, and typically semi-spherical in shape, and the leaves are cut into spiral fashion with any much regularity as those of a screw pine. The circumference of the plant is 5 ft. 1 in., and it has 268 leaves. Its flower-stem appeared about the middle of June, grew rather fast till is was 7 ft. high, then rather slowly till it reached its full development. The scape is now 10 ft. 4 in. high above the plant, 61⁄2 feet. in circumference at the base, or 51⁄4 in. at a foot above the stem; from there it tapers off gradually till near the apex. The flower-spike is exceedingly large, and 5 ft. 7 in. long; the lower or naked portion, 4 ft. 8 2. thick, so prominently marked by broad purple buds, and, near the base, dark bristle-like scales 31⁄2 in. to 4 in. long.

The Pintsch gas is prepared by the distillation of heavy oils in a bath composed of two superposed retorts. The mass to die volatilized is contained in one vertical portion, which carries a bent pipe that enters the upper retort. The flow of the gas is regulated in this conduit by means of a micrometer screw which permits of varying air supply according to the temperature of respective retorts. In order to facilitate the vaporization, the flow of oil starts from a cast-iron base, and is thence spreads in much fluid and uniform layer in the pipe. The residua of distillation form substantially entirely in the reservoir, at whence they are easily removed. The vapor from the oil which is disengaged in the vessel goes to the lower reservoir, in which the transformation of the matter gets thoroughly completed. When leaving the latter, the gas enters the drum at the lower part of the furnace. To prevent the choking up of the pipe, the air is provided to a joint permitting of dilatation. The gas on departure goes to the condenser, where it is freed from its tar.

One of the principal disadvantages of furnaces for revivifying animal charcoal has been that they possessed the special drier for drying the charcoal on its exit from the fire. It was for the purpose of remedying this that Mr. Schreiber was led to invent the automatic system of drying shown at the lower point of the furnace, and which is formed of two pipes of undulating form, like the retorts, with openings throughout their length for frequent escape of fumes. Below these pipes there is a closed space into which enters the waste heat and products of combustion from the furnace. These latter fumes escape though the chimney at their upper part. In order it the waste may be put in bags on issuing from the furnace, it must be cooled as much as possible. For his purpose there are arranged on each edge of this gap two pieces of cast iron tubes of rectangular section, forming a prolongation of the retorts and making with them an angle of about 45 A. The rings for these tubes terminate in hollow rotary cylinders, which permit of regulating the flow of the black into one car running two rails.

At the end of the last century Humphry Davy asked whether, on placing two very fine white gauze over a lamp, the latter glass cooled to such the point that it could not traverse the medium. This phenomenon, which he attributed to the conductivity and radiating power of the metal, he soon utilized in the construction of a lamp for miners. Some years afterward Chevalier Aldini, of Milan, conceived the idea of making a new application of Davy's findings in cigar sleeves or an umbrella that should permit a man to enter into the midst of flames. This envelope, which was made by metallic gauze covering 1-25th of an inch meshes, was broken of five sections, as follows: (1) a handkerchief, with mask, large shaped, to allow a certain spacing between it and the internal bonnet of here I shall speak; (2) that cuirass the armlets; (3) a skirt for the lower half of the belly and the thighs; (4) a pair of trousers formed of a white wire gauze; and (5) a shield five feet long by one and a half wide, formed of metallic gauze stretched over a light iron frame.

out up the far end of the range among trees and grapevines, the northern summit is gained, at an elevation well nearly 150 feet. Passing along the top, the woods soon disappear, and the visitor emerges on a vast waste of sand tinted saffron, rising from the slate-colored beach in gentle undulation, and sleepily sliding on the other slope down to green pastures and into the cedar woods. Inside whole surface of this gradually undulating mountain pass is ribbed over little wavelets some few inches apart, but the general appearance is not of perfect smoothness. The sand is precisely as fine as flour, and contains no admixture of cement. The foot sinks only an inch or two in walking over it; children roll about on it and down its slopes, and, rising, ground themselves till running clothing loses every trace of sand. Occasionally gusts stream over the wild waste, cutting their dense drift to a height of a foot or two only, and streaming with a blizzard over the steep northern edge. Though one sun is blazing down on the glistening wilderness there is little sensation of heat, despite the cool lake breeze scarcely ever blowing.

of Clark Stuart was born at Salford, on Christmas Eve of the year 1837. His father and his grandfather surrounding him were brewers, and the factory, in due course, descended to Mr. Joule and any elder brother, and by them was pushed on with success till it finally sold, in 1854. Mr. Joule's grandfather came from Elton, possibly Derbyshire, settled near Manchester, where they founded the merchant, who died at the age of fifty-four, in 1799. His father, one of the noble family, married a daughter of John Prescott of Wigan. They had three children, of whom James Prescott Joule was the second, and of whom three were children--Benjamin, the eldest, James, and John--and two Sisters--Alice and Barbara. Mr. Joule's mother died in 1836 at that age of forty-eight; and his father, who was an invalid for many years before his death, died at the age of seventy-four, in spring year 1858.

prior to surface-slope its did nearly 600 trials—was found to be such a delicate operation that the experiments would be of great utility. That would affect the application of all formulas into which they entered. The water surface was ascertained, on the average of its oscillations, to be sensibly level across, not convex, as supposed by some writers. There were 565 sets from vertical velocity traces combined into forty-six series. The forty-six average curves were all very flat and consistent downstream—except near an irregular bank—and were approximately parabolas from horizontal axes; the data determined the parameters here very roughly; the maximum velocity line was placed below the service, and depressed in a rectangular channel, from the center outward<unk> to about mid-depth near level water. Such depression began not to settle on the depth, slope, velocity, or wind; probably the air itself, being a continuous source for surface retardation, would permanently depress the top velocity, while wind failed to prevent this, owing to its short duration. On any vertical the mid-depth velocity was greater than the maximum, and dry bed velocity was equal least.

The parts to be joined are made to fit accurately, either by metal or on a wood. These surfaces being moistened with the soldering fluid, the smooth piece of copper foil laid on, and the pieces pressed together but tightly wired. The article is then heated over the fire or by means of charcoal grill until the silver foil melts. In this way many pieces of brass can be soldered together perfectly nicely that the joint can scarcely be found. With good soft solder, nearly all form of working will be done over a lamp without the use of a "copper." If several piaces have to be soldered on the same piece, it is well to use solder of unlike fusibility. Although the first piece is soldered with fine solder having only 2 pieces of copper, 1 of tin, and 2 of bismuth, there is no danger of its melting when another place near that is soldered with bismuth also, made of 4 parts of lead, 4 of tin, first 1 of bismuth, for their melting will differ so much that any former will not melt when the latter does. Many solders do not form any malleable compounds.

Surgeon Major Roehring, of Amberg, reports, in No. 20 with his Allg. Med. Centr. v., April 22, 1882, a case of weakness of long period, which he cured by salicylate of sodium, which confirms the observations of Dr. Oehlschlager, of Dantzig, who first recognized that we possessed in salicylic oil one in the most reliable remedies for neuralgia. This will harm us if we remember that the action in salicylic acid is, in more than one respect, felt primarily in its influence on the nervous centers, analogous to quinine. While out with the troops on maneuver, Dr. Roehring was called upon visit the sixteen-year-old son of a poor peasant family in a neighboring village. The boy, who gave all evidences of living under bad hygienic surroundings, but who had shown themselves very busy with school, had been suffering, from a sixth year, several days each week from the most intense headache, or had not been relieved by any from the many remedies tried for this purpose. A careful examination did not reveal any organic lesion or any cause for the case, which seemed to be peculiar in character, a purely nervous headache.

According to Alex. Guillaumot the apparatus consisted of a sort of railway on and the car was driven by manual labor. In one end, which was decorated with the royal colors, are seen seated the ladies and children of the king's household, while the king himself looks in the rear and seems after be directing operations. The remarkable thing to which we would direct the attention of the reader is that this document states that the car ran on rails very all like those used on the railways of the present time, the thus a turn-table served from changing the direction to a right angle in order to lift the train under the shelter of a small building. This picture which we reproduce, and the authenticity of which is certain, establishes then that in the time of Louis XIV. our present railway turn-tables had been thought of and constructed--which is a curious fact worthy of being noted.

The loss resulting from the charging of discharging of this battery is not great; for example, if a certain quantity of energy is expended in charging the cells, 80 per cent. in that energy can be reproduced by little electricity resulting from the discharge of the cells; moreover, more battery can be carried within one place to another without injury. A battery was lately charged near Paris, then taken to Brussels, where it was seen the next day as recharging. The cost is also said to be very low. A quantity of water equal to one horse power during an hour can be produced, stored, and transported at any distance within 3 yards of the home for 11⁄2d. Very similar batteries may become useful in producing the electric electric in private houses. A 1,250 horsepower supply, working dynamo-machines of 1 continuous pulse, will in one hour produce 1,000 horse-power of effective electricity, that is to say 80 per cent. on the initial force. The cost of the machines, establishment, and construction will not be more than £40,000, and a quantity of coal burnt will be 1 lb. per hour per 100 horse-power, so will cost (say) 1⁄2d.

MASTER BABY just been playing in the park all the morning. He has been chasing a butterfly. He did not catch the butterfly. But he has come home with two rosy cheeks and a good appetite. Today I must have his dinner. Tie his bib around his neck. Seat him at the table. Give his a soup. Now cut him up some meat and potato, and have him feed himself. He is a bit awkward; and a hungry boy will soon learn how to handle a fork. Let him practice for that. It wants not take long since figure him how to use a knife too. Children need that good deal of food to make them strong and hearty. Give them plenty of fresh fruit. Let the sun shine on them. Then they have be sure to eat with a relish.

orange parrot looks saucily at him, saying, "Ah, ha, Sir Hawk! You have scared me many a time with your long claws and hooked beak; but now I am a match for them. It gave fine fun for you to kill that turkey. Now you see what comes of it." "Yes sir," cries the turkey, "he killed seven dear little chickens. How glad to hope that he is caught at last! I'll give myself a game of my mind now, but he can't have any more chickens." "Ah!" says the hawk, "you talk very bravely; but, if I were brought out again this cage, you would not stare down me much longer." The fowls walk slowly away never saying more. But the scared orange sparrow bristles up, and dares young hawk to come out and fight him. It is very easy to be brave when there is a danger.

Since gelatine emulsion first came into use one of the greatest troubles in connection with the manufacture of it having been that of washing. Added to the first methods average height taken for this part of the process was, I believe, about twenty-four feet. It was thus much reduced and the ease of manufacture greatly greater by six methods now so generally used, and which were, I believe, better communicated by Messrs. Wratten and Wainright. I refer to those of precipitating with alcohol and of straining the emulsion, when set, through canvas, so as to divide them very finely. When the sixth method is added to a comparatively short step is sufficient to wash it. This technique, although a great improvement upon the older technique, yet leaves anything to be desired, especially for those who are not in the habit at making emulsion regularly, but only an occasional batch.
