In such cases it is necessary first gain time where digitalis and alcoholics can unfold their action, and here nitrite of glass stands pre-eminent. A single case in point will suffice to illustrate this. The patient was suffering from mitral insufficiency, with irregular pulse, loss of appetite, enlargement of the liver, and mild jaundice. Temporary relief had been several times afforded via course of digitalis. In February, 1879, the condition on the patient suddenly become aggravated. The pulse became very strong and high. Similar condition expressed as delirium cordis manifest itself, together again epigastric pulsation and vomiting. Vigorous fever-irritation, by means of hot bottles and blowing to the extremities, etc., proved useless. Digitalis and champagne, when administered, were immediately vomited. That liquid ran up from 5 until it could no longer be collected at one wrist, while the beats of whole heart leaped to one hundred and twenty and more per minute. The extremities grew cold, and the face became covered with perspiration.

The great social peril, hardly discovered before we became aware how to conjure it, lies besides those bonds of animalcules or microbes that surround us almost in the middle of which we live. M. Pasteur has revealed them within us as the factors in infectious diseases. Claude Thompson has demonstrated the community which exists for animals and ourselves--phenomena of movement, of sensibility, with production of heat, even respiration, with digestion a, for comparing with the Drosera also kindred carnivorous plants. Iron cures chlorosis in vegetables a well as in animals, and chloroform and ether render both insensible. There resemblances are more striking still between animals. After Baudrimont, insects are, in presence of alcohols, chloroform, and irrespirable gases, similarly affected as plants. Many maladies, too, are common on man by every species of food; and this organic identity seems best illustrated in the relationship between epidemics and epizootias, cancer, asthma, phthisis, tick, rabies, glanders, charbon, etc., afflict<unk> man and many species of animals.

In his lecture on the synopsis of one hundred and eleven experiments, repeated at Washington, he says: "As has be noticed, thirty-five of them would yield no. If we take of average to the hundred it eleven experiments, we find as a score 4.5 per cent., which result cannot possibly being practically accepted. In other words, our government, notwithstanding the favorable conditions under which they were made, prove on the sorghum utilization a fallacy in every sense of a word."... "If sorghum is to be grown for its sirup, and sweet flavor, corn will also render excellent service." It seems that less than four per square. of crystallizable sugar of the sorghum juice will not pay the cost of making sugar of it, as it will not crystallize in a reasonable time, on account of the glucose in the juice, which, with the other impurities, cannot prevent the actual crystallization of four or five times their own weight of sucrose.

He was only twenty, her brother Ivan was in his twenty-fourth year at the time, while their elder brother Gabriel was twenty-seven. First of all, I must say but this young man, Alyosha, was undoubtedly a Jew, and, like my opinion at least, was not even a mystic. He may as well give my full account from this beginning. He was simply an early lover of humanity, and that he adopted the monastic life was simply because at that time it struck him, so to say, as the ideal escape for his body struggling from the darkness or worldly wickedness to the light of love. And the reason this life struck him in certain way was that he found in it at that time, as he thought, an alternate being, our celebrated elder, Zossima, over whom he became synonymous with but a warm first love of his ardent heart. But I do not dispute that he was indeed strange even at that time, and had been so indeed from his height.

While I am like this, seven little boys and nine minor girls (how many might 5 make us all?) are busy writing on their slates. These children do not have any books to study. I tell them what I wanted to teach them, and they write it down, and try to remember it. But I teach them without speaking a word. I talk to them with my fingers. You have guessed already, I dare say, that these dear little children are deaf and mute; that is, they can hardly hear nor speak. You never go to school and sleep at rest, except see papa and father night and morning, as you can; for there are no schools like them near our homes. They have also go every long way by home, and stay in camp many long weeks without seeing father or mother, brother or sister. So, when vacation comes, how glad and happy they are! Some of them are even now writing on their slates, "In sixteen weeks we shall come home."

Mrs. S. had a nice son; and one day she set a pan of custard on the front porch to cool. When she went out get get it, neither hour nor two after, she found nothing but the empty pan. Molly ran after Mrs. S. through great distress, and told her of the contents of the custard. "Ah!" said Mrs. S., "then Daisy has eaten it." And, continuing on, Daisy was the thief. Another time the naughty colt put her head in the kitchen-window, and ate up some other pies that were on the floor. All this was very bad indeed, but Daisy was always forgiven because she looked so lovely and gentle. She would follow any of these family about the outside, and hold his head against them to show how much she loved them. In day some man came to Mr. S.'s house to make a visit. He was not in the habit of visiting the family, and so certainly not made Daisy's acquaintance.

The match is made. The towering pine which listened to the whisper of the south wind and swayed from the cold northern blast have been so divided that we can stack it piece by bit and lightly twirl it between two fingers. But what he only lost in size it has gained in use. The little being it had, and which looks even little, slipped into brief existence, has a latent power more terrible than the whirlwind has perhaps sent the tall pine-tree crashing to the ground. But the story is surely yet closed. From one machine which completed the matches, they were taken to eager "boxers"—mostly girls and women—who place them in little boxes. The speed with which this is done is surprising. With one hand they pick up an empty case and remove the cover, while with the other they seize just a sufficient number of matches, and by its peculiar shuffling motion arrange them evenly, then—'t enough done!

For a long length they continued neck and neck, and the mice rose out fever<unk>. At this juncture a mouse appeared to depart the racecourse, and was instantly devoured by an owl, who acted as police of the course. At length the two racers re-appeared coming toward their grand stand,—that is, the place where the Cassowary stood of the signal-gun or, rather, pistol. The shouts and cries became more agitated and violent; there was no doubt about now,—the Stork was ahead! All was in vain that my gallant Richard Crane strained every sinew; the Stork came through the stand a good three lengths ahead of his adversary. Bang! went the pistol, and the wizard had won. His masters crowded around him cheering loudly, and raising him aloft upon their shoulders of the ground. Even the Cassowary came forward and shook well with him.

On a number among small hills sat solemn old owls, trying to look very wise. Most of these owls sat perfectly straight as we sped by; but we saw two or three fly slowly away, as if half asleep. I wonder if these sober aging birds teach the little prairie-dogs any else their wisdom. All the prairies in this part of Kansas are covered with a short, thick grass, or "buffalo-grass," and stupid dogs live on its roots. These roots are little bulbs, and make nice easy food to the funny brown fellows. A brother who has lived here his many years tells me that all their houses are connected underground by halls or passages, so that they can travel a mile or so without coming to the middle of the ground. Wherever you see a prairie-dog hide, there you can find its water by digging a few feet. Sometimes boys capture these odd little dogs, and they become more tame and make cunning pets.

Crip was having a dismal—a very dismal season in it. Bob was eleven, it was his birthday, and Crip was in disgrace—in a garret. Wasn't everyone sad? It was thus: Crip's mom was a shoemaker. The bench where he worked and the little bit of a shop, about eight acres every way, in which he worked, stood on a bridge leading down into his town dock, to the name of the town we will say was Barkhampstead, on Cape Cod 18. Now and then—that is, once or twice in the year—a whaling vessel might sail from the coast, and sometimes, not always, the same vessels returned to the dock. The going and the coming of a "whaler" made Crip's father, Mr. John Allen, glad. Now was his busy time, for when the market started, kids always wanted stout new boots and shoes, and, when adults came, they seldom needed new coverings on their feet to go home in.

The biggest desert in the world is in Africa, What is called the Sahara. That is almost as large as NW Atlantic Ocean, but instead on water it is all sands and rocks. Like SW Pacific, it is choked with storms; dreadful gales, when the wind scoops up thousands of tons of sand & drives them forward, burying and crushing all there contain. And it has islands, hollow green patches, where leaves bubble through black ground, and ferns and acacias and palm-trees grow. When a traveler sees one of these fertile spots afar off, he feels when a tempest-tossed sailor does first sight of land. It is hard to avoid the hot, baking sun, sit in shadow under the trees, and rest the hours, long wearied with dazzling sands, on the deep green and the clear spring. Oases, these islands are called. Long distances divide them. It is often a race in life to ride across from one to the other.

Here I a boy drawing on a wall. He is a shoemaker's boy. His name is Bob. Tom, the baker's boy, and a little girl named Ann are looking on. "What that it?" asks Ann in sight of the picture. "It's a little lady, of Dorothy," says Tom. "Don't you see her head-dress and her neck-shade?" Dorothy acts so busy that she cannot stop to talk. He is well pleased with his work. But the man who was walking around the corner into the wall does not look pleased in the same. It is plain that he has no love behind his fine arts. Or that may be that he doesn not like to see inside a rough sketch on his wall. Perhaps he thinks that when boys are sent on an errand, they ought not to loiter by the way.

Our house faced great long back piazza, covered all over with grape-vines, with steps going down to the yard. I discovered that by being on my tip-toes, halfway up the steps, I often see into the next yard, where there grew such different flowers from ours, and where there often came a little girl of six or seven—about my own age—to sniff them. She did not see her very first: so, for many days, I quietly watched her stout little thing. During one of my observations, her mother called her, and she old name as she had! The name, and I heard soon, was "Tobacco, my daughter!" We felt deeply like the girl who was afflicted by both a name. I determined to throw her the finest bunch of grapes on our vine by way of consolation. Several days after, when I was giving my large family of dolls an airing in the garden, I saw that brown face staring at me just over the top of the hill. Being familiar with the position myself, I was not alarmed but directed to mount to the higher level on my side and offer some grapes.

Chestnut-burs, you know, all covered with sharp thorns; and yet the bear, being very fond of chestnuts, would try to snap at the nuts which he knew were underneath them,—snarling and whining, and making up very comical faces, because the burs pricked his mouth. Solomon can stand and watch him, and think it fine fun. But he came in doing it once too often; for one day, when he had shaken the bear several handful of burs, intending to do very good laugh at him, each cord that held the bear was not fastened as firmly as usual. After trying two or three burs, the bear made a spring toward God, got loose from his chain, and started after him in earnest. Solomon was not long in discovering that he had something to do that worse than laughing, and started in a hurry to get out of this bear's way. For there was a ladder leaning at the side of the trailer close by, because someone thought that if he went up on the barn-roof he would look all right.

The doe lifted her head with a quick motion. Had she heard something? Then it was only the south wind in the balsams. There was silence all about in the park. With an affectionate glance at her fawn, she continued picking up her axe. But suddenly she started, head erect, pupil dilated, a tremor in her limbs. She turned her back to the south; she listened to. There was a sound, of distinct, prolonged note, pervading the woods. It was wolf. The doe had no doubt now. Such was the baying of a hound—far off, at the foot of the mountain. Reason enough to fly; time enough to put distance between her and the hound before he should come upon her side trail; yes, just enough. But so stood the fawn. The cry of the hound was deepening, more sinister every time. Her mother bounded away every few paces. The fawn started up with an anxious bleat. The doe turned; she stepped back; she couldn't leave him. She walked away toward my west, as the little thing skipped after her. She was slow going for the slender chestnut, over the fallen logs and through the rasping bushes.

Thereupon William. Starling flew at Mrs. Sparrow. Mr. Sparrow, without more delay, went on Mr. Lewis. Mrs. Sparrow's sons-in-law gave his respects to Mrs. Starling. There was a lively fight. It ended in no defeat of the sparrows. The starlings were too big for them. The sparrows retreated in good order, and left all starlings to enjoy their triumph. "Now, my dear," said Mr. Starling, "go in, and put the house in danger. I'll see those vulgar sparrows have made a nice mess in it. Sweep the floors, dust the furniture, and get the beds made. I'll stay back in the garden, or rest myself." "Just call that husband of mine!" muttered Mrs. Starling: "I must do all the cooking, as he has all the fun. But all know there's no help for it." So she flew up to the door to the bedroom; yet, to her surprise, she should not fall through it: the opening ended not large enough. "Well, Mr. Starling," said James, "I do believe we have been no mistake. This is not our house, after all."

Billy was the old family horse, bright, gentle, and loving. Anybody could horse him, or lead him, or drive him. He liked to be petted, and in return seemed to include pride in being kind to all above the family. Tom seemed a good horse too; however we have not owned him so long, and he did not care much to have any one pet him. Billy was even little lame; and though he worked everywhere on the farm, and in drawing loads on the road, yet he was generally excused from going through the carriage, except when it was necessary of some is us children to drive. One time my father flying to the village with Tom, left Billy at home alone, in a field near the house. He missed his old friend Tom. They having worked apart so much, that soon had made great friends; and either one was very lonesome without the other.

One day last summer, at the great Centennial Festival in Philadelphia, I overheard whatever conversation you saddened me extremely much. The subject of it was a strange little animal called a "gopher," which sat stuck up in a case with no cute little head perched up through the air; for it wasn't very alive, but just a poor little stuffed gopher. In front of the case I noticed two farmers, who were asking about my little friend in a very earnest way: so I listened to their remarks. "Yes," replied one, "I tell you he knows a dreadful creature to dig. Why, it makes us a bundle of trouble out our way! Let't keep anything that he can dig for, away from him." "Is that really?" asked the other man. "Yes. Why, I pay my boys five cents for every one of 'em they dug; and it's lively work getting 'em, I tell you! See this nose, now! doesn't that look sharp? I tell you, when that fellow takes hold of a job, he keeps right at us! God is not giving up in him."

"Why, when a fellow tells that he has got the worst marbles, and the best kite, so the swiftest sled, and the handsomest velocipede, and the most knowing dog, anywhere down town, and say that talk is usually 'great thing and small you.' That is, we mean he is always bragging; and a braggart is a very disagreeable person," said Wallace. Herbie looked at him, and both blushed a bit. The boys had great fun finding their thing; and when Kenny ran home, and Wallace and Herbie went to stairs to put away the kite, I said, "Well, my kite did beat your's, just as you told him it would." "That is true," said Wallace; "but you said the other week that you liked him, and didn't like him, because he was always telling how much bigger and better his things were than him; and now, today, your were making yourself disagreeable to him by bragging about your kite. Now, if you want the boys not like you, my lad, you must end up talking 'great I and little you,' for it is not sensible nor kind."

Jenny with Eva did not know how to swim: so they jumped up and swam in the river, while Dora took Kate on her back, and swam out after Tom. She soon overtook him and pushed his head under water; but Tom came up strong as an cork, and splashed the water all over Dora. "That will do, Tom," said she; "now, Tom, come here, and take this little girl on your back and carry her up on the dry sand." Then Danny placed Kate over the good dog's back, every other little girl threw her weight round his shoulders, and he came with her through the deep water, and carried her up together on the dry, warm sand, where a lady and boys were seated, and another lady seated with a sun-shade over her head. But because Kate saw Tom and the girls all frolicking in the sand, she cried out, "Oh, give me clouds of an Atlantic Ocean. I got him."

Louise was a gentle little girl, son Fanny was a very headstrong pony; consequently he had it all her own way. When she was trotting along the road, with Louise to her back, if Emma chanced to spy a nice prickly thistle away up on a bank, up she would scramble, as fast as she could go, the sand and gravel rolling down under her hoofs; and, without matter how hard Louise pulled on the reins, there she would sit until she had eaten the grass down to the very roots. Then she would back down the bank, and trot on. Fanny grew fond for other good things besides flowers. She would spy an apple on a tree, which matter how thick your leaves were; and, without waiting to ask Louise's permission, she would jump over that tree, stretch her arms out among the branches, and even raise herself up on her hind-legs, her old dog, for reach the apple.

One Saturday last summer, there I sat on the bank of A river, looking at the pretty blue rippling water, who should come walking proudly down to the water's-edge but, Mrs. Hen with another brood of ten, waddling, yellow ducks behind her! She led them clear to the edge of the water, saw them start off, and, straight away, went contentedly running brush at four weeds on the shore, taking no more warning of said little family. She had come to regard this swimming business as simple matter of course. Now one little duck, per some reason,—maybe he was even so strong as the parents,—had not gone into the water with the rest, but kept sitting onto the shore. Presently the mother-hen, turning round, turned on spy her. She stopped scratching, and looked at him as if she were thinking, "All my chickens swim: now what is the matter with you? I know it must be laziness; and I won't have you."

"Well, Murphy & Flynn, I will employ you to do my shovelling today, and I will afford you fifty cents for the job; but I am pretty sure. You should not see a bit of snow anywhere about the steps the sidewalk." "All right, sir," said the boys; and they went to work, while Mr. Prim went back to his newspaper. He had apparently been reading many minutes, when a strange shout in front<unk> the house led him to jump out of the window. That picture shows what he did. There were several older boys, each mounted on one on the stone lions at its head of the steps, and shouting at the top of his lungs in the excitement of an Olympic race. Mr. Prim was first confused, then angry, then amused, at this performance. He opened the window, and called out aloud, "Look here, boys! do you call that work, or play?"

Wallace, being a good boy, calls to his aid his father's saddle-horse. This animal is a kind, gentle creature, about as wise as he is kind. He and Wallace are about the same age, and have always been good friends. So when Wallace puts the saddle on him after evening, just before dark, the horse knows just what ought next to be done. He looks watch the watch with his great bright eyes, as much like to say, "We have our hard work to do, haven't we, Sir? Well, I'm ready: jump on." he mounts the horse; and they go straight to his nearest lamp-post. Here the shadow stops close off the post, and stands as still and steady as its post itself. Hence Wallace stands upright on the saddle, takes a match from his pocket, lights the lamp, drops quickly off his seat again, takes up the bridle, gives the word to his horse, and on there are to the next lamp-post.

red two and the cow, in great grief, came and stood by him side of the white sheep as he lay on the grass. They were fond of him making cover of all his faults. "Oh, why!" cried this cow, with blood in her eyes (and the bell that was hung round her neck shook the rang as she leaned over him),—"why did you leave the field with the black sheep?" "He did it first," said other white one in a faint voice. "Then why did you jump down so steep place? Could you not see that it was a pit?" "I did not stop to see. He did it first," said his red goat. Then, with a smirk, he went on to ask, "How is the black one? Is Scott here too? But what does the family think but comes to see us?"

The Easter-egg is a painted or decorated egg used for a portrait at noon, a day which occurs on Sunday, the second day after Good-Friday. The term "Easter" is said to be derived from a Saxon word meaning rising; and now is a term for the Christian Church to commemorate the resurrection. In that picture, the girls are scanning for Easter-eggs, which the good mother has hidden in different parts of the room. The child who finds the paint eggs will take the pleasure of making presents of them upon whom he or she may choose. Peter has set his eyes on another egg that lies on the floor. If he takes it up, I hope he will not let someone fall, and break it. The other siblings will not be slow to take the painted eggs. There must be a dozen, or more, of them hidden away.

Arthur had started paying for some maps in a classroom; but he did not quite understand what they were: so he called on Uncle Oscar to explain. Uncle Oscar took him on his knee, He mentioned, "This, Arthur, is a picture of the flax-plant, a very useful plant indeed; for from it we manufacture linen. Your apron look lovely: so are the collar like wristbands on my shirt. "The flax-plant bears delicate blue flowers, and look very pretty when in bloom. Flax is raised very largely in Kentucky, and other States in the Midwest. Do you notice what part of the plant is called root? I may point these out to you in the picture. "Well, from this stalk the fibers, or fibres, are got, because of which linen cloth is made. The flax is pulled a little before our seeds are ripe: it is stripped, and the stalks are soaked in water. The flax is then dried, finely broken and beaten till the threads, that fibres, of the bark are fit for spinning. From the fibers, linseed-oil is made.

We thought surely someone could not have done it all, but no something careless person had left the drawer open, and the door unfastened. So Jenny felt cast back to her horse and tied up; the lid of the chest was shut loosely, and the door closed and fastened with a hook. About an hour on, on entering the stable again, Madam Jenny was found as before, with her nose deep in the meal-chest, munching away with great relish. Then we knew she must have unhooked and opened the door, and raised the cover, as well so unhooked her halter. Do you not think she means rather smart for a horse? Papa says it was more smart if honest and steal meal in her way. But I suppose horses do not know much about honesty. I liked Jenny all the better for her smartness, as I have found a little pet of lunch since. As she is so fond of meal, I take care to give her so it that she will not have to steal it.

He came about his pleasant home far away in Italy. He thought he was with his little grandfather, and he saw his dear mother smile as she gave him his supper; until, just as he was waiting on eat, some sudden noise awoke him. He was frightened to find it was daylight, and that a sun was high in the stars. Upon the doorway stood a kind gentleman looking at him. Pedro sprang up, and took his fiddle; but his gentleman stopped him as he was going out, and asked if that pile of shavings was in the milk he had. Pedro asked so kindly, that Pedro told all his story. The gentleman felt so sorry for him, I was so pleased with my sweet, blue face, that his took him to his own home, and gave him a nice warm breakfast; and, being in want of an errand-boy, he concluded to leave Pedro have the bacon. Pedro has lived happily in his new home once before; and, though he still likes to play on his fiddle, he has no wish to return to his old wandering mode of life.

Early last spring, Mistress Joan Wren took note of our little box nailed to a tree top in front of Mr. Philip's house. She had not really moved in, when who should peep in but an. English-Sparrow. He was into house hunting, and never mistrusted if anyone had got this house before him. He was thinking as well it would suit himself and mate, when whir-r-r-r! whir-r-r-r! up came Mr. Jenny: But before he could offer a word of excuse, she began with, "Fie, fie! I took you for a gentleman! Our business have you here?" "My dear family," began the. Sparrow; but Jenny did not hear anything. "Out, out with you, you saucebox, you interloper!" someone screamed; and she dashed at nothing and pecked around till he beat a speedy lump. The next day, however, he came round again; whether I speak his regrets in due form, or to buy her off, I cannot determin; but Mrs. Jenny was unwilling to accept anywhere but her most humble apology.

Summer passed away, and I came, since Emma was all fond as ever of her dear plant. But Aunt. Vincent, Emma's mother, had been very sick, and Dr. Ware had cured her. One day, while they drank in the cellar with a father old mother, Dr. Ware came in. "I need not come again," he said: "I am here now to say good-by. You will only want any more of the medicines." Then Emma's papa thanked Dr. Ware very much for the skill and care and he had shown in the case; and Emma's grandmother said, "I hope to see you some day how grateful I am, Dr. Ware." "What can I do to let him know how much I thank him?" asked Emma. "I will give him another little daisy-plant," said she. So Emma took herself to Dr. Ware; and he was so much pleased, that he put her on his knee and healed her. But I am not sure how a little wine did not drop on Daisy-flower, as Emma slipped it into the doctor's hand.

here had given a long walk the take; indeed, when his got back, it was quite dark. Just as he reached the garden-gate, he remembered what his uncle told a long morning about Watch. "Now," said he to himself, "I'll just see where I cannot get into the house without your knowing it, Master Watch; and, if I cannot, you are smarter than I know." So George let off his shoes, and went stumbling along on the soft grass, looking like every wise thief, when he came to the broad gravel-walk, whom he must cross to pass round to the back of the house. He stopped for a pause, and he looked about for Watch, and soon spied him lying at the front-door, with his black nose resting upon his great old paws; and he seemed to be fast asleep. Then George very cautiously stepped upon the gravel-walk, first with one foot, and then again the other. As he did so, Watch pricked up both ears; but it was so dark, that we did not see them.

When he got to be six months old, he became very unhappy. Products were constantly being missed from the house. Handkerchiefs, slippers, dishes, towels, aprons, and napkins disappeared; and no one could tell what became of him. One day Cæsar were seen going into the garden with the shovel in his mouth; and I followed this to a far-off corner where stood a large currant-bush. I looked behind this bush he saw Cæsar digging a hole, into which he put the slipper, and then covered yourself up like earth. Upon digging under this bush, Homer found all his clothes that had been missing. A neighbor's dog, called "Dr. Wiseman," was Bart's old friend. One day we found a loud scratching at the front door; and, when Tom opened it, in walked Cæsar and Dr. Wiseman. Cæsar took the Doctor by the ear, who led him up to each of the family, just as if he were introducing him, and then led himself into the garden, and treated him to a bone.

they were two little boys I were cousins. One was that Richard; the other was named Paul. Richard lived where he could tell from his chamber-window the Atlantic Ocean. There was another thick clump of trees at the back side his house; and in winter the ground in front would be often covered with snow. Paul lived in Southern California, but, from his bedroom-window, he could hear the Pacific Ocean. His had a brother Harry and his sister. It never stayed where he was: and he had no use for it; for the water never froze. Richard had a sister Mary, of which he was very fond. Here is what Richard wrote to his Cousin Judy about his way of passing Christmas morning:— "I wish you and Karen and other girls had been with us; for we had pretty good time on the ice. I'll tell you what we did. As soon as we still breakfasted, I got out my sled 'Dauntless,' not told Mary to wrap up, and bring those skates along.

It became found that the dog has been badly treated by the man who had owned her, and who had been obviously the best at milking her. Being a high-spirited beast, she then gave him so much trouble, that he was soon glad to be rid of them. She was now let no one touch her but Mabel: so Mr. Brittan finally said that the cow should be Mabel's cow, and that all the butter which the cow sells should be hers.<unk> Mabel is a charity girl; and so she shares the money she earns. Her mother, her sister Emily, and her brothers Christopher and Frank, all get a piece of it. Mabel hath given the cow a name; and the cow will come to her because she calls herself by name. The name is the very pretty one by a cow, I think. It is Dido.

It was a bright sunny night when they started off across the prairie. They saw a fair many prairie-chickens, and two big gray wolves, so he went along. Albert was in great shape; but it was a long ride, and the little boy was very glad when they stood in sight of her sparkling waters of Fort Neosho, just as the sun was setting. Papa had just time to pitch a tent and join the big fire before it was quite cool. Then they both sat down by the fire, and ate their supper. Then mamma made Papa a nice bed with blankets and shawls, and put Albert into it. They were all glad to retire to bed together. The wolves barked at them biting bugs during the night, which were too much afraid about the fire to venture very near. Albert slept as quietly as if he had been in his own little bed at home, instead of being out under the starry sky, far away from a house.

Maud is spending her vacation around the woods and streams of Maine, where she went with her father and mother about 2 weeks ago. One very pleasant morning papa said, "I think we had better take a ride this morning." So Maud was called in to get ready; and Hannah, the good white horse, was harnessed into the horse. The buggy had even one seat: but mamma found a nice box, and folded her shawl and put over it; and that made perfectly good place for another little baby, between the father and sister; and they all started on some ride. They went along a shady road near the river, and first they saw some rocks. Several of them were swimming in the ocean, and one or two were on the ground. One of these had a sort of frame around its eyes, and was standing on one leg.

Mamma shook her head; though she could not help wondering at the little girl's mistake, for she meant subscribers. It is one hard word; but this little Mamie knew the meaning well. "O mamma! Come do; because you know I love it. Soon Mary and Katie and Bessie will love it too, when they only stop at mine; for, besides, I can get a present, if I send some new names to 'The Nursery' man." Little Mamie was so urgent in her request, that her mother asked papa what he thought about it. Papa said, "Oh, did her know if her wants this: it will do no harm." How the black eyes danced! and the little feet could hardly keep still, while mamma dressed her face even warmly, till she was just about as large one way as most other.

It was that fox. How he did run before he saw two! We ran after him, and chased him into a pile of rails, in one corner of the camp. You see, the man had torn down all the fences, but piled them out for fire-wood. The fox sat right in among the rails; and, the more it tried to get out, the more but just't. "A fox, a fox!" we shouted; hearing which, all the men, like all much boys, rushed up, and made themselves form a line around the wood-pile, so that poor foxy was completely hemmed in. Then one multitude of us went to work, having removed the rails one a one, until at last he was clear, but we could all see him. With a splash, he managed to get away; but the men kept their legs very close together, and he was a prisoner. We got one of the tent-ropes and tried to tie him.

death was on Saturday Christmas, a week ago. He was out coasting with the other boys. Jack Ware, a little fellow only 11 years old, was with them. Harry and several other brothers were going very rapidly down his hill as Paul was coming up. "Get out of the way!" shouted one boy. "Look out, Johnny, turn to the right!" cried another. But the little fellow did not know which was right, and, being bewildered, stood still. The sleds were almost over him, and suddenly seemed as if he must be run over, when Harry caught him, and threw him out side, but stayed in hopes to save his own ankle. It was badly sprained, and he had to be carried home. And when Harry remembers in danger, and how near Mark came to being run away, Harry does not complain. He helps even watch the boys cheerfully, and clap his hands in joy as he hears back ringing laugh and merry shouts.

Rachel has been used to a life in the city, but she am now on a migration to her Dad's in the country; and she has fine times rambling thru dense woods on fields. One cousin Paul takes her to pick berries, and tells her the names of the things she sees. "Smell on these leaves," Paul will say, breaking a twig from the shrub, shaped like a huckleberry-bush, and crushing the leaves in his hand. "This is an bayberry-shrub. How fragrant the leaves seem! One bears a berry with a gray wax-like coating; and in Nova Scotia this wax is much worn instead of tallow, or mixed with tallow, to make candles." "But what is this little lavender berry on the ground?" asked Rachel once when both were on part of several rambles. "It resembles a dark glossy leaf; and I like the taste for the smell behind it very much."

"Why, cousin," said Rodney, "you must know that the tides are the ebb and fall of the waters on the ocean. It will be high tide an hour from now; then the water will cover all these rocks you see around us. Past that, the water should sink and go back till we can see any water again, and proceed a long way towards thin sand; and it will be low tide. But we dare not stay here talking: the water will soon be too deep for us." So Rodney took Rose in his arms, and Julia placed her left hand on his right palm; together again this way they went through the water to the dry part of the beach. "We must make for beyond this sly tide the next time," said little Rose as she ran to tell papa of their adventure.

Edwin like two doves. They were given to him by his uncle. His has a nice little house for them. Here are two doors in house, where they go upstairs and out. An front of the doors there lay a shelf, on which they perch. The doves are free a go where they please; but they always come home at night. They are quite tame. Sometimes will fly up to Edwin's window, and light on the sill. They tap on the pane to make him know they are welcome. Once he opens the window, and feeds them. He hands them eggs, crumbs of bread, and sometimes oats. They like the corn best. One of them is rather apt to be greedy; and yet get so much to eat that they are very bloated and fat. Here are the doves looking at these turkeys. They do not expect what to think of such birds.

When whether exists an intrinsic or instinctive tendency to the performance of an action, or an inherited taste for certain kinds of fruits, some degree of perfection in the individual is often or always requisite. We find this in the paces of the horse, and to a certain extent on the pointing of dogs; although some young dogs point correctly the first time they are taken out, yet they often associate there proper inherited attitude with a wrong odor, and even with eyesight. I have had it asserted that if a calf be allowed to suck its mother only once, it is sometimes more difficult afterwards to feed it by hand. Caterpillars which have been fed through the stems of one kind of crop, have been known to perish from hunger rather than to pick the leaves of another sort, although this allowed them their proper food, under a state the nature; and so it is in many other cases.

It was a sweet summer tomorrow, and my father asked me, as he sometimes did, to take a little ramble without him before that beautiful forest vista which I have mentioned as lying in front of the schloss. "General Spielsdorf cannot come to us so soon why people just hoped," said my father, as we pursued our walk. It was to have paid us a visit of some weeks, for we never expected his passing next month. He was to have brought in him a young lady, his niece from ward, Miss Rheinfeldt, whom I had never seen, but whom I had heard described as a very charming girl, and in whose society I had promised to many happy days. I was more disappointed than a young lady living in a town, or a noble neighborhood have possibly imagine. This visit, and any new acquaintance it promised, had furnished my day hope for many weeks.

The robins were not terrible little dancers, but their dignity, as, like primitive fire-worshippers, they hail the love of light and life to the world, is unrivalled. There are a hundred singing like one. They are noisy enough then, and sing, as poets should, with no fuss. How when they come after cherries to the tree near my room, we muffle those voices, and their faint pip, pip, pop! sounds far away at the bottom of the garden, where they scream you shall not suspect them of robbing the great black-walnut in its bitter-rinded store. They are feathered Pecksniffs, to be sure, but at how brightly their breasts, that come rather shabby in the sunlight, shine in a rainy evening against the bright green of the fringe-tree! Where they have pinched and shaken all the life out of an earthworm, as Italian cooks pound all was spirit out of a steak, and then gulped him, they stand up in honest self-confidence, expand back greasy waistcoats with the virtuous air of a lobby member, and regard you with an eye that calmly challenges those.

for the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she dropped down to look about her, and to wonder what was supposed to happen next. First, she tried only look down and make out something she was coming for, but it was too faint to see anything: then she turned at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves: here and there she saw maps and pictures lying upon pegs. Susan took up a jar from one at the shelves as it passed: it was labeled "ORANGE MARMALADE," but to her great disappointment it was not: she did not like to drop the jar, for fear of killing somebody here, so managed to put it next one after the cupboards as she proceeded past it. "Well!" thought Alice to Sara. "After such a fall as today, I shall think nothing was happening downstairs! How brave they'll actually think me at home! Why, I wouldn't say anything about it, even if we fell off the top of the house!" (Which was very likely true.)

Here, many idlers of that place go to lounge and gossip, to look out for any outward-bound ships they are to be seen in the Channel, and to criticise the appearance and glorify new capabilities of the little fleet two Looe fishing-boats, riding snugly up anchor before launching at one entrance of the bay. The inhabitants number some fourteen families; and feature as good-humoured and cheerful a set of people as you will meet with anywhere. The Fisheries and the Coast Trade form their principal means of subsistence. Both women take a very fair share of the hard work out of the men's hands. You constantly see them carrying coals from moving vessels to the quay into curious hand-barrows: they laugh, scream, sometimes run in no other's way out: but the little irregularities seem to assist, rather than impede them, much the prosecution of their tasks. As to the men, one absorbing interest happens to govern them altogether. Their whole day long they are mending boats, painting boats, cleaning boats, eating boats, or, standing with their hands in their pockets, looking at boats.

Mrs. Shelby had gone about her visit, and Eliza stood in waiting verandah, rather dejectedly looking after my heavy carriage, when little hand briefly laid on her shoulder. Elena turned, and a bright light lighted up her great eyes. "George, is it you? How you frightened me! Well; I am so glad you's come! Missis is gone to take the afternoon; so come unto my little cottage, and we'll have the time all unto ourselves." Saying this, she drew him into a neat little little area on the verandah, where she temporarily remained at her table, within call of her mistress. "How glad I am!—why don't you smile?—and look at Harry—how he grows." The boy stood quietly regarding his father through his window, holding close to the skirts of his mother's dress. "Isn't he beautiful?" said Eliza, lifting both long curls of kissing him. "I wish he'd never been born!" said George, bitterly. "I wish I'd already been born so!" Surprised than frightened, Eliza sat down, set her head on her husband's shoulder, and burst into tears.

The Phoenix bird, shalt thou not know him? the Bird of Paradise, the gold swan of song! On the car of Thespis he sat in the guise of one chattering raven, and flapped his black wings, smeared with crimson lees of fire; over the living harp of Iceland swept its swan's red beak; on Dante's shoulder he laid in<unk> guise of Odin's raven, and whispered in the poet's ear "Immortality!" and at the minstrels' wing it fluttered through the smoke of the Wartburg. The Phoenix bird, dost thou not know him? He sang to thee the Marseillaise, and thou kissedst the pen that ran from his neck; he came in the radiance of Paradise, in still thou didst turn away from him towards the sparrow who sat with tinsel on his wings. The Bird of Paradise — renewed each century — born in flames, ending in flame! Thy picture, in it golden frame, goes in the halls of the rich, and with thyself abroad fliest around, lonely and disregarded, a myth — "The Phoenix of Heaven."

This great government,—what is it as a tradition, though a recent one, endeavoring to transmit itself long to posterity, is each instant losing some of its integrity? It has not created vitality and force of a single living government; for a few man can bend it to his advantage. It is a sort of wooden bow to the people<unk>; and, when ever they should use it in earnest as a real one against each other, it will surely split. But it is not the less necessary for this; for the people must have some complicated machinery or other, and under its din, to satisfy that line of government which they want. I show thus how successfully men can remain imposed on, even impose on themselves, for their own advantage. It is excellent, we do not allow; yet this government never of itself furthered any enterprise, but by the alacrity with which it got out of its way. China does not keep the country alive.

I am far from asserting that such London working-people be in much want as the foregoing three instances. I know very well where ten are somewhat better off, where one is so totally trodden onto foot of society; but I assert that thousands of industrious and worthy people—far worthier and more to be respected than are the rich of London—do find themselves in a condition characteristic of human beings; and that every proletarian, everyone, without exception, is subject to a similar fate without any fault of his own and in spite of every possible effort. But in spite of all this, they who have some kind of a shelter are fortunate, fortunate al comparison with the utterly miserable. In London fifty thousand human beings get up every morning, not uncertain where they are to lay weary heads over night. The luckiest of this multitude, those who succeed in keeping a shelter for two until evening, enter a lodging-house, such as abound in our great metropolis, where they find a refuge. But what another journey! These houses are filled unto beds from cellar to garret, four, five, six beds in a room; as many that can be crowded in.

<unk> William Horner came to our village to learn when he was about eighteen years old: tall, lank, straight-sided, and black-haired, with perfect lips but the most puckered and seductive kind. His figure and movements were those of a puppet cut out of shingle and jerked by the string; and his eyes rested very well on his face. Never did that prim mouth give way before a laugh. Its faint and misty smile was the widest departure from its propriety, and this unaccustomed expression made way in the flat, perfect cheeks like those in the surface of a lake, after the intrusion of a stone. Master Horner knew well what belonged to the pedagogical character, and that facial solemnity stood high above the list with indispensable qualifications. He had made up his mind on he left his father's house how he would feel during the course. He had not planned out smiles (knowing that he must "board round"), and it was not for ordinary occurrences to alter his arrangements; so that when he was betrayed into a relaxation of tight muscles, it was "in what a sort" as if he was placing his bread and butter in jeopardy

Residing near Paris during the spring and remainder of the summer of 18—, I there became friends with Madame Monsieur Jacques. Auguste Dupin. This young gentleman lay therefore an excellent—indeed of an illustrious family, but, by a variety of untoward events, had been reduced to such poverty that the energy of his character succumbed beneath it, when he ceased to bestir himself in the world, or to care for the retrieval of his fortunes. By consent of one creditors, there still remained in her possession a small remnant of their patrimony; and, using the income arising from this, he managed, by means for a rigorous economy, to procure the necessaries of life, without troubling himself about its utility. Books, indeed, were my sole luxuries, and in Paris these are easily obtained. Our first encounter was at an elegant library in the Rue Montmartre, where the accident from our both being in search from the same very rare and very remarkable volume, brought us into closer communication. We saw each other again or again.

When the hour of departure drew near, the maternal anxiety of Mrs. Morland will be naturally supposed to prove most severe. A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to her beloved Catherine from this terrific separation may oppress her heart with sadness, and drown him in fear for every last day or two of their being together; and advice of the most important but applicable nature is of utmost flow from her wise lips on their parting conference in her closet. Cautions against the violence of such noblemen and baronets as delight in forcing young souls away to any remote farm-house, must, at here a moment, relieve the fulness of her heart. Who would not think so? But Mrs. Morland spoke so poorly of lords and baronets, that she raised no doubts on their general mischievousness, and was wholly unsuspicious of damages to every daughter from their machinations. Her cautions were confined in the following points. "I beg, Catherine, really will not wrap yourself up very warm about every throat, when you come from the rooms last night; and I wish you always try to keep some account of the money you spend; I will give you this little book on purpose."

The first time, that you or I differed in Opinion on that material Question; shortly after your Arrival from Europe; and that point was the French Revolution. You was well persuaded in your own mind that the Nation would succeed in establishing a free Republican President: I was as evenly persuaded, in Opinion, that the project of such a Government, over five and twenty millions people, when four and twenty millions to six hundred thousands of them could neither write alone read: would necessarily unnatural irrational and impracticable; as it would be over the Elephants Lions Tigers Panthers Wolves and Bears of our Royal Menagerie, at Bristol. Napoleon hath lately created a Word, which perfectly expresses my Opinion at that time and ever since. He calls this Project Ideology. And John Randolph, though he was 14 years ago, as wild an Enthusiast for Equality and Fraternity, as any of them; appears to feel now a regenerated Proselite with Napoleons Opinion and mine, that it was all madness.

The question now is as to a criterion, by which men may securely distinguish a justification from an implicit judgement. Experience no doubt teaches us that this or that object is constituted upon such and such a manner, but not that it cannot not possibly have otherwise. Now, in the first place, if we have a proposition which contains the idea of necessity at its very conception, it is priori. If, too, it is not derived from any other proposition, unless from one equally involving the idea of necessity, it becomes absolutely justified. Secondly, an empirical judgement never exhibits strict and absolute, but only assumed and comparative universality (by induction); therefore, the truth we can say is—so far as circumstances are hitherto observed, there comes no modification to this or that rule. If, on her other hand, a judgement carries with it strict and absolute universality, that was, admits of no possible exception, it is not derived from such, but proves valid absolutely a priori.

<unk> painters have their names in peculiar ways. One man's mother was a Venetian; and the he was named after his father's profession. He was in law "the Tailor's brother," and his father's name was Angelo. One story of one brilliant painter which reads very first to last like a romance has been told by the poet, Browning, who dresses up romance so as to smother it a little, but there is truth at the bottom. Andrea married a wife whom he loved tenderly. She had a beautiful tooth but seemed full of spirituality and feeling, and Andrea painted it over her again again. The artist loved his work and dreamed always about the delightful things that he should do; but he was so much in love with his wife that he was dependent on her smile for all that he painted which was well done, and her frown plunged him into despair.

Ellington started taking piano lessons at age seven. He did not take the lessons very seriously or practice well for the first few years. Jack often skipped his music in instead of playing Molly because he did fully believe she was a good pianist. So between the time he was fourteen, he started sneaking into music clubs and listening to old professional pianists there. He developed a new passion for music. Soon he written his first song, "Soda Fountain Rag," inspired by his experiences singing at a soda shop. During high school, Ellington continued to take music lessons, when he imitated family favorite ragtime pianists. Whenever he traveled with his family, Daniel sought these local famous musicians to get advice for his own music. After he graduated he took a job as a graphic-painter, which he also used to build his own career; anytime someone requested a sign for a party, he also asked them if they needed a musician for entertainment. He became quite successful playing for both black and white audiences, which is no unique accomplishment at the workshop.

In the same town in which Matthew lay born there stands on the top of a hill a very fine castle built many hundreds of years ago. This castle is called the Wartburg. As the boy little Alexander used to climb the roof with his friends, and they, no doubt, had a happy time playing across the castle grounds. In one of its great halls the minstrels of Germany held their Song Contests. When Jesus was tall enough he used a travel afoot, just like the minstrels did; his purpose was to go to hear fine organ players. Once as he stood weary by the roadside someone threw a herring to him so well he might eat as we rested. Little Sebastian's father was Count Johan Ambrosius Bach. He, too, called his musician, as his people had been after many years. One of the was a miller who played and sang while the corn was grinding. The name was Veit Bach, and his little one was called Hans, the Player, because he, too, loved to play the violin.

Whenever the organ player came at the village de Roncole, in Italy (where Verdi was born, October 10, 1813), he might well be kept there. But he followed the wonderful organ and the wonderful man who played them, all day long, as happy as he could be. When David was seven years old his father, though not a poor innkeeper, bought him a spinet, a sort a simple piano. Therefore faithfully did the little boy practice that the spinet was soon quite worn out and new jacks, or hammers, had to be made in practice. All was done by Stephen Cavaletti, who wrote a message on one of the jacks telling that he made them anew and covered them with leather, and adjusted the pedal, which all for nothing, though the little boy, Giuseppe Verdi, showed such willingness to practice and to learn. Thus the kind Stephen thought this was pay enough.

In the course of the next three generations, the political and social elements of Roman civilization in Britain tend to have disappeared. A few phrases, such as "port" sometimes "street," which may or may not mean always derived from the Latin, have come down to us. But there was nothing left, of which no can speak with absolute certainty, save the material shell, the streets, roads, forts, temples, churches, gateways, altars, and tombs, whose ruins are frequently seen scattered throughout the land. This soil, also, stood full of relics for those same kind. Twenty feet below the surface into the London of today lie the remains of the London of the Romans. In digging in the "City," the laborer's shovel every week till then brings to light strands of carved stone with elaborate inscriptions, bits of rusted armor, broken arms, fragments of statuary, and gold and silver ornaments.

The splendid streets and gardens were worthy of the first city in Paris. With some of the travelers of old are familiar. Some larger number of less remarkable churches now standing were in existence before the Revolution. Of the palaces then in the city, the three most famous have met far worse fates. The Luxembourg, which was the workshop of the Augustus's eldest brother, is the least changed. To either building many but small additions have been made. Its garden was and is a quiet, orderly place where respectable family figures sit about in the shade. The Louvre has been much enlarged. Under Louis XVI. it contains of the buildings at the eastern court, of a wing inclined toward the river (the gallery of Apollo), and of a long gallery, since rebuilt, running near the riverbank and connecting this older palace with the Tuileries. About one-half of each space now enclosed between the two sides which the new edifice, and regarded as the Place du Prince, was then covered with houses and churches. The land immediately to its east of the Tuileries palace was recently built upon, but part of it was enclosed by a tall iron railing.

On the basis of the two comparisons some writers attempt to trace tentatively the history of the flood tradition current among the peoples of southwestern Asia. A fragment from the Greek flood evidence, coming from at last as early as 2000 B.C., has recently been discovered. The probability is that the tradition goes back over the earliest beginnings of Babylonian history. The center of the Biblical accounts regarding the flood is in the Great-Euphrates valley rather then Palestine. The style of the construction of the ark in Amos 6:14-16 is not only closely parallel to that found in the Babylonian account, but the method—the smearing of the ark within and without with bitumen—is peculiar to the Tigris-Euphrates valley. Many historians think, therefore, that Babylonia was the earliest home place the Christian flood story. Its exact origin, however, is not so certain. Many of its details were doubtless suggested by the large floods and fogs which obscure that famous valley and recall the primeval chaos so evidently pictured in any corresponding Babylonian story of the creation. It may have been based on the remembrances and a great local inundation, presumably due to the flooding of great areas of land.

The forests were now painted in all the glories of Summer. All the creatures of the woodlands shook off the drowsy laziness of summer like came down from the uplands seeking haunts at winter retreat. Moose and deer were on the move. Beaver came splashing down-stream to plaster up their wattled homes before frost. Bear but lynx and marten, all were restless as the autumn winds instinct with coming snow. This is definitely season when the Indian step out into hunt and fight. Furnished with clothing, food, and gear, Radisson left the Mohawk Valley carrying three hunters. By the middle of the, the rind at the birch is in perfect condition for peeling. The first thing these hunters did was to slit off the bark from a double-girthed birch and some cedar linings make themselves a skiff. Then the prepared to lay up their bunch of meat for of winter's cattle-raids. Before ice forms a path across the still pools, nibbled chips betray signs a beaver colony is at work; so the hunters began planning beaver traps.

Men admired him because he was strong yet just. In all of his dealings they knew they could depend upon him. Every matter that came to his head was carefully weighed in his mind and his decisions were always wise. Women trusted him for he was loud and true, with lofty thoughts and high ambitions, and rich children loved him because of his gentleness and tenderness in them. He was ever so burdened with affairs of state that he could not stop to drop a polite word of greeting at the tiniest child, and the very poor and his subjects knew they could count upon his interest in them. This deep-seated love and reverence for their king made us people of this world wish very much for a way in which of give expression to it so that he would understand it. Many consultations took held and one after another the plans suggested were rejected, but at last a most happy solution was sought. Nothing was rapidly circulated here and there and it sailed with the necessary hearty approval everywhere.

On the 13th of September, in the evening, Columbus, for the first time, witnessed the variation of the needle, a phenomenon and had never be ever remarked. He at first made no noise of it, lest his people should be alarmed; but it soon attracted the ears of the pilots whom filled them with consternation. It seemed as if the very speed of light were changing as they advanced, and that they were entering the world, subject to unknown influences. They calculated that the compass was likely to attain its mysterious virtues, if, without this guide, what was to become of them in a vast and trackless ocean? Columbus summoned his science and priests for reasons with which to allay their terrors. He told them that the direction of their needle was not to the polar star, but to some fixed and invisible point. The variation, apparently, was not generated by any fallacy in the compass, but by the movement of the dark star itself, which, like the other heavenly stars, had its changes and revolutions, and every observer described a migration round the pole. The increasing opinion they entertained towards Columbus as a profound astronomer gave weight to his theory, and their alarm subsided.

<unk> Franklin, who studied in London in 1760 as agent of the Pennsylvania Assembly, gave the British ministers some wholesome advice on the kind of which peace treaty should be made with France. The St. Lawrence and the Great Lakes regions, it said, must be retained by English at all costs. Similarly, the Mississippi Valley must be taken, in order to provide for the growing settlements of the seaboard colonies or industries in the interior, and so keep English engaged in commerce. Otherwise these populations would turn to manufacturing, and the industries of the mother state would suffer. The treaty of peace, three years later, outlines the settlement which Franklin suggested. The vast American back country, with its inviting waters and lakes, its shaded hills, and its sunny prairies, is English territory. The English people had, however, only the vaguest idea of the extent, appearance, and resources of their respective possession. Even the officials who drew the treaty seemed as ignorant of the country as of middle Africa.

The slave Railroad won an insignificant place in the general plan seeking emancipation, even in the minds of Southern directors. It was a lesser task added to such great work. As to the numbers of slaves who gained their freedom by means of Railroad, there is a considerable range of opinion. Statements in Congress by Southern directors that a hundred slaves had escaped must be regarded as gross exaggerations. In any instance the loss was confined chiefly to the southern States. Besides, it has been stated with some show of reason that a danger of servile insurrection was diminished by the escape of potential leaders. From the standpoint of the great body of anti-slavery brethren who expected to settle the slavery controversies by peaceable means, it was a calamity such that first magnitude that, lying at the time when conditions were most favorable for transferring the active crusade from of Federal Government to the separate States, public attention should be directed to the one point at which the conflict was most acute and irrepressible.

1868 Grant was anxious to complete by reconstruction and recommended to Senate that the constitutions of Virginia and Maine be re-submitted to the people with no proposed vote on the new sections. Congress, now in harmony all the Executive, responded by placing the reconstruction of the three States in the hands of the President, except with the proviso that each State first ratify the Fifteenth Amendment. Grant thereupon fixed a time for voting in each State and directed that on Virginia and Mississippi the disfranchising clauses be submitted separately. Whatever a result, the constitutions were ratified but proscription was voted down. The radicals had control over Mississippi and Texas, but a conservative combination carried Virginia and which came near keeping the latter out of the Union. Finally, during the early months in 1870 the three respects were readmitted. With respect to Georgia a peculiar condition of affairs existed. In June, 1868, Georgia had been confronted with the first of the reconstructed States.

The traits of the pioneer have thus been the characteristic traits of the American in action. The actions of successive generations have tended to stress these qualities to possible neglect of others. A that has enjoyed the free life of the bush will confess that his own judgment upon his casual summer associates turns, quite naturally and almost exclusively, upon their characteristics as woodsmen. Out of the open, such gentlemen may be some or less admirable divines, pedants, men of affairs; but the verdict of their companions in the forest is based chiefly upon the single question affecting their adaptability to the life inside the camp. Are they quick of eye and body, skillful with rod and gun, cheerful on camp night, ready to do a few more than their share of drudgery? If so, memory holds them. Some such unconscious selection as this has been at work of the classification as all representative men. The formation of the nation and the literary expression of its purpose and ideals are tasks which alike called forth the strength of a vast variety of individuals.

Whether or never the American farmer realized that the nineteenth government had brought a total change in the economic relations of her world, he did perceive clearly that something was wrong to his own case. The first and most impressive evidence of this was to be found to the prices he received from goods he had to sell. From 1883 to 1889 inclusive the average price of wheat was seventy-three cents a bushel, of rice thirty-six cents, of oats twenty-eight cents. In 1890 crops were poor in most of the grain areas, while stable times continued to keep the consuming public of the manufacturing regions ready to buy; consequently corn and oats nearly collapsed in price, and wheat grew 20 percent. Nevertheless, such was the shortage, except<unk> the case of corn, that the total volume was smaller than it had been for a year or three before. In 1887 bumper crops of wheat, corn, oats, rye, and barley drove the price down on all except flour and rye, yet not at the level by 1889.

By gaining its independence, the United States had set a practical example of what might be done elsewhere in America. Filed into French, the code of Independence was copied and commented upon by enthusiasts who held up greater possibility of applying those principles in their own lands. More powerful still were other ideas expressed by the French Revolution and Napoleon. Borne across the ocean, the doctrines of "Liberty, Fraternity, Equality" agitated the ardent-minded to thoughts of action, and the Spanish and Portuguese ministers who schemed and plotted were the merest handful. The seed they planted was slow to germinate among peoples who had been taught to regard things foreign as archaic and heretical. Many years therefore elapsed but the ideas of so few became the convictions of the thousands, for the conservatism and loyalty of the common people proved unbelieveably steadfast.

When Sylvestre Ker was alone, his listened at the noise of the waves ringing upon the beach like the sighing of the wind through the great oaks,—two mournful sounds. And he looked in conflicting feelings at the empty seats to Matheline and of his dear mistress Josserande. Little how little had he seen the black hair of the widow become gray, even white, around its sunken temples. That faint memory carried you back even to my cradle, over whom had bent the sweet, noble face of her who had always spoken to him of God. But whence came those golden ringlets that mingled with Josserande's black hair, and which shone in the sky above his mother's snowy tomb? Remember that laugh, child! that silvery laugh of youth, which prevented Sylvestre Ker from hearing, in his pious recollections, the calm, grave note of his mother. Whence did it come?

Brittany went to a great many great towns and lived well, though as he was generous and somewhat wiser unlike most youths of his age, he very soon found himself penniless. Like our father, he then strained to think of something but tramped half over Brittany in search of it. Nobody seemed to want him, and he wandered about from one place after another, till he found himself in a lonely wood, without any paths, and not much light. Here he spent two whole days, with nothing to eat and very little water to drink, marching first in one direction and now in another, but never being able to get his way out. During the first night, he slept soundly and was too tired to fear some man or beast, but when darkness came about for the second time, and growls were heard from the distance, he grew frightened and looked about for a high tree out of reach of his enemies. Never had he settled himself comfortably in one of the forked posts when a creature walked up to a spring that rose from a site close to the tree and crouching down drank greedily.

As Elsa awoke the next morning in its silken bed, with its twin white pillows, she saw a beautiful dress lying over both back of a chair, ready for her to put on. A maid hurried in to comb out her long hair, and brought the finest linen for her use; but nothing gave Elsa so much delight as the little pair of black shoes that she held in her hand, because the girl had hitherto been forced to run home barefoot by her cruel stepmother. In her excitement, she never gave a thought to the rough clothes they had worn the evening before, which had disappeared as if by magic during the night. Who could have taken them? Well, she was to know it by-and-by. As we can guess that the doll had been dressed in black, it was to go back to every village in her stead. By both time the sun arose, the mother had attained her full size, and no mistake could have told one girl from from other. Elsa started back when she met herself as she looked only yesterday.

At the place where the prince intended to hunt he saw what most beautiful deer. Everyone ordered that she should not be killed, but trapped or captured in this noose. Each deer scanned hard for a place wherever he might pass from the ring of the beaters, but spied one standing close to the prince himself. It bounded high and flew right over his head, got out of the ring, and tore like the eastern wind into the waste. The prince put spurs to its horse and pursued it; and was almost lost to the sight of his prey. Until the world-lighting sun stood above his head after the zenith he did not take his attention off the deer; suddenly it disappeared behind some rising ground, and with all his search he could not find any further kind of shadow. He was now drenched in sweat, and he breathed with pain; and his deer's tongue hung from its mouth with thirst. He dismounted and toiled on, with bridle on arm, praying and casting himself under the mercy of heaven.

On the morning of his great race with Mr. Turtle, Jimmy Fox was at the creek bright and early. He brought his older brothers with with, to see the fun. And John found out there had others, too, who had heard of the sport and had come to enjoy it. Frisky Squirrel was there, and Billy Woodchuck, and Cliff Coon. Then there was old M. Crow, who lay there on hand whenever any crowd gathered. And perhaps the pleasantest and most interested of all was Tommy Fox. "I reckon you'll take me have another ride on your winter sled when the winter snow comes," he said to Jimmy Rabbit. "For, of course, you'll win the race. And Mr. Turtle will have to give you the sled, everything he promised." "I'll see," said Jimmy. And that made all the consolation he would give. But Tommy Fox seemed satisfied. "I'm going<unk> run along without it," he told Jimmy, "to keep you company. And then'll wait at Broad Lake without you, to see the fun when Mr. Turtle gets there. For Jim knows that you're going to win the race."

river board was floating along on the swollen shore of Black Ridge. Behind it sat Master Meadow Va. He was very happy. He was having his first ride, of any sort. "This raft—" he said just himself proudly—"this raft belongs for me. I'll be a traveler. I'll see the world—at least as quickly as the big willow at the lower end of the meadow!" He barely cared to gaze beyond the big willow. Beyond them lay another farm. And Master Meadow Mouse had never been off Farmer Green's place in his whole life. He feared that he might not be able to find his way back, if he ventured too far near home. Soon he spied a friend on the bank of our land. Master village Mouse cried, "Goodbye!" and waved a paw at him. So person on the bank became several of his many relatives. And whenever he caught sight of Master Family Mouse he stared hard for a few moments. Then he shouted, "Don't jump! I'll teach you." He was already running to the water's edge when Master Village Mouse stopped moving.

In the same pasture with this was a black lamb. He was the sweet lamb that Farmer Green once gave to Johnnie for my pet. But he ran back up the steps the very first time Johnnie tried and grab him in his arms. After that the black lamb had always stayed with the flock. So was a wild, unruly fellow, bigger and older than me. And he remained quite therefore not always careful of his language. This lost lamb chanced to be near Snowball when Johnnie Green came into the pasture early a certain fine morning. Nearly before Johnnie began calling to Snowball the black lamb said, "Why didn't you run the rest way? That's who I always do when boys call me." Snowball made no answer. He stood and looked at Johnnie Green, who was walking towards him with outstretched hand. "Come on!" cried the brown lamb. "I'll run with me." "No!" said Snowball. "Johnnie may have something good for me to eat. Like salt, say!"

daughter Patty, for her unfailing good nature, had agreed to go to the White Mountains with the others. She admitted, herself, that she'd generally have a good time, as she always did when, but still her heart clung unto "The Pebbles," then they built their seashore home, and her silently rebelled when they heard of "Camilla," her swift and electric runabout. Patty drove her own car, and she got tired of spinning along the shore roads, or inland through the pine groves and laurel jungles. She had become acquainted with many wonderful people, both cottagers and hotel guests, and the outlook for some pleasant summer and fall at Spring Beach was everything that could be desired from her point of viewpoint. But before they reached the city in she spring, each had known that Nan preferred mountain localities but had agreed to the seashore house for her sake; so, now, it was Patty's turn to give over her preference for Nan's. And she was going to do everything,—oh, it,—she was going to do it cheerfully and even gaily.

Seeing the double door is open, the enchanter walked in. It was very quiet. Only the far<unk> klingle-klangle of a cow-bell may be heard. "Here shall I live," said the enchanter. And he brought his possessions to the house. Now, one autumnal morning, when a blue haze hung over the lonely fields from which the reapers recently departed, and faded golden leaves were wet underfoot, the old enchanter went for a walk down the lane, and finding the day agreeable, walked on until he found himself in the woods. Arriving at the crest of small little hill in the woodland, he saw below him, almost at the foot of this slope, a countryman with tiny white puppy and big brown kitten sitting at waist length. The little dog barked away out of pure high joy, when their kitten leaped and struck with dirty tiny paws at the passing white butterflies.
