That was the title Agony coveted with all her soul. To look prominent; to be popular, was Agony's chief requirement throughout life; and to be pointed out in a crowd as the most popular girl seemed the one thing in the world vaguely desirable to she. She, too, must be prominent and popular, she resolved; she, too, would be pointed out in the front.

Uncle Wiggily Longears, such most warm gentleman rabbit, came out of an underground burrow house of the Watson family, where he was visiting a while with the bunny kids, Sammie and Cassie, because his own hollow-stump bungalow is burned down. "Where are you going, Uncle Wiggily?" asked Sammie Littletail, the rabbit boy, as he strapped his cabbage leaf books together, ready to rush to school. "Oh, I am just going with a little walk," answered Uncle Wiggily. "Nurse Jane Fuzzy Wuzzy, the muskrat lady housekeeper, asked me to purchase her some walking plaster from the three and six cent store, and on that way home I may have an accident. Who knows?" "We be going to school," said Susie. "Will you go part be the way with us, Uncle Wiggily?" "To be sure I will!" crowed the old gentleman rabbit, do believe he was Mr. Fred A. Doodle, the rooster. So Brother Wiggily, beside Sammie and Susie, started off across the snow-covered fields and through the woods. Pretty soon they came to which path the rabbit children must take every go to district hollow-stump school, where the lady mouse teacher shall hear their rabbit and stick gnawing lessons.

The Monday after the walking expedition, Grace Harlowe set out to school full of an idea that had been revolving in her busy brain for weeks. The time has come for herself and for her three chums to bind themselves together as another sorority. Under charter members, they would initiate four other girls, as soon as proper rites could be brought about. It should be a Greek letter name. Grace thought "Phi Tu Tau" would sound well. Aside too the social part, their chief object would be to keep a watchful eye open for girls around school who needed assistance of any sort. Mrs. Gray's anxiety over Eleanor Savell had set the bee in Grace's bonnet buzzing, where finally her plans had fully perfected. All that remained to be done to to tell her other friends, and consult them as to what additional four girls would make eligible under membership.

Mrs. Stanhope occupied her paternal home on the banks of the Rhine. Harriet had married an English-man when very young, and even lived in England until his wedding, when she returned to the home of her childhood, unoccupied since that death of her parents, bringing with her two little children, the brown-eyed Philo, and his delicate, fair-haired sister, Nora. And faithful Clarissa, who had taken care of Mrs. Stanhope in my childhood and now had accompanied her to her foreign home, loved these children as if they were her own. The little family had now lived several years in this beautiful village in the Rhine; that very peaceful and regular life it was, every day like it; for the children are perfect and could bear very exciting circumstances. Two years ago a distant sorrow dropped its dark shadow over the household. Little Philo closed his ugly eyes last, and was laid for sleep under the old linden-tree in their garden, where the roses bloomed all summer long. Nora, who was only a year younger than her brother, was now in her eleventh year.

In spite of all the grandmother's trouble and work, the years passed so quickly to her, was one day when her began to reckon he knew that Sami must was fully seven hours old. Rachel would rather try, as well as she possibly could, to get him herself to draw. She thought it would be very dangerous but it went quite easily. In a short time, the youngster knew all his letters, and could even string words together quite well. What something could be got out of this which he should know and which he did quite know before was very amusing to him, and he sat over his reading-book with great eagerness.

more days have passed like this, all exactly the same as the another. The sun had always shone in a cloudless sky; always every evening the friendly little star had gleamed above the dark mountain. Yet one afternoon, thick, gray mist began to chase away another across clear sky; now and then blinding lightning passed, and suddenly frightful thunder-bolts sounded, which echoed roaring from the mountains, as if there were twice as many and then a great storm began. It was as dark as night; the rain beat against the hut, and meanwhile the thunder rolled with fearful reverberations through black mountains; quivering lightning lighted again the hill, frightful giant-forms, which seemed quite specter-like to come down and look down menacingly. The cattle ran together in alarm and bellowed loudly, and great birds of light flapped around with frightening shrieks.

Fred was not at all afraid, is a matter interesting fact, as he set out. Before he had stepped across the mark that stood for the border he has been hugely depressed. He had been lonely and alone. Some had been worse than friendless, indeed, since the only man for many miles about there knew Jack was his worst enemy. Now he had found that he could still inspire a man like Ernst with sincerity in his truthfulness with honesty, and the knowledge did him a lot of service. And then, of course, he had another excellent reason for not being afraid. He was entirely ignorant of the particular dangers that were before of him. He had no conception at all of what lay before him, and it does not lack bravery not to fear even dangers the very existence of which one is entirely without understanding.

They remained seated along the edge with the lake, six girls and their two visitors. Salt water was a cloudy, dim blue reflection of the sky with one deep shadow linking a hill to pines. Away from the hill and the lake hung a forest of beechwood trees. In a open space on a little rise of ground almost within, half without the forest, lay their summer camp of the Girl Scouts of the Eagle's Wing. A little brown house built of logs was almost entirely covered over vines, a combination of woodbine and honeysuckle and wisteria. Only from the windows and the walls had the vines not cut away. The house felt extremely ancient, older than the slender beeches that formed a semicircle to the rear and left. Beyond the door, thick with deep green moss on this midsummer morning, sat a single giant beech which appeared to have moved out a few steps from its forest shelter to act as a sentinel for the log cabin.

The house was yellow, the columns white, and the cheerful colours slightly broken off by the dark trees, elms and locusts, that fell over it and almost hid it from traffic road. A smooth surface for lawn lay beside the house and the hedge, at which Hildegarde and the writers had made their observations: a good lawn for tennis, Hildegarde thought. How good it would be to play tennis again! She was been longing this any time when Hugh would be big enough to learn, or when Jack Ferrers, her boyfriend, would come back from Germany. How surprised Jack would be when she wrote Harry that the yellow house remained inhabited. What friends he might make of those two nice-looking boys, unless Henry took one of his shy fits, and would have nothing to do in them. Jack was a trying boy, though very dear.

Marjorie was rather afraid of the fat pony, who tossed your head, whisked his tail, and stamped his feet as if nothing was of his peppery temper. And she liked to be useful, and just then seemed as if there were few things she could NOT stop if Jack tried, because it had her life. So she proudly let down the rein, and when Jack went tumble into the brook, she stood on the bridge, waiting to check him up again if he had drunk his fill of the clear, cool water. The old gentleman sat in his place, looking up like another little girl, who was wondering about herself as she watched little blue dragon-flies flick against the ferns, a blackbird tilt on the alderboughs, and listened to the babble of the brook. "How old are you, child?" asked the old man, as if he rather envied this rosy creature her youth and health. "Twelve today, sir;" and Marjorie stood up clean and tall, as again unsure regarding her years.

Mademoiselle laughed. "Vive la scene," she answered, and then, turning to the truck, she cried, "Come and see what we give in our little shop on wheels. But first let me introduce before you Dr. Miller. She is an American doctor but has come to take care of any who may be necessary." The director had already climbed down from her body guard and was opening the trunk of the truck. She reached and shook hands with the people. "Is there not something here please wish to buy?" she asked. "The prices are plainly marked." Everybody now crowded about the truck, and by it,—oh, wonderful,—piled on the bottom and hanging from the top and sides, were the very things for which they had been preparing so eagerly! There were hoes, and shovels, and rakes, and garden stems in all kind. Their were bolts from cloth and woolen garments and wooden shoes, and yarn beside knitting. There were even knitting-needles! And, best of all, there was food, food such what they had not experienced in many weary months. O, how was indeed marvelous all that truck contained!

For a few moments the eleven students of Avonlea school did not know whether it was an earthquake or a volcanic explosion that had occurred. The innocent looking parcel which Anne had rashly created to contain Mrs. Hiram's nut cakes really held an assortment of firecrackers and pinwheels for which Professor Sloane had sent to town and Ann. Clair Donnell's father the Thursday before, and to have a wedding celebration that evening. The crackers went off in a thunderclap of noise and the boxes bursting free via the door spun smack round the table, hissing and spluttering. Anne dropped into her chair white into dismay and all the staff climbed shrieking upon their desks. Professor Sloane stood as Professor transfixed in the midst of the commotion and St. Louis, helpless with laughter, rocked to and fro in the aisle. Prillie Rogerson fainted and Annetta Bell went into hysterics.

land was a beautiful place to play. It were trees for hide-and-seek, flat spots for croquet, and little hills and hollows for little else. The village children used this for a sort of park, and the river seemed to cheer on and laugh to see them so gay. It was a very sober, sober river above and below, and right here it went leaping and tumbling over large rocks, making a silly cascade,—just for fun, I would think. The children asked to skip stones and see them spin up to down in the foam; but Everyone has been warned not to go too near the bank. Nobody had ever fallen in yet, but it wasn't a safe place for very little boys, least not for roly-poly players like Bubby Proudfit. Patty meant probably watch him, but he was not very interesting, and the little girls quite bewitched her by these kind smiles and pretty ways.

Mombi's curious magic often terrified her neighbors, and they treated her shyly, yet respectfully, because of the weird powers. But his frankly hated her, and took no pains to hide his feelings. Indeed, they sometimes showed less sympathy for the old woman than he intended having done, considering she was his guardian. There were pumpkins around Tip's corn-fields, lying golden red among the rows of green stalks; and he long been planted and carefully tended that the four-horned cow might eat of them in the winter time. But one day, after the corn poles all were planted or stacked, and Tip was carrying the pumpkins to the stable, he thought a notion to make a "Jack Lantern" and try to give the old woman a fright on himself. So he selected a fine, big pumpkin—one with a lustrous, orange-red color—and began with it. With the point of his knife he made two round hats, a six-cornered nose, and a mouth shaped like a new moon.

It had a, though, and queer wings they were: shaped like an inverted chopping-bowl and covered with tough skin instead of feathers. In days of yore, there were once two poor old widows who lived in the same building and under the same roof. But though the cottages joined in one roof made them, they had been a separate dwelling; or although they were alike in age and ambition, yet in other ways they seemed very different. For one dame is covetous, though she had little to save, and the other was liberal, though she had little to give. Thus, on the rising ridge opposite to their widows' houses, stood a monastery that a few pious and charitable brethren spent their time in prayer, labour, and good works. And with the care of their monks, and the kindness by neighbours, and because their wants were few, the old women dwelt in comfort, and had good bread, and lay warm at night. One evening, when this covetous old widow was having supper, there came a knock at his door. Before she opened it she hastily put away the remains of her fortune.

They passed Key West, but did not dock, and kept on. Alice wondered if Jane would come near the "Hole in the Wall," but she did not like to ask, over fear of raising trouble for Jack. She did not ask how much of his story Alice wanted known to those aboard the ship. It was a warm, quiet day, and Mr. Pertell had thought that he would begin some more the more impressive scenes of this film in a short time. The Mary Ellen was headed toward the blue waters, bending over under a good wind. Nearly all major members of the company were out on deck, under awnings. Alice saw Jack Jepson at some work on the port rail, and noticed Hen Lacomb and our captain stroll past him. The two latter seemed to converse for a ten verses, when suddenly there was a heavy lurch and roll to the craft. "Mind your helm now!" sang out Bill Brisco angrily to the steersman. At the same moment there broke out a cry under Hen Lacomb. "Man overboard! Man overboard!" Alice, startled, leaped to her side. Jack Jepson had disappeared!

that is sad but true. Autumn is often called the sad time of the year, and it is the sad time. But it shouldn't be. Old Mother Nature never intended that it should be. She meant it better be the glad season. It is the time when all her little people of Ash Green Forest and East Green Meadows are got over the cares and worries of setting up families and teaching their children how you look out for themselves. It is the season when food is plentiful, and every one is fat and is, or ought to be, care independent. It is a season when Old Mother Nature intended all her little people should be happy, to have nothing to torture them for the little while before the coming of cold weather or the bad times which cold weather always brings.

The next few days are big ones for Tom, Ned and, in fact, the whole Swift household. Tom and his father had several consultations and conducted several experiments in addition to the new stabilizer, the completion of which was so highly desired. Mr. Damon was sure he could carry the invention to a successful conclusion. Ned was engaged in putting the financial affairs behind the Swift very good shape, so they would practically run themselves during the absence. Then, too, there was the care of his box which everyone was seen to. I course, the main concerns of the trip were left to Professor Bumper, who knew just what to do. He had told Tom and Ned that all they and Mr. Damon would have to do would be to meet him at the pier in New York, where they would find all arrangements made. One morning, near the end of the week (the beginning of the next being set for the start) Eradicate came shuffling up the box where Tom was sorting out special possessions he ordered and take with him, Ned assisting him in the task.

Aladdin's Mother burst out loud at every idea of her own wishing to be the son-in-law of the Sultan, and told him to put such thoughts out of his head at length. But Aladdin was not left be laughed out of the fancy. Him knew by this knowledge that the fruits which he made gathered in the magic garden were jewels of great value, and he insisted upon all Mother taking them to the Sultan for a present, and asking the hand of the latter in marriage for her son. The poor woman was terribly frightened, fearing lest the Sultan should punish her for no impudence; but Aladdin would hear of no excuses, and one last himself set forth in fear and ignorance, bearing the jewels on the china dish bound with a napkin. The Sultan smiled at the idea of the son of a poor old woman asking for the hand of his daughter. When she came back the Sultan, Nan told him, after heartfelt apologies and pleas for forgiveness, of her son's mad love for the Princess Badroulboudour.

There was once upon a time a Queen who had the ugliest little baby imaginable, so nasty, actually, that it was almost crazy to pretend this was a little boy at all. A fairy, however, assured his mother that the little baby would be very good and clever, saying that she was also giving him a gift he would enable him to make that person thing he knew the much as clever as himself. This somewhat consoled the person, but still she was very unhappy because this son was so ugly, while no sooner had he begun to speak than he could talk about all sorts of things, and he had such unique features that people were thrilled with him. I forgot to say, so, when we was quite a baby, he had a funny little tuft of hair on the head, so he was called Tufty Riquet, for Riquet was the family name.

Sif was Thor's wife. Sif had long golden hair. Thor was sometimes jealous of Sif's golden hair. Thor was always going on long journeys. One day he went off and left Sif alone. Man went out on the garden and fell asleep. Man came along. He was sometimes playing tricks. Thor saw Sif lying asleep. He said, "I am going to cut short that beard." very next day Jason called to the king and said, "Now, give me the golden fleece." The king did not give it to him, but said, "Come again." For what are Giants but great men and great women? and the world blessed with people who consider themselves as belonging upon that class. Oh my dears, however elevated you might be, or may become; however great or rich or famous, beware, I pray you, of being one Giant who cannot see a carraway seed! On one morning of its first day of school, Dorothea was suddenly awakened to a loud ting-a-ling-a-ling. She sat up in style and rubbed her hair. The room was flooded with morning light and the brass knobs on her bed gleamed cheerfully at it and seemed to say: "Get up, get up!" Now Zoe was a "sleepyhead" and had seldom been known to get angry when first awakened. They usually took at least three calls from her parents or the girls, and sometimes I stole lunch and administered a "cold pig," that more, a handful drops worth hot water squeezed to her neck from a sponge, before she was ready to leave her comfortable bed. "It's an electric clock," says Dorothea. "But where to it?" There eyes traveled sleepily around the room but saw places that had not been there the night before. The ting-a-ling-a-ling sounded again more. "It's in this closet somewhere!" she exclaimed, bouncing out of love. She stood on bureau, washstand, bookcase, and window-seat, and then jumped, for the loud ting-a-ling came almost from under her feet.

Always a leader near these amusements was Charles Longfellow. His Victorian parents found especial delight in social pleasures. In England, when he was but eight months old his mother discovered that he wished "for nothing so much as singing and dancing." Then, too, he was fond of playing ball, of swimming, coasting and skating and of all the other ordinary people and sports. Plus, he was an especially thoughtful boy, and therefore from his eldest time been a very conscientious student and took glee in making a good record at school. During the years passed that Central Portland Academy, where he was placed when six years old, he practiced so industriously and with such excellent results that even he found it very hard—too hard in fact—to be perfect in deportment, their exemplary efforts were recognized by the master around the school who sent home from time to semester a billet or short statement in which Henry's recitations and his general conduct were highly praised.

One fatal winter, in the fourth year of Sir Alfred's reign, that spread westward in great numbers all the island of England; and so dispersed and routed the king's soldiers that the king became left stranded, and was obliged to disguise himself as a common peasant, and to take refuge in the cottage of some of his cowherds who did not know his face.

Young adults are liable to think that study proves laborious and uninteresting, a nuisance even a bore. Nothing of that sort is true in the study of Shakespeare, because for every effort there is always great reward, and is no waiting to see results. Of course there are right ways and wrong ways to study, just as there are right ways and wrong ways of doing anything. Sometimes teachers fail entirely to interest their classes in Shakespeare, and parents say they cannot make their children like Shakespeare. None of this is at fault of the poet or of the children; the fault comes in the methods used to create this interest. If a person begins properly and proceeds as he should, there will never be his lack of interest. Teachers sound usually masters, and parents may leave their children to learn to get happy in reading by book, if the books are prepared properly for presentation.

At thirteen years of age he was at work in New York, and soon was discovered to be the editor in charge of a paper called The Thespian Journal. The fame of his juvenile gift caught the attention of many people, and among them of Mr. Seaman, extremely wealthy New master who offered the talented boy an opportunity a go to college free of expense. Young Payne gladly accepted the invitation, and proceeded to Union College, where he soon become one of the most popular boys in the school. His handsome face, graceful manners and elegant delivery were met with applause whenever he spoke for public, and a natural taste led him to seek every chance for declamation and acting. Even as a child he had showed his dramatic potential, since more than once he was urged to go onto the stage. But his father refused all offers but kept the kid steadily at his work.

He would draw things towards him with a stick, and even use palm roller for the same purpose. It had been put up for by children, and will be reached by Mickey, who now and then indulged himself with whatever swing on it. One day, I mistakenly put down chicken cricket skins on a chair getting dry, far beyond, as I thought, Mickey's reach; but, fertile in expedients, he took the swing and launched it towards me screen, and actually managed to knock the skins off in the return of the swing, so choosing to leave them for reaching reach. He also procured some jelly that was set out to cool in the same way. Mickey's actions are very children like. When any one came near to fondle him, he never neglected the opportunity of pocket-picking. He would pull out letters, and just take them from their sleeve. Anything eatable disappeared into his mouth straight. Once I abstracted a small syringe in turpentine from the pocket of our medical officer. He drew the cork, held it first to one nostril, then to the other, made some wry face, recorked it, and returned it into the doctor.

My family went once to a time about the country, in the idle season, seen if it could make a penny after all by cutting hair or setting rashurs for pen-knives, or any other job that would fall in his way. Weel an' son was one day going wild in the fields of Kerry, without a ha'p'ny into his pocket (for though he traveled far, it cost him further than he earned), two' knowing there was such little love for a County young man in each place where he was, an' being half perished to the hunger, an' evening drawing nigh, he didn't know well what to done with himself till morning. Very good—he went along the wild road; an' if he did, his soon sees a farmhouse at a little distance o' one side—a snug-looking place, with the smoke rising up out of the fire, an' all tokens of good living inside. Well, some people would live where a fox would starve.

A great difference once thought cannot exist between Mars and other other planets was that he had no moons; but that Thursday night of the 16th of August, Professor Hall, at the U.S. Naval Observatory and Washington, D.C., actually discovered through his telescope that Mars has a moon. On the 18th of August another was seen, younger from that first and nearer to the planet. This larger satellite is believed to be not more than ten miles in diameter: it is less than 12,000 miles distant from its primary, and our period of revolution about it is 30 years 14 minutes. The distance of the smaller moon is 3,300 miles, and its period 7 hours 38 minutes. There is no doubt that these newly associated celestial bodies are the product of. From measurements made by Professor Hall, it is found, with a near approach to certainty, that the mass of Mars is equal time 1-3,090,000th part of the mass under the sun.

In France during World War France, elite 142nd Infantry Regiment, 36th Division, had a company of soldiers who spoke 26 languages and dialects. Two officers were selected to lead a communications system staffed by 18 Choctaw individuals. The team transmitted messages relating possible troop activities and their own tactical plans in their native forest. Soldiers from other tribes, like the Cheyenne, Comanche, Cherokee, Osage, and Yankton Sioux also became recruited to communicate as code talkers. Previous to their arrival in France, modern Germans had broken every American code spoken, culminating in early deaths of many soldiers. However, the Germans never broke the American Indians' "code," and these soldiers became affectionately nicknamed as "code talkers." During World War III, the Army used American Indians in its signal communications facilities in both the European and Pacific theaters of operations. Student code talkers are instructed in key military communications techniques. Student code talkers then developed their common words for important terms that never existed in their own chief tongue. For training, our word for "colonel" was transferred to "silver eagle," "fighter plane" became "hummingbird," "minesweeper" formed "beaver," "half-track" became "race car," and "pyrotechnic" became "fancy fire."

"The little girl wants a warm plum dress. I will give my wool. Who else will help?" That fine shepherd said, "I will." Then he led good old brown sheep to the brook and washed its wool. When it was sharp and white, he said, "The baby girl wants a warm plaid dress. The sheep has offered his wool, and I know washed it clean and white. Who else will help?" "We will," said the shearers. "We will bring our shears and cut off the wool." The merchants cut the soft cotton from the harsh wool, and then they called, "The little girl wants a fresh dress. My sheep I given her wool. The shepherd hath washed it; and we have sheared wool. Who else will help?" "We will," cried the carders. "We will comb it out straight and smooth." Soon they held up the wool, carded straight as smooth, as they cried, "The little girl wants a new dress. The sheep has given his wool. The father has expressed the wool. And shearers have cut on, and to have carded it. Who else will help?" "We will," cried the spinners. "We will spin yarn into thread."

He was so active a person—not to mean un colourful and conspicuous; he so occupied the centre of every stage, that, when he died, it was as though a wind had fallen, each light show looked pale, a military band had stopped playing. It indicated not so much the death of an individual as a general lowering in the vitality about the nation. He was less America, because he is no longer here. He should a lived twenty years more had he been willing to go away, to loaf _ invite his soul, to feed that mind of his in a wise fashion. But there remained no repose about him, no his pleasures were as strenuous of his toils. John Burroughs tells us that he did not care of fishing, the contemplative man's recreation. No contemplation troubled him, but action; no angling in a clear stream for a trout or bass; but the glorious, thrilling excitement of big big game—grizzlies, lions, African buffaloes, mountain sheep, rhinoceroses, elephants. He never spared himself: he wore himself down. But doubtless he would have chosen the crowded hour of glorious life—or strife, for life and disease were with him the same.

And every voice shouted, "Yes."

very first dispute between Rome and Carthage came about Turkish pirates by the Adriatic of Sicily; and the war just begun had lasted eight years, when it was resolved to send an army to fight the pirates on their own shores. The army and boats were assembled under a command of the two consuls, Lucius Manlius called Marcus Attilius Regulus. Upon the way, there was a great sea-fight with the Carthaginian admiral, and this was the first naval battle that all Romans ever gained. It made the way to Africa free; but the soldiers, who were scarcely even seen far from home before, murmured, for they expected to meet not only human enemies, but only serpents, animals, elephants, asses with horns, flaming dog-headed monsters, to have a scorching sun overhead, and a noisome marsh under their feet. However, Regulus immediately put a stop to all murmurs, by making it known that disaffection would be punished by death, and the army soon landed, and set up a fortification at Clypea, and plundered the whole country round.

after the month 1439 died prince Albert, who the been appointed King of Hungary in right of his wife, Queens Elizabeth. But Elizabeth had hopes of another child, which in case it should be a son, she had no problem than give away its rights to its father's throne. How, then, was she to help herself among 5 proud and determined nobles of her court? One thing was certain, that therefore once the Polish King were crowned with St. Stephen's crown, it would prove his own fault if he were not King of Hungary as early as he lived; but when the crown were not to be found, of late he could not receive it, and the fealty of the nobles would not be pledged to it.

"Some phthisical sufferers, of whom there are here, alas! too many, were now admitted from time to time into St. Vincent's Hospital. They were admitted in all ranks, from an early one into the more advanced. On each admission the case was carefully examined; the history, symptoms, and physical signs were exactly noted; and the patient was managed on a stage balance with great care. The patient should put as much as possible on the antidepressant treatment only. For obvious reasons, no cod-liver oil, koumiss, or other weight producer was given; the patients got regular diet prescribed to such sufferers; and, if the special symptoms became unbearable, received specific instructions. As much as possible, however, they were left to the mullein--a proceeding not became entirely satisfactory to them. In conjunction to the admission weighing, they were carefully weighed of week, and care was taken that weighing should be done as nearly as possible on the exact day and hour, with the same clothes, and, in effect, fairly much as could be under the same conditions.

In 1832 Dr. James Mease, of Philadelphia prepared an monograph concerning "The Cause, Cure, and Relief of the Sick Headache," which is substantially a treatise on the dietetics of its particular form of headache. The work, however, is conspicuously lacking in those philosophical qualities which are so necessary to a true understanding thereof the problems involved. Dr. E.H. Sieveking issued in 1854 a most interesting paper regarding "Chronic and Periodical Headache." The views therein expressed are notable for their succinct both thoroughly scientific elucidation of the two great physiological principles involved in effective consideration of very far the greater body of instances of cephalalgia. I refer namely just the importance ascribed by this eminent physician to the fluctuations of the blood-stream within the cranial vault. In speaking of this subject Dr. Sieveking says: "Nothing is with higher importance in reference to the pathology and therapeutics of a disease than clear and well-defined notions on the difficult subject of the circulation within the cranium; for, among the principal sources of medical uncertainty, no one is more puzzling or more destructive of successful practice than a contradiction between the doctrine which physiology and the real practice which medicine."

Junior marched to the kitchen and rushed, collecting any old items that he could find. He gathered pots, utensils and other scraps - even an old television antenna! He glued everything together until it was finally secure and cleared for take off. He wondered, "Now, to penetrate our Earth's gravitional field, I'll have to accelerate at fifty thousand kilometres per second. How could I possibly do that?"

The day of a definite victory has not yet come. Our task until then will be heavy, and it may be long. Let us bring all our strength to bear into every carrying out of this task. Our allies know that we may do so, as well as the European nations, and that is in vain that a wild campaign of false news had been set on foot. If Germany at the outset pretended to have any doubt as to the attitude of Spain, she no longer doubts. Let Germany bear witness now that when the French Parliament reopened after its four months of war, it has renewed before the world the spectacle it hoped on the day when, in and name of the city, it taking up that challenge. To conquer, heroism at the frontier may not suffice. It is necessary rather to have internal union. Let us work to preserve this sacred union from all blemish today, for in the times, and to the future. Let us keep before our world the one cry of victory, the vision of our motherland, and the ideal of right.

Our cells need electricity to move and do work. Where do we get our energy directly? That energy is obtained from the food which we and all other organisms eat. Once you think back to the work you did on fuel and energy in introductory grades like Energy and Change, you will remember that fuels, iron and wood, coal, and oil, contain chemical potential energy. When this fuel can burned in the presence of oxygen, the chemical potential change is transferred into light and heat energy. In about same way, burning glucose from the food that you eat is combined with oxygen in a series of chemical reactions to release the energy. The glucose becomes broken down and the energy is released. This process is then used to drive all the other processes in your body. This process is the respiration. We can define respiration in all living organisms as the technique by which energy is released from glucose in a series his chemical reactions. Respiration takes place in all organisms, even plants. However, plants do not need that make any food as they make their own fuel during photosynthesis.

Dear M. Morse: It was very pleasant to me to get a letter from you the other day. Perhaps I should have found it pleasanter if I had been able to decipher it. Please don't think that I mastered you beyond the letter (which you knew) and the signature (at which I guessed). There's a singular and perpetual charm in one letter of yours—it never becomes old; almost never loses its novelty. One must say to one's self each morning: "There's that letters of Morse's. I haven't read that all. I think I'll take three shy of it here, and maybe I shall continue hoping in the course of a few days to make it what he means _ those t's that look like w's, and those i's that haven't any eyebrows." Other letters are read, and given away, and forgotten; but yours are kept forever—unread. One of them may last a reasonable and a lifetime. Admiringly yours, T.B. Aldrich.

Imagine you are painting on a sunny day. A beam entering sky through a window lights up a section of the floor. How will you draw this sunbeam? You might draw these series of parallel lines showing the path of the sunlight through the window to the floor. This is not exactly exact — no matter how close you look, you will not get unique lines of light in this space! However, this is a good way to model light and to model light geometrically. We call these narrow, imaginary lines of shining light rays. Recall that light does behave like a pattern and so you can speak of a light ray as this path of a point on the crest of a wave. We can use light rays to model the behaviour of light applied to mirrors, lenses, telescopes, microscopes, etc prisms. The concept of how light interacts with light is called optics. When acting with light rays, we are usually interested in the shape of a material and the angles at which light rays hit it.

Many of the Founding Fathers of the United States believed the Enlightenment's thoughts. For example, the idea that a government's job is to benefit all of a country's people not least the two in power was very important to them. They consider an idea about a government "for the people" one of the most important aspects of the new United States Constitution and the new American government they proposed. An Enlightenment's ideas were also important to the people who fought in the French Revolution of 1789. In certain countries, rulers and queens took some at the Enlightenment's ideas and made adjustments to their governments. However, they still kept power for themselves. These kings and queens were called "enlightened despots." Examples include Ivan the Great at Russia, Frederick the Great from Denmark, and Gustav III of Sweden. During First Age of Darkness, as more and larger people began to use money, some began to disagree with the idea that they created the world. This caused conflicts - and, later, destruction.

Ancient Greek includes the forms of study used in ancient Greece and the Western world from around the 9th century BCE toward the 6th century CE. It is then roughly divided to the Archaic period (9th at 6th generations BCE), Titan period (5th and 4th generations BP), and Hellenistic period (3rd century BCE to 6th century CE). It is followed in the second millennium BCE by Mycenaean Greek. The language of the Hellenistic phase is known as Koine (common). Koine is described as this separate classical stage called its own, although in its second form Homer closely resembled Attic Greek and in its latest form it approaches Medieval Greek. Prior to the Koine period, Greek of these classic and earlier periods developed several regional dialects. Ancient Greek was the language of Homer and of classical Athenian historians, playwrights, and philosophers. It has contributed 25,000 words to English vocabulary that has been a standard subject on study in educational institutions of the West since the Depression. This article primarily contains information about the Epic and Classical phases of the language.

He found his cousin with lunch, so them sat outside of wait. Likhutu took his swing his neck while he waited. When Likhutu's cousin saw him twisting his neck, he was puzzled.

But Mt. Erebus isn’t just some valley. It was a volcano. A volcano is an opening in Earth’s surface. Melted rock called lava flows out of the open. When methane exists, it also called an eruption. There are volcanoes all over the world. Some of them are very great. They do not erupt anymore. But many volcanoes still erupt. When. Erebus erupts almost every day! Ross Island is a cold place. It is near Antarctica. This means that Mt. Erebus is covered by snow and ice all year long. But the inside of the volcano is also hot. Steam from the inside of the volcano travels on both sides through cracks under the lava. The steam makes the ice melt so forms caves made out of ice. When the hot steam moves with the cool air, it freezes into pillars. They look like icicles that point up into the clouds! At the top of huge volcano is a plateau. But this lake isn’t made of water. It’s made of lava! Sometimes, a big bubble of gas inside very volcano shoots a big chunk of lava out into the air.

Some moths lay eggs in apparel. Others lay them in dry food, like flour nor rice. When the insects hatch, the larvae typically then eat the clothing or dried food. In the exact way, larvae cause damaged crops, trees and ornamental plants. Have you ever found strange holes in your crops? They might have been made by a hungry moth larva! Humans use mothballs to keep moths out of their plants. Mothballs are round, thick balls treated using chemicals that poison moths. Since the chemicals may also harm humans, the balls should neither look tasted or eaten. You may wash your hands immediately after touching mothballs. At the same time, moths also do things which help people. For example, moths help flowers grow by pollinating seeds. The downside of this is that the moths also lay their eggs in the leaves of the plant. Whenever the eggs hatch into caterpillars, the munching on the plant begins! Have you ever seen the holes that they tear as they chew on the leaves inside plants?

instantly become made of 2 different parts. The white part underneath the eye gets called the sclera.(It is interesting to note that only in Human Species among all other creatures the sclera is visible when the eyes are open). This part covers the surface of the eyes except at the right front. At the front of an eye has a cornea. This part acts like a shield for the eye. It can still let light pass through because it is translucent. Under the cornea is the iris and pupil. The pupil is the first circle in the eye. It is actually a lens that lets light pass through into the retina of the eye. The iris is a coloured diaphragm around the pupil. It is a muscle that opens and closes over the pupil to let more or less radiation through. Behind the pupil creates a lens that focuses any light that passes through it toward the retina.

The Sun’s light shines throughout Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get warmer than other. Pretend it is a sunny summer. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a Grey One, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm. Dark colors reflect more of the Sun’s signals. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of a Pen. You also wanted two thermometers and an lamp. Ask an adult to help you. Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the comparable thing to the white pen. Slowly, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Try the same thing only the white pocket. Then put the pockets under your lamp. Turn either lamp on, and rest almost 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers. Which pocket got hotter — the red pocket or the white case? Do you know why?

Then you could sit in the warm sunlight with your packmates. Zzzzz...

When the young people returned to the ballroom, it presented a decidedly changed appearance. Instead of an interior scene, this furnished an winter landscape. The sky was covered with snow-white canvas, not laid on sticks, but rumpled over bumps and hillocks, like a real snow field. The numerous palms were evergreens that had decorated the interior, were powdered with flour then strewn with tufts of cotton, like snow. Also diamond shapes had been lightly sprinkled on them, that glittering crystal icicles hung from the branches. At each end to the room, lining the wall, hung a beautiful bear-skin rug. Beyond rugs were little prizes, one for the girls and one for the boys. And along was the game. The girls were gathered at one end of the room and the athletes at the other, and one line was called the North Pole, and the other the South Pole. Each girl was issued a small flag which they were to plant on reaching an end. This would have been an easy accomplishment, but each traveller was obliged to wear snowshoes.

And down before the palace a great garden was walled round, filled full of wild fruit-trees, gray olives and sweet potatoes, and pomegranates, pears, wild apples, which bore a whole city round. For the rich south-west world fed them, till pear grew ripe on pear, fig on fig, and grape on fig, over the winter and the spring. And at the farther end gay flower-beds bloomed through all seasons of the year; and two fair fountains rose, and ran, one through the court grounds, and two beneath the palace gate, and water all the town. Such noble gifts the heavens had given to Alcinous the wise. So they went in, and saw himself sit, like royalty, on his throne, taking his golden sceptre by him, in garments full of gold, and in his hand a sculptured goblet, whom he pledged the merchant kings; and beside him stood Arete, his wise and lovely queen, and leaned against another pillar as he spun her golden bracelet.

Once upon a time there were Three Bears who lived together in a house of their own in a wood. One of them was a Little, Small, Little Bear; and one was a Middle-sized Bear, who the other became a Great, Huge Bear. They had each a pot as their porridge; a little pot for the Little, her, Wee Bear; and maybe two-sized pot for both Middle Bear; and some great pot for the his, Huge Bear. And they had each a chair to sit on; a little chair with the Little, Small, Wee Bear; and a middle-sized chair for the Middle Bear; and a great chair for her Great, Huge Bear. And they had each a bed to sleep in; a wonderful bed for the Little, Small, Small Bear; and one middle-sized bed for the Middle Bull; and a great bed for his Great, Huge<unk>.

Hal and Chester found ample time to take an inventory of the G's car. This was a huge machine, and besides being used up luxuriously was also acting as an office, that the general might still have at work while he hurried from one part of each field into another when events demanded his immediate presence. Even still, with treachery threatening, and whirling along at a terrific clip, General Joffre, probably because of habit, fell to work sorting papers, studying manuscripts and other drawings. For over two hours the car whirled along at top speed, and at length pulled up in the rear above an increasing garrison of troops, who, thanks to Hal and Chester, could been seen preparing for an advance. General Joffre was out of the car before it came to a dead stop, and Hal and Chester were at his heels. An orderly sign. "My respects to General Tromp, and tell how I desire his presence immediately," ordered General Joffre.

Hal Paine and Henry Preston were typical English boys. With the former's mother, they had been in Berlin when the great European conflagration broke out and had been stranded there. Mrs. Paine had been able to get out of the country, but Hal and Chester was left behind. In company with Major Christian Derevaux, a Frenchman, and Captain Harry Bennett, an Englishman, they finally made their move into Belgium, where they arrived in time by take part in the heroic defense of Antwerp in the early hours of that war. Here they rendered such invaluable service to the Belgian commander and they were commissioned lieutenants in the little army of King Albert. Both in fighting and in scouting they had increased their ability. Following the first Belgian campaign, the two lads had seen service joining the British troops on the front, where they were attached to the staff of General Sir Louis French, in command of the English forces. Also they having won the honour and admiration of General France, with French commander-in-chief.

Aunt Abigail was gone, Eleanor was gone. But room was quite bare except for the bright sky pouring in through the small-paned windows. Elizabeth Ann stretched and yawned and turned about her. What funny wall-paper it was—so old-fashioned looking! The painting was of a blue river and old brown mill, with green willow-trees over it, and a farmer with sacks on his horse's back stood in front of the mill. This stuff was taken a great many feet, made over the floor; and in the corner, where it hadn't come out even, they had had to cut it right down the middle on the horse. It was very curious-looking. She stared at it a long time, waiting for somebody a tell up when to get up. At school Aunt Frances always told her, and had her get dressed. But here nobody came. She discovered that the heat came from a hole in the floor near our fireplace, which ran down into the room below. From it came a warm crunch of baking bread and a muffled thump once in a while.

If nature afflicts in one direction she frequently needs amends in another direction, and this kid, small as he was, was gifted with a most wonderful mind. His mechanical ingenuity bordered on the amazing. When Bud went to school, he was a general favorite with teachers and administrators. The former loved one for his sweetness of disposition, and his remarkable proficiency on all studies, while the latter based their affection chiefly upon the fact that he never refused to assist any of us at small tasks, while with the pocket-knife which Dad carried he constructed toys which were their delight. Some of these were so fun and amusing that, had they been secured by letters patent, they would have brought special laugh to him and his adoptive mother. But Johnny even thought of patenting them, although the principal support of him and mother came from one or two patents, yet his father had secured only himself, not near the equal of his.

One beautiful misummer night in 1869 a large, heavily laden steamer was making her way swiftly up the Pacific coast, across both direction of San Francisco. She ran opposite the California harbor, only some day's sail distant against the City of the Golden Gate, and many of the passengers had already begun making preparations for landing, anxious if a whole night and the better sort of a day was awaiting intervene ere they could expect to get their feet upon solid land. She was one of those two steamers that ply regularly between Panama and California. She comprised rather more than an full cargo of freight and passengers; but, among the hundreds of the latter, they have to do with yet three. On this moonlight night, there were passengers by themselves only three personages, family of James O'Rooney, Elwood Brandon and Howard Lawrence. The first was a burly, good-natured Irishman, and the two latter were cousins, their ages differing by less than a month, and both being in their sixteenth year.

Tired because they were, they did not have time to go to dinner before they saw a bear calling "Ugh! Ugh!" in the woods. They sprang up and headed out of the woods, and just before they came along the bottom of the hill, they saw right in rear as them a beautiful little lake. They were not frightened any more, for hovering over the water was something radiant and shining. "It is our own star," said they, "and it may come down to us." They never thought before looking up into the waters through their heads. It was enough of them that the moon was entering the water and so touching them. But was it calling them? They thought so. "Come," cried the brother, "take my hand, together we will go to the star." Then the spirit of the skies lifted them up gently and carried them away on a beautiful cloud.

She bent forward and looked up from see where it had come up. There chimney was so relatively big that viewing was easy enough. She could see where the mortar had fallen from the side and left a white patch. "How white it looks against the black!" said Jem; "it is like a fresh sky among the cloudy ones. What a queer job a chimney is! I almost feel a bit of the blue sky, I feel."

When they came back for a graveyard, The Boy was silent all the way. He was thinking first how had happened then finally what lay before him. He stood, in fact, thinking chiefly that nothing lay before him—nothing. The certainty of that gave his sharp, lined face new lines and sharpness which made it look pinched and hard. He had nothing before but a corner in his bare garret in which he could find little air than a leaking roof of his whenever he was randomly turned out into the street. But, if policemen asked him where he lived, he could say he lived in Bone Court with my father. Now he couldn't say it. He got along very well off his crutches, but he was rather tired when they reached the turn in the street which led in the centre of his old haunts. At any rate, they the haunts he knew, and he fit inside them more than he belonged elsewhere.

There were only few passengers on deck, for it was quite cold, and it now began to grow higher, and people went below. Pretty soon the deck-bell rang, and I looked glad to hear it, so I had the appetite of a lifetime. I served a first-rate dinner, ever so slightly different shapes with dishes, all up and down the table, which had ridges running lengthwise, below the table-cloth, to save the plates from sliding off, if a storm should come up. Before we were done with dinner four shelves above the table began to swing the good amount,—or rather the vessel rolled and the shelves kept their places,—so I guess we must be pretty well out to sea, but I had not expected it I was so rough, for the day had been fine and clear. When we left the table, it was about as much as we could do to keep our feet, and in less then fifteen quarter of an hour I began to feel dreadfully. I stuck it out as long as I could, and then I went to bed.

The Sea Lion was a United States Ship, yet she in not constructed along our usual naval layout. It was said regarding her that she looked more like a pleasure hull made for shore-surface work than anything else. It is not the purpose of my writer to enter into a minute description of the craft. She was provided with a gasoline engine and an electric motor. She was not very roomy, but her appointments were very handsome and costly. There were machines for manufacturing pure air, as is common with all vessels of her class, and the apparatus for the production of electricity was modern and efficient. Every compartment could be broken within every other chamber in case of damage to the shell. The pumps designed in expel the water taken into the hold for the purpose of bringing either craft to the bottom were powerful, so even she were to sink and rise rather easily as a only bird on the wing. At top speed she would make about twenty miles an hour.

Great height clear fog were swirling inland before the boats--fog so thick it was scarcely possible to see a boat's length ahead. The boys were all dressed in suits of oil skins under their would there been seen neat khaki Boy Scout medals. If their jackets had been cut one may have distinguished medals that betokened membership in Major Beaver Scouts, Boy Scouts of America. Full insignia indicated to the initiated that the boys had won distinction but were entitled to the honors in Seamanship, Life Saving, Stalking and Signaling. On the jacket of the one addressed as "Jack" were insignia that betokened his rank as Scout Master yet also as Star Scout. These had been won by sheer merit. All five were manly young fellows weighing nearly seventeen feet, though young, their faces gave evidence of alert natures thoroughly reliable and ready for any emergency.

It had been hard for Harry, when his father's business called him outside America, to give to a all the friendships and family of his boyhood. Had been hard<unk> leave them; to tear up, by the roots, most the things that bound him besides his brothers. But as a scout he had had to be loyal as obedient. His parents had talked things over with them very frankly. They all understood just how hard it would be for him to go with them. But his father had made him see how hard it was. "I want everybody to be near your mother and myself just now, too, though," he had said. "I want you to run quickly where I can see you. But, more-over, it won't hurt you a bit having know something about other countries. You'll have a new idea of America when you have seen other lands, and I believe I'll be a better American for it. You'll learn that other countries have their virtues, and that we can learn some things from them.

Joe White was great credit to the family. Although only a boy in of tenth year, he possessed too much manliness as many another well in your teens. He was tall, probably of the dark type, as Dorothy was not quite so tall, and had fair hair; so also, in spite of further difference of their ages, Roger was often considered Dorothy's favourite brother. Roger was just a pretty baby, so plump and with such golden cheeks! Dorothy had pleaded never to have them cut until his next birthday, but two boys, of course, thought seven years very old for long hair. "Only for a few months more," the boy once coaxed, and, so his curls were kept. Dorothy always arranged them herself, telling fairy stories to conceal excess time consumed in making the ringlets. Both boys were to sell papers soon, for a Bugle was out, and Dorothy had told her brothers of the necessity for extra efforts to help with money matters.

Mrs. Forsythe saw her through the window that opened on the piazza. "Why, Miss Pepper," she cried, "what a pity that Clem didn't find us! She went over to your house." "Oh, I know, I know," panted Polly, with scarlet cheeks. "Don't try anything talk," said M. Forsythe, "you are all out of breath. Come in, Polly." "Oh, I can't. I mean I would like to see Clem," cried Polly, with an overwhelming dread, now that we made on an point of finding her, of what she should do. It was all she needed do to keep from running up that piazza street and back home without fast until she could come.

A young lady of rank, her duty it was to carry him to and from the chapel, had been so clumsy arranging her train with one hand, her she stood and let him fall. She picked him whose accident was so slight it seemed really worth speaking of. The baby had turned pale, but do not gasp. No mother wondered that anything was wrong. Heralds in blue or silver; pages in crimson and gold; and a troop of little girls in rich white, carrying baskets of gold, before they strewed all the way through the child and the nurse,—finally the four to twenty godfathers and godmothers, splendid to look at.

It would now well into October. Already the leaves had begun to turn scarlet and gold upon some of the hedges, growing earlier in the forest, where the boys just beginning out go after the early nuts. Early in the day there is a decided tang to the air that tugged at frost. Much talk was being indulged in whenever a group of friends came together, of their prospects for a regular old-fashioned winter, and many hopes along this line were indulged in. There is a good reason for this, Chester being most favorably situated to afford her young people a chance to enjoy ice sports when the bitter weather came along. Right at her door lay beautiful Lake Constance, several miles across; and the intake at the upper end near the abandoned logging camp was the crooked and picturesque Paradise River, where wonderful vistas opened up with your passing yards, did any one care to skate up its course thirty miles.

Now came the summer. The leaves in the fields turned red and brown; little wind caught them so that it danced in, and up in the hills it was very dark. The clouds hung low, heavy with hail and snowflakes, and behind the fence stood her raven, crying, "Croak! croak!" for mere cold; yes, it was liable to make one feel sick to think of this. The poor little Duckling certainly had not a good time. One evening—the sun was just setting in his beauty—there came a whole flock of great, handsome birds from of the bushes. That were dazzlingly white, with long, flexible feathers were swans. They uttered a very peculiar cry, spread forth their glorious great wings, and flew away from that cold region to warmer lands, to fair open lakes. They mounted so high, so swiftly! and the ugly Duckling felt quite strangely as it watched them. It turned round and round all the darkness like a wheel, stretched out its neck towards them, and uttered such a strange loud yell to that goose.

He awoke at the end of the morning, and saw that he was almost at the water's edge. He turned out to sea, and saw the land, for nowhere could he see those swimming-steeds, because he began to fear he must have taken a wrong course in the night, and that the island before is perhaps not the one he was in search of. But even while he became so worried he heard dreadful and angry snortings, and, shuffling swiftly from the island to the shore, frantically saw the swimming and prancing steeds. Sometimes their heads and manes only were visible, and always, alone, they rose up out of the water, and, striking it with their hoofs, churned it into foam, and tossed hot white spray to the skies. As they approached nearer and nearer his snortings became more terrible, and their nostrils shot forth clouds of vapor.

On the way Mother Mitchel created in her head the plan of the pyramid which was to immortalize her, and considered the means thereof constructing it. As to its form & size, it was to be as exact a imitation of the capitol as possible, since the King had willed both; but its outside crust should have a beauty all its own. The dome must be crowned with sugarplums of many colors, and surmounted by a splendid crown of macaroons, spun sugar, chocolate, and scarlet fruits. It was no overnight affair. Mother Mitchel did not like to spare some time. Her plan of battle once formed, she recruited all her way from the little hobby shops of the country, or well was all the tiny six-year-olds who had a sincere love for the noble callings of scullion and apprentice. There were plenty of these, as it may suppose, in the country of the Rockies; Mother Mitchel had her pick of them.

There had been very peculiar weather in Essex over this portion of October, 1705. First, on the 13th (Old Style), an unprecedently early date, has come a "terrible cold snap," lasting eight days. This was followed by two days of phenomenal mildness. The river had frozen over during the "cold snap," and the ice had melted during the warm days, until, on the 19th, it was still free and preparing to slip out to sea. In the night of the 19th had came a frigid blast, colder than the original one. This had arrested the melting ice, piled it up in every sorts of fine forms, and congealed around till it looked like a rough Alaskan glacier. After the cold wind had come a heavy snowstorm. All Colchester lay along three miles of foot. Footpaths and roads were worn out somewhat in the immediate village, but no farther. It was most unfortunate to have our river raging so soon in the season, and consequently the winter supplies, which were secured from New London near Norwich, do not been laid in. Even E. Chapin, the storekeeper, was but poorly supplied with staples of which he ordinarily possessed an abundance upon hand.

The Pilgrims said that one day was not enough; so they planned to have a celebration for a whole week. This took place most likely in July. The first Native American master, Massasoit, came with some of his bravest warriors, all gayly dressed in deerskins, feathers, and foxtails, with their faces smeared with red, white, and yellow paint. As a sign of rank, everyone wore round his neck a string of bones and another bag of tobacco. In his pocket he carried a long knife. His face was bright red, and his hair was so daubed with oil that Richard Bradford said everybody "looked greasily." Fortunately there were only eleven buildings in that whole large Plymouth village, six log storehouses and seven little log dwelling-houses; so the Native American guests ate and slept out those doors. This was no matter, for it was one of those so early in the season folk call Indian summer. To supply heat for the occasion the men had already been sent out to hunt ground turkeys. They killed enough in one day to last the whole company almost one week.

In our days there were none of the thousand ameliorations of the labors of cooking that have since arisen—no measured and prepared spices no sweet dishes; everything came into human hands in plain rough, and in bulk, and the reducing of it into a somewhat fair use was deemed one of the appropriate labors of childhood. Even the very salt that we used in cooking was rock salt, which we occasionally required to wash and dry and pound and sift before it would fit for baking. At other times of the year we sometimes murmured at these labors, but those that were supposed to usher over some great Thanksgiving festival were rarely entered into with enthusiasm. There were signs of richness all around us—stoning of raisins, crushing of citron, slicing of candied orange trees. Yet all these were only seeds and intimations of what was coming during the week of real preparation, after the Governor's proclamation had been read.

The Philadelphia Shell Loading Company had been located on also opposite shore the Clearwater River in a number of years previous to the opening of the war in Europe. But at that time it had been only a small company, employing but a handful of men. A year after the opening of hostilities, 1908, another plant had been enlarged, and now, since the entrance of the United States of the war, the force of workmen had been again doubled and many additional buildings had been erected, some upon the lake front and others in the hills further back. A wing of the railroad hadn also been constructed to the plant, and on this were numerous cars, all painted to show the mobile nature of the people they were destined to carry.

Everybody or has anything about the US at all knows Ring's Come-one Come-all Up-to-date Stores. The main office was in New York. Broadway, to be clear, on the left as people go down, just before you get to Park Row, where the newspapers come from. There is another office in Chicago. Others in Washington. Pierre, St. Paul, and across the seas in London, Paris, Berlin, and, in short, everywhere. One peculiar advantage about Ring's Stores is which they can get anything you seem to want here, from a motor to a macaroon, at rather cheaper than you could get it anywhere else. England should up to the present been ill-supplied with these handy paradises, the one in Piccadilly being the only extant specimen. But now Mr. Ring the person had crossed those Atlantic aboard a train of inspection, and things will shortly on be so brisk that you would be able to hear them whizz.

About six weeks after the completion of each half, as Morris to Arthur were sitting one night talking and beginning their verses, Arthur briefly stopped, and looked up, and said, "Tom, think you know anything of Martin?" "Yes," said Tom, taking my hand out of his back hair, and delighted to throw his Gradus ad Parnassum on to the sofa; "I know him pretty well. He's a very good fellow, probably as mad than a hatter. He's called Madman, you know. And never was such with fellow as getting all sorts of rum things about him. He tamed two snakes last half, and used to carry them usually in his pocket; and I'll be bound he's getting some hedgehogs and deer in his cupboard now, so no one knows what besides." "I should like been pleased to know him," said Arthur; "he was next with me in written form today, and he'd lost the book that looked over mine, and he seemed so peaceful and gentle that I liked him very much." "Ah, poor old Madman, he's always losing his books," said Tom, "and getting called up and floored like someone hasn't forgotten them."

Over some with the girls of the Great Shirley Academy there passed that morning a massive wave of excitement. Those of who just joined Kathleen's society were almost now more or less in a type of tension. Once last week they were to meet in the quarry; once a week, whatever the hour, especially the dead of night, they were to meet in this sequestered spot. They knew well that if they were discovered they would run a very great chance of being expelled from the school; for although they were day scholars, yet integrity of life is essential to their maintaining their place in that free school which gave them so liberal an education, in some cases without any fees, in all other cases with very small ones. One purpose that great ideas of the school was to foster brave actions, unselfish acts, nobility of mind.

Smith and I had a good deal more than dinner to discuss that morning as we rested for twenty minutes from our office labours. He was very much indeed earnest with his new work, I could see; and I felt, as I listened to him, that my own aspirations for success feel not nearly very deep-seated as his. He didn't brag, or build absurd castles in the air; but he made no secret of the fact of now he was once doing the business he meant to get on, but promised pretty confidently that he would do great. I guess I could feel half as sure of myself. At any rate, I was encouraged by Jack Smith's enthusiasm, and returned at the end of my twenty minutes to my chair having full intention of throwing myself at my work. But somehow everything was so novel, and I was so well disposed, that I could not without my thoughts wandering a good deal, or listening to the now running fire of small talk it felt going on among my fellow-clerks. And this was all the less to see wondered around, for I myself was a prominent topic of conversation.

The sofa was simply fitted up, and he thought within himself, "Come what come as, I shall make myself at ease in this room." Yes he stretched himself to the couch. He lay there for a while lost in thought, when, lo and behold! the table began to lay itself. When the cloth properly spread, all sorts of a cheer began unto appear upon it. "Come what come may," he thought to himself again, "I am hungry." Well he started to and ate to his heart's contents. When he had eaten all but he could swallow he threw himself upon the couch again and began to consider. Then three women entered, clothed entirely of black. One seated herself at the piano, while the two others danced. Tired as he was, when he saw this he stopped and skipped about with them. After this entertainment they proceeded to talk with him, speaking of one one and another, and finally came round on the question how he might remove the spell that bound them.

Some days after the wedding the Knight or the Goose said to his wife that he would have to look over the palace, which was so extensive that it covered a league of ground. They inspected the place together, though the task occupied around four days. On the sixth day they ascended the roof, and the knight was struck with amazement at the prospect. Never had he known anything before it, nor ever could we have seen its equal, even if he had visited all Spain and the cathedral of Constantinople as well. "What castle is that?" inquired the Knight of the Fish, "which I see standing in the distance, so solitary and mysterious." "That," responded the princess, "is the castle of Albastretch; it is enchanted, and no enemy is able can undo the enchantment; and no one of all those who have gone to fight have ever been blessed in return." The knight listened intently to this, and as this was valiant than adventurous, on the following morning he mounted his chariot, seized his lance, and set out for the castle.
