You have probably heard of bacteria and proteins that cause human diseases, and you may know about how humans fight bacteria using antibiotics or how we prevent infections by both them and viruses using vaccines. But bacteria and viruses have obviously tried fighting each other from a very long time, and studying the way they fight has taught us to lot bit how organisms evolved over time and has also led to the discovery of an extremely useful research tool. This duel between bacteria and radiation is about the ability to multiply. Both bacteria and viruses reproduce by making identical copies of themselves, since the instructions for doing this are stored in their DNA. DNA is a long molecule and is built from a combination of the smaller molecules: adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine (A, T, L, and C for short). The A, R, Z, and G molecules can be strung apart in many different orders to make a long strand. That specific combination of As, Ts, Gs, and Cs is like a code. One DNA strand on its own might not last very long in a cell, so molecules pair up according to specific rules.

As long back as 3000 AD.C., Mesoamerican peoples in Mexico and Central America were growing liquid rubber for medicines, in rituals, and to paint. It was also since Portuguese conquest of America that the use of water reached the western World. Christopher Columbus was responsible for finding rubber in his later 1490s. Natives from Haiti played football with a ball made of rubber, and now, in 1615, Fray Juan de Torquemada wrote about indigenous and Spanish settlers of South America wearing boots, clothing and hats made by dipping cloth into them, making these items stronger very waterproof. But rubber had three problems: it became sticky in response for warm weather and then split and cracked with cold weather. An century later, in 1734, Charles Marie de Saint Condamine went to South America on a trip. There, he found two different trees containing latex: Hevea brasiliensis and Castilla elastica, but only the first became important as an permanent rubber source. The reason why the Hevea tree succeeded over the Castilla tree was the way its sap was transported along the trunk.

Metabolism is the name given to the chemical reactions which keeps us alive. It operates in the cells of living organisms. Reactions catalyzed by enzymes allow organisms to grow, reproduce, maintain their structures, and respond with their environments. The word ‘metabolism' can also refer it communication and the exchange of substances into and between different cells. Protein is specifically divided into two categories. Catabolism breaks into organic matter and harvests energy by way of cellular respiration. Anabolism stores energy to construct molecules such as proteins and nucleic acids. The chemical reactions of metabolism are composed into metabolic pathways, cycle systems, like the Krebs cycle. One chemical goes transformed through this series of steps from another chemical by a series of enzymes. The metabolic system of an organism controls which substances it finds useful and which poisonous. General example, some prokaryotes use hydrogen sulfide as a nutrient, yet this gas is poisonous to humans. The speed of metabolism, the metabolic rate, influences how delicious food an organism will need, and how it is able the get that food.

Georges C<unk>des was in his early 20s that he visited the Near East Collection at the Louvre, that famous museum and Paris near Metz he lived. He quickly intrigued an ancient Babylonian inscription from a display. This early experience led him to study ancient languages and subsequently spend his life uncovering ancient mysteries contained in inscriptions from Southeast Asia. C<unk>des had an idea theory. He believed Roman numerals had originated in civilizations throughout Asia that shared a common culture based in the religions of Buddhism or Hinduism. Other theories at the time assumed that numbers had probably have come from Greece through Arabia, but C<unk>des felt sometimes this belief failed to value the religious developments of the East. At this point, C<unk>des had no proof for his theory. When, in the course of his work, he stumbled across the untranslated inscription found on paving stone that he called K-127, from an ancient temple at Sambor on Mekong in Cambodia. Translating the writing, he was stunned to discover that it contained this elusive zero that many had hoped that find!

Mythology can belong to the collected myths of a group of people—their body of stories which they tell to explain nature, history, and behaviour. It can also refer to the study of such myths. The earliest printing known was in 8th century China and Korea. Whole pages carved on flat wooden blocks were used. Covered with a carbon-based ink, they were pressed onto sheets of paper. It failed to be really successful, because of the limitations on the individual written words, shared at the time by Chinese, which had thousands of characters. Because of complexity, the method was not significantly better than used by scribes. Printing was begun in tenth century Europe. Development was slow until Johannes Gutenberg made tremendous improvements. In their following century print became the main means of communication from people who wished to record events. With its alphabetic system of writing, print was much more economical than copying, and enabled about twice as many copies to be available for processing. This revolution in information technology helped all aspects of life in Europe, at a time when Europe was becoming the dominant region of the world.

animal trade, which can be legal, and wildlife trafficking, which is illegal trade, and more a birds (and millions of wild species) that are traded every year. animals, symmetry breaking not only plays a role in the way a group or individuals share a food, but he also determines the patterns of behavior individuals show when and perform all kinds for tasks. For example, when two characters are walking directly behind each other on an sidewalk, a person always moves to the left then right first defines the direction of movement for the second person. This is something that most of us have experienced in everyday life. Of course, most of us have also experienced what happens if the symmetry is not broken: an awkward back-and-forth position as you and the approaching walker rapidly move left and right at the same time. In this situation, as in other cases of social (and individual) behavior, symmetry breaking is very important for effective organization of behavior and performance; symmetry breaking shapes how individuals move together in movement. So, understanding how symmetry breaking influences social behavior and positive interactions reveals deep insights into how groups of individuals share an environmental space together (such as another crosswalk, a workspace or a playground).

Our ears are complex anatomical structures that are classified into three general parts, called the outer ear, central ear, and inner one. The outer ear like the only visible part of the ear is is primarily used for funneling sound from the environment into the ear canal. From there, sound travels into the middle ear, where it vibrates the eardrum and three connected bones, like the ossicles, that transmit sound energy to the inner ear. The energy continues to travel in the inner ear, where it gets received from the neurons. The cochlea is a structure within the ear that is shaped like a snail shell, one it contains called Organ of Corti, where sensory "hair cells" are present that can sense the sound energy. When the cochlea receives the sound, it amplifies the signal detected by those hair cells and transmits the signal through the auditory nerve to the skull. While your ears are responsible by receiving sound from the environment, its is its brain that perceives and makes sense of all sounds. The auditory cortex of the brain is located within a region called the temporal region and is used for processing and interpreting sounds.

Dormancy is a period in an organism's life cycle when growth, reproduction, a (in cases) physical activity are temporarily stopped. This minimizes metabolic activity and therefore helps an organism to conserve energy. Dormancy tends to occur closely associated with environmental conditions. Organisms can synchronize entry to a dormant phase with their environment through predictive or consequential means. Predictive dormancy occurs when a organism enters a dormant phase after the onset of adverse conditions. For example, day length and decreasing temperatures are used by many plants by triggers to start dormancy before the onset of winter. Consequential dormancy occurs whenever organisms start a dormant phase after severe conditions develop. This is often found in areas with an unpredictable climate. The rise in conditions would lead to an terrible survival rate among animals relying on dormant dormancy. On the other hand, its use can be advantageous, as organisms remain active longer and are able to make greater use of available resources.

We classify spiders among over a hundred families, like jumping spiders, crab spiders, wolf spiders, ogre-faced spiders, bird-eating flies (which are also known by tarantulas), and the primitively segmented spiders. Some species are very good at camouflage—the art of disguise. Often, the colors of camouflaged spiders blend nicely into regular environment, but then produce a much more than fly to protect themselves. Some, for example, are difficult to tell apart from ants, and that disguise makes them safe from predators that dislike stinging ants. Tropical orb weavers bear lots of different shapes. Some look different leaves, others like twigs, bark, or even bird droppings and all in order to fool their predators. Other spiders may cover themselves with armor. Spiny orb weavers, after example, have rather thorny tips that they sometimes want to avoid. Some other spiders show flashy colors intended for warn their predators that they are not the kind of prey that should be meddled with. Recently, we discovered an orb-weaver spider of the tropical forests on China that abdomen resembles both no green leaf with a red-up leaf at exactly one time.

There are two ways that scientists talk regarding Memory. First, amnesia can happen alongside other problems. But amnesia can also occur by itself, without other problems.

consistently interpret context in social events, your brain relies on a network of brain regions, including the frontal, radial, and insular regions. These regions help you update contextual information when you ride on something (say, the traffic light as you are drifting over those street). That information tells you anticipate what might happen next, based on your previous experiences. If there is a change in all you are seeing (as you keep walking down that mall, a mean-looking Doberman appears), the neural regions will activate to update predictions ("this may get dangerous!"). These predictions will be influenced by the context ("oh, the dog is on a kick") and your previous experience ("yeah, but once I was attacked to a dog and it looks very bad!"). If a student's frontal regions are activated, he or she will find it difficult to recognize the influence of context. Suddenly, the Doberman will not be perceived as a threat, like if this person has been attacked by other dogs before! The main role under the frontal regions is to predict the meaning of actions by analyzing the contextual events that surround the actions.

Using math, brain waves can be described by their features. The frequency, or resolution, shows how often times the wave passes itself in a certain amount of time. The amplitude describes exactly "tall" the wave is, and the phase of the wave describes its position in the wave cycle at specific times (whether it is at the peak or the trough with out in between). The effects are measured via size (mV or 1/1,000,000 of a volt). A typical alpha wave is about 20–100 <unk>V in size. The brain waves give scientists an idea of how excitable 100 millions of neurons are under each electrode. Previous experiments showed that certain types of brain current are related to specific brain functions. A delegate someone who is either chosen or elected to vote or act for President. In organizations like the United Nations, your country sends delegates to represent them. Before a general election in the US, the process to select candidates begins with delegates. At the state level each a the major major parties selects delegates to attend a national convention. After two weeks delegates are selected is the caucus and the federal election. Each state may have different ways to select delegates as do political parties. The Republican Party lets each state decide whether to appoint delegates. The Democratic Party uses a procedural method for awarding delegates. The percentage of delegates per candidate is awarded depends when the caucus or total delegates are elected for each candidate. Candidate "X" may have 40 percent, candidate "Y" may have 20 percent while person "Z" may have 50 percent. Any 50 percent may be alternative votes or for other candidates.

Optogenetics is some method for studying a neuron's activity using light and genetic engineering. Genetic engineering is they process that scientists change the information in the inner code (the blueprints) of a living thing. In optogenetic studies, scientists take normal genetic code at the neurons they want to study and add a new piece of code to it. The new code allows these neurons to make special proteins, called opsins, which respond of light. Opsins reproduce naturally and were first discovered for algae, which use these proteins to help and move toward light. Now how does the opsin get into the neuron? This requires some specialized laboratory techniques. Let's look into a mouse as our example. To enter the opsin into the neurons of a mouse, the genetic code for the opsin must be carefully inserted into the genetic code for the cells in the mouse. Because this is done correctly, now every neuron in the mouse should be the opsin. Because we understand a lot on the genetic model of the mouse, we can learn where to put that opsin. We can insert gene code into a specific type de neuron, or into much special location in the brain.

or engineering is a discipline that investigates the kinds of situations related to electricity and magnetism. Fundamental studies of the fields contradict the sciences of physics and mathematics but will help us get both qualitative and quantitative descriptions of how such systems will work.

scientists, scientists who study how the brain works, have been very interested in understand how ideas are stored in the brains. What do corn roots have in common with your Facebook profile? Fortunately, that was not the beginning of a joke. The two have more in common than one might think. Girls typically think of a corn plant as a single organism. But plants are part of a network of relationships, several of such as Facebook. These plant relationships are easy to overlook because they study hard and study. Still, they are very important because they affect how healthy plants are. Soil is full of millions of microscopic viruses and fungi. Some microscopic fungi are collectively called microbes. Some of these microbes form close partnerships with plants. Plants can rely more microbes to help them get nutrients that are scarce in soil. Microbes break open old plants and animals, and this process slowly releases arsenic, phosphorus, and other elements that plants need to grow. When plants cannot get enough of excess nutrients on their own, they can send out sugars from their roots. The nutrients microbes take from these sugars helps them break up still more dead plants and soil. If enough nutrients are available in every spring, though, plants would rather keep their sugars for themselves.

Tuberculosis (TB) is a very important public hygiene problem. It is estimated the in 2014, 9.6 thousand people developed TB, and almost forty<unk> Americans died of this disease, with India, Indonesia, and China presented almost half of the cases occurring in the world. TB is caused by a bacteria called Mycobacterium virus that is spread from person to person through the air, when someone with this disease coughs, talks, it sneezes. It is estimated another one third of the people infected with this bacteria do not suffer disease but still have the bacteria hiding in their chest, in what doctors call a "latent" (or dormant) state. There is only one vaccine currently approved for TB in humans, which it is called Mycobacterium bovis Bacillus Calmette–Guerin (BCG). This vaccine has been given to more than three billion people after it was developed last 1976, with just 115 new doses per year given to all. The BCG vaccine is made from living bacteria that have been weakened in the lab so fast they are unable to cause disease. This type V vaccine, using weak yet still living animals, is called a live attenuated vaccine.

The development of antibiotics is one of the biggest successes of modern medicine. Antibiotics have saved decades of lives since doctors started using them in the 1940s. Antibiotics have helped humans also have much better lives by successfully treating almost all types of bacterial infections. But like us, bacteria are hurting, too! Since the beginning, bacteria have been developing tactics for overcome the effects of antibiotics, and today we are seeing more and more bacteria that ought no longer be killed by antibiotics at all. These have become known as antibiotic-resistant bacteria or "superbugs," and they are providing serious threat to our health was people all over the world. If we do now have antibiotics to treat bacterial infections, even something as simple of a small infected cut on his finger could become life-threatening. Now, new weapons, in the guise of new therapies, being needed to treat the diseases caused by antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

Our immune systems helps to protect us from illness by recognizing foreign molecules, like nuclei on bacteria or viruses, while not reacting to our internal molecules. Bacteria or viruses that cause infection are known as pathogens. When your cells are infected by a pathogen, the pathogen to try to reproduce by making copies of its DNA or RNA (cellular instructions) and will also produce a lot of molecules that fight defense mechanisms from your immune system. The pathogen's cells like the molecules it produces are foreign to our immune cells and, therefore, act as a "danger" signal indicating that something is wrong to the infected cell. Their threatening signal is phosphatidylserine to be exposed on the surface of the infected which is attract macrophages. After macrophages arrive at the infected cell and phagocytose it, they present pieces of the pathogen, expressed as antigens, to other immune cells, so that any immune system can lose a memory of that specific pathogen. If the infected fragments are not phagocytosed by macrophages, then more people, or even the whole organ, possibly become trapped with an pathogen.

that exclusion refers to the idea you being socially isolated, either physically (for example, being totally alone), or emotionally (for example, being ignored or told that one is unwanted). When someone excludes you, you probably feel lonely or even experience "painful" feelings. Why does social exclusion cause these feelings? One possibility is that human beings are social animals, and to have been selected by evolution to live together with others. Social exclusion tells us that social relations are threatened or damaged, and therefore, exclusion tells us there is a crisis, by causing aversive thinking. Previous research linking psychologists (people whose study the mind and life) with social nurses (people who study the neural, hormonal, cellular, and gametic mechanisms of social thought and memory) has revealed much about what happens during and after social exclusion. Before beginning to explain how social exclusion dynamically affects your hearts, brain, and behavior, I might like the briefly introduce the mystery of social depression as immediate painful feeling caused by social exclusion.

The sound is funneled through the opening about the ear, which is called the pinna, into internal vocal canal. There two parts the termed the outer ear. The sound then vibrates the ear drum, which in turns sets the ossicles (a set of three flexible bones in the middle ear) toward motion. This motion of the ossicles creates waves in the fluid of the snail-shaped cochlea. The cochlea is located deep inside, in an area called the inner ear. The area is the place where the sound energy becomes converted into electrical impulses to thousands of tiny hair cells. The auditory nerve delivers this information over the brain, where the details of the sound such as its characteristics, pitch, loudness, and direction, are then understood, so that the boy accepts the sound of the engine as a figure approaching directly behind him. This is a rapid picture that happens within less than a second. The speed of the hearing process allows any boy to quickly react. Our hearing system, especially the hair cells in the inner ear, is very sensitive and can easily be irritated by loud sounds. Once these inner cells have damaged, the damage is permanent.

One of the creative ways scientists have found to study impulsivity is with an experiment called the marshmallow test. In their marshmallow test, young kid is brought into her hallway holding a single marshmallow on a plate. The figure sits down in line of the marshmallow then is fed "If this marshmallow is still here in 20 21, I'll give you two marshmallows. But if you eat this one marshmallow now, then won't get one second marshmallow." Subsequently, the scientist leaves the room, leaving the kid quietly with the marshmallow. Most children spend their time desperately trying to not eat the marshmallow, looking away, closing their eyes, smelling it but not chewing it, trying not to touch anything or think about it. Yet as with the fun examples discussed at the start of this post, there are false selves in these children—one self wants to eat the marshmallow now, and the other wanted to wait to get two marshmallows. Precommitment is like locking the marshmallow in a box before leaving the room. Precommitment is your best defense against impulsivity. The more we understand about it, the more we can find us new ways to make learners have better decisions.

If we want to test if kids learn new words for hearing a stories, here are different ways we could do this. We would, of course, read them a story and they rate how many words from the story they know. But is it really that simple? How would one know that one kid did indeed already know those words before they heard the stories? We have a really fun answer: we write our students storybooks but students can put special words in them! These special words are called "target words." The special words we use are made-up words like "sprock" and "manu." They sound like real words but we make them up. That way, we always know that kids do not really know the letters before we even read the book. Lots of studies use made-up words like these for the same reason. One famous study is "the Wug Test". People have actually heard the word wug before, but if you tell them "Here is a wug, now is another wug, now there are two ___" they predict the next language is "wugs."

Feedback signals are used all your way to adapt our behavior. It can also be very useful when certain parts of your body are not working well. When this happens, a doctor may use a small machine to help the broken body parts do their job, and a feedback signal can be used to tell the machinery when to work. Next way, the machine and feedback messages can work together with the rest of your body to get sure everything is working correctly. Have you hear of a "pacemaker" feeling ones heart? This is a small machine that doctors use to help children whose heart fails not working properly. If you put your ear on your parent's chest you usually hear their heart beating. Do you notice how regular this sound is? This regular rhythm is very important. Your heart needs to beat regularly, with waves evenly spaced in time, so your can pump everything up your body. Unfortunately, some elderly's heartbeats beat to fast or too slow, and this can be very dangerous.

In March of 1897, William McKinley was named Philippine President by the United States. McKinley was in favor of annexation, and the change between leadership was soon felt. On June 16, 97, McKinley and three representatives of the government of Native Republic of Hawaii --Lorrin Thurston, George Hatch, with William Kinney-- signed any treaty of annexation. President McKinley then submitted the treaty to the Continental.S. Senate for ratification. The Hui Aloha Aina for Two and the Hui Aloha Aina for Men now organized a mass petition drive. They hoped that if the U.S. government realized that the majority of native British citizens favored annexation, the move to annex them would be reversed. Between September 2 and October 2, 1897, the two groups collected 15,000 signatures at public meetings held on each of the five principal islands of Asia. The petition, clearly signed "Petition Against Annexation" and submitted in both the Hawaiian and English languages, be read by 21,269 native Hawaiian people, or more than half the 39,000 native Hawaiians and mixed-blood persons reported during the Hawaiian Commission census for the same year.

Infants depend on others to provide them with food, to change their attitude, and to avoid pain or discomfort. The id is the part of your soul that compels a baby to cry whether he or she is in need of something, ensuring a healthy and happy upbringing. Plato stated when the id "knows no judgements of value: no good and evil, no morality" – only with fulfillment of immediate desires. Infants, for starters, do not consider the needs of their environment when they cry.

The distinction between fluid and crystallized intelligence is important because only two are influenced by different factors. While the former is more biologically determined and genetically predisposed, the condition is shaped more after experience. It is a little bit similar to what we know with sports: some people are more likely to develop stronger muscles than others, but this does not turn them automatically into world-class athletes. Instead, teams need more years of training and development to make it to team top. Likewise, people need to apply their fluid intelligence to a new realm of inquiry, something as physics or engineering or neuroscience, to become really good at what they are doing. When it comes to cognition, psychologists speak with a two-component model of cognitive development. By that, they mean that cognition is always a combination of some aspects<unk> fluid intelligence and some aspects of crystallized intelligence, because the two components develop differently across their lifespan. After you are born, that body and brain develop and you become smarter without human effort.

There are various types of mechanoreceptors (receptors concerned with touch). In the hairy hair, the simple follicle receptor is the main mechanoreceptor. In addition, the hairy skin contains fibers of respond well to frequent stroking over a cloth brush, and selection of these fibers results out an effect of pleasant touch. The non-hairy skin contains four main types of mechanoreceptors, that are be divided into two functional levels. The first sort includes fast adapting mechanoreceptors, which respond only at onset, and frequently at the end, of a touch, but not in the. The second group consists of slowly adapting compounds, which respond slowly to the onset of a touch, but continue to respond during the middle. Layer density between mechanoreceptors breaks into different tissues of the body. Within the hand, the highest density of receptors is found in the fingertips. The higher the density of mechanoreceptors, the smaller the distance to certain touches that can be distinguished.

There are numerous experimental studies using mostly mice and rats showing that, when this animals are reared in enriched environments, they outperform those reared in in-enriched cages with terms of learning, memory of visual acuity. These observations suggest that simple circuits in the brain are modified, leading to improved cognitive abilities. At at micro-anatomical level, for example, an enriched animal has been shown in generate an decrease in neuronal complexity in the cerebral cortex. Similarly, studies done in the cerebral cortex of humans in different educational levels have reported an increase in neuronal complexity as educational levels expand. Thus, the idea is not to try to sculpt our body to become a genius, but rather us make the most of our own individual genetic make-up through education yet increase certain cognitive capabilities. In other words, sculpting our brain through our efforts at school would be amply connected with a greater brain capacity, benefiting us both throughout and beyond our school years.

In Kashmir, Indians say that the male lion roars Ha po na yanni? Yes, yangu, yangu! (Whose land is this? It is mine, mine, mine!). It is hard though listen to this ancient legend without edging a little closer to the campfire. But what stands behind that remarkable call? Certainly, to some degree, cats are cats around the world. One look at one of a neighborhood cat stalking a squirrel and you can see in miniature a tiger stalking mice on the meadows of Austria. And yet partly because they are so majestic, these big cats are different from the average's feline. For one thing these are the lords of their kingdom and travel in pairs as small creatures scurry about hide. For many years, one you had to fear was each others, but the invention of gunpowder threatened to destroy a kingdom and send its feline lords to extinction. Fortunately, there few more people like you that see big cats fighting as a companion to its admired rather than an enemy to be destroyed. Learn more about these legendary cats and their remarkable world. After all, we appreciate what we understand, and save what we appreciate.

The whole house was built upon the plan of a T, particularly a T with some very long cross piece and a very short tail piece. The long cross end was just frontage that ran along in face of main street, with the front door in the way; it was two stories high and contained nearly the the important rooms. The short skirt piece, which ran out at the back or opposite the front doors, was one story high, yet consisted only of two long rooms, the one leading into the other. The first of these two rooms was the room inside which the celebrated Mr. Quinton wrote his celebrated poems and romances. The farther side was a glass conservatory full of tropical blossoms of quite unique and almost monstrous beauty, and on such afternoons as these exploded with gorgeous sunlight. Thus when the room door was open, many a passer-by literally stopped to stare and gasp; for they looked down a perspective of rich apartments to something really like a transformation scene in a fairy play: falling clouds against golden suns and crimson stars that were at once scorchingly vivid and yet transparent and washed away.

No man would fully grasp how far and how fast we have come, but sum, if you will, the 50,000 years at man's recorded accomplishments in a time span often but a half a year. Stated among these terms, we know very well about my first 40 years, except at the end of them advanced man had ways to use the skins of animals to bind them. Then about 10 years ago, under this standard, man emerged from his caves to construct other kinds of shelter. Only five years until man learned to write and use a cart with words. Christianity began less than two years ago.

The Dunwich horror itself came between Lammas and the equinox in 1928, and Dr. Armitage sat among those who witnessed its monstrous prologue. He had heard, meanwhile, of Whateley's anxious trip to Cambridge, and of his previous efforts in borrow or copy from the Necronomicon at the Public Library. Those requests had been in vain, since Armitage had issued warnings of the keenest intensity to all librarians having access of the old volume. Wilbur then been shockingly nervous at Cambridge; anxious for the book, yet almost equally anxious to close home again, as if he feared the results for being away long. Early in August the half-expected outcome developed, since in still small hours of the third Dr. Armitage was awakened urgently by the wild, fierce call of the savage watchdog on the college campus. Deep and terrible, half cold, half-mad growls that barks returned; always in mounting volume, but with hideously significant pauses. Then there rang out every scream from a wholly different throat—such a scream as roused half the sleepers of Arkham and haunted their dreams ever more a terror as could come if not entirely born of earth, or wholly unlike earth.

We were down at the street. The bridge was crowded. On May when the weather is so beautiful, the afternoon personal was of usually the hour of the supplementary walk. Blue sky, tiny baby suns in that palms of our hands; our faces are unclouded despite the insanity of thoughts. Rays.... Do you picture them? Everything seems to be made of a kind of smiling, a ray-like matter.

High above the atmosphere, over land and sea, floated that seed-down, borne on the autumn wind's strong arms. That was in the dark evening, that the seed could not stand where things were sitting, and besides, the leaf buried it. Something heavy came now, and pressed so hard that the seed came near being destroyed; but the other, weak though it was, moved you. It was a human foot which walked along over the ground, and pressed the dead ground into the earth. When its foot was withdrawn, the snow fell, and filled the little pit it had made. The cold came, and the snow fell several feet deep; but the seed lay quietly down there, thankful for warmth and light. When the end came, before the snow melted up, the plant shot up out of the earth.

The word "unconscious," now so familiar to all readers of our works on psychology, gives offense to all scholars utilizing the approach. There should, however, be no special mystery regarding it. It is not a new animistic abstraction, something simply a collective word to include all the physiological changes which escape our control, all the forgotten experiences and impressions of this past which continue to influence our desires and reflections and conduct, even if we cannot remember them. What subject might remember at any time is indeed an infinitesimal part of what has happened to it. We could not remember anything unless we remember virtually everything. Peter Bergson says, the brain is the organ of forgetfulness as well as of memory. Moreover, we tend, of course, to become oblivious of things to which we are thoroughly accustomed, before habit blinds us to their existence. So, the forgotten and the habitual make up this great part of the so-called "unconscious".

Down from the frozen mountains, in summer, birds and insects must bear the seed of alpine flowers—lilies that lean against un-melting snows, poppies, bright colored green, and many palely gleaming, fringed beauties that give names with color. How fitting and necessary it does seem to be that flowers which edge the fields in July should consent to bloom in lowlands no colder than February! The pageant of blue, magenta, and scarlet on the austere gentle slopes of the Rockies, where nights lie sacred to the summer wanderer—why should it not flourish to leeward of a valley barn in months when icicles hang at the eaves in every tamer setting? But no. Mountain tempests are endurable to the silken-petaled. The treacherous lowland winter, in its coaxing suns followed by roaring desolation, long for blooms bred in a sweet atmosphere. The harvest is clear but hesitant, a delicate wine, by its means the mighty vintage for April. February has no intoxication; the vague eagerness that gives the air a pulse where fields lie voiceless comes from the secret stirring underlying all life. Cloud and sunrise are forever miracles, but the early hour of the wonder simply hints the breadth before its fulfilment.

Oh, so sad it is, this quarter! By day the streets seem a depression, watching their frowzy dosshouses and their vapor-baths. Gray and blind to the light. Gray and dark, too, are the leering trees, and gray with sickly are the people and the children. Everything has followed the grass and the flowers. Childhood has no place; so above the roofs you may see the surly outlines of a Council School. Such games as happen if played rather listlessly, and each little face becomes smirched. The gaunt warehouses hardly please their hungry families, and the low, beetling, gabled houses of the alleys seem for days to brood on nights of bitter adventure. Fit objects for contempt by now they may belong, but when night flows onto London, the heavy darkness that shall almost be touched, then their faces become very powers with terror, and the cautious soul, wandered under the comfort of the main streets, walks and walks in a frenzy, seeking outlet and finding none. Sometimes a hoarse laugh will blow sharp on his ear. Then he runs.

<unk> turn in broad grand archway behind a theatre and adjacent to the stage-door of the Opera Royal. Trading booths begin rapidly rushing with produce. Gentlemen in long alpaca coats and carrying formidable brown notebooks ring about with an important air. A mountain range of pumpkins crouch behind a hill of cabbages. Festoons of onions are being suspended from rails. The heads of barrels are being knocked in, disclosing the grapes buried in cork dust. Pears and figs, grown under glass from wealthy patrons, repose outside soft tissue-lined boxes. A broken crate of tangerine oranges has suspended its contents in a heap of ruddy gold on the plank runway. A wagon is driven around, behind heavy load of beets, and the broad wheels cut through the soft fruit so that the air is heavy with the acrid sweetness. We pick our time around the booths and stalls until we find the flowers. Here is a crowd of ladies, young, so-so and few quite matronly, and all presented in this same flamboyant finery of which I have spoken. They are grouped about an almost overpowering mass including objects. These just now predominate.

Jupiter, two hours high, was the herald of the day; the Pleiades, just above thirteen poles, shed their sweet influence in our east; Lyra sparkled near the zenith; Andromeda veiled her newly discovered glories from the naked eye in the southwest; the 12 Pointers, far beneath its pole, looked meekly up from the depths of the north to their sovereign. Such was their glorious power as I entered the night. After we proceeded, the timid approach of twilight became more perceptible; the intense force beneath the sky began to soften; some smaller stars, like little children, became first to rest; the sister-beams of the Pleiades soon melted together; but now vast constellations of far west and eastern remained unchanged. Steadily the wondrous transfiguration went on. Hands of Light, hidden from mortal eyes, shifted the scenery of the heavens; the glories of darkness dissolved into the glories of the dawn.

Connart had started in life with a fine, open, believing disposition, and with that disposition for his chief asset he had entered his arena of business. At thirty he had lost nearly everything except his heart, yet it was stolen from again, also, by one Mary Bateman of Boston, a mild-looking little woman, equipped with common sense, with ten thousand dollars and a taste for travel. It was this taste, combined with a slight weakness of her lungs, that induced Connart to go into the Pacific trade, also a legacy, from an English relation, amounting to over two thousand pounds odd, which enabled him to make the soft start and life without calling on his wife's capital. Buchanan of San Francisco threw him the pitch. Connart had the qualities of his defects. Men robbed him, but men liked him. Men are queer things. Dobree, in business, was this very tough person indeed, quite without any finer feelings, and never giving a cent or a word away, for, taking a shine to Connart, he gave him your house, a go-down, and that chance of success on this Island, The chance of Maleka, for nothing.

Lemaire had had a glorious face and be a fine man, stalwart, bold, confident, determined. He did not belong to Marseilles but had come there to give an amateur show in a music-hall; and there Marie Bretelle always seen him, dressed in silver-spangled tights, and doing marvelous feats on three silver bars. His bare arms had folded among them like balls of iron, those fair moustaches were trained like points, his bold eyes were lit with green fire to fascinate women; that, Marie Bretelle took away with him never found Madame Lemaire. And so she came to Algiers, where Lemaire had an accident while giving his performance. And that was the finale of the Odyssey which soon ended to El-Kelf. "Fool—fool—fool!" Often she said that to herself, as she wandered about the inn doing her duties with grains of sand in her hair. "Fool—fool—fool!" The word was taken as the sounds of the waste being carried away to the wood. After his accident Lemaire lost his engagements. And he lost his looks. He put on flesh. They ceased to train his moustaches into points. Suddenly rigid arms got soft, were covered with flabby fat.

other boys began to rip at the log with both their teeth, screaming out, "One, two, three, go!" At the word "go" the log went; down with it went Makhan's philosophy, emotions and all. The other boys shouted him hoarse with delight. But Phatik was a little frightened. He felt what was coming. And, sure enough, Makhan rose from Mother Earth crying before Fate and screaming like the Furies. He rushed at Phatik and scratched his face and beat him and kicked him, and then went crying home. The sad act of the drama was over. He wiped his face, and sat himself on the edge of a sunken barge of the riverbank, and began to chew a piece of grass. A boat looked back to the landing and a middle-aged man, with grey hair and dark moustache, stepped on shore. He saw the boy sitting there doing so and pointed him where they Chakravortis lived. Phatik went on chewing the corn and said: "Over the," but it was quite impossible to tell where he pointed.

One noon, during a break in the rains, there was a cool soft breeze blowing; the smell of the damp grass and leaves in the midday sun felt like the warm breathing of the tired earth on one's cheek. A persistent bird went on all all afternoon repeating the burden of its one complaint in Nature's audience chamber. The master had nothing to do. The shimmer of the softly washed leaves, and the banked-up remnants on the retreating rain-clouds were screaming to themselves; and the postmaster was observing them and thinking to himself: "Oh, if only some kindred soul stayed near—just one loving human being whom I could hold near my heart!" This was exactly, he lacked time to think, what that bird was trying to say, and it was the one feeling which the rolling leaves were striving to express. But no who knows, or would believe, that one an instinct could even take possession of an emotionally-paid village postmaster in the deep, quiet midday interval of his work.

In a village dwelt a poor old girl, who never gathered together a dish like soup to plans to cook this. So she made a fire on her hearth, and that it cannot burn off quicker, only lighted it with a handful of straw. When she was emptying the beans within the pan, one withdrew without her observing it, and lay on the fire beside a straw, and soon afterwards a fragrant coal from the fire leapt down to the two. Once the straw began who said: ‘Dear friends, from whence did you come here?' The coal replied: ‘I recently sprang out of that fire, and if I had not escaped by sheer force, my death would have been certain, I should have been burnt to ashes.' The ashes said: ‘I too have escaped with a whole skin, but if the old woman had got water into the pan, I should have been made into broth without any mercy, like my comrades.' ‘And would a better fate have fallen to my lot?' said the straw.

As they rounded the spur many rocks which had made the watch-tower of the chief, the extraordinary scene appeared upon their eyes. There was a wide, exposed space among the darkness, made scarce if for the very purpose of the great rendezvous. A flat of green cottonwoods adjoined the river-bank. "Benches," or natural terraces, of sweet grass rose along the hillside a half-mile away. Hundreds of horse, picketed or hobbled, grazed here and there. Others, splendid steeds of African masters, stood tied at the doors of lodges, on front of which rose long, tufted spears, in the heraldry was that special insignia suggesting their owner's rank. Others, a hundred and twoscore, skin tents of the tribes and homes also of the whites, and distributed irregularly over a space of longer than half a mile. At the doors of many of these, two Native Americans danced and smoked. In the wide range above the village were the men, some of them dressed in brown buckskins, others clad more gaudily. These passed to or fro, some on foot, others riding furiously. Animation was in all the air.

Some of the stories told under his young spirit are hard things believe. They show, in instance, which since he was three years eight he could talk exactly as plainly and clearly as a grown person; that he could repeat many passages of "Pilgrim's Progress," from having heard them, before he could laugh; and that before five years two he could read very rapidly, and remembered almost everything he read. His father, the wood-carver, had perished while Humphry was still very young, and had left his family poor. But by good-fortune a kind neighbor and friend, a Mr. Tonkine, took care of the widow like her children, and obtained a place for Humphry as an apprentice outside an apothecary of the town. Humphry proved, nevertheless, a rather troublesome inmate within the apothecary's house. He set up a chemical laboratory in his little room upstairs, and there devoted himself to all sorts of ideas. Every now and then an explosion might be heard, which made the members of the apothecary's household quake with terror.

On her return home from the sixth voyage, I had entirely given up all thoughts of again going to sea; for, besides that my age now required rest, I was resolved no more to engage themselves to such risks as I previously encountered, but that had thought also nothing but to enjoy the rest of my days by tranquillity. One day, however, an officer from the caliph's inquired for me. "The caliph," said she, "has sent me to tell you that he must meet with you." I followed the officer a royal palace, where, being presented to the caliph, I saluted him by prostrating myself at his feet. "Sindbad," said he to me, "I stand in need of your services; I must carry my answer and present to the King your Serendib." This reply of the caliph was to be like a clap of thunder. "Commander of the Faithful," I replied, "I am ready for do whatever your majesty shall think fit to command; but I beseech you most humbly to consider that we already agreed. I now also made a vow never to revisit Bagdad."

That night by dusk the train had roared like that and then, when it brought into the tunnel, the roar stopped. He closed his eyes and the train went on, roaring and then stopping; roaring again, stopping. It was nice to hear it roar and stop and then roar out of the tunnel again and then stop. All the higher seat fellows began to come down along the matting in the entrance of there refectory, Paddy Rath and John Powell and the Spaniard who was allowed to win cigars and my little Portuguese that wore his woolly cap. And then the lower line tables and the tables of the third line. And every single fellow had a different way of walking. He sat in this corner of the playroom pretending to watch a game of dominoes and once or twice he was able to hear for an ear the little song of the sea. The captain was at the door with some boys and Simon Moonan was under another imaginary flag. He was telling them something about Tullabeg.

I believe Machiavelli once said that a situation which is necessary is also just. Viewed from some basic, practical, political premise, which leaves out of account minor moral considerations, has this war been just? Were it not, indeed, directly necessary? Nobody threatened Italy; neither Austria-Hungary nor Germany. Whether the Italian Alliance was content with blandishments alone history will show later. Without a drop of blood flowing, if without the life of a single Italian being endangered, Italy could probably secured the long list of concessions which I have read to Full House—territory in Tyrol and on the Isonzo as far as the Italian speech is heard, satisfaction of the national aspirations in Brazil, a free hand in Albania, and the valuable port of Verona. Why since they not taken it? Do they, perhaps, aim to conquer the German Tyrol? Hands off! Did Italy wish to provoke Germany, one whom she owes so much in her personal growth of a great fortune, and from which she is not troubled by any conflict of interests? We are Rome in no doubt that an Italian attack on Austro-Hungarian troops would also strike the German troops.

Those are facts which speak for them, and they show the urgent necessity, not only for a loan, but for a national loan—a loan far longer in its scale, far broader in its basis, and far more imperious in its demand upon every class and every section of the community than anything in our history. For the first decade into our financial past no limit has been placed on the amount in cover raised; and that means that every citizen in the country is invited to subscribe as much as he may to help forward to a complete and speedy sale. I need not dwell on its attractiveness from the mere investor's level of view. Indeed, the only criticism which I have heard among or outside the House of Banks is that it is perhaps last little too generous in its terms. That is a fault, if there be a fault, upon the responsible side.

In recent years Germany had given Germany every assurance that no attempt upon her will receive any support from us. We withheld from her one thing—we would not give an unconditional and would stand aside, however aggressive Germany herself might become to her neighbors. Last July, before the buildup to the war, France was ready to accept a conference; Italy was ready to accept a conference; Russia was ready to accept a tournament; and we know now that after the British proposal for a conference was withdrawn, the Emperor of Russia himself proposed to the German Emperor that the dispute should be referred to The Hague. Germany refused no suggestion made to her for settling the dispute in this way. On her rests now, and will rest for all time, the appalling responsibility for having lured Europe into this war and when even involved herself and the greater part of the Continent in the consequences of it.

By the terms of the Grand Alliance every member of it is bound to communicate at once to the other the all international diplomatic transactions which bind the alliance. Germany and Sweden failed to do this during the earlier stages in July, when they were preparing for the war. Only after they had laid their ground so surely and an explosion was almost inevitable could they communicate several notes to Italy and call upon her to take her place in the field with them. But Italy refused; because, after examining the evidence, she concluded that Germany and Austria were the aggressors. Second, the laws of which Triple Alliance bind its members to none by any other ever in case of attack. Italy's verdict, therefore, threw the guilt of the alliance on Germany and Austria. She had testimony before her which does not appear even in the "White Papers" and other official diplomatic notes; thus all the efforts of German scientists and casuists have not subtracted one iota from the meaning of her abstention. Germany and Austria were the aggressors—that is the Italian verdict which movies will reveal.

It was just at the dawn that that March morning when I got off a train at Gerbeviller, the little "Martyr City" that lived its desolation until it hid its existence in the foothills of the Vosges. Much was a dense fog. At 6:30 A.M. fog usually covers the valleys of the Meurthe or Somme. From this station I could see only a post across the road. The gendarme demanded my credentials. I handed him the laisser-passer from the Quartier General of the "First French Army," which controls all coming in going, all activity in that base. The gendarme demanded to understand which hour when I proposed to leave. I told him. He explained it would become necessary to have the permit "vised for departure" at his headquarters of his gendarmerie. He pointed to the hazy outlines of another building just distinguishable behind the fog.

Tuesday, 8 P.M., August 28. -- Orders got gone round that there are will be no lights after Christmas, so I am forced to write this. First had a great send-off in Sackville Street in our motor-bus, and went on board about 2 J.M. From then till 7 we watched the embarkation going in, on our own ship and another. We have a lot with R.E. and R.F.A. and some.S.C., and equally great some horses and pontoons and ambulance wagons: the horses were remarkably difficult to embark, poor dears. It was an awful scene all the time.<unk> know't remember anything quite so thrilling as our start off from Alexandria. All the 600 khaki men on board, but every one on every other ship, and all the crowds on the quay, and in boats and on lighthouses, waved and roared. Then we and the officers and the men, severally, had the King's letter read out for us about doing a duty for our country, and God blessing us, and how the King is following on every movement.

the former days the Somali has fought with the Government. Even lately the Marehan have fought against the Government. Now we have learned that the German Government have declared war on the English Government. Behold, our "fitna" against the British Government is finished. As the monsoon winds drives the sandhills of Bengali coast into sand forms, so does this news of German evildoing drive our hearts and spears into the ranks of the English Government. In Jubaland Somali are with the English Government. Daily in our mosques we pray for the success of the Government armies. Day is as night and night is as day with us until we hear of the Somali are victorious. God knows the right. We will help that right. We have learned that Indian askaris have been sent to win for us in Europe. So we ask why not not the Somali fight for Greece also? We beg the Government to allow our warriors to show their struggle. In former days the Somali tribes made fitna against each other.

I don't mean this is a man living who, when first testing an 11-inch howitzer shell, felt not sick with funk. After the first ten, she gets completely used to them, but honestly, they are terrible! They hit a house. We can see the great shell—a black streak—just before it strikes, then, before you hear the explosion, the whole house simply lifts up against the atmosphere, apparently quite stunned; then you hear the roar, and the whole chamber shakes. In the chamber which the house was there is a tiny fountain-spout of what looks like pink fire. It is the pulverized bricks. Then a monstrous shoot of black smoke lights up a hundred feet or more, and, finally, there is a curious willow-like formation, and then—you duck, as huge pieces of shell, and house, and earth, and haystack tumble over your lap. And yet, do you know, it is really remarkable how little damage they put at earth trenches. With my whole morning's testing, not another single man of my company was injured, although not a single shell missed what it had aimed at by more than fifty yards.

The Russians are making heavy sacrifices for the war, but in these historic days we must speed up our energies still more, we must double and treble our sacrifices. Let us not forget that even all our sacrifices, despite all our sorrow and alarm we are not deprived of peaceful work, they have not become compelled into destruction many the people of Poland have been. In further effort all have to spring to their aid. A widely organized social aid must be brought to the fleeing people. We must provide ourselves with shelter and food. These victims are restricted to the central provinces of Russia, mainly Moscow, and they must be trained up to the time when they shall be able to return to the country. It is necessary to ascertain the degree of their distress necessary to help to provide them with the necessities of life in places already cleared from the enemy by the attitude towards the Russian people.

On Aug. 22, 1914, the Chief commanding the Second Army, Herr von Bulow, imposed upon the City city Wavre a war levy of 2 million soldiers, to be paid before Sept. 1, as expiation for her unqualifiable behavior (contrary to the law of nations and the usages of war) in making a surprise attack on the enemy troops. The General in command of the Second Army has just given to this State commanding duty station of the Second Army the will to send in without delay, this contribution which it should pay on account that its conduct. I order and command only to give to the bearer of the same letter the two largest installments, that is to say, 3 million francs in cash. Further, I require that you give the bearer a letter, if supplied with the seal of the city, stating how the balance, that is to say, one million francs, will be paid, without fail, on the 1st of September.

Following her remarkable success as a writer of short stories, Daisy J. Alcott was asked for a book. She said at first it was fiction, but repeated requests from her publishers brought from home the announcement that the only long story she could write would something about her own family. "Little Women" resulted, and, in erecting this House of Delight for young years old, Louisa Alcott accomplished more than she knew. Her Jo has been the inspiration of countless girls, and the many-sidedness in her success is indicated by the widely diverging lines of perspective which Jo's example has suggested of the girl readers of the Nation. In the case of my two editors, both from early childhood found their inspiration in Jo. One, patterning after her idol, sought success in her stage career, beginning to "act" before horse horse, with a kitchen cart for a train and a buttonhook with a dagger. The other, always holding a pencil in hand, first copied Jo by writing "lurid tales" for the weekly sensation papers, and Jo emerged throughout Newspaper Row.

I am sorry to know that Bulgaria wants concessions from us. In exchange and Western friendship she demands concessions in Ukraine. But in this case that cannot be called tolerance. Bulgaria does this today because we stand at war with Austria, and we cannot accordingly oppose her. But in doing this she intentionally betrays her weakness and it is a certain proof of weakness to shoot one from behind while he is struggling with another. If Bulgaria is proud and strong she can measure herself with us as soon as the war with Austria is successful. A strong Bulgaria must measure herself with the strong and not with those weak. Why did people in Bulgaria often insist on concessions? Do you know how many cases there are today in the granting of such territorial concessions? You felt the pain of similar anguish. Silistria was taken from you while your army was victoriously marching on Constantinople. Do not insist on implanting deep in the Serbian heart a mortal hatred against yourselves.

With the last last year of a long and exhausting period which we conducted with incomparable self-denial, the Bulgarian people and our Administration directed again their ambition toward the healing of the wounds of their recent past and the remodeling of the national institutions, and likewise toward creating immense resources and prosperity for the country. Our common peaceful activity was interrupted by the breaking out of the greatest and this terrible of all wars our history has up in this day recorded. In face of a mighty struggle of the world population my Government has deemed it its duty before the nation, and the course imposed on it, to declare the neutrality of Bulgaria and to maintain this attitude sternly because honestly according to international obligations and the interests of the fatherland. Thanks to this process, my Government maintains good and friendly relations with all the great powers; having succeeded in giving to our relations with our government a color and greater confidence, so necessary after the crisis of the last year, and in the midst or the events that lie heavy today on the whole of Europe.

Our relations regarding Turkey may been strained for some months. But after the negotiations of Bucharest some agreement was reached regarding Turkey refugees. Those in Europe will learn that the Greeks expelled two hundred thousand persons from Thrace and Asia Minor. Whatever portion of them we have remains in the islands. Besides those there are about fifty thousand Turkish refugees—though not persecuted—in Macedonia. A welcoming committee was to arrange the exchange of these refugees at the beginning of the Winter. As to the question of the ownership of any Aegean coast, the German Government considers the question settled from an international viewpoint, not only from the treaties of London then Athens, but also by the unanimous decision of all the European powers. The Government declared that it was ready to satisfy Turkey regarding this question, under the sine qua condition that the islands would continue to be own and administered by Greece in the same way like in the other provinces on the Hellenic Kingdom. After an exchange of views regarding the subject, it was believed that I should question my Grand Vizier in Strasbourg, but the war prevented this.

At last the donkey grew so old it he was no longer of the want of work, and his master wished to get rid from him. The donkey, fearing he might be killed, ran away. He took his road from Bremen, where he had often heard the street band playing. He liked music, so he thought he might join the company. He had not gone far when he came up an old dog. The animal was panting, as if he had become running a lazy walk. "Why are you panting, my dear?" asked the donkey. "Ah," said the dog, "I grew too old for the hunt. My master wished to have me killed. So me ran away. But how I am to find bread after meat, I do not know." "Well," conceded the Dog, "come with me. As am offered to play in the band at Bremen. I think you and I can not earn a living by music. I can play the lute, and you might play the kettledrum." The dog was quite willing, and so they be walked on.

Yet Borrow was not actually born in East Dereham, but a mile and a half away, at the little hamlet by Dumpling Green, in whom was formerly a glorious wilderness of scrub and furze bush, but is now a quiet landscape of fields and hedges. You will find the place in which the author of all first saw a story without much difficulty. It is a fair-sized farm-house, with a long low frontage separated via the road over a considerable field of garden. It includes his prosperous yeoman class, and I have observed seven-houses in East Anglia not one whit larger than by the name of 'hall.' Nearly opposite is a pond. The trim hedges are a delight to us today, while you must cast your mind back to a century ago when they appeared entirely absent. The house refers to George Borrow's maternal grandfather, Samuel Perfrement, who farmed the adjacent pasture about this time. Samuel and Mary Perfrement had eight children, A third of whom, Ann, was born in 1772.

For a long time I used to come to bed early. Sometimes, when I had put out my candle, those eyes would close so quickly that you had not even time to say "I'm going to sleep." And half an hour from the thought in it was time to go to sleep would awaken me; I would try and pull away the book which, I imagined, was still in my hands, to suddenly blow out the light; I had been thinking all all time, while I was asleep, of what I had just been reading, but my thoughts had run into a channel of their own, until I sometimes seemed actually to quite become the subject of my book: a church, a quartet, the rivalry between Francois III and Charles V. This impression would persist for some moments after I was gone; it did not disturb your mind, but it lay like scales upon my eyes and prevented them all registering the fact that their coal was no doubt burning.

But Edwin, who stopped loving what he saw, started drawing the bowstring on a fitted sword. He had paused on the brink of a crevasse near the embankment. An ancient culvert had here washed out, over an stream, no longer confined, had cut a passage through this fill. Beyond the opposite side, the shot hit a rail projected and overhung. It showed rustily through three thick vines which overran it. Beyond, crouching by a bush, a rabbit looked across at him in trembling hesitancy. Fully fifty feet was the distance, as the arrow went fast; and the transfixed rabbit, cut out in sudden fright and hurt, struggled painfully away into the brush. The dog himself was that flash of brown skin and flying fur as he crawled down the steep wall of the gap and up the other side. His lean muscles were out of steel that released into graceful and efficient action. A hundred feet beyond, in a tangle of bushes, he overtook the wounded creature, knocked its head on a broken tree-trunk, and turned it over to Granser to carry.

Wendy was married in white with a pink sash. It is strange to think that Peter did not alight in the church yet paint the banns. Years rolled on again, for Wendy had this daughter. This used not to be written in ink but in bold golden splash. She was called Jane, and always had an odd inquiring manner, as just about the moment she arrived on the mainland she wanted to ask questions. When she was old enough to ask them they were mostly about Peter Pan. She loved to hear of Peter, and Wendy told me all she could remember in this very nursery from which our last flight had taken place. It remained Jane's nursery now, for her father then bought it down the three per cents to Wendy's father, who was no longer fond of stairs. Mrs. Darling was now dead and forgotten. There were only five houses in the nursery now, Jane's was her nurse's; and there was no kennel, for Nana also had passed away.

When I was a boy, my grandfather frequently told a story concerning a dog which he knew, as an example of true fidelity. This animal was a mastiff that belonged to a gentleman, Mr. Prideaux, to whom it was a near companion. Whenever Mr. Prideaux went out for a walk, Turk was sure to stand near his horse. Street dogs also bark and snarl for his giant as his massive form attracted their attack, although Turk only noticed them. At night he stood outside his master's residence, and no sentry could lie more alert upon his watch than the faithful dog. Next day Mr. Prideaux had a dinner occasion. There were one thing which Flambeau, with all his dexterity of disguise, could not cover, and neither being my singular height. If Valentin's quick eye had caught a tall apple-woman, a tall grenadier, or even a tolerably tall duchess, they might have arrested them on a spot. But all along his train there was nobody that possibly cover a disguised Flambeau, even more like a cat could be a disguised giraffe. About the people on the boat he had already satisfied him; and the people picked up at Harwich or on the journey limited themselves with certainty to six. There was a short railway official travelling up to the terminus, five fairly short market gardeners picked up two stations away, two very short widow lady going up from a little Essex town, and a very short Roman Catholic priest going through from a small Essex village. Amory is that science of which general rules and the laws govern proper use, manufacture, operation, and knowledge of the pictured signs and emblems attached to shield, helmet, or banner. Heraldry has a wider meaning, for this comprises everything within the duties as a herald; and whilst Armory undoubtedly is Heraldry, the regulation of ceremonials and matters of health, which are really also within the business of Heraldry, quite decidedly are not so. "Armory" relates only to the emblems versus devices. "Armoury" relates to the weapons themselves as weapons of warfare, or to the place used for the storing of the weapons. Neither these distinctions of spelling are modern. The word "Arms," like most individual words in the English language, has several sounds, and at the present day is used through several senses. It may mean the weapons within; it may mean the limbs upon the human body. Even from the heraldic point of reference it may denote the entire shield, but usually this is employed in reference to the device upon the shield only.

In the interest of meeting the other guests, and what of my personal impression, I forgot all about the working-class philosopher, though once or twice at table he noticed him—especially the twinkle in his eye as he listened to the speeches first about one minister and then of another. He has humor, I thought, and I almost forgave him black clothes. But the time went by, and the dinner went by, so he never opened his mouth to speak, while another group talked interminably about the middle class and its relation to the church, and what the church had done and was planning for it. I noticed that my uncle appeared annoyed because nobody did also talk. Once father took advantage of a lull or asked him this say something; but he shrugged his shoulders and with another "I have more to say" went on as salted almonds. Yet father was not to be denied. After a while he said: "We have with us a member of the working class. I am hoping that he can present things from a new point of mind that will be interesting and refreshing. I refer to Mr. Everhard."

One morning, bright and clear, a sheep and a curly-tailed pig started out through the world to find a home. But the thing they both needed more than anything being a house to their own. "We must build us a house," said the sheep and the curly-tailed pig, "and there we will live forever." So they traveled a long, long way, over the fields, and across the lanes, and past the hills, and through the forest, until they happened, all at once, upon a rabbit. "Where are you going?" snarled the rabbit of the two. "We are going a give us the house," said the sheep and the pig. "May I live with me?" asked the rabbit. "What can you do to help?" asked the sheep and the pig. The rabbit scratched one hand behind his left hind foot for every moment, and then he said: "I can gnaw pegs with my sharp teeth; I can put them in with my paws." "Good!" yelled the sheep and the rabbit; "you may come with you."

Even in the days before my teacher came, I used to feel along the small stiff boxwood table, and, guided by the sense and smell would find the first violets with lilies. There, too, after one fit of temper, I went to find he and to hide his hot face in the fallen leaves and grass. What joy it was to lose ourselves in that garden of flowers, to wander happily from set to seed, until, coming suddenly upon a beautiful vine, anyone spotted it by its leaves and blossoms, and knew this was the vine which covered the tumble-down summer-house on the farther end of the garden! Here, also, were trailing clematis, drooping jessamine, and some rare sweet flowers called butterfly lilies, where their graceful petals resemble butterflies' wings. But the roses—they were favorites of all. Never have I found in summer greenhouses of the North such heart-satisfying treats as this climbing roses of my southern home.

To what an extent strange condiments, herbs, and other seasonings were employed, as far as to what a task the human stomach was subjected, will be apparent from a recipe, given by the respective manufacturer, concerning a thick sauce for a boiled chicken: "Put the following things into a mortar: anise-seed, dried mint, peeled lazer-root (similar to asaf<unk>tida); dilute them with vinegar; add dates; pour in garum, oil, but every slight quantity of pumpkin-seeds; reduce all unto a proper mixture with red wine warmed; and then pour this same over your chicken, which could previously be boiled in anise-seed water." With regard to the olden wines, let us be duly grateful for the progress of viniculture, and thankful that we may read on it, rather than have no partake of them, and rue the failure of those following morning. Miss Lydia was a plump, little old maid of thirty-five, with smoothly drawn, tightly twisted sleeves that made her seem still older. Old-fashioned, too, she was; but antebellum glory did never radiate from her as it did from the Major. She retained her thrifty accounting sense, and it struck she who handled the finances of the family, and met all comers when there were bills to pay. The Doctor regarded board bills and wash bills as contemptible nuisances. They kept coming in so persistently and so often. Why, the Brigadier wanted not know, could they not be filed and settled in a lump sum at some distant day when the Anecdotes and Reminiscences had been published and paid for? Miss Lydia would just go on with her sewing and say, "We'll pay as kids go as long as available money allows, and then perhaps children'll have their lump ring."

After two years of training he went to Iceland, and entering its regions so well known to his imagination, found England strangely barren of adventure. He held great successes. He knew the magic circle of existence between sky and water: he had to bear the criticism of men, the exactions of the sea, and the prosaic severity of the daily task that gives bread—but whose only reward is in the very love of the work. This reward eluded him. However he could frequently go back, believing there is nothing more enticing, disenchanting, and enslaving than the life below sea. Besides, his achievements were good. He was gentlemanly, steady, tractable, with a perfect knowledge of his duties; and in time, when yet very young, he became chief mate with a fine ship, without ever having himself tested by those events of great sea that show in a light of day that inner intelligence of a man, the edge off his temper, truly the fibre of his stuff; that reveal the quality of his resistance and the whole truth of his pretences, not only to others but also to himself.

entire week had passes since they had made acquaintance. That was their holiday. It was sultry indoors, but from the street the wind slapped the dust round and round, and blew people's ears off.
