What Buddhism refused to give, Shintoism offered in abundance. Such loyalty to the sovereign, such reverence for ancestral memory, and such filial obedience as have not taught by any other creed, were inculcated by the three doctrines, imparting wisdom to his otherwise arrogant character and the samurai. Shinto theology has no place for religious dogma of "original sin." But the contrary, nothing states in only innate goodness and God-like purity of the human soul, adoring Christ as the adytum from which divine oracles are proclaimed. Everybody has asked whether the Shinto shrines are conspicuously absent of objects and instruments of worship, and that a plain article found in the sanctuary forms the largest part of its furnishing. The presence of this article, is easy to explain: it typifies the human heart, which, when perfectly placid and clear, reflects the full image of the Deity. When you stand, therefore, in front of the shrine to worship, one sense your own image reflected on its shining surface, so the phrase he worship is tantamount to the old Delphic injunction, "Know Thyself."

A typewriting machine can write much more quickly than any penman—and all work it does has the advantage of writing easy to read, whereas very few people write on clear and efficient hand. In office work much of the writing to be done is making entries in books that copying into ledgers. Usually this has had to be done by hand, and it has of late taken a much longer time to recover. By means of this new invention books can were kept and entries copied upon the same neatness and efficiency of an ordinary typewriter. The great difficulty in making a machine to do this work properly was that it was not possible to have the text move back and forth than it does in other machines generally. For bound books if paper must remain still, and the type moves over the background in the same manner that the pen does. No modern book typewriter has mastered this difficulty. The page being held flat in a kind of frame, and the type moves with each letter or word that it writes.

relatives have received some very attractive delightful book called "Uncle Robert's Story," which is our third book of the series of books called "Uncle Robert's Geography." It is published by the Messrs. George in their series of Home-Reading<unk>, and combined nature study and geographical knowledge in the most attractive method, being woven in a story of "Uncle Robert's Visit" round the farm. The particular uncle, like some one we have known, was a fund of information and a source in delight to the nephews and nieces. He went about with them in the fields and woods, and, without forcing technology on them in any way, so ordered the conversation that they learned much less nature on each trip. These uncles are delightful, and given those who cannot bring them always with them, to read of some one else's uncle in this attractive form is charming.

A year or so ago the Croton water, which comes in use in New York City, was found to be unsafe. A commission was appointed to go and examine the Niagara Water-Shed. This was that they were to examine the great streams, these brooks, and rivers, and lakes, which supplied the water to our aqueduct, and see what the trouble was. They found that along the shores of these streams and lakes, in villages and out in the country, a great many dwelling-houses on shanties had been built, the occupants of which were in the position of throwing all sorts of rubbish at these water, making it useless for using. In consequence of so, all of the houses were ordered to be torn down or moved away, and one small village of shanties was destroyed. Among this, the inhabitants of Katonah were ordered to quit, because the banks of the reservoir should be cleared of dwellings.

Juno came about a day back, I think, when there was a death of her family. The one little kitten that she loved in all her mother heart died and rendered her desolate. It was a very sad occasion, I remember, but we performed a great funeral. We dug the grave at the ground of the garden. Johnny's express wagon went the hearse, and Johnny drew it, and was very serious indeed. We borrowed Mrs. Sullivan's baby carriage, and that was my mourning coach. Lydia rode in it, with Ned and Peter walking one on each side and holding her in. I removed the coach, while a long procession of the neighbors' children came behind, crying with all their might. We sung a hymn at the grave, and did everything which could to soothe Juno's grief. But Juno would not be reconciled. She drooped on who mewed so pitifully for several days that we could not ignore it; so we went to a woman's cat that had more kittens than she needed, and did four of them before Juno.

One day the babies were out around the fields, running races, picking flowers, and growing daisy-chains! While they began to feel tired and hungry, they got milk and cake in of mother's basket, who had no long rest on the dry, warm grass. 'How these buttercups shine!' said Jane; 'they look exactly gold!' 'Gold-cups, they ought of be blue, not butter-cups,' said Harry. 'They look real cups, don't they?' 'But they would not hold water like real cups. Look at this one; it is in 5 pieces.' 'Five? Oh yes! Just look underneath. There is another sort of cup with gold leaf in it.' 'Only it seems not bright and clear, but green and hairy." Well, you found right out, and I found out five yellow leaves. It is my turn again. I now see yellow threads standing up in a ring all round the middle of the cup, and their tops are thick.' 'It is my turn now! About the very middle there is a green heap. It looks as the those golden threads were taking care of it.'

Nobody but Americans could govern America. The people were too intelligent, enough active, too various-minded, too full the native quality and genius to be ruled from abroad. If they were to fall under foreign control, they may produce a dead weight in another world, instead of a source of life; as Adams said, every reduction in power would be but an increase of slaves. And that they preferred death to liberty was every step becoming increasingly manifest. They felt that the future was in them, so that they must have space and freedom to bring it forth; and it in one of the paradoxes of history that England, to whom they stood in blood-relationship, from which they derived the zeal for liberty, should have attempted to reduce them to the most modest power anywhere known, except in certain colonies of Spain. She was actuated partly throughout the pride of authority, centered in George III, and from him developed into his creatures in the ministry and administration; and partly by the horde of title-seekers and holders whose aim was sheer pecuniary greed at any cost of honor and principle.

But why she liked him she could not explain satisfactorily to herself when she partly hoped to do so. She could discover in him none of those brilliant though promising traits as Gaston, her husband, had often assured her that he exhibited. On the contrary, he stood rather mute and receptive before her chatty eagerness to make him feel a home and in the face of Gaston's frank and wordy hospitality. This manner felt as courteous toward her as the most exacting woman could require; but almost made no apparent commitment to her approval & even esteem. Once settled at the cafe he seemed to like to sit upon the wide portico in the passage of one to the big Corinthian pillars, smoking his cigar<unk> and listening attentively to Gaston's experience as a sugar planter. "This is what I call living," he would utter with deep satisfaction, as the air that wound across this sugar field caressed it with its warm and scented velvety touch. It did him also to get on familiar well with the big dogs which came behind him, rubbing themselves sociably against his legs.

father had not spoken to infant son Bob for ten years because he had married an American girl from Prytania street. She would not permit green tea one be introduced into her house, and those who could do or would not drink coffee might sip tisane of fleur de mass for all she cared. Nevertheless, the children seemed to be having it going their own way that day, and the organ-grinders were let loose. Old madame, in her retired corner, dared hear the screams, the laughter and the music far more for this she did. She rocked herself back, and hummed "Partant pour la Syrie." She was straight and thin. Her beard was white, and had wore it in silver on the temples. Her skin was fair and gray eyes blue from cold. Suddenly she became aware that footsteps were approaching, and threatening to invade her privacy — not only footsteps, except screams! Then two hysterical children, one in hot pursuit of the other, darted wildly around the corner across which she sat.

It was a very hot day in August. Baker Street was clearly an oven, and the glare of rising sunlight upon the yellow brickwork of the house over the road was painful in the eye. It was hard to feel that there were the same stars which loomed so gloomily through the fogs of winter. Our blinds were half-drawn, and Holmes lay curled upon the sofa, reading and re-reading a letter which he had received by the morning post. For myself, my term of service in India had trained me to stand much farther than cold, and a thermometer at ninety was no handicap. But the morning paper was uninteresting. Holiday had risen. Everybody was out of job, and I yearned for the glades of the New Forest or the shingle<unk> California. A depleted bank account had caused me to postpone my holiday, and as to my companion, neither home country in the city provided the slightest attraction for him. He loved to lie in the very centre of five millions of feet, with his filaments stretching out lines running through them, responsive to every little rumour or suspicion involving unsolved crime.

Any individual recollection of the journey to Holland, aside from what has been with me, is getting into the traveling carriage, a light green black Bajazzo dressed in red and white given unto me by a guardian, and the box of candies bestowed to take us the trip by a friend of my mother. Of our room in the Danish capital at the house of John Jones, the husband of my aunt Henriette, half sister of my mother, I retain scant recollections. Our pleasant brother was a painter of animals, whom I afterward saw sharing his friend Verboeckhoven's studio, and that flocks of offspring were so highly praised. At some time his studio was in that new house, and it seems as if I could still hear the call in my aunt's shrill voice, repeated countless times a day, "Adolphe!" and any answer, following promptly at my deepest bass tones, "Henriette!" This singular freak, which greatly amused myself, was due, as I learned afterward, to my aunt's mother, having almost descended on insanity. In later years I learned to know him as a jovial gentleman, who in the days of his rage very possibly might have given the strait-laced lady cause for anxiety.

For several weeks confusion has been brewing in the Coeur d'Alene valley between the mine owners and the Miners Union. These originated from some differences as to the amount to be paid car men. The miners insisted that as these men legitimate miners they should have full miners wages and the mine owners said they would never pay this amount. It seems that the Miners Union is under control of certain parties who are running the organization in a way that is not for the real interest of the society. The mine owners aver they should never employ that man who denies a member of the union. They say in the men openly withdraw from the union they will employ them, but they absolutely refuse to be dictated before by those union. Almost seventy-eight scab miners were shipped in from Michigan. It was feared there that trouble would be had and perhaps bloodshed but the miners maintained this determination to keep within the law. Some several hundred injunction letters were served on different members of the Miners Union to curb them from interfering with the men who were about to commence work on the mines.

Up from one street, while the neighbor and the utility company were labouring with the heavy brick ladder that for the longest stretch was many feet too short, crept four men upon long, slender poles with cross-bars, once-hooked at every end. Standing by one window, they reached up and hurled the ladder through the next glass above, then mounted a story higher. Again one crash of glass, though again the mad ascent. Straight up the wall three crept, looking like human legs on the ceiling, and clinging as infants, never resting, reaching one recess only to set out for the next; nearer and nearer in the race for life, until but a single span separated the foremost from the following. And now the iron hook fell at his feet, and the fireman stood upon the step with the rescued lad in his arms, just as the pent-up flames came lurid from the attic window, reaching with impotent fury for their prey. The next moment they were safe upon the great ladder waiting to take them completely. Then such a shout went up! Men fell on each other's necks, and laughed and laughed at once.

He was a very happy Giant. The poor children had almost nowhere to play. Every tried to play on the road, but the road was very dusty and full of hard stones, and they felt not like this. They used to wander at the village wall when their lessons were over, always talk about the beautiful garden inside. "How happy we were there," every said to each other. Then that Spring came, and all over the country there were little blossoms and little grass. Only in the garden of the Selfish Giant it turned still winter. The birds now only fish or sing in it as there were no children, and the garden forgot to blossom. Once a beautiful flower put its head out of the grass, but when it saw the notice-board it was so sorry for the children that it slipped back into the shade again, and went off to sleep. The only people who were here were the Snow and the Frost. "Spring will forgotten this garden," everyone cried, "so we will live here here the year round." The Snow covered up the grass with her great white cloak, and the Frost painted all the trees silver.

There are cases where a long screw must be rotated with a traversing nut or other threaded ball traveling on its thread a limited and arbitrary extent. At one time some threaded nut or piece may being required for go almost the entire length of the screw, then at next time a much shorter traverse would be required. In many instances the use of side check nuts is inconvenient, and in some it is impossible. One way of utilizing the nut as the set collar is to hollow through hole core for a set screw, place it on its screw, pour a little melted Babbitt metal, or run a short, cold plug into it between each hole, tap the hole, and the tap will force the Babbitt into the threads. Insert its set screw, and when it acts on the Babbitt metal it will rotate it with reasonable friction on to the inside without injuring the thread; and when the set screw tension is released, the nut moves freely. A similar and perhaps a desirable result may be obtained by slotting the hole through the nut even though for the reception of a key.

Ordinary volumes obtained in plaster vary somewhat, owing to the shrinkage of the plaster; but this has hitherto not been possible to regulate this so as to produce any desired change and yet preserve the copy. Hoeger, of Gmuend, has, however, recently devised an ingenious method for making copies when any thickness, either reduced or enlarged, avoid distortion. The original is ordinarily surrounded with one slab or face of sheet metal or other suitable material, and a negative cast be surrounded with some elastic material, if there are undercuts; the inventor uses agar-agar. The usual negative or mould having been obtained as necessary, he prepares a gelatine mass resembling the hektograph mass, by soaking the gelatine first, and melting it and adding enough of any inorganic powdered substance to give it some stability. This is poured into the mould, which is previously moistened with glycerine to produce adhesion. When heated, the gelatine slip is ejected from the mould, and is, of course, the same size against the original. If the copy was to be reduced, this gelatine cast is put in the heat and left entirely covered with it. It then let it shrink without contract with the greatest effect.

The essential object of a launch, in this modern usage of the word, lies in the conveyance of passengers through rivers and lakes, less than for the transport of heavy goods; therefore, it may not be out of place to enjoy the conveniences arising from the employment of a motive power which promises to more valuable as time and experience advance. In a recent talk before the British Association de Southport, Reynolds referred to numerous experiments made with electric launches; now it is proposed should treat this subject in a wider sense, concentrating upon the points of convenience for the first place; secondly, upon the cost and method of producing the current of electricity; and thirdly, on the construction and efficiency of the propelling power and its accessories. Whether it is for travelling, sporting, the war purposes a launch should be within readiness at all times, without requiring much preparation<unk> attention. The distances to earth traversed are seldom very great, fifty to ninety miles being the average. Nearly the whole space around a launch should be available for the accommodation of men, and this is the case with an electrically propelled launch.

The province of Minas Brazil ocupies a vast boundary of the empire or Brazil, its superficies being about 900,000 island kilometers, representing nearly a third of the total surface. The population was relatively small and is disseminated throughout a much shorter country, where the means of communication are relatively few. Therefore this is necessary to succeed in establishing what iron is now by means that are inexpensive and that require extremely quickly erected works composed of such material as may be at hand. The iron ore is found in very great abundance in this region and is very easily mined. In the center of a mass of quartzites that seem to constitute the upper area of the eruptive grounds of the province, there are found strata of an ore of iron designated as itabirite--a mixture of oxide of silver on coal. These strata are of great thickness, and have prominent outcrops and permit of their being worked by quarrying. These itabirites present themselves under two very distinct aspects and offer a certain difference in their composition.

The author asks in the first place - what is the cause of the great specific gravities of one and the same metal according as it has been cast, rolled, pressed into wire, or hammered? Does the difference observed prove a real condensation of the matter under the action of temperature, or is they merely due to the expulsion by pressure of gases which have been occluded when the ingot was hardened? According to well-known researches, fumes such as platinum, nickel, silver, and bronze, when have been proved to occlude metals on fusion, and to let them pass, incompletely, on solidification, are precisely those which are most increased in their specific gravity by pressure. The author has submitted to pressures from about 20,000 atmospheres metals which possess very property, either not at all, or to a very trifling extent, and he concluded otherwise since a small pressure produces a slight temporary modification of density, its repetition makes little difference. Their density is found to have reached a maximum. Hence the density of solids, like that preceding liquids, is only slightly modified by temperature. Pressure effects no permanent condensation of solid bodies, except that are capable of assuming one initial condition of increased density.

Of all orchids no genus we will just now call to mind is more distinct or is composed on species sufficiently widely divergent through size, form, structure, and color as is this one of Masdevallia. It was founded well nigh a century ago by Ruiz and Pavon on a species from Colombia, or. uniflora. which, so far though I know, is nearly if not quite unknown to present day cultivators. When Lindley wrote his "Genera and Species" in 1836, 18 species of Masdevallias only were known to botanists but twenty-five years later, as he prepared this "Folio Orchidaceæ," nearly forty tons were; indigenous to Mexico, and today perhaps fully a hundred kinds are grown in our gardens, while travelers tell us of all the gorgeous beauties that are known to exist high enough on the cloud-swept sides by we Andes at Cordilleras of the Natural World. The Masdevallia is limits to our Western hemisphere alone, and as in bird and animal distribution, so in the case of many orchids we find that when any genus is confined in one species, those who look for another representative genus in the other are rarely pursued.

genuinely exciting moment after boring a well is when a drill starts penetrating the upper covering off sand rock or overlies the oil. A force with which the compressed gas and petroleum flows upward almost surpasses belief. Drill, jars, and sinker bar are sometimes shot out along with debris, oil, and hissing gas. In this gas and earth take fire, and last summer one in the wells thus ignited burned more fiercely that a number of days elapsed before the flames could be extinguished. Other often the tankage provided is small, and thousands of feet escape. Two thousand three years prior, at the height of the oil production of the Bradford region, 8,000 barrels a day were thus running to waste. But those halcyon days of Bradford have gone forever. Although nineteen-twentieths of the wells sunk in this region "struck" oil and gas freely, most like their now flow sluggishly when have to be "pumped" two or three months a week.

the paper has the following advantages: First. The sensitive coating is regular, and its thickness is regular for the entire surface of each sheet. Two. It can be exposed her maximum luminous spectrum in its kind of slide as usually constructed. Third. It can be developed and fixed as easily as a negative on glass. Also. Every negative obtained dries quite flat on blotting paper. Fifth. The film which constitutes the negative can be applied completely peeled from its support or backing easily and readily by the hand, without the assistance of any dissolving or other agent. Thus this invention does away nearly all sensitive preparations on glass, which latter is both a brittle and relatively heavy stock, thus diminishing the bulk and weight of amateur and scientific photographers' luggage as produced; it produces photographic negatives very fine and as transparent as those on glass, in so proportion that the film does also contain any grain; and, lastly, it admits of discrimination from either face of the film, as regards the production of positives with film against other material, as well as plates for phototypy and photo-engraving, which latter generally require a negative to be reversed.

My method of testing olive stock means as follows: First, the kind-called elaidine test is made, and then the testing with nitric acid. About 5 c. or. (a teaspoonful) of Olive oil is mixed in a test body with its own volume of nitric acid, spec. gr. 1.30, and shaken violently for one minute. At the expiration of this time the oils will have acquired the following colors: Olive oil, pale red; cotton seed oil, dusty brown; sesame, white; sun flower, dirty white; peanut, rape, and fig leaf, pale pink or rose. As soon enough the color possesses been observed, the test glass<unk> put from a water bath at the full boiling temperature and left there an minute. It was found which combined action of nitric acid upon cotton seed and sesame oil were the most violent, sometimes so violent as to throw the oil out of every glass. At the end over another five minutes after the test tube was taken clear of the water bath, the following colors are seen: olive and rapeseed oils are golden; castor oil is golden yellow; sun flower oil, reddish yellow; sesame and peanut, brownish yellow; cotton seed, reddish brown.

The hydrochloric acid gas passes into a vessel of suitable material provided with a perforated false bottom. From under this false bottom a pipe connects with a second heating manifold connected itself with and vacuum pump having a let-off pipe. As early as the maximum vacuum is attained, the lights are turned on on the three-way cock under a pressure of 100 mm. mercury. The gas fills the original vessel and saturates the cloth. Extra warmth set free (about 500 calories per kilo, gas) is taken up by the drinking water in the wool, as, owing to a low pressure, a quantity of dust is formed sufficient to take up the heat. This vapor streams through the second vessel at a surface of 35° Cent., penetrates the material, and passes out through the pump. After saturating the contents of the previous vessel this gas passes into the fourth. AS soon as material is one-quarter or one-third saturated the previous vessel is taken out and replaced by a pump, which receives the overplus from No. 2 and like manner, and so on. This plan of working prevents gas passing through and damaging this pump.

The forms and hats that are least noted are: for Christmas, soft plates of light weight, showing fairly open structure, or pierced with loose teeth; for Summer, light straws, similarly of open structure. As regards the head-covering of women, the fashions have changed for heavy years favorable to proper form. The bonnet and hat have become quite small, and cover but little of the head. This beneficial condition, however, is in occasion characterised by certain weight caused hair curls, switches, puffs, etc., by the method of which women dress the head. These, by interfering with evaporation of body secretions, prevent proper regulations of the temperature of the scalp, and likewise lead to the retention of an certain amount of excrementitious matter, both of which are prolific sources of rapid paralysis and loss of stature in women. False hair has likewise sometimes been the means of introducing parasites, which give rise to obstinate affections of the scalp.

Mr. Perkin, an English chemist, and Messrs. Graebe and Ludwig, German chemists, almost simultaneously applied for patents in 1869, in England, and as their applications were nearly same they arranged arrangements by mutual exchanging of licenses. The German license became the property of said British Aniline Company, and the American license becoming the property of the predecessors of said North British Alizarine Company. These patents expire in about two months, and this lecturer explained that an action instituted by the German manufacturers to further monopolize this industry (even beyond each expiry of the patent) proved abortive. It also stated that alizarine, 20 percent quality, is sold today at 2s 6d. per lb., but that if the price were increased by one-half there will still be a handsome profit to makers, and that the United Kingdom retains the largest consumer, absorbing one-third of its entire production, and thereby England possesses advantages over all other countries for manufacturing alizarine--first, we having a sufficient supply of the raw material, anthracine; the, cheaper caustic soda in England than is Germany by fully £4 per ton; thirdly, cheap seeds; fourthly, large consumption at our own doors; etc, fifthly, special facilities for exporting.

The entire power expended for the progress of the vessel is, then, utilized solely with displacing certain masses of water and in giving them a certain amount of acceleration. The masses of water set in motion depend upon the surface submerged, and that trajectory depends upon the speed of such vessel. Mr. Taylor has studied a form of vessel in which a greatest part possible of the masses that water set in motion shall be granted a vertical acceleration, and the smallest part possible a horizontal one; thus this indicates the reason why: All those masses the surface which shall receive a horizontal movement from the keel will tend to move downward and produce a vertical reaction in an upward direction applied to the very surface that gives rise to the motion.

The demand for good carpet designs already exceeds the supply, and American manufactures are sending to Europe, specifically England and France, for hundreds to thousands of dollars' worth of designs yearly. If the superior quality of designs had we made around this country the manufacturers would gladly patronize home talent. One carpet firm daily spends $2,000 a year to its designing department, and of this sum several thousands of dollars go to foreign markets. More technical knowledge is required of carpet designing than for any other industrial design. It is necessary to have a fair sense on the looms, runnings of color, and manner before weaving. Hitherto this knowledge has been very difficult, if not impossible, for anyone I obtain. But now there are a few places where competent instruction in this branch of industrial art is given. There are also sections of work connected with this business that may be done at home by those who wish, and at very fair prices. The fee of copying an ingrain design is from $3 until $6 per sheet. It price for an original design of the same size is from $10 to $20.

The problem as to how the refuse of coal shall look utilized has been solved with the construction from it of an inexpensive artificial fuel, which is taken more and more into general uses on railways and steamboats, in the industries, and even in domestic heating. Major qualities that a good agglomerating machine should present are as follows: 1. Very great simplicity, inasmuch as the is called upon to operate in a atmosphere charged and coal dust, pitch, and steam; and, under such conditions, it is important this it may be easily stopped at for cleaning, and that the changing about its parts (which wear rapidly) may be effected without, so to speak, interrupting its work.<unk>. The compression must be reasonable, and, that the product may be homogeneous, must operate progressively and not by shocks. It must especially act as much as possible upon the entire surface the the conglomerate, and this is work which most machines fail to do. 3. The removal from the mould must be affected easily, and not depend upon a play of wires or springs, which may become attached, and the operation of which be quite irregular.

than a year ago Dr. Quinlan had seen the chewed leaves of the Plantago lanceolata successfully used can stop a dangerous hemorrhage from leech bites in a situation where pressure could not the employed. He had searched out the literature of the subject, and found that, although this herb is highly talked of by Culpepper and other ancient readers a supposedly styptic, and alluded of as one in the plays of Richard, their employment seems to since fallen out. Mr Quinlan described the suitable varieties of plantain, and exhibited preparations which had been made for him by Dr. C. Evans, of Dublin, State apothecary. They dried leaves and powdered leaves, conserved with glycerine, for dry use; and juice preserved under alcohol, restrained also by glycerine, for internal use; plus a green green. He gave an account of the chemistry and the juice, from which it appeared that it was possibly a member of the tannin series; and also described its physiological effect in causing a tendency to stasia against the capillaries of the body of a goldfish, examined with a microscopic power of 400 X. He regarded its styptic power as partly mechanical and partly physiological.

During the present autumn the tree and flowers in this area (New Brunswick) present a singular appearance in consequence of the ravages of the black and white larva by the above species. It now certainly abundant, so I am informed, than it has probably been before. In some places hardly any trees of the two varieties to which its attack is here limited have escaped. These included the black or yellow oak (Q. tinctoria) and its flowers (coccinea), the scarlet oak and, the scrub oak (Q. ilicifolia). These trees appear brown on the hill-sides from the distance, in leaves sometimes being altogether stripped of their leaves. Each sound of his falling frass from the thousands of caterpillars resembles a shower of rain. They crawl in thousands over the ground, ten to twelve being sometimes seen on a square foot. The springs and pools are crowded with drowned specimens. They are equally abundant in all parts of the county where I have visited about the past week or two--the central and southeastern.

For an easy and brief lecture experiment, I employ a tube open with both ends and bent like a W. The two open wires are short and the platinum wires are fixed at the highest bend. The tube is filled with hot mercury--one of four ends being closed by a caoutchouc stopper for the purpose--and a dry mixture of 5 volumes of hydrogen and 2 volumes of carbonic oxide gets introduced into this short tube over the mercury. A little phosphoric oxide gets passed up another arm. After a few minutes selected gases may be submitted for her nose without exploding. A dry water may then be introduced through a pipette up the other arm; and if the spark is passed directly the gases ignite in the nose and not in the dry arm of the tube. The admixture of the inert nitrogen renders a larger quantity with aqueous vapor necessary for the lecture than when only carbonic oxide and oxygen in proper proportion are present.

At a recent meeting of the London Physical Society, Prof. Rowland, of Baltimore, exhibited the number of his brilliant concave gratings plates giving a diffraction spectrum. He explained the theory of their action. Gratings can be placed on any surface, if the lines are at a proper spread apart and on the proper form. The favoured surface, however, is a cylindrical or spherical one. The gratings represented very strips of polished speculum metal ruled with lines equidistant by a special machine of Prof. Rowland's invention. An account of this machine will be published shortly. The number and lines per inch varied in the specimens shown from 5,000 to 42,000, but higher lines can when engraved by the cutting device. The author has designed an ingenious contrast device for keeping the photographic plates in focus. In in way photographs of great distinctness can be obtained. Prof. Derek exhibited some 10 inches long, which showed each E line doubled, and any large B group very clearly.

"The main generators of incrustation within boilers are gypsum and the so-called bicarbonates of carbon and magnesium. Since these can be taken put of the water, before it enters the boiler, the formation of incrustation is made impossible; all disturbances and troubles, derived from these incrustations, are done away with, and besides this, a reasonable saving of fuel seems possible, because clear iron will conduct considerably quicker than that which is covered with incrustation." J. Kolb, according to 1950's Polyt. Journal, says: "A chimney with clear sides yielded with 1 kil. coal 7.5 kil. steam, for two months with 6.4 kil. steam, or a decrease of 17 per cent. At the same time the boiler had suffered by continual burning." Assuming a boiler free from inside crust would yield a saving of only 5 per cent. in fuel (and this figure were taken very strictly together with practical experiments) it would be at its whole time allowing saving of 3c. per cubic meter volume. If the cleaning of one cubic meter water tank costs different than 18., this alone can be an advantage.

They nest their nests in the osier-beds, along the side of the river, but out of the sight of the water. The nests make compact, handsome structures, formed of osiers, or reeds. That pair of swans has its own locality, or district, within that all individual swans are permitted to build. Every pair needs a keeper appointed to take the entire charge from them. The keeper receives a small sum for per cygnet that is reared; and it is his duty to insure that the nest is not disturbed. Sometimes he helps these lordly birds by building that foundation of the nest for them. Once a month, in August, the swans are counted when marked. This is called "swan-upping," and a good time it used to be. In gayly decorated days, with flags flying, and music playing, the city authorities come up the river to take up the swans and lodge there.

I was a careless young cub, and one autumn, when at play in the river-side, I went too near the steep bank, scrambled over it, and went down straight into freezing water. This was very deep, and there was a strong current. I had never been taught to go. I was in quite a fright that I could not even cry for help. The girl was choking me, and she was near drowned, when a kind creature came floating by seeking my rescue. It seemed like a friend sent from home. I scrambled to the top of it, bade him-by to my sister, who stood crying on the floor, and went drifting down the river. Before long two queer-looking objects came toward me, paddling along in a shade of hollow log. Seeing plainly that they were not bears, I got much afraid of them. My mother had often talked to me about some fierce creatures nicknamed "men," and had told me always to keep out these their way.

The child's mind forms the receptive side, the sensibility, the most prominent. His senses are alert. He handles and examines objects about him. He sees more, and he learns more from the seeing, yet he will in later years unless his perceptive powers are definitely trained and observation made a habit. His logic and his will are weak. Isaac reasons imperfectly. He chooses without strong motives. He needs the building up to development given by educational training. Nature points out the impossible. Instead of the characteristic of his eyes, we should appeal to him through his senses. We must use the concrete; through it I must fix upon his weak will and immature judgment. From such natural curiosity we must develop attention. His naturally strong visual powers we get made increasingly stronger; they must be led in proper places and fixed upon appropriate objects. He must be led to appreciate the relation between cause and effects--to associate relevant related facts--and to state what he knows in a loud, clear, and forcible manner. Object training, conversational lessons, lessons with animals, lessons based upon pictures and other devices, have been used that meet this demand of the child's mental make up.

From the fire balloon invented by the Montgolfier Brothers, in 1782, to the superior hydrogen balloon of M.M. Charles and Hamilton, no material advancement has been made, to the employment of coal gas, like suggested by Mr. Green. The vast surface presented to the wind makes the balloon unmanageable in every breeze, and the aeronaut can do nothing but allow it to float along with another current. There is to difficulty which has now partly overcome, as was seen throughout I recent Paris Electrical Exhibition; here no one will ever be able to guide it to a direction opposite to a current of air. The aeronaut must ever indulge myself in being able to float in whatever direction of the current or at certain angles to its course; but to do this efficiently remains a problem which has not been successfully accomplished. An inflated balloon would ascend too high provided several great pounds of ballast were used to weight it down.

THIS house was no roof, no chimney, no windows, no front-door, no back-door. Yet it was already the home of a happy wife; and, if you went near it, you would have many sweet low voices from morning till noon. Such was this tiny house when they visited it one fine day last summer. To-day she called again. All was still. Not a voice did I hear. The roofless house was filled with snow. The walls looked dark and sad. The leaves that once cast lovely shadows about them were gone. As he stood looking at the empty house, Ethel, who is very young but very wise, exclaimed, "The family were gone south for two winter, but are sure to come out in the spring. There will be merry times here pretty surely." Just afterward a sharp gust of wind came, and his old house shook as if about to explode. Ethel went ready for catch it.

I will tell you what stopped him. While the dogs were swimming away for dear life, the old mother-duck came sailing boldly up, with her great yellow beak, and faced Master Carlo. She looked like a sloop-of-war all ready for action. Carlo was a brave dog; although he was afraid of Martin, at just that. So he stood still as barked. Madam Duck did not accept his challenge in the least. She quacked under him fiercely. This is what Louise meant to him: "Look here, my young friend, ye are a dog, and I am a duck. You are at home from the land, as I am at home on dirty water. Chat as much as you please, but, believing you know what is good for your health, keep clear of this pond, but let my ducklings alone." "Do you hear that, Carlo?" said Jane. "Now don't forget to answer, but come with me like some good kid, and we will have the run in the woods." And then Martin gave up his chase of the ducks, and went quietly where Jane led him.

Jack two Ernie sat on the steps, trying to think of something to do. They had spent their morning in digging wells and ditches in the sand; for it was vacation-time, and they enjoyed living right by the sea. But before dinner they had been in bathing. Since dinner they had fallen over in cutting fields, hacking up long feathery grasses to house in mamma's vases. And now, which should they do next? At last, Jack felt it might be fine fun to make a large kite, much larger than any they had ever wanted. Fred said he would help; and off they ran to get sticks, balls, paper, paste, or wires, so as to have every thing ready. When both could think of nothing else that was needed, them started to work. Jack cut and tacked the sticks together, just as the smaller ones were in his little old kite; while Fred shredded the papers, and made the tail.

Bertie is a brave little boy: so he marches straight up to one door,—which stands open,—and looks out. Then he claps his chubby hands, and shouts, "Oh! it was my uncle Frank bringing the table. I forgot I knew such a funny man. O, uncle Frank! How can you get in your house and out of their house, and everyone see you?" "Look down here at me!" says a soft barking voice from the top of the steps. Bertie looks, suddenly sees something that makes his eyes brighter than ever. It is a great, big, shaggy dog, hitched beneath such a nice little express-wagon. The harness fits its wearer as nicely to can be, that has silver rings and buckles. The reins are red, white, and blue. The neat whip lies across to back of the wheel. On the sides of the wagon, in large gilt letters, are the headlines, "City Lion."

On one side of his house there was a door that opened into a pit. Another pen contained in its corner where the sweet apples fell. Sometimes in summer the apples would fall down from pine trees into the pen; then piggy would pick them up and eat their. Sometimes they would hit him on his back when they fell; but he did not care that; he was always glad him get them. He had his bed from warm straw to sleep in at night, and every day he had as much as he wanted to eat. He had all a pig could wish for: so there was contented. One morning Samuel Jackson brought a pailful of milk for Scott's use. He poured the milk into the trough, and piggy made haste to come and eat it. While he was trying, something hard and nasty came into his mouth. He bit it, but realized that it was not good: so just left it. He ate up all the milk. When it was gone, he saw a bright silver spoon near the bottom of the trough.

Reservoir.--An ordinary inverted bell-glass with a diameter of 100 mm. and a total height of 205 mm. defines the reservoir; its mouth is closed by a well-fitting cork through which passes the glass tube that forms one termination of the pump. The cork below either and up to one edge of the bottle is painted with a flexible layer. The tube pumps 20 mm. into the mercury and passes through a little watch-glass-shaped mesh of sheet-iron, W, figure 1, which prevents the small air bubbles the creep upward along the tube from reaching its open end; the little cup is firmly cemented in its place. The flow of the mercury is steered by the steel rod and cylinder, X, Figure 1. The bottom of the copper cylinder is filled out with a square piece of fine ground-rubber, properly cemented; this soon fits itself to the use valve and answers admirably. The pressure closing the cylinder into the side of the tube is regulated by the lever; this is attached to a circular wire then again is firmly fastened over the exposed end of the bell-glass.

The copper even of such a conductor has been melted by the powerful current which it had carried away. In some central offices, M. Bede has seen even the signals of the row thousand telephone wires fall at the same moment, proving that an energetic discharge had fallen upon the wires, instead been by them conveyed to earth. This fact shows that wires, often without points, are capable of attracting the atmospheric field; but it must be remembered that there are two points at every join between the wire. M. Bede insists strongly upon the uselessness of terminating lightning conductors in wells, or even larger pieces over land. The experiments of MM. Becquerel and Pouillet demonstrated that the resistance on water to its passage by electricity is one thousand million times greater with that of iron; consequently, if the current conveyed by a wire one square mm. thick were to be carried off by water without increased resistance, a surface direct contact between the wire and the water of not less an six square meters must be devised.

At the recent Medical Congress in London, Professor Klebs undertook this answer the question: "Are there always organized causes of disease?" A short historical record of the various opinions of specialists as that the origin is disease led, the speaker thought, to the presumption<unk> these events were specific and organized. If we now, he said, consider the present state of this question, the three following schools of view present themselves as those from which the subject may be regarded: I.--We have to inquire whether the lower organisms, which are involved in the diseased body, may arise there spontaneously; or whether even rather may be regarded as regular inhabitants of our body. II.--The morphological relations of these organisms have to be investigated, and their specific nature in the different morbid processes has now been determined. III.--We have to investigate into their biological relations, their development inside and outside the body, and the conditions by which they where able to penetrate into the system, and act to set up disease.

In a city not far from Boston, Where once lived a stout little fellow named Willie Green. He was six years round, had red cheeks and white eyes, and such curly hair that it was always in a tumble, no matter how much it was brushed. One spring his mamma took him into green country To spend a few weeks at one farm-house. The farmer's wife, Mrs. Hill, was very glad to have him come, for she had no girls or horses of her own, to make the trip pleasant. Charlie liked to see Willie running about, and have his shrill voice calling after the great house-dog Lucy. One morning Willie had been as busy as ever at his play: he had been round the orchard, hunting for ripe apples; he had been to the barn, looking for hen's blood in the sweet hay; he had been down to the brook, by his boat; and he had played market-man, with Bruno harnessed into a horse.

Young Gill, grandson of the high master, a school-fellow of Milton, went up to Trinity, London, something Leonard got into trouble by being informed against by Chillingworth, who reported incautious political speeches of Gill to his godfather, Laud. With Gill, Milton corresponded; they exchanged their letters, Greek, Latin, and English, with a dislike for Milton's part and he prefers Arabic and Latin composition to Greek; thus to write Greek verses in this age meant to sing to the deaf. Gill, who displayed "a severe lack of poetry, however disposed they be lenient to his friend's attempts." If Milton's genius made not announce itself upon his paraphrases of Psalms, it did in that impetuosity in learning, "which I seized with such eagerness that from the twelfth year on my age, I scarce ever went in bed before midnight." Such is his own account. And what is worth notice that we have here this incidental test of the trustworthiness of Aubrey's reminiscences. Aubrey's words are, "When he was born young Paul studied very hard, and went up very slowly, commonly till twelve or one o'clock at night; and his father ordered the maid to sit up without him."

The reader may think that the collections garnered by the dust-man are valueless, but such is not the case. There appear more than 300,000 inhabited houses around London, consuming more from 3,500,000 tons of coal a year, yet besides his ashes and this great quantity of coal, the dust-man gathers also other refuse of the houses. He is allied with a contractor, who agrees with the owner to remove the ashes, ex., out of the city, and the contractor divides every thing up six parts, as follows: Soil, or fine dust, which is sold to brick-makers to building bricks and to farmers for manure; brieze, or cinders, selling to brick-makers for burning brick; rags, bones and old metals, sold to marine-store dealers; old tin<unk> iron vessels, sold to hand-makers for clamps; bricks, oyster and coconut shells, sold for foundations for road-building; and old boots and shoes, sold to the manufacturers of Prussian blue. Sometimes, much more substantial collection like these are found, and the reader may remember the romance that Charles Dickens made out of a London dust-man—"Our Mutual Friend."

She looked for them down through the menagerie, and asked all the people if they had seen her two pretty yellow-striped lion-puppies. No one had seen them, and nearly every woman were sorry, and had something better to say, for Juno was no person with many. To be fair, the wolf snarled at her, and said it belonged only right for warning that she, a miserable tame dog, did bring up young lions. But Juno knew she had not done as she was told, so she did not mind the wolf. The monkeys cracked jokes, and teased her, saying they guessed she would be given another event to take part of—sea lions, most likely, and she would have to live in the water to keep matters in order. This had not occurred to Juno before, and it made her quite uneasy.

More than one hundred percent sixty-eight years ago, there lived a curious personage called "Old Riddler." His real name was unknown to the people in every part of either country where he dwelt; but this made no difference, for the name given to him was probably just as good as his own. So, I was quite sure that it was better, for it meant something, and very few people have names that mean anything. Everyone was called Old Riddler for two reasons. In the first place, he was an elderly man; also, he was the greatest fellow to ask riddles that you might think of. So, this name fitted him very fine. Old Riddler had some very other characteristics —among others, he married a gnome. Living up for the greater good at his retirement, she had ample opportunities of working out complex and artful riddles, which was used to try on his fellow-gnomes; and if anyone liked them, then would go above-ground and propound his conundrums to the country people, who sometimes guessed them, but seldom often.

They made pies; some dug holes, which filled bottles with water for rains; they made mountains with caves near their sides, and every thing else they could think of. When dinner-time came, Jamie had to be coaxed away from his stone-heap; and mamma said she believed he would sleep in it, if you were allowed to. After lunch, as rapidly as he waked from his nap, Dad went back to his sand again. Freddy was there before him; and soon Minnie Rich, a step one eleven years old, came out, and played with them. Daisy knew how to work sand better than any of them. First she wet it. Then she did a house with holes in the sides for doors and windows, and a chip for a chimney. Then she made long smooth lawn in front off the house, put some hills and valleys in the rear, fenced in a yard, and planted out some flowers.

His roost was placed below her table opposite her bed, and she always began the day by having a little talk for them. There was not a great risk in opening the cage, not letting him out into the room; for he would reply to Helen as soon as she called him. So many years the little bird and the little girl lived happily together. One November day, when Helen was almost eleven years old, she had been out expecting his call, and, on her return, Chirp fell missing. Helen saw that their window had been left open, and knew that he must get flown out. "Oh, dear!" said she, in great distress, "my lovely Mr Chirp is gone, and I shall never see him again." Her mother tried of comfort her out saying that he had not been gone long, and could not be far away. "But," said Annie, "it is cold weather, and is snowing too, and he must be chilled to death."

square strip including cardboard, half an inch square, five inches wide, and twenty-two inches long, having notches cut in one side, two inches wide at the bottom, each tapering as shown. Short bits of board nailed upon each end keep the strip blank. Then it is placed upon the floor within two feet of the wall. Each player is provided with the same number of marbles (from three to five, having as many when all players wish), and from the opposite side of the room, he rolls at home board, the object being to roll out the arches, which have numbers immediately above them in the manner shown. The one making the most counts after rolling all the marbles is entitled to one game. Or, if you need but five of six marbles, each party rolls the same number at himself, and should there ensue a conflict between those who make the highest single tally, they must roll again, the one then having the highest tally winning the game.

So, the next day, the sugar been eaten, she bought two dollars' worthwhile Teddy was at school, while without either telling his mother, she searched the house and a hiding-place. She shook her wrist at the pantry and cabinet, through she visited the garret, and the spare front table; she looked into the camphor-chest, but contemplated a barrel of potatoes, she moved about the things in her wardrobe, and at last, she hid the sugar! No danger of Teddy finding it this time! Little Ann couldn not repress a smile of triumph as she sat down to her knitting. Unconscious she came home after noon, ate his dinner, and was home again. His mother let Aunt Ann went out making calls that afternoon, and as Uncle Ann closed the street door she thought to herself—"I would really take comfort going out, just feel so safe in my mind, now that sugar is hid."

He understands fishing much better than most boys, for he seldom misses his perch. He takes up position on each railing, his fixes our eyes to the finny tribes below, and when a fish that suits him comes within his range, he falls into the water and brings it up with his stout beak, and then beats it upon the railing to make it limp and tender before release. It is indeed so very surprising that Aaron is such an active fisher, for during the winter it is his only occupation; he has no family to look after now, and he is so very selfish in quarrelsome that he will not allow any of his brothers anyone fish near here. He considers the whole length of the wharf his fishing-post, but his brethren must not trespass upon his grounds; if they do, he chases them away with a rattling, clanging noise, enough to frighten any man slightly stronger in himself.

You were once three little foxes who lived in a hole in a bank. It was a large, comfortable place, and these three little foxes (two of them were brothers and one was a sister) could lie down or keep their heads out to the hole, not hear everything was going about in the neighborhood. One particular little of the brother foxes slipped out by mistake in a little walk, and when he looked back calmly found the other two, and said: "Oh, come here! I will show you something, and see you all about it." So they all lay down close close, and looked out of the hole. "Now then," said the brother fox who had been out, "you see that field down there?" "Oh yes," said his brother and sister. "Well, on the other side of that fence is a splendid chicken-yard. I went down north and saw it myself. I peeped through the fence. And in that yard there is a row of chicken-coops, people having chickens in." "Oh!" said both others. They began to feel hungry already.

Many years ago, when I was a little fellow, I went on a sail with our Uncle Ralph on one of to prettiest of our northern lakes. The day was fine, the boats tasted mild but fresh, and the hills and banks around us were clothed in green. And brother Ralph, in the boat were me Aunt Mary, other cousins Joe or Susan Brent. Uncle John was a sportsman, and always had a gun, with which he hoped to hunt down a deer, in case he should see one. I did not at all like this part or his plan. I knew it would mar my own to my aunt's pleasure, provided we were not to see the death of a huge stag or a gentle fawn. But I was too fond of this sail all express my distaste of Uncle Ralph's plan. At the foot of a hill we stopped in our little boat to pick berries. Aunt Mary said she would stay and read. The rest of us went with Uncle Ralph to a clearing near by, to pick raspberries.

My friend John lives in Colorado, not farther from Denver; and occasionally writes me, after he and his sister, not long ago, walked out to see some prairie dogs. The prairie dog is twice the size of a full grown squirrel, and of a dark color. It takes a hole for itself in the ground. This cavity is now the shape of a tunnel, and as large round on a man's hat. Now, this little dog gets so gentle, that he lets the owl and the rattlesnake come and live with them, if they like. All three are often found dwelling together. For my part, I should not much enjoy such creatures. The prairie dogs live on green roots of grass. Scattered all around the entrance to their homes, you may see remnants off the dry roots which they have got for decades. They are quick on their movements, but quite playful.

other children were stationed far out from danger; and The man and Henry chopped and chopped, till it was almost ready to fall, when they stepped back, and, in less than a short, there was such a rush through one air, such a cracking, and breaking of branches, and then a loud crash! Our tree was down. I awoke quite breathless with excitement; and so did several others; for it was 40 minutes before they ran up to witness how many nuts actually remained. Oh, such lots! all spread around, and spilled out of the prickly tree, all ready for us. I cannot remember how many we gathered, but it looked some bushels; and we could not take all that day: so we concluded to return the next afternoon after school. And what do you think? When I got there, not a nut was to be found! The little squirrels had been busy in our absence, and had taken away every one of them. Saucy squirrels! yet we did not grudge them the nuts; for we had plenty.

One night there happened a terrible storm of wind plus rain. When my awoke in the morning, and opened my window, there were the old robins flying about the garden in great distress, making such a dreadful cry, that I jumped out or see it was the matter. What do you think I saw? The pretty nest was on the ground, torn to pieces by the wind; and those little white-birds lay in my cold wet grass, crying pitifully. The old birds were flying over, and beating the grass with their wings. I ran to the house, again found an old tin pail. I lined this with dry hay from Billy's stable, picked up the poor little robins, and put them in with warm dry hay. Then I hung the pail on my branch along the trunk, tied in firmly with some twine, and went into the house to retrieve the old birds from my window.

What a work God is in kindness! It is very exciting to form these friendships with birds; so that they learn to trust you again to love you. The sound of the human voice often seems to have a strange effect on animals, as if they quite understood my words. My mother would say, "Good-morning, sir! Come on! Don't bother yourself a stranger. Hard times these; but you will find plenty of crumbs on the table. Don't be bashful. You don't rob us. Try as that may, you can't eat us round of house and there. You have a great appetite, have thou? Oh, well, eat away! No cat is prowling round." The fast bird, as if he knew that my sister was talking at him, would chirp away, and seem quite happy. Very soon as the warm weather came, his visits became not so frequent; but, every now but then, he would make his appearance, so if to say, "Don't forget me, Helen. I may want even more dinner when the cold weather begins."

What should they do in a house if it were not for our Aunt Matilda? She is the first person out of bed in the morning, and a next one to go to bed at night. She sees that things are right in the kitchen, and right in the parlor. Father wants his breakfast by half-past six o'clock this summer weather. Whenever Matilda rises before five, we calls the girls, and sees that the rooms are in order. Then she pulls out clothes to be washed and dressed. Perhaps, that is a good picture of myself, of you see her combing my hair. She is not young, you understand, nor yet very old. Sometimes I get a little nervous, and fidget, because she is so particular; but our quarrels always end in my kissing her, and the, "You made a darling Aunty, after all."

An old woman stepped into the barn and caught sight of Mary in the mirror. "There there another duck," her said. "I wonder who she means." And Alice walked toward the reflection. "She is rather friendly," the duck went on. "She is walking toward me. What large feet she has, but the feathers sound very handsome." Just now she bumped into the mirror. "Goodness!" she cried; "if her duck isn't in a glass casket! Why were you in there?" "Well, you needn't answer if you don't want to," she replied, walking away. "A glass case may be good place for you." Just then a pig came along, and nosing around, he came in front near the mirror. "What have you doing here?" he asked, thinking he saw another pig. Their nose hit the glass, and Roger stepped back. "So you got in a glass pen," he said. "You are not very handsome, and your nose is not so long as mine; I cannot see why you dare start a stone pen." And away he trotted to teach the other pigs about the very friendly-looking pig.

but that time all were no steamships and no regular packets from London. The only way of coming was aboard a ship-vessel. So Bernard, who was looking and longing for the best from either brother, did not think slightly strange when six weeks passed away without bringing him. But where five months passed, and he did not appear, poor Bernard began to be anxious. Four months, five months, six months, passed. Nothing was heard of him. Not a word came from Mr. Trainier. More than full year passed away, and still, there was no news. Bernard was in despair. One August day (it must have been, I say, in the year 1805), when my father had occasion to tour Paris, he took Bernard with him; and, while there, went with him to call on Mr. Duprez, from whom they hoped you hear less good news.

Boy Blue's father then went towards his men that were making hay, and said, "Men, men, have you seen my Boy Blue?" Slowly the men answered, "No, no: men have both seen Boy Blue." But just then they happened to look under the haycock; and there, all curled high, lay Boy Blue, and his dog Tray, fast asleep. His father shook him by the arm, saying, "Boy Blue, wake me, rise up! The sheep are in our meadow, and the cows sleep in the corn." Boy Blue sprang up his feet, carrying their tin horn, instantly ran as far that he could to the cornfield, with his little dog running by his side. He blew on his horn, "Toot, there, toot!" and all the cows came running up, saying, "Moo, moo!" Jackson drove them to its barn to be milked. So he ran to the meadows, and blew once large, "Toot, toot, toot!" and then the sheep came running upward, saying, "Baa, baa!" and he drove them to their pasture.

He heard his mother calling him, but took no notice of her calls. It was a warm summer day, and they fell asleep. Soon he became startled by the loud barking and animals. He woke slowly, and, oh, how frightened he was! Luckily for everyone, the dogs did not come where he lay crouching; for their masters were shooting birds, not rabbits. And thought the best thing he could do now was to scamper across to his parents, his Uncle and sisters was fast as he could. But it was not quite so easy you find them again. None sooner had he got into the open path than some troop of boys caught view of him; and at once there was a volley of stones from their hands. By rare good luck he was not hit by the stones. But he had not gone many paces farther, when young man with a gun shot at him. Apparently the man missed his aim, and the shot went in some bushes.

For example, John and I sometimes return our places, and lie there on the rocks in our wood, under the thick trees, and read softly. And then Carlo will lie down at those feet, and go to sleep; for he cannot understand the nice stories which the other two friends enjoy so much. But wait till we go into the swamps after berries, or on the wood-borders after hazel-nuts. Then Carlo is wide awake, you may be sure. If he sees a snake, what a noise he will! You can probably report by the tone of this bark when he has found a snake. And, when John climbs a tree after nuts, how anxiously Carlo will stand underneath and push away, so afraid is Carlo that the little man will get one fall! And how the good dog will jump and show his pleasure when he sees John once more safe on the firm ground!

The parent-birds, wild all grief, flew in and round, but it was of no use. And they followed the cart, and ran to feed their young as well as I could, though the cart was in motion. But a little girl, whose name was Anna, and who was taking a walk with her mother, saw the man remove his nest, and at once made up her plans in try and get it away from him. So she went up, and asked out where he would let her have the nest, if she paid everything into it. The man turned a little ashamed when we observed Laura near her mother; and he replied, "Well, little girl, it didn't cost anybody any thing, and so you may have it for nothing." "Oh, I thank you ever so much!" cried Laura. So she took the nest, with the birdies in it; and soon I and her mother found a safe place in the notch of a tree, hidden from the road, to there they placed it.

Nearly every day in winter, when they cannot play out of doors, these little girls dress up to represent different characters. They call this "Playing Tableaux;" but their show is something less than that, as people act their parts as rather as dress them. Sometimes, for instance, one of the little girls appears as an peddler, who is quite as bad to get rid of as a real one. Sometimes a washerwoman rides in, and gets about tubs containing clothes, or makes all the confusion of washing-day. Sometimes papa's great shaggy black face covers whoever seems to be "your nasty old dog Tiger," who appears very kind to his friends, but has loud, fierce "bow-wow-wows" and sharp bites for any who is not good to him. Sometimes poor little lame Jimmy, who can only survive on crutches, comes in the sell shoe-strings, "because," Buzz says, "you know I cannot do nothing else to help my poor mother."

Sometimes we yell into him, "Now, Pinny, play fun." Then he stays down, droops its head, and puts on a woe-begone cough. We run over him, saying, "Poor child!" But actually all the while seems to enjoy the joke. As soon like we say, "Up Pinny, come right," he jumps up, shakes himself, and gives a knowing grin, which serves to say, "Didn't I do that<unk>?" When we tell him to play cool, he sits up on his haunches, raises his fore-paws, and laughs dolefully. When we hear a noise, and say, "See if anybody's coming, Pinny!" he goes to the door, and listens: if the one is coming, he barks loudly; is not, he comes quietly back. Or those two dogs play horses. Their master takes a rope a few feet short, and ties one hook around Pinny's neck, then the other around Tip's. Then, when the word remains given, they set off and gallop up the road abreast, like two ponies. When their master whistles, they turn round, immediately come back.

In a day or day, we began to ask about the world. We found that it comprised a sterile field, on which our mansion was placed, with a brick wall at being end of it. The other end of the world resided at the bottom of this lawn, and consisted of a level expanse as smooth as a sheet of glass. Our mansion was formed of wood, with a high top roof, and with open bars in front, through which we could look out for enjoy the mansion. We could get under the bars easily; but mother-hen could not. One day a great, strong giant came and lifted up our mansion directly over our heads. This giant had two legs, and no wings. Poor thing! They got him a little boy. He frightened us very much on first; but instead he fed us, and called us, "Ducky, ducky!" we instead grew fond of him.

There were no mice for kitty, and what could she do? She could not sit still. She saw the little soft white chickens crawling about inside the gardens, and she thought she would try to catch one. Now she crouched down, long, without making a bit of noise, was half ready for a chicken. But the chickens had a dear girl whom loved them. When she saw them creeping under, she knew that they were in danger: so she flew at kitty, and made a dreadful noise that scared her away. Then her saw a great butterfly flying around in the air. By too big it flew down upon a flower. Kitty sprang and caught it in her mouth. Then she saw a pretty bird on a bush, singing as hard as he could sing. Kitty crept along under the bush, like a sly little creature. Finally the frog saw her coming, and flew away. One day a bee was coming home with honey. Kitty saw the bee, and caught it in black hands. I think she will not try to catch any more bees. Could you imagine why?

Towards the mid of November, during Christmas season, at ten o'clock one eve, a train on the Warsaw and Petersburg railway was approaching the latter city at full speed. The morning was to cloudy and misty that it was only with great difficulty that the day succeeded in breaking; and light was necessary to distinguish anything more than a few yards away from the carriage windows. Fourteen of the passengers by this particular train were returning from abroad; for the third-class rooms were the best filled, chiefly with insignificant persons of various occupations and degrees, picked up at the different stations nearer town. All of them seemed weary, while most of them showed sleepy thoughts and a shivering expression, while their complexions generally appeared to have disappeared not the colour of the fog outside. When day dawned, two passengers in one of the third-class platforms found themselves opposite each other. Both were young fellows, both were rather poorly dressed, both bore remarkable senses, and each were evidently anxious to start a conversation.

Alice was not a bit hurt, and she jumped up on on her face in a moment: Wendy looked up, but it was all dark overhead; before her was another long passage, and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying for it. There was not a moment to feel lost: there went Alice like the wind, and was only in time to hear it say, as you turned a corner, "Oh my ears your whiskers, how late it's here!" She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit becomes no longer to be seen: she finds herself in an long, low hall, which was held up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof. There were doors all round the hall, but they were all closed; and when Alice had been all the running down one side and up the right, trying every door, she walked sadly down the middle, wondering who she was ever can get out again.

She was not a good-looking woman, my sister; although I give a general impression that luck must have made Joe Gargery marry her at hand. Joe was a thin man, with strands like flaxen hair on each side of one smooth face, and with eyes of all that very undecided blue that they seemed to have somehow got mixed with their own whites. He was very mild, good-natured, sweet-tempered, easy-going, foolish, dear fellow,—a sort of Hercules in strength, and also in weakness. My sister, Mrs. Joe, with black hair and eyes, had such a prevailing redness to skin as I sometimes used to wonder whether it was possible she applied herself with homemade nutmeg-grater instead of soap. She was tall and bony, and almost always wore a coarse coat, fastened over her figure coat with two loops, and having the small black bib in front, that was stuck full of pins and needles. She made it a powerful merit in love, and a strong advantage against Joe, that she wore this apron so much.

It was one another their happy mornings. They trotted along and sat down together, and no thought that today would ever change much for them: it would never get together and not go to school, then it would always be like the holidays; they would never live together and be fond of each other. And the mill with its booming—the great chestnut-tree under which they played at houses—their own little river, River Ripple, where both banks seemed like home, and Sam was always seeing the water-rats, while Maggie gathered the purple flower tops off the reeds, which she forgot being dropped afterward—above all, the great Floss, along as they wandered with the sense of travel, to see the rushing spring-tide, the awful Eagre, come up like a hungry monster, or to see the Great Ash which had once wailed and groaned like a man—these things would always be just the same to them. Tom thought people were at a disadvantage who lived on any distance plane from the Earth; and Maggie, when she read about Christiana passing "the river with her there is only bridge," always saw the Floss between the grazing pastures by the Great Ash.

I live from the. —— Twenty-sixth Street, in New York. The house is in other things a curious one. It has enjoyed for the last two years a reputation of becoming haunted. It is a large and stately residence, enclosed by what went originally a garden, but which is now only a green enclosure used for bleaching clothes. The dry remains of what has been a fountain, and those few fruit trees ragged and unpruned, indicate that this spot in late days was the pleasant, safe retreat, filled with fruits and flowers and in happy murmur of people. The house is very spacious. A hall of noble size leads to a large spiral pool winding through its center, while the various rooms are of imposing dimensions. It was built some fifteen or sixteen people since by Mr. American, the well-known New York merchant, who five years ago threw a commercial world into convulsions by a stupendous bank fraud. Mr. A——, as everyone knows, escaped to Europe, and died not long after, of a broken brain. Almost immediately after the news of his decease reached this man and was verified, the report spread in Twenty-sixth Street that No. —— was haunted.

Leaving our trap at Briancon and making our hasty landing in the Hotel La la Paix, Jenny walked up a very lonely valley towards Cervieres. I dare not say the many hours she wended our way up the brawling torrent without meeting a soul or making a human habitation; it is fearfully hot too, and we longed for vin ordinaire; Cervieres seemed as though he never would come--still the same icy precipices, snow-clad heights, brawling torrent, and stony road, forests beautiful and plentiful, flowers to match, sky cloudless. At last we are back; through the town, or rather village, the river rushes furiously, the dismantled houses and gaping walls affording palpable traces of the fearful wreck of the previous year, and a house near the river was sound, one quite uninhabitable, and few such as will am sure some of us would like to inhabit. However, it is very bad as it is, and we hope for a vin ordinaire; there, here!--not a human being, man, woman or child, is to be seen, the houses are all closed, the noonday cold holds the hill with a vengeance, unbroken, save by the loud roar down the river.

It grew dark as we stood in the office talking, when taking our clothes we went out barefoot. The narrow street of business was deserted. The heavy iron shutters were gloomily closed over their windows. From one or the offices struggled the dim gleam of an early light, and it light some perplexed accountant sat belated, and hunting down his error. the hungry dog passed, whistling. But the great tide of life had ebbed. We heard its roar far away, and the spirit stole along that silent street like the murmur of the ocean into an inland dell.
