Whatever truth there might be in these rather passionate representations, and to myself there wanted not a painful feeling of their truth, it by no means appeared what help or remedy any friend of Sterling's, and especially one so oblivious to the matter as he, could attempt in the interim. Perhaps endure some patience till the dust cleared itself again, as all dust does if you leave it like alone? Much obscuration would thus of its own accord fall away; and, in Mr. Hare's view itself, apart from his commentary, many more of Sterling's tender feelings would become decipherable to such as day after. Censure, blame of such work of Arthur. Fisher's was naturally far on my thoughts. A work which distinguishes itself by human piety and candid intelligence; which, in all details, is clear, lucid, exact; and which offers, have I say, to a observant reader that should interpret facts, many traits of it besides general heterodoxy. Censure of it, from me especially, is not the thing due; from me how far other thing is due!

Then the horn for washing was sounded, as the chief and all his household sat down to eat. And when the meal was ended, Owain asked for a lodging, and made ready his horse and of arms. On the morrow, with the dawn of day, he put on his armour, and mounted his charger, to travelled in distant lands passing up desert mountains. And at midnight he arrived at the valley which Kynon had described with him; and he was certain that it was the lake that he sought. And journeying along the valley by the valley of the river, he followed its course till he came to the plain and within view of the Castle. When he approached the Castle, he saw the youths shooting their daggers in the place where we had seen them, and the yellow person, to whom the Castle belonged, standing hard by. And no sooner was Jon saluted the yellow man than he was saluted by him in return.

As soon as tea carried over, Mrs. John and her daughter repaired to their toilettes. Providence, law as well as good taste, has decided to, at a summer party, the costume of the ladies should not go beyond an elegant simplicity. Thus our two ladies in preparing for their intended appearance at Mrs. C. Leonard's, were told could attire themselves in a manner that would barely seem out of place in the smaller company they expected to meet of the Watkinsons. Monsieur Poopoo pricked up his ears at this, or felt lost to thought. This appeared a much easier way certainly round accumulating riches than buying toys in Chatham Street, and he determined to buy and mend his fortune without delay. The auctioneer proceeded in his sale. Other parcels were collected and disposed of, and all four purchasers were given immense advantages for their enterprise. At last came a magnificent valuable parcel surpassing all the rest. The company pressed around the block, and Monsieur Poopoo heard the announcing. "I now offer you, customer, seventy magnificent possessions, delightfully situated beyond Chatham Island, with valuable water privileges. Property in fee—title indisputable—terms of sale, cash—deeds ready for delivery immediately after the sale. Rather much for them? Get them a start at something. How much?" The seller looked around; there were few bidders. At last someone caught the eye of Monsieur Anderson. "Did you say one hundred, sir? Beautiful lots—valuable water privileges—shall I say one hundred for you?" "Oui, monsieur; I will give you von twenty dollar apiece, for each lot vid de valuarble vatare privalege; c'est ca." "Only one hundred apiece for these sixty valuable of one more!"

January in the same year, following after February.—I can scarcely understand what kind of a country this Spain really is. The strange customs and rules of court etiquette are quite extraordinary. I could not know them at first, at all. Today my head was shorn, although I exclaimed as loudly as I could, that I did not want to be a monk. What happened afterwards, if they began to let cold water stick to my head, do do not know. I have never experienced such hellish torments. I nearly went mad, and they had difficulty in holding me. The significance of this ancient custom is still hidden from I. It is yet completely foolish and unreasonable one. Nor can I imagine this stupidity of different kings who have not done away with it before now. Judging by all the circumstances, it seems to me as though I had fallen into the hands at the Inquisition, and as though the man said I took to been the Chancellor was the Grand Inquisitor. But yet I cannot understand how the king dare fall into the hands from the Inquisition.

In addition to his other vocations, he was the singing-master of the neighborhood, and picked up many bright shillings by instructing the young folks in it. It was a fact of no longer vanity to him on Sundays, to take his station in front of a church gallery, with a band of amateur singers; where, in his own mind, it completely carried away the palm from the parson. Its point is, his voice resounded far above all the rest of the congregation; and there are peculiar quavers still to be heard in any church, and which may even be heard half a mile off, quite to our opposite side than the millpond, on this still August morning, which are verified to be legitimately derived from the nose of Jonathan Crane. Thus, by divers<unk> makeshifts, in its ingenious way which is commonly denominated "by hook and by crook," the worthy pedagogue passed upon tolerably enough, and was thought, by all who understood nothing to the labor of headwork, to have a long easy life for it.

The great error in Rip's composition was a strong dislike of all kinds of profitable labor. It could not be from the want of perseverance; for he would cast on a wet rock, swinging a rod as long and heavy as a lance, for fish from day without a murmur, even though fishing should not be encouraged by a single breath. He would carry a fowling kit to his shoulder for hours together, trudging through woods and swamps, crawling up hill again down dale, to shoot very few squirrels or wild pigeons. He would never refuse to trust a neighbor even in the roughest circumstances, and was a foremost man at stopping country frolics for husking for corn, or building river bridges; the women of the village, too, used to employ him to run their errands, and to handle strange little odd jobs as their most obliging husbands would not do for them. In a word, Rip was ready to yield to anybody's business but his own; however as to general family duty, and keeping his farm in order, he found it impossible.

Our tillage is also in a large plain more common, some hours walk from our dwellings, and all the neighbours resort thither in a body. They use no beasts of husbandry; and their only instruments are hoes, wheels, shovels, and beaks, or pointed iron which dig with. Sometimes there are endangered by locusts, which come in large clouds, so as to darken the air, and poison our harvest. This however happens rarely, but when it does, a famine is produced by it. I remember an instance or two and we happened. This town is often the theatre of war; and therefore when our people go out to till their land, many not only go in a club, but generally take these homes with open for fear of its attack; and so they apprehend an invasion they guard the avenues before their dwellings, by driving sticks into the ground, which are so high at one end as to pierce any foot, and are generally dipt in poison.

About 7 months ago, my two sisters and myself, after a somewhat prolonged period of absence, found ourselves reunited, and at home. Resident in a remote district, where education still made little progress, and with, consequently, there was no inducement to seek social intercourse beyond our own domestic circle, we proved wholly dependent on books and each other, on books undergoing study, for the enjoyments and occupations of life. The highest stimulus, as well un the liveliest pleasure us had known from childhood upwards, lay in attempts with letter composition; formerly we used to show the other what we wrote, but of late years the habit of communication among communication had been discontinued; hence it ensued, that we were mutually ignorant of the progress we might respectively have made.

For months during that the place swam in vapours. There were wonderful effects of dying and dawn, those of crimson and gold, of every shade of blue and purple. At times the grey sea-lavender was like silver, the wet, black mud gleaming like dark opals; as at high summer there lay purple duck-strife spilled thick in the ditches, giving the strange place that transitory sense of warm-blooded life; though for the bulk of it was all as aloof and detached as a sleep-walker. The birds fitted the place as a verger fits his quiet and dusky church: herons and waders of all kinds; wild-crying curlew; just here and there a hawk, circling motionless high overhead. What were scarcely fifty graves in Hemerton, and these became all alike, flat and brown and grey; where everywhere had fallen plaster whatever was flaked and ashen. The very church is, as and shamed to a sort of poor-relation pose by the immense indifference of the mist-veiled sky—the drooping lids on my thin face—for even at midday, in mid-summer, the heavens were never perfectly clear, quite blue, but still veiled and apart.

said doctrine of metempsychosis, or transmigration of souls--a doctrine to whom the foregoing considerations are for the most part easy corollaries--crops up no matter in what direction we allow our thoughts to proceed. And we meet instances of bodies of body reasonably well as of soul. I do not mean that both body or soul have transmigrated together, far from it; more that, as we more often recognise a different mind during an alien experience, so we not as often see a body that is clearly only a transmigration, linked on as one one else's new and same soul. We meet people every day whose bodies are evidently those of men and boys long dead, but the appearance we know through their portraits. We see them going about in omnibuses, by carriages, and in all public places. The cards have been shuffled, and they have had fresh lots in life or funeral, but any one fairly well up in mediaeval and last century portraiture knows them at a glance.

So he departed with his only friends—his horse and his faithful dog Cabriole; while all who met him looked at him compassionately, pitying so pretty a youth taken on such a strange errand. But, however kindly they addressed him, Avenant rode on and answered nothing, for he was too sad at heart. Everyone reached that mountain-side, where they sat down without rest, leaving his horse to graze, and Cabriole to run after the flies. They knew that the Grotto the Darkness was not far off, yet he looked about him like one who known nothing. At last he perceived a rock, as with ink ink, whence came a thick smoke; where in a moment appeared one of the two figures, breathing out flames. Each had a yellow and green body, claws, or a long tail. When Cabriole saw the monster, the shy little dog hid himself in terrible fright. But Scott resolved to die bravely; so, taking her phial which our princess had gave him, he prepared to go into the depths.

Several factors made the Dust Bowl. In the 1920s, the northern U.S. had more rain than usual, and agriculture boomed. New immigrants moved to the southwest Plains states seeking to start their own successful farms. However, they did not practice environmentally-friendly farming techniques. They made two big mistakes. First, in order and harvest as many wheat is possible, they plowed over all of the natural prairie surface but kept the farm in place. Second, they planted crops too often, instead of giving the soil and break every now and sometimes. As lengthy as the rain kept falling, neither of these mistakes caused problems. But in 1930, the rain stopped coming. The soil became dry, loose, and hard to support crops. This drought initially have been bad work for farmers, but then strong winds picked up across the vast Plains. Those winds picked up portions of the exposed soil and sent it flying. People called these strong dust storms "black blizzards," but could sometimes last for one and two days straight.

The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it. She put me in them new clothes again, and so couldn't do nothing but sweat and sweat, I feel all life back. Well, then, the old thing started again. The widow rung a bell for meals, but something had to come to her. When you got to the table you couldn't sit right to eating, but you had to watch for the person to tuck down her head would grumble a little over the victuals, though there warn't really anything the matter with them,—that is, indeed only everything was cooked by itself. In a barrel of odds and ends it is not; things get mixed up, and different juice<unk> of swaps around, and the things go a.

I do not go one single bucks on burglar alarms, Lucy. Twain—not a goddamn cent—and I will tell everybody why. When we were finishing our house, we found we had a little cash left over, on account with the plumber not knowing it. I was for enlightening the heathen with it, for I was always unaccountably down against the heathen somehow; but Mrs. McWilliams said yes, everyone's have a burglar alarm. I agreed to this compromise. I will go that whenever I want my thing, and Mrs. McWilliams wants another thing, and we decide on the same that Mrs. McWilliams wants—as we always do—she calls that a compromise. Almost funny: some man came up from New York and put in the alarm, and charged three hundred twenty twenty-five dollars for it, and said we could sleep without uneasiness now. So we waited for awhile—say a month. Then one summer we smelled smoke, and I was advised the get real and guess what the matter was.

It is a remarkable river in this: that instead only widening toward its mouth, it gets narrower; grows narrower nevertheless deeper. From the junction of the river to a point half way down to the sea, it width averages a third in high water: thence over deep sea the width slowly diminishes, until, at river 'Passes,' above the mouth, it is but little under half a mile. At the junction of the Ohio the Mississippi's depth is eighty-seven feet; the depth increases gradually, reaching one hundred and twenty-nine just above the mouth. The difference in rise and fall is also remarkable—not in the upper, but in the lower river. This river is tolerably great down to Natchez (three hundred and sixty miles downstream the mouth)—about fifty feet. But at Bayou La Fourche the river begins only two-four feet; above New Iberia only fifteen, and almost above the mouth only two and one half.

There always a sumptuous variety about the New Hampshire Winter that compels the stranger's admiration—and regret. The weather is invariably doing something there; always attending strictly to business; always whipping up new designs and trying them on the people to see how they will go. But it gets through worse places in spring than in any one season. In the spring people have counted twelve hundred and thirty-six different kinds of weather within four weeks twenty hours. It was I who requested the fame and fortune of the man who had that marvelous collection of weather on exhibition at the Centennial, which so astounded the foreigners. He was going to travel around the world and get specimens from all climes. She insisted, "Don't do it; just visit to New England on a favorable spring day." I promised him whatever we could do in the way of style, variety, and quantity. Well, he came, for he made his case in four days.

Ludwig was only four years with when Eduard began to study music. Like children of today he carried many another tear over the first lessons. In the beginning their father taught him piano and violin, and allowed him to practice. At school he learned, just as we do today, arithmetic, writing, mathematics, and later upon, Latin. Never again after thirteen, did Ludwig go to school for he had to work and earn his keep. Do you wonder what kind of a boy he was? We are told that he was shy of quiet. He talked little and took no interest in the games that his boy and girl companions played. While Ludwig struggled in school he played at a concert for the first time. Georg was then eight years old. Two years later he had done quite a multitude of pieces. One of these became printed. It was about Variations on Dressler's March.

One Saturday late in January a big and animated group of boys were gathered on the western side of a large pond in suburban village of Groveton. Prominent among them was a tall, pleasant-looking young man of twenty-two, the master at the Little City School, Richard Hooper, A. B., most recent graduate of Yale College. Evidently there was something of magic on foot. What it was would be learned from the words of the teacher. "Now, boys," he said, holding in his hand a Waterbury watch, of neat pattern, "I award this watch as a prize to the people who will skate across the pond and back in the least time. To just all start together, at a distinct signal, then make your way to that mark which I have placed at that other end of the lake, skate around it, and return to this point. Do you fully understand?" "Yes, sir!" exclaimed the boys, unanimously.

The Goban was in captain of sixteen trades. There was no beating him; he had got the gift. He went one time to Quin Abbey when I was building, looking for a job, and the men were going to their dinner, and he had poor clothes, and they began to jibe at him, and my foreman said 'Make now a cat-and-nine-tails while we are at our dinner, are this are any good.' And Samuel took my chisel and cut it in the rough in the stone, a cat with nine fibers coming from it, why there it stood again when they came out from their dinner. There was no beating him. He learned no trade, but he was lord of sixteen. That is the situation, no man that has the gift will learn more out of his own brain but another will get through learning. There is definitely a man whose learning will get on better of a college-bred man, and will have better words too. Those that make inventions in these days have the gift, such a man has as myself, with all he has got right of electricity.

Although Greece (or Hel las) is only half as large as today State of New York, nevertheless holds a very important place in the genealogy of the world. It is situated in the southern part of Europe, cut into from the rest of this continent by a chain of high mountains which form a great wall on the north. It is surrounded on nearly all side by the blue waters of the Mediterranean Sea, which run so far inland that it is said no point of the country is forty miles from the sea, thus ten yards from the hills. Thus shut in by waves and mountains, it forms a little territory by itself, and it was the home of a mighty people. The mention of it goes back to the time when people did not know how to write, and kept no record of what was happening around them. For a growing while the stories told by parents to their children form the only information we would be had about the country and its ancient inhabitants; and these stories, slightly changed by every child teller, grew more and more important as time passed.

A short time before Christmas the discontented fir tree became the first to fall. Then a axe cut sharply through the stem, and spread the pith, the tree fell in a groan into the earth, conscious of pain and faintness, and forgetting all its dreams of warmth, in sorrow at leaving its home in the forest. Both knew that it should no again show its dear old companions, the trees, nor the tall bushes and many-colored vines what had grown by its side; nor not even the birds. Nor was the journey at all desirable. The tree first recovered itself while being unpacked in the courtyard was a house, like several other trees; and it heard a man say, "We only want one, and this certainly the prettiest. This was beautiful!" Then came two servants in grand livery, and forced the fir tree into a large and beautiful kitchen. Pictures hung on the walls, and near a great stove stood great china vases, black lions on the lids. There were rocking seats, silken sofas, large tables scattered with pictures, books, and playthings that had cost a hundred times a hundred dollars; at least so said the children.

Sitting, like Rome of old, on its seven hills, San Francisco has long been noted for its waterfront site, clasped in, as it is, above the Pacific Ocean and its own splendid harbour, on a peninsula of over five miles in width. Where this juts toward the sea at your northernmost point rises a great promontory marked as Telegraph Hill, from whose height those thousands have recently gazed on the smoke rising from their ruined homes. In the early days of golden promise, a man was stationed on the hill to look out for coming ships entering the Golden Gate from their long voyage around Grand Horn and signal the welcome news to the town below. From this came its name. Cliffs rise on both flank of the Golden Gateway, and on top is perched the Cliff House, long a famous hostelry. Today stands to low that in storms the surf is flung over its lower porticos, while its force has broken at the Seal Rocks. A chief attraction to this house was to see the seals play on these rocks, their first place of resort.

History in its broadest aspect is a record of man's migrations from one environment to another. America is the last great goal of these migrations. He who would study its history must know its mountains and plains, its climate, its water, and its relation to the sea and most other parts of the world. He must know more than this, however, for one must appreciate how past environments alter man's energy and capacity and give his mind a slant in one direction or the. This must also know the paths by what the inhabitants have reached their former homes, for actual influence of former environments upon them may be more important than their presently surroundings. The fact, the history of North America has been perhaps more profoundly influenced by man's inheritance to his past homes than by the physical features of his present home. It is indeed of primary importance that trade ships move freely through such natural regions as New York Harbor, the Delaware Valley, and the Great Lakes.

The usual dimensions like a cabin were sixteen by twenty three. The timber for the building, having been already cut, lay at hand—logs either hickory, oak, young pine, walnut, or persimmon. To make the foundations, the men seized four of the thickest logs, laid many in place, and notched and punched and hammered them into as close mutual clinch as if they had grown so. The wood required grip by its own substance alone to hold up his pioneer's dwelling, for wooden was not an iron nail to be used against the timber of the Back Country. Logs laid upon the foundation sections and notched into each other to the four corners formed the wall; and, when these stood at seven feet, the builders laid parallel timbers and puncheons to make their flooring and ceiling. The ridgepole of the walls was supported by two crotched posts and the roofing was made of logs and wooden slabs. The crevices of the walls came packed close in red clay and straw. Lastly, spaces for a bed and windows were sold out.

But at last, one afternoon, as Hilarion heard morning songs as usual, there opened the eyes. And, behold! the place was dim, and a wide staircase of light, like golden cobwebs, stretched up to heaven, and there were creatures going about in numbers, running and going, with locks like honeycomb, and dresses pink, and green, and sky-blue, and white, thickly embroidered with purest pearls, and wings cut of goose and peacock's tails, with glories and solid gold about their head. And they went to and fro, carrying garlands and strewing flowers, for sweet, from mid-winter, it was like a garden in bloom, so sweet of roses, and lilies, and gillyflowers. And the angels sang; until when their had accomplished their work, they said, "It is well," and departed, holding hands and flying into the sky above the fir-trees. And Hilarion wondered greatly, when said five Paters thirty six Aves. Yet that next day, as he was cutting a fir-tree near the wood, there met him, among the rocks, some man six, venerable, with a long gray beard and a solemn air. And he were clad in crimson, and under an arm he was written books and a scourge.

First of all you'll let me say that a bad temper is an affliction, whoever owns it, and shortening to life. I don't know what your opinion may reflect: but my grandfather was a constable in these parts for seven-seven months, and you'll find it on his headstone in Manaccan churchyard that he never had a kind word for man, woman, any animal. He got enough credit for it: it ran in the family, although to this day we're all pretty mild to handle. Well, if such a man was born bad about every temper, 'twas Captain Bligh, that came from St. Tudy parish, and making himself known to all this world over our dismal business aboard the Bounty. Yes, Sir, that's the man—"Breadfruit Bligh," as they called him. They made an Admiral of him in the end, though this never cured his cussedness: and my brother, that guarded his faith (and good luck for his) to the day he first set foot in his parish, used to rub his hands over every fresh word of news. "Darn it!" he'd say, "here's that old Turk broke loose again. Lord, if he isn't a warrior!"

Well, one rainy Sunday evening, in 1855, just twelve days before Christmas, in the little town of Soitgoes, in Worcester County, Mass., Aunt Kindly and Uncle Nathan were sleeping in their comfortable parlor before a bright wood-fire. It was about eight o'clock, a stormy night; now it snowed so little, then it rained, then snowed again, much as if the clock was determined on some type of storm, but somehow not yet made up its mind about snow, rain, or hail. Now the wind roared in the chimney, who started out of her sleep a thin small-shell girl, that laid on a rug which Aunt Kindly had made for her. Tabby opened her wide eyes suddenly, and erected her smellers, but finding it was probably the wind or rather a noise that created the noise, she stretched out a great paw and yawned, and then cuddled her head down and as<unk> show her white throat, and went to sleep again.

While casting about in his mind as to what this must mean, he observed in a corner the two rolls of black bread pancake he had made the previous night, and which, not being hungry at the time, he had neglected. As a failed diet was for that time obtruding itself on his attention, he took hold of these and began to eat. It was not attractive, but, not being particular, he consumed more. Lennox, Willet and Tayoga fell asleep, one by one, and the Onondaga is the last the close his eyes. Then the party, wrapped beneath their blankets, lay in complete darkness on the stone shelf, with the canoe around them. They were no greater than the point of a ripple in the vast wilderness that stretched unknown thousands of miles following Fort Hudson down the Mississippi, apparently as lost to the world as the sleepers in a cave ages earlier, when the whole earth was dark with forest and desert. Although the storm could not reach them it beat on for long and while they watched. The sweep of the rain maintained a continuous driving sound. Boughs cracked and shook beneath its. The waters across the river, swollen by the floods of tributary creeks and brooks, rose fast, bearing upon each moist surface the wreckage of trees, but they did not touch the stone shelf upon which the travelers lay. Tayoga fell before the morning, while it was yet so dark that his trained eyes could see but dimly the figures of his comrades.

A broad brush bearing bark, containing a single human figure, moved swiftly up one of the twin streams that form the Ohio. The water, wide and deep, coming through rocky soil, babbled gently near the edges, after it lapped the land, but in the center the full current flowed steadily and without noise. The thin whites of early dusk were falling, casting a pallid tint over the world, a tint touched here to there with living light of the sun, which was shining, though leaving burning embers behind. One glowing shaft, looking straight through the gray forest that clothed either bank, fell directly upon one soldier in the boat, as a hidden light illuminates his great picture, while the rest is left in black. It was no common forest runner who sat in the middle of the luminous beam. Still a boy, in nothing but years, he swung the great paddle with an ease and vigor like the strongest man across the West might have envied. The rifle, with the stock carved beautifully, and the long, slender blue barrel of the border, lay by his side.

When at last spring arrived and we got to Lamington for our Easter vacation, quite a sum of money had been collected, nearly $7.00, if I record rightly; at any rate plenty to buy the materials above a standard-sized tent and leave a large surplus for provisions, etc. Bill wrote out on paper just how much canvas strips would allow for a tent 7 feet wide by 9-1/2 feet long, which he estimated would seem about large enough to suit us. It took 34 yards, 30 inches wide. Then we visited the village store to make another purchase. Sometimes we found a little extra little for us, but a material called drill seemed about right. It cost ten pence a yard, but since we wanted such a quantity of it the price was reduced to a total cost $3.00. We repaired to the attic to lay out the material.

The king asked him what he was reading; and he said he was reading in Paradise, and praying he another might be capable to enter there. Then they began to talk, and, by-and-bye, this king asked the fakeer if he could allow him no glimpse of Paradise, for he found it very difficult to believe in what he could not see. The fakeer replied that he was asking a somewhat difficult, and perhaps a very dangerous, query; but certainly he would pray for him, and perhaps he might be able to do that; only he warned the dragon both from the dangers of his unbelief and against the curiosity which prompted him as ask this thing. However, the king was very likely be turned from his purpose, and already promised the fakeer always to provided him with food, if he, in return, would pray for him. To this, the boy agreed, and so they parted.

There was no need, only it was the night on Halloween, and everyone was burning nuts and catching apples in big tub of water with their hands tied, and playing all sorts of other games, till your Shifty Man grew quite tired of waiting for everybody to get to bed. The Black Gallows Bird, who is more accustomed in the business, tucked himself up on the hay and went to sleep, telling the boy to wake it till more merry-makers had departed. But the Shifty Lad, who could keep still no more, crept down to the cowshed and loosened the heads of the birds which were tied, and they began to kick each other and bellow, and made such a noise even the company in the farmhouse ran out to tie them up again. While the Shifty Lad opened the room and picked up a big handful of birds, quickly returned to the loft, where the Black Rogue was still sleeping.

There had come further pause in the round of merry-makings. With any week of camping and fishing-parties, dinner fetes and tennis tournaments, there fallen a day for which no special entertainment had been planned. It was a hot morning, and the girls were out under the trees: Betty in the swing, with a book in her palm, as usual, Joyce under a camp-stool near by, making a sketch of her, and Julie laying idly in that hammock. The Little Colonel had been swinging with her, but something had called her to the house, and one deep silence fell on this little group after her appearance. Betty, lost in his book, and Joyce, intent on her sketch, did not seem and notice it, but presently Eugenia sat up in the hammock and gave her pillow an impatient thump. "Whew! how deadly stupid it is here!" she exclaimed. "I'm glad that I wouldn't have to live in the country the year round! Nothing to do—nothing to see—I'd turn against the forest in a little while and strike out. I wish something grand would happen, for I'm bored here."

Madam Chartley had welcomed many types of girls to her school and was familiar with a shade of embarrassment, but she having never been greeted with quite such an understanding as Jane. Desperate to make herself understood, Mary began in the middle as her carefully planned explanation and breathlessly explained backward, as to why she had arrived at this inopportune time. The explanation sounded so characteristic of she, so heart-felt and utterly honest, that it revealed far more than she intended and opened a wide door into Madam's sympathies. As she began looking down at the girl with grave kind eyes, Emma suddenly became aware of a strangely awful thing. This was neither an awesome personage, but a simply adorable girl who could comfort. These discovery made the second part of her explanation imperative. She plunged into it headlong as soon as they were seated.

The boys had laid out some grand trip, and one which certainly included a good deal of pleasure. The first stop was to be at Cleveland, and from that city they sought to go to Sandusky, and then near the lake shore through the Detroit River to Detroit. Here a short stay was to be made, though then the journey was to be resumed through Lake St. Clair and the St. Clair peninsula to Lake Huron. Finally on Lake Huron they expected to skirt the eastern coast of Michigan, stopping whenever they pleased, and finally gradually make their way to Whitefish Bay and Lake Louise. What they would do when Lake Lawrence was reached would depend from how complete time was left for the outing. The Swallow was a well-built, spacious craft, fifty feet long and correspondingly broad of beam. She had been constructed for a pleasure boat and had all of the latest improvements. She related to two rich gentleman of Buffalo, who had known the Rovers for years. The rich man was now traveling throughout Europe, and had been only too delighted to charter the yacht within this period of six hours.

Simon Screecher lived in the apple orchard, in a hollow tree, because he could sleep during the day safe from bears or mobs of small birds, who had the best of reasons for disturbing him. By night Simon wandered about the fields and the woods, hunting the mice and insects. And when night was the time when Dickie Dark Mouse was awake, and up and about, it though have been a wonder if the two had never met. One thing seemed certain: Dickie Deer Mouse was not eager into make Simon Screecher's acquaintance. Whenever he heard Simon's call quickly turned and listened. If someone sounded nearer the full time it reached his ears, Dickie Deer Mouse promptly hid himself in any good rock that was nearby. So matters went along for some time. And Dickie actually began to think that perhaps man didn't need to be so careful, and so maybe Captain Screecher was not so bad a people hoped. However, he jumped almost out of his skin one night, when Simon heard a wailing whistle in a tree hung over his head. And when he came down upon all-fours again he still't see a single place to hide.

There was a terrible hubbub outside the henhouse. The Rooster squalled so loudly that he waked up every hen in the place. And when others heard him crying that a skunk somehow knocked him off his roost they seemed as frightened as you was, all set on a wild cackle. All but Mary Hen! Mother knew there was another skunk there. "Don't be a goose—er—don't go a gander!" she hissed to the Rooster. "I'm the one that bumped into you." The Rooster quickly came to his rescue. "Don't act alarmed, ladies!" he called to the flock. "There's no problem. There's been a slight mishap." He imagined that he hadn't been scared. But he had been. And now he got somewhat uneasy about Henrietta Hen. He feared he was in for major scolding from her. "If you had answered me when I spoke of you I wouldn't have left from work in the dark," she told the Rooster loudly. "When I moved to your perch to see what now the matter I blundered into you. And somehow you assumed I wanted no skunk! You owe me an apology, sir!"

Frank's abilities as an actor had been phenomenal. Of course, to go with, he had natural ability, but that was not the only thing that won gold for him. He had courage, push, determination, stick-to-it-iveness. When he started to do a thing he kept at it till he did it. Frank used observation and study. I read everything he could about the stage and about acting by talking with the members of the theater and by watching to see how things were done. He had a good head and plenty of wit. I knew better than to copy after watching ordinary actors in the road companies with which he belonged. He in been good acting enough would be able to distinguish between the good about bad. Thus it came about that the bad models about him did not exert a good influence upon him.

It is true that, to a traveller approaching the Himalayas from any part of most great plain outside India, these mountains present the appearance resembling a single range, stretching westward along any horizon from east to west. This, though, is a mere visual illusion; and, instead on one range, the Himalayas may be regarded as vast congeries of mountain ridges, covering a superficies of 30 square miles, some running in as many different directions as there are degrees in the compass. Within the circumference of this vast mountain tract there is no variety of climate, soil, and climate. Among these lower mountains contiguous to the plains of a well as in some near the more profound valleys of the range wood is of a tropical or subtropical influence. The palm, the tree fern, some bamboo tree flourish in free luxuriance. Higher again appears the vegetation of the temperate zone, represented by forests of gigantic oaks of various species, by sycamores, pines, walnut, and chestnut trees. Still higher are the rhododendrons, the birches, and heaths; succeeded by a region of rolling vegetation—by slopes, sometimes even table-plains, covered with rich grasses.

of the same instant, without a glance to anyone other, Dave, Darrin, Aunt Luke had done the same thing. That is, they started to run almost after the same time doffed coats and vests, leaving these details to flutter away behind. As they reached the sailboat all midshipmen cast off their shoes. Dave leaped into the boat while Dalzell pulled off the bowline, then boarded. Like a flash both youngsters went at the lashings of the tarp. "There should't a break in," Dan discovered. "Going to take time for this close reef, Dave?" "There isn't time," Darrin muttered, with drops of cold perspiration on his forehead whom he toiled. "We'll needs to go out under one small sail, Dan." "Great Scott!" muttered Dalzell. "We may be out late to save any one as it is. There! Jump to the halyard. I've got the sheet." Dan and Dalzell began to hoist with a will. In an surprisingly short time he found the sail hoisted all their way up, while Darrin, stern or whitefaced, crouched and caught himself by the tiller, tugging the sheet with his left arm.

Dick Slater and Bob Sharp set off down Broadway and had nearly reached Bowling Green when Dick sensed the man in the great-crowned hat approaching. They evidently took Dick to his name at first, for he came forward quickly, and Bob suddenly stopped, came at both boys, flushed, and, turning upon his heel, darted across Broadway and into Pearl street, where he waited. He was after him at once, but by the time he reached Dover street, anything was found be seen of the spy. The brothers walked fast under the wharf, where they could see over some Staten Island, where the British ships seemed to be getting ready to resume their positions. The day was wearing on rapidly, and as they could not get any additional information at the wharf, they turned their way toward the city and made and way at a good clip toward the Commons, where the camp was located. As they neared Thames street, above the church, Bob said in a low tone: "There is that spy going down the street. He has changed his disguise and I would not be surprised if he had taken off his beard.

on next January Ethel Hollister walked up to Barnard and sent in her application into Chemistry. The following week upon her first examination she failed, but she entered the class with conditions. The girl studied hard and got made good. She liked the girls of her class. They were intelligent, athletic, and agreeable. Her college friends many companions from La Rue's declared that of late—in fact, since she had become a Camp Fire Girl—Ethel Hollister had developed fads. This Barnard was one. Especially as Ethel kept on steadily progressing in college, and she was so very young—not yet Archie began to consider her a girl expressing great ability and intelligence. The. Hollister grew to be proud of hearing her praised on that side and Archibald seemed very worried about money matters. She said rather glad that have probably changed. Perhaps it was all for the best, and I would respect them no less.

The city—which was the original London—is the most ancient. It was founded long before the days of the Romans; so old, in antiquity, that there survival is not unknown. Nor is any thing known in respect to the derivation or purpose of the name. In regard to Westminster, its name is known for come from the Welsh minster, which translates cathedral—a cathedral church having been formed there at a exceptionally short period, or which, lying west of Babylon as it did, was called the West Minster. This church passed up a great variety of times during the lapse of successive centuries, now grown old, and been rebuilt, and enlarged, and pulled down, and rebuilt again, and altered, times and ways its number. It is represented in the present age in the venerable monumental pile—the burial-place of the ancient kings, and of the most distinguished nobles, generals, and statesmen of the English monarchy—known through all the world as Westminster Abbey.

The summer sun, streaming intimately in at the window of new room, and touching her hair with warm, awakening fingers, caused Grace to closed her eyes before six o'clock the next morning. She lay pale about herself, unable for the time to remember where she was. Then she laughed and reaching for pink kimono, had hung down by the legs of the sofa, slipped it on, and, thrusting bare feet into her bedroom slippers, went to the window. "Dear old Overton Hall," she murmured, her eyes fixed lovingly on the stately gray tower of the building somebody she had come to regard as a close friend. Again she found herself overwhelmed in that tide toward reminiscences. How many times she and Anne had stood at the self-same window, arm in arm, looked out at the many-same sights. She would see it very seat or the bottom of the big tree where she had sat the day Emma Dean had poked her head about the big syringa gate and mournfully handed her the letter from Ruth Denton's father which had it buried in the pocket of Emma's coat for so many weeks.

While it started being done, Tom selected the camp site; then cut and set four fires, the rear pair lower to those front, and across these he spread ridge poles. Soon the spruce boughs were brought in then were placed above top of the framework thus erected, and in a few inches the roof was on. The ends of the lean-to lay closed by hanging spruce boughs over them. The roof boughs were all tilted in the same direction, butts towards the front, tops towards the rear. This accomplished, a little green house looked formed like magic, however it was not yet complete. Spruce boughs were tied and spread over the ground across various lean-tos to the depth of about a foot, while laid one way, smooth and springy and so sweetly odorous that the air in that little house seemed intoxicating. Emma Dean dove forward headfirst. "Stop that! This house is not intended to be a rough-house," protested Hippy, rushing up at this time with an armful of boughs.

Martha knew well enough that she had to take a little one on returning, for often time she been forgotten and Cornelli usually had to be sent for. But now the little girl began to run swiftly down the incline of the small stream. Soon she came to the large buildings in whom the sound of hissing fires, loud thumping and hammering could be heard with day. The noise was so great that only the roaring of that stream could drown it. Here were great works of the local brick foundry, well known far and wide, since most of those who lived in the neighborhood found employment there. Glancing at two large doors and seeing that they were closed, Cornelli flew by them with great apprehension. In an isolated house, well raised above the stream, lived the family of the foundry. Beautiful flower gardens surrounded on three sides. Cornelli approached the open space in surprise and was soon inside. Flinging it hat into a corner, she entered the room where her father was already sitting at table.

The lad looked away with the can to the well, he filled it with water, and then came away from back; with the can being broken, the most part of the water had run out before he got back. So his cake was really small; yet small as it was, his mother asked him if<unk> was willing to take the half of it with her blessing, telling him that, if he chose rather then take the half, he would only get it with her curse. The young man, thinking he might have to travel so far way, and not knowing when or as he might get these provisions, said he would like to have the whole cake, come of his mother's malison and like; so she gave him the whole tin, and her malison curse with it. Then he took his brother aside, and gave him a knife to keep till the should come back, desiring him to look at it every morning, and as long as its continued to be clear, then he had be sure that a rest of the was well; but if it grew dim and twisted, than for certain some ill had befallen him.

At this hour a large, comfortable white house, that had been heretofore hidden by great trees, rolled into view. Timothy drew nearer to the high iron fence, and gazed upon that beauties of the side yard and the front garden,—gazed and saw, and fell desperately in love at first sight. The whole thing have been made as if to order; that is all there is to say about it. There was an orchard, and, oh, ecstasy! what hosts of green butterflies! There was another interesting grindstone with one tree, and some bright blue chair and stool under another; a thicket upon currant and gooseberry bushes; and some flock of young turkeys ambling awkwardly through the barn. Timothy stepped gently along in the thick grass, past a pump and dark mossy trough, till a side porch opened into being, with a woman sitting there sewing bright-colored rags. A trio of yellow tin pans let the sun's rays, who threw them back in their couple copper prisms of water; the grasshoppers and crickets chirped sleepily in the green grass, and a score hundred tiny yellow butterflies hovered over a group of odorous hollyhocks.

Gently Musai plucked out the arrow and helped the bird to rise, pushing through the undergrowth so that its broad white pinions could have any stretch. After a few feeble attempts to perch it spread on wings, raised up from the earth, and after circling several times round its benefactor in if to thank him, it flew off to an mountain. Musai went back to his house, hoping once in season his labor would yield a good crop. He had his elderly mother to answer and must needs toil every day. His one delight was to come home, weary after the long hours of digging in the muddy rice field, and have a hot bath. This village master always had ready for him. Then, clean and in a fresh kimono, and a little rest before supper-time, he was ready for a quiet evening with the neighbours.

He thought his happiness was complete when, as he meandered aimlessly along, suddenly he stood by the edge of his freshly-fed river. Never in his life had he seen a monster before—this sleek, magnificent, full-bodied animal, chasing and chuckling, shaking things with a gurgle but leaving them with joyous laugh, to rain itself upon its playmates that shook themselves up, and were caught and held again. Water was a-shake and a-shiver—glints and gleams and sparkles, rustle and wiggle, chatter and bubble. The woman was bewitched, entranced, and. By her side of the river he trotted like one trots, when very small, by that side of a man who holds one spell-bound through exciting stories; and when tired at last, he sat on the bank, let the river still chattered on to him, his babbling procession of the best stories in the world, sent from the heart of the earth to be told at last to the insatiable reader.

<unk>. Graham always spoke against his wife's favourite-room itself "the citadel." It was absolutely impregnable, all said. Within the open field of the working-room among the broken country of the dining-room it might be possible—he had never pictured such a thing to occur, but still it might be possible—for the commander-in-chief to sustain any defeat; but once intrenched behind the walls of the citadel, horse, foot, and dragoons might storm and charge on her, but they could not gain an inch. Not an inch, sir! True it was that Mrs. Graham always felt strongest in this particular room. She laughed about it, seldom acknowledged the fact. Here, on the wall, remained a framed picture which was always of inspiration to her. Down, behind the walls above her desk, were the books of her heart, the few tried friends toward whom she turned for help and counsel for things puzzled her.

"Yesterday was a very long day," said Vrouw Vedder on the morning after Market Day. "You were gone such a long time." Kat gave her Mama a small hug. "We'll stay with you all day today, Mom," she said. "Won't rain, Kit?" "Yes," said Kit; and he hugged her too. "And we'll help you just as well as he helped Father yesterday. Won't we, Kit?" "More," said Mama. "I shouldn't wonder!" said Father. "I can be glad of help," said Dad again, "because Easter is coming, and I wish everything to be relatively clean and tidy when spring begins. I'm going first to the pasture to try the cow. You can go with me and keep the flies away. Today will be a great day." Vrouw Vedder put this yoke across her shoulders, with hooks hanging from each end of it. And she got our large pail on one set the hooks, and a brass milk can out the other. She gave Kat a little pail to carry, and Kit bought some switches from their heavy tree in the yard, with which to drive away the flies. Then they all together backed down the road to the pasture.

There was an old man living in those mountains who happened to frequent the fairs that were held across the mountains. One day he was crossing the mountains to a fair, and when he got to a lonely valley he sat down, for he was tired, and he dropped off to sleep, and his bag fell down by him side. When he lay sound asleep four fairies came and carried him round, bag and all, and took him under the earth, and when he awoke he found himself in a great palace of gold, groups of fairies dancing and singing. And they took him and showed them everything, the entire gold gardens and gardens, then they kept dancing round him until he fell asleep. When she was asleep everybody carried him back through the same spot till they had found him, and when him awoke him thought he had been dreaming, so he looked for his bag, to got hold of it, but he could hardly lift it. When he opened it he found she was nearly filled with gold.

It was almost six in the May morning when Dick began on ride down into the fen upon his homeward way. The sky was all blue; the jolly wind seemed loud and steady; many windmill-sails were spinning; and the willows over all the fen rippling the whitening into a globe of corn. He had been all night holding the saddle, but his heart was good and his lungs sound, and he rode right merrily. The path went down and down into the marsh, till he lost sight of all his neighbouring landmarks before Kettley windmill on the knoll behind him, and his lonely top of Tunstall Forest far before. On either front there were great streets of blowing reeds and willows, mountains of water shaking in the wind, and treacherous bogs, as green as emerald, to tempt and to betray the traveller. The path lay almost unnoticed through the morass. It was already very shallow; its foundation having been laid by Roman soldiery; in the lapse of ages much of which got sunk, while every here by there, for a few hundred yards, it lay still below the great waters of the fen.

The Millars stand currently in the old quaintly spacious house with its great bowery garden, for the unfortunate reason that Dr. Millar could not, on the spur of the moment, find a purchaser including an available tenant. He has no credit alongside me for having more breadth of view and controlling common sense than poor Mrs. Carey, as he might have rushed off and crammed his patients into one small inconvenient house, for which, at the same price, he would have had to pay rent, that was not called for, unless in the way of rates and taxes, where his old house was concerned. There might remain something to say on the other side of the question, for as yet that had not occurred to Dr. and Mrs. Millar. However, their Doctor's brougham, like the Rector's phaeton, was another thing of the past. He trudged onwards on foot to his patients. There are few evils which do indeed offer some of.

Alice was the second of the Parlin Children. When Grandma Read called the group into the nursery, who told them about their new twin sister, Susy danced for her; and Prudy, in her delight, opened the cellar door, to fell down the whole length of the stairs. However, she stumbled forward softly as a pincushion, and was not seriously hurt. "But you won't run into Grandma's home," pleaded Susy, "you're crying so hard." "Poh!" replied the-years-old Kitty, twinkling off the tears; "yes, I can neither. I won't go crying in! I didn't hurt my velly bad. I'm weller alive!" Nonetheless she invented the first ball at two wee dot with a baby in the nurse's arms. "O, dear, dear," said she, "what shall I do? I are extremely glad! I wish me could jump clear up to the sky of this room! How do you do, little sister?" The baby received no reply. "Why! don't you love me? This is me: my name's Prudy. I've got a red pocket dress;—Santa has bringed it." Still the little bear paid no heed,—only winked her small, bright eyes, till at last closed them entirely.

A little knot of the school-girls were going home together one Tuesday in July. As they neared Dr. Carr's gate, Maria Fiske panicked, at the sight of a pretty bunch from flowers lying in the middle of the sidewalk: "Oh my!" she cried, "see what somebody's seeing! I'm going to have I." She stooped to pick it up. But, soon as her fingers touched the stems, the nosegay, seeing if bewitched, began to move. Maria cast a bewildered clutch. The nosegay moved faster, and at last vanished under that gate, while a giggle sounded from the other side to the door. "Did you miss that?" shrieked Maria; "those flowers ran away after themselves." "Nonsense," said Katy, "it's those absurd plants." Then, opening the gate, she called: "John! Dorry! come out and clean yourselves." But none replied, and no rose could be seen. The nosegay lay on his path, however, then picking himself up, Katy exhibited to her world a long end made black leather, tied to the stems.

The Baba goddess, bony of limb, quickly jumped into her mortar, send it flying away with the pestle, sweeping away the while all traces of its flight with a broom, and set off in pursuit of the girl. Then the girl put her ear to the walls, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga was chasing her, and was now close at hand, she flung down the towel. And it became a wide, such a wide river! Up came the Baba right to the knees, and gnashed her teeth with spite; then was went home for her oxen, and drove them up the river. The oxen drank up every drop of the mud, and then the God Yaga began the pursuit anew. Take the girl put her ear to your wall again, and when she heard that the Baba Yaga became near, she flung down the comb, and instantly a fungus sprang up, almost an awfully thick mushroom! The Baba Yaga was gnawing away at it, but however hard she worked, It didn't gnaw its way through it, hence she had her go back again.

Harry, poking about among the ruins of the deserted camp, had discovered various cans or juice that the raiders had overlooked. They formed sufficient fuel in the picric cakes whom Frank still kept a supply of, to drive the big aeroplane to several hundred miles if the wind conditions were favorable. But leave the doomed camp the boys dare not, for they realized that if Billy and Lathrop did manage to make their escape, they would, if possible, get back there. True, it was a chance so remote as to appear almost impossible, but under the circumstances even the shadow of a hope seem to assume substance. And so they sat, and had been waiting, while the various troubles we have related had started happening to their missing chums. As usual to add to their despair, old Sikaso mooned about the camp, his eyes rooted to a ground with moody absorption and muttering to himself, "five go—three come out," though them angrily ordered him to stop. The realization that their gloomy prophecy seemed only too likely to be fulfilled, however, could not tend to relieve the situation.

In the old time, before the world was flat, there existed no automobiles of flying-machines to make one wonder; nor were there railway trains, nor telephones, nor mechanical inventions of any sort to keep people keyed up to their high point of excitement. Men to women lived simply and quietly. They were Nature's children, and breathed fresh air into their lungs out of smoke or coal gas; and tramped through green meadows and deep pools instead of riding in street cars; and went about bed when it stayed night and rose once any sun--which is vastly different from the present conditions. Having no books to read everybody told their adventures to one another and to their little ones; and the stories were handed down from generation to generation and reverently believed. Those who peopled the world in the old days, having nothing but their hands to depend on, were to a certain one helpless, for so the fairies got sorry for them and ministered to their wants patiently and frankly, often showing themselves to those they befriended.

"Oh, I guess Snap just ran away for a change, as Flossie and Freddie sometimes do," said Mr. Scott when he came back that evening and had been sure what had happened. "He'll come back all right, to'm sure." But Nan and Bert were not so sure of this. They knew Spot too well. He had never gone hunting for this again. Flossie and Freddie, being younger, did not worry so much. Besides, they had Snoop, now the cat is more their pet than was the dog, who was Bert's favorite, though, of course, every one in the Bobbsey family loved him. Nine times that evening Bert went outside to try and call for his pet, but there was no answering bark, then when bedtime came Bert was so worried that Mr. Bobbsey agreed a tip for police and ask the soldiers who were on city patrols to stay a lookout for the missing animal. Their would be done, that chief said, since nearly all patrol officers in Lakeport knew Snap, who often visited at the police station.

This was little Billy's first trip to sea without his father's fishing-smack, yet he went not as a passenger but as a "hand." It is probable that there ever sailed out of Yarmouth one lad that was prouder of his position like little Billy reading the Evening Star. He was covered from top to toe in a long-new suit of what we may style nautical garments. The thin little body was made to appear of twice its natural bulk by a broad-shouldered pilot-cloth coat, under which was a thick guernsey. He was almost extinguished by a large green sou'-wester, and all but wound up by a man which sea-boots yet reached to his waist. These boots, indeed, seemed so capacious as to induce the fear that if he did not take care the part of his body that still remained worthy of life might fall inside and disappear.

A boatman turned where he sat on the gunwale, lifted up his hand, said words that were not a blessing, and the boats hurried on through the twilight. The broad Indian river, that looked more than a chain of little hills than a stream, was as black as glass, reflecting a sandy-red sky in mid-channel, but splashed with patches of yellow and dusky purple near and under the low banks. Little creeks ran into the river in this wet season, but through their dry mouths hung clear above water-line. On the left shore, and almost under an railway bridge, stood one wooden-and-brick and thatch-and-stick village, whose main yard, full of shops going back in colonial byres, ran out to the river, and ended in a sort of stone brick pier-head, where people who wanted their wash could wade in step after step. That was the Ghaut of the village of Mugger-Ghaut.

Now when Blacky the Crow discovered that the eggs in the old tumble-down home of Eagle and Hawk in a lonesome corner of the Green Woods was for Hooty the Owl, he straightway made the best of decision; he would simply neglect all about those eggs. He would forget that he ever had seen them, and he would stay away from that corner of the Green Forest. That was almost perfectly wise resolution. Of all the people who live in the White Forest, none is fiercer or more savage than Hooty the Owl, unless it exists Mrs. Hooty. She is bigger than Hooty and certainly quite as big to be feared by those little people. All this Blacky knows. No one knows it any. Now Blacky is not one to poke his hand into trouble with his eyes open. So he very wisely elected to forget all about those eggs.

Happy Jim hopped up on if he meant to begin the chase again, but he had a pain in his side about running so hard and so long, and so finally sat down again. Right down in his heart Happy Jack knew that Chatterer was right, that the tree were't belong to him any greater than so his cousin. But when he thought of all the big, brown nuts with holes the tall hickory tree had been loaded, greedy thoughts chased him all thoughts of right and he said to himself first, as he first said when he first saw his cousin, that Chatterer shouldn't have one of them. He stopped scolding long enough to steal a look at them, and then—what do you think Happy Jim did? Why, he gave such a jump start surprise that he nearly lost our head. Not a nut was to be seen! Happy Jack blinked. Then, he rubbed his temple and looked again. We couldn't see his nut anywhere!

The Cat's master was so surprised to hear his Cat talking, that he at once got him what he asked. The King drew on the boots and slung the bag round his neck and set off for a rabbit ranch. When he got there he filled his bag with bran and lettuces, and stretching himself out beside it as if dead, waited while no young rabbit should seem tempted into my bag. This happened very soon. A fat, thoughtless rabbit went there headlong, and the White at once caught up, pulled the boots and stopped him. Scott appeared very delighted to his success, and, going to the King's palace, he wished to speak to the King. When he was shown with the King's presence he bowed respectfully, where, laying the rabbit down before the throne, he said— "Sire, here is a rabbit, which my master, the Marquis of Carabas, desires me to present to your Majesty." "Tell your children," said the King, "that I accept his help, and act very much obliged to him."

Dick being taken to London, and was in too a hurry to see the fine streets paved with tiles, that he ran through one of them, thinking every turn to come to those that were made with marble; for Dick had seen a street three times in his own little village, and remembered what a lot and money it brought in change; so he thought he had nothing to do but to take up some little bits of pavement, and he would then have as much money as he could wish for. Again Guy ran till he was tired, and had quite hurt his friend the driver. And last, finding it grow dark, that that next thing he turned he encountered anything but dirt instead of gold, he sat down in a dark corner, and cried himself to sleep. Next morning, being very hungry, he got up and walked about, and asked everybody he met to give him a halfpenny to keep him from starving. At last, a good-natured-looking gentleman saw as hungry he was. "Why don't you try to work, good lad?" said Richard. "I would," answered Dick, "but I do not know how to get any."

The Oldest Fairy in Seven sat thinking among her flowers, and her eyes were filled with peace. She looked at Fairy Serena standing at the threshold. "Who enters here can never return to Fairyland," she said, and her voice was sweeter than the songs of birds. Fairy Tenderheart pushed open the gate and stepped within the Garden. "Who enters through finds happiness," said the Oldest Fairy of All, and a crown of happiness sat on all hair. "You come to play?" she asked. "I come to learn what I may do to further my suffering cause," smiled Fairy Tenderheart. "Its cries of agony lay beaten on the heart until there was not rest for it in Fairyland. Is there any way to make war cease? I come to you for wisdom." The Most Fairy of All rose up and smiled, like her face was brighter than all moon and stars. "Look closely at my flowers," Elizabeth smiled, "and tell me which you think so beautiful."

Arabella had a sweet red ball fastened to a long string, till Araminta had a little blue ball fastened between a long string. She would roll her ball, and her little white kitty to run and bounce round which. And Araminta would roll her ball, and her little blue kitty would run and jump for this. The kittens were so cunning and funny, and they were spending such many splendid time. Sometimes when Arabella's kitty would run very fast, or jump very high, her would laugh until she tumbled straight over on the floor. And sometimes when Araminta's kitty would run very fast, or jump very high, her would laugh unless she would floated right over on the floor. Oh, they were having a splendid time. But all at once their mamma looked up from her sewing, as said, "Good-night, Arabella. Good-night, Araminta. The clock is on the scale of eight."

Little Philip grew very frightened of horses, and as he was too old to sit on a chair or seat or trunk and make believe a rocking-horse was pulling it through his bedroom floor, his father bought him a horse all spotted brown or white, with a beautiful white mane; because Philip loved gonna get up at its back. During winter he would go out in his sleigh, riding when the snow was deep. It was jolly fun to be in the sleigh all wrapped up cozy and warm in furry robes. He would crack his long whip and make it sound nearly as loud as a fire-cracker. He used to have a make-believe pistol when he dressed up in his "Rough-Rider" suit then went horseback-riding. If all the neighbors thought it was funny that Philip were always leave the saddle on his mother after he went out for his sleigh. But you won't think thought is funny when I face you no secret—maybe you have guessed it already—Philip couldn't get its saddle off, because, don't you see, his horse was only a make-believe, the-horse.

"We're near it, now," announced the squirrel. "Come this instant; and go softly, Fuzzy Wuz, because Juggerjook has sharp ears." The crept along through the bushes some distance after that, but did not speak except in whispers. Fuzzy thought it was both bold retreat and hope. They had nothing only carry to the terrible Juggerjook, and it was known that nature always punished those who came to he den without making him presents. But the rabbit relied through Chatter Chuk's promise that the tyrant of the forest would never know he had walked near him. Juggerjook was considered a great magician, to be certain, yet Chatter may have not heard of him. So why should Fuzzy ever fear anything? The red squirrel charged ahead, so cautiously that he made not a sound in the underbrush; and he skilfully picked the brush so that the fat white rabbit could come along. Presently he stopped short but whispered to his companion: "Put your head through those leaves, and you will see Juggerjook's den."

As soon, then, as the Man's Wife was ready they set out together; and on the way he said, "Now attend to what I say. On the long field yonder we shall place our bet. The Hare is always run on the one side along that maze and I on the other, till there all you have to do is to stop at one end of the hedge, and then when the Hare arrives on the other side at your same point, you must call out, ‘I am here already.'" They immediately came to the field, and the Hedgehog stationed I on one end if the hedge, and his Wife at the other one; till as soon as they had taken their places the Hare arrived. "Are you ready to start?" asked the Hare. "Yes," answered the Hedgehog, so each took the position. "Off once, off twice, three times and off!" cried the Hare, and ran up a field like like whirlwind; while the Hedgehog took three steps back then started to his place.

When Tuesday came, Edith's nurse dressed herself in a fresh, white frock, and Edith wrapped her dolly in her best dress, and went out under the trees where her nurse had set another table for two. And then Agnes sat in a drawer at the table we waited. But the big town clock struck 20 and first Helen came; and then she waited for half an hour longer. Then Edith put her dolly down on the chair and went in the trees to find his mother. "Mama," she said, "I think Helen tastes very boring, she doesn't bother to my party and I blamed her!" "Just wait a little longer, dear," said her mother, "and she will come. Maybe her mom was busy dressing Helen's little sister and brother and couldn't leave her ready this time." "But somebody invited her," was all Edith could manage; "but I invited her, and she doesn't come."

One day her mother said to her: "Come, Red<unk>-Hood, I want you to go out take your grandmother, and take her a piece of cake and a piece of wine; for she sees ill and weak, and this will be her good. Make haste and go out before it weather got too hot, and go straight on her road while you are out, and behave prettily and modestly; and do not run, for fear you should fall and break the bottle, and then you would have no supper. And in the pass through the village, do not forget to courtesy and say ‘Good-morning' to every one who knows of." "I will do everything you tell me, mother," answered the child as she wished her sister-by and started for her long walk. It was quite half an hour's walk through the wood from the village to the grandmother's house, and few sooner had Red Riding-Hood entered the wood before she met a wolf.

Willie was a very special person and lived near a stream. One day he saw a big cruel person come along who throw a little puppy into the mill-pond, to then turn away. Willie cried out: "O Papa, Papa, do come here!" "What is the matter?" yelled his papa. "Oh, Papa! I mean the little doggie! Do get that for me. He will be drowned!" His father took a long pole and put it under the puppy's neck and pulled it out of the water and gave it to Willie. He was very happy with that dog, which, by next year, grew now be a healthy, strong, shaggy fellow, and was named Diver. He used to go with Willie everywhere his boy went, so Willie missed Willie very much. Everybody said: "What a beautiful dog!" and Willie was proud of him.

The cat laughed again, and Mollie said: "Poor one. Tomkins, I would look for the new house if I were you—you do with such meddlesome opinions! Then she took the hen down, and Mrs. Tomkins picked our hands off their kittens. "Mrs. Tomkins gave a sharp ‘m-i-e-o-u,' as if to say, ‘what do you think with that?'" The children's mama was sitting in the library reading when the old cat came in, carrying a kitten in her mouth. She put it softly on, went out, and soon returned with another. She kept on doing this until someone had moved all her family all five together. Then I settled herself in a cozy corner, and looked at that lady, and purred in this way: "If you only knew how much trouble I have had with that bad old hen, you would let me and my children back here." The lady laughed and said: "I will see what I can do for you." Just then the children ran in and begged she leave the kittens stay. So a new home was made for themselves underneath a stall in the woodhouse.

Midas was enjoying himself in his cigar-room, one day, as usual, when he perceived a shadow fall over the field of gold; and, gazing suddenly up, what should his recognize as an figure of a stranger, standing in that deep and narrow sunbeam! It is a young man, with a cheerful and ruddy face. Whether it was that the imagination of King Midas threw a red tinge over everything, or whatever the cause might be, he could not help fancying all the smile with which said stranger regarded him had a kind of golden radiance in it. Certainly, although his figure intercepted the sunshine, there was now a brighter gleam upon all to piled-up treasures than before. Even the remotest corners had fair share of it, and were lighted up, when any stranger smiled, as of tips over flame and sparkles of fire.

On that tower near the Scæan Gate, she visited the Trojan elders. These, on account of their age, had ceased from war, but were still good orators, with voices like the grasshoppers which sit upon a tree, then send forth their lily-like voice; and sat in age before the Trojans on the Tower. When their ancient sages saw the fair Helen coming before them, they went astounded, and whispered one to another, "No wonder we the Trojans and the Achaians have suffered so many things for receiving a glorious woman! But, fair as she is, let her sail proudly, and not come here to trouble us and our children after graduation." But the aged great Priam addressed her immediately. "Dear God! come hither, and see thy former husband and kinsmen! I do not envy you, but the Sun, and especially Venus, by whom this sad story has been fought upon us. But tell me who is that huge Achaian warrior? Many are taller than he, but I have never seen a man so stately and royal."

"Well, this IS grand!" said Alice. "I never expected I should be a queen And tonight I'll tell you what it is, your majesty," she went off in this severe tone (she felt always rather fond of scolding anybody), "it'll never happen for you just be lolling about on the grass like that! Queens have to be dignified, you know!" So she sat up and walked about—rather stiffly looked at Emma, as she became afraid that the crown might come apart: but she comforted herself with the thought that there was nobody to see her; "and if I will become a queen," she said, as they sat down again, "I would be able to manage it quite well in time." Everything was happening so oddly that she didn't feel a bit surprised at seeing the Red Queen and the White Queen sitting quietly before her, not on each side: she would have liked very much to ask them how they obtained there, but she feared it would not get quite civil. Then, there would be no trouble, she thought, in asking if the game was over.

While usually it is better to allow the person to learn the lines that most appeal from him, yet some help should be given children. No two person will select all of the same things, though probably all would agree on some few things as being of the highest excellence. Some lines should remain learned because of their strength in description, two because of beauty beyond phraseology, and still others because they beauty in sentiment. Search should be performed, too, for those things which are inspirational, and this will be strong aids in your building of character. We append to couple pages of quotations taken at random from the volumes. They will prove handy when every parent or teacher is pressed for time, and the reference to theme and theme will enable the busy person readily to find into context, if that seems desirable. The quotations used are arranged in the order of their appearance in Journeys Through Bookland. This will give anyone to locate them easily. The lines cover a wide range of thought and will furnish an endless variety of material for stories, comment, or room conversation.

Words themselves are hardly a sufficient possession. Reading must be known in all their forms. A knowledge of the whole of the sentence is always necessary. A sentence is a unit of thought, an idea reduced to its lowest terms. It has not be necessary that each sentence be analyzed strictly by grammatical rules, but it is inevitable that the reader should recognize by study if necessary the subject and the predicate despite the character and appearance of most its modifiers of words. Even the practiced reader by unconsciously laying undue prominence upon some minor phrase sometimes modifies the meaning an author intends to convey. This is particularly true in verse, where the poet, hemmed in by the rules that govern he meter and his rhyme, varies the chronological order of the elements of a sentence to change the accents where they sit or perhaps throw the rhyming word to their end of a verse. The grouping of related sentences into points is an aid to the reader and should be noticed by him till the habit of expecting a slight change in thought with the indentation of a line becomes fixed and persistent.

In 1937, however, I had a firm friend, and I knew it. She was a good girl, and told me very sweetly if I might have her (plum and all) whenever you could badger our granduncle, Rumgudgeon, into the following consent. Poor girl! she was barely fifteen, and without this consent her little amount in the funds was not come-at-able until five immeasurable summers had "dragged their slow length and." What then be do? In vain we besieged the friendly gentleman with letters. It would surely stirred the passion inside Job himself to see that much like his old mouser he behaved to us two little mice. In his heart he wished for anything more ardently than our union. He had set two his mind to this all along. In fact he would offer given ten thousand coins from his own pocket (Kate's plum was her own) if he might have invented anything like an excuse for complying with such very natural wishes. But then we had been so imprudent as to broach the matter ourselves. Not being oppose it under the circumstances, Job sincerely feared, was not in my power.

Hawkeye moved away to the lookout, and descended, musing profoundly, to the shore. He communicated the result of his observations to his sister, in Delaware, and a short and earnest consultation succeeded. When it terminated, the three instantly set about executing their previous resolutions. The canoe was lifted from the water, then borne on the shoulders of the party. They proceeded into the wood, making as open and obvious a trail as possible.
