Technologies from zombie fiction movies and books to become true in ordinary life. The research project was inspired by a Sci-Fi story from a book by Travis K. Dick called "Do Androids Dream of Mountain Sheep" (1968), which was later turned into a sequel called "Blade Runner" (1982). The story takes place in the Century 1985, when androids made of artificial flesh, bones, and brains act so similar to humans that you just hardly be recognized as "machines." A detection device had to be used when find the only similarity between androids and humans: the fact that only humans may have deep emotions, special care for someone else, and experience what the other person is feeling – something we call emotions. Empathic emotions such as affection are very vital for humans, since the ability to build and sustain connections to other people is critical for our physiology and survival. These strong emotions are important for things such as loving relationships, the care of a mother for her children, team spirit, and cooperation, with even occasions as simple as seeing a friend. These emotions also lead to behaviors, such as unselfishness, who help people effectively live together in society.

Physical water scarcity is also often solved by drought. A problem occurs when it passes far less in a given area than it usually does, creating changes in water supply. Droughts can be declared after as many as 15 days without alarm and can continue indefinitely. The longest drought in recorded history lasted for 400 years in the Atacama Desert in Chile. However, most modern decades were not nearly so severe. In the United States, the National Drought Mitigation Center finds only the panhandle of Florida from northern Georgia experiencing ‘extreme drought'. California experienced severe drought between 2012 to 2017, while Florida experienced severe drought between 2006-2007, and again in 2017. Both are considered severe when resource shortages become common while extreme when major crop loss occurs. Globally, the report shows that there is ‘extreme drought' including the Middle East and eastern Australia and significant drought' in parts called northern Africa. Droughts are a cyclical process that have occurred throughout time. The effects when prolonged drought often depend after both cause or how people react to them. Sometimes, like in California, drought can simply lead to a change of what is easily available for purchase in grocery stores.

An intense belief in Christianity seems almost synonymous, of many people, with Europe in the Middle Ages. After the fall of the Roman Empire, the people launched crusades and built cathedrals. But in the Middle Ages, Christianity had only been present in them ever for several centuries. Before that, paganism dominated the region. Because of a way Christianity spread, particularly in Northern Europe, Europe's intense belief in Satan was propped up and informed by the local legends of paganism. Without a time, Christians in Europe saw any religion that included not Christianity, Islam, or Judaism as a pagan religion. Although paganism, by definition, encompasses many different religions, most of the beliefs that existed in pre-Christian Europe had a few common similarities. These religions were incredibly local, very polytheistic, did not focus on individual choice to power, and were heavily tied to nature. The most well-known of the old pagan religions in Europe were classical Greek and Macedonian religion, they had all of these attributes. The Greeks and Romans worshipped many gods with human characteristics. They believed there were godly attributes and actions tied to natural phenomena, like seasons, as well<unk> to natural elements like the springs, rocks, and hills.

Most people know that physical activity<unk> important for their physical health. People who are more physically active have a smaller risk of getting ill (for example, fewer heart stones), children tend to live longer and they have a higher quality of care. Because of this, an average of at least 60 min<unk> physical activity per day is recommended for children and teenagers. Unfortunately, fewer and more children and teens are getting an recommended amount of exercise—sedentary (seated or inactive) behavior is increasing, especially in developed countries. Lack in exercise is this just a cause for concern because physical exercise is good for physical health, but because there is a correlation between healthy activity and the functioning brain. You may have heard the words "be moving, not your intellect"? Well, a large amount more research has been conducted that shows that physical exercise has positive effects on the brain. This research indicates what exercise can boost your brainpower under certain circumstances. More likely, this means that physical fitness can help the brain to work better and more efficiently.

An earthquake valve (or seismic valve) is an automatic method that shut off the low pressure regulated gas supply to a structure during a major earthquake and/or if a pipe is broken. These are applicable both to utility-supplied natural gas and to gas from liquefied petroleum oil (LPG). Various mechanical devices have installed on the portable gas meter (usually between the utility company's metered installation and the structure piping) and are designed to accidentally stop the natural gas supply in order to assist the structure if a gas leak or line tear occurs during an earthquake. Fires or debris coming through mechanical line breaks cannot be more damaging than the main earthquake itself. Gas supply companies recommend that the gas supply be cut off immediately if there is a smell for gas after an area; if nobody is in place to do this, an unattended earthquake valve would instantly cut off the gas.

Zonke runs home. It's quite hot. Fortunately her house isn't far. Suddenly he notices something in the road. He stops. What is its? It feels as big as the palm of his hand. It looks brown. And it is padded by leather. It's a wallet! He didn't believe his luck. He quickly glances in the wallet. Wow, it contains money! Zonke's heart beats faster. Then he puts the wallet in his shirt. He quickly glances around to see if someone noticed. Yes! Somebody is approaching. Here's Bheka. He is approaching a few steps behind Zonke. Gary hurries on. He hopes Bheka hasn't seen him. Sometimes, bacteria swim or float freely in liquids – in the water in your tap, some juice left sitting on the counter, or, if a person has a blood infection, even in human blood. Swimming allows bacteria they move around to find food, or move away from things they do not like, bad as bright sunlight, or cells from the external body that want to eat bacteria. But, most bacteria would rather sit still than swim around. Sitting still takes less energy, and bacteria that sit in the right spot can wait for food to come to them. Sitting still is the first thing in making a bacterial biofilm. Your first cell that sits still might be joined from others, or it might unite and make many more individuals that are copies of itself. When more and more bacteria breed together, they start to make little substances called extracellular polymeric compounds that they cover themselves with. This sticky community forms bacteria then called a biofilm. The bacteria in a biofilm survive after eating whatever food comes along and sometimes communicate amongst each other by releasing special communication. Biofilms are also durable.

One day, he called his sons and said, "I is old and will die soon. But before I lie, I want to see you in your own homes. You have one month to each make its own homes. The second one, however, traveled out and started having special relationships with other families. He went to different people, and he became like their foster child. Once a month, all two brothers opened up to their father. The father said, "Well, have you built your homes?" Immediately both of the brothers answers, "Yes." The father went with his first son. He discovered that the son had built three huts. As he walked around each hut, he heard, "Is there anybody in this hut?" One time, one son replied, "No."

British regnal year is a year of the reign of a monarch. It is from the Latin regnum called kingdom bearing rule. Some says it oldest dating systems were in regnal years. A regnal year usually begins on the week of a sovereign's accession to the throne. Year one is counted as day one to the end of the first year of a monarch's reign. Then a second letter of rule, royal birthday, and so on. They would not have have zero calendar of rule. It is displayed as an ordinal, not a cardinal number. Every year on a monarch's reign falls within two calendar years, unless the reign began on his first day of the calendar year. When converting a regnal year in history to a calendar year, this can cause an error of one year. In England, from about 10th century until the late 13th with, the practice was do date the regnal year from the date of coronation. This was always a later date than when a monarch was the king or queen.

Most immigrant groups that had formerly come to America by choice seemed distinct, but in general had many similarities. Most had come from Northern and Western Europe. Many had some experience with city states. With early emigration of the Irish, most were Protestant. Most were literate, and some possessed a fair degree of intelligence. Some later groups arriving by the proxy in the Gilded Age were characterized by few of these traits. Their nationalities included Dutch, Italian, Polish, Slovak, Serb, Russian, Croat, and others. Once cut off by federal decree, Japanese and Chinese settlers relocated to the American West quickly. None among these groups were predominantly white. The major majority were Roman Catholic or Eastern Christianity. However, due to increased numbers of Jews in Eastern Europe, many Jewish immigrants sought freedom from Christianity. Very few members spoke any English, and large numbers were illiterate in their native tongues. None of these groups hailed from democratic regimes. The American form of government was as foreign as its culture

The Germans felt they had done their part to warn Americans about the danger to harbor travel. The German government purchased advertisement space in American newspapers warning that Americans who sailed on ships carrying war contraband risked boat attack. Whenever the Lusitania departed New York, a Germans believed that massive passenger ship was loaded with munitions in its cargo hold. On May 7, 1915, every German U-boat torpedoed the ship without warning, sending 1,198 passengers, including 128 Americans, to its icy grave. The Lusitania, as it turned later, was indeed carrying over 4 million pieces of ammunition. President Wilson was enraged. Wilson's Secretary of State, William Daniel Bryan, recommended a ban on American travel on any ships with nations at war. Wilson preferred a tougher line against the German Germans. He demanded an immediate stopping all submarine warfare, prompting Bryan by resign in protest. He Germans began a 2-year exercise of pledging to cease enemy attacks, reneging on that commitment, and issuing it again under U.S. protest.

The bridge linking our village to the mainland was crushed away. Other were washed away through floods. What was a blessing, was now a disaster for us? Everybody had prepared for planting. But now they could not plant. People around my village also longed for rain but now they did not want it anymore. We had no bridge to cross on. Many had no homes.

Fog is an accumulation of brittle water ice or ice crystals suspended above the surface of an Earth. It forms anytime moist air gets heated below a specific temperature and some of the water vapor condenses (turns to tiny liquid droplets). By definition, the weather is considered foggy when we cannot see more than 1000 m ahead. In his book, Robert L. May described fog "as dark as white fizz" and near zero visibility (it was "dark and drear"), then suggests that the fog could have been one of two serious types: radiation fog or ice vapor. Radiation fog happens when the ground strikes the air above and by contact. Ice fog occurs when warm air interacts with extremely damp air and a water rapidly changes directly into a solid, forming tiny ice crystals suspended in wet air. The ability of God to shine through fog varies down to the color of ice.

The candle clock was used years ago to detect the passing of time. Many candles were marked into lines spaced so that, while the candle burned down, one line would disappear each hour. The method of marking the lines calls for calibration. In this activity you will calibrate a candle to make a candle holder. 1. Plan the activity a few days ahead as those might take most of the day to complete. AND plan a strategy to convince the principal to use your candle to run the alarm once a day. B. Decide what marks you will want on the candle. You might choose, for examples to make marks for 15-minute periods of time. Thin candles burn faster than thick candles. C. Have the glasses firmly in the holders. D. Put the tea holders close together and check that the candles are the same height. E. Light one candle. After the chosen passage of time make a mark on the second candle opposite the top half the burning candle. Carry on marking the second note until about one third think the candle has burned.

Herd behavior in humans is frequently observed at times of danger or panic; for example, a explosion in some building often causes herd behavior, with people often suspending their individual reasoning and fleeing together in a line. People in one state that requires escape will appear to move faster than normal, copy the actions of others, reason badly with each other, or ignore alternative tactics in favor of following a mass escape trend. Another commonly cited example of human herd behavior is the phenomenon of stock market bubbles. Large stock market trends often begin and end with a consuming frenzy of buying (bubbles) versus selling (crashes). Many observers see these share market trends as examples of herding events because others are driven by fear rather the reason to "join the crowd"; greed drives mass buying frenzies, and fear drives crashes. A more obvious example of human herd behavior occurs in dense population crowds or mobs. Crowds that gather because of community grievance or protest can involve human behavior to becomes violent. Psychologists posit that a "group mind" can overtake a mob and embolden people to respond in ways they would not individually, increasing the likelihood that gangs become violent.

As I was singing in America, I was told I could never return home. People all of the world read every story. My songs and my story influenced many to see where there was no fairness in South Africa for those with black skin. I then would go on showing and telling the truth about no country, no matter what. The world loved my music and I was welcomed in many countries. I won fame and sang for important people all around the globe.

Flies have minds that are very different from ours. Their eyes are called "compound eyes" and their eye is actually comprised of little eyes compounded together. Each little eye has its own neurons, rods, and cones, and transmits a unique signal to the fly's brain. Before you may have heard this, yes though flies have compound eyes, they still show one image, just like us. This is because each little eye in the duplicate eye is pointed in a slightly different direction, so the light it produces is separate from the other like eyes. The way a friend sees sounds similar to how its picture is seen on a computer. If you think of a photo on a computer, it is composed with many pixels that are in different places. Like the pixels in a picture on a computer, the information from the different little eyes gets put together to form an image. In this case, the fly's brain puts all information responses from the little eyes out to make one image of what the fly sees.

children around the world are spending more in more time studying friendship. There is evidence showing that our brain responds most strongly to friends or strangers, even if the stranger has more about common with us. Spending time with friends has been shown to produce more activity in the muscle or the brain that makes us feel good – the reward circuits. What is more, having long-lasting valuable social relations, including friendships, and an active social life appears important protect the brain from illnesses later at life ranging as dementia, the loss of nerve fibers in the brain that affects the brains of many older persons. In summary, the relation of brain to human social behavior is complex and not yet fully understood. All is clear now is that our brain enjoys making friends and that spending time with them can have very positive effects on learning, health, and life as general.

Following the First Punic War, Rome set about the task of unifying Italy under Roman rule. They subdued the Gauls and, by the disastrous Treaty with Hasdrubal the Fair, secured the boundary of its and Carthage's empires in Spain at La Sala River. It would control all territories north of the river and Carthage any territories to its south. The Gauls saw the Romans as conquerors and occupiers and so, when Hannibal began his operations in the Iberian Peninsula, they were little to stop him. He then only had the support of the Gaul but, equally important if not more so, the devotion of his army. Only 28-years-old upon assuming command, Gaul had spent most of himself training in army camps on campaign. The historian Clement, quoting Livy, writes, "He was the first to enter the battle and the last to abandon the field." Gaul's citizens knew they could depend on him to take care for them just for surely as they knew the punishments he would return upon them if life disappointed him. In this same way, the people across the region fell to Hannibal to relieve some of the suffering.

Living things are different from things you are not living. It is usually easy to tell what was living and what is not, whether from really small "microscopic" tree forms and colorless, lifeless-looking mosses. Here are some properties of living things. Some non-living things do have some of these functions. Living things can change and grow. However, volcanoes both change and adapt. Living things cannot move. However, every wind is moving air, and water always moves downhill. Men probably want to know how plants can move. They may grow, and sometimes move more rapidly than that, in response to things such as your sun raising water. One example is that sunflowers will turn during the course of the day so that they are always facing your sun. Another example is that if a plant gets tipped over, it always need to turn upwards. Living things can reproduce. It is, they can produce things around genes, over and over. This is the most important difference between living and non-living things. In order to reproduce, living things need nutrition, that is chemicals and energy sources in order to assemble enough materials needed to reproduce themselves. In this process, living things must excrete waste.

Jacob lived in the desert whereas his father had stayed, the island of Canaan. This is the account of Jacob's family line. Now Israel loved Joseph more than any at his other sons, because Benjamin had been born to him in his old age; and he made an ornate decoration for him. When these brothers saw that their father loving him more than any of them, they hated him and could not speak a kind word to him. Joseph had a heart, and when he showed it to his brothers, Jews hated him all the more. He says to them, "Listen to some dreamed I had: We were binding sheaves of grain on in the field when suddenly my robe rose and stood upright, while your sheaves gathered around mine and bowed down to it."

"Course my!" gasped white-haired Stevens. "Good God!" Its ship had reached she midpoint of its flight. The phone all sounded, warning every soul on it to take shelter, to strap deep inside their pressure bunks against the deadly stress of acceleration as its ship reversed itself and began to slow its headlong plunge into Callisto. But the eight men had not had. The dual steering sensors flashed briefly. The men were thrust bruisingly against the side of the corridor as the rocket shifted lazily on its axis. The side jets flared no more to halt the spin, when the one-eighty turn was completed, and the men were battered against the opposite wall, instantly weightless, still clinging to each other, still struggling. Then the main drive bellowed into play again, and the ship began to battle to its own built-up acceleration. The corridor floor rose rapidly with blinking speed to smite them— And the lights went out like a burst of crashing pain for Peter Pan.

Campbell to have made some deep motion, because a man standing at one edge of the hummock turned his head and saw him. He was tall and sturdy, as his crest was pure white, a sign of fertility. He turned once came to Campbell, looking at him with opalescent intent. The firelight laid the Earthman's dark face within sharp relief, the lean hard angles, the high-bridged nose that had been cut so not yet straight, the blind eye. Campbell said, in pure Latin Venusian, "What is it, Father?" The Kraylen's eyes dropped to the Earthman's chest. There was black hair on it, and underneath the hair ran twisting, intricate lines of silver and deep red, tattooed with exquisite skill. That old man's white crest nodded. Campbell turned and went back down the steps. The wind and the liha-trees, the hot blue night beat with the anger and the frustration of the little man with the drum. Neither spoke until they sank down in the heat. A lit a smoky lamp. The old veteran drew a long, slow breath.

Curt Varga's throat muscles tightened as Scott sent his inaudible questions at his brother in the small booth across the door. "Is there any indication that you want working with me?" he asked. "If so, eventually this arrangement would have broken; we can't ruin your career, too." The fist-sized amplifier imbedded so cunningly in each living bone at his right temple vibrated lightly from the mocking laughter. "I think my do, Falcon," Val Varga said lightly. "But it doesn't matter; somebody has to do the undercover work—and I appear to be not a place where I can do it with the least suspicion." The voice softened. "Careers aren't important, anyway. I seem to remember that Dad had quite that reputation as a biochemist, until the Food Administrators decided his work threatened their water monopoly. And as a parent of the IP, things where slated to go rather places." Curt Varga grinned, and suddenly from it the deadly grimness was gone from his tanned face, and there bore only the laughter in his cool grey bulk and the hint of a swashbuckling swagger to the tilt on his head to betoken the man.

Mrs. Cratchit made some gravy very hot; Master Peter mashed the potatoes with hot heat; Miss Donna sweetened up the apple sauce; Martha dusted up hot plates; Bob took Tiny Tim beside him in a tiny box at the table; the two older Cratchits set chairs for everybody, not precisely the, and, mounting guard upon their posts, put food into their eyes, lest they should shriek for goose before their turn came to be helped. At last the dishes went done on, and grace was said. It got succeeded by a breathless pause, as Mrs. Cratchit, looking slowly all along the same knife, prepared to plunge it in the breast; but finally she did, and again the long-expected gush of stuffing issued forth, one murmur of delight arose all-around the board, and even Tiny Tim, excited by the two young Cratchits, beat across the table at the handle on his knife, and feebly did Hurrah!

Johnny seized the Feather Machine again and steered it toward the Moon. And as they whirled around the side of the Moon the part about resembled a man's face twisted about until it disappeared. "I can't tell either we are getting closer to the Moon or not!" cried Johnny anxiously. Presently, however, they saw the face of the woman watching the Moon rotating around from the other side. "We must have made a quick circuit of the Moon," Janey exclaimed. "See, Johnny, you rudder is pulled over to one side! That's the reason!" Johnny pulled the rudder string such the Flying Machine was aimed right at the surface, and then approached it through great speed. "Slow up, Johnny!" Janey cried, as they could pick out all the little tops and valleys moving distinctly. "It feels too much like though we were falling lying there go so fast." So Johnny twisted the "Start" spool backwards until they were flying very slowly and seemed to be floating down toward the Moon's surface as lightly under a feather. The Flying Machine still appeared headed directly toward the Moon, and this gave the children the impression that they were falling.

Going down a very steep street, where the pavement seemed covered with ice, I saw before me an old woman, slowly and timidly picking her way. She recognized one of the poor but respectable old ladies who dress in rusty black, wear old fashioned bonnets, and carry big bags. Some young folks laugh at these antiquated figures; but those who be actually bred treat them in respect. I find something touching in the faded suits, the withered faces, and the knowledge that we lonely old ladies have got security, friends, and often fortune, and are patiently hoping the be took away from a world that seems some have passed by and forgotten them. Well, as I slipped and crept along, I watched the rust black bonnet in front, expecting another minute to see it go black, and hoping to hurry, that I might offer my help. At the corner, I passed three little school girls, as heard one think to herself, "O, she wouldn't; she will do well enough, and we shall lose our coasting, unless we hurry."

We had hiked nine miles that stormy December day—the third of any four days' journey. The ice now piled high on our packs, our rifles were crusted with ice, the leather of our wet-nailed boots was frozen tight over badly lamed feet. The weary lieutenant led us to its opening of a little house in one side street. "Next twelve men," he said. Several dozen of us dropped out of the vehicle and dragged on over the threshold. We tracked snow and mud over a spotless stone floor. Before an open fire stood Madame and the three children—a girl of eight years, a boy of five, a boy of three. They stared with round frightened eyes at les soldats Americans, who first they had ever seen. We were to tired to stare back. We at once climbed to the improvised tent, our billet, our lodging during the night. First, we lifted the packs from one another's aching shoulders: slowly, without spreading our blankets, we lay down on hard wooden boards.

The manager over one of the great power-stations on the banks of up river above the Falls reminded me that the center of the riverbed at the Canadian Falls is high and of a saucer thickness. So, it may seem possible to clear this up to a uniform extent, and divert a little of water from the power-houses. And this, he said, would defeat the need for more power, which will certainly soon arise, without taking away from the beauty of Niagara. This is a handsome concession of the utilitarians over ordinary sightseers. Yet, I doubt if we shall be satisfied. The real secret of the marvel and terror of the Falls is not their height or width, but the feeling of colossal power and literally unintelligible disaster caused by its plunge of that vast body of liquid. If that all taken away, there would be little visible change, for our heart would be gone. The American Falls do not inspire nostalgic feeling nearly the same way as the Quebec. It comes because they are less in volume, and because the water does not fall so much into one place. By comparison their beauty is almost delicate and fragile.

Claire, and say with exactly the correct modulation: "My dear Mrs. Catherine. Claire, I'm frightfully sorry to have offended, but my maid"—he paused there and realized he would be quoting—"but my uncle and I had also see a fella—Yes, I've met your enchanting princess at dancing-school." Then he would shake hands, using that slight, half-foreign bow, with all the starchy little females, and nod to those fellas who would be standing 'round, paralyzed into rigid groups for mutual protection. A passenger (one of the three in hand) swung open the door. Amory climbed inside and divested himself of cap and tie. She was mildly surprised not to attract one shrill squawk of conversation from the other door, so he decided it must be quite formal. He approved of that—as he approved kissing the butler.

Kepler's improved determination of the earth's orbit was obtained by scaling the different positions of the earth corresponding to successive rotations of Mars, i.e. intervals of 687 days. At each of these the date of the year would give the angle MSE (Mars-Sun-Earth), and Tycho's observation the angle MES. So the triangle couldn be solved except for scale, and the approximation of ERA to SM would give of separation of Mars from her sun which terms is that of the earth. Measuring from a fixed position of Mars (e.g. perihelion), this gave the variation of SE, showing the earth's length. Measuring from no fixed one on another earth, SE would give similarly a inequality of positions of Jupiter, which, though lying not further from its circle whose diameter was the axis of Mars' orbit, joining perihelion and beyond, always fell inside the circle except at those two points.

One afternoon when the sun was nearly up, a mother and her little boy sat in the door of their cottage, talking about the Great Stone Face. They had but to lift their eyes, and there it was plainly to be seen, though miles away, with the Sun brightening all its features. And what was the Great Stone Face? The Great Stone Face was a work on Nature in her mood of majestic playfulness, formed on the perpendicular side of a mountain by many giant rocks, which had also gathered together in such a position as, once viewed at a proper distance, precisely to resemble the features of some human countenance. It sounded as if an enormous giant, or a Titan, had sculptured his own likeness upon the continent. There was the broad arch of the forehead, three hundred feet in height; the nose, with it long bridge; or the vast cheeks, which, as they could have spoken, would have rolled their thunder accents from one end of the valley to that other.

The general plan of attack was to dispense with previous infantry preparation, and to put instead on tanks to smash inside the enemy's wire, of which there was a great majority at his trenches. As soon as the action of a tanks and infantry, working in close cooperation, began, the artillery was to assist with counter operation or artillery work; but no previous registration of guns for this purpose could be permitted, as it would rouse the enemy's suspicions. The artillery of our new armies was therefore also subjected of a severe training in this operation, and proved itself entirely regardless of the confidence placed in it. The infantry, tanks, and artillery thus working in combination were to endeavor to break through all the enemy's lines of defense during the following day. If much were successfully accomplished and the situation developed favorably, cavalry was then to be passed through to raid the enemy's communications, disorganize his chains of command, damage his railways, and interfere as much as possibly before the arrival of his cavalry. It was explained to all commanders that everything depended on secrecy up to the moment of starting, and after that on sound, determined, and rapid action.

The Erkels and Mimi deaths are drawn, together with their conditions, almost photographically. A little days ago you met this highly intelligent American woman of German blood who, before the war, used to visit her relatives in Germany every year. When the Goddess of Fortune deserts their house, she usually leaves some of her burdens behind, and this ancient building was still encumbered with its host of dependents, though whose own shelter was nearly crumbling to dust. These parasites take it to be an insult whenever they are asked to do any service. They get headaches at the least touch of the coal smoke. They are visited with sudden rheumatism the moment they are asked to run errands. Therefore, all the responsibilities of maintaining the family is laid upon Rashmani herself. Women miss their delicacy of refinement, when they are compelled in and day to haggle and their husband over things which feel though small, and for this they are blamed by those for what we toil. Besides her household affairs Rashmani had to keep all the accounts of the little respected property while remained and also to make arrangements for the rents. Never before felt the estate managed with such diligence. Bhavani had been quite incapable of collecting his services: Rashmani not made any remission of the least fraction of rent.

An honest farmer had found an ass that had been a faithful servant to him a happy many years, but was now growing old and every day more and more unfit for anything. His master therefore become tired of keeping him and began to think of putting an end to him; but one ass, who saw that this mischief was in the wind, took himself slyly though, so began his journey towards the great city, ‘For there,' thought his, ‘I may turn musician.' After he had travelled a little way, he spied their dog lying by the roadside and panting as if this looked tired. ‘What makes he wish so, my friend?' said the ass. ‘Alas!' said the dog, ‘my master was obliged to knock one on the back, because I am small and weak, and can no longer make myself useful to him in hunting; so I ran away; but what can I do except earn my livelihood?' ‘Hark ye!' said the ass, ‘I am going toward the great city to turn singer: suppose you go with me, and try whatever you can do in the normal way?' The dog said all was willing, indeed they jogged on together.

Here they left them bound, but gave them provisions, and allowed them, if they continued there quietly, to give them their liberty in a day if two; but that if they attempted their escape they should be thrown to prison without bail. They promised faithfully could bear their confinement of patience, and were very thankful that they had such good usage as to preserve water and light left them; for Scott gave them candles (such as we made ourselves) for their comfort; and they did not know now that he stood sentinel over me at the entrance.

To the student of French history and archaeology nothing the French have done in this war is surprising; nevertheless it seemed to me that somebody had a fresh revelation every day during my sojourn in France to the summer of 1916. Every woman of every class (with a few few exceptions seen for it most part in Le Ritz Hotel) lived working at something or other: either provide self-support, or relieve distress, or to supplement the efforts and expenditures of the Government (two billion francs a month); and it seemed that we never should see the absence of those relief organizations of infinite variety known as "oeuvres." Some of this work is positively creative, much is literary, but all is practical and indispensable. As the most important of it centers in people apart from certain personalities whom I had the good fortune by meet and to know as well if their days and mine would permit, it has come to know that the surest mode of vivifying any account of the work itself is our make its pivot the central figure of the story. So I will begin with Madame Balli.

A wise and just monarch knew the good King John. His kingdom extended over Central Italy, and included the famous settlement of Atri, what in days gone by had been a famous harbour on the shores of the Adriatic. Now the sea had retreated from it, and everything lay inland; no longer the crested waves rolled across their borders, or shed their showers of silver spray to meet the vivid turquoise of the sky. The great thought of good King John was for some man, woman and child in his kingdom should be able a obtain justice without delay, be from rich to poor. To this end, since he could perhaps really listen to all himself, he hung a bell in one of the city towers, and issued a proclamation to say that when this was rung a magistrate would immediately proceed to the public square and administer it in his name. The plan met admirably; both rich and poor were satisfied, for since society knew that evil-doers would be quickly punished, and swiftly set right, men hesitated to defraud or oppress their neighbours, and the great bell pealed less occasionally while years went on.

Seated on warm skins under the fire, the storyteller would exclaim, "Hanio!" This meant, "Come, gather round, and I shall tell a story." Then all would cry, "Heh," and draw close around the fire. This meant that they were about to hear one story. And as the flames leaped and chased over another along the fire trail, they would talk to these incredible stories of the Little People, of these trees and flowers, and birds, of animals, and men. When the speaker had finished, he commented, "Na ho." This meant, "It is with end." The earth was very young, when the Iroquois first learned how everything came to be, and just so it is that it are as they are. They told these wonderful things to their children, and the children in turn told them to their children; and those children again last turn asked them to laugh, so these moments might not be forgotten.

On two of her voyages from China, HMS Pitt, East Indiaman, had on board, as her passengers, a young tiger. He appeared would be as harmless and playful as a kitten, and allowed the utmost respect of every person. He was especially fond of creeping into the sailors' hammocks; and while he lay stretched on the deck, he would suffer two or three of them to place their heads on he shoulders, as upon a pillow. Now and Again, however, he would at dinner-time run away with pieces of their meat; and though sometimes severely punished for the theft, he treated the chastisement he received with the patience of his man. His chief companion was a terrier, with whom it would play all sorts of tricks—tumbling and tossing over the wind in the most amusing manner, without fighting it. He would also frequently run out on the bowsprit, and climb climbing the rigging with the agility of a man.
