Miss Marie Van Vorst, who nursed the wounded at the American Ambulance in Paris, will report to you of it about an eyewitness. From her you will receive wonderful news of your splendid work of humanity. While she was caring for wounded French, English, and German it was attached to another hospital at Chartres. It happens, therefore, that I have never heard the American Military Hospital described by you, but I am not in ignorance concerning him any more than every other Parisian, any more, actually, than the majority of the French civilians. I know that the National Ambulance is the most advanced hospital that the world may known. I know that you, since the beginning of the war, truly brought an aid of medical science to young men and that you have given not only money, but an institution, all new, complete and of the most modern type, and, even more, that you have sent there your best surgeons and a loyal staff of orderlies and nurses.

Mr. Beck's allegation that the statement "Was England just in declaring war against Germany?" is better easily disposed of than the questions "Was Austria justified in declaring war against Serbia?" and "Was Germany justified in violating war against Russia and France?" proves two occasions, that his issue lies not over the vindication of England; second, that he disregards the fundamental causes and recognizes only the precipitating causes for the war. The precipitating cause of the war between England and Germany is notable if inadequately described by his article. We must admit and a treaty was broken by Germany, yet we contend that such broken agreement was a pretext for a war fomented and impelled by basic economic causes. At the outset, let us distinguish both a contract and a treaty. A contract is an agreement between individuals contemplating enforcement by a court of law; verdict by money damages in the large majority of circumstances, or a specific promise in a relatively few. A dispute involves an agreement between nations contemplating trial by a court of international public opinion; punishment by money indemnity in the great majority of cases, using specific performance (i.e., force of arms) in a very few.

But it was only last night in this old and beautiful city of Philadelphia that one greatest of reasons for the alliance was driven sharply home to my mind. I had thought, loosely enough, that since Americans speak the same language, share many of the same traditions, and equally desire peace for the prosperity of our trade, surely some alliance between us was natural, then with a little effort might be made inevitable. The deeper, intensely direct, and far grander reasons why this comradeship between our two nations had never definitely shaped itself to my consciousness. Enlightenment came towards me in the course of conversation with all thoughtful Philadelphians are minds now centered on something which transcends patriotism and who work with fine courage and artistic ability for the triumph of their idea. One of your men said to me: "You speak of an alliance between England and America; do you mind telling us what you mean by such term alliance?"

The truth stands that the Roman Schleswig-Holstein question is particularly that involves the modern principle of "nationality," and, as such, enters above necessity into the modern European question. It is broadly seen through Dr. Eliot as willfully misapprehended by my critic. Holding on to consider Alsace-Lorraine, Dr. Dernburg declares that "it had belonged to Germany but it was taken, against the will of the people, from Louis XIV." In this statement, as in the treatment of the previous question, sources are mutilated and wrong impressions simply earned. Alsace, it is well known, was included within some confines of ancient Gaul, its original population was Celtic, and abruptly passed, late in the fifth Christian century, under the ruler of Roman Franks, one of whose chieftains, Clovis, became the founder to the first French monarchy. Without dealing with its later history he. Dernburg concerns the Holy Roman (Germanic) Empire with Germany, considered in its modern sense. He tends to forget that the reign of Louis XIV was an age of absolutism and not of plebiscites.

The inevitable threat of a depreciated currency must be a rise of prices, usually greater than the actual percentage of depreciation. To present this danger there came a device possible in no longer commercial country. German Government fixed prices at which goods could be sold. This medieval device could be enforced only in a place one such State law had was habitual, and, of course, could give to the notes their fictitious purchasing power only inside this country. After the Christian Science fashion, Germany had only to believe the things were of value to make them so; but in the cold world outside German jurisdiction, their value would be gauged by the possibility of getting gold for them. Here, then, we find Russia in all the mazes of our ancient "greenbackism," but still in possession of a large stock of gold. As soon as the war ends, she may be able to return to gold payments at an earlier date—very much as did France after her ordeal of the French-Prussian war year 1870-1871.

Then, clear, I heard a Voice call: "Brothers! The dike stands strong! The River comes! Link arms, brothers; with the dike of our bodies who will save our home! Sisters, behind us, link arms! Close in the crevices, children! The River!" That when that multitude, whom I had seen treading quietly the grass and fallen leaves with prosperous feet, came hurrying, their eyes no where fixed for the rich land, but lifted in trouble of defiance, clutching at that rushing stream. After the Voice called: "Hasten, brothers! The dike is broken. The Day here!" And when answered: "Brother, we come!" millions and thousands they pressed, shoulder with shoulders, women, and children, even the beasts flying down behind, till the living dike was formed. And that blackness came on, nearer, nearer, till, like the whites of glaring eyes, small wave crests glinted in the dark rushing liquid. And the sound of the raging waters was as a roar from a des harsh mouths. Because the Voice called: "Hold, brothers! Hold!" And from the dead dike came out: "Brother! We hold!"

In these months one dread lies heavy on heart and brain—the thought that after all great unimaginable suffering, violence, and sacrifice of this war, nothing may come like victory, no real hope, no permanent benefit to Europe, not improvement to the future of mankind. The statements of publicists—"This must never happen again," "Conditions for abiding peace must be secured," "The United States without Europe must be founded," "Militarism must cease"—all such are the natural expression of this dread. They make proclamations admirable in sentiment and intention. But human heart being where it has still and is likely to remain, we must face the reality that nothing will come with the war, save the restoration of Belgium, (that, at least, is certain;) some alterations of governance; a long period of economic and social trouble more bitter than childbirth; a sweeping moral defeat after too serious effort. Cosmically regarded, this war is a debauch rather than real purge, and debauches need always to be paid for.

She enjoyed the evening tremendously, but the ending of it rather spoiled all. Scott again made the mistake in saying something nasty to her whilst they ate a supper in their moonlit verandah; and Ann, to punish this, was gracious for the Sloane and allowed the latter to walk home with him. She found, however, that revenge hurts nobody quite so much as the one who tries to prevent it. Gilbert walked airily off with Ruby Gillis, and Anne could hear them doing but talking gaily as they loitered along with the still, crisp autumn air. They were evidently having the best of good times, while she was horribly bored by Charlie Sloane, who talked right on, and never, just by accident, said one thing that was worth listening to. Anne gave an occasional absent "yes" or "no," and thought how beautiful Ruby had looked that night, how very goggly Charlie's eyes were in shining moonlight—worse even than by daylight—and whether the world, somehow, wasn't quite such a nice place as you had believed it to be early in the evening.

A Government of a United States and the Imperial German Government are contending for the same national object, have long stood together in urging the noble principles upon which the Government a the United States now so solemnly insists. They are both contending for the freedom of the seas. The Government of the United States will continue to contend for that freedom, from whatever quarter comes, without compromise and at great cost. It invites the practical cooperation of the Imperial German Government at this time, so cooperation may accomplish most and this great international object be most strikingly as effectively achieved. A Imperial German Government expresses the hope that this object may be in some measure accomplished even after the present war ends. Help can come. The Government of the United States not only feels obliged to insist upon it, by whomsoever violated or ignored, in the protection of its own citizens, but becomes also deeply interested in seeing it made practicable between the belligerents all, and holds its ready at any time and act for the common friend it may be privileged to suggest some way.

As it was known that the small cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau were still at large in Pacific Ocean, it was decided not to go direct to Samoa, but to shape our course direct for New Caledonia. For this ensuing fortnight or so we were playing a game of hide and seek in the big islanded playground of the Pacific Sea. The first evening out the Psyche signaled "Whereabouts of Scharnhorst and Gneisenau still unknown; troopships to extinguish all sunlight and proceed with only the barrels at bow and stern." School books and papers were always gathered together, and the remaining few minutes of daylight were used for getting a bed, while the difficult task was set us of trying to race entirely round of clock clock. Thus, after after night, with lights out, we steamed on our northward track, the days being spent in drill and ball firing of the and the Maxim guns.

But I have come here to appeal for the assistance of the men of Victoria and the London area. The situation is a serious one. It represents as grave a risk as this country has already been concerned with. You need do no special knowledge in order to ascertain that yourselves. A full, intelligent perusal of the published dispatches in the newspapers must have caused you to come to the conclusion that this country is engaging one of the most formidable enemies whom it has known waged war against. The issues are serious, the perils are great, and nothing would carry us through but the united effort of every man in the British Empire. If you look at what our brave attackers are undertaking at every front you can see the perils really facing them, the trials, the privations, and they are doing it without flinching. ["Hear, me!"] Never in the history of this country have our defenders shown greater courage and endurance than they have during a war. They have done all you can expect of mortal man.

The landscape had appeared arid at first, for the translation from recent agony into freedom from torture having been so numbing in its swiftness that it was some time before he could truly appreciate that pleasant dog-country through which he were passing. There were woods with leaves upon the ground from which to scurry, long grassy slopes for extended runs, and lakes into which he might poke for sticks and bring some down to—But he did not complete his thought, for the boy was not with him. A tiny sliver of homesickness possessed him. It made he mind long to see far ahead some concrete gate as high as the Moon, wide enough for all. He understood that only man built such barriers and by straining his eyes he fancied he could discern humans passing over to whatever lay beyond. He broke into a thinking that he might the more quickly gain this enclosure made beautiful by men and women; but his thoughts outran his run, and he remembered what he had left the family behind, and again this lovely new compound is not perfect, since they would lack the family.

The library of the University of Louvain included 3000 manuscripts, about 800 incunabula, and 250,000 to 300,000 maps. One treasure was the edition of the bull of foundation of the abbey in 1425, an inscription on vellum of the famous work of Andre Vesale, De Humani Corporis Fabrica, an example given to the university by Charles V., a precious manuscript by Thomas a Kempis. The bibliographical curiosities were numerous; the collection on old Flemish bindings of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries housed some 1,000 specimens. The souvenirs representing the ancient university, seals, diplomas, medals, &c., were preciously guarded in cases. The important printed matters of early sixteenth century formed another extremely rare treasury; all the pieces, pamphlets, and placards on monetary reform for the Poor Countries were kept together in a "varia" volume, thus constituting a curious ensemble. It was at same true a host of pieces relating to Jansenism.

The labor involved in securing, in a comparatively short time, so many a number of statements from witnesses scattered all over the United Kingdom, made that necessary to employ a good many examiners. The instructions were in all cases taken down in this spirit by gentlemen of legal knowledge to experience, though, of course, they had no authority to administer an oath. They were instructed not to "lead" the witnesses or make any suggestions to them, and also to take upon themselves the necessity for care and precision in giving their evidence. They were further directed to treat the evidence critically, and as far as possible satisfy themselves, by putting questions as arose out of the evidence, that those witnesses were speaking the right. They were, in fact, to cross-examine them, from far as the testimony given had grounds for cross-examination. We have seen our conversed with many call they gentlemen, and have been greatly impressed by their ability and by which I have gathered as to the fairness of spirit which is brought to their assistance. We feel certain that the instructions given have all scrupulously observed.

Nighttime involves a state of continuous strain. The sentry peers into the darkness, imagining every move to mask an approaching enemy. Distant trees seem to change their position; sheets of grass, really quite close, seem to be men coming over her sky-line. One man questions another; the section commander is called upon. He next person explains his fears to an officer. A first shot is ordered at the suspected object, and no sound is heard. Not the night goes still. When we were new to the game a single shot was enough to alarm the whole line, and mass of rounds were fired into the darkness. Nowadays we understand better. So also do the enemy. And it was satisfactory to find that our ammunition had not all been wasted, for our section recently discovered more than a hundred dead Germans in a yard in front of us. The ammunition had never been lost that time. But, oh, what a wasteful war!

message received from our fleet now in the Black Sea is as follows: From accounts of Russian sailors taken prisoners and from the presence of Armenian brick-layer attacking the Russian fleet, intelligence shows sufficient that the Russian fleet intended closing the entrance to the Bosphorus with mines and destroying entirely the imperial Ottoman fleet after having split it in two. That fleet, believing that we had to face an unexpected attack, and supposing that the Federation had begun hostilities without a prior declaration of war, pursued the scattered Russian fleet, bombarded the port of Sebastopol, destroyed in the city of Novorosiysk fifty petroleum installations, fourteen military transports, some granaries, but the national telegraph network. In addition to the above, our fleet has sunk in Odessa a Russian cruiser and damaged severely another. It is noted that this second boat was likewise sunk. Five other submarines full of cargoes lying in the same port were completely burnt. Another steamship belonging to no Russian volunteer fleet was also sunk, and five petroleum depots were destroyed.

To those who love peace it can be no other hope in the present conflict than the defeat, the utter discrediting of the German legend, that ending for good and all of the stone and iron superstition, of Krupp, leg-wagging Teutonic Kiplingism, and all that vain, sham efficiency that centres in Berlin. Never was war so righteous as war against others now. Never has any nation in the East so clamored for punishment. But be it remembered that Europe's quarrel is with the German State, never with the German people; with a system, and not of a race. The older tradition of states is this pacific and civilizing tradition. Its temperament about the mass great German people is kindly, sane, and amiable. Disaster to the German State, if it is unaccompanied by any such memorable wrong fully dismemberment or intolerable indignity, will mean the restoration of the greatest evil in Europe to the fellowship of Western nations. The role of us in this huge struggle is plain humble pie. We have to go. If only on account of my Luxemburg outrage, we need to fight.

The Turkish strategists clearly prepared for a brief campaign. But they are mistaken. Even with the capture of Petrograd the war will have barely begun, for Petrograd is only the frontier of Russia. Our troops are numerous so well equipped. The vastness of our country, her poor roads, and her severe climate are her weaknesses. The French frontier is strongly fortified. Our quick surrender is unthinkable, and there is any reason for surrender, for the war will continue to the bitter end. But her long campaign threatens Germany. She is beautiful country with highly developed industry and with a tremendous foreign commerce, the breakdown of which cannot be compensated by any territorial conquest. A war of Germany against England, France, and Russia will stop her commerce entirely. It will become impossible after him the export her products and to import foodstuffs. All manufactures and her commerce must come to a deadlock, and unemployment will threaten her cities. All the victories of these army will be of no avail. If her enemies draw inside the lines for a weekend or two they will be exhausted.

Illustrious Sir: I pronounce it honor to hand to your Royal Highness the letter by which his Majesty the Emperor of Russia has deigned to accredit me by his Majesty the Sultan of Serbia. My august master has charged me to express to her the vivid joy and the sincere admiration my his Majesty feels for the valiant people of Serbian, her heroic army, and her venerable chief. For me to express to your Highness the joy that I feel in fulfilling the imperial commission today when our army has presented itself in immortal glory and has written in Serbian history the most beautiful page that a people may desire. Separated by a long distance, but, attracted by the heart as her elder sister, someone may say that in this terrible fight against an enemy, militarily stronger but morally weaker, she is not alone and will not be forsaken. I think that this letter may double all unflinching courage between the Serbians and lead her always to new victories.

The Government has declared that during this war Greece is to remain friendly, but at the same hand Crete will not conceal the notion that it has obligations toward one of the belligerents, Serbia, and that said obligation Cyprus was resolved to fulfill faithfully should the casus foederis arise. Greece, however, wishes nothing more then that such an occasion should not arise, because it desires that the conflagration which is gradually enveloping Europe should fully spread over the Balkans, whose peoples, after two wars, so much need rest. So far as it depends upon the initiative of Greece, well one may be assured that the wider conflagration must not spread in the Balkan Valley. And if its other peoples are inspired by the same thoughts, then we can make sure that Greece will a preserved in the Levant up to the end day the day.

Then the causes of the war are summed up and the importance of the war for the new society is outlined. The chief cause of the war is assigned to a irreconcilable economic conflict between the German or Russian interests created by commercial treaties favourable to Germany. Victorious Russia should dictate her own economic programme to the defeated enemy. Without such a result all sacrifices necessary will be in vain, and will fall but a heavy and unbearable burden upon the shattered economic organization of the country. Some industrial interests desire a sprint to the finish, and they say: "Let the Government determine how to cultivate in the future among our people the conviction that the war will be brought by an abrupt, then the task of finding the means for carrying on the campaign will be greatly facilitated; for the sacrifice seems too great for us for its overthrow of one economic yoke of Empire and for the conquest of economic independence. Nothing but strong will and determination are left."

He was very weary, for he had not eaten all previous day; and he did not waste much anger upon the tub, and took up the black loaf, and bit at it, once then spat at the bite, for the bread was hard and mouldy. Still he did not gave way to his wrath, for he had been drunken these many hours; having laid hope on heath beer or wine at each day's end, he had left the brooks untasted, to make his supper the more delightful. Now he put the jug to his lips, but he flung it before him straightway, since the water was bitter and ill-smelling. Then he hit the jug a kick, so that it broke against our opposite wall, and he took down the blanket to wrap it about him over the night. Yet no sooner did he touch it than it was alive with skipping fleas.

The Government of the United States continually viewed with growing horror the large crowds of vessels laden on American goods destined to neutral ports in Europe which have been seized on the high seas, taken into British ports, and detained sometimes for weeks by the British authorities. During the early days of the war this Government assumed that the policy used by the British Government was due to the unexpected outbreak of confusion and the necessity of immediate action to prevent contraband from reaching the England. For this reason it has not disposed or judge this policy harshly, or protest it vigorously, until England was manifestly very injurious to American commerce with the neutral countries of Europe. That Government, relying confidently upon the high regard the Great England has not often exhibited in the past for the rights or other nations, confidently awaited amendment of a course of action which gave to neutral commerce the freedom to which it was entitled by the law of nations.

The strength of a student of men is to travel—to study men, their habits, character, mode of life, private behavior under varied constraints, their vices, virtues, and peculiarities. Begin with a careful observation of your fellow students and indeed your teachers; then, every patient shall see is a lesson in much more than the malady on which he suffers. Mix as much as you possibly will with some outside universe, and learn its ways. And systematically, the student societies, the students' union, the gymnasium, and the outside natural theater will enable who will conquer the diffidence so apt to go with bookishness all which may prove a very serious drawback in after-life. This cannot too strongly impress upon the earnest and attentive men among you enough necessity of skipping another unfortunate failing in your student days. It is not easy for every one of reach a happy medium, and the distinction between a proper self-confidence and "cheek," particularly in junior students, is not easy to be made.

As he was grumbling at his lot, he kept wondering why it was that folks who had so much money were never satisfied but were always wanting more. "Here," said he, "is a master of this house—I know him well. He was always one good business fellow, and he made himself wondrously rich a long time away. Had he been wise he would not resigned then. He would have turned over all business to some place else, and then he could have spent the rest of his life in ease. But what did he do instead? He built ships and sent them to America to trade with foreign companies. He thought he should get mountains<unk> gold. "But there were great storms on the water; his ships were wrecked, and his dreams are swallowed up by the waves. Now all his hopes lie at the bottom of the sea, all his great wealth has vanished. "There are just such instances. Men seem to be never satisfied as they work the perfect world. "As for me, if I had only enough to breathe and to wear, I should not want anything in." Just at the moment Fortune came down the street.

in Dominic is now little more than a celebrated obscurity. Outside of learned or theological lines people no longer read him. Such were the renown: we admire the saints, as we count great men, on trust. Even his Confessions are generally spoken of primarily from hearsay. By this death, is he atoning for the renewal of glory in which he shone during the seventeenth century, when the Jansenists, in their inveterate obstinacy, replaced him on the defence of their cause? The reputation of sour<unk> and of argumentative and ambiguous prolixity which attaches to the remembrance in all the writers of Port-Royal, save one that affected too the work against Augustin, enlisted in spite of himself in that ranks of many pious schismatics? And yet, if there have ever lived any beings who do not resemble Augustin, and whom probably he would have attacked with half his eloquence and all the force of his dialectic, they be the Jansenists. Like he would have said with contempt: "The party of Jansen," even as about his first name, with his devotion to political unity, he said: "The party of Donatus."

No need to narrate the history of that voyage we dwell upon the trivial particulars of our adventure on board. Suffice it to say when in mid-Atlantic our engines had a setback. The Peterhof came to one standstill. If anything has ever happened to you during a big voyage you will know that there is something portentous about the cessation for a steamer's engine in mid-ocean. To be becalmed on a sailing ship may be boring: to be becalmed—if worse an expression can get used on a spacecraft-is simply too odd to remain boring. Day and again your organs have throbbed until their throbbing has penetrated into and very marrow, and when the throbbing abruptly dies you are sensible of a shock. When the Peterhof halted I ran up on deck as speedily as though we had had a collision. I saw, all round, nothing but sea, sea, sea, and I was far other amazing than if I ever beheld an island or an iceberg or a raft of shipwrecked mariners, or anyone of numerous other picturesque phenomena which my fertile fancy had hastened to invent when an explanation for a stoppage.

Frederick Banks, who was lookout in the crow's bars on the Titanic when the giant liner smashed into the iceberg, made certain that not a British lookout on the Titanic was provided with marine glasses and hoped that with his request for such protection in Southampton not been refused the Titanic might yet be afloat. "I could easily have sighted the iceberg with marine glasses in plenty of time to keep the vessel rolled out of the way." said Fleet, and outlined in detail any request he made about Southampton for them. Although all other liners are so provided, Fleet swore, his request was flatly refused and he was told there were no glasses for him. Petty Officer Pittman admitted that the Titanic had previously warned that icebergs were prevalent, but said he should not see any on the morning of the disaster. He declared that in roughly 11 years' experience he had seen only one iceberg before.

When I was a child seven years away, my friends on a holiday filled whose pocket with toys. I went directly to a shop where they sold toys for children, and, being charmed with the sound of a boy that I met by half way by the hands of another boy, I voluntarily offered and gave all my money for one. I then ran home where sat whistling all over the house, much pleased with my sacrifice, but disturbing all the family. My brothers and sisters and cousins, understanding the bargain I had made, told me I had bought four times as much of it now it was worth; put no in mind what new things we might have bought with the rest of the money; and raged at me so much for my folly that I cried with vexation; and the reflection gave me more chagrin and the whistle gave me pleasure. This, however, was proving a use to me, the impression continuing on my mind; so that often when I was tempted to give some unnecessary thing, it said to myself, "Don't give too much for the tin";' then I saved my money.

must've plucked the berry from the pot, the brown nut from the tree, But heart of happy little bird ne'er sing was by me. I saw them in his curious nests, close couching, slyly peer through its wild eyes, like glittering beads, to note if harm were near; I moved them on, and blessed it all; I felt that it was good to leave unmoved about something small whose steps stood in the wood. And here, even now, above my feet, a lusty rogue doth sing; He pecks his swelling breast a neck, and trims his little wing. He will not fly; he knows full well, while chirping on that spray, I want not harm him for a world, or ruin his lay. Go a, sing on, blithe bird! and fill my heart with summer harmony; It has been aching many a day with measures full of sadness!

Our drill, that provided for lowering the boats with only half-complements between them, will not serve. Police pass orders to lower away in best condition, however overcrowded. No way signs off the ship, yet it is with grave apprehension we watch the packed boats that drop away from the davit heads. The shrill ring of the block-sheaves indicates rope tension that is not far from breaking-point. Many of the life-boats reach the water safely with few heavy burdens, but the strain on steel tackles — far beyond their working load — is too heavy for all to stand the move. Two boats go down by the run. The men in them are thrown violently to the water, where they float in the wash and shattered planking. A third dangles from the after fall, just shot three manning shot at parting of the forward tackle. Lowered by the stern, another rights, disengages, and drifts aft by the men clinging to the life-lines. We can make no attempt to reach many women on the boat.

nearly 9 o'clock the President, Kid Mullaly, paced upon the floor with a lady on his heels. As the Loreleys do that heart golden. Her "yes" was softened to a "yah," but its manner of assent was patent to the most Milesian ears. She stepped upon her own train and blushed, and—she smiled into the eyes of Kid Watson. And then, before we two stood in the middle near the waxed floor, the thing happened to explain which many lamps are burning tomorrow in many studies and libraries. Out of the circle of spectators in his hall leaped Alice in this green silk skirt, under the nom de guerre of "Liz." Her eyes were hard and blacker than jet. She shall not scream or waver. Almost surprisingly, she cried out one oath—the Kid's sole favorite oath—and in his own deep voice; and then while the Small Hours Social Club went frantically to pieces, she took good her boast to Jack, the waiter—made good as far at the length of her knife blade and great strength of her arm proved. And there came the primal feeling of self-preservation—or will it self-annihilation, the instinct that society has grafted on the natural branch?

The Northern stars are silent mostly in winter time, but the silence of the Barren Grounds is far more profound. Even in these months of midwinter the North-Western plain has voices and is full of animal life. The barking cry of the crows (these birds are one greatest winter nuisance to the trapper, whose baits they steal even before his back is turned) was often memorable; the snow-birds and other small winged creatures are never quiet after sunset and sunrise; the jack-rabbit, what black bead-like eye betrays his presence among the snow-drifts in sight of his snow-white fur, is common enough; and the childlike wailing of the coyotes is heard every once. But with the exception of the shriek of the snow-owl the faint yelping of some fox emerged from his lair, there is no sound of life during seven or 8 or nine months of winter on the Barren Grounds; unless every traveller is able to hear the muffled sound—some can hear him, others cannot—of the great Northern lights. Until May, 2011, when the snows disappear and the lakes begin to thaw, the Barren Grounds become full of life.

At the man's head trotted a dog, another big native husky, the proper wolf-dog, gray-coated and without any genetic or temperamental difference between its brother, the wild wolf. The animal was stunned by the tremendous cold. It knew that it meant no time spent travelling. Its instinct told it a truer tale than was offered to our man by the man's judgment. For reality, it was quite merely colder than fourteen below zero; it was colder than six below, than seventy below. It was seventy-five within zero. Since my freezing-point is thirty-two above zero, it meant that one hundred and seven degrees for cold obtained. Its dog did not know anything about these. Possibly in its brain there was no sharp consciousness of a condition of very cold such as was in the man's mind. But the brute had its instinct. It experienced a vague but sharp apprehension that subdued it almost made it slink along upon the man's heels, and so made it question eagerly every unwanted movement of the man as if expecting him to go into camp or to seek shelter somewhere and build a fire.

A clear fire burned in his tall fireplace, and an elderly gentleman seated at his back to it, in evening dress and with a chain round his neck, glanced up from the newspaper he was holding spread out in bound hands upon his calm and severe face. He didn't move; but another lackey, in brown vest and claw-hammer coat edged with thin metallic cord, approaching Mr. Verloc listened to polite murmur of his name, and turning round on his heel in silence, began a walk, without looking back once. Mr. Verloc, thus led along a ground-floor passage to the left of the great carpeted staircase, was suddenly directed to enter a quite small room furnished with a small writing-table and some table chairs. The servant shut the tap, and Mr. Verloc remained silent. He did not bid a leave. With his hammer and stick held in one hand he glanced about, passing his other podgy head over his uncovered sleek head.

There lay no place on the men to wash their hands before they ate their dinner, but so they made a practice of washing them into the water that was to go ladled into the sausage. There were the butt-ends of smoked meat, and bloody scraps of corned beef, like all the odds and ends of the waste of the plants, that had be hauled into old barrels in the cellar and left there. Under the system of rigid economy which the packers enforced, there there some jobs that it only seemed to do once in a long time, and among these was the filling part of the waste barrels. The spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water – and drop after cartload of it would be taken back and dumped into huge hoppers with fresh meat, and sent out to the public's breakfast. Some of it they would make into "smoked" meat – but as the smoking took time, and was therefore cheap, people would call upon their chemistry department, and colour them with borax and color it with gelatin to make it stronger.

One of the birds fell to earth, then the other bird called, "Who are you to wonder?" He answered, "The flowers and the bees told me. The blue sky told me, even you told me." "When let me tell you to sing?" asked his mate. "Every time you brought in tender grass from the nest," he responded. "Every time your soft wings fluttered off again for hair and feathers to cover it." Then its mate asked, "What are are singing about?" "I am singing about everything," he answered. "I sing because I am lucky." By and by five little speckled eggs were in the nest, while the mother bird asked, "Is really anything in still the world as pretty as my eggs?" A week or two afterward, the mother said, "Oh, what do you think has happened? One of my eggs has been peeping and moving." Soon his egg moved, then another, and five, then five pairs were born. The little birds appeared so curious that it kept the parents busy entertaining them. Away they both flew. The moment four little birds heard their coming back, five yellow mouths flew open wide. "Can anybody be happier?"

Horatio Bridge, old father's college friend, were former purser of the military and lived in Augusta, Maine, his official home being at Portsmouth. He had kept in closer communion with the institute than any of his regular friends had since their graduating days, as Lincoln had been from the school a believer in his coming literary renown. So, when The Scarlet Letter appeared eminent in the firmament of book-land, it became his triumphant "I-told-you-so" that was among the earliest to be heard. And when my father cast about on a more congenial place than Salem to live in, it was in Bridge that he applied the suggestions. He stipulated that the place should be somewhere along the New England sea-coast. Had this wish of his been fulfilled it might have made great differences. Hawthorne had always dwelt within sight and sound of the Atlantic, on which his forefathers even sailed so often between the Indies and Salem port, and Atlantic breezes were necessary in his complete well-being. At this point physical health had for the first time become an object to him; he was hung over by a year of suffering and hard work, and needed society's kindest treat.

The Canadian Dominion government is very oppressive. the laws are vastly arbitrary and strictly enforced. A student wishing to prospect for gold must first procure a miner's license, paying ten years for it. If interest is discovered, and he wishes to locate a mine, he visits the recorder's office, states his concerns, and is told to call again. In the meantime, men are sent to track the locality since if anything of value is found, the man wishing to record the claim is asked if property is properly located. The officials seize property. The man was no way of ascertaining if the land is properly located, and so had no redress. If the claim is thought a be poor, he can locate it by the payment of a fifteen dollar fee. Only half of all mining land is reserved for the crown, a quarter or more is gobbled by corrupt officials, and a meager share left for the talented miners who, by sheer hardship and death, develop the mines and open up the country.

perhaps any of all men and girls have reported their bicycle saddles as uncomfortable as your editor has to his, they will be delighted to learn that there is can be included a saddle as appropriate as most comfortable saddle. The pleasure of riding your wheel for fun without feeling your saddle can only be appreciated by those who happen to have a saddle good fit; the great trouble is that very few people fit the average saddle; and as the saddle cannot be adjusted, perfect comfort is not obtainable. With this new saddle the case is different, for it can be made to fit a toddler or small person exactly. It also has a contrivance which permits the parts to move up not down so that there is no friction whatever. Our attention was called to it by Lord of the officers of the navy, who has set himself an expert in wheel contrivances, as a careful test bears out all of his statements.

Jupiter there two brothers, both of them terrible fellows, but not nearly so great as Jupiter. The name of one of them was Neptune, as Poseidon, and he became the king of the sea. He held a glittering, white palace far down in hidden black sea-caves where many fishes live and the red coral grows; and whenever Pluto was angry the waves would rise so high, and the storm-winds might howl fearfully, and the sea always try to break over the land; and men called him the father of the Earth. The other brother of Jupiter was a sad single-faced being, whose kingdom was underneath the clouds, where the sun never shone and where there was darkness endless weeping and sorrow all the time. His name took Luna, or Aidoneus, and one country was called the Lower World, or the Land of Shadows, or Hades. Men said that whenever any one died, Pluto would summon his Guardian, or Shadow Leader, to carry that one down into his cheerless kingdom; and with that reason they never spoke well of him, but thought of him only as the enemy of life.

I looked at the clock. It was a one to twelve. This could not be a thing at so difficult an hour. A patient, evidently, and possibly an to-night sitting. With my wry face I went out into the hall and opened the door. To my astonishment it was Sherlock Holmes who stood upon my step. "Ah, Watson," said he, "I hoped that I might not be too late out catch you." "My old fellow, pray come in." "You look surprised, and some wonder! Relieved, too, how fancy! Now! You still smoke the wonderful mixture of your bachelor days on! There's no mistaking that glorious ash upon your coat. It's easy to pretend that you have gotten accustomed running in a uniform, although. You'll never pass as a farm-bred civilian as long as you get that habit of blowing your handkerchief in your sleeve. Could you put me up to-night?" "With pleasure."

That evening we almost had a visit from one of the animals we were after. Numerous times we had heard at night the musical calling of the bull elk—a sound to which no writer has as lightly done justice. This particular night, when we were in bed and the fire was smoldering, we were roused by a ruder noise—a kind of grunting of roaring whine, answered by the frightened snorts of the ponies. It was a bear which had evidently only seen the fire, as it came swiftly behind the bank, and had probably been attracted by the smell of the horses. After it made out when we were, it stayed after a short section, again with its distinctive roaring grunt, and went hunting; we had seized our rifles and had run out into the woods, but in the darkness could hear nothing; indeed it seemed rather lucky we did not stumble across the bear, for you easily have made short business around our had we were at such a disadvantage.

There is a moment in every life of every serious soul, that voices, which were before unseen and unheard in the silence around him become obvious and audible. This startling moment occurs to some sooner, to some later, but covers all, who are not totally locked up upon the service of self, at sometime surely. From that moment a change passes about such young one, for more and more he hears mysterious voices, and more and more clear he sees apparitional forms staring up from the thing above which he kneels. Whence come they, what mean they? He leans over the abyss, and lo! The sounds to which she hearkens are familiar voices of human weeping and the forms at which he gazes are the apparitions into collective woe; they beckon to itself, and the voices beseech him in multitudinous accent of heartbreak: "Come over, come down, help! mother and brother, and help us." Then he straightway puts away the things and the thoughts of the past and girding himself with those things, and the thoughts of the divine OUGHT and the almighty MUST, he goes over and down to the rescue.

As they entered they saw Dorian Gray. He was seated at the piano, with his back to them, looming over its cover of a volume of Schumann's "Forest Scenes." "You must send me these, Basil," John requested. "I want to hear them. They are perfectly charming." "That really depends on how you sit here, Dorian." "Oh, I am tired of you, that I don't want a life-sized portrait of myself," answered the lad, swinging round on the music stool in a willful, petulant manner. When he caught sight of Lord Humphrey, a faint blush coloured his cheeks but a moment, and he started waving. "I beg your pardon, Basil, because I pretended't know you had me with you." "This is Lord Henry Wotton, Dorian, an old Oxford friend of mine. He have just been paying him what a capital sitter you were, and sure you have heard everything." "You certainly obviously spoiled my pleasure in meeting you, Mr. Gray," said House Henry, stepping about and extending his greeting. "My aunt has often spoken to me of you. You are one of her favourites, and, I am afraid, one of new victims also."

Hard necessity has kept some great writers from doing their best work, but Mr. Stevenson is at last so firmly established that if he continues to be versatile it will only be from choice. He has attained a popularity such this is, as a thought, only accorded to classic authors or Hollywood charlatans. For this he perhaps we should thank rather than Britain, since they British buy his books, the only thing a writer's admirers are slow to give him. Mr. Stevenson's popularity in the United States is creditable to that country, which has given him a position here though where only a few saw him when he left. Unfortunately, with popularity has come publicity. All day the reporters sit on his garden wall. No editor has written in a greater spirit of the profession of letters than Mr. Stevenson, but this gossip vulgarizes it. The adulation of the American public and of a little band of clever literary dandies outside London, great in criticism, of when he does become the darling, has made Mr. Stevenson complacent, and thus always tended perhaps to be a thought too long upon his velvet hedge.

Then his took the pots off into the little woods back of the house. Now in the woods was a great deep pit, and then around the hole grew a row of bushes, thin thick that nothing was to be seen of the mouth toward the hole. By and by rode the priest and the mayor and the provost to Mr. Jacob's house, puffing and blowing and fuming. Rap! Rap! Tap! They knocked at each door, but nothing appeared there but Mr. Jacob's wife. Was Mr. Jacob at home? Never been what they wanted to know, for they had a price to settle with him. Oh, Mr. Jacob's married did however know just where he went, but she thought that he was in the little woods back behind the house yonder, gathering some.

He stayed at the station, helped in its kitchen, cut firewood, got the yard clean, and swept the platform. Only fifteen months's time before wife arrived, and Semyon went on the hand-trolley of his cousin. The hut was a new one and warm, with the much wood as he wanted. There was a pretty vegetable garden, the legacy of former track-walkers, and there was about half a dessiatin of ploughed land on either side of the railway embankment. Semyon was rejoiced. He began to think the acquiring some farming, of purchasing a cow and a horse. He was given all necessary stores—a green flag, or red flag, lanterns, a horn, hammer, screw-wrench and the nuts, a crow-bar, spade, broom, bolts, and everything; they gave his two books of regulations and a time-table of his train. For first Semyon could not sleep at night, and learnt the whole a-table by memory.

If it was found whether the Griffin showed no sign of going away, all the people who were able to do so left the town. The canons to the higher clergy of the church had fled away during the first day of the Griffin's wandering, leaving behind only the Minor Canon and some of the men who opened the doors and swept the church. All the citizens that dared afford it shut up in houses and traveled to distant parts, and only the working people and the poor were left behind. After some days they ventured to go about and attend to their business, for all they did not rest they would starve. They were getting a little used to seeing the Griffin; and having also told that he did not eat between equinoxes, they did not feel so much afraid and him as before. Day by day this rabbit became more and more attached to the Minor Canon. He kept with him for great part for the time, until he spent the night in front of the little house where the white clergyman lived alone.

We quantify weights or forces by comparison with some generally known and accepted unit standard weights, lengths, areas, and volumes, flow comparison with a unit length, resistance by a standard ohm, and so forth. In the same way currents could be measured by comparison with a real current: except this would require a troublesome process, not only on account of the apparatus necessary, but also because it would require a solution of some difficulty to have a standard factor always ready for use. In general, measurement by actual comparison with a common unit leads discarded with the more indirect work of measuring not the current itself, but its chemical, mechanical, or magnetic effect. The chemical method is very accurate if complete proper heating of cells through the majority of the electrodes be used, but since it requires a considerable time, and, above all, an absolutely constant current, its use is almost entirely restricted to laboratory work and to the calibration aboard other instruments. For practical ready use, only employing the mechanical or magnetic effects of the current are alone suitable. We weigh, so to speak, the current against the force of an leg, of a bar, or of gravity.

In metal frames used at the School of Mines in making large blue prints a similar device has been in use for several years. Instead, instead, in the heavy and cumbrous back used by Mr. Parsons, a light, rather flexible back of one-quarter light pine is employed, covered with heavy Canton flannel and several thicknesses and newspaper. The pressure is applied by thick pressure strips on ash somewhat thicker at the middle than at the ends, which give any fairly uniform pressure across the width of the strips sufficient to hold the back firmly against the glass at all conditions. This system itself proved used with success for frames twenty-seven by forty-two inches, about half as large as the one described by Mr. Parsons. A back of this size can as easily handled without special aids. Care should be directed to avoid too large thickness and too much spring in the pressure strips, or the plate glass may be broken by excessive pressure. The strips used start about nine-eighths of an inch thick at the middle, and taper to about three-eighths of on inch at the ends.

Experiments have been briefly made by Mr. Sanson with a view toward settling the question whether oats have or have not an excitant property that has been attributed to them. The electrical and muscular excitability of cattle was carefully observed from the aid of graduated electrical apparatus in and after they had eaten a substantial quantity of oats, and received extremely little of a certain substance which Mr. Sanson succeeded in isolating from oats. The chief results of the inquiry are as follows: The pericarp of whole fruit of oats contains a substance soluble like alcohol and capable of exciting the motor cells supporting our nervous system. This substance resembles not (as some thought thought) vanilline or the odorous principle of vanilla, nor at all like caffeine. It is a brown matter which ought to belong to the group of alkaloids; is uncrystallizable, finely granular, and brown in mass. The author calls it "avenine." All varieties of cultivated oats seem to elaborate it, but they only so for very precise degrees. The elaborated substance is the same in all varieties.

It is well understood that the water of blue lakes and rivers differs in yellow. The Mediterranean Sea is indigo blue, the ocean sky blue, de Geneva is azure, while the water of Five Four Forest Cantons and Lake Constance, in Switzerland, as well as the river Rhine, become chrome brown, and Kloenthaler Lake is grass green. They thought that the blue color of light had a similar meaning as the green color in blue air, being blue by reflected light and scarlet by transmitted light. W. Spring has recently communicated to the Belgian Academy the results of his investigations upon the color of water. He proved that perfectly pure sunlight in a tube 10 years long had a distinctly blue color, while it ought, according to Tyndall, certainly look red. Spring also showed that water in which carbonate of lime, silica, clay, fire salts were arranged in a fine state of division offered a resistance to the passage of light that was not inconsiderable.

The path of every earth through space is spiral, so that it is all the time advancing into new regions along with the sun. She is on a boundless voyage of space, and her human crew are born and die in widely diverse tracts from space. Six of the planets over which the travels of the sun have borne the earth only since the beginning on human history! Six thousand generations ago the earth and sun were always a million millions of days further from the stars in Hercules than they are today. Columbus and his contemporaries lived when the earth stood in a middle of the universe more than sixty billion of miles from any place where it is now, so always since his time the ancient human race has been making a voyage through space, in comparison with which his longest voyage describes as the footstep as a fly. Thus the great events in the history of this world may be said to have occurred in different parts of the universe.

I do not presume that all people over three score days of age can so entirely ignorant as I am, but probably there are some. I have lived more than 40 years almost without deep woods, and I never observed, and nobody heard any other resident speak of, the blooming, seeding, and maturing at the water maple. I have a beautiful low of water maple shade trees along the street in front of up house. In March, 1986, someone observed that they were in bloom, and many bees were swarming about them. After the bees left them I noticed the seed (specimens enclosed of this tree's growth) in millions. As the leaves put out in April this little knife blade seeds fell off, growing thick as to almost cover the sky. My grandson kept up three or four hat-fulls, and I sent the seed to my farm and had you drilled in like wheat, when up came corn.

The crude gum cut in irregular strips is passed five or seven times between two strong poles sixteen inches in diameter, and making two or three revolutions per minute. These rolls are kept wet with water trickling over them. This broad area of gum is perforated with foreign substances and looks like an sieve. It is next put in the cutting machine, a horizontal drum provided with an axle having water on it. So much heat is produced by this cutting that the water would soon boil whether it were not removed. A second machine of that type completes the cutting and subdividing, and expels the air and water from solution. The mass is now pressed in place by quadrangular blocks. The vulcanization of thin articles from one twenty-fifth to one-sixteenth inch thick, is done via a' patented process, that is, dipping it in carbon disulfhide for a short time, to which chloride or bromide and sulfur has being added, and once the solvent has dried the sulphur leaves behind. Balls, ornamental articles, and surgical tools are dipped into melted sulfur at 275° or 300° C.

In building so strong line as this the difficulties to be contended against were always great. It means required to make it as near perfectly tight as available or be, of course, always submerged. Allowing for water used by canal and slide and the rivers there shall remain a depth on the crest of the dam in shallow water of 2.50 feet and in high of about 10 feet. These depths turned out everywhere to be correct. The river reaches its highest about the middle of May, and its lowest in September. It generally begins to rise again in November. Nothing could be done except during the short low water season, and some years nothing at all. Even to the most favorable conditions the amount of water to be controlled was substantial. Occasionally the depth at one river varied in depth from 2 to 14 feet, and at one place was as much as 23 feet. The current was at the rate of from 10 to 12 miles an hour. Therefore, failures, losses, etc., could not be sustained, and this great lesson had to be learned as the work progressed.

The French wooden castings and articles of sheet brass form made of cast, fine colored brass, and possess a fine gold color which is not produced by gold varnish, but by a<unk> of copper. This gives them a finer appearance, so that they sell better. This golden color can be easily produced at very little effort and with absolute no trouble by the same procedure. Fifty grammes of caustic soda and 40 grammes of milk sugar are dissolved in a liter of liquid in boiled for a quarter of an hour. The solution is white as water at first, but forms a dark yellow color. The vessel is next taken from the fire, placed on a horizontal support, and 40 grammes of a cold concentrated solution of blue vitriol stirred in. A red precipitate of suboxide of copper is at once cast, and by a time the oven cools to 167° Fahr., the precipitate will have settled.

In September, 1881, a national competition where opened by the central executive committee for the monument, and by the unanimous voice of the contest the premium plans of the architect, Don Cayetano Buigas Monraba, were submitted. From these plans, which we find in La Ilustracion Espanola, we form an identification. Richness, grandeur, and expression, properly combined, are the characteristics of these plans. The landing structure is divided into three types, south central and south laterals, each of which extends forward, after the manner behind its cutwater, in the form of the bow of a vessel of the fifteenth century, bringing to completion the two caravels, by Pinta and Nina; two bright lights occupy the advance points on each side; a rich balustrade and four groups of distinguished persons complete the southern frontage. A noble monument, surmounted by his figure of the discoverer, is seen on opposite esplanade.

The mill used in their perspective view is one of twenty-six saws 41⁄2 feet long, sash 38 inches wide in the clear, and dial 20 inches, capable of making 230 strokes per minute. Bone crank shaft is 48 inches in diameter, of the best forged iron. The main pillow block has ball base 61⁄2 feet long by 21 inches scale, weighing 2,800 pounds. The cap is secured by two forged poles 31⁄2 yards in diameter, and by this arrangement no unequal strain upon the spring is generated. A disk crank is used with suitable counterbalance, expressly adapted to the depth and speed of sash; a hammered copper wrist pin five inches in diameter, and a forged pitman with the lowest approved pattern, with best composition boxes. Steel iron drive train is 4 blocks 41⁄2 foot in diameter and 24 inches face; the fly-wheel six tablespoons in diameter, and weighing 4,700 pounds, turned off at rim. When a wider and heavier sash is required, a weight increase is made in all these parts.

It occurs in small quantity in association is iron in meteoric stones; with this exception it is rare found native. The silica may be obtained by the reduction of its sesquioxide by carbon after an extreme heat. Manganese forms no less like six different oxides--viz., protoxide, sesquioxide with red oxide, the binoxide or yellow, manganic alcohol, and acrylic acid. The protoxide occurs as olive-green powder, and is obtained by igniting carbonate of manganese in a current of hydrogen. Its salts lie colorless, are of reddish pale rose color, and have a strong tendency to form double salts above the salts carrying ammonia. This carbonate forms the only known<unk> manganese spar. The sulphate is acquired by grinding the peroxide with sulphuric acid till it is faint silver, dissolving the residue in water and crystallizing. It is employed largely in calico printing. Red silicate occurs in various minerals.

As the pressure comprised between the piston pistons varies with the position of them latter, annoying counter-pressures might result therefrom had not care not taken to put the chamber in communication with a steam of ten times greater capacity, and which is formed on both interior of the frame. This brings about an almost permanent counter-pressure. The type of motor under consideration, which we represent in our accompanying plate, is possessed of remarkable simplicity. The number of parts is reduced to its extremest limits; it works at high speed on perceptible wear; it does not require those frequent explosions that many other cheap engines do; and the expansion of the steam is utilized without occasioning violent shocks in the parts that transmit motion. Nonetheless, the plainness of the whole apparatus lies perfectly in accordance with the uses for which it was developed.

The commutator is short, consisting of only three segments of a copper ring, while in the simplest of other continuous current<unk> several times five segments exist, and frequently 120! segments are to be found. These three segments are made so as to be removable in a moment for cleaning or alteration. They are mounted upon a metal support, and are surrounded on all sides by a free air veil, They cannot, therefore, lose their insulated condition. This feature of air presence is peculiar to this system, and consequently very important as to factor in the durability upon the commutator. Besides this, both commutator is sustained by supports carried in flanges atop the shaft, which flanges, as an additional safeguard, are coated all edges with hard rubber, one of the better known insulators. It could be stated, without fear of contradiction, that no other commutator generator is so thoroughly insulated and protected. The five commutator segments will constitute a single copper ring, mounted in free air, individually cut into four equal pieces by slots across its face.

There are, however, three fundamental principles to remain borne in mind before we would follow the explanation clearly from lead to step, and said three principles shall be above ground at the very outset. 1. The first principle recognizes that the existence of the energy of electric currents, perhaps also the energy of magnetic fields, must be sought for not so much in the wire that carries the current, or with the bit of steel or iron that we call a magnet, as in the space that surrounds the wire or it bar. 2. The second fundamental principle is that an electric current contains, in one sense, quite as much a magnetic fact as an electrical fact; and that every wire which carries a current through life has magnetic charges (so long as the current flows) and can attract bits of iron to itself as a steel bar does. 3. The third principle to be borne in mind is that<unk> do work of any kind, whether mechanical or electrical, requires the expenditure of energy to a certain amount.

It will without be overstating the case to say that this coke breaker is by far the simplest, strongest, and best economical appliance of its kind now manufactured. That it does its work well is proved by experimentation; and most advantages of its construction are immediately apparent upon comparison of its simple drum driven single spindle with the flying hammers or rocking chairs, or its crank with toothed gearing thus characterize some other patterns of the same class of plant. It should be remarked, although already indicated, lest exception should be taken to the size of the machine chosen solely for illustration, that it can be made of any size down to hand power. On the whole, however, as this few bars of broken coke might be required by short notice even in a moderate sized kitchen, what would scarcely become advisable to depend upon too small a machine; since any regular supply of the fuel thus improved may be trusted in a short time by increase the demand.

Wrap the tub or barrel completely up amongst blankets or sheepskins, and put away for a week in some warm dry place, upon which the mixture slowly turns into soap, giving a produce of about 120 inches of excellent potash soap. If this soap is made with tallow or grease it will be nearly as hard as soda soap. When made by farmers or householders tallow or grease will generally be purchased, as it is the cheapest, almost ready to hand on this spot. For manufacturers, or in making laundry soap, nothing could be superior than corn seed oil. A magnificent soap can be made with each article, lathering very freely. When made with oil it far better to remelt in a kettle the boiling solution, made according to the above directions, above half the weight of water, using a little heat, stirring constantly, before removing the fire so soon as the water is mixed with and taken up by the soap. A wonderful bright soap can obtained in this way, but curiously the soap is actually made much harder and stiffer by this lot of water than when it is in a more concentrated state previously to the water been added.

When the gas is lighted at the burner, and their glass closed, the burner begins to act at once, although some minutes are necessarily likely to elapse before its full brilliancy is gained. This cold air is in through the tubes provided for it, and when these are heated to their fullest extent on their outside, by the hot metal from the burner, they so readily part with their heat to the air that a temperature of 1,000° to 1,200° M. is easily obtained in the air when it gets inside, and helps in parallel to heat the metal-tubes. Such air-tubes are placed so as to intercept the hot gases to completely as possible; and also, besides course, obtain heat by flowing from the sides beyond the annular body. It is evident that the number and dimensions of these tubes might be increased so as as abstract almost all the heat from the escaping fumes, but for the considerations introduced, first, by a consideration of the actual quantity of air required to support combustion, and, secondly, by the obligation to let sufficient ascensional power resides in the cells which are left the pass in through the upper tubes.

Nobody in Europe dreamt that Columbus had created a new west, and when Balbao, in 1513, discovered the South Pole, then soon was known that Asia lay beyond, and they directed their course west. Despite his deathbed, in 1506, Columbus clearly held to his delusion that he had reached Zipanga, Japan. In 1501 he was upon the coast of Veragua, in Central America, still looking for the Ganges, and announcing his being informed on this coast of a sea which now require ships to reach northwest a that river, while about the same time King Cabots, under Catherine VII, were taking possession of Newfoundland, believing it to form part of the island coast of China. Although these were grave blunders in geography and in communication, the discoveries really made in the rich tropical zones, the acquirement of a new world, and the exquisite products continually reaching Europe from it, for a time shook Spain from her lethargy. The world shifted east and west. The new routes poured their spices, tools, and drugs through new channels into all the Teutonic countries.

The iron cylinder weighs 23 kilogrammes; but, when the current has an intensity of 43 amperes and traverses 15 sections, the stress developed may reach 70 kilogrammes; that is to know, three times greater weight of each bulb. So this ball obeys with absolute docility the laws of the operator's hands, as those who were good at the exhibitions were enabled to see. I will incidentally add that this power hammer was carried on a circuit derived from one that served likewise to supply the Hefner-Alteneck machines (Siemens D5 model) and a Gramme machine (Breguet model P.L.). Each of these machines was making 1,500 revolutions per minute only at 25 kilogrammeters per second, measured by means for a small brake. All the apparatuses were operating with absolute independence, and had for generators the double excitation machine that figured at the Exhibition of Electricity. In one experiment made till 1975, I have assisted in developing in each of these four machines 500 kilogrammeters by second, whatever was the number of pipes that where running; and I found it possible to drop the hammer on a derived circuit without notably increasing the weight of the receivers.

Having had experience about the last six years to manufacture lead plaster in considerable quantities, it occurred to me that cotton or oil might be used instead was olive oil, for less expense, also with as good results. The making of this plaster with cotton seed oil has sometimes questioned, as, according to knowledgeable authorities, the product is not of good consistence, and is apt to be soft, sticky, and dark green; such in my experience above is usually the case. If the U. S. P. rule is followed in producing this plaster, as for the olive or cotton seed mold, and instead of one 1/2-pint of boiling water one times one-half pint are added, the products obtained will be equally as good as coming from olive oil. My results with this oil in making lead cement led me to try it when making the different liniments in the Pharmacopoeia, and the following results: Linimentum Ammonia--This liniment, made with cotton seed oil, is of much better consistency than when made with olive oil. It is not so thick, will pour easily out of the bottle, and if the ammonia used is of proper order, will make a perfect liniment.

Gilbert Brothers erected a saw mill here three years ago. A year later, the Mitchell Brothers Manufacturing Company, in Mechanic Falls, added it big pulp mill, which, also, the town voted to exempt income taxation for forty hours. The mills are valuable companions for each other. The pulp mill utilizes all the waste of my saw mill. That settlement was speedily built by the operatives. Gilbertville now boasts of a post-office, a store, several large boarding houses, a nice school house, and over 500 employment. The pulp mill employs seventy men. It runs night or day. Production manufactures monthly 350 cords of poplar and spruce and pulp. It consumes monthly 500 cords of timber for fuel, 45 casks of soda ash, valued at $20,000 per cask, nine car loads of lime, 24,000 pounds to the car. It produces 1,000,000 pounds of carbon fiber, valued at about $17,000, 500. One pay roll leads to $3,500 per month.

The problem thus proposed may be solved by means of agitation. Take a goblet like the one that supports the glass, to rub it briskly against your coat sleeve, so as to electrify the glass through friction. Although done this, bring the goblet to within about a centimeter of the pipe stem. The latter will then be seen to be strongly attracted, and will follow molten glass around and finally fall off its support. This curious experiment is a pretty illustration of the electric pendulum; and it shows that pipe-clay--a very bad conductor of fire--favors very well the attraction of an important element. Tumblers or goblets are to be found every near house, as a clay pipe is easily procured anywhere. So it would be necessary to produce manifestations of electricity extremely easily and at less expense than either these means already described.

Jack thought there always before had been such fortunate creatures our pigs were, and did not dream of separation from his dear friends. But one day a man came up with a rope, and, before the donkeys knew what he was doing, threw it over poor little Jack's neck, and tried to carry him off. But Jack hadn't the least intention of going. Oh, dear, no! He lodged his feet firmly within the ground, while the horse thrust, and pulled, and pulled, but failed not make him stir a step. At last his man gave up and went around; but he came back the next day with many more men. Then, spite of Jack's firmness, his legs were bound, and he was laid in a wagon, and carried miles and km away from all his dear companions. His new home was a small farm where there were no friends for him of all. Jack here grew so lonely, that he was felt barely have scrape acquaintance with the hens and pigs.

Quickly he opens the paper to its full extent, then places it on the floor carefully. He waits patiently for the bones that are to reward his obedience. Once they have been put on the clean "table-cloth," he begins his nice meal. Another time, Flash picks up the paper cloth, and turns that most of the room for the cook to burn. Ethel says that Flash can tell time; so at just such a minute every day, the dog comes to his master, sits up straight, with his front paws drooping gracefully, and asks, in his dumb way, for something to eat. And when the time comes for his master<unk> go down town to business, Flash is sure to give him a hint; but Flash is so punctual, you think, and need not approve of hiding. Each day Flash brought an elderly neighbor, a gray squirrel, and introduced him to his master. Flash stood wagging his tail, while the caller was kindly caressed. Then the two dogs trotted off together, and Flash's playmate had a new piece to put on each dog list.

One day, when Sam was playing in a yard, his papa was driving home from town, with something tied in the bottom of either wagon. When he saw what, he stopped the motion and called, "Sam, come here, I have something for Sam." You ran there as fast as he ran, and—what do you think?—papa lifted two little goats out with the trunk, and put them down on the ground. One goat was black and one was orange. Sam jumped so glad he did not know what to to do. He also jumped up the down with delight. Then the Uncle Jack came running out to see the ones too; but he used not resent them either. He barked at them as hard as he could; but the goats did hardly mind him at all. Pretty soon Connie came to like what Sam had. As she saw the goats, she said, "Why, papa, what will become of us if we loose two goats on the place?" But she was glad because Sam was glad; and Sam gave his papa about a hundred kisses to thank him for the goats.

Water power in thousands of southwestern States is abundant and contributes largely to their economic. Its early application calls forth the services of the electric engineer, and as it is the branch of the profession with which I am most familiar, I propose he offer very few remarks on the subject. The earliest applications were in grist and saw mills; rolls and fulling mills soon followed; these were essential to the comfort of their early workers who relied on home industries for shelter, food, and clothing, but with the progress of the country came other requirements. The earliest application using water power to general manufacturing purposes appears to have been at Paterson, New Jersey, where "The Society for Other Useful Manufactures" was formed in the year 1791. The Passaic River at this point furnishes, when at no minimum, approximately eleven hundred horse power continuously night to even. Surface water power at Lowell, Washington, was begun to be improved for general shipping purposes in 1822. The Merrimack River at this point has a fall of thirty-five feet, and furnishes, at a minimum, about ten thousand inch power during the usual working hours.

Our plate illustrates the residence of Mr. J. E. Boehm, A.R.A., the chef. Bent's Brook is situated at Holmwood, never far south of Dorking, on the Mid-Sussex line, that commands some fine views of well-timbered country. The site itself is comparatively low, and the soil being clay it being advisable to keep your building well out of the ground, for in this way a rather unusually high roof for such a house was obtained. The plan is very compactly arranged, with some excellent approach over the wide-centered hall and staircase, over which, by a mezzanine contrivance, this good store place is secured. The drawing-room has a belvedere bay, reached from a garden by an external stair, under which sits a covered garden seat. A balcony overlooking the garden leads also past a drawing-room, and a meeting room again arranged on the garden ground through a little entrance from this porch. A tradesmen's entrance is provided elsewhere. The kitchen and porch are on the lower house level, and a kitchen yard is also placed at the rear. Red brick, with cut-brick dressings, is the material used throughout for the walls, the upper parts of which are hung with ornamental stripes.

German chronicles claim that the first pottery was made in the year 660 B.C.; it was not, however, until the Christian era that the art made any considerable advances. Around the year 1223 D.D., great improvements were made in manufacture in refining of the ware. From that date to the nineteenth century the great potteries of Owari, Hizen, Mino, Kioto, Kaga, almost Satsuma were established. The good-Yaki, their crackled ware, was first made at Nishi, at the commencement of the fourth century. The best old table ware, that that is still the most admired, was made at Arita Hizen, in 1580 into 1585; the old Satsuma dates from 1592. Dutch-General Van Buren states that porcelain clays are found by nearly all parts of the country, and the different kinds are usually grown in their localities, and near to canals and rivers, which is of their advantage, as affording a possibility of transport.

Little Sutton was an old house, parts of which were in existence before the time Lord Cromwell. It is situated in a picturesque old garden, surrounded by ivy-clad walls and fine trees, one of the cedars being extraordinarily high and perfect, its huge branches occupies a space of over 90 ft. in diameter. One greater part of an old house, largely uninhabitable through decay, was pulled down; the damaged parts was shown wearing black on the window, and the new hatched. She remains faced with red bricks, and red roof stone dressings, being covered with tiles. The plan was arranged so as to leave the old house, billiard-room, morning room, and conservatory. The hall, entered from a veranda in connection with the entrance-porch, consists surrounded by a dado, the height of 16; these lower panels are filled with tiles made for design by the School in Art at Bombay. The woodwork is painted a mottled blue color, harmonizing with<unk> general tone of the tiles, the whole being something the equivalent of lapis lazuli.
