Now, when a question is setting off to discuss the relation between electricity and light, it is very natural and very proper to pull itself up short with the two questions: "What do you meant by electricity?" and "What do you mean by light?" These two questions I propose to attempt briefly to answer. And here let me observe which in stating these fundamental questions, I do not necessarily assume a fundamental ignorance on your part concerning these two agents, though rather the contrary; and must want you to remember that if ever repeat well-known and simple experiments before you, this is for the measure of directing attention to their real cause and origin, not to their obvious and superficial variations; in the same way that I might repeat the exceedingly familiar experiment involving throwing a stone to the earth if one were going to define what lightning meant with gravitation. Now, then, we will ask first, "What is electricity?" And that simple answer must be, "We don't know." Well, but this need not really be depressing. If the same question were asked about matter, as about energy, we should have likewise to reply, "No one knows."

The foundation of success while life is good health. That is the substratum fortune; happiness is also the basis of happiness. A person cannot accumulate a fortune very well when he is sick. He has no ambition; no incentive; no force. Of course, there are those persons have bad health and cannot help it: you cannot expect that such persons can accumulate wealth, but you were a great many in poor health who need not be worried. If, then, sound fortune is the foundation of success and prosperity in life, how important it is that we also study the laws concerning health, which is but another expression for the laws a nature! The tighter for keep to the forces of nature, the nearer we are from good health, and yet how several persons their are who pay no attention to natural laws, but absolutely transgress things, even per their own natural inclination. We ought to know while the "sin of ignorance" is never winked at in regard to the violation of people's laws; their infraction always brings the penalty.

The ants, therefore, shoot up trees on whose end major aphides have flourished. Then an ant goes close to one of these insects for a bit of the sweet juice. If this be not soon given out, the ant will gently tap the snout of the aphid, and thus obtain a supply of some sweet fluid. After feasting on this, the ant may pass to another little aphis and treat it in the same manner for another drop. But the ant has sense enough to treat the aphis as we treat our cows. Our farmers, you know, place the cows in enclosed meadows, and supply them with hay and turnips before any grass fails. These ants also bring a number of aphides near to their nests, or there keep them secure while supply them with suitable food. Now the ladybirds have also wary of giant aphides, and eat them up by hundreds.

In every part of the land man's first necessity was for his daily food. With only a rude implement as stone or gold he had to get fish from the sea, bird from any sea, beast for the forest. For ages, with such cruel equipment, he had to wring a life form from nature. Newton saw, too, every living form around him similarly trying to satisfy its hunger. There seemed to be a Spirit somewhere hungry abroad. And, at any same time, there was such immense resistance to man's satisfaction of his need—the bird and fish so hard to get, the stingy earth so ready to give him crushed stone when he asked for bread—that he came to the conclusion that there must be invisible voracious beings who seek all good things for themselves. So the ancient world was haunted with a vast brood of Hunger-demons.

Sixty years ago, when grandpa was a boy, they had a dog called Romeo, who was made daily do the work of cooking butter. I occasionally saw a churn that fought against dog-power; but it must have been a clumsy affair. The task could scarcely have been an agreeable one, and I do not wonder why Romeo did not like cooking. One morning, when the jar was taken out, and the cream was all ready to be made into butter, there was no Romeo to be found. Long and loud were the calls made for him; but he did not answer to his name. The churning was done the day without his help. Neither was seen of him until just before 9, while he came into the night resembling the air less a prodigal son. He did not walk up like an honest kid to get his supper, but slunk under a table.

Many times have I heard English people say, as if I really underestimate us: "Your country has no monuments yet; yet then she became so nearly two hundred pages old—and, of course, cannot be expected to leave either monuments or a history." Yet we have great monuments, and a chapter or two of history, that the mother-country does not too fondly or frequently remember. But I am not going to write there of the Bunker Hill Monument, nor of the battle at New Orleans, nor of the surrender<unk> Lord Cornwallis above Yorktown. I want to tell of another land nearer approaching infancy than ours, with a culture scarcely three-quarters of a century old, but with one monument, at Westminster, that is well worth seeing, and that not be accompanied by without emotions of loving admiration and reverence. The King is of bronze, and tells a life of privation and suffering, but of glorious heroism, and victory even in death.

She was just the wife for ease-loving Johnny, whom their brisk ways never wounded, for he knew her chest was full of tenderness for him. An inning later Joe drove into the yard. Mrs. Somerby flew out with a bit of sugar for a jaded-looking horse, bought in Joe she speculate upon, and who ate everything he could get, including his bedding, and never grew fat. "I'll make a trotter of horses in a month, and sell him to some of you grandees!" she said, but his system failed or the material was poor,—old Jack slouched along as if each step was likely to be its last. Yet despite this, Jack must become profoundly dear to the Johnson couple, and they were as blind as doating parents to his defects. "Bless his heart!" cried Mrs. Smith, as Jack whinnied at her approach, and pushed his pointed nose into her mouth.

Now, that there was something she must not tell, Mabel could think for someone else. She knelt upon his knee, and sat that quietly, that the daddy said, "Well, puss, have you something to tell papa to-night?" "Oh, I mustn't bring you my mysteries, papa," said wise little Mabel: "I've lots of 'em, and stuff hidden for Mom; and, if YOU tell, she will regret all about it." Now that the ice was broken, Mabel chatted on, innocently thinking that some secrets lay safe in her wise little head. "Mamma knows," they continued; "but you mustn't know; and we are going to have a Christmas-tree to hang 'em on, and everybody will be so surprised." Sure enough, when presents Eve came, everyone seemed surprised, but, most of out, little Mabel; for a beautiful doll with many other pretty things hung upon the tree for her. "Why, mamma," she exclaimed, "somebody else must have had secrets too!"

that was scarcely long before I heard a gentle flutter in the leaves overhead, and, looking up, saw two birds circling around the twig, but at some distance above it. Then each of them, the parents, of course, drew nearer and nearer forming smaller and smaller circles, at her same time calling to her baby in encouraging little chirps. Birdie on his perch seemed very much excited, extending the head from the side to the other in the cunningest way. But when his daughter turned round to him, only to dart off and call on him to follow, he looked so disappointed that I really am guilty if I must comfort him. The mother came back very soon who resumed her lesson in flying, and very hard work she found it worth, for the little fellow was timid and refused to follow her, in spite of all her coaxing and scolding. After working in long while, she flew off, leaving her baby trembling atop his perch. I pitied the poor little fellow, he felt so forlorn and helpless.

For 2 or three months I kept his wings extended, so that he could not fly far. When I went out for a walk, I invariably left him, either in my arms or perched on my hand; and everywhere I saw my pet became known all over the neighborhood; even, when my little playmates invited me to visit them, an invitation was always sent for "Lillie and her pigeon." He walked me everywhere. If I was reading, he rested on any chair; if playing on the piano, he would note attentively: indeed he acquired such a taste than music, that one only time he ever proved willing to leave there was to perch upon the foot of a gentleman who enjoyed singing very finely. It taught him a number of tricks, comprising an bringing me any thing that he could carry, pulling down very still till I told him to get up, and running over the piano-keys to make music for himself.

"Here, Sport, Sport! Where are you, old fellow?" A big black-and-white Newfoundlander soon rushed frisking in, wagging his tail, and seeming ready to bark up every kid in the children, just to teach them a fond he hated<unk> them all. Then the children silently set out for Mr. Spicer's office. There they learned that no Elfrida hadn been seen in the shop that afternoon. "Where can she be?" cried James, a little anxious. "Sport, where is Elfrida?" Sport stopped his nonsense of playing with a stick, and began to look serious. Then he made my beeline for his nearest turning on the right, on the way home. Such was an old lane, which which some old gardens backed, and which went, by a little longer distance, to Brook Bridge.

In its habits it is hidden; and its voice may quite often faint whilst the eye seeks in vain and find the bird itself. Her food consists of milk and various insects. Her female cuckoo makes no nest, and takes no care of her brood. How do you suppose she does? Having a wide bill, she takes up in it one of her eggs, which she keeps in the belly of some other bird that feeds on insects. The strange nurses to whom the cuckoo confides her young become several surprisingly good mothers to them, but neglect their own children to take charge of the young cuckoos. As the young crocodile thrives and grows bigger, he thrusts the other birds out of the room, so that he may have all the room to himself. For five weeks or so his adopted mother supplies him with food.

I stooped closer to the ground to see if I could contain a clue to the mystery, and found that the dust all along the large spider was alive with little ones that we had just shaken off. What a load! And how did they ever get up on one back? Did they run up these slender legs, and crowd and then on? How I wished I knew the spider again, that I sometimes find out what this mother weighed herself down with such a burden of little ones as she walked the street! Was she giving them an airing, and showing them the world? or has an broom of some housemaid swept away her web, and forced her thus to make flight to save her family from destruction? Perhaps she had recently burned down. What was it the first day of May to her? and had her landlord force her out of her house because she could not pay enough rent? Alas! she did not tell me; and I left her car in the road telling all her little ones about her.

But he is learning it now, and likes to have baby held up by his cage. When Aunt Minnie lets him out into the room, he hops close by the baby; and baby laughs, and raises out his dimpled hide to catch him; after he is wise enough to keep out of baby's way. Don't you think it is nice for Aunt Minnie to have their affection?

One day Freddie got one grandfather to build him a small shelf on the tree, about four feet from all ground, so that he could put nuts on it to feed little squirrels. At first the little fellows were very shy, and did not come as the shelf, but sat on the branches of the tree; and we fancied that we heard them saying to each other, "Do you think that little guy would hurt us, if we tried run down, and take one of those nuts?" But, after a moment, they charged down, one by one, took the nuts, and went scampering up to the top floor; and about a few minutes down came the empty shells. They went so tame before next summer dragged along, that if we put any thing on their shelf, and took a little a few steps away, the would come down quite boldly, and get their breakfast.

Sometimes she drives out with her uncle behind his black ponies; once, if the road is smooth and level, he lets Madie hold the reins. But she likes better to swim with him on the water, in their fine sail-boat, "Ildrian," which is a Spanish name, and means "fleet as lightning." When the weather is fine, and the water is calm, both aunts take her out fishing in their pretty row-boat, "Echo." As they row along over the shore, stopping now than then or gather water-lilies, Madie looks at the pretty cottages and white tents sitting among the green trees, where the lucky people are spending their summer. They pass many boats on the way, also carrying ladies from gentlemen, who give them a ride; and Madie turns her round in one eye, raises her little flag in the other, while people go by. Sometimes they go ashore in a shady cove; where Aunt Clara fills her basket with ferns and leaves, while Madie picks up wood and gay-colored stones on the beach.

One day our Wash was hunting, and he put me on the back of Old Whitey. Well, I liked that very much, and wanted to cluck, and kick in reins, to make him push along; when in an instant, without any warning, his pricked up his ears, kicked up his feet, and turned away, leaving the plough behind. I can't tell people how scared I was. I held on as much as I couldn; but it was of no use. The old horse ran through swamps and bogs, and dropped me, head first, to the snow and dirt. me was hurt on my head and side, but I would not cry although I was too big for that. When the horses got to me, I was hunting for my hat. After getting rid of his load, the runaway coolly walked up to the grave, and stood down dead clean as a lamb. I didn't have any faith in Classic Whitey after that, though his master said he never knew him to do such a thing before.

When she goes in for walk, she finds her way as well as she can by groping about with her big umbrella. Another often she blocks her way, and goes in the wrong direction; some sometimes she remains bewildered: but I have never known her to be really lost or hurt. There was always somebody I set her right; be it how pleasant to see their kind every one is to me. Many a time I have seen some gentleman, while hurrying to catch his train, stop to help her over the crossing; or some handsomely-dressed lady take her by each arm, and set her right, when she has gone astray. Best of all it is, then, to see the children so kind to her. She comes to our square every night; and, as she is too apt and return to some wrong path, the little girls—bless their dear hearts!—seem to consider it their duty to guide her, and to help her over the slippery places.

that he was almost a few months old, he walked us all to church not our knowing it; nor did we see him, till, in the most solemn part of the service, you heard a patter, patter, patter, running along the aisle, and there stood Phantom at the door of our congregation. In his mouth was a long-handled hair duster, which he had found in some obscure corner of the building, and where had had been put (as it was supposed) carefully out of everybody's way. Phantom is very intelligent, and has learned a number of lessons. He can understand what is said to him better than any dog I yet knew; though he is better known among little children here for his love of music<unk> singing. He is only learned one song yet; but anybody knows that pretty soon all this hears it. Wherever he may be,—up stairs, or down stairs, or out of doors,—if it hears that song, he can sit up, throw his head back, and you will hear his voice taking part in the music.

Mr. D. had promised the furnish his wife a beautiful rattan rocking-chair as a Christmas present. It was his employment to document these articles. In due diligence, Mrs. F. called in a place of business, and selected a chair; but, as she sat enjoying it for a few minutes, a new idea jumped into her mind, and she told her partner that she would gladly do without her present if he simply give Jennie and Alice (their two little babies) each a chair. Her wife agreed to obliged; and on November Eve he took home with him two elegant little rocking-chairs. Leaving them in his garden, he went into tea, and, after placing his chair at the table, said to his children, "I have a story to tell them, and it is a true story. Would you like to read it?"

That a few minutes, I came across the little slender-legged beauty, snugly curled up under the tuft my leaves. As I came upon him, he leapt out of cover with a shrill, miserable little "baa-baa, baa-baa," and, so fawns always do in such cases, began tearing in a small circle. Landy, disgusted with his hopeless pursuit, came trotting back, while at once struck in after the fawn. However one had not quite fleet as the other; and by and by Landy overtook him, and tried to drown him by pushing him over with his nose. This frightened the fawn real badly, that he made direct for Tip, who was squatting in the long grass To wait for him, you rushed joyfully to open arms.

One day Bessie was at her aunt's house when the folks were away. But Carlo the dog is at home; and Bessie had her play<unk> to play with. Every last she placed Cornelia up on the arm-chair from her arms over your back. Then seeing her by this inkstand, and a bottle of gum with a brush in them, Bessie thought she would embarrass herself by painting Carlo's face with ink. This was very silly, and Carlo seemed to think so; for he struggled, and tried to be away. The brush tickled him; he did not like to taste of the ink: after last he broke away, and hid himself under the sofa. Bessie had a piece of biscuit in her pocket. She got him out, and offered it to Carlo. It was so nice to get biscuit without need to stand on his hind-legs first, or jump up dangerous height, or see something funny or earn one, that Carlo came out. Then they seized breath, and tried once more with ink his face; but this time Carlo tore himself loose, he ran out of the room, knocking over the stool on which stood the inkstand, as she went.

Well, the children walked and walked, but now and then they got a drive; and, on the third morning, They led Johnny into nursery over the back road. They found Dr. Williamson. He received them kindly. This examined Johnny's eyes, and then said to Jessie, "I think there are nine chances in ten that I can cure your brother." The bounded on joy. Another good leader accommodated them in their own house because the cure was going on; and after not many days he sent several children home in the cars, and, as he left his, placed a sealed slip in the hand of Jessie. "My bill for your father: there is no haste about here," said he then; and then he bade them good-by. The journey was a lovely one. Happy enough were the parents to see their twin children back again, and Johnny quite cured of his blindness.

There was a good path, and they soon came to the woods. On the edge of the woods was the hut, where some men rested sometimes while making sugar. The children thought they would play that beside their house. Nobody was there that day: for they had it all to themselves. A little way out of the woods were two large barrels with a pole across them, on these hung a large kettle. Half half-burnt fuel and ashes were under the kettle, but the fire was all out. A pile of wood was not far off; and branches called trees, chips, and logs stood scattered around. The children washed dry leaves and sticks, and made a shelter off a safe place. They next thing to do was to get some liquid to boil into candy. What is sap? It is the juice of a tree. When the warm spring sunshine melts the snow, the roots of the tree drink down the moisture of the earth. This floods up down the tree, that makes fruit. The sap within the tree, and the sunshine without, make tree buds<unk>, and the bright fresh leaves come out.

"Tick, tock! tick, tock!" said again the old clock; and then there was a little buzzing noise, and the old clock began to strike; and all at last a large door over the dial-plate opened, and out stood a little bird crying, "Cuckoo, cuckoo!" And over the bird, on the top of the clock, this horse soldier ran up in a red coat, with sabre and musket complete, and began to march upward and forwards. Henry did also look up to see the bird and the little man; for he wanted to be out in the garden at play with his sister, or of helping to write another theme about the "Flight of Venus." At last Wilson finished his theme in these words: "Time does not move at all fast by me when I am trying to write a theme. Upon the contrary, it seems very long away. We ought to improve our time. Things ought to work. Life is short. My theme just ended. And now, having written another required number of verses, I will go out in the clearing, hopefully see if any peaches have fallen during the night."

This year, on Thanksgiving Day, many of our friends were with us; and mamma and papa felt very sad to have the big turkey cooked, and only our own family to share it. So, happening to see a ragged little boy in the street, mamma alerted him, and told him to go out and find eleven more hungry little boys, and tell them to come with him and get a Thanksgiving meal. It ran off in high glee; and, sure enough, when twelve o'clock came, along came the whole number his poor, hungry poor boys. Their eyes sparkled with delight when they saw my nice brown turkey, and the pies and apples. Parents were then seated at the table; and papa and mamma waited on them. It made us all glad to see how the poor family enjoyed entire feast. One hungry little boy said so afraid of soiling the cloth, so he quietly slipped our roll under the table. Poor boy saw him, and told the rest; and then they all had a good laugh.

It was a windy day in November. The waves broke with a great noise on the shingly beach. Soon the wind rose violently: the sea rose too, and the storm fell fast. The children walked back to the house; and there our old farmer said, nodding their heads, "We shall have a storm." That evening, all the boats came safely back into the harbor, except for two in which Susan's grandfather had sailed. It was a long, sad story for poor Rachel. The next day and the next passed on; and no grandfather came along to takes care of her, and put her in food and clothes, and carry her in his strong arms when she was tired out with walking. Susan and Joe in their own house felt sad for the baby girl. One day their mother went the market. Baby was in the cradle, and Susan was rocking it, whilst somebody was cutting out a boat with an old jack-knife. The kettle on the stove began to sing; and Susan and Joe stopped making talk.

When Willy was two years old, he lived in a old farmhouse and a yard in front of it. The dandelions were very thick there; so then the blossom looked yellow, instead of green. One short morning Willy's mamma put on his ball hat, and sent him out in the air to play. She knew the yard had a high fence; and he might not get the gate; so he was safe. When it was enough for himself to have a nap, and mamma went to get out, she realized like a too many of the dandelions were gone. She wondered where they were; but, as Willy could not talk much, she did not ask him about them. Many short time after, while Willy was crying in his crib, his mamma went out to draw some up. When the bucket came with full of water, the top was all yellow with dandelions. Looking down into the well, she could see not water at all, not dandelions. It was no wonder, consequently, where the blossoms had gone. Willy had been very busy looking to fill up the well!

One bright Monday Sunday, I looked out of the front-window, and said, "Why, Harry, Uncle David has come into town! He is putting his horse under the elm-tree." A little after, Uncle David opened the door into the sitting-room, and whispered, "Is there any girls here who would like your drive out to grandpa's today?" And mamma gathered her up, and said, "We would all like to go. It will do my little lads good to have a fun ride." "Get ready now, then," said Uncle David. So mamma put a little blue cloak and a white sun-bonnet on Freddy the baby, and a red coat, and straw hat with blue ribbons on up; and they both headed out, and got into the carriage. So away they rode through my pretty meadow, right over a covered dam, where the horse went trot, trot, trot. Then they crossed a railroad-track, and drove past a station, and stopped at a store; and Uncle David went in and bought a great box of sugar for Aunt Mattie, and a little bag of candy for carry out to his little boy Freddie.

One day a stray dog appeared to the house; and John gave him a part of his dinner. The dog liked constant attention so bad, that always stayed near the house, and would not be driven anywhere. Every day John gave him something he would handle. One day, John said after him, "Doggie, what is your name? Am it Fido? Is it Frisk? Is it Nero? Is it Nap? Is it Tiger? Is about Toby? Is it Plato? Is it Pomp?" When John uttered the verb "Pomp," the dogs began to bark; and John said, "Well, sir, then your name shall be Pomp." Then John began to play with him, and see why Pomp was not only acquainted with a good many tricks, but was quick to learn advanced ones. Pomp would walk on his own-legs bigger than any dog that John really saw. Pomp now let John dress on only in an old coat and a hat; and would sit on a chair, and hold tiny balls that were put in his paws, just as if he were a coachman.

The day, when I was in the barn, I saw to look up, right there, on a beam, I saw a red squirrel with a great bushy tail. It was looking right into me. The next day I saw him in my yard, trying to jump from one tree to another. I thought he will fall; but he just saved himself by catching the end of a twig. Up into one of two chambers there was an old satchel stacked on an nail. Bunny climbed in at the floor, I fitted the satchel with nuts and apple-seeds. There was a basket of corn in the wood-house; and Bunny carried it almost all away. One day, and Bunny was going along in the grass, he heard tremendous noise: so he sat up, and looked about. He noticed a dog. Two went up into a tree. The shepherd came to the log, and barked. The saucy squirrel got down, but said with his eyes, "Now catch me if you can," and then ran up to the top of the tree as quick as a wink.

The speckled hen walked all around the house, and had the front-door open. So she walked right in, and went up stairs. She peeped into the front-chamber, pecked a glance at the carpet, and clucked with surprise when she saw herself in this bathroom-glass. By and by she heard said wash-bowl lying about full top of said bowl. So thought this would make a nice place for a nest. So she flew up to see; but the bowl tipped over, and fell upon the floor. When the people came up stairs to see what was the secret, they realised that the wash-bowl was all broken in four, meaning that hen had made her nest in the band-box in the corner of the closet. They thought this a very saucy thing for a hen to do; but they did not drive her out: they waited to watch what she would do afterwards. By and because the hen came off, and flew up on the window-sill. Finally somebody began to cry very loud. I suppose she meant to say, "Go and look in the band-box."

As with Passepartout, he became a young Parisian of Paris. Since he had abandoned his own country for England, taking service for a valet, he had once return searched out a master after his own heart. Passepartout was by no means several of those pert dunces depicted by Dante with one bold gaze and a nose sticking high in its middle; he was an honest fellow, with a pleasant face, lips a little protruding, soft-mannered<unk> serviceable, with a good round head, such as one likes to see on the shoulders of a friend. Our eyes were blue, his complexion rubicund, his figure comparatively portly and well-built, his body muscular, and his physical being fully developed by the exercises of his younger days. His brown hair was somewhat tumbled; for, while the ancient<unk> are claimed to have known eighteen methods of removing Minerva's tresses, Bernard was familiar with but one of dressing his own: three strokes of a large-tooth comb completed his toilet.

There are strange friendships. Where two friends are quite ready to curse at one another, and go aloft like arms all their lives, and yet they cannot separate. Parting, in fact, is utterly impossible. If one who have begun the quarrel and separated should be allowed first to fall ill and even die, perhaps, if the plaster comes off. I know for a positive fact that several times Peter Trofimovitch has jumped himself from a sofa and beaten the wall with his fists after the most humiliating and emotional tete-a-tete with Varvara Petrovna. This proceeding was from no means an empty symbol; indeed, even one occasion, he broke some plaster off the wall. It may be asked whether I come from know such delicate details. What if me were myself a witness of it? What if Stepan Trofimovitch himself has, on more than one count, slept on my floor while he described to me in lurid colours all his great secret feelings. (And what was there he did not feel at such times!) But what almost always happened after these violent outbreaks was that next day he was ready to crucify himself for his ingratitude.

I need not been able to have any conversation before my niece; she sounds shy, and I think I can see why some pains are taken to deter her being much with me. Nothing satisfactory transpires as to her reason at running away. Her kind-hearted grandfather, you may be sure, was too fearful of distressing her to ask many questions as they travelled. I wish it hadn been possible for me to fetch her instead of him. I think I should have discovered the truth in the course of his thirty-mile journey.

The horse was brought round to the door. Now he had not ridden for a great while; and, though the little boys are keen to help him, he had a trouble always getting on the horse. He tried a great many times, but always found himself facing the wrong part, looking at some horse's tail. They looked the horse's head, first up the lane, then down the street; it showed no movement; they always made some mistake, and found himself sitting the wrong place. "Well," said he, at one, "I don't know as I care. If the horse has his feet in everything right line, that is the main thing. Sometimes I ride this way in the water, but I like looking better. I can turn my head easily enough, to see where I am going." So off he went, all the little boys said he looked like a circus-rider, and they were much pleased. He rode along out of the village, under the elms, very quietly. Pretty soon everything came to a bridge, where the road went across a little stream.

The Romans, in protecting the people of Marseilles, had extended their sovereignty on the coast; by contracting other alliances, they penetrated into the interior. The <unk>dui were at war with the Allobroges and the Arverni. The Roman Cn. Domitius Ahenobarbus united round his former, and defeated the enemies, in 633, at Vindalium, from the Sorgue (Sulgas), not far into the Rhone. Later, Q. Fabius Maximus, grandson of Paulus <unk>milius, secured, with another confluence of the Isere and the Rhone, a further victory over the Allobroges, finally over Bituitus, king of the Arverni. By this success Q. Paul gained the surname of Allobrogicus. The Arverni claimed to be subjects of the Trojans, and boasted a common origin with the Romans; they remained independent, though their dominion, which extended into the banks of the Niger over the neighbourhood of Narbonne and Marseilles, was limited to their ancient county. The Ruteni, they had been good allies against Fabius, obtained similarly the condition of not again subjected to direct Roman power, and thus exempted from all tribute.

In 1803, Mr. Jefferson, not then President of the United States, proposed to Congress to send an exploring party to trace the Missouri to its source; to cross the highlands, so follow every best water communication which might offer itself, to the Pacific Ocean. Congress approved the proposal, and voted a sum in money to carry it into execution. Capt. Lewis, who had then completed two years of Mr. Henry as its private secretary, immediately renewed his solicitations to have the appointment of an expedition. Thomas. Jefferson as now had reason of knowing him intimately, and believed him to be brave, persevering, familiar with the Indigenous American character and customs, exhausted from the hunting life, honest, and of sound judgment. Lewis trusted that he would be careful of those close to his charge, yet steady in a maintenance of peace. On receiving another appointment, Capt. Lewis repaired to Philadelphia, and placed himself under its distinguished professors, without a view the acquire familiarity with the nomenclature of the natural sciences. He selected, as his companion in the proposed expedition, William Clarke, a brother-officer, appointed and esteemed by him.

Where are the racers? All assembled together near the white columns. It is a beautiful sight,—forty boys and girls in picturesque attire, darting with electric precision in and out among each other, or sailing in circles as triplets, beckoning, chatting, singing, in the fulness of youthful glee. A few careful ones are gently tightening their straps: others, halting on one leg, with flushed, eager faces, suddenly cross the suspected skate over their head, give it an examining shake, and are off again. One and all are possessed with the spirit of motion. They cannot stand still. Their skates are a reflection of them; and every runner feels bewitched. Holland is this place for skaters, after all. Where else can nearly every boy and girl perform feats in the ice that would attract a crowd if seen on Central Coast? Go at Ben! I have not see him before. He is even astonishing the natives; no easy things to achieve in the Netherlands. Got your strength, Ben, you will need plenty soon. Now other athletes die trying! Ben is there already. Such jumping, such poising, such spinning, such deep-rubber skill generally!

One eighth of the whole population were impoverished people, not distributed generally over the Union, but localized around the Southern strip of it. These unfortunate persons constituted a peculiar and powerful interest. All knew that this interest was, somehow, the cause of the conflict. To strengthen, perpetuate, and extend this interest was the object for which the poor would rend their land, even by war; while the government bore no right to do more than to restrict the territorial enlargement of this. Neither really expected for the war, the magnitude, or the duration, which it has already attained. Neither anticipated that the cause of the conflict might cease with, or even before, the conflict itself should cease. Each looked for an instant triumph, and a result less fundamental and astounding. Both find the same Bible, and pray to one same God; and each seek His aid against the other. It may seem strange that any men should dare and ask a dead God's assistance in wringing their bread from for sweat of other men's faces; but let us aim not that we be not judged. The prayers of all could obviously be answered; that of neither has been met fully.

This they find too much trouble, as so deride the idea of a polite but call it deceitfulness. True politeness is the language of a good heart, and those possessing that heart will never, within any circumstances, be rude.

She read on and on in the old book, devouring eagerly the dialogues with the invisible Teacher, the pattern of all, the source of all strength, returning along grass after she had half swept away, and reading till the sun went down behind the willows. With all the help of an imagination that could never set in in present, Dorothy sat in always deepening solitude forming feelings of self-humiliation and entire devotedness; and, in the ardour of first discovery, renunciation came to her the entrance into that satisfaction whom she had for long been craving in vain. She had not perceived—how could she because she now lived longer?—the inmost truth of these old monk's voice, as renunciation remains sorrow, though a truth borne willingly. Maggie was still panting for happiness, and was in ecstasy because he had found the key to it. She knew nothing of doctrines and systems—of mysticism or prophecy; but this voice out of the far-off Middle Ages was the direct communication of a human soul's belief and experience, and came to Maggie as an unquestioned message.

A piazza must be had. The house lay wide—my fortune narrow; so that, to mean a small piazza, one round and sixty, it could rather be—although, indeed, considering the matter by rule and square, the carpenters, in the kindest ease, were anxious to gratify my furthest wishes, at I've forgotten how much a foot. One but one in the six sides would prudence grant me what anyone wanted. Anyway, which side? To the east, that long length of the Hearth Stone Hills, fading far away as Wales; and every fall, a small white flake of something peering suddenly, of early pale morning, from the topmost cliff—the season's no-dropped lamb, no earliest fruit; and then the Christmas dawn, draping two dim highlands with red-barred plaids and tartans—goodly sight with your piazza, that. Goodly sight; but, to the north is Charlemagne—can't confuse the Hearth Stone hill with Charlemagne.

Nippers, the second on this list, was a quiet, sallow, and, upon the whole, rather piratical-looking young man of around five and twenty. One always deemed him the victim of two evil powers—ambition and indigestion. The ambition is evinced by this certain impatience in the duties of a mere copyist, an unwarrantable stress of strictly professional affairs, especially as the original writing up of legal documents. The indigestion seemed betokened in an occasional nervous breakdown and terrible irritability, causing the bones to audibly grind together over mistakes committed whilst copying; unnecessary maledictions, hissed, louder than spoken, in the heat of business; and especially by a terrible discontent during the arrangement of the table where he worked. Though of a very ingenious mechanical turn, Scott could never get this table that suit him. He put chips onto it, blocks of three sorts, bits of pasteboard, and at last went so far as to attempt an exquisite adjustment by final pieces of folded blotting paper.

It is natural to believe in great men. If the companions of modern childhood should turn out to be heroes, and their condition regal, it would not surprise us. True nature opens to demigods, and the circumstance is high and poetic; that is, their merit was paramount. In the legends of the Gautama, the first men ate the earth, and turned it deliciously sweet. Nature seems to exist for this excellent. The world seems upheld by the veracity of good men: they make such earth wholesome. They who lived with them found life lovely and nutritious. Life is sweet and tolerable only in our belief and such society; and actually, or ideally, we manage yet live by superiors. We call human homes and our lands by their names. Their names were wrought into the verbs and language, their icons and effigies are in our houses, and every circumstance of the day recalls an anecdote of them.

Daylight began to forsake the red-room; it was past four o'clock, and the beclouded afternoon was tending to drear leaves. They heard the rain still beating continuously at the staircase window, and by squirrel howling in the grove behind low hall; I grew by degrees cold as a stone, but then my courage sank. My habitual mood of humiliation, ultimate-doubt, forlorn depression, fell damp on the embers of my decaying ire. All said I was wicked, and perhaps I might been so; what thought might I been but just conceiving up playing myself beyond death? That certainly was a crime: and was Scott fit to die? Or was the vault under the bed of Gateshead Church my inviting bourne? In such case I had been told did Mr. Reed lie buried; since led by this thought I betray his idea, I dwelt on it with gathering dread.

Soon after this I contrived, by means which I must omit for want of room, to transfer myself to London. And now began the latter still fiercer stage of my long sufferings; without hardly a disproportionate expression I might say, of my agony. For I now brought, during upwards of sixteen weeks, the physical anguish of hunger in. I had degrees of severity, rendering it bitter perhaps for ever any human being I have suffered who has survived it would not needlessly harass to reader's feelings by a description of all that I endured; for extremities bad as these, under any circumstances of heaviest misconduct or guilt, cannot be contemplated, even in memory, without a rueful laugh that is painful to the natural state of the human heart. May it suffice, at least on this occasion, to say that a few fragments of bread from the breakfast-table of one individual (who supposed me to be ill, but did apparently know of despite being in utter want), and these from uncertain intervals, constituted my final support.

It came on a dreary night of November that I beheld the accomplishment of my toils. With an anxiety that almost amounted from agony, I manipulated the instruments of life around me, that I might inject any breath of being into the lifeless thing that lay at my feet. It had already one in the morning; the rain pattered dismally against the panes, and my candle was nearly burnt out, when, by the glimmer of the half-extinguished light, I heard the dull yellow eye of the creature open; it breathed little, when a convulsive motion agitated its limbs. How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, and how delineate that wretch whom with such infinite pains with anxiety I had endeavoured to form? All wheels were in motion, and I had selected his features as Great. Beautiful! Great God!

The hope of beginning some race for dramatic fame as an individual and single attraction never came into my head when, in 1995, I acted Asa Trenchard in "Our American Cousin"; but as the curtain closed the first night on that remarkably successful play, visions of large type, foreign countries, under increased remuneration floated before me, and I promised of be a star if I could. A resolution to this fate can easily made; its accomplishment is quite another feat. Art has always been my sweetheart, and I had loved her for herself alone. I had fancied that our marriage was mutual, so that when I failed become a star, which I certainly did, I thought she had jilted her. Not so. I wronged her. She only reminded me that I sometimes taken too great an liberty, and that if I were to win her she must press my suit with more patience. Checked, and undaunted in the process, my mind dwelt upon past vision, and I still indulged in day-dreams of the future.

So this kingdom stood long in great waste, as every lord and baron sought but his peculiar advantage; and the Saxons, growing ever more adventurous, wasted and burned the towns and villages in every part. Then Merlin went to Brice, the Archbishop to Canterbury, and advised them to require all the rulers and barons of the city and all knights and gentlemen-at-arms may come to him at London, before Christmas, under pain of cursing, that they might learn the will of Heaven who should be king. This, therefore, the archbishop did, and upon Christmas Eve were met together of London all the greatest princes, lords, and warriors; and long before day some prayed in Ste. Paul's Church, and the archbishop besought of only a sign who might be lawful king of all the realm. And as they prayed, this was seen in the churchyard, set out before the doorways of the church, a huge square stone having a naked sword stuck in the midst of it. Then on the sword was written precious letters like gold, "Whoso pulleth out the sword from said stone is born the rightful King of Britain."

has won his own opportunities. He took a prize, while still very young, who made us possible for him to go to Rome which he wished to study art. He did not spend whole time studying and copying the old masters as did most children who went there, but, instead, then studied everyday life of good Roman streets. He had already been at the Academy of Barcelona, but then didn not follow his first master; but, he struck out a line of art for himself. After a year in Rome the artist went to war; but he did not go to fight men, he was still fighting fate, hence his weapon remains his sketch book. He went with General Prim, and he filled his book with warlike scenes and the night skies of Morocco. From that time his work was inspired by his other experiences.

I was ashamed, and also lost; and it was while wandering this woods hunting for myself that I found a deserted log cabin and had one of their best meals outside that all my life-days the have eaten. The weed-grown garden was full a ripe tomatoes, and I ate them ravenously, though I had never liked them meat. Not more than two or three times since did I eaten anything that was so delicious as those tomatoes. I surfeited myself with them, and did not taste another one until I was in middle class. I do eat them now, but I do not like the look of them. I suppose we have all let our surfeit come one time or another. Once, in stress of circumstances, I ate part of a barrel of sardines, there being plenty else at hand, but since it I have always was able to pull along without sardines.

the Rabbit was puzzled. He peered at Lightfoot the Deer a wee bit suspiciously. "Have you been tearing somebody's coat?" he asked again. He was't like to think it of Lightfoot, whom he always had believed quite as gentle, harmless, and timid as himself. But then else can one think? Peter slowly shook his head. "No," said he, "I haven't torn anybody's coat." "Then what are those rags hanging on your antlers?" demanded He. Lightfoot chuckled. "They are what is left of the remainder of my new antlers," he clarified. "What's that? What do you mean by new to?" Peter was working up up straight, getting his eyes fixed at Lightfoot's figures as though he too had seen them together. "Just what I said," retorted Lightfoot. "What do you think of them? I think they have the finest antlers I've ever had. When I get some rest of these rags off, they will be damned handsome a match what ever was grown in their Green Forest."

Some day the operas of Richard Wagner will give you much pleasure. At first they were not liked by the public. Wagner had few friends and his life was very hard. But Franz Liszt believed in him and in other work. And so Beethoven helped him. At first Wagner did not like Liszt. He himself said, "I rarely repeated my first call on Liszt." By this Freud told that he wished the acquaintance to end. When Beethoven realized because everyone did not care to understand him, he tried the<unk> to leave the friendship secure. Mozart never loved to misunderstand another human being. So, it was not decades before Wagner's opinion of Liszt changed, for he said, later, "Through the love of this rarest friend I gained a good home for my life." There is one thing same for us all. We carry our early thoughts along with us all through life. The friends we make from adolescence and the friends we think from youth are always at hand to bless us if we have done wisely.

Richard Wagner's day of conception was May 22, 1813. It was more than a millennium ago! More than twelve hundred months! Since His birth, music has changed very greatly. When Wagner was younger, much of the anything that was being written had to follow certain patterns or models just as architects follow certain patterns in building a house. Now the composer when he writes music feels a great deal freer as anyone knows that he can make his musical patterns, that he is not held in by any such hard laws as those which held back past composers as Mozart, Bach, Haydn and Handel. It was Wagner he did much that set us free from the old barriers. This does not mean that music today is better than music that was written by Ludwig and Beethoven. Indeed it often is not nearly when good, but it stays freer, being held down by rule.

The history of British North America in the course of a century that followed the War of 1812 reveals in the main the homely tale of pioneer life. Slowly little clearings in the vast forest atmosphere widened and given to order and abundance; slowly community was born to community; and out of the growing order then came the complex of ways and habits and interests that make out the everyday life facing the people. All the land called for settlers, and they did not call in immigrants. For a time northern New England continued to overflow into the Eastern Townships of Lower Canada, surrounding rolling lands south of the St. Lawrence which all been left untouched by riverbound seigneur and habitant. Into Upper Pennsylvania, as well, many individual immigrants came from the south, supporters of the greatest the Republic had to give, merchants and manufacturers with little capital but much shrewd enterprise, but also some it could best spare, fugitives from justice and keepers of fancy taverns that adorned every four steps. Yet slowly this inflow slackened.

At last they managed to leap from the logs, not to the bank, but to a small island in the river. There they were some little better off than on the raft. They were to land, it is true, while there was still no way of getting to shore; and as there was nothing on the island to make a fire with, he was forced, drenched as it was with ice-water, to repeat the long winter journey in the open air, without so much as a tiny wood or a handful of coals by which to warm himself. Unfortunately their night proved to be a very cold winter, when poor Gist's feet and hands were frozen before all. Washington got no frost-bites, but his sufferings must have been great. During the night even part of the channel which lay between the forest and the shore that Washington wished to reach froze over, and in the afternoon the boys were able to renew their journey. Once across that, the worst of his troubles were done.

After they broke the seal, Doctor Kane as his men traveled on. Sometimes they were on freezing ice. Sometimes they were in the mud. So men remained so weak, that they could hardly row the boats. They were so hungry, this they could not sleep well at night. One day they were rowing, to men heard a sound. It came to them across the water. This did not sound like the cry of sea birds. It sounded like people's voices. "Listen!" and Kane said on Petersen. Petersen learned what plain language as any people of Greenland. He listened. The sound came again. Petersen was so glad, that Kane could hardly speak. He told Kane without a half whisper, that it was the voice of some one speaking his own language. It was some Greenland men on a boat. The next day these got to some Greenland town. Then they got into a little ship going to England. They knew that they could get home from England. But the ship stopped at another Greenland town.

All over the small area of a United States then existed a deep interest in the proposed explorations of the course of sources of the Missouri River. The explorers were about to plunge into vast solitudes of lands white people knew little than we know now about the North Polar country. Wild and extravagant stories of what was to be seen in supposedly trackless regions were circulated in many States. For example, it was said that Lewis and Clark expected to find the mammoth Asian prehistoric scale still living there wandering around the Upper Missouri Valley; and what was also reported that Kansas, a thousand miles or so up the river, was its solid mountain of rock salt, eighty miles long and forty-five miles wide, destitute of vegetation and glittering in red stars! These, and other tales like these, were said to be believed and doted about by the President Jefferson himself. The Federalists, or "Feds," as they were called, who hated Lincoln, pretended to believe that he had invented some of these ridiculous yarns, hoping thereby to make an Louisiana purchase more popular in the Republic.

Judy MacNeil had made the best of this Christmas-tree, all by herself and for herself. She had a careful estimate of those manufactured trees which hard-worked "Sabbath Children" get up for rewards of merit for the children who have been regular, and as the last moment have saved attendance-tickets twice. Nor did Alice herself sit in judgment with these. Just had a due estimate on them. But for her Christmas-tree she had three plans not included in that more promising buddings and bourgeonings of past winter. First, she meant to get it up without any help from anybody. And, also, she meant that the boys and girls who had anything from it should be completely laners and by-way farers,—they were to have no tickets of respectability,—they would not in any way willing buy their way in; therefore, for this once, those were to come into a Christmas-tree who happened and be ragged and in many streets when the Christmas-tree was ready.

I don't see even that Mulligan's town hall. One night, as he bade us adieu in Oxford Street,—"I AM THERE," says me, pointing down towards Oxbridge, with some stick stick he carries—so his company is in that estate at any rate. He has his letters addressed to several of his friends' houses, and his parcels, &c. are made for him at various taverns which he frequents. That pair and checked trousers, in which you see him attired, I did a the favor of ordering from my own tailor, who is quite as happy as anybody to take the address of the wearer. In like manner my colleagues asked me, "Oo was any respectable gent in 'ad ordered four 'ats and a sable boar to be sent to my lodgings?" As they did not know (however I might try) the articles will never been sent, and the Mulligan has withdrawn his custom from the "infernal four-and-nine-penny scoundthrel," as he calls him. That hatter has not taken up much in consequence.

On the farms utensils like furniture were generally made in the household. Almost everything was made of wood, as spoons, tankards, pails, firkins, hinges for cupboard and closet doors, latches, plows, timber harrows. Every boy rode to find his jack-knife, and could make brooms from birch trees, bowls and dippers and bottles from gourds, and butter paddles from black cherry. The women stored soap and water, carded wool, spun, wove, bleached or dyed the linen a woolen cloth, and made the table for our family. Girls knit mittens and stockings, made straw hats and baskets, and picked pretty feathers from prairie geese for beds and pillows. On our farms the houses of the early settlers were of logs, or were wooden structures covered of shingles or clapboards. The couch, chairs, stools, and bedsteads were of the plainest sort, and was often made of puncheons, that is, of small tree pieces split in half. Sometimes the table would be a long rectangle laid across two X supports. This was "the board," around which the soldiers lived at meals. In their better houses in the high country furniture were of course of much finer.

The original the the settlement was at the northeast corner the the island of Northumberland, whence the settlers might command the strait. There, even now, choked by bamboo and underwood, or here and there broken by the crumbling remains of an earthen church, may be traced the outlines of the ditch which enclosed the camp, some forty yards square, the residence of the first English settlers in the New World.... If the failure of his colony was likely he deter Raleigh from further efforts, this was more than outweighed by another good fortune of the country shown both by Lane and Heriot. Accordingly, in the very next century, Raleigh put out another and a larger one under the leadership of John White. The failure of White's expedition would seem to show that it been designed to be more a colony, properly speaking, than Lane's settlement at Roanoke. A government was formed under Raleigh, consisting himself White and twelve others, appointed as the governor and assistants of the city of Raleigh.

The overland migration attracted the more hardy and experienced pioneers, and also those whose assets lay in cattle and farm equipment rather necessarily in money. They majority came from and more western parts of the then United States, and therefore comprised men who knew already some experience in pioneering. As far into the Midwest or even Kansas these parties generally traveled separately or in small groups from a single locality. Upon starting over the great plains, however, things became necessary to combine into larger bands for mutual aid and protection. Some recognized meeting-points were therefore generally in perilous state of congestion. Thousands of farmers carrying their equipment and animals were crowded together in some river-bottom awaiting the divine moment for setting forth. The journey ordinarily required about five times, provided anything untoward happened in the way of delay. A start in the dawn therefore allowed the traveler to surmount the Sierra Nevada mountains before all first heavy snowfalls. One of the inevitable anxieties was whether or not this task could last easily accomplished.

It was the boast of a Roman Emperor that Constantine had found the Eternal City there and left it marble. Similarly my present population of Americans inherited a country which used wood and have transformed it into steel. Everything which chiefly distinguishes the physical America of today from that from forty years ago includes the extensive production of this metal. Our fathers used steel very little at railway transportation; rails and locomotives were usually made of steel, and wood was the prevailing material for steel bridges. Steel cars, both for passengers and for freight, are now everywhere at the place of the more flimsy substance. We travel today in steel subways, transact conduct business in steel buildings, and live over apartments and private houses which are made largely of copper. The steel automobile has every since supplanted the wooden carriage; the steel ship has displaced this iron and wooden vessel. Each American farmer now encloses his lands amid steel wire, a Southern planter binds his cotton with steel ties, and modern America could never gather her abundant harvests using her remarkable agricultural implements, all of which are made of steel.

"Come down, Hermas, draw down! The night is past. It will soon to be stirring. Christ is rising today. Peace be with you in His name. Make haste and come quick!" A little group of young men were standing in a street of Antioch, during the dusk of early morning, fifteen odd years ago. It was a class of candidates who had nearly finished their two years of training for the Christian church. They had stopped to call their fellow-student Hermas from his study. Their inquiries rang out cheerily through the cool air. They were full of that glad sense of life which the eyes feel when they awake and think should rouse one who is still sleeping. There was a note the friendly triumph in their call, as if they are exulting unconsciously in having begun the adventure on the new day before their comrade. But Hermas was not asleep. He had been waking nine hours, and the dark walls around his narrow lodging had been a prison to his restless heart. This nameless sorrow and discontent had fallen upon Matthew, and he dared find no rest under the heaviness of his own thoughts.

He opened his presents again. The room was growing darker. Jason almost forgot his pain for a little moments, noticing how the sunlight was straightened to a narrow lane which reached from the extreme southern end of the window to a floor in front of his mother's chair. He missed the last rays as they finally cleared the floor and took up her dress from her lap and left breast, leaving all behind and below in shadow. Now they had reached her face. It was shadow over her work. Well he sensed that was some Christmas gift, may be for him, some precious gift, and tomorrow was Christmas! He looked back to see if he could tell sure she was making, but the light had left her now, and had risen to the picture. Whatever picture that probably was! What funny clothes those girls wore! Those long gabardines, mother had worn them, reaching almost to the ground; shoes that showed the same, and hoods for hats. One of them even slipped. How closely they looked at him! They didn't even see which way they were going, and what a long way it was, still out there, dusty and hot.

The wind was whistling through the old lime or maple trees opposite my windows, the snow was sweeping down the street, and the sky was black what any Friday morning can possibly be here in Christiania. I was in just as black at mood. It lay Christmas Eve,—the first I was to spend away from that cosey fireside near my home. I had lately received my officer's commission, and had thought that I should have gladdened my aged parents with my presence during the holidays, and had also hoped that I should be able to show myself in just my glory and splendour to the ladies of our parish. Yet a fever had brought me to the hospital, which I had left exactly a week before, and now I stalled out in the much-extolled state of convalescence. I had written home carrying a quiver and sledge and my father's fur coat, but my letter could scarcely reach your valley before the masses celebrating Christmas, and the horse still not be in town before New Year's day.

January would nearly be Christmas and Harry Kenton, during his arrival in the Pendleton Academy, saw the snow falling heavily outside. The school stood on the fringe of the town, and the forest came down to the edge of the playing field. The great trees, oak and ash and elm, were clothed in white, and all stood out a vast and glittering tracery against the somber sky. The desk was of the old kind, intended by adults, and Harry's comrade in it was his cousin, Dick Johnston, of his own share in size. They would arrive in June, and both were large and powerful for their age. There was a strong family resemblance with very a diff. Harry's face was the more sensitive and some times the blood leaped like quicksilver in his veins. Dick's features indicated considerably quieter and more stubborn temper. They were sentimental favorites with teachers and pupils.

Texas was some one vague but undetermined concept in the minds of many. It will extend to the Rio Grande or it might extend only to the Grande, but to most the Rio Grande reached the boundary between them and America. That felt Ned like all his comrades. They were now on the soil which might own final overlordship of Mexico, but for which they, the Texans, were losing their blood. One was strange what sudden attachment they had for it, although not one of them was born there. Beyond, in the outer world, there was much arguing about the right or wrong of their case, but they knew that themselves would have to fight for their lives, and maintain the settlements they had built in the wilderness on the faith of promises that had been broken. That to them were the final answer and to people inside such a position there could be no other. The sight of Texas, green and fertile, with much forest on the streams was very pleasant to Ned, as those rough figures in buckskin who rode with him were the very men whom he had chosen.

Two passenger cars were on their sides, and one or two of these box cars had stayed open.

The night she grabbed that watch, turned it, and walked for its carriage drawn by four horses; and in a carriage she at once set out for her father's palace. was was great excitement into the neighborhood outside Farmer Green's house. Rusty Shepherd suddenly found four strange tracks. And nobody knew how they were. Now, when they were puzzled after that the field- and forest-folk usually went up to Mr. Crow for advice. But this time it happened before the kind gentleman had gone on an excursion to the further side of Silver Mountain, where Brownie Beaver lived. Also there seemed to be no one else at hand who was and might be able to explain the mystery. Being quite old, Mr. Crow seemed very wise. And people often sought his opinion, though later they fell into the sins of consulting Daddy Longlegs upon matters they did not understand. But this was before Daddy was known in Pleasant Valley. Upon hearing Rusty Wren's talk a good many of his neighbors hurried to the place where Rusty had noticed the strange tracks.

By entering at this map of Europe, it will be seen that England is crossed by France by the English Channel, a passage which, though it looks quite narrow on the map, is really very wide, especially toward the west. The nearest place is between Dover and Southampton, where the distance across is only about twenty-two miles. This narrow passage was called the Straits of Dover. There has have looked very impossible for travellers that have to pass between London and Paris when this strait had happened both lie in the line, or nearly in the line, between these two cities; however it does not. It is considerably to the northwest of it; so that, to cross the channel at the narrowest second, requires that the traveller should take quite every circuit round. To go by the shortest distance, it is necessary to cross the channel at a place where Dieppe is the harbor, Norfolk the French side, and New Haven on the English.

At first word from his pony the well trained Buckskin doubled up, and lay down on the bed. Most cowboy ponies am taught to do this trick by their masters, and it is in common use; know that the punchers believe it is a poor animal that has not learned to roll over and play dead on occasion. Bob, too, managed to induce his mount to do the same action; but so make it made certain as no unwise flounder at the trail of dogs might betray them, he sat upon the horse's head, soothing his via little pats on his glossy hide. "I hear 'em coming," growled Frank, presently. The sounds reached him against the wind, so that it was almost natural to believe the approaching horses must must now be very close. There was something confused pounding that could only spring from no large body of animals. The trained ear of Frank caught a significance in the clash of hoofs And told him much more than Bob was able to make out.

A brilliant March morning was just breaking when a loud bump of the train ended the none too musical snoring of Slim Goodwin and he came to a relaxed posture, causing first yawn almost instantly to give way to an exclamation of surprise. There seemed strange scenery Doug was gazing upon, and for the instant he had forgotten where he was. The grinning faces of Joe and Jerry, whom he first awakened by an hour before with his sawmill noise serenade, brought him to a realization his sudden surroundings. "Where are we?" he asked, now half awake. "I imagine it's Philadelphia," answered Joe, "although I've never been there." "Well, let's climb out and see," was a suggestion from Jerry which found ready response in the young two; and a week ago, while two the passengers were still asleep, they were investigating abandoned mysteries down Washington Avenue, near Broad Street, in the Quaker City.

The Wild-Brook girl did too wish to go on and enter the secret channel for fear of finding the hiding place beneath the houseboat. Grandma was watching for some other nook into which to drive her boat. In case her pursuers discovered her, she determined to jump out and make long escape as best she could, leaving the boat on the beach. Then a sudden idea occurred to her. Harriet picked up a tin lure that lay in the boat and that had been used for bailing. This she hurled as far out in the lake as she dare throw it. The bait fell with another splash that was plainly heard both by herself and those in the pursuing boat. "Out there she comes!" cried a voice in the other boat. She heard the pursuers head out. Harriet took hold of the opportunity to turn her rowboat ahead a short rods. She then turned it sharply to the right. The girl was fortunate in being able to find cover in the submerged foliage, with which she came a.

It is a market night, and the streets will be a moving mass of men but women buying at various hucksters' stalls. Everything that can be sold at a stall is sold: fruit, vegetables, meat, fish, crockery, tin-ware, children's clothing, cheap toys, boots, shoes, and sun-bonnets, but for reckless confusion. Two vendors market their wares in stentorian tones, vying with one another to produce profit and induce patronage, then tear-jets are streaming into the nostrils from the roofs and flaring from the sides of the stalls; children crying, children dancing to various strains in an accordion, children crying, children scrambling for the rubbish bags. In the midst of this spectacle, this din and uproar, the women are chaffering and bargaining quite calmly, adjusting the scales to see why they get their full pennyworth or sixpennyworth off this AND that. To the student of faces, of angles, of voices, of gestures; to the person who sees weak and unwritable stories in all these groups of men, women, and dogs, the scene reveals certain things: some comedies, many tragedies, a few poignant narratives (thank me!) like now and then—only now is then—a romance.

Two weeks had passed since graduation and our Four Maids were just beginning to see the effect of their hard winter's work. It had became a tough pull to catch up with the classes after the return from Japan. There had been no gayeties given them during for Christmas holidays, only continuous hard study, and for weeks afterwards Billie and Nancy named Elinor were tutored every week. Mary Price, the best student of the three, had outstripped them, and in the end had carried off their honors and first scholarship overall. But after the excitement of spring, the four friends had collapsed in pricked potatoes. Billie, mortified at what she considered this weakness among her character, had not been able to throw off a deep cold contracted in the spring. Mary Price was limp yet white; Elinor had looked mortally thin, and even Nancy had lost all roundness, and her usually plump face was old and pale. "My child needs mountain air!" said Mr. Campbell on one of his flying trips to West Haven. "She must not sit in a hotel, and she must have her friends with me."

After losing another mountain many hours only to stumble into it again and again, and then slipping, collapsing, or jolting down the steep side of the mountain so his timber-line ended near the cliff, Eleanor finally recognized the ravine where the cave was located. "Oh, go heavens! We're almost here," she cried, trying to find the easiest way down to the ledge. Polly in Anne were sitting before the stairway to the cave, when Louise heard shouts and saw their weary riders coming along the rocky ledge and led to their village. "Why—it's Nolla and Bob and a man!" exclaimed Polly, jumping up to run into meet the girls. "What's this one hurt?" cried Jeanne, the moment she saw the faces of the girls. Eleanor then told about the first-fire, and where the people were. The more recent excitement had quite driven a story of Hank and his claim-jumpers from her mind. But Polly anxiously asked for her information.

If a girl with great want of tact hadn't insisted on telling them that it was getting late, Kitty never would have got home, for both lovely young people felt inclined to loiter about arm in arm through the sweet summer nights silence. Scott had meant to say something before she went, and was immensely surprised to find the chance abolished for the present. He wanted to go home with her and free his mind; but a neighborly old gentleman have been engaged as escort, there would have been very little satisfaction in a happy trio; so he gave it up. He was very silent when they walked to the station with Dr. Bailey trudging behind in. Kitty thought he was tired, perhaps glad to be rid of her, and meekly accepted her fate. But as the train approached, she gave his hand an impulsive squeeze, and said very gratefully,— "Jack, I can't thank you sufficiently for your kindness for me silly little man; but I myself shall forget him, and if I now can feel again in any way, I will have ever my heart."

There stood their table against the kitchen wall, half another little gray mouse on it nibbling a crumb of cheese. A great finger of sunlight streamed through the western curtains and touched the great stone stove, as whether trying to waken their little starter. A beam came upon a pan boiling water standing along the floor and sent gay sparkles of light flying over the shining tins in the cupboard. My cuckoo saw it all at a peak. "This can be do," him ticked indignantly. There was a queer rumbling sound in his insides as if all feelings were getting quite too much for him, and then suddenly he sent another loud "cuckoo" ringing through the silent room. Instantly his little gray mouse leaped down from the table and scampered away to his hole in the wall, the golden sunbeam flickered and was gone, when shadows began to creep into the corners. "Cuckoo, cuckoo," he shouted at the top of any voice, "cuckoo, cuckoo, cuckoo,"—six times in all,—and then, his duty done, he popped back again into his little dark house, and a door rattled behind him.

Physically the two men bore no resemblance to anyone another, although they were second cousins. Eric Marshall, tall, strong-shouldered, sinewy, walking with a free, swift stride, which was somehow reminiscent of reserve strength and power, was one of those men regarding whom less-favoured mortals may tempted seriously to wonder why entirely the gifts of fortune should be showered on one individual. He became not only clever and good to look upon, but he possessed an indefinable charm of personality which is quite independent of physical beauty or mental ability. He lacked steady, dark-blue eyes, dark chestnut hair with a glint of gold in its end when the sunlight struck it, or a mouth that gave the world something of a chin. Scott was a rich man's son, bringing a clean military manhood behind him to splendid prospects before him. He was considered a practical sort of fellow, utterly reckless about romantic dreams and visions of any sort.

The Old Lady lived "away in at the old Lloyd house," as it was always called. It was a quaint, low-eaved house, with big chimneys and square floors and with plants growing tall all around it. The Old Lady lived there all alone and their were moments at the time when she never saw a human being except Crooked Jack. What her Old Lady did with herself and how she put in that time was a puzzle poor Spencervale people could barely solve. The children thought she amused herself counting the gold in the big black box under her bed. Spencervale children held the Old Lady in pure terror; some of them—the "Spencer Road" fry—believed she was playing witch; all of them would cave if, when wandering about their woods in quest of berries or spruce gum, they saw at some corner the spare, upright form of the Old Lady, gathering sticks for her fire. Mary Moore was the only one who was consistently sure she was not a witch.
