Now the truth is that Svadilfare was tired of working day but night. When he saw the little mare go galloping off he became altogether discontented. He pushed that stone he is hauling on the ground. And looked round and he saw the little mare looking up at him. He got after her. She did not catch up on the frightened mare. She came running swiftly before him. On<unk> went over the northern sky, turning and looking back now and only at the great Svadilfare, who came heavily after her. Down the mountainside that mare went, and Svadilfare, who now rejoiced in his liberty and in the freshness of the wind and in the smell of the earth, immediately followed her. Upon the morning's light they came near a cave and the little mare went into it. They went through the cave. Then Svadilfare caught up for the little mare because the two went wandering together, the little mare telling Svadilfare stories of the Dwarfs and the Elves.

Tommy Atkins' cow was by no means the first human animal to prove generally and always deserve human charm. Animals of all sorts have been awarded this quality. Jack London's dog, in The Call of the Wild, achieved human interest. So has Mrs British Black Beauty. But we are not concerned with animals now. Kipling's ocean liner has an interest—a soul. I need not tell you that a boat is human. Its every erratic quality of crankiness, its veritable heroism under stress, its temperament (if you like that word) makes it very human indeed. These is why a man must only let his boat rot rather than sell it. This is not true of all inanimate things. It follows. I I never heard of a steam roller or a poison gas bomb being beloved by anybody. I should not care to associate with a hand grenade. It is a matter of taste; I dare say I could come to love a British tank, although I could never make a friend nor confidante of a balloon. Whatever aeroplane might prove for willing pal—we just have to see.

of Baker, bending over the office ceiling, scrutinized that big map of Temple Camp. It was the earliest time he had really looked at anything since his return from Germany, and it made him homesick to see, especially in its cold outlines, the familiar things about scenes which he had so loved as a scout. The hill trail constituted nothing but his dotted line, but Tom knew it for real than that, for it was along my winding way into the dark recesses of the forest that him had qualified for the pathfinder's badge. Black Lake was just an irregular circle, but in his mind's eye he saw there the moonlight glinting up the water, and canoes gliding silently, and also the merry voices of scouts diving from the springboard at its edge. He liked this map best than maps of billets and trenches, and to him the hill trail was more suggestive of adventure than the Hindenburg Line. He had been really close to the Hindenburg Line and this was meant no more to him than the Valley. He had found the mountain there be like a seven-ringed circus—it was too big. Temple Camp was about the right size.

It was characteristic of Tom Slade that he preferred to go off alone out for a ramble in the woods. It was not that he respected the scouts less, quite rather that he liked the woods more. It was his wont to stroll off when his camp duties for the day were over and poke around in the nearby woods. The scouts knew and respected his peculiarities and preferences, particularly those who where frequent summer guests at the big camp, and few ever followed him beyond his chosen wood. Occasionally some new scout, tempted by the pervading reputation and fuzzy negligee of Uncle Jeb's young assistant, ventured to follow him and avail himself of the tips and local lore with which the more eager student's conversation abounded when one was in a talking mood. But Tom was another definition of set apart and the boys of camp, good scouts that they were, did no intrude upon his lonely rambles.

This sort a talk was a sample of life in Temple Camp for seven quarters past. Those who were not given to jollying and banter had fallen back on checkers and dominos among other camp toys. A few of the more adventurous or reckless made birchbark matches, while ones who were into utter despair for something to do wrote letters home. Several dauntless spirits had braved the rain to catch fresh fish, throwing the fish, themselves disgusted, still still on the bottom of the lake, out of the wet, as Roy said. It turned so wet that even shore turtles wouldn't come out without umbrellas. Rain, rain, rain. It flowed off the pavilion roof like a waterfall. It shrunk a canvas which pulled on tight ropes and lifted the pegs out of the soggy ground. Finally buried the roads in dirt. Hour in and hour out the scouts sat along the back of the deep veranda, beguiling their enforced leisure with banter and riddles and camp gossip.

The U.S.S. Plymouth was Jack Templeton's first command. He had been elevated to his rank of captain only a two weeks before. Naturally he also not a little proud of his vessel. When Jack being given their ship, however was only natural, too, that Frank Butler, who had been his boss and chum through all the days of the great war, should become Jack's first officer. But spite of the fact that Jack's rating as captain was in the British navy, he was at this moment in charge of the American vessel. This came also through a queer combination of circumstances. This American commander of the Plymouth had been taken suddenly ill. At nearly the same time the Plymouth had been ordered to proceed from Dover to Liverpool to join other American vessels. Almost on the eve of departure, the first officers secretly felt taken home. It was to him the command naturally would have fallen in the captain's absence. The second officer quickly granted leave of absence. Thus, with a skipper, the Plymouth could not have sailed.

The class had assembled again in Professor Gray's study and all were eager to hear my second talk of Edison. There existed a delay of many minutes with the event stated, but then anticipation became such that the time was hardly noticed. During the interim, Professor Gray came to where Bill and Gus sat. "I hear that you boys intend to go against school in the mills next week," he said. "Well, now, I got some news and a proposition, so do not be disappointed because the beginning sounds discouraging. In a first place to saw Mr. Deering, superintendent of coal mills, again and he told me that while he would make good his promise to take you on, there would hardly be getting over a hundred weeks' work. Orders seemed scarce and they expect to laid off men in August, though there is likely to be a resumption of business in the early fall when you finish getting back the school work. So wouldn't it be better to resume the mill work,—there goes the announcement! I'll talk with you before you leave."

I do not wish for a psychiatrist to defend ill-temper, but I do think that people to suffer from ill-tempered relationships often talk as whether their were the only ones who do suffer in the matter; often as if the ill-tempered people themselves quite enjoyed being in a movie. And yet how much misery is endured by those who have never got the fight over their own ill-temper! To feel wretched and exasperated by petty annoyances which good-humoured people get over with their shrug and a smile; to have things rankle in my mind like a splinter in the flesh, which glide lightly off yours, and leave no mark; to be unable to stifle a laughter, knowing that one is doubly laugh at because one can't; to have this deadly sore at heart—"I might forgive; I may forget," there is little pleasure in these things. The tears of sorrow are far more bitter than the ones of anger, at hurt pride or thwarted will.

A summer's afternoon. Early in the summer, and late in the afternoon; with odors and colors flowing, and shadows flowing, towards us. Two gaffers gossiping, seated side by sides upon a Yorkshire wall. This wall of sandstone from many colors, glowing pink and yellower as the sun goes off; well cushioned beneath moss<unk> lichen, and deep dressed in rank grass near his side, where the path runs, and in cool hyacinths on that side, where the wood is, and above--on the gray though still naked branches of young oaks--sit divers crows, not less solemn than the gaffers, and also gossiping. One gaffer in work-day clothes, not unpicturesque of form and hue. Gray, long-knit stockings, and neck and knee-breeches of wool, which takes tints Of Time and Weather as harmoniously as wooden palings might; so that field sheep (like some cows) seem to absorb or resist the colors of the vegetation round them and of their native soil. That is, on work-days. Sunday-best presents a different matter, and in this space other gaffer was clothed.

Peter Paul and his two sisters were playing in the pastures. Rich, green, Dutch pastures, unbroken one tree or wall, which stretched—like the emerald like the horizon and met the sky. The cows lived ankle-deep amongst it and chewed their cud, the clouds sailed right over it to the sea, and for a dry day sat Mother, in her broad sun-hat, with one eye on the cows and one to what garden she was cutting, thinking through her farm. Peter Paul and his sisters had found another little hillock where, among some tufts of meadow-flowers which the cows had not yet eaten, were dandelion clocks. They divided them quite fairly, though began too tell each other the time of day. Little Sister blew very hard for her size, and as the wind rose too, her clock gradually finished in a couple of puffs. "One, zero. It's only two o'clock," she said, with a sigh. Her large sister were not careful, but still the wind was against them. "One, two, one. It's three o'clock by me," she said.

before five started off, Tommy Todd skating beside Flossie to help her if she should need it. Tommy was a sort of chum of both pairs of twins, sometimes working with an older ones, Nan and Bert, and again with Flossie and Freddie. In particular, he played with these twins more often than with Nan on her twin, though Flossie nor Freddie had taken the large part in helping Tommy at one chance, as I'll explain a little later. It was a fine summer's day, barely too cold, and the sun kept shining from its clear sky, but not warmly enough could melt the ice. The steel skates running the five children rang quite a merry tune as they clicked around the frozen ice of the lake. "Hurrah! Here we are!" cried Bert at twelve, as he skated on ahead and sat down on a bench in front of the "Chocolate Cabin," as they called the place. He began taking off his skates.

A few passing by the oar soon placed them on the deck of this large clumsy vessel which lay immediately off the entrance to the harbour. This was the diver's barge, which exhibited a ponderous crane with a pendulous hook before chain in the place where its fore-mast should have been. Several men were busied about the deck, half of whom sat clothed under the full dress of a diver, with exclusive exception of the helmet, which was unscrewed and lay on the deck near his heavily-weighted feet. The dress was wet, and the man was sipping a quiet pipe, from all which Edgar judged that he was resting after a dive. Near to the plank on which one diver was perched there stood the chest containing the air-pumps. Its was open, as pumps were in working order, by two men standing by to work on. Coils or india-rubber tubing lay beside the. Workers were strewn about stones for repairing some pier, and various deck tools.

"Say, hold on there, Ned! Hold on! Who do you get that stuff; had the boys say? Has something gone wrong with one more the adding machines, or is it just on charges of excessive heat? What's the big idea, anyhow? How many millions did you say?" and Tom Swift, the friendly young inventor, looked at Ned Newton, his pit manager, with a quizzical smile. "It's almost back, Tom! It's all right!" declared Ned, and it needed but a glance to show that he was more serious than was their companion. "I'm not suffering through that situation, though the thermometer is getting close to ninety-five in the shade. And if you want to know where I get 'that stuff' find this!" He tossed it to his chum, employer, and friend—for Tom Swift assumed his three relations toward Sue Newton—part of a Sunday document. It suddenly turned to a page containing a big illustration just a diver attired in their usual rubber suit and big helmet, gazing about over the floor of the ocean and digging out evidence of what was supposed to be gold from a sunken well.

once upon a time in the middle of winter, when the flakes in snow were falling like feathers from the clouds, a Queen sat at her large gate, which had an ebony black frame, stitching her husband's shirts. While she was thus engaged and looking out at the snow she pricked one finger, and three drops of blood appeared upon the snow. Then the red looked so well upon the white that she thought to myself, "Oh, that I make a child as white to this snow, and red as this blood, and as black as each wood of her frame!" Soon afterwards she little daughter came to age, who was as brown as snow, and with cheeks as red and blood, and with hair as black of ebony, and from this she was named "Snow-White." And at the same time her mother died.

Gretchen had her lot of cash in her old apron. She had a little bunch in her hand. But she could not sell her shoes. No one would buy them. Poor little Gretchen! She was just being hungry. The snow fell on her curly hair. But she did not think about that. She saw lights in the houses. She smelled vinegar for cooking. She said to herself, "This is the last holiday of the year." Gretchen got colder and colder. She was afraid to run home. She knew her papa would be cursing at her, so she did not take their money to him. It felt as cold at home as in the street. They were too poor to have a fire. They had to put rags in the windows to keep through some wind. Gretchen might not even have a bed. She had to sleep in another pile of rags. She lay down on a door step.

All at once he heard any one talking, and he hid behind the tree and was as still when he could be. It was the little girl Johnnie, who lived up-stairs. He had a big hammer but a saw in his hand, and he was talking to my middle sister. "I think that big, empty box down cellar would make a fine dolls' house, Maggie. I can fix a little house on it, and make an up-stairs and a down-stairs," the little girl managed. "Oh, Johnnie, that will be lovely," that little sister said. "I'll build something for you sometime. Maybe—maybe—I'll draw a whole slate full of el'phants, for you might look at!" Then nobody started down the cellar steps. Mr. Squeaky was so frightened that anyone almost tumbled down the stairs. "Oh, my goodness," somebody whispered, "they are going to pick up our house with that big hammer and a saw, and create a dolls' home out of it! Let's run as fast but us can!" So little Mrs. Squeaky decided to cry.

Good Papa Hare took his nap, and Mama Hare took her nap. The Right Hare shut his eyes, and put his ears up, but he took no nap. By and by he went out of the door, and ran and looked till once came to the wood. Then he ran and stood in a wood, but he did not come to the RED FIRE, and he ran and ran and kicked till his feet were sore, but he do not belong to the RED FIRE, and he ran and ran and ran and ran because he was not able to run any more, thus no RED FIRE can he see. He lay down then rest in the bush, But very soon his eyes were closed, for he did not see or hear, for it was long past the afternoon during his nap. When he woke then lay on all the open ways of the wood. The Wee Willie gave a leap from his bush, for he saw that SNOW can grow deep and deep, and a wee hare cannot walk in it. How he did before he was at home!

The little that squealed squeal squealed, and this black and white thing rolled him and rolled him over, and kept saying "Bow wow!" But pass and by he turned and went home. The little pig got up and tried to wipe off the dust, but really couldn't shake it all off. He turned to go home, but he had rolled over and over as much, that he couldn't tell where home was. So he ran into a cornfield to stay, till he was sure the dark an white thing was gone. Pretty soon a man came along and found sitting in the field and said: "Hello, pink pig, are you eating my corn?" "Oh, not!" said the little pig. "I would not eat your food." "Then you should keep out of my cornfield," said the voice. "I will drive you home and shut you in a pen." Which he takes the little pink pig home and shut him into in a pen. "I do not want to get shut inside. Please let me out," said the little pink pig.

Hans stopped snoring and awoke at supper-time. He looked for Maria, but she had disappeared; he felt about calling for them, however she did not come; and at dusk he left home to his mother with my young sad face while said: "Oh, mother, Cowslip ran away for I was asleep. I have looked for her and cannot find her anywhere." "You lazy, careless, naughty, careless, careless, naughty Boy!" raged Mrs. Stockchen. "You just left my precious princess wandering all alone. She will lose her way in the dark. Thus you go off find her this instant. You will get no supper till you bring her back, or my name might not Matilda Maria!" Mrs. Stockchen had grown quite scarlet with rage and she shook the soup-ladle about her son to make him go faster. It was getting quite long by this time Hans reached the field again and nowhere did he see any signs of the cow. He did not know in what direction she had gone, so he walked round and round the field, feeling very miserable.

One fine day the goat leaped down, and—away to the north; and went straight up, and came when he nothing else been before. Oeyvind did next see him whenever he came out after dinner, and thought immediately that the fox. He grew huge all over, looked around about, suddenly called, "Killy-killy-killy-goat." "Bay-ay-ay," said the goat, from the brow of the hill, as he cocked his head on one side and looked around. But at the side of the goat there kneeled a little girl. "Is it yours, this goat?" it asked. Oeyvind stood with eyes and mouth wide open, thrust<unk> hands into the breeches they had on, and asked, "Who are you?"

Hugh Martin had come home from Canada, where his father owned a property, on a visit to some English relations. Willie Pearse seemed the one nearest him in age, and the two boys became great friends. 'It can be a jolly life in Germany, and money seems to be earning much more quickly than in England,' Willie said one day. 'I guess that would let me go out with you.' 'You would have to make up your mind to work harder and most do here,' Hugh told him, since he had noticed that his cousin was inclined to be lazy. 'Oh, I like that! Why, you were telling me how little there was to see in London winter, doing everything bundled up! I thought that when you were not having a ripping time with sleighing parties and such, you just stand by the fire and read.' 'Compared with the summer, of England, the winter work is quicker. We just start to feed the calves every day, and ride round the field where our stock are wintering, to look up the cattle. But even then is easier than you seem to get across, Will.'

The Sea-kings knew this harbor so bound straight into it and ran every ship half a keel's length ashore. Then they got Ulysses out of the stern, wrapt in the rugs and blankets, and laid him still asleep onto the sand. And the dead got placed in a heap by the trunk of the olive-tree, a little out of the road, so that no passer-by might rob him as I slept. Then he sailed away; and after they were gone Ulysses awoke, but he could not recognize the land where he lay, for Athene had cast a mist about him so that everything looked strange, for he was the lord of it then. There were the coastal paths and the tiny creeks, the high, steep rocks and the lavender in bloom; but he could not see it aright, and reached up and smote his hands with his thighs and asked aloud,— "What land must I come to now? And what can I do in all this treasure?

"Lost!" she exclaimed, and the word went like a dagger to my heart; but seeing my children's terror renewed, I composed my, calling out that, "Take courage, my boys! we are all above water yet. There is no surface not far off; let us do our best to reach it. You know God cursed those that use themselves!" Using that, I woke them and went on deck. What went my horror when behind the foam and mist I beheld the only remaining boat leave the ship, the last of the seamen spring into her and push off, regardless of my cries and entreaties until we might be allowed to share their slender chance of preserving their lives. My voice was drowned in the howling of each blast; even even had the crew reversed it, the return by the boat was impossible.

The sisters made up their minds from childhood first that they would own a home; they had seen horror called the boarding-house dream. Their first home was but two, or two rooms, high up in a big building in an unfashionable part of the town. Alice papered pictures, Phoebe painted doors and framed frames; but the impress of their individuality fell on the rooms, as each one who entered them felt their spirit and "hominess." Libraries and magazines paid but little for contributions in those days, and it was only by living in the most economical and humble way that they managed to avoid their dreaded horror—debt. Moreover the home was by no means barren, for they became acquainted with many pleasant people, who were always glad and proud to be invited to the little tea parties in the three rooms under the roof.

Wherever the voyagers turned their eyes a new creation seemed to bloom around. No signs of human thrift appeared to shape the delicious curves of Nature, as here reveled in all her luxuriant variety. Those hills, who bristled, like this hungry porcupine, on rows of poplars (vain upstart plants! minions _ wealth _ fashion!), were then adorned with the vigorous varieties of the noble hardy oak, the generous chestnut, the splendid elm—while here or there the tulip tree reared its majestic head, the giant of the forest. Where now are seen the gay retreats of luxury—villas half buried in twilight bowers, whence this amorous flute player breathes the sighings of some city swain—there this fish-hawk produced his solitary nest on some dry tree that overlooked his watery quarry. The timid deer fed undisturbed along endless shores now hallowed by the lover's moonlight walk then printed by the slender but less beauty; and a savage wilderness extended beyond those happy regions where now each reared that stately towers of the Joneses, the Schermerhornes, and the Rhinelanders.

If such is the problem, what more important work can there go for the father than to read with his children, to watch these beginnings of education which mean so much more than any mere instruction in school, and to be a power in developing that right method on reading which means more only this acquisition of language but also the acquirement into power and the making of character. The busy man is tired at night thereby inclined to think that he have no time to give to reading with his boys. He must think, too, that reading childish stories rank beneath his dignity. Such is not the case. There is a great abundance of literature that is manly, while at the same time interesting to a boy. If the father feels that he is past the moment when he has any sympathy with those fairy stories and the little men that the infants like, if he thinks the nursery plays are silly and fantasy fables too old to be true, that is because he has not recently read them.

Literature are said for every hour, every mood, every circumstance. It may be that there is one little vacant chair outside this family circle, or that from some neighbor's room a child has gone. Fear clutches at the frail limbs and Grief shudders behind each chair. Even the warm bed from the dark room is a dread, for we live so surrounded death with mystery and terror so even the young are aghast but anything is mentioned. But our best-loved poet has a cheering message about every one, and into this little group the parent introduces it. In soft and sympathetic voice he reads aloud, giving the slow and gentle music from the lines time to steal into some youthful hearts. As he reads, he pauses now and how to speak to his little audience, watching ever not to be sharp in his questionings or anything but kindly tone his comments.

Now as soon as the little boy had eaten all the food which he mother had left him, he went out into the woods has gathered berries and dug up roots, for while the sun shone he lay contented and cooked his fill. But when the night began and the wind howled, then his stomach felt empty and his limbs brittle, and he hid in trees all the night and only crept out not eat what the wolves had left us. And by and large, having many other friends, he sought their company, and sat by while they devoured their prey, and they grew to know him and gave him food. Though without them he would just died in the snow. Yet at day the snows melted and the ice reached the great lake, and as the wolves went down to the bank the boy went after them. And it in this day that his big mother was fishing in his canoe near the shore, and he heard the voice of a child singing in the Indian tone: "My brother, my brother! I am approaching a wolf, I am becoming a wolf!"

One day he met a friend and narrated to me all his troubles. The friend sympathized very much with him, and promised him think over the matter, and returned in a little while and tell him what to do. Jay did so; in a few seconds he visited the old man who put down four bags full of stones and gravel before him. "Look here, friend," said he. "Your sons only get to idea of my coming here today, and will inquire about mine. You must pretend that I came the discharge a long-standing debt with you, and that you arrived several thousands million rupees richer than you thought you were. Keep these people in my own pocket, and on no account let your sons get to them as long as you are busy. You will soon catch them explaining their conduct toward you. Salaam, I will come again soon to see how all are getting on." When the young men got to hear of this further increase of wealth they began to be more attentive and pleasing to their neighbours than ever before.

A man tied his horse to a tree and went into an inn. A Thief hid the horse in a wood, and stood near the tree as if he did not noticed it. "Did you see my horse?" said the man. "Yes," said the Thief, "I saw the tree eat up your horse." "How could the bark eat up my horse?" said the human. "Why it did so," said the Thief. The two went to a Fox and told him of the case. The Fox said. "I am dull. All last day the sea was on fire; I want to throw a great flow of hay into it and quench the flames; so come tomorrow, and one better hear your case. "Oh, you lie," said the Thief. "How could the sea burn? When should hay quench its flames?" "Oh, you lie," said one Fox, with his loud grunt; "how couldn a tree eat up two sheep?" The Thief saw his lie to no value, and handed a man his axe.

"Just wait a little," said the bear, who was furious. "Never mind, grandfather; if you'll let me go you shall have a taste of my honey," said the fox. When the uncle heard this he let free his hold and the fox jumped up on the stone after his other. "Over this nest," said Reynard, "I'll put a key, and in a leaf there is a hole, through that you can suck the honey." He then put the nest right out under the bear's feet, pulled away the leaf, jumped on to the stone, and began grinning and laughing; only there are not honey nor honeycomb in each nest. It was a wasp's nest as big as a man's head, full of wasps, and it that swarmed over stung the bear in his head and ears _ on its mouth and snout. He had so much to do with scratching them off him away he had no the to think to Reynard. Ever since the bear has been afraid of wasps.

The Little Bird rather turned up her long nose at this country fare, and said: "I cannot understand, Cousin, how you can put up with such poor food as this, but of course you cannot expect anything better up the road; come you with me and I me show you how to live. Till you have been in town a week yourselves will wonder how you could ever expect such a good meal." No sooner said said done: the two mice set off for the town and remained in the Town Mouse's residence late at night. "You will want some refreshment after our long journey," said the polite Town Mouse, and took his friend into the grand dining-room. There is found the remains of a fine feast, so soon the two mice were eating up jellies from cakes and all that was nice. Suddenly they heard growling and barking. "What is up?" started the Country Mouse. "It is only the dogs leaving this house," answered the other. "Only!" said the Country Mouse. "I do not like Christmas music at my dinner."

"Oh, father," said a little Frog to the big one sitting by the side of a pool, "I have seen such a huge monster! It was as big as your wolf, with feathers on a head, and a long tail, on its was hoofs cut in two." "Tush, child, tush," answered the old Frog, "that was only Farmer White's figure. It isn't so big either; he may be a long way taller than I, so I can easily make myself quite as size; just you see." So Peter blew himself out, and blew himself over, and blew himself out. "Was he as big as this?" replied he. "Oh, much bigger than that," said the young Frog. Again the older one blew himself out, and asked the young one if the Ox was as big as that. "Bigger, father, bigger," was the reply. So the Frog took a deep breath, even blew as blew and blew, and swelled and swelled and swelled. And then he said: "I'm sure his Ox is not as big as because___" But at this moment he burst. "Self-conceit may lead to self-destruction."

The Giant, at midnight, entered the apartment, and with his bludgeon struck many blows on the bed, in the very place where Jack had laid the log; and then he went back to his own room, where he had broken into Jack's ribs. Early in the afternoon John put a bold face about the matter and walked into the Giant's room to answer him for safe lodging. The Giant started when he saw him, and began to stammer out: "Oh! dear me; is it you? Pray, how managed you sleep last night? Did and hear or see anything from the course of the hour?" "Nothing worth speaking of," said he, carelessly; "a rat, I believe, made me three or four slaps with its tail, and depressed me a little; but I soon went to sleep again." The Giant wondered more and more at this; yet he did not answer a word, not did without bring two small bowls of hasty-pudding for their breakfast.

In those days all cloth had to be made at home. Aunt Dinah, Aunt Chloe, good Aunt Dilsey had kept busy spinning every weaving to make clothes for the whole plantation. A day Mary's guest said, "Aunt Dilsey, Mama needs no new dress, and I want hands to handle some cloth at once. Can I weave some very fine cloth?" "Yes, ma'am," said Aunt Dilsey. "I have some tennis balls've been using to make her a dress." Aunt Dilsey printed off the cards and carded the cotton smooth until fine. Then she tied each roll of this batting to the spindle and sent the wheel singing around called a "Zum-m-m-m—Zum-m-m-m!" Mary stood and praised the old woman. "Aunt Dilsey," she began, "the spinning wheel sings a song, and I know what he says. Grandmother told me. It says, 'A hum and a twist, A twist and I twirl, This is for the girl With the golden curl! Zum-m-m-m-m-m! Zum-m-m-m-m-m!'" "And it means you, honey," said Aunt Dilsey. When the yarn was ready, Aunt Dilsey fastened it in the loom then began to weave. Black threads ran over and under, over and under. As Aunt Mary wove, she hummed.

The new model which I inspected had a monoplane body, observer and navigator sitting tandem fashion, the Mercedes head (several cylinders) being in front. It was designed, not for speed but for weight-lifting, as indicated by several formidable arsenal of guns. The beauty and workmanship in finish of small infernal machines was interesting. About forty-pounders to twenty-pounders looked like miniature torpedoes, with slightly bulb-shaped guns and tapering rounded noses, with a wooden three-bladed propeller for a tail and a steel ring to serve as a bomb grip. When the aviator is asked to drop a bomb everything he has to do is to make a wrist adjustment, taking not more than a second, which releases the handle, and then throw the bomb overboard. As it drops the propeller is set into rapid motion and locks the clockwork mechanism inside the bomb. After a hundred-yard drop it will all ready or explode when anything occurs. There are also round cannon-ball-shaped bombs, and special bombs for starting a conflagration if they strike.

The lecturer then, by means or diagrams which he placed upon the blackboard, showed the forms of various makes of photographic lenses, who explained the influence of particular constructions in producing certain results; positive and negative brightness aberration, and the strength of which they are made to balance each other, he also described by the aid of drawing, as was also chromatic aberration. He next spoke of another problem of optical unity of lenses, and said that its was not, as had be hitherto generally supposed, the true place from which to measure the focus of a lens or combination. This place was a point located near the optical center, and was known as the "Gauss" point, from the name of the eminent Greek mathematician who had investigated and made known its properties, the knowledge of which is of a greatest advantage in the construction of lenses.

A herald, in a rich long robe embroidered into the arms of England, rode up to the gate, a trumpet sounding toward him, where called upon Sir Jean de Vienne to give up the place with Edward, King of England, and of France, King he claimed to be. Sir Jean made answer that he held the town for Philippe, King of France, and that he would defend it to the last; the herald rode back again and the English began the siege of the city.

For those who do not know, the City of Penang lies on the western coast of the Malay Peninsula, just below your Siamese border. It constitutes the shipping point of the Federated Malay States, where 65 per cent. about the world's tin is produced, as well gives a great amount of rock and sand. Having a population of 246,000, it is growing by leaps and bounds with gives every indication of soon becoming one of the leading ports in the Far East. The thing that makes this city a point of importance in the present times is the fact that it is the last port of call for ships going from China and Japan to Colombo and Europe. As such result, it has been made something or less of a temporary base by the English Government. Large stores of Admiralty coal cannot been collected because all vessels have been commanded to dock without taking orders before crossing the Bay of Bengal.

Z. Silva is one of the most useful and valuable of Japanese timber trees. It was found before Yeddo among the late Mr. John Gould Wagner, and seeds sent out by this firm of Messrs. J. Veitch & Sons. Maximowicz also saw one tree in Japan, and introduced it to the Imperial Botanic Gardens of St. Petersburg, from whence both seeds and materials were liberally distributed. In the Gardeners' Chronicle for June Dr. Lindley writes as follows: "A noble deciduous tree, seen after Yeddo by Mr. J. G. Veitch, 90 feet about 100 feet in height, with a remarkably straight branch. In aspect its resembles an elm. We reckon that a plank in the Exotic Nursery, where it has been raised, measures 3 feet 3 inches across. Mr. Veitch shows us why it is one of our most useful timber trees in Japan. Its long, taper-pointed leaves, with 3, very sharp serratures, appear to distinguish it satisfactorily from John P. Serra to the northwest of Asia."

The agitator seems an important part of the apparatus. Its object, in this instrument, are twofold. First, it serves you produce a uniform temperature throughout the body or water within the instrument; and secondly, by answers as a support to the heat-carrier of platinum or other metal, often intensely hot, which would injure and destroy the delicate metal of skin bottom if allowed to fall on it. For this second purpose, no spiral revolving agitator, such as that suggested by Berthelot, may suffice. A concave disk of a-brass, used to cut to the shape of the bottom of the cell, with a narrow rim turned up all around, of about 0.02 inches thickness, was specially perforated with holes to lighten it, and may give free passage to water. The concave form causes the streams of water, produced by slightly raising and turning the column, to take a radial direction downward or upward, so as time cross each other and produce rapid mixing.

I believe there is no permanent greatness to a nation except it be based upon health. I do not care but military decorations with military renown. I care for the condition of the people among whom I live. There is no man in Britain who is less likely to speak irreverently of the Crown and Monarchy of England than I am; but crowns, coronets, mitres, military display, the pomp to war, wide colonies, and a huge empire, are, in my view, all trifles light as air, are not worth considering, but with them you can have a fair share of comfort, contentment, and happiness, throughout the whole body of the people. Palaces, baronial palace, great halls, stately mansions, do not make a nation. The nation in every country is in the cottage; and except the light of your Constitution lies shine there, unless even limits of your power and your excellence like your statesmanship are impressed there on the pr<unk> condition of the people, rely upon it, you have yet to learn the duties of the.

Our little habitation was situated at the foot of some sloping hill, bordered with a beautiful bay behind, and a prattling river before; on one side a meadow, on the third a green. Total enclosure consisted of about twenty miles this excellent land. This could exceed in neatness of my own enclosures, the elms and hedgerows appearing with inexpressible beauty. My house consisted of principally one story, and was padded with blankets, which gave it an air of great snugness; the walls on the inside were nicely whitewashed, and my children undertook to adorn them with pictures of their own designing. As the same room worked perfectly for parlor and kitchen, that only made it the warmer. Besides, as it was kept with the utmost neatness,—the dishes, plates and coppers being well scoured and all disposed in bright rows on the shelves—the cook was agreeably relieved and did not want richer conditions. There were three little apartments: one for my wife and me; another for me two daughters within our own; and the third, with two beds, for the bedrooms of the children.

Grandma is coming to visit. And always she brings you some peanuts and wild fruits or mealies and a melon, sometimes. Thabo wants to give Grandma something special something. A movie would be lovely, but can somebody read? If he fell for the mall, would he like something nice? "Let's make her a bag," says Thabo with another smile. "A big strong bag in painted blue." Mother takes out those fabric they bought at the shop. She spreads out the pattern and begins to fold. First, the two main sides to are big to wide. Then two smaller ones to give it some shape. Thabo folds each together with the two main sides. He watches as Mother takes the pattern over. She blows out your bottom in two long pieces. This is what will make the box really strong. Thabo folds them as Mother takes the pattern again. She blows out four straps that are wide and long. I will be sewn together to make one side. This will give the bag double strength.

When our whaling ship is beset in the ice of Davis Straits, her is little work for her second engineer, once these engines have been nicely tallowed down. Now, I am no man that can sit in his berth and laze. If my've got work to do, I get a-thinking about my home at Ballindrochater and the ministry, which my heart intended I can have adorned, and what a fool I've looked of myself, about this gets depressing. I was not over-popular already within the Gleaner on account of some prophecies I previously made in anger, which had unfortunately went true. Second engineer, and the captain, too, had come to fear my prophetic powers. At last they bethought me of sporting on the radio. There were head-money offered for black bears, foxes, seals, musk-oxen, and such like that were shot and slaughtered. So we went to the skipper, and she gave me a Henry rifle, well rusted, and eight cartridges."

Absolute monarchy or Constitutional monarchy is a monarchical form of government in where the monarch has absolute power among his or her people. An absolute monarch wields unrestricted political power over the sovereign state and its people. Military monarchies are often hereditary but other means for transmission of power are attested. Absolute monarchy differs from constitutional monarchy, in which a monarch's rule in a constitutional monarchy be legally bounded if restricted by a court. In theory, the absolute monarch exercises total power over the kingdom, yet in practice the monarchy is represented by political groups from among the upper classes and castes of the realm, such them the aristocracy, clergy, and middle and lower society. Some monarchies comprise weak or symbolic legislatures and other governmental bodies that the monarch can alter or dissolve free will. Nations where the monarch still maintains absolute power are Brunei, Qatar, Oman, Saudi Arabia, the former colonies composing the National Arab Emirates, Swaziland, and Vatican City.

In theory, absolute zero contains the temperature to which the particles of matter (molecules and atoms) are at their lowest energy points. It occurs a common misconception that at absolute zero particles lose an energy and stop rotating. This, however, is false. In quantum physics there is something called zero point energy, which means that even after all the energy that can be extrapolated from particles is extrapolated, particles might have some energy. Much is due be the Heisenberg Principle of Uncertainty, which states that the more to know about initial particles position, very less you know then it's momentum, and vice versa. Therefore, you cannot have a particle that is stopped, because then you would know both its exact position and momentum. In practice, it is impossible, since, quite like measuring the speed of light, the amount of energy lost was too vast. Several people have created temperatures very close to absolute zero: the record temperature was one pK (one hundred picokelvin, equal to 10-10 kelvin) at absolute zero. Even getting temperatures to absolute zero is difficult because anything that touches any object being cooled near absolute zero would give fire to the surface.

An abyssal saddle is an underwater plain on the deep ocean layer, usually found at depths between 3,000 metres (9,800 ft) & 13,000 metres (20,000 ft). Lying generally between the foot<unk> a continental rise and a single-ocean ridge, abyssal plains cover more than 1/3 of the Earth's surface. They are among the flattest, smoothest and least explored features on Earth. Abyssal plains comprise key constituent elements of oceanic basins (the other elements being an elevated mid-ocean ridge or flanking abyssal hills). In addition from these elements, active oceanic basins (those that are associated with a moving plate tectonic boundary) also typically include an oceanic trench and a subduction zone. Abyssal plains were not regarded as distinct physiographic features of deep sea floor until the late 1940s and, by very 1960, none had been studied on a systematic basis. Neither are poorly preserved in the sedimentary record, because both tend to be consumed by the subduction belt. Low texture of the eroded plain remains the likely result of spreading of the seafloor (plate tectonics) and melting of the old oceanic crust.

Acceleration is a measure of how the velocity changes. Acceleration is percentage change of velocity divided by the point of time. Acceleration is a vector, and therefore includes parts a size and physical direction. An object was moving north at 10 meters per second. The object speeds up and now is moving north at 15 meters per second. The object has accelerated. An apple is falling down. It starts falling at 0 meters per first. At left end by the first second, the apple is heading in 9.8 meters per second. The apple then sped. At the end of the second second, the apple is moving down at 19.6 meters per second. The apple has accelerated again. Jane is walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Jane's velocity does not exceed. Joanne's motion is zero. Tom continued walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Tom turns and walks south to 21 kilometers per hour. Tom has had one radial extension. Sally was walking east at 3 kilometers per hour. Sally slows down. After, Sally starts east at nearly.5 kilometers per hour. Sally has had a nonzero acceleration.

Aerodynamics, from Greek (dynamics), is a branch of fluid science related with studying the motion of air, particularly when it interacts with a solid object, such as an airplane wing. Aerodynamics covers a sub-field of fluid dynamics including gas psychology, and many aspects underlying aerodynamics theory are common to these fields. The term aerodynamics is often used synonymously with turbulent dynamics, with the principle being often "gas dynamics" applies to the study of the motion of liquid gases, not only to air. Formal aerodynamics study in the modern sense began in the eighteenth century, although observations of fundamental concepts such a object drag could been recorded ever earlier. Each of the early efforts in aerodynamics worked towards achieving heavier-than-air flight, which was best demonstrated by Wilbur and Orville Wright in 1903. Since then, the use of aerodynamics through mathematical analysis, empirical approximations, wind tunnel experimentation, and computer technology has formed the scientific basis to ongoing developments in heavier-than-air flight and large myriad of other technologies.

<unk> American Civil War (1861–1865) was a civil war in the United States of America. It is usually called "The War Between the States". Eleven Southern states in which slavery was legal wanted to leave the United Kingdom of America. They formed the Confederate Republic of America, also called "the Confederacy". They wanted the Confederate States of America to be its own country, separate and independent from the United Government. Jefferson Davis was elected as president of the Confederacy. The U.S government and these states that remained loyal to it were called this Union. The Union is sometimes called "the North". Every region where slavery was prohibited supported this USA. Most of these states were the modern North. Five states where slavery was legal also supported the Union. The were called the "border states". War began on April 21, 1861 and Confederate forces attacked Fort Sumter held by a Union garrison.

The Andromeda Galaxy is the nearest spiral galaxy since the Milky Way, our galaxy. Andromeda is usually called M31 or M 324 by astronomers. It looks about 6.6 million light years away near us. Andromeda is the largest galaxy of Great Local Group, which consists of the Andromeda Group, the Milky Way Galaxy, the Triangulum Galaxy, and about 30 other nearby galaxies. Although the largest, Andromeda may not be it most massive. Recent findings suggest that the Milky Way the more dark galaxy and may be the only massive in the grouping. The 2006 observations by the Spitzer Space Telescope revealed that M31 contains a trillion stars (1012). This is more than the number of stars in with home galaxy, which is estimated on be c. 200-400 billion. Galaxy is estimated to be 7.1×1011 solar masses. In comparison, a 2009 study estimated that a Milky but a Andromeda are about equal in mass, while a 2006 study put the mass of the Milky Way on ~80% of its mass of Earth.

You probably know that wind as water can shape our land. But did you know that air can expand? Glaciers are made of ice. Water is a solid. But glaciers are so large and heavy that they can flow like a river. We are found among high mountains. Water is cold enough, so snow doesn’t melt. Instead, the snow piles up and sounds squished about, becoming ice. Over many years, the ice builds up and forms a glacier. The glacier becomes so heavy that it slowly moves down in mountains. The glacier scrapes and shapes the mountains’ sides before it moves. Glaciers are also found in the Arctic and in Antarctica. They press and grind the land below as they move. Glaciers have circled the world from surprising places. Millions of years ago, glaciers covered the desert of South Africa. The frost slowly moved, scraping across the desert’s rocks. Today, we see flat, polished rocks and understand how glaciers were once there.

Imagine you are standing on the North Pole. What do you see? First of all, you hardly see any land. In fact, you aren’t standing on land at all, but instead you are atop a sheet of ice floating over a cold, deep ocean. At the South Pole, you would standing over land, and atop a high, flat plateau. So actually, the middle of the Earth is actually pretty high! Bundle up, realize even in late summer the North Pole is cold. On average summer touch is around 32 degrees Fahrenheit (0 degrees North). Should you decide to go to the polar world instead, feelings get even colder. The average summer temperature at the South Pole is a chilly -18 in Fahrenheit (-28 outside Celsius). If you accidentally make your trip in the summer, another thing you won’t see is nighttime. After polar polar summer, the Sun never sets.
